341     ETYMOLOGY.
342   
343   
344     (Supplied by a Late Consumptive Usher to a Grammar School.)
345   
346     The pale Usher—threadbare in coat, heart, body, and brain; I see him
347     now. He was ever dusting his old lexicons and grammars, with a queer
348     handkerchief, mockingly embellished with all the gay flags of all the
349     known nations of the world. He loved to dust his old grammars; it
350     somehow mildly reminded him of his mortality.
351   
352     “While you take in hand to school others, and to teach them by what
353     name a whale-fish is to be called in our tongue, leaving out, through
354     ignorance, the letter H, which almost alone maketh up the
355     signification of the word, you deliver that which is not true.”
356     —_Hackluyt._
357   
358     “WHALE. * * * Sw. and Dan. _hval_. This animal is named from
359     roundness or rolling; for in Dan. _hvalt_ is arched or vaulted.”
360     —_Webster’s Dictionary._
361   
362     “WHALE. * * * It is more immediately from the Dut. and Ger. _Wallen_;
363     A.S. _Walw-ian_, to roll, to wallow.” —_Richardson’s Dictionary._
364   
365   
366     חו,                 _Hebrew_.
367     ϰητος,              _Greek_.
368     CETUS,              _Latin_.
369     WHŒL,               _Anglo-Saxon_.
370     HVALT,              _Danish_.
371     WAL,                _Dutch_.
372     HWAL,               _Swedish_.
373     WHALE,              _Icelandic_.
374     WHALE,              _English_.
375     BALLENA,            _Spanish_.
376     PEKEE-NUEE-NUEE,    _Fegee_.
377     PEHEE-NUEE-NUEE,    _Erromangoan_.
378   
379   
380   
381     EXTRACTS. (Supplied by a Sub-Sub-Librarian).
382   
383   
384   
385     It will be seen that this mere painstaking burrower and grub-worm of
386     a poor devil of a Sub-Sub appears to have gone through the long
387     Vaticans and street-stalls of the earth, picking up whatever random
388     allusions to whales he could anyways find in any book whatsoever,
389     sacred or profane. Therefore you must not, in every case at least,
390     take the higgledy-piggledy whale statements, however authentic, in
391     these extracts, for veritable gospel cetology. Far from it. As
392     touching the ancient authors generally, as well as the poets here
393     appearing, these extracts are solely valuable or entertaining, as
394     affording a glancing bird’s eye view of what has been promiscuously
395     said, thought, fancied, and sung of Leviathan, by many nations and
396     generations, including our own.
397   
398     So fare thee well, poor devil of a Sub-Sub, whose commentator I am.
399     Thou belongest to that hopeless, sallow tribe which no wine of this
400     world will ever warm; and for whom even Pale Sherry would be too
401     rosy-strong; but with whom one sometimes loves to sit, and feel
402     poor-devilish, too; and grow convivial upon tears; and say to them
403     bluntly, with full eyes and empty glasses, and in not altogether
404     unpleasant sadness—Give it up, Sub-Subs! For by how much the more
405     pains ye take to please the world, by so much the more shall ye for
406     ever go thankless! Would that I could clear out Hampton Court and the
407     Tuileries for ye! But gulp down your tears and hie aloft to the
408     royal-mast with your hearts; for your friends who have gone before
409     are clearing out the seven-storied heavens, and making refugees of
410     long-pampered Gabriel, Michael, and Raphael, against your coming.
411     Here ye strike but splintered hearts together—there, ye shall strike
412     unsplinterable glasses!
413   
414   EXTRACTS.
415   
416     “And God created great whales.” —_Genesis_.
417   
418     “Leviathan maketh a path to shine after him; One would think the deep
419     to be hoary.” —_Job_.
420   
421     “Now the Lord had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah.”
422     —_Jonah_.
423   
424     “There go the ships; there is that Leviathan whom thou hast made to
425     play therein.” —_Psalms_.
426   
427     “In that day, the Lord with his sore, and great, and strong sword,
428     shall punish Leviathan the piercing serpent, even Leviathan that
429     crooked serpent; and he shall slay the dragon that is in the sea.”
430     —_Isaiah_.
431   
432     “And what thing soever besides cometh within the chaos of this
433     monster’s mouth, be it beast, boat, or stone, down it goes all
434     incontinently that foul great swallow of his, and perisheth in the
435     bottomless gulf of his paunch.” —_Holland’s Plutarch’s Morals_.
436   
437     “The Indian Sea breedeth the most and the biggest fishes that are:
438     among which the Whales and Whirlpooles called Balaene, take up as
439     much in length as four acres or arpens of land.” —_Holland’s Pliny_.
440   
441     “Scarcely had we proceeded two days on the sea, when about sunrise a
442     great many Whales and other monsters of the sea, appeared. Among the
443     former, one was of a most monstrous size.... This came towards us,
444     open-mouthed, raising the waves on all sides, and beating the sea
445     before him into a foam.” —_Tooke’s Lucian_. “_The True History_.”
446   
447   
448   
449   
450     “He visited this country also with a view of catching horse-whales,
451     which had bones of very great value for their teeth, of which he
452     brought some to the king.... The best whales were catched in his own
453     country, of which some were forty-eight, some fifty yards long. He
454     said that he was one of six who had killed sixty in two days.”
455     —_Other or Other’s verbal narrative taken down from his mouth by King
456     Alfred, A.D._ 890.
457   
458     “And whereas all the other things, whether beast or vessel, that
459     enter into the dreadful gulf of this monster’s (whale’s) mouth, are
460     immediately lost and swallowed up, the sea-gudgeon retires into it in
461     great security, and there sleeps.” —MONTAIGNE. —_Apology for Raimond
462     Sebond_.
463   
464     “Let us fly, let us fly! Old Nick take me if is not Leviathan
465     described by the noble prophet Moses in the life of patient Job.”
466     —_Rabelais_.
467   
468     “This whale’s liver was two cartloads.” —_Stowe’s Annals_.
469   
470     “The great Leviathan that maketh the seas to seethe like boiling
471     pan.” —_Lord Bacon’s Version of the Psalms_.
472   
473     “Touching that monstrous bulk of the whale or ork we have received
474     nothing certain. They grow exceeding fat, insomuch that an incredible
475     quantity of oil will be extracted out of one whale.” —_Ibid_.
476     “_History of Life and Death_.”
477   
478   
479   
480   
481     “The sovereignest thing on earth is parmacetti for an inward bruise.”
482     —_King Henry_.
483   
484     “Very like a whale.” —_Hamlet_.
485   
486   
487     “Which to secure, no skill of leach’s art Mote him availle, but to
488     returne againe To his wound’s worker, that with lowly dart, Dinting
489     his breast, had bred his restless paine, Like as the wounded whale to
490     shore flies thro’ the maine.” —_The Faerie Queen_.
491   
492   
493   
494     “Immense as whales, the motion of whose vast bodies can in a peaceful
495     calm trouble the ocean till it boil.” —_Sir William Davenant. Preface
496     to Gondibert_.
497   
498     “What spermacetti is, men might justly doubt, since the learned
499     Hosmannus in his work of thirty years, saith plainly, _Nescio quid
500     sit_.” —_Sir T. Browne. Of Sperma Ceti and the Sperma Ceti Whale.
501     Vide his V. E._
502   
503   
504     “Like Spencer’s Talus with his modern flail He threatens ruin with
505     his ponderous tail. ... Their fixed jav’lins in his side he wears,
506     And on his back a grove of pikes appears.” —_Waller’s Battle of the
507     Summer Islands_.
508   
509   
510   
511     “By art is created that great Leviathan, called a Commonwealth or
512     State—(in Latin, Civitas) which is but an artificial man.” —_Opening
513     sentence of Hobbes’s Leviathan_.
514   
515     “Silly Mansoul swallowed it without chewing, as if it had been a
516     sprat in the mouth of a whale.” —_Pilgrim’s Progress_.
517   
518   
519     “That sea beast Leviathan, which God of all his works Created hugest
520     that swim the ocean stream.” —_Paradise Lost_.
521   
522     —“There Leviathan, Hugest of living creatures, in the deep Stretched
523     like a promontory sleeps or swims, And seems a moving land; and at
524     his gills Draws in, and at his breath spouts out a sea.” —_Ibid_.
525   
526   
527   
528     “The mighty whales which swim in a sea of water, and have a sea of
529     oil swimming in them.” —_Fuller’s Profane and Holy State_.
530   
531   
532     “So close behind some promontory lie The huge Leviathan to attend
533     their prey, And give no chance, but swallow in the fry, Which through
534     their gaping jaws mistake the way.” —_Dryden’s Annus Mirabilis_.
535   
536   
537   
538     “While the whale is floating at the stern of the ship, they cut off
539     his head, and tow it with a boat as near the shore as it will come;
540     but it will be aground in twelve or thirteen feet water.” —_Thomas
541     Edge’s Ten Voyages to Spitzbergen, in Purchas_.
542   
543     “In their way they saw many whales sporting in the ocean, and in
544     wantonness fuzzing up the water through their pipes and vents, which
545     nature has placed on their shoulders.” —_Sir T. Herbert’s Voyages
546     into Asia and Africa. Harris Coll_.
547   
548     “Here they saw such huge troops of whales, that they were forced to
549     proceed with a great deal of caution for fear they should run their
550     ship upon them.” —_Schouten’s Sixth Circumnavigation_.
551   
552     “We set sail from the Elbe, wind N.E. in the ship called The
553     Jonas-in-the-Whale.... Some say the whale can’t open his mouth, but
554     that is a fable.... They frequently climb up the masts to see whether
555     they can see a whale, for the first discoverer has a ducat for his
556     pains.... I was told of a whale taken near Shetland, that had above a
557     barrel of herrings in his belly.... One of our harpooneers told me
558     that he caught once a whale in Spitzbergen that was white all over.”
559     —_A Voyage to Greenland, A.D._ 1671. _Harris Coll_.
560   
561     “Several whales have come in upon this coast (Fife) Anno 1652, one
562     eighty feet in length of the whale-bone kind came in, which (as I was
563     informed), besides a vast quantity of oil, did afford 500 weight of
564     baleen. The jaws of it stand for a gate in the garden of Pitferren.”
565     —_Sibbald’s Fife and Kinross_.
566   
567     “Myself have agreed to try whether I can master and kill this
568     Sperma-ceti whale, for I could never hear of any of that sort that
569     was killed by any man, such is his fierceness and swiftness.”
570     —_Richard Strafford’s Letter from the Bermudas. Phil. Trans. A.D._
571     1668.
572   
573     “Whales in the sea God’s voice obey.” —_N. E. Primer_.
574   
575     “We saw also abundance of large whales, there being more in those
576     southern seas, as I may say, by a hundred to one; than we have to the
577     northward of us.” —_Captain Cowley’s Voyage round the Globe, A.D._
578     1729.
579   
580     “... and the breath of the whale is frequently attended with such an
581     insupportable smell, as to bring on a disorder of the brain.”
582     —_Ulloa’s South America_.
583   
584   
585     “To fifty chosen sylphs of special note, We trust the important
586     charge, the petticoat. Oft have we known that seven-fold fence to
587     fail, Tho’ stuffed with hoops and armed with ribs of whale.” —_Rape
588     of the Lock_.
589   
590   
591   
592     “If we compare land animals in respect to magnitude, with those that
593     take up their abode in the deep, we shall find they will appear
594     contemptible in the comparison. The whale is doubtless the largest
595     animal in creation.” —_Goldsmith, Nat. Hist_.
596   
597     “If you should write a fable for little fishes, you would make them
598     speak like great whales.” —_Goldsmith to Johnson_.
599   
600     “In the afternoon we saw what was supposed to be a rock, but it was
601     found to be a dead whale, which some Asiatics had killed, and were
602     then towing ashore. They seemed to endeavor to conceal themselves
603     behind the whale, in order to avoid being seen by us.” —_Cook’s
604     Voyages_.
605   
606     “The larger whales, they seldom venture to attack. They stand in so
607     great dread of some of them, that when out at sea they are afraid to
608     mention even their names, and carry dung, lime-stone, juniper-wood,
609     and some other articles of the same nature in their boats, in order
610     to terrify and prevent their too near approach.” —_Uno Von Troil’s
611     Letters on Banks’s and Solander’s Voyage to Iceland in_ 1772.
612   
613     “The Spermacetti Whale found by the Nantuckois, is an active, fierce
614     animal, and requires vast address and boldness in the fishermen.”
615     —_Thomas Jefferson’s Whale Memorial to the French minister in_ 1778.
616   
617     “And pray, sir, what in the world is equal to it?” —_Edmund Burke’s
618     reference in Parliament to the Nantucket Whale-Fishery_.
619   
620     “Spain—a great whale stranded on the shores of Europe.” —_Edmund
621     Burke_. (_somewhere_.)
622   
623     “A tenth branch of the king’s ordinary revenue, said to be grounded
624     on the consideration of his guarding and protecting the seas from
625     pirates and robbers, is the right to _royal_ fish, which are whale
626     and sturgeon. And these, when either thrown ashore or caught near the
627     coast, are the property of the king.” —_Blackstone_.
628   
629   
630     “Soon to the sport of death the crews repair: Rodmond unerring o’er
631     his head suspends The barbed steel, and every turn attends.”
632     —_Falconer’s Shipwreck_.
633   
634     “Bright shone the roofs, the domes, the spires, And rockets blew self
635     driven, To hang their momentary fire Around the vault of heaven.
636   
637     “So fire with water to compare, The ocean serves on high, Up-spouted
638     by a whale in air, To express unwieldy joy.” —_Cowper, on the Queen’s
639     Visit to London_.
640   
641   
642   
643     “Ten or fifteen gallons of blood are thrown out of the heart at a
644     stroke, with immense velocity.” —_John Hunter’s account of the
645     dissection of a whale_. (_A small sized one_.)
646   
647     “The aorta of a whale is larger in the bore than the main pipe of the
648     water-works at London Bridge, and the water roaring in its passage
649     through that pipe is inferior in impetus and velocity to the blood
650     gushing from the whale’s heart.” —_Paley’s Theology_.
651   
652     “The whale is a mammiferous animal without hind feet.” —_Baron
653     Cuvier_.
654   
655     “In 40 degrees south, we saw Spermacetti Whales, but did not take any
656     till the first of May, the sea being then covered with them.”
657     —_Colnett’s Voyage for the Purpose of Extending the Spermaceti Whale
658     Fishery_.
659   
660   
661     “In the free element beneath me swam, Floundered and dived, in play,
662     in chace, in battle, Fishes of every colour, form, and kind; Which
663     language cannot paint, and mariner Had never seen; from dread
664     Leviathan To insect millions peopling every wave: Gather’d in shoals
665     immense, like floating islands, Led by mysterious instincts through
666     that waste And trackless region, though on every side Assaulted by
667     voracious enemies, Whales, sharks, and monsters, arm’d in front or
668     jaw, With swords, saws, spiral horns, or hooked fangs.”
669     —_Montgomery’s World before the Flood_.
670   
671     “Io!  Paean!  Io! sing. To the finny people’s king. Not a mightier
672     whale than this In the vast Atlantic is; Not a fatter fish than he,
673     Flounders round the Polar Sea.” —_Charles Lamb’s Triumph of the
674     Whale_.
675   
676   
677   
678     “In the year 1690 some persons were on a high hill observing the
679     whales spouting and sporting with each other, when one observed:
680     there—pointing to the sea—is a green pasture where our children’s
681     grand-children will go for bread.” —_Obed Macy’s History of
682     Nantucket_.
683   
684     “I built a cottage for Susan and myself and made a gateway in the
685     form of a Gothic Arch, by setting up a whale’s jaw bones.”
686     —_Hawthorne’s Twice Told Tales_.
687   
688     “She came to bespeak a monument for her first love, who had been
689     killed by a whale in the Pacific ocean, no less than forty years
690     ago.” —_Ibid_.
691   
692     “No, Sir, ’tis a Right Whale,” answered Tom; “I saw his sprout; he
693     threw up a pair of as pretty rainbows as a Christian would wish to
694     look at. He’s a raal oil-butt, that fellow!” —_Cooper’s Pilot_.

746     October 13.  “There she blows,” was sung out from the mast-head.

748     sir.” “Raise up your wheel.  Steady!”  “Steady, sir.” “Mast-head
749     ahoy! Do you see that whale now?” “Ay ay, sir!  A shoal of Sperm
750     Whales! There she blows!  There she breaches!” “Sing out! sing out
751     every time!” “Ay Ay, sir!  There she blows! there—there—_thar_ she
752     blows—bowes—bo-o-os!” “How far off?” “Two miles and a half.” “Thunder

846   
847   
848   
849   CHAPTER 1. Loomings.
850   
851   Call me Ishmael. Some years ago—never mind how long precisely—having
852   little or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to interest me
853   on shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part
854   of the world. It is a way I have of driving off the spleen and
855   regulating the circulation. Whenever I find myself growing grim about
856   the mouth; whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul; whenever
857   I find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and
858   bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever
859   my hypos get such an upper hand of me, that it requires a strong moral
860   principle to prevent me from deliberately stepping into the street, and
861   methodically knocking people’s hats off—then, I account it high time to
862   get to sea as soon as I can. This is my substitute for pistol and ball.
863   With a philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I
864   quietly take to the ship. There is nothing surprising in this. If they
865   but knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other,
866   cherish very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.
867   
868   There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by
869   wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs—commerce surrounds it with her
870   surf. Right and left, the streets take you waterward. Its extreme
871   downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and
872   cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of sight of
873   land. Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.
874   
875   Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon. Go from Corlears
876   Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall, northward. What
877   do you see?—Posted like silent sentinels all around the town, stand
878   thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean reveries. Some
879   leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the pier-heads; some
880   looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some high aloft in the
881   rigging, as if striving to get a still better seaward peep. But these
882   are all landsmen; of week days pent up in lath and plaster—tied to
883   counters, nailed to benches, clinched to desks. How then is this? Are
884   the green fields gone? What do they here?
885   
886   But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and
887   seemingly bound for a dive. Strange! Nothing will content them but the
888   extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of yonder
889   warehouses will not suffice. No. They must get just as nigh the water
890   as they possibly can without falling in. And there they stand—miles of
891   them—leagues. Inlanders all, they come from lanes and alleys, streets
892   and avenues—north, east, south, and west. Yet here they all unite. Tell
893   me, does the magnetic virtue of the needles of the compasses of all
894   those ships attract them thither?
895   
896   Once more. Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes. Take
897   almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down in a
898   dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream. There is magic in
899   it. Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his deepest
900   reveries—stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going, and he will
901   infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all that region.
902   Should you ever be athirst in the great American desert, try this
903   experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied with a metaphysical
904   professor. Yes, as every one knows, meditation and water are wedded for
905   ever.
906   
907   But here is an artist. He desires to paint you the dreamiest, shadiest,
908   quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all the valley
909   of the Saco. What is the chief element he employs? There stand his
910   trees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a crucifix were
911   within; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his cattle; and up
912   from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke. Deep into distant woodlands
913   winds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of mountains bathed in
914   their hill-side blue. But though the picture lies thus tranced, and
915   though this pine-tree shakes down its sighs like leaves upon this
916   shepherd’s head, yet all were vain, unless the shepherd’s eye were
917   fixed upon the magic stream before him. Go visit the Prairies in June,
918   when for scores on scores of miles you wade knee-deep among
919   Tiger-lilies—what is the one charm wanting?—Water—there is not a drop
920   of water there! Were Niagara but a cataract of sand, would you travel
921   your thousand miles to see it? Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon
922   suddenly receiving two handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy
923   him a coat, which he sadly needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian
924   trip to Rockaway Beach? Why is almost every robust healthy boy with a
925   robust healthy soul in him, at some time or other crazy to go to sea?
926   Why upon your first voyage as a passenger, did you yourself feel such a
927   mystical vibration, when first told that you and your ship were now out
928   of sight of land? Why did the old Persians hold the sea holy? Why did
929   the Greeks give it a separate deity, and own brother of Jove? Surely
930   all this is not without meaning. And still deeper the meaning of that
931   story of Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the tormenting, mild
932   image he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and was drowned. But that
933   same image, we ourselves see in all rivers and oceans. It is the image
934   of the ungraspable phantom of life; and this is the key to it all.
935   
936   Now, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I begin
937   to grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of my
938   lungs, I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as a
939   passenger. For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse, and a
940   purse is but a rag unless you have something in it. Besides, passengers
941   get sea-sick—grow quarrelsome—don’t sleep of nights—do not enjoy
942   themselves much, as a general thing;—no, I never go as a passenger;
943   nor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea as a
944   Commodore, or a Captain, or a Cook. I abandon the glory and distinction
945   of such offices to those who like them. For my part, I abominate all
946   honorable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations of every kind
947   whatsoever. It is quite as much as I can do to take care of myself,
948   without taking care of ships, barques, brigs, schooners, and what not.
949   And as for going as cook,—though I confess there is considerable glory
950   in that, a cook being a sort of officer on ship-board—yet, somehow, I
951   never fancied broiling fowls;—though once broiled, judiciously
952   buttered, and judgmatically salted and peppered, there is no one who
953   will speak more respectfully, not to say reverentially, of a broiled
954   fowl than I will. It is out of the idolatrous dotings of the old
955   Egyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted river horse, that you see the
956   mummies of those creatures in their huge bake-houses the pyramids.
957   
958   No, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,
959   plumb down into the forecastle, aloft there to the royal mast-head.
960   True, they rather order me about some, and make me jump from spar to
961   spar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow. And at first, this sort of
962   thing is unpleasant enough. It touches one’s sense of honor,
963   particularly if you come of an old established family in the land, the
964   Van Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes. And more than all, if
965   just previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you have been
966   lording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest boys stand in
967   awe of you. The transition is a keen one, I assure you, from a
968   schoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of Seneca and
969   the Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it. But even this wears off
970   in time.
971   
972   What of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a broom
973   and sweep down the decks? What does that indignity amount to, weighed,
974   I mean, in the scales of the New Testament? Do you think the archangel
975   Gabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I promptly and
976   respectfully obey that old hunks in that particular instance? Who ain’t
977   a slave? Tell me that. Well, then, however the old sea-captains may
978   order me about—however they may thump and punch me about, I have the
979   satisfaction of knowing that it is all right; that everybody else is
980   one way or other served in much the same way—either in a physical or
981   metaphysical point of view, that is; and so the universal thump is
982   passed round, and all hands should rub each other’s shoulder-blades,
983   and be content.
984   
985   Again, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of
986   paying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single
987   penny that I ever heard of. On the contrary, passengers themselves must
988   pay. And there is all the difference in the world between paying and
989   being paid. The act of paying is perhaps the most uncomfortable
990   infliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon us. But _being
991   paid_,—what will compare with it? The urbane activity with which a man
992   receives money is really marvellous, considering that we so earnestly
993   believe money to be the root of all earthly ills, and that on no
994   account can a monied man enter heaven. Ah! how cheerfully we consign
995   ourselves to perdition!
996   
997   Finally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome
998   exercise and pure air of the fore-castle deck. For as in this world,
999   head winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is, if
1000  you never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the
1001  Commodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from
1002  the sailors on the forecastle. He thinks he breathes it first; but not
1003  so. In much the same way do the commonalty lead their leaders in many
1004  other things, at the same time that the leaders little suspect it. But
1005  wherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea as a
1006  merchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a whaling
1007  voyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who has the
1008  constant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and influences me in
1009  some unaccountable way—he can better answer than any one else. And,
1010  doubtless, my going on this whaling voyage, formed part of the grand
1011  programme of Providence that was drawn up a long time ago. It came in
1012  as a sort of brief interlude and solo between more extensive
1013  performances. I take it that this part of the bill must have run
1014  something like this:
1015  
1016  “_Grand Contested Election for the Presidency of the United States._
1017  “WHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL. “BLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN.”
1018  
1019  Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers, the
1020  Fates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when
1021  others were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and short
1022  and easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in farces—though I
1023  cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I recall all the
1024  circumstances, I think I can see a little into the springs and motives
1025  which being cunningly presented to me under various disguises, induced
1026  me to set about performing the part I did, besides cajoling me into the
1027  delusion that it was a choice resulting from my own unbiased freewill
1028  and discriminating judgment.
1029  
1030  Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great whale
1031  himself. Such a portentous and mysterious monster roused all my
1032  curiosity. Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his island
1033  bulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these, with all
1034  the attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and sounds,
1035  helped to sway me to my wish. With other men, perhaps, such things
1036  would not have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented with an
1037  everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and
1038  land on barbarous coasts. Not ignoring what is good, I am quick to
1039  perceive a horror, and could still be social with it—would they let
1040  me—since it is but well to be on friendly terms with all the inmates of
1041  the place one lodges in.
1042  
1043  By reason of these things, then, the whaling voyage was welcome; the
1044  great flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open, and in the wild
1045  conceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into
1046  my inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and, mid most of them
1047  all, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air.
1048  
1049  
1050  CHAPTER 2. The Carpet-Bag.
1051  
1052  I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my
1053  arm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific. Quitting the good city
1054  of old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford. It was a Saturday night
1055  in December. Much was I disappointed upon learning that the little
1056  packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no way of reaching
1057  that place would offer, till the following Monday.
1058  
1059  As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop at
1060  this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as well
1061  be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing. For my mind was
1062  made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because there was a
1063  fine, boisterous something about everything connected with that famous
1064  old island, which amazingly pleased me. Besides though New Bedford has
1065  of late been gradually monopolising the business of whaling, and though
1066  in this matter poor old Nantucket is now much behind her, yet Nantucket
1067  was her great original—the Tyre of this Carthage;—the place where the
1068  first dead American whale was stranded. Where else but from Nantucket
1069  did those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes
1070  to give chase to the Leviathan? And where but from Nantucket, too, did
1071  that first adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with
1072  imported cobblestones—so goes the story—to throw at the whales, in
1073  order to discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the
1074  bowsprit?
1075  
1076  Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before me
1077  in New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it became a
1078  matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep meanwhile. It was a
1079  very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and dismal night, bitingly cold
1080  and cheerless. I knew no one in the place. With anxious grapnels I had
1081  sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver,—So,
1082  wherever you go, Ishmael, said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of
1083  a dreary street shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the
1084  north with the darkness towards the south—wherever in your wisdom you
1085  may conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to
1086  inquire the price, and don’t be too particular.
1087  
1088  With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of “The
1089  Crossed Harpoons”—but it looked too expensive and jolly there. Further
1090  on, from the bright red windows of the “Sword-Fish Inn,” there came
1091  such fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the packed snow and
1092  ice from before the house, for everywhere else the congealed frost lay
1093  ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,—rather weary for me,
1094  when I struck my foot against the flinty projections, because from
1095  hard, remorseless service the soles of my boots were in a most
1096  miserable plight. Too expensive and jolly, again thought I, pausing one
1097  moment to watch the broad glare in the street, and hear the sounds of
1098  the tinkling glasses within. But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; don’t
1099  you hear? get away from before the door; your patched boots are
1100  stopping the way. So on I went. I now by instinct followed the streets
1101  that took me waterward, for there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not
1102  the cheeriest inns.
1103  
1104  Such dreary streets! blocks of blackness, not houses, on either hand,
1105  and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a tomb. At
1106  this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that quarter of
1107  the town proved all but deserted. But presently I came to a smoky light
1108  proceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which stood
1109  invitingly open. It had a careless look, as if it were meant for the
1110  uses of the public; so, entering, the first thing I did was to stumble
1111  over an ash-box in the porch. Ha! thought I, ha, as the flying
1112  particles almost choked me, are these ashes from that destroyed city,
1113  Gomorrah? But “The Crossed Harpoons,” and “The Sword-Fish?”—this, then
1114  must needs be the sign of “The Trap.” However, I picked myself up and
1115  hearing a loud voice within, pushed on and opened a second, interior
1116  door.
1117  
1118  It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet. A hundred black
1119  faces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black Angel of
1120  Doom was beating a book in a pulpit. It was a negro church; and the
1121  preacher’s text was about the blackness of darkness, and the weeping
1122  and wailing and teeth-gnashing there. Ha, Ishmael, muttered I, backing
1123  out, Wretched entertainment at the sign of ‘The Trap!’
1124  
1125  Moving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the
1126  docks, and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a
1127  swinging sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly
1128  representing a tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words
1129  underneath—“The Spouter Inn:—Peter Coffin.”
1130  
1131  Coffin?—Spouter?—Rather ominous in that particular connexion, thought
1132  I. But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I suppose this
1133  Peter here is an emigrant from there. As the light looked so dim, and
1134  the place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and the dilapidated
1135  little wooden house itself looked as if it might have been carted here
1136  from the ruins of some burnt district, and as the swinging sign had a
1137  poverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought that here was the very
1138  spot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea coffee.
1139  
1140  It was a queer sort of place—a gable-ended old house, one side palsied
1141  as it were, and leaning over sadly. It stood on a sharp bleak corner,
1142  where that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse howling than
1143  ever it did about poor Paul’s tossed craft. Euroclydon, nevertheless,
1144  is a mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with his feet on the
1145  hob quietly toasting for bed. “In judging of that tempestuous wind
1146  called Euroclydon,” says an old writer—of whose works I possess the
1147  only copy extant—“it maketh a marvellous difference, whether thou
1148  lookest out at it from a glass window where the frost is all on the
1149  outside, or whether thou observest it from that sashless window, where
1150  the frost is on both sides, and of which the wight Death is the only
1151  glazier.” True enough, thought I, as this passage occurred to my
1152  mind—old black-letter, thou reasonest well. Yes, these eyes are
1153  windows, and this body of mine is the house. What a pity they didn’t
1154  stop up the chinks and the crannies though, and thrust in a little lint
1155  here and there. But it’s too late to make any improvements now. The
1156  universe is finished; the copestone is on, and the chips were carted
1157  off a million years ago. Poor Lazarus there, chattering his teeth
1158  against the curbstone for his pillow, and shaking off his tatters with
1159  his shiverings, he might plug up both ears with rags, and put a
1160  corn-cob into his mouth, and yet that would not keep out the
1161  tempestuous Euroclydon. Euroclydon! says old Dives, in his red silken
1162  wrapper—(he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! What a fine frosty
1163  night; how Orion glitters; what northern lights! Let them talk of their
1164  oriental summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give me the
1165  privilege of making my own summer with my own coals.
1166  
1167  But what thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holding them up
1168  to the grand northern lights? Would not Lazarus rather be in Sumatra
1169  than here? Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise along the
1170  line of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit itself, in
1171  order to keep out this frost?
1172  
1173  Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before the
1174  door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should be
1175  moored to one of the Moluccas. Yet Dives himself, he too lives like a
1176  Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a president of a
1177  temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of orphans.
1178  
1179  But no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there
1180  is plenty of that yet to come. Let us scrape the ice from our frosted
1181  feet, and see what sort of a place this “Spouter” may be.
1182  
1183  
1184  CHAPTER 3. The Spouter-Inn.
1185  
1186  Entering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,
1187  low, straggling entry with old-fashioned wainscots, reminding one of
1188  the bulwarks of some condemned old craft. On one side hung a very large
1189  oilpainting so thoroughly besmoked, and every way defaced, that in the
1190  unequal crosslights by which you viewed it, it was only by diligent
1191  study and a series of systematic visits to it, and careful inquiry of
1192  the neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an understanding of its
1193  purpose. Such unaccountable masses of shades and shadows, that at first
1194  you almost thought some ambitious young artist, in the time of the New
1195  England hags, had endeavored to delineate chaos bewitched. But by dint
1196  of much and earnest contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and
1197  especially by throwing open the little window towards the back of the
1198  entry, you at last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however
1199  wild, might not be altogether unwarranted.
1200  
1201  But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,
1202  portentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the
1203  picture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a
1204  nameless yeast. A boggy, soggy, squitchy picture truly, enough to drive
1205  a nervous man distracted. Yet was there a sort of indefinite,
1206  half-attained, unimaginable sublimity about it that fairly froze you to
1207  it, till you involuntarily took an oath with yourself to find out what
1208  that marvellous painting meant. Ever and anon a bright, but, alas,
1209  deceptive idea would dart you through.—It’s the Black Sea in a midnight
1210  gale.—It’s the unnatural combat of the four primal elements.—It’s a
1211  blasted heath.—It’s a Hyperborean winter scene.—It’s the breaking-up of
1212  the icebound stream of Time. But at last all these fancies yielded to
1213  that one portentous something in the picture’s midst. _That_ once found
1214  out, and all the rest were plain. But stop; does it not bear a faint
1215  resemblance to a gigantic fish? even the great leviathan himself?
1216  
1217  In fact, the artist’s design seemed this: a final theory of my own,
1218  partly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with
1219  whom I conversed upon the subject. The picture represents a Cape-Horner
1220  in a great hurricane; the half-foundered ship weltering there with its
1221  three dismantled masts alone visible; and an exasperated whale,
1222  purposing to spring clean over the craft, is in the enormous act of
1223  impaling himself upon the three mast-heads.
1224  
1225  The opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish
1226  array of monstrous clubs and spears. Some were thickly set with
1227  glittering teeth resembling ivory saws; others were tufted with knots
1228  of human hair; and one was sickle-shaped, with a vast handle sweeping
1229  round like the segment made in the new-mown grass by a long-armed
1230  mower. You shuddered as you gazed, and wondered what monstrous cannibal
1231  and savage could ever have gone a death-harvesting with such a hacking,
1232  horrifying implement. Mixed with these were rusty old whaling lances
1233  and harpoons all broken and deformed. Some were storied weapons. With
1234  this once long lance, now wildly elbowed, fifty years ago did Nathan
1235  Swain kill fifteen whales between a sunrise and a sunset. And that
1236  harpoon—so like a corkscrew now—was flung in Javan seas, and run away
1237  with by a whale, years afterwards slain off the Cape of Blanco. The
1238  original iron entered nigh the tail, and, like a restless needle
1239  sojourning in the body of a man, travelled full forty feet, and at last
1240  was found imbedded in the hump.
1241  
1242  Crossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way—cut
1243  through what in old times must have been a great central chimney with
1244  fireplaces all round—you enter the public room. A still duskier place
1245  is this, with such low ponderous beams above, and such old wrinkled
1246  planks beneath, that you would almost fancy you trod some old craft’s
1247  cockpits, especially of such a howling night, when this corner-anchored
1248  old ark rocked so furiously. On one side stood a long, low, shelf-like
1249  table covered with cracked glass cases, filled with dusty rarities
1250  gathered from this wide world’s remotest nooks. Projecting from the
1251  further angle of the room stands a dark-looking den—the bar—a rude
1252  attempt at a right whale’s head. Be that how it may, there stands the
1253  vast arched bone of the whale’s jaw, so wide, a coach might almost
1254  drive beneath it. Within are shabby shelves, ranged round with old
1255  decanters, bottles, flasks; and in those jaws of swift destruction,
1256  like another cursed Jonah (by which name indeed they called him),
1257  bustles a little withered old man, who, for their money, dearly sells
1258  the sailors deliriums and death.
1259  
1260  Abominable are the tumblers into which he pours his poison. Though true
1261  cylinders without—within, the villanous green goggling glasses
1262  deceitfully tapered downwards to a cheating bottom. Parallel meridians
1263  rudely pecked into the glass, surround these footpads’ goblets. Fill to
1264  _this_ mark, and your charge is but a penny; to _this_ a penny more;
1265  and so on to the full glass—the Cape Horn measure, which you may gulp
1266  down for a shilling.
1267  
1268  Upon entering the place I found a number of young seamen gathered about
1269  a table, examining by a dim light divers specimens of _skrimshander_. I
1270  sought the landlord, and telling him I desired to be accommodated with
1271  a room, received for answer that his house was full—not a bed
1272  unoccupied. “But avast,” he added, tapping his forehead, “you haint no
1273  objections to sharing a harpooneer’s blanket, have ye? I s’pose you are
1274  goin’ a-whalin’, so you’d better get used to that sort of thing.”
1275  
1276  I told him that I never liked to sleep two in a bed; that if I should
1277  ever do so, it would depend upon who the harpooneer might be, and that
1278  if he (the landlord) really had no other place for me, and the
1279  harpooneer was not decidedly objectionable, why rather than wander
1280  further about a strange town on so bitter a night, I would put up with
1281  the half of any decent man’s blanket.
1282  
1283  “I thought so. All right; take a seat. Supper?—you want supper?
1284  Supper’ll be ready directly.”
1285  
1286  I sat down on an old wooden settle, carved all over like a bench on the
1287  Battery. At one end a ruminating tar was still further adorning it with
1288  his jack-knife, stooping over and diligently working away at the space
1289  between his legs. He was trying his hand at a ship under full sail, but
1290  he didn’t make much headway, I thought.
1291  
1292  At last some four or five of us were summoned to our meal in an
1293  adjoining room. It was cold as Iceland—no fire at all—the landlord said
1294  he couldn’t afford it. Nothing but two dismal tallow candles, each in a
1295  winding sheet. We were fain to button up our monkey jackets, and hold
1296  to our lips cups of scalding tea with our half frozen fingers. But the
1297  fare was of the most substantial kind—not only meat and potatoes, but
1298  dumplings; good heavens! dumplings for supper! One young fellow in a
1299  green box coat, addressed himself to these dumplings in a most direful
1300  manner.
1301  
1302  “My boy,” said the landlord, “you’ll have the nightmare to a dead
1303  sartainty.”
1304  
1305  “Landlord,” I whispered, “that aint the harpooneer is it?”
1306  
1307  “Oh, no,” said he, looking a sort of diabolically funny, “the
1308  harpooneer is a dark complexioned chap. He never eats dumplings, he
1309  don’t—he eats nothing but steaks, and he likes ’em rare.”
1310  
1311  “The devil he does,” says I. “Where is that harpooneer? Is he here?”
1312  
1313  “He’ll be here afore long,” was the answer.
1314  
1315  I could not help it, but I began to feel suspicious of this “dark
1316  complexioned” harpooneer. At any rate, I made up my mind that if it so
1317  turned out that we should sleep together, he must undress and get into
1318  bed before I did.
1319  
1320  Supper over, the company went back to the bar-room, when, knowing not
1321  what else to do with myself, I resolved to spend the rest of the
1322  evening as a looker on.
1323  
1324  Presently a rioting noise was heard without. Starting up, the landlord
1325  cried, “That’s the Grampus’s crew. I seed her reported in the offing
1326  this morning; a three years’ voyage, and a full ship. Hurrah, boys; now
1327  we’ll have the latest news from the Feegees.”
1328  
1329  A tramping of sea boots was heard in the entry; the door was flung
1330  open, and in rolled a wild set of mariners enough. Enveloped in their
1331  shaggy watch coats, and with their heads muffled in woollen comforters,
1332  all bedarned and ragged, and their beards stiff with icicles, they
1333  seemed an eruption of bears from Labrador. They had just landed from
1334  their boat, and this was the first house they entered. No wonder, then,
1335  that they made a straight wake for the whale’s mouth—the bar—when the
1336  wrinkled little old Jonah, there officiating, soon poured them out
1337  brimmers all round. One complained of a bad cold in his head, upon
1338  which Jonah mixed him a pitch-like potion of gin and molasses, which he
1339  swore was a sovereign cure for all colds and catarrhs whatsoever, never
1340  mind of how long standing, or whether caught off the coast of Labrador,
1341  or on the weather side of an ice-island.
1342  
1343  The liquor soon mounted into their heads, as it generally does even
1344  with the arrantest topers newly landed from sea, and they began
1345  capering about most obstreperously.
1346  
1347  I observed, however, that one of them held somewhat aloof, and though
1348  he seemed desirous not to spoil the hilarity of his shipmates by his
1349  own sober face, yet upon the whole he refrained from making as much
1350  noise as the rest. This man interested me at once; and since the
1351  sea-gods had ordained that he should soon become my shipmate (though
1352  but a sleeping-partner one, so far as this narrative is concerned), I
1353  will here venture upon a little description of him. He stood full six
1354  feet in height, with noble shoulders, and a chest like a coffer-dam. I
1355  have seldom seen such brawn in a man. His face was deeply brown and
1356  burnt, making his white teeth dazzling by the contrast; while in the
1357  deep shadows of his eyes floated some reminiscences that did not seem
1358  to give him much joy. His voice at once announced that he was a
1359  Southerner, and from his fine stature, I thought he must be one of
1360  those tall mountaineers from the Alleghanian Ridge in Virginia. When
1361  the revelry of his companions had mounted to its height, this man
1362  slipped away unobserved, and I saw no more of him till he became my
1363  comrade on the sea. In a few minutes, however, he was missed by his
1364  shipmates, and being, it seems, for some reason a huge favourite with
1365  them, they raised a cry of “Bulkington! Bulkington! where’s
1366  Bulkington?” and darted out of the house in pursuit of him.
1367  
1368  It was now about nine o’clock, and the room seeming almost
1369  supernaturally quiet after these orgies, I began to congratulate myself
1370  upon a little plan that had occurred to me just previous to the
1371  entrance of the seamen.
1372  
1373  No man prefers to sleep two in a bed. In fact, you would a good deal
1374  rather not sleep with your own brother. I don’t know how it is, but
1375  people like to be private when they are sleeping. And when it comes to
1376  sleeping with an unknown stranger, in a strange inn, in a strange town,
1377  and that stranger a harpooneer, then your objections indefinitely
1378  multiply. Nor was there any earthly reason why I as a sailor should
1379  sleep two in a bed, more than anybody else; for sailors no more sleep
1380  two in a bed at sea, than bachelor Kings do ashore. To be sure they all
1381  sleep together in one apartment, but you have your own hammock, and
1382  cover yourself with your own blanket, and sleep in your own skin.
1383  
1384  The more I pondered over this harpooneer, the more I abominated the
1385  thought of sleeping with him. It was fair to presume that being a
1386  harpooneer, his linen or woollen, as the case might be, would not be of
1387  the tidiest, certainly none of the finest. I began to twitch all over.
1388  Besides, it was getting late, and my decent harpooneer ought to be home
1389  and going bedwards. Suppose now, he should tumble in upon me at
1390  midnight—how could I tell from what vile hole he had been coming?
1391  
1392  “Landlord! I’ve changed my mind about that harpooneer.—I shan’t sleep
1393  with him. I’ll try the bench here.”
1394  
1395  “Just as you please; I’m sorry I can’t spare ye a tablecloth for a
1396  mattress, and it’s a plaguy rough board here”—feeling of the knots and
1397  notches. “But wait a bit, Skrimshander; I’ve got a carpenter’s plane
1398  there in the bar—wait, I say, and I’ll make ye snug enough.” So saying
1399  he procured the plane; and with his old silk handkerchief first dusting
1400  the bench, vigorously set to planing away at my bed, the while grinning
1401  like an ape. The shavings flew right and left; till at last the
1402  plane-iron came bump against an indestructible knot. The landlord was
1403  near spraining his wrist, and I told him for heaven’s sake to quit—the
1404  bed was soft enough to suit me, and I did not know how all the planing
1405  in the world could make eider down of a pine plank. So gathering up the
1406  shavings with another grin, and throwing them into the great stove in
1407  the middle of the room, he went about his business, and left me in a
1408  brown study.
1409  
1410  I now took the measure of the bench, and found that it was a foot too
1411  short; but that could be mended with a chair. But it was a foot too
1412  narrow, and the other bench in the room was about four inches higher
1413  than the planed one—so there was no yoking them. I then placed the
1414  first bench lengthwise along the only clear space against the wall,
1415  leaving a little interval between, for my back to settle down in. But I
1416  soon found that there came such a draught of cold air over me from
1417  under the sill of the window, that this plan would never do at all,
1418  especially as another current from the rickety door met the one from
1419  the window, and both together formed a series of small whirlwinds in
1420  the immediate vicinity of the spot where I had thought to spend the
1421  night.
1422  
1423  The devil fetch that harpooneer, thought I, but stop, couldn’t I steal
1424  a march on him—bolt his door inside, and jump into his bed, not to be
1425  wakened by the most violent knockings? It seemed no bad idea; but upon
1426  second thoughts I dismissed it. For who could tell but what the next
1427  morning, so soon as I popped out of the room, the harpooneer might be
1428  standing in the entry, all ready to knock me down!
1429  
1430  Still, looking round me again, and seeing no possible chance of
1431  spending a sufferable night unless in some other person’s bed, I began
1432  to think that after all I might be cherishing unwarrantable prejudices
1433  against this unknown harpooneer. Thinks I, I’ll wait awhile; he must be
1434  dropping in before long. I’ll have a good look at him then, and perhaps
1435  we may become jolly good bedfellows after all—there’s no telling.
1436  
1437  But though the other boarders kept coming in by ones, twos, and threes,
1438  and going to bed, yet no sign of my harpooneer.
1439  
1440  “Landlord!” said I, “what sort of a chap is he—does he always keep such
1441  late hours?” It was now hard upon twelve o’clock.
1442  
1443  The landlord chuckled again with his lean chuckle, and seemed to be
1444  mightily tickled at something beyond my comprehension. “No,” he
1445  answered, “generally he’s an early bird—airley to bed and airley to
1446  rise—yes, he’s the bird what catches the worm. But to-night he went out
1447  a peddling, you see, and I don’t see what on airth keeps him so late,
1448  unless, may be, he can’t sell his head.”
1449  
1450  “Can’t sell his head?—What sort of a bamboozingly story is this you are
1451  telling me?” getting into a towering rage. “Do you pretend to say,
1452  landlord, that this harpooneer is actually engaged this blessed
1453  Saturday night, or rather Sunday morning, in peddling his head around
1454  this town?”
1455  
1456  “That’s precisely it,” said the landlord, “and I told him he couldn’t
1457  sell it here, the market’s overstocked.”
1458  
1459  “With what?” shouted I.
1460  
1461  “With heads to be sure; ain’t there too many heads in the world?”
1462  
1463  “I tell you what it is, landlord,” said I quite calmly, “you’d better
1464  stop spinning that yarn to me—I’m not green.”
1465  
1466  “May be not,” taking out a stick and whittling a toothpick, “but I
1467  rayther guess you’ll be done _brown_ if that ere harpooneer hears you a
1468  slanderin’ his head.”
1469  
1470  “I’ll break it for him,” said I, now flying into a passion again at
1471  this unaccountable farrago of the landlord’s.
1472  
1473  “It’s broke a’ready,” said he.
1474  
1475  “Broke,” said I—“_broke_, do you mean?”
1476  
1477  “Sartain, and that’s the very reason he can’t sell it, I guess.”
1478  
1479  “Landlord,” said I, going up to him as cool as Mt. Hecla in a
1480  snow-storm—“landlord, stop whittling. You and I must understand one
1481  another, and that too without delay. I come to your house and want a
1482  bed; you tell me you can only give me half a one; that the other half
1483  belongs to a certain harpooneer. And about this harpooneer, whom I have
1484  not yet seen, you persist in telling me the most mystifying and
1485  exasperating stories tending to beget in me an uncomfortable feeling
1486  towards the man whom you design for my bedfellow—a sort of connexion,
1487  landlord, which is an intimate and confidential one in the highest
1488  degree. I now demand of you to speak out and tell me who and what this
1489  harpooneer is, and whether I shall be in all respects safe to spend the
1490  night with him. And in the first place, you will be so good as to unsay
1491  that story about selling his head, which if true I take to be good
1492  evidence that this harpooneer is stark mad, and I’ve no idea of
1493  sleeping with a madman; and you, sir, _you_ I mean, landlord, _you_,
1494  sir, by trying to induce me to do so knowingly, would thereby render
1495  yourself liable to a criminal prosecution.”
1496  
1497  “Wall,” said the landlord, fetching a long breath, “that’s a purty long
1498  sarmon for a chap that rips a little now and then. But be easy, be
1499  easy, this here harpooneer I have been tellin’ you of has just arrived
1500  from the south seas, where he bought up a lot of ’balmed New Zealand
1501  heads (great curios, you know), and he’s sold all on ’em but one, and
1502  that one he’s trying to sell to-night, cause to-morrow’s Sunday, and it
1503  would not do to be sellin’ human heads about the streets when folks is
1504  goin’ to churches. He wanted to, last Sunday, but I stopped him just as
1505  he was goin’ out of the door with four heads strung on a string, for
1506  all the airth like a string of inions.”
1507  
1508  This account cleared up the otherwise unaccountable mystery, and showed
1509  that the landlord, after all, had had no idea of fooling me—but at the
1510  same time what could I think of a harpooneer who stayed out of a
1511  Saturday night clean into the holy Sabbath, engaged in such a cannibal
1512  business as selling the heads of dead idolators?
1513  
1514  “Depend upon it, landlord, that harpooneer is a dangerous man.”
1515  
1516  “He pays reg’lar,” was the rejoinder. “But come, it’s getting dreadful
1517  late, you had better be turning flukes—it’s a nice bed; Sal and me
1518  slept in that ere bed the night we were spliced. There’s plenty of room
1519  for two to kick about in that bed; it’s an almighty big bed that. Why,
1520  afore we give it up, Sal used to put our Sam and little Johnny in the
1521  foot of it. But I got a dreaming and sprawling about one night, and
1522  somehow, Sam got pitched on the floor, and came near breaking his arm.
1523  Arter that, Sal said it wouldn’t do. Come along here, I’ll give ye a
1524  glim in a jiffy;” and so saying he lighted a candle and held it towards
1525  me, offering to lead the way. But I stood irresolute; when looking at a
1526  clock in the corner, he exclaimed “I vum it’s Sunday—you won’t see that
1527  harpooneer to-night; he’s come to anchor somewhere—come along then;
1528  _do_ come; _won’t_ ye come?”
1529  
1530  I considered the matter a moment, and then up stairs we went, and I was
1531  ushered into a small room, cold as a clam, and furnished, sure enough,
1532  with a prodigious bed, almost big enough indeed for any four
1533  harpooneers to sleep abreast.
1534  
1535  “There,” said the landlord, placing the candle on a crazy old sea chest
1536  that did double duty as a wash-stand and centre table; “there, make
1537  yourself comfortable now, and good night to ye.” I turned round from
1538  eyeing the bed, but he had disappeared.
1539  
1540  Folding back the counterpane, I stooped over the bed. Though none of
1541  the most elegant, it yet stood the scrutiny tolerably well. I then
1542  glanced round the room; and besides the bedstead and centre table,
1543  could see no other furniture belonging to the place, but a rude shelf,
1544  the four walls, and a papered fireboard representing a man striking a
1545  whale. Of things not properly belonging to the room, there was a
1546  hammock lashed up, and thrown upon the floor in one corner; also a
1547  large seaman’s bag, containing the harpooneer’s wardrobe, no doubt in
1548  lieu of a land trunk. Likewise, there was a parcel of outlandish bone
1549  fish hooks on the shelf over the fire-place, and a tall harpoon
1550  standing at the head of the bed.
1551  
1552  But what is this on the chest? I took it up, and held it close to the
1553  light, and felt it, and smelt it, and tried every way possible to
1554  arrive at some satisfactory conclusion concerning it. I can compare it
1555  to nothing but a large door mat, ornamented at the edges with little
1556  tinkling tags something like the stained porcupine quills round an
1557  Indian moccasin. There was a hole or slit in the middle of this mat, as
1558  you see the same in South American ponchos. But could it be possible
1559  that any sober harpooneer would get into a door mat, and parade the
1560  streets of any Christian town in that sort of guise? I put it on, to
1561  try it, and it weighed me down like a hamper, being uncommonly shaggy
1562  and thick, and I thought a little damp, as though this mysterious
1563  harpooneer had been wearing it of a rainy day. I went up in it to a bit
1564  of glass stuck against the wall, and I never saw such a sight in my
1565  life. I tore myself out of it in such a hurry that I gave myself a kink
1566  in the neck.
1567  
1568  I sat down on the side of the bed, and commenced thinking about this
1569  head-peddling harpooneer, and his door mat. After thinking some time on
1570  the bed-side, I got up and took off my monkey jacket, and then stood in
1571  the middle of the room thinking. I then took off my coat, and thought a
1572  little more in my shirt sleeves. But beginning to feel very cold now,
1573  half undressed as I was, and remembering what the landlord said about
1574  the harpooneer’s not coming home at all that night, it being so very
1575  late, I made no more ado, but jumped out of my pantaloons and boots,
1576  and then blowing out the light tumbled into bed, and commended myself
1577  to the care of heaven.
1578  
1579  Whether that mattress was stuffed with corn-cobs or broken crockery,
1580  there is no telling, but I rolled about a good deal, and could not
1581  sleep for a long time. At last I slid off into a light doze, and had
1582  pretty nearly made a good offing towards the land of Nod, when I heard
1583  a heavy footfall in the passage, and saw a glimmer of light come into
1584  the room from under the door.
1585  
1586  Lord save me, thinks I, that must be the harpooneer, the infernal
1587  head-peddler. But I lay perfectly still, and resolved not to say a word
1588  till spoken to. Holding a light in one hand, and that identical New
1589  Zealand head in the other, the stranger entered the room, and without
1590  looking towards the bed, placed his candle a good way off from me on
1591  the floor in one corner, and then began working away at the knotted
1592  cords of the large bag I before spoke of as being in the room. I was
1593  all eagerness to see his face, but he kept it averted for some time
1594  while employed in unlacing the bag’s mouth. This accomplished, however,
1595  he turned round—when, good heavens! what a sight! Such a face! It was
1596  of a dark, purplish, yellow colour, here and there stuck over with
1597  large blackish looking squares. Yes, it’s just as I thought, he’s a
1598  terrible bedfellow; he’s been in a fight, got dreadfully cut, and here
1599  he is, just from the surgeon. But at that moment he chanced to turn his
1600  face so towards the light, that I plainly saw they could not be
1601  sticking-plasters at all, those black squares on his cheeks. They were
1602  stains of some sort or other. At first I knew not what to make of this;
1603  but soon an inkling of the truth occurred to me. I remembered a story
1604  of a white man—a whaleman too—who, falling among the cannibals, had
1605  been tattooed by them. I concluded that this harpooneer, in the course
1606  of his distant voyages, must have met with a similar adventure. And
1607  what is it, thought I, after all! It’s only his outside; a man can be
1608  honest in any sort of skin. But then, what to make of his unearthly
1609  complexion, that part of it, I mean, lying round about, and completely
1610  independent of the squares of tattooing. To be sure, it might be
1611  nothing but a good coat of tropical tanning; but I never heard of a hot
1612  sun’s tanning a white man into a purplish yellow one. However, I had
1613  never been in the South Seas; and perhaps the sun there produced these
1614  extraordinary effects upon the skin. Now, while all these ideas were
1615  passing through me like lightning, this harpooneer never noticed me at
1616  all. But, after some difficulty having opened his bag, he commenced
1617  fumbling in it, and presently pulled out a sort of tomahawk, and a
1618  seal-skin wallet with the hair on. Placing these on the old chest in
1619  the middle of the room, he then took the New Zealand head—a ghastly
1620  thing enough—and crammed it down into the bag. He now took off his
1621  hat—a new beaver hat—when I came nigh singing out with fresh surprise.
1622  There was no hair on his head—none to speak of at least—nothing but a
1623  small scalp-knot twisted up on his forehead. His bald purplish head now
1624  looked for all the world like a mildewed skull. Had not the stranger
1625  stood between me and the door, I would have bolted out of it quicker
1626  than ever I bolted a dinner.
1627  
1628  Even as it was, I thought something of slipping out of the window, but
1629  it was the second floor back. I am no coward, but what to make of this
1630  head-peddling purple rascal altogether passed my comprehension.
1631  Ignorance is the parent of fear, and being completely nonplussed and
1632  confounded about the stranger, I confess I was now as much afraid of
1633  him as if it was the devil himself who had thus broken into my room at
1634  the dead of night. In fact, I was so afraid of him that I was not game
1635  enough just then to address him, and demand a satisfactory answer
1636  concerning what seemed inexplicable in him.
1637  
1638  Meanwhile, he continued the business of undressing, and at last showed
1639  his chest and arms. As I live, these covered parts of him were
1640  checkered with the same squares as his face; his back, too, was all
1641  over the same dark squares; he seemed to have been in a Thirty Years’
1642  War, and just escaped from it with a sticking-plaster shirt. Still
1643  more, his very legs were marked, as if a parcel of dark green frogs
1644  were running up the trunks of young palms. It was now quite plain that
1645  he must be some abominable savage or other shipped aboard of a whaleman
1646  in the South Seas, and so landed in this Christian country. I quaked to
1647  think of it. A peddler of heads too—perhaps the heads of his own
1648  brothers. He might take a fancy to mine—heavens! look at that tomahawk!
1649  
1650  But there was no time for shuddering, for now the savage went about
1651  something that completely fascinated my attention, and convinced me
1652  that he must indeed be a heathen. Going to his heavy grego, or wrapall,
1653  or dreadnaught, which he had previously hung on a chair, he fumbled in
1654  the pockets, and produced at length a curious little deformed image
1655  with a hunch on its back, and exactly the colour of a three days’ old
1656  Congo baby. Remembering the embalmed head, at first I almost thought
1657  that this black manikin was a real baby preserved in some similar
1658  manner. But seeing that it was not at all limber, and that it glistened
1659  a good deal like polished ebony, I concluded that it must be nothing
1660  but a wooden idol, which indeed it proved to be. For now the savage
1661  goes up to the empty fire-place, and removing the papered fire-board,
1662  sets up this little hunch-backed image, like a tenpin, between the
1663  andirons. The chimney jambs and all the bricks inside were very sooty,
1664  so that I thought this fire-place made a very appropriate little shrine
1665  or chapel for his Congo idol.
1666  
1667  I now screwed my eyes hard towards the half hidden image, feeling but
1668  ill at ease meantime—to see what was next to follow. First he takes
1669  about a double handful of shavings out of his grego pocket, and places
1670  them carefully before the idol; then laying a bit of ship biscuit on
1671  top and applying the flame from the lamp, he kindled the shavings into
1672  a sacrificial blaze. Presently, after many hasty snatches into the
1673  fire, and still hastier withdrawals of his fingers (whereby he seemed
1674  to be scorching them badly), he at last succeeded in drawing out the
1675  biscuit; then blowing off the heat and ashes a little, he made a polite
1676  offer of it to the little negro. But the little devil did not seem to
1677  fancy such dry sort of fare at all; he never moved his lips. All these
1678  strange antics were accompanied by still stranger guttural noises from
1679  the devotee, who seemed to be praying in a sing-song or else singing
1680  some pagan psalmody or other, during which his face twitched about in
1681  the most unnatural manner. At last extinguishing the fire, he took the
1682  idol up very unceremoniously, and bagged it again in his grego pocket
1683  as carelessly as if he were a sportsman bagging a dead woodcock.
1684  
1685  All these queer proceedings increased my uncomfortableness, and seeing
1686  him now exhibiting strong symptoms of concluding his business
1687  operations, and jumping into bed with me, I thought it was high time,
1688  now or never, before the light was put out, to break the spell in which
1689  I had so long been bound.
1690  
1691  But the interval I spent in deliberating what to say, was a fatal one.
1692  Taking up his tomahawk from the table, he examined the head of it for
1693  an instant, and then holding it to the light, with his mouth at the
1694  handle, he puffed out great clouds of tobacco smoke. The next moment
1695  the light was extinguished, and this wild cannibal, tomahawk between
1696  his teeth, sprang into bed with me. I sang out, I could not help it
1697  now; and giving a sudden grunt of astonishment he began feeling me.
1698  
1699  Stammering out something, I knew not what, I rolled away from him
1700  against the wall, and then conjured him, whoever or whatever he might
1701  be, to keep quiet, and let me get up and light the lamp again. But his
1702  guttural responses satisfied me at once that he but ill comprehended my
1703  meaning.
1704  
1705  “Who-e debel you?”—he at last said—“you no speak-e, dam-me, I kill-e.”
1706  And so saying the lighted tomahawk began flourishing about me in the
1707  dark.
1708  
1709  “Landlord, for God’s sake, Peter Coffin!” shouted I. “Landlord! Watch!
1710  Coffin! Angels! save me!”
1711  
1712  “Speak-e! tell-ee me who-ee be, or dam-me, I kill-e!” again growled the
1713  cannibal, while his horrid flourishings of the tomahawk scattered the
1714  hot tobacco ashes about me till I thought my linen would get on fire.
1715  But thank heaven, at that moment the landlord came into the room light
1716  in hand, and leaping from the bed I ran up to him.
1717  
1718  “Don’t be afraid now,” said he, grinning again, “Queequeg here wouldn’t
1719  harm a hair of your head.”
1720  
1721  “Stop your grinning,” shouted I, “and why didn’t you tell me that that
1722  infernal harpooneer was a cannibal?”
1723  
1724  “I thought ye know’d it;—didn’t I tell ye, he was a peddlin’ heads
1725  around town?—but turn flukes again and go to sleep. Queequeg, look
1726  here—you sabbee me, I sabbee—you this man sleepe you—you sabbee?”
1727  
1728  “Me sabbee plenty”—grunted Queequeg, puffing away at his pipe and
1729  sitting up in bed.
1730  
1731  “You gettee in,” he added, motioning to me with his tomahawk, and
1732  throwing the clothes to one side. He really did this in not only a
1733  civil but a really kind and charitable way. I stood looking at him a
1734  moment. For all his tattooings he was on the whole a clean, comely
1735  looking cannibal. What’s all this fuss I have been making about,
1736  thought I to myself—the man’s a human being just as I am: he has just
1737  as much reason to fear me, as I have to be afraid of him. Better sleep
1738  with a sober cannibal than a drunken Christian.
1739  
1740  “Landlord,” said I, “tell him to stash his tomahawk there, or pipe, or
1741  whatever you call it; tell him to stop smoking, in short, and I will
1742  turn in with him. But I don’t fancy having a man smoking in bed with
1743  me. It’s dangerous. Besides, I ain’t insured.”
1744  
1745  This being told to Queequeg, he at once complied, and again politely
1746  motioned me to get into bed—rolling over to one side as much as to
1747  say—“I won’t touch a leg of ye.”
1748  
1749  “Good night, landlord,” said I, “you may go.”
1750  
1751  I turned in, and never slept better in my life.
1752  
1753  
1754  CHAPTER 4. The Counterpane.
1755  
1756  Upon waking next morning about daylight, I found Queequeg’s arm thrown
1757  over me in the most loving and affectionate manner. You had almost
1758  thought I had been his wife. The counterpane was of patchwork, full of
1759  odd little parti-coloured squares and triangles; and this arm of his
1760  tattooed all over with an interminable Cretan labyrinth of a figure, no
1761  two parts of which were of one precise shade—owing I suppose to his
1762  keeping his arm at sea unmethodically in sun and shade, his shirt
1763  sleeves irregularly rolled up at various times—this same arm of his, I
1764  say, looked for all the world like a strip of that same patchwork
1765  quilt. Indeed, partly lying on it as the arm did when I first awoke, I
1766  could hardly tell it from the quilt, they so blended their hues
1767  together; and it was only by the sense of weight and pressure that I
1768  could tell that Queequeg was hugging me.
1769  
1770  My sensations were strange. Let me try to explain them. When I was a
1771  child, I well remember a somewhat similar circumstance that befell me;
1772  whether it was a reality or a dream, I never could entirely settle. The
1773  circumstance was this. I had been cutting up some caper or other—I
1774  think it was trying to crawl up the chimney, as I had seen a little
1775  sweep do a few days previous; and my stepmother who, somehow or other,
1776  was all the time whipping me, or sending me to bed supperless,—my
1777  mother dragged me by the legs out of the chimney and packed me off to
1778  bed, though it was only two o’clock in the afternoon of the 21st June,
1779  the longest day in the year in our hemisphere. I felt dreadfully. But
1780  there was no help for it, so up stairs I went to my little room in the
1781  third floor, undressed myself as slowly as possible so as to kill time,
1782  and with a bitter sigh got between the sheets.
1783  
1784  I lay there dismally calculating that sixteen entire hours must elapse
1785  before I could hope for a resurrection. Sixteen hours in bed! the small
1786  of my back ached to think of it. And it was so light too; the sun
1787  shining in at the window, and a great rattling of coaches in the
1788  streets, and the sound of gay voices all over the house. I felt worse
1789  and worse—at last I got up, dressed, and softly going down in my
1790  stockinged feet, sought out my stepmother, and suddenly threw myself at
1791  her feet, beseeching her as a particular favour to give me a good
1792  slippering for my misbehaviour; anything indeed but condemning me to
1793  lie abed such an unendurable length of time. But she was the best and
1794  most conscientious of stepmothers, and back I had to go to my room. For
1795  several hours I lay there broad awake, feeling a great deal worse than
1796  I have ever done since, even from the greatest subsequent misfortunes.
1797  At last I must have fallen into a troubled nightmare of a doze; and
1798  slowly waking from it—half steeped in dreams—I opened my eyes, and the
1799  before sun-lit room was now wrapped in outer darkness. Instantly I felt
1800  a shock running through all my frame; nothing was to be seen, and
1801  nothing was to be heard; but a supernatural hand seemed placed in mine.
1802  My arm hung over the counterpane, and the nameless, unimaginable,
1803  silent form or phantom, to which the hand belonged, seemed closely
1804  seated by my bed-side. For what seemed ages piled on ages, I lay there,
1805  frozen with the most awful fears, not daring to drag away my hand; yet
1806  ever thinking that if I could but stir it one single inch, the horrid
1807  spell would be broken. I knew not how this consciousness at last glided
1808  away from me; but waking in the morning, I shudderingly remembered it
1809  all, and for days and weeks and months afterwards I lost myself in
1810  confounding attempts to explain the mystery. Nay, to this very hour, I
1811  often puzzle myself with it.
1812  
1813  Now, take away the awful fear, and my sensations at feeling the
1814  supernatural hand in mine were very similar, in their strangeness, to
1815  those which I experienced on waking up and seeing Queequeg’s pagan arm
1816  thrown round me. But at length all the past night’s events soberly
1817  recurred, one by one, in fixed reality, and then I lay only alive to
1818  the comical predicament. For though I tried to move his arm—unlock his
1819  bridegroom clasp—yet, sleeping as he was, he still hugged me tightly,
1820  as though naught but death should part us twain. I now strove to rouse
1821  him—“Queequeg!”—but his only answer was a snore. I then rolled over, my
