1822  neck feeling as if it were in a horse-collar; and suddenly felt a
1823  slight scratch. Throwing aside the counterpane, there lay the tomahawk
1824  sleeping by the savage’s side, as if it were a hatchet-faced baby. A
1825  pretty pickle, truly, thought I; abed here in a strange house in the
1826  broad day, with a cannibal and a tomahawk! “Queequeg!—in the name of
1827  goodness, Queequeg, wake!” At length, by dint of much wriggling, and
1828  loud and incessant expostulations upon the unbecomingness of his
1829  hugging a fellow male in that matrimonial sort of style, I succeeded in
1830  extracting a grunt; and presently, he drew back his arm, shook himself
1831  all over like a Newfoundland dog just from the water, and sat up in
1832  bed, stiff as a pike-staff, looking at me, and rubbing his eyes as if
1833  he did not altogether remember how I came to be there, though a dim
1834  consciousness of knowing something about me seemed slowly dawning over
1835  him. Meanwhile, I lay quietly eyeing him, having no serious misgivings
1836  now, and bent upon narrowly observing so curious a creature. When, at
1837  last, his mind seemed made up touching the character of his bedfellow,
1838  and he became, as it were, reconciled to the fact; he jumped out upon
1839  the floor, and by certain signs and sounds gave me to understand that,
1840  if it pleased me, he would dress first and then leave me to dress
1841  afterwards, leaving the whole apartment to myself. Thinks I, Queequeg,
1842  under the circumstances, this is a very civilized overture; but, the
1843  truth is, these savages have an innate sense of delicacy, say what you
1844  will; it is marvellous how essentially polite they are. I pay this
1845  particular compliment to Queequeg, because he treated me with so much
1846  civility and consideration, while I was guilty of great rudeness;
1847  staring at him from the bed, and watching all his toilette motions; for
1848  the time my curiosity getting the better of my breeding. Nevertheless,
1849  a man like Queequeg you don’t see every day, he and his ways were well
1850  worth unusual regarding.
1851  
1852  He commenced dressing at top by donning his beaver hat, a very tall
1853  one, by the by, and then—still minus his trowsers—he hunted up his
1854  boots. What under the heavens he did it for, I cannot tell, but his
1855  next movement was to crush himself—boots in hand, and hat on—under the
1856  bed; when, from sundry violent gaspings and strainings, I inferred he
1857  was hard at work booting himself; though by no law of propriety that I
1858  ever heard of, is any man required to be private when putting on his
1859  boots. But Queequeg, do you see, was a creature in the transition
1860  stage—neither caterpillar nor butterfly. He was just enough civilized
1861  to show off his outlandishness in the strangest possible manners. His
1862  education was not yet completed. He was an undergraduate. If he had not
1863  been a small degree civilized, he very probably would not have troubled
1864  himself with boots at all; but then, if he had not been still a savage,
1865  he never would have dreamt of getting under the bed to put them on. At
1866  last, he emerged with his hat very much dented and crushed down over
1867  his eyes, and began creaking and limping about the room, as if, not
1868  being much accustomed to boots, his pair of damp, wrinkled cowhide
1869  ones—probably not made to order either—rather pinched and tormented him
1870  at the first go off of a bitter cold morning.
1871  
1872  Seeing, now, that there were no curtains to the window, and that the
1873  street being very narrow, the house opposite commanded a plain view
1874  into the room, and observing more and more the indecorous figure that
1875  Queequeg made, staving about with little else but his hat and boots on;
1876  I begged him as well as I could, to accelerate his toilet somewhat, and
1877  particularly to get into his pantaloons as soon as possible. He
1878  complied, and then proceeded to wash himself. At that time in the
1879  morning any Christian would have washed his face; but Queequeg, to my
1880  amazement, contented himself with restricting his ablutions to his
1881  chest, arms, and hands. He then donned his waistcoat, and taking up a
1882  piece of hard soap on the wash-stand centre table, dipped it into water
1883  and commenced lathering his face. I was watching to see where he kept
1884  his razor, when lo and behold, he takes the harpoon from the bed
1885  corner, slips out the long wooden stock, unsheathes the head, whets it
1886  a little on his boot, and striding up to the bit of mirror against the
1887  wall, begins a vigorous scraping, or rather harpooning of his cheeks.
1888  Thinks I, Queequeg, this is using Rogers’s best cutlery with a
1889  vengeance. Afterwards I wondered the less at this operation when I came
1890  to know of what fine steel the head of a harpoon is made, and how
1891  exceedingly sharp the long straight edges are always kept.
1892  
1893  The rest of his toilet was soon achieved, and he proudly marched out of
1894  the room, wrapped up in his great pilot monkey jacket, and sporting his
1895  harpoon like a marshal’s baton.
1896  
1897  
1898  CHAPTER 5. Breakfast.
1899  
1900  I quickly followed suit, and descending into the bar-room accosted the
1901  grinning landlord very pleasantly. I cherished no malice towards him,
1902  though he had been skylarking with me not a little in the matter of my
1903  bedfellow.
1904  
1905  However, a good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a
1906  good thing; the more’s the pity. So, if any one man, in his own proper
1907  person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not be
1908  backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and be spent in
1909  that way. And the man that has anything bountifully laughable about
1910  him, be sure there is more in that man than you perhaps think for.
1911  
1912  The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in the
1913  night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look at. They were
1914  nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and third mates,
1915  and sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea blacksmiths, and
1916  harpooneers, and ship keepers; a brown and brawny company, with bosky
1917  beards; an unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing monkey jackets for morning
1918  gowns.
1919  
1920  You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore. This
1921  young fellow’s healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue, and
1922  would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three days
1923  landed from his Indian voyage. That man next him looks a few shades
1924  lighter; you might say a touch of satin wood is in him. In the
1925  complexion of a third still lingers a tropic tawn, but slightly
1926  bleached withal; _he_ doubtless has tarried whole weeks ashore. But who
1927  could show a cheek like Queequeg? which, barred with various tints,
1928  seemed like the Andes’ western slope, to show forth in one array,
1929  contrasting climates, zone by zone.
1930  
1931  “Grub, ho!” now cried the landlord, flinging open a door, and in we
1932  went to breakfast.
1933  
1934  They say that men who have seen the world, thereby become quite at ease
1935  in manner, quite self-possessed in company. Not always, though:
1936  Ledyard, the great New England traveller, and Mungo Park, the Scotch
1937  one; of all men, they possessed the least assurance in the parlor. But
1938  perhaps the mere crossing of Siberia in a sledge drawn by dogs as
1939  Ledyard did, or the taking a long solitary walk on an empty stomach, in
1940  the negro heart of Africa, which was the sum of poor Mungo’s
1941  performances—this kind of travel, I say, may not be the very best mode
1942  of attaining a high social polish. Still, for the most part, that sort
1943  of thing is to be had anywhere.
1944  
1945  These reflections just here are occasioned by the circumstance that
1946  after we were all seated at the table, and I was preparing to hear some
1947  good stories about whaling; to my no small surprise, nearly every man
1948  maintained a profound silence. And not only that, but they looked
1949  embarrassed. Yes, here were a set of sea-dogs, many of whom without the
1950  slightest bashfulness had boarded great whales on the high seas—entire
1951  strangers to them—and duelled them dead without winking; and yet, here
1952  they sat at a social breakfast table—all of the same calling, all of
1953  kindred tastes—looking round as sheepishly at each other as though they
1954  had never been out of sight of some sheepfold among the Green
1955  Mountains. A curious sight; these bashful bears, these timid warrior
1956  whalemen!
1957  
1958  But as for Queequeg—why, Queequeg sat there among them—at the head of
1959  the table, too, it so chanced; as cool as an icicle. To be sure I
1960  cannot say much for his breeding. His greatest admirer could not have
1961  cordially justified his bringing his harpoon into breakfast with him,
1962  and using it there without ceremony; reaching over the table with it,
1963  to the imminent jeopardy of many heads, and grappling the beefsteaks
1964  towards him. But _that_ was certainly very coolly done by him, and
1965  every one knows that in most people’s estimation, to do anything coolly
1966  is to do it genteelly.
1967  
1968  We will not speak of all Queequeg’s peculiarities here; how he eschewed
1969  coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided attention to
1970  beefsteaks, done rare. Enough, that when breakfast was over he withdrew
1971  like the rest into the public room, lighted his tomahawk-pipe, and was
1972  sitting there quietly digesting and smoking with his inseparable hat
1973  on, when I sallied out for a stroll.
1974  
1975  
1976  CHAPTER 6. The Street.
1977  
1978  If I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish
1979  an individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society of a
1980  civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking my first
1981  daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.
1982  
1983  In thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will
1984  frequently offer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from foreign
1985  parts. Even in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean mariners
1986  will sometimes jostle the affrighted ladies. Regent Street is not
1987  unknown to Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo Green, live
1988  Yankees have often scared the natives. But New Bedford beats all Water
1989  Street and Wapping. In these last-mentioned haunts you see only
1990  sailors; but in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand chatting at street
1991  corners; savages outright; many of whom yet carry on their bones unholy
1992  flesh. It makes a stranger stare.
1993  
1994  But, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans, Pannangians,
1995  and Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the whaling-craft
1996  which unheeded reel about the streets, you will see other sights still
1997  more curious, certainly more comical. There weekly arrive in this town
1998  scores of green Vermonters and New Hampshire men, all athirst for gain
1999  and glory in the fishery. They are mostly young, of stalwart frames;
2000  fellows who have felled forests, and now seek to drop the axe and
2001  snatch the whale-lance. Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence
2002  they came. In some things you would think them but a few hours old.
2003  Look there! that chap strutting round the corner. He wears a beaver hat
2004  and swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and sheath-knife.
2005  Here comes another with a sou’-wester and a bombazine cloak.
2006  
2007  No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one—I mean a
2008  downright bumpkin dandy—a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his
2009  two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands. Now when a
2010  country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a distinguished
2011  reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you should see the
2012  comical things he does upon reaching the seaport. In bespeaking his
2013  sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats; straps to his
2014  canvas trowsers. Ah, poor Hay-Seed! how bitterly will burst those
2015  straps in the first howling gale, when thou art driven, straps,
2016  buttons, and all, down the throat of the tempest.
2017  
2018  But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals,
2019  and bumpkins to show her visitors. Not at all. Still New Bedford is a
2020  queer place. Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land would
2021  this day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast of
2022  Labrador. As it is, parts of her back country are enough to frighten
2023  one, they look so bony. The town itself is perhaps the dearest place to
2024  live in, in all New England. It is a land of oil, true enough: but not
2025  like Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine. The streets do not run
2026  with milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave them with fresh eggs.
2027  Yet, in spite of this, nowhere in all America will you find more
2028  patrician-like houses; parks and gardens more opulent, than in New
2029  Bedford. Whence came they? how planted upon this once scraggy scoria of
2030  a country?
2031  
2032  Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty
2033  mansion, and your question will be answered. Yes; all these brave
2034  houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian
2035  oceans. One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up hither from the
2036  bottom of the sea. Can Herr Alexander perform a feat like that?
2037  
2038  In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their
2039  daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises a-piece.
2040  You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for, they say,
2041  they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night recklessly
2042  burn their lengths in spermaceti candles.
2043  
2044  In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples—long
2045  avenues of green and gold. And in August, high in air, the beautiful
2046  and bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by
2047  their tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms. So omnipotent is
2048  art; which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced bright
2049  terraces of flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside at
2050  creation’s final day.
2051  
2052  And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red roses. But
2053  roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of their cheeks
2054  is perennial as sunlight in the seventh heavens. Elsewhere match that
2055  bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in Salem, where they tell me the young
2056  girls breathe such musk, their sailor sweethearts smell them miles off
2057  shore, as though they were drawing nigh the odorous Moluccas instead of
2058  the Puritanic sands.
2059  
2060  
2061  CHAPTER 7. The Chapel.
2062  
2063  In this same New Bedford there stands a Whaleman’s Chapel, and few are
2064  the moody fishermen, shortly bound for the Indian Ocean or Pacific, who
2065  fail to make a Sunday visit to the spot. I am sure that I did not.
2066  
2067  Returning from my first morning stroll, I again sallied out upon this
2068  special errand. The sky had changed from clear, sunny cold, to driving
2069  sleet and mist. Wrapping myself in my shaggy jacket of the cloth called
2070  bearskin, I fought my way against the stubborn storm. Entering, I found
2071  a small scattered congregation of sailors, and sailors’ wives and
2072  widows. A muffled silence reigned, only broken at times by the shrieks
2073  of the storm. Each silent worshipper seemed purposely sitting apart
2074  from the other, as if each silent grief were insular and
2075  incommunicable. The chaplain had not yet arrived; and there these
2076  silent islands of men and women sat steadfastly eyeing several marble
2077  tablets, with black borders, masoned into the wall on either side the
2078  pulpit. Three of them ran something like the following, but I do not
2079  pretend to quote:—
2080  
2081  SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF JOHN TALBOT, Who, at the age of eighteen, was
2082  lost overboard, Near the Isle of Desolation, off Patagonia, _November_
2083  1_st_, 1836. THIS TABLET Is erected to his Memory BY HIS SISTER.
2084  
2085  SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF ROBERT LONG, WILLIS ELLERY, NATHAN COLEMAN,
2086  WALTER CANNY, SETH MACY, AND SAMUEL GLEIG, Forming one of the boats’
2087  crews OF THE SHIP ELIZA Who were towed out of sight by a Whale, On the
2088  Off-shore Ground in the PACIFIC, _December_ 31_st_, 1839. THIS MARBLE
2089  Is here placed by their surviving SHIPMATES.
2090  
2091  SACRED TO THE MEMORY OF The late CAPTAIN EZEKIEL HARDY, Who in the bows
2092  of his boat was killed by a Sperm Whale on the coast of Japan, _August_
2093  3_d_, 1833. THIS TABLET Is erected to his Memory BY HIS WIDOW.
2094  
2095  Shaking off the sleet from my ice-glazed hat and jacket, I seated
2096  myself near the door, and turning sideways was surprised to see
2097  Queequeg near me. Affected by the solemnity of the scene, there was a
2098  wondering gaze of incredulous curiosity in his countenance. This savage
2099  was the only person present who seemed to notice my entrance; because
2100  he was the only one who could not read, and, therefore, was not reading
2101  those frigid inscriptions on the wall. Whether any of the relatives of
2102  the seamen whose names appeared there were now among the congregation,
2103  I knew not; but so many are the unrecorded accidents in the fishery,
2104  and so plainly did several women present wear the countenance if not
2105  the trappings of some unceasing grief, that I feel sure that here
2106  before me were assembled those, in whose unhealing hearts the sight of
2107  those bleak tablets sympathetically caused the old wounds to bleed
2108  afresh.
2109  
2110  Oh! ye whose dead lie buried beneath the green grass; who standing
2111  among flowers can say—here, _here_ lies my beloved; ye know not the
2112  desolation that broods in bosoms like these. What bitter blanks in
2113  those black-bordered marbles which cover no ashes! What despair in
2114  those immovable inscriptions! What deadly voids and unbidden
2115  infidelities in the lines that seem to gnaw upon all Faith, and refuse
2116  resurrections to the beings who have placelessly perished without a
2117  grave. As well might those tablets stand in the cave of Elephanta as
2118  here.
2119  
2120  In what census of living creatures, the dead of mankind are included;
2121  why it is that a universal proverb says of them, that they tell no
2122  tales, though containing more secrets than the Goodwin Sands; how it is
2123  that to his name who yesterday departed for the other world, we prefix
2124  so significant and infidel a word, and yet do not thus entitle him, if
2125  he but embarks for the remotest Indies of this living earth; why the
2126  Life Insurance Companies pay death-forfeitures upon immortals; in what
2127  eternal, unstirring paralysis, and deadly, hopeless trance, yet lies
2128  antique Adam who died sixty round centuries ago; how it is that we
2129  still refuse to be comforted for those who we nevertheless maintain are
2130  dwelling in unspeakable bliss; why all the living so strive to hush all
2131  the dead; wherefore but the rumor of a knocking in a tomb will terrify
2132  a whole city. All these things are not without their meanings.
2133  
2134  But Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these
2135  dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope.
2136  
2137  It needs scarcely to be told, with what feelings, on the eve of a
2138  Nantucket voyage, I regarded those marble tablets, and by the murky
2139  light of that darkened, doleful day read the fate of the whalemen who
2140  had gone before me. Yes, Ishmael, the same fate may be thine. But
2141  somehow I grew merry again. Delightful inducements to embark, fine
2142  chance for promotion, it seems—aye, a stove boat will make me an
2143  immortal by brevet. Yes, there is death in this business of whaling—a
2144  speechlessly quick chaotic bundling of a man into Eternity. But what
2145  then? Methinks we have hugely mistaken this matter of Life and Death.
2146  Methinks that what they call my shadow here on earth is my true
2147  substance. Methinks that in looking at things spiritual, we are too
2148  much like oysters observing the sun through the water, and thinking
2149  that thick water the thinnest of air. Methinks my body is but the lees
2150  of my better being. In fact take my body who will, take it I say, it is
2151  not me. And therefore three cheers for Nantucket; and come a stove boat
2152  and stove body when they will, for stave my soul, Jove himself cannot.
2153  
2154  
2155  CHAPTER 8. The Pulpit.
2156  
2157  I had not been seated very long ere a man of a certain venerable
2158  robustness entered; immediately as the storm-pelted door flew back upon
2159  admitting him, a quick regardful eyeing of him by all the congregation,
2160  sufficiently attested that this fine old man was the chaplain. Yes, it
2161  was the famous Father Mapple, so called by the whalemen, among whom he
2162  was a very great favourite. He had been a sailor and a harpooneer in
2163  his youth, but for many years past had dedicated his life to the
2164  ministry. At the time I now write of, Father Mapple was in the hardy
2165  winter of a healthy old age; that sort of old age which seems merging
2166  into a second flowering youth, for among all the fissures of his
2167  wrinkles, there shone certain mild gleams of a newly developing
2168  bloom—the spring verdure peeping forth even beneath February’s snow. No
2169  one having previously heard his history, could for the first time
2170  behold Father Mapple without the utmost interest, because there were
2171  certain engrafted clerical peculiarities about him, imputable to that
2172  adventurous maritime life he had led. When he entered I observed that
2173  he carried no umbrella, and certainly had not come in his carriage, for
2174  his tarpaulin hat ran down with melting sleet, and his great pilot
2175  cloth jacket seemed almost to drag him to the floor with the weight of
2176  the water it had absorbed. However, hat and coat and overshoes were one
2177  by one removed, and hung up in a little space in an adjacent corner;
2178  when, arrayed in a decent suit, he quietly approached the pulpit.
2179  
2180  Like most old fashioned pulpits, it was a very lofty one, and since a
2181  regular stairs to such a height would, by its long angle with the
2182  floor, seriously contract the already small area of the chapel, the
2183  architect, it seemed, had acted upon the hint of Father Mapple, and
2184  finished the pulpit without a stairs, substituting a perpendicular side
2185  ladder, like those used in mounting a ship from a boat at sea. The wife
2186  of a whaling captain had provided the chapel with a handsome pair of
2187  red worsted man-ropes for this ladder, which, being itself nicely
2188  headed, and stained with a mahogany colour, the whole contrivance,
2189  considering what manner of chapel it was, seemed by no means in bad
2190  taste. Halting for an instant at the foot of the ladder, and with both
2191  hands grasping the ornamental knobs of the man-ropes, Father Mapple
2192  cast a look upwards, and then with a truly sailor-like but still
2193  reverential dexterity, hand over hand, mounted the steps as if
2194  ascending the main-top of his vessel.
2195  
2196  The perpendicular parts of this side ladder, as is usually the case
2197  with swinging ones, were of cloth-covered rope, only the rounds were of
2198  wood, so that at every step there was a joint. At my first glimpse of
2199  the pulpit, it had not escaped me that however convenient for a ship,
2200  these joints in the present instance seemed unnecessary. For I was not
2201  prepared to see Father Mapple after gaining the height, slowly turn
2202  round, and stooping over the pulpit, deliberately drag up the ladder
2203  step by step, till the whole was deposited within, leaving him
2204  impregnable in his little Quebec.
2205  
2206  I pondered some time without fully comprehending the reason for this.
2207  Father Mapple enjoyed such a wide reputation for sincerity and
2208  sanctity, that I could not suspect him of courting notoriety by any
2209  mere tricks of the stage. No, thought I, there must be some sober
2210  reason for this thing; furthermore, it must symbolize something unseen.
2211  Can it be, then, that by that act of physical isolation, he signifies
2212  his spiritual withdrawal for the time, from all outward worldly ties
2213  and connexions? Yes, for replenished with the meat and wine of the
2214  word, to the faithful man of God, this pulpit, I see, is a
2215  self-containing stronghold—a lofty Ehrenbreitstein, with a perennial
2216  well of water within the walls.
2217  
2218  But the side ladder was not the only strange feature of the place,
2219  borrowed from the chaplain’s former sea-farings. Between the marble
2220  cenotaphs on either hand of the pulpit, the wall which formed its back
2221  was adorned with a large painting representing a gallant ship beating
2222  against a terrible storm off a lee coast of black rocks and snowy
2223  breakers. But high above the flying scud and dark-rolling clouds, there
2224  floated a little isle of sunlight, from which beamed forth an angel’s
2225  face; and this bright face shed a distinct spot of radiance upon the
2226  ship’s tossed deck, something like that silver plate now inserted into
2227  the Victory’s plank where Nelson fell. “Ah, noble ship,” the angel
2228  seemed to say, “beat on, beat on, thou noble ship, and bear a hardy
2229  helm; for lo! the sun is breaking through; the clouds are rolling
2230  off—serenest azure is at hand.”
2231  
2232  Nor was the pulpit itself without a trace of the same sea-taste that
2233  had achieved the ladder and the picture. Its panelled front was in the
2234  likeness of a ship’s bluff bows, and the Holy Bible rested on a
2235  projecting piece of scroll work, fashioned after a ship’s fiddle-headed
2236  beak.
2237  
2238  What could be more full of meaning?—for the pulpit is ever this earth’s
2239  foremost part; all the rest comes in its rear; the pulpit leads the
2240  world. From thence it is the storm of God’s quick wrath is first
2241  descried, and the bow must bear the earliest brunt. From thence it is
2242  the God of breezes fair or foul is first invoked for favourable winds.
2243  Yes, the world’s a ship on its passage out, and not a voyage complete;
2244  and the pulpit is its prow.
2245  
2246  
2247  CHAPTER 9. The Sermon.
2248  
2249  Father Mapple rose, and in a mild voice of unassuming authority ordered
2250  the scattered people to condense. “Starboard gangway, there! side away
2251  to larboard—larboard gangway to starboard! Midships! midships!”
2252  
2253  There was a low rumbling of heavy sea-boots among the benches, and a
2254  still slighter shuffling of women’s shoes, and all was quiet again, and
2255  every eye on the preacher.
2256  
2257  He paused a little; then kneeling in the pulpit’s bows, folded his
2258  large brown hands across his chest, uplifted his closed eyes, and
2259  offered a prayer so deeply devout that he seemed kneeling and praying
2260  at the bottom of the sea.
2261  
2262  This ended, in prolonged solemn tones, like the continual tolling of a
2263  bell in a ship that is foundering at sea in a fog—in such tones he
2264  commenced reading the following hymn; but changing his manner towards
2265  the concluding stanzas, burst forth with a pealing exultation and joy—
2266  
2267  
2268    “The ribs and terrors in the whale, Arched over me a dismal gloom,
2269    While all God’s sun-lit waves rolled by, And lift me deepening down
2270    to doom.
2271  
2272    “I saw the opening maw of hell, With endless pains and sorrows there;
2273    Which none but they that feel can tell— Oh, I was plunging to
2274    despair.
2275  
2276    “In black distress, I called my God, When I could scarce believe him
2277    mine, He bowed his ear to my complaints— No more the whale did me
2278    confine.
2279  
2280    “With speed he flew to my relief, As on a radiant dolphin borne;
2281    Awful, yet bright, as lightning shone The face of my Deliverer God.
2282  
2283    “My song for ever shall record That terrible, that joyful hour; I
2284    give the glory to my God, His all the mercy and the power.”
2285  
2286  
2287  
2288  
2289  Nearly all joined in singing this hymn, which swelled high above the
2290  howling of the storm. A brief pause ensued; the preacher slowly turned
2291  over the leaves of the Bible, and at last, folding his hand down upon
2292  the proper page, said: “Beloved shipmates, clinch the last verse of the
2293  first chapter of Jonah—‘And God had prepared a great fish to swallow up
2294  Jonah.’”
2295  
2296  “Shipmates, this book, containing only four chapters—four yarns—is one
2297  of the smallest strands in the mighty cable of the Scriptures. Yet what
2298  depths of the soul does Jonah’s deep sealine sound! what a pregnant
2299  lesson to us is this prophet! What a noble thing is that canticle in
2300  the fish’s belly! How billow-like and boisterously grand! We feel the
2301  floods surging over us; we sound with him to the kelpy bottom of the
2302  waters; sea-weed and all the slime of the sea is about us! But _what_
2303  is this lesson that the book of Jonah teaches? Shipmates, it is a
2304  two-stranded lesson; a lesson to us all as sinful men, and a lesson to
2305  me as a pilot of the living God. As sinful men, it is a lesson to us
2306  all, because it is a story of the sin, hard-heartedness, suddenly
2307  awakened fears, the swift punishment, repentance, prayers, and finally
2308  the deliverance and joy of Jonah. As with all sinners among men, the
2309  sin of this son of Amittai was in his wilful disobedience of the
2310  command of God—never mind now what that command was, or how
2311  conveyed—which he found a hard command. But all the things that God
2312  would have us do are hard for us to do—remember that—and hence, he
2313  oftener commands us than endeavors to persuade. And if we obey God, we
2314  must disobey ourselves; and it is in this disobeying ourselves, wherein
2315  the hardness of obeying God consists.
2316  
2317  “With this sin of disobedience in him, Jonah still further flouts at
2318  God, by seeking to flee from Him. He thinks that a ship made by men
2319  will carry him into countries where God does not reign, but only the
2320  Captains of this earth. He skulks about the wharves of Joppa, and seeks
2321  a ship that’s bound for Tarshish. There lurks, perhaps, a hitherto
2322  unheeded meaning here. By all accounts Tarshish could have been no
2323  other city than the modern Cadiz. That’s the opinion of learned men.
2324  And where is Cadiz, shipmates? Cadiz is in Spain; as far by water, from
2325  Joppa, as Jonah could possibly have sailed in those ancient days, when
2326  the Atlantic was an almost unknown sea. Because Joppa, the modern
2327  Jaffa, shipmates, is on the most easterly coast of the Mediterranean,
2328  the Syrian; and Tarshish or Cadiz more than two thousand miles to the
2329  westward from that, just outside the Straits of Gibraltar. See ye not
2330  then, shipmates, that Jonah sought to flee world-wide from God?
2331  Miserable man! Oh! most contemptible and worthy of all scorn; with
2332  slouched hat and guilty eye, skulking from his God; prowling among the
2333  shipping like a vile burglar hastening to cross the seas. So
2334  disordered, self-condemning is his look, that had there been policemen
2335  in those days, Jonah, on the mere suspicion of something wrong, had
2336  been arrested ere he touched a deck. How plainly he’s a fugitive! no
2337  baggage, not a hat-box, valise, or carpet-bag,—no friends accompany him
2338  to the wharf with their adieux. At last, after much dodging search, he
2339  finds the Tarshish ship receiving the last items of her cargo; and as
2340  he steps on board to see its Captain in the cabin, all the sailors for
2341  the moment desist from hoisting in the goods, to mark the stranger’s
2342  evil eye. Jonah sees this; but in vain he tries to look all ease and
2343  confidence; in vain essays his wretched smile. Strong intuitions of the
2344  man assure the mariners he can be no innocent. In their gamesome but
2345  still serious way, one whispers to the other—“Jack, he’s robbed a
2346  widow;” or, “Joe, do you mark him; he’s a bigamist;” or, “Harry lad, I
2347  guess he’s the adulterer that broke jail in old Gomorrah, or belike,
2348  one of the missing murderers from Sodom.” Another runs to read the bill
2349  that’s stuck against the spile upon the wharf to which the ship is
2350  moored, offering five hundred gold coins for the apprehension of a
2351  parricide, and containing a description of his person. He reads, and
2352  looks from Jonah to the bill; while all his sympathetic shipmates now
2353  crowd round Jonah, prepared to lay their hands upon him. Frighted Jonah
2354  trembles, and summoning all his boldness to his face, only looks so
2355  much the more a coward. He will not confess himself suspected; but that
2356  itself is strong suspicion. So he makes the best of it; and when the
2357  sailors find him not to be the man that is advertised, they let him
2358  pass, and he descends into the cabin.
2359  
2360  “‘Who’s there?’ cries the Captain at his busy desk, hurriedly making
2361  out his papers for the Customs—‘Who’s there?’ Oh! how that harmless
2362  question mangles Jonah! For the instant he almost turns to flee again.
2363  But he rallies. ‘I seek a passage in this ship to Tarshish; how soon
2364  sail ye, sir?’ Thus far the busy Captain had not looked up to Jonah,
2365  though the man now stands before him; but no sooner does he hear that
2366  hollow voice, than he darts a scrutinizing glance. ‘We sail with the
2367  next coming tide,’ at last he slowly answered, still intently eyeing
2368  him. ‘No sooner, sir?’—‘Soon enough for any honest man that goes a
2369  passenger.’ Ha! Jonah, that’s another stab. But he swiftly calls away
2370  the Captain from that scent. ‘I’ll sail with ye,’—he says,—‘the passage
2371  money how much is that?—I’ll pay now.’ For it is particularly written,
2372  shipmates, as if it were a thing not to be overlooked in this history,
2373  ‘that he paid the fare thereof’ ere the craft did sail. And taken with
2374  the context, this is full of meaning.
2375  
2376  “Now Jonah’s Captain, shipmates, was one whose discernment detects
2377  crime in any, but whose cupidity exposes it only in the penniless. In
2378  this world, shipmates, sin that pays its way can travel freely, and
2379  without a passport; whereas Virtue, if a pauper, is stopped at all
2380  frontiers. So Jonah’s Captain prepares to test the length of Jonah’s
2381  purse, ere he judge him openly. He charges him thrice the usual sum;
2382  and it’s assented to. Then the Captain knows that Jonah is a fugitive;
2383  but at the same time resolves to help a flight that paves its rear with
2384  gold. Yet when Jonah fairly takes out his purse, prudent suspicions
2385  still molest the Captain. He rings every coin to find a counterfeit.
2386  Not a forger, any way, he mutters; and Jonah is put down for his
2387  passage. ‘Point out my state-room, Sir,’ says Jonah now, ‘I’m
2388  travel-weary; I need sleep.’ ‘Thou lookest like it,’ says the Captain,
2389  ‘there’s thy room.’ Jonah enters, and would lock the door, but the lock
2390  contains no key. Hearing him foolishly fumbling there, the Captain
2391  laughs lowly to himself, and mutters something about the doors of
2392  convicts’ cells being never allowed to be locked within. All dressed
2393  and dusty as he is, Jonah throws himself into his berth, and finds the
2394  little state-room ceiling almost resting on his forehead. The air is
2395  close, and Jonah gasps. Then, in that contracted hole, sunk, too,
2396  beneath the ship’s water-line, Jonah feels the heralding presentiment
2397  of that stifling hour, when the whale shall hold him in the smallest of
2398  his bowels’ wards.
2399  
2400  “Screwed at its axis against the side, a swinging lamp slightly
2401  oscillates in Jonah’s room; and the ship, heeling over towards the
2402  wharf with the weight of the last bales received, the lamp, flame and
2403  all, though in slight motion, still maintains a permanent obliquity
2404  with reference to the room; though, in truth, infallibly straight
2405  itself, it but made obvious the false, lying levels among which it
2406  hung. The lamp alarms and frightens Jonah; as lying in his berth his
2407  tormented eyes roll round the place, and this thus far successful
2408  fugitive finds no refuge for his restless glance. But that
2409  contradiction in the lamp more and more appals him. The floor, the
2410  ceiling, and the side, are all awry. ‘Oh! so my conscience hangs in
2411  me!’ he groans, ‘straight upwards, so it burns; but the chambers of my
2412  soul are all in crookedness!’
2413  
2414  “Like one who after a night of drunken revelry hies to his bed, still
2415  reeling, but with conscience yet pricking him, as the plungings of the
2416  Roman race-horse but so much the more strike his steel tags into him;
2417  as one who in that miserable plight still turns and turns in giddy
2418  anguish, praying God for annihilation until the fit be passed; and at
2419  last amid the whirl of woe he feels, a deep stupor steals over him, as
2420  over the man who bleeds to death, for conscience is the wound, and
2421  there’s naught to staunch it; so, after sore wrestlings in his berth,
2422  Jonah’s prodigy of ponderous misery drags him drowning down to sleep.
2423  
2424  “And now the time of tide has come; the ship casts off her cables; and
2425  from the deserted wharf the uncheered ship for Tarshish, all careening,
2426  glides to sea. That ship, my friends, was the first of recorded
2427  smugglers! the contraband was Jonah. But the sea rebels; he will not
2428  bear the wicked burden. A dreadful storm comes on, the ship is like to
2429  break. But now when the boatswain calls all hands to lighten her; when
2430  boxes, bales, and jars are clattering overboard; when the wind is
2431  shrieking, and the men are yelling, and every plank thunders with
2432  trampling feet right over Jonah’s head; in all this raging tumult,
2433  Jonah sleeps his hideous sleep. He sees no black sky and raging sea,
2434  feels not the reeling timbers, and little hears he or heeds he the far
2435  rush of the mighty whale, which even now with open mouth is cleaving
2436  the seas after him. Aye, shipmates, Jonah was gone down into the sides
2437  of the ship—a berth in the cabin as I have taken it, and was fast
2438  asleep. But the frightened master comes to him, and shrieks in his dead
2439  ear, ‘What meanest thou, O, sleeper! arise!’ Startled from his lethargy
2440  by that direful cry, Jonah staggers to his feet, and stumbling to the
2441  deck, grasps a shroud, to look out upon the sea. But at that moment he
2442  is sprung upon by a panther billow leaping over the bulwarks. Wave
2443  after wave thus leaps into the ship, and finding no speedy vent runs
2444  roaring fore and aft, till the mariners come nigh to drowning while yet
2445  afloat. And ever, as the white moon shows her affrighted face from the
2446  steep gullies in the blackness overhead, aghast Jonah sees the rearing
2447  bowsprit pointing high upward, but soon beat downward again towards the
2448  tormented deep.
2449  
2450  “Terrors upon terrors run shouting through his soul. In all his
2451  cringing attitudes, the God-fugitive is now too plainly known. The
2452  sailors mark him; more and more certain grow their suspicions of him,
2453  and at last, fully to test the truth, by referring the whole matter to
2454  high Heaven, they fall to casting lots, to see for whose cause this
2455  great tempest was upon them. The lot is Jonah’s; that discovered, then
2456  how furiously they mob him with their questions. ‘What is thine
2457  occupation? Whence comest thou? Thy country? What people? But mark now,
2458  my shipmates, the behavior of poor Jonah. The eager mariners but ask
2459  him who he is, and where from; whereas, they not only receive an answer
2460  to those questions, but likewise another answer to a question not put
2461  by them, but the unsolicited answer is forced from Jonah by the hard
2462  hand of God that is upon him.
2463  
2464  “‘I am a Hebrew,’ he cries—and then—‘I fear the Lord the God of Heaven
2465  who hath made the sea and the dry land!’ Fear him, O Jonah? Aye, well
2466  mightest thou fear the Lord God _then!_ Straightway, he now goes on to
2467  make a full confession; whereupon the mariners became more and more
2468  appalled, but still are pitiful. For when Jonah, not yet supplicating
2469  God for mercy, since he but too well knew the darkness of his
2470  deserts,—when wretched Jonah cries out to them to take him and cast him
2471  forth into the sea, for he knew that for _his_ sake this great tempest
2472  was upon them; they mercifully turn from him, and seek by other means
2473  to save the ship. But all in vain; the indignant gale howls louder;
2474  then, with one hand raised invokingly to God, with the other they not
2475  unreluctantly lay hold of Jonah.
2476  
2477  “And now behold Jonah taken up as an anchor and dropped into the sea;
2478  when instantly an oily calmness floats out from the east, and the sea
2479  is still, as Jonah carries down the gale with him, leaving smooth water
2480  behind. He goes down in the whirling heart of such a masterless
2481  commotion that he scarce heeds the moment when he drops seething into
2482  the yawning jaws awaiting him; and the whale shoots-to all his ivory
2483  teeth, like so many white bolts, upon his prison. Then Jonah prayed
2484  unto the Lord out of the fish’s belly. But observe his prayer, and
2485  learn a weighty lesson. For sinful as he is, Jonah does not weep and
2486  wail for direct deliverance. He feels that his dreadful punishment is
2487  just. He leaves all his deliverance to God, contenting himself with
2488  this, that spite of all his pains and pangs, he will still look towards
2489  His holy temple. And here, shipmates, is true and faithful repentance;
2490  not clamorous for pardon, but grateful for punishment. And how pleasing
2491  to God was this conduct in Jonah, is shown in the eventual deliverance
2492  of him from the sea and the whale. Shipmates, I do not place Jonah
2493  before you to be copied for his sin but I do place him before you as a
2494  model for repentance. Sin not; but if you do, take heed to repent of it
2495  like Jonah.”
2496  
2497  While he was speaking these words, the howling of the shrieking,
2498  slanting storm without seemed to add new power to the preacher, who,
2499  when describing Jonah’s sea-storm, seemed tossed by a storm himself.
2500  His deep chest heaved as with a ground-swell; his tossed arms seemed
2501  the warring elements at work; and the thunders that rolled away from
2502  off his swarthy brow, and the light leaping from his eye, made all his
2503  simple hearers look on him with a quick fear that was strange to them.
2504  
2505  There now came a lull in his look, as he silently turned over the
2506  leaves of the Book once more; and, at last, standing motionless, with
2507  closed eyes, for the moment, seemed communing with God and himself.
2508  
2509  But again he leaned over towards the people, and bowing his head lowly,
2510  with an aspect of the deepest yet manliest humility, he spake these
2511  words:
2512  
2513  “Shipmates, God has laid but one hand upon you; both his hands press
2514  upon me. I have read ye by what murky light may be mine the lesson that
2515  Jonah teaches to all sinners; and therefore to ye, and still more to
2516  me, for I am a greater sinner than ye. And now how gladly would I come
2517  down from this mast-head and sit on the hatches there where you sit,
2518  and listen as you listen, while some one of you reads _me_ that other
2519  and more awful lesson which Jonah teaches to _me_, as a pilot of the
2520  living God. How being an anointed pilot-prophet, or speaker of true
2521  things, and bidden by the Lord to sound those unwelcome truths in the
2522  ears of a wicked Nineveh, Jonah, appalled at the hostility he should
2523  raise, fled from his mission, and sought to escape his duty and his God
2524  by taking ship at Joppa. But God is everywhere; Tarshish he never
2525  reached. As we have seen, God came upon him in the whale, and swallowed
2526  him down to living gulfs of doom, and with swift slantings tore him
2527  along ‘into the midst of the seas,’ where the eddying depths sucked him
2528  ten thousand fathoms down, and ‘the weeds were wrapped about his head,’
2529  and all the watery world of woe bowled over him. Yet even then beyond
2530  the reach of any plummet—‘out of the belly of hell’—when the whale
2531  grounded upon the ocean’s utmost bones, even then, God heard the
2532  engulphed, repenting prophet when he cried. Then God spake unto the
2533  fish; and from the shuddering cold and blackness of the sea, the whale
2534  came breeching up towards the warm and pleasant sun, and all the
2535  delights of air and earth; and ‘vomited out Jonah upon the dry land;’
2536  when the word of the Lord came a second time; and Jonah, bruised and
2537  beaten—his ears, like two sea-shells, still multitudinously murmuring
2538  of the ocean—Jonah did the Almighty’s bidding. And what was that,
2539  shipmates? To preach the Truth to the face of Falsehood! That was it!
2540  
2541  “This, shipmates, this is that other lesson; and woe to that pilot of
2542  the living God who slights it. Woe to him whom this world charms from
2543  Gospel duty! Woe to him who seeks to pour oil upon the waters when God
2544  has brewed them into a gale! Woe to him who seeks to please rather than
2545  to appal! Woe to him whose good name is more to him than goodness! Woe
2546  to him who, in this world, courts not dishonor! Woe to him who would
2547  not be true, even though to be false were salvation! Yea, woe to him
2548  who, as the great Pilot Paul has it, while preaching to others is
2549  himself a castaway!”
2550  
2551  He dropped and fell away from himself for a moment; then lifting his
2552  face to them again, showed a deep joy in his eyes, as he cried out with
2553  a heavenly enthusiasm,—“But oh! shipmates! on the starboard hand of
2554  every woe, there is a sure delight; and higher the top of that delight,
2555  than the bottom of the woe is deep. Is not the main-truck higher than
2556  the kelson is low? Delight is to him—a far, far upward, and inward
2557  delight—who against the proud gods and commodores of this earth, ever
2558  stands forth his own inexorable self. Delight is to him whose strong
2559  arms yet support him, when the ship of this base treacherous world has
2560  gone down beneath him. Delight is to him, who gives no quarter in the
2561  truth, and kills, burns, and destroys all sin though he pluck it out
2562  from under the robes of Senators and Judges. Delight,—top-gallant
2563  delight is to him, who acknowledges no law or lord, but the Lord his
2564  God, and is only a patriot to heaven. Delight is to him, whom all the
2565  waves of the billows of the seas of the boisterous mob can never shake
2566  from this sure Keel of the Ages. And eternal delight and deliciousness
2567  will be his, who coming to lay him down, can say with his final
2568  breath—O Father!—chiefly known to me by Thy rod—mortal or immortal,
2569  here I die. I have striven to be Thine, more than to be this world’s,
2570  or mine own. Yet this is nothing: I leave eternity to Thee; for what is
2571  man that he should live out the lifetime of his God?”
2572  
2573  He said no more, but slowly waving a benediction, covered his face with
2574  his hands, and so remained kneeling, till all the people had departed,
2575  and he was left alone in the place.
2576  
2577  
2578  CHAPTER 10. A Bosom Friend.
2579  
2580  Returning to the Spouter-Inn from the Chapel, I found Queequeg there
2581  quite alone; he having left the Chapel before the benediction some
2582  time. He was sitting on a bench before the fire, with his feet on the
2583  stove hearth, and in one hand was holding close up to his face that
2584  little negro idol of his; peering hard into its face, and with a
2585  jack-knife gently whittling away at its nose, meanwhile humming to
2586  himself in his heathenish way.
2587  
2588  But being now interrupted, he put up the image; and pretty soon, going
2589  to the table, took up a large book there, and placing it on his lap
2590  began counting the pages with deliberate regularity; at every fiftieth
2591  page—as I fancied—stopping a moment, looking vacantly around him, and
2592  giving utterance to a long-drawn gurgling whistle of astonishment. He
2593  would then begin again at the next fifty; seeming to commence at number
2594  one each time, as though he could not count more than fifty, and it was
2595  only by such a large number of fifties being found together, that his
2596  astonishment at the multitude of pages was excited.
2597  
2598  With much interest I sat watching him. Savage though he was, and
2599  hideously marred about the face—at least to my taste—his countenance
2600  yet had a something in it which was by no means disagreeable. You
2601  cannot hide the soul. Through all his unearthly tattooings, I thought I
2602  saw the traces of a simple honest heart; and in his large, deep eyes,
2603  fiery black and bold, there seemed tokens of a spirit that would dare a
2604  thousand devils. And besides all this, there was a certain lofty
2605  bearing about the Pagan, which even his uncouthness could not
2606  altogether maim. He looked like a man who had never cringed and never
2607  had had a creditor. Whether it was, too, that his head being shaved,
2608  his forehead was drawn out in freer and brighter relief, and looked
2609  more expansive than it otherwise would, this I will not venture to
2610  decide; but certain it was his head was phrenologically an excellent
2611  one. It may seem ridiculous, but it reminded me of General Washington’s
2612  head, as seen in the popular busts of him. It had the same long
2613  regularly graded retreating slope from above the brows, which were
2614  likewise very projecting, like two long promontories thickly wooded on
2615  top. Queequeg was George Washington cannibalistically developed.
2616  
2617  Whilst I was thus closely scanning him, half-pretending meanwhile to be
2618  looking out at the storm from the casement, he never heeded my
2619  presence, never troubled himself with so much as a single glance; but
2620  appeared wholly occupied with counting the pages of the marvellous
2621  book. Considering how sociably we had been sleeping together the night
2622  previous, and especially considering the affectionate arm I had found
2623  thrown over me upon waking in the morning, I thought this indifference
2624  of his very strange. But savages are strange beings; at times you do
2625  not know exactly how to take them. At first they are overawing; their
2626  calm self-collectedness of simplicity seems a Socratic wisdom. I had
2627  noticed also that Queequeg never consorted at all, or but very little,
2628  with the other seamen in the inn. He made no advances whatever;
2629  appeared to have no desire to enlarge the circle of his acquaintances.
2630  All this struck me as mighty singular; yet, upon second thoughts, there
2631  was something almost sublime in it. Here was a man some twenty thousand
2632  miles from home, by the way of Cape Horn, that is—which was the only
2633  way he could get there—thrown among people as strange to him as though
2634  he were in the planet Jupiter; and yet he seemed entirely at his ease;
2635  preserving the utmost serenity; content with his own companionship;
2636  always equal to himself. Surely this was a touch of fine philosophy;
2637  though no doubt he had never heard there was such a thing as that. But,
2638  perhaps, to be true philosophers, we mortals should not be conscious of
2639  so living or so striving. So soon as I hear that such or such a man
2640  gives himself out for a philosopher, I conclude that, like the
2641  dyspeptic old woman, he must have “broken his digester.”
2642  
2643  As I sat there in that now lonely room; the fire burning low, in that
2644  mild stage when, after its first intensity has warmed the air, it then
2645  only glows to be looked at; the evening shades and phantoms gathering
2646  round the casements, and peering in upon us silent, solitary twain; the
2647  storm booming without in solemn swells; I began to be sensible of
2648  strange feelings. I felt a melting in me. No more my splintered heart
2649  and maddened hand were turned against the wolfish world. This soothing
2650  savage had redeemed it. There he sat, his very indifference speaking a
2651  nature in which there lurked no civilized hypocrisies and bland
2652  deceits. Wild he was; a very sight of sights to see; yet I began to
2653  feel myself mysteriously drawn towards him. And those same things that
2654  would have repelled most others, they were the very magnets that thus
2655  drew me. I’ll try a pagan friend, thought I, since Christian kindness
2656  has proved but hollow courtesy. I drew my bench near him, and made some
2657  friendly signs and hints, doing my best to talk with him meanwhile. At
2658  first he little noticed these advances; but presently, upon my
2659  referring to his last night’s hospitalities, he made out to ask me
2660  whether we were again to be bedfellows. I told him yes; whereat I
2661  thought he looked pleased, perhaps a little complimented.
2662  
2663  We then turned over the book together, and I endeavored to explain to
2664  him the purpose of the printing, and the meaning of the few pictures
2665  that were in it. Thus I soon engaged his interest; and from that we
2666  went to jabbering the best we could about the various outer sights to
2667  be seen in this famous town. Soon I proposed a social smoke; and,
2668  producing his pouch and tomahawk, he quietly offered me a puff. And
2669  then we sat exchanging puffs from that wild pipe of his, and keeping it
2670  regularly passing between us.
2671  
2672  If there yet lurked any ice of indifference towards me in the Pagan’s
2673  breast, this pleasant, genial smoke we had, soon thawed it out, and
2674  left us cronies. He seemed to take to me quite as naturally and
2675  unbiddenly as I to him; and when our smoke was over, he pressed his
2676  forehead against mine, clasped me round the waist, and said that
2677  henceforth we were married; meaning, in his country’s phrase, that we
2678  were bosom friends; he would gladly die for me, if need should be. In a
2679  countryman, this sudden flame of friendship would have seemed far too
2680  premature, a thing to be much distrusted; but in this simple savage
2681  those old rules would not apply.
2682  
2683  After supper, and another social chat and smoke, we went to our room
2684  together. He made me a present of his embalmed head; took out his
2685  enormous tobacco wallet, and groping under the tobacco, drew out some
2686  thirty dollars in silver; then spreading them on the table, and
2687  mechanically dividing them into two equal portions, pushed one of them
2688  towards me, and said it was mine. I was going to remonstrate; but he
2689  silenced me by pouring them into my trowsers’ pockets. I let them stay.
2690  He then went about his evening prayers, took out his idol, and removed
2691  the paper fireboard. By certain signs and symptoms, I thought he seemed
2692  anxious for me to join him; but well knowing what was to follow, I
2693  deliberated a moment whether, in case he invited me, I would comply or
2694  otherwise.
2695  
2696  I was a good Christian; born and bred in the bosom of the infallible
2697  Presbyterian Church. How then could I unite with this wild idolator in
2698  worshipping his piece of wood? But what is worship? thought I. Do you
2699  suppose now, Ishmael, that the magnanimous God of heaven and
2700  earth—pagans and all included—can possibly be jealous of an
2701  insignificant bit of black wood? Impossible! But what is worship?—to do
2702  the will of God—_that_ is worship. And what is the will of God?—to do
2703  to my fellow man what I would have my fellow man to do to me—_that_ is
2704  the will of God. Now, Queequeg is my fellow man. And what do I wish
2705  that this Queequeg would do to me? Why, unite with me in my particular
2706  Presbyterian form of worship. Consequently, I must then unite with him
2707  in his; ergo, I must turn idolator. So I kindled the shavings; helped
2708  prop up the innocent little idol; offered him burnt biscuit with
2709  Queequeg; salamed before him twice or thrice; kissed his nose; and that
2710  done, we undressed and went to bed, at peace with our own consciences
2711  and all the world. But we did not go to sleep without some little chat.
2712  
2713  How it is I know not; but there is no place like a bed for confidential
2714  disclosures between friends. Man and wife, they say, there open the
2715  very bottom of their souls to each other; and some old couples often
2716  lie and chat over old times till nearly morning. Thus, then, in our
2717  hearts’ honeymoon, lay I and Queequeg—a cosy, loving pair.
2718  
2719  
2720  CHAPTER 11. Nightgown.
2721  
2722  We had lain thus in bed, chatting and napping at short intervals, and
2723  Queequeg now and then affectionately throwing his brown tattooed legs
2724  over mine, and then drawing them back; so entirely sociable and free
2725  and easy were we; when, at last, by reason of our confabulations, what
2726  little nappishness remained in us altogether departed, and we felt like
2727  getting up again, though day-break was yet some way down the future.
2728  
2729  Yes, we became very wakeful; so much so that our recumbent position
2730  began to grow wearisome, and by little and little we found ourselves
2731  sitting up; the clothes well tucked around us, leaning against the
2732  head-board with our four knees drawn up close together, and our two
2733  noses bending over them, as if our kneepans were warming-pans. We felt
2734  very nice and snug, the more so since it was so chilly out of doors;
2735  indeed out of bed-clothes too, seeing that there was no fire in the
2736  room. The more so, I say, because truly to enjoy bodily warmth, some
2737  small part of you must be cold, for there is no quality in this world
2738  that is not what it is merely by contrast. Nothing exists in itself. If
2739  you flatter yourself that you are all over comfortable, and have been
2740  so a long time, then you cannot be said to be comfortable any more. But
2741  if, like Queequeg and me in the bed, the tip of your nose or the crown
2742  of your head be slightly chilled, why then, indeed, in the general
2743  consciousness you feel most delightfully and unmistakably warm. For
2744  this reason a sleeping apartment should never be furnished with a fire,
2745  which is one of the luxurious discomforts of the rich. For the height
2746  of this sort of deliciousness is to have nothing but the blanket
2747  between you and your snugness and the cold of the outer air. Then there
2748  you lie like the one warm spark in the heart of an arctic crystal.
2749  
2750  We had been sitting in this crouching manner for some time, when all at
2751  once I thought I would open my eyes; for when between sheets, whether
2752  by day or by night, and whether asleep or awake, I have a way of always
2753  keeping my eyes shut, in order the more to concentrate the snugness of
2754  being in bed. Because no man can ever feel his own identity aright
2755  except his eyes be closed; as if darkness were indeed the proper
2756  element of our essences, though light be more congenial to our clayey
2757  part. Upon opening my eyes then, and coming out of my own pleasant and
2758  self-created darkness into the imposed and coarse outer gloom of the
2759  unilluminated twelve-o’clock-at-night, I experienced a disagreeable
2760  revulsion. Nor did I at all object to the hint from Queequeg that
2761  perhaps it were best to strike a light, seeing that we were so wide
2762  awake; and besides he felt a strong desire to have a few quiet puffs
2763  from his Tomahawk. Be it said, that though I had felt such a strong
2764  repugnance to his smoking in the bed the night before, yet see how
2765  elastic our stiff prejudices grow when love once comes to bend them.
2766  For now I liked nothing better than to have Queequeg smoking by me,
2767  even in bed, because he seemed to be full of such serene household joy
2768  then. I no more felt unduly concerned for the landlord’s policy of
2769  insurance. I was only alive to the condensed confidential
2770  comfortableness of sharing a pipe and a blanket with a real friend.
2771  With our shaggy jackets drawn about our shoulders, we now passed the
2772  Tomahawk from one to the other, till slowly there grew over us a blue
2773  hanging tester of smoke, illuminated by the flame of the new-lit lamp.
2774  
2775  Whether it was that this undulating tester rolled the savage away to
2776  far distant scenes, I know not, but he now spoke of his native island;
2777  and, eager to hear his history, I begged him to go on and tell it. He
2778  gladly complied. Though at the time I but ill comprehended not a few of
2779  his words, yet subsequent disclosures, when I had become more familiar
2780  with his broken phraseology, now enable me to present the whole story
2781  such as it may prove in the mere skeleton I give.
2782  
2783  
2784  CHAPTER 12. Biographical.
2785  
2786  Queequeg was a native of Rokovoko, an island far away to the West and
2787  South. It is not down in any map; true places never are.
2788  
2789  When a new-hatched savage running wild about his native woodlands in a
2790  grass clout, followed by the nibbling goats, as if he were a green
2791  sapling; even then, in Queequeg’s ambitious soul, lurked a strong
2792  desire to see something more of Christendom than a specimen whaler or
2793  two. His father was a High Chief, a King; his uncle a High Priest; and
2794  on the maternal side he boasted aunts who were the wives of
2795  unconquerable warriors. There was excellent blood in his veins—royal
2796  stuff; though sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal propensity he
2797  nourished in his untutored youth.
2798  
2799  A Sag Harbor ship visited his father’s bay, and Queequeg sought a
2800  passage to Christian lands. But the ship, having her full complement of
2801  seamen, spurned his suit; and not all the King his father’s influence
2802  could prevail. But Queequeg vowed a vow. Alone in his canoe, he paddled
2803  off to a distant strait, which he knew the ship must pass through when
2804  she quitted the island. On one side was a coral reef; on the other a
2805  low tongue of land, covered with mangrove thickets that grew out into
2806  the water. Hiding his canoe, still afloat, among these thickets, with
2807  its prow seaward, he sat down in the stern, paddle low in hand; and
2808  when the ship was gliding by, like a flash he darted out; gained her
2809  side; with one backward dash of his foot capsized and sank his canoe;
2810  climbed up the chains; and throwing himself at full length upon the
2811  deck, grappled a ring-bolt there, and swore not to let it go, though
2812  hacked in pieces.
2813  
2814  In vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a
2815  cutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King, and
2816  Queequeg budged not. Struck by his desperate dauntlessness, and his
2817  wild desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented, and
2818  told him he might make himself at home. But this fine young savage—this
2819  sea Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain’s cabin. They put him down
2820  among the sailors, and made a whaleman of him. But like Czar Peter
2821  content to toil in the shipyards of foreign cities, Queequeg disdained
2822  no seeming ignominy, if thereby he might happily gain the power of
2823  enlightening his untutored countrymen. For at bottom—so he told me—he
2824  was actuated by a profound desire to learn among the Christians, the
2825  arts whereby to make his people still happier than they were; and more
2826  than that, still better than they were. But, alas! the practices of
2827  whalemen soon convinced him that even Christians could be both
2828  miserable and wicked; infinitely more so, than all his father’s
2829  heathens. Arrived at last in old Sag Harbor; and seeing what the
2830  sailors did there; and then going on to Nantucket, and seeing how they
2831  spent their wages in _that_ place also, poor Queequeg gave it up for
2832  lost. Thought he, it’s a wicked world in all meridians; I’ll die a
2833  pagan.
2834  
2835  And thus an old idolator at heart, he yet lived among these Christians,
2836  wore their clothes, and tried to talk their gibberish. Hence the queer
2837  ways about him, though now some time from home.
2838  
2839  By hints, I asked him whether he did not propose going back, and having
2840  a coronation; since he might now consider his father dead and gone, he
2841  being very old and feeble at the last accounts. He answered no, not
2842  yet; and added that he was fearful Christianity, or rather Christians,
2843  had unfitted him for ascending the pure and undefiled throne of thirty
2844  pagan Kings before him. But by and by, he said, he would return,—as
2845  soon as he felt himself baptized again. For the nonce, however, he
2846  proposed to sail about, and sow his wild oats in all four oceans. They
2847  had made a harpooneer of him, and that barbed iron was in lieu of a
2848  sceptre now.
2849  
2850  I asked him what might be his immediate purpose, touching his future
2851  movements. He answered, to go to sea again, in his old vocation. Upon
2852  this, I told him that whaling was my own design, and informed him of my
2853  intention to sail out of Nantucket, as being the most promising port
2854  for an adventurous whaleman to embark from. He at once resolved to
2855  accompany me to that island, ship aboard the same vessel, get into the
2856  same watch, the same boat, the same mess with me, in short to share my
2857  every hap; with both my hands in his, boldly dip into the Potluck of
2858  both worlds. To all this I joyously assented; for besides the affection
2859  I now felt for Queequeg, he was an experienced harpooneer, and as such,
2860  could not fail to be of great usefulness to one, who, like me, was
2861  wholly ignorant of the mysteries of whaling, though well acquainted
2862  with the sea, as known to merchant seamen.
2863  
2864  His story being ended with his pipe’s last dying puff, Queequeg
2865  embraced me, pressed his forehead against mine, and blowing out the
2866  light, we rolled over from each other, this way and that, and very soon
2867  were sleeping.
2868  
2869  
2870  CHAPTER 13. Wheelbarrow.
2871  
2872  Next morning, Monday, after disposing of the embalmed head to a barber,
2873  for a block, I settled my own and comrade’s bill; using, however, my
2874  comrade’s money. The grinning landlord, as well as the boarders, seemed
2875  amazingly tickled at the sudden friendship which had sprung up between
2876  me and Queequeg—especially as Peter Coffin’s cock and bull stories
2877  about him had previously so much alarmed me concerning the very person
2878  whom I now companied with.
2879  
2880  We borrowed a wheelbarrow, and embarking our things, including my own
2881  poor carpet-bag, and Queequeg’s canvas sack and hammock, away we went
2882  down to “the Moss,” the little Nantucket packet schooner moored at the
2883  wharf. As we were going along the people stared; not at Queequeg so
2884  much—for they were used to seeing cannibals like him in their
2885  streets,—but at seeing him and me upon such confidential terms. But we
2886  heeded them not, going along wheeling the barrow by turns, and Queequeg
2887  now and then stopping to adjust the sheath on his harpoon barbs. I
2888  asked him why he carried such a troublesome thing with him ashore, and
2889  whether all whaling ships did not find their own harpoons. To this, in
2890  substance, he replied, that though what I hinted was true enough, yet
2891  he had a particular affection for his own harpoon, because it was of
2892  assured stuff, well tried in many a mortal combat, and deeply intimate
2893  with the hearts of whales. In short, like many inland reapers and
2894  mowers, who go into the farmers’ meadows armed with their own
2895  scythes—though in no wise obliged to furnish them—even so, Queequeg,
2896  for his own private reasons, preferred his own harpoon.
2897  
2898  Shifting the barrow from my hand to his, he told me a funny story about
2899  the first wheelbarrow he had ever seen. It was in Sag Harbor. The
2900  owners of his ship, it seems, had lent him one, in which to carry his
2901  heavy chest to his boarding house. Not to seem ignorant about the
2902  thing—though in truth he was entirely so, concerning the precise way in
2903  which to manage the barrow—Queequeg puts his chest upon it; lashes it
2904  fast; and then shoulders the barrow and marches up the wharf. “Why,”
2905  said I, “Queequeg, you might have known better than that, one would
2906  think. Didn’t the people laugh?”
2907  
2908  Upon this, he told me another story. The people of his island of
2909  Rokovoko, it seems, at their wedding feasts express the fragrant water
2910  of young cocoanuts into a large stained calabash like a punchbowl; and
2911  this punchbowl always forms the great central ornament on the braided
2912  mat where the feast is held. Now a certain grand merchant ship once
2913  touched at Rokovoko, and its commander—from all accounts, a very
2914  stately punctilious gentleman, at least for a sea captain—this
2915  commander was invited to the wedding feast of Queequeg’s sister, a
2916  pretty young princess just turned of ten. Well; when all the wedding
2917  guests were assembled at the bride’s bamboo cottage, this Captain
2918  marches in, and being assigned the post of honor, placed himself over
2919  against the punchbowl, and between the High Priest and his majesty the
2920  King, Queequeg’s father. Grace being said,—for those people have their
2921  grace as well as we—though Queequeg told me that unlike us, who at such
2922  times look downwards to our platters, they, on the contrary, copying
2923  the ducks, glance upwards to the great Giver of all feasts—Grace, I
2924  say, being said, the High Priest opens the banquet by the immemorial
2925  ceremony of the island; that is, dipping his consecrated and
2926  consecrating fingers into the bowl before the blessed beverage
2927  circulates. Seeing himself placed next the Priest, and noting the
2928  ceremony, and thinking himself—being Captain of a ship—as having plain
2929  precedence over a mere island King, especially in the King’s own
2930  house—the Captain coolly proceeds to wash his hands in the
2931  punchbowl;—taking it I suppose for a huge finger-glass. “Now,” said
2932  Queequeg, “what you tink now?—Didn’t our people laugh?”
2933  
2934  At last, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the
2935  schooner. Hoisting sail, it glided down the Acushnet river. On one
2936  side, New Bedford rose in terraces of streets, their ice-covered trees
2937  all glittering in the clear, cold air. Huge hills and mountains of
2938  casks on casks were piled upon her wharves, and side by side the
2939  world-wandering whale ships lay silent and safely moored at last; while
2940  from others came a sound of carpenters and coopers, with blended noises
2941  of fires and forges to melt the pitch, all betokening that new cruises
2942  were on the start; that one most perilous and long voyage ended, only
2943  begins a second; and a second ended, only begins a third, and so on,
2944  for ever and for aye. Such is the endlessness, yea, the intolerableness
2945  of all earthly effort.
2946  
2947  Gaining the more open water, the bracing breeze waxed fresh; the little
2948  Moss tossed the quick foam from her bows, as a young colt his
2949  snortings. How I snuffed that Tartar air!—how I spurned that turnpike
2950  earth!—that common highway all over dented with the marks of slavish
2951  heels and hoofs; and turned me to admire the magnanimity of the sea
2952  which will permit no records.
2953  
2954  At the same foam-fountain, Queequeg seemed to drink and reel with me.
2955  His dusky nostrils swelled apart; he showed his filed and pointed
2956  teeth. On, on we flew; and our offing gained, the Moss did homage to
2957  the blast; ducked and dived her bows as a slave before the Sultan.
2958  Sideways leaning, we sideways darted; every ropeyarn tingling like a
2959  wire; the two tall masts buckling like Indian canes in land tornadoes.
2960  So full of this reeling scene were we, as we stood by the plunging
2961  bowsprit, that for some time we did not notice the jeering glances of
2962  the passengers, a lubber-like assembly, who marvelled that two fellow
2963  beings should be so companionable; as though a white man were anything
2964  more dignified than a whitewashed negro. But there were some boobies
2965  and bumpkins there, who, by their intense greenness, must have come
2966  from the heart and centre of all verdure. Queequeg caught one of these
2967  young saplings mimicking him behind his back. I thought the bumpkin’s
2968  hour of doom was come. Dropping his harpoon, the brawny savage caught
2969  him in his arms, and by an almost miraculous dexterity and strength,
2970  sent him high up bodily into the air; then slightly tapping his stern
2971  in mid-somerset, the fellow landed with bursting lungs upon his feet,
2972  while Queequeg, turning his back upon him, lighted his tomahawk pipe
2973  and passed it to me for a puff.
2974  
2975  “Capting! Capting!” yelled the bumpkin, running towards that officer;
2976  “Capting, Capting, here’s the devil.”
2977  
2978  “Hallo, _you_ sir,” cried the Captain, a gaunt rib of the sea, stalking
2979  up to Queequeg, “what in thunder do you mean by that? Don’t you know
2980  you might have killed that chap?”
2981  
2982  “What him say?” said Queequeg, as he mildly turned to me.
2983  
2984  “He say,” said I, “that you came near kill-e that man there,” pointing
2985  to the still shivering greenhorn.
2986  
2987  “Kill-e,” cried Queequeg, twisting his tattooed face into an unearthly
2988  expression of disdain, “ah! him bevy small-e fish-e; Queequeg no kill-e
2989  so small-e fish-e; Queequeg kill-e big whale!”
2990  
2991  “Look you,” roared the Captain, “I’ll kill-e _you_, you cannibal, if
2992  you try any more of your tricks aboard here; so mind your eye.”
2993  
2994  But it so happened just then, that it was high time for the Captain to
2995  mind his own eye. The prodigious strain upon the main-sail had parted
2996  the weather-sheet, and the tremendous boom was now flying from side to
2997  side, completely sweeping the entire after part of the deck. The poor
2998  fellow whom Queequeg had handled so roughly, was swept overboard; all
2999  hands were in a panic; and to attempt snatching at the boom to stay it,
3000  seemed madness. It flew from right to left, and back again, almost in
3001  one ticking of a watch, and every instant seemed on the point of
3002  snapping into splinters. Nothing was done, and nothing seemed capable
3003  of being done; those on deck rushed towards the bows, and stood eyeing
3004  the boom as if it were the lower jaw of an exasperated whale. In the
3005  midst of this consternation, Queequeg dropped deftly to his knees, and
3006  crawling under the path of the boom, whipped hold of a rope, secured
3007  one end to the bulwarks, and then flinging the other like a lasso,
3008  caught it round the boom as it swept over his head, and at the next
3009  jerk, the spar was that way trapped, and all was safe. The schooner was
3010  run into the wind, and while the hands were clearing away the stern
3011  boat, Queequeg, stripped to the waist, darted from the side with a long
3012  living arc of a leap. For three minutes or more he was seen swimming
3013  like a dog, throwing his long arms straight out before him, and by
3014  turns revealing his brawny shoulders through the freezing foam. I
3015  looked at the grand and glorious fellow, but saw no one to be saved.
3016  The greenhorn had gone down. Shooting himself perpendicularly from the
3017  water, Queequeg, now took an instant’s glance around him, and seeming
3018  to see just how matters were, dived down and disappeared. A few minutes
3019  more, and he rose again, one arm still striking out, and with the other
3020  dragging a lifeless form. The boat soon picked them up. The poor
3021  bumpkin was restored. All hands voted Queequeg a noble trump; the
3022  captain begged his pardon. From that hour I clove to Queequeg like a
3023  barnacle; yea, till poor Queequeg took his last long dive.
3024  
3025  Was there ever such unconsciousness? He did not seem to think that he
3026  at all deserved a medal from the Humane and Magnanimous Societies. He
3027  only asked for water—fresh water—something to wipe the brine off; that
3028  done, he put on dry clothes, lighted his pipe, and leaning against the
3029  bulwarks, and mildly eyeing those around him, seemed to be saying to
3030  himself—“It’s a mutual, joint-stock world, in all meridians. We
3031  cannibals must help these Christians.”
3032  
3033  
3034  CHAPTER 14. Nantucket.
3035  
3036  Nothing more happened on the passage worthy the mentioning; so, after a
3037  fine run, we safely arrived in Nantucket.
3038  
3039  Nantucket! Take out your map and look at it. See what a real corner of
3040  the world it occupies; how it stands there, away off shore, more lonely
3041  than the Eddystone lighthouse. Look at it—a mere hillock, and elbow of
3042  sand; all beach, without a background. There is more sand there than
3043  you would use in twenty years as a substitute for blotting paper. Some
3044  gamesome wights will tell you that they have to plant weeds there, they
3045  don’t grow naturally; that they import Canada thistles; that they have
3046  to send beyond seas for a spile to stop a leak in an oil cask; that
3047  pieces of wood in Nantucket are carried about like bits of the true
3048  cross in Rome; that people there plant toadstools before their houses,
3049  to get under the shade in summer time; that one blade of grass makes an
3050  oasis, three blades in a day’s walk a prairie; that they wear quicksand
