3051  shoes, something like Laplander snow-shoes; that they are so shut up,
3052  belted about, every way inclosed, surrounded, and made an utter island
3053  of by the ocean, that to their very chairs and tables small clams will
3054  sometimes be found adhering, as to the backs of sea turtles. But these
3055  extravaganzas only show that Nantucket is no Illinois.
3056  
3057  Look now at the wondrous traditional story of how this island was
3058  settled by the red-men. Thus goes the legend. In olden times an eagle
3059  swooped down upon the New England coast, and carried off an infant
3060  Indian in his talons. With loud lament the parents saw their child
3061  borne out of sight over the wide waters. They resolved to follow in the
3062  same direction. Setting out in their canoes, after a perilous passage
3063  they discovered the island, and there they found an empty ivory
3064  casket,—the poor little Indian’s skeleton.
3065  
3066  What wonder, then, that these Nantucketers, born on a beach, should
3067  take to the sea for a livelihood! They first caught crabs and quohogs
3068  in the sand; grown bolder, they waded out with nets for mackerel; more
3069  experienced, they pushed off in boats and captured cod; and at last,
3070  launching a navy of great ships on the sea, explored this watery world;
3071  put an incessant belt of circumnavigations round it; peeped in at
3072  Behring’s Straits; and in all seasons and all oceans declared
3073  everlasting war with the mightiest animated mass that has survived the
3074  flood; most monstrous and most mountainous! That Himmalehan, salt-sea
3075  Mastodon, clothed with such portentousness of unconscious power, that
3076  his very panics are more to be dreaded than his most fearless and
3077  malicious assaults!
3078  
3079  And thus have these naked Nantucketers, these sea hermits, issuing from
3080  their ant-hill in the sea, overrun and conquered the watery world like
3081  so many Alexanders; parcelling out among them the Atlantic, Pacific,
3082  and Indian oceans, as the three pirate powers did Poland. Let America
3083  add Mexico to Texas, and pile Cuba upon Canada; let the English
3084  overswarm all India, and hang out their blazing banner from the sun;
3085  two thirds of this terraqueous globe are the Nantucketer’s. For the sea
3086  is his; he owns it, as Emperors own empires; other seamen having but a
3087  right of way through it. Merchant ships are but extension bridges;
3088  armed ones but floating forts; even pirates and privateers, though
3089  following the sea as highwaymen the road, they but plunder other ships,
3090  other fragments of the land like themselves, without seeking to draw
3091  their living from the bottomless deep itself. The Nantucketer, he alone
3092  resides and riots on the sea; he alone, in Bible language, goes down to
3093  it in ships; to and fro ploughing it as his own special plantation.
3094  _There_ is his home; _there_ lies his business, which a Noah’s flood
3095  would not interrupt, though it overwhelmed all the millions in China.
3096  He lives on the sea, as prairie cocks in the prairie; he hides among
3097  the waves, he climbs them as chamois hunters climb the Alps. For years
3098  he knows not the land; so that when he comes to it at last, it smells
3099  like another world, more strangely than the moon would to an Earthsman.
3100  With the landless gull, that at sunset folds her wings and is rocked to
3101  sleep between billows; so at nightfall, the Nantucketer, out of sight
3102  of land, furls his sails, and lays him to his rest, while under his
3103  very pillow rush herds of walruses and whales.
3104  
3105  
3106  CHAPTER 15. Chowder.
3107  
3108  It was quite late in the evening when the little Moss came snugly to
3109  anchor, and Queequeg and I went ashore; so we could attend to no
3110  business that day, at least none but a supper and a bed. The landlord
3111  of the Spouter-Inn had recommended us to his cousin Hosea Hussey of the
3112  Try Pots, whom he asserted to be the proprietor of one of the best kept
3113  hotels in all Nantucket, and moreover he had assured us that Cousin
3114  Hosea, as he called him, was famous for his chowders. In short, he
3115  plainly hinted that we could not possibly do better than try pot-luck
3116  at the Try Pots. But the directions he had given us about keeping a
3117  yellow warehouse on our starboard hand till we opened a white church to
3118  the larboard, and then keeping that on the larboard hand till we made a
3119  corner three points to the starboard, and that done, then ask the first
3120  man we met where the place was: these crooked directions of his very
3121  much puzzled us at first, especially as, at the outset, Queequeg
3122  insisted that the yellow warehouse—our first point of departure—must be
3123  left on the larboard hand, whereas I had understood Peter Coffin to say
3124  it was on the starboard. However, by dint of beating about a little in
3125  the dark, and now and then knocking up a peaceable inhabitant to
3126  inquire the way, we at last came to something which there was no
3127  mistaking.
3128  
3129  Two enormous wooden pots painted black, and suspended by asses’ ears,
3130  swung from the cross-trees of an old top-mast, planted in front of an
3131  old doorway. The horns of the cross-trees were sawed off on the other
3132  side, so that this old top-mast looked not a little like a gallows.
3133  Perhaps I was over sensitive to such impressions at the time, but I
3134  could not help staring at this gallows with a vague misgiving. A sort
3135  of crick was in my neck as I gazed up to the two remaining horns; yes,
3136  _two_ of them, one for Queequeg, and one for me. It’s ominous, thinks
3137  I. A Coffin my Innkeeper upon landing in my first whaling port;
3138  tombstones staring at me in the whalemen’s chapel; and here a gallows!
3139  and a pair of prodigious black pots too! Are these last throwing out
3140  oblique hints touching Tophet?
3141  
3142  I was called from these reflections by the sight of a freckled woman
3143  with yellow hair and a yellow gown, standing in the porch of the inn,
3144  under a dull red lamp swinging there, that looked much like an injured
3145  eye, and carrying on a brisk scolding with a man in a purple woollen
3146  shirt.
3147  
3148  “Get along with ye,” said she to the man, “or I’ll be combing ye!”
3149  
3150  “Come on, Queequeg,” said I, “all right. There’s Mrs. Hussey.”
3151  
3152  And so it turned out; Mr. Hosea Hussey being from home, but leaving
3153  Mrs. Hussey entirely competent to attend to all his affairs. Upon
3154  making known our desires for a supper and a bed, Mrs. Hussey,
3155  postponing further scolding for the present, ushered us into a little
3156  room, and seating us at a table spread with the relics of a recently
3157  concluded repast, turned round to us and said—“Clam or Cod?”
3158  
3159  “What’s that about Cods, ma’am?” said I, with much politeness.
3160  
3161  “Clam or Cod?” she repeated.
3162  
3163  “A clam for supper? a cold clam; is _that_ what you mean, Mrs. Hussey?”
3164  says I, “but that’s a rather cold and clammy reception in the winter
3165  time, ain’t it, Mrs. Hussey?”
3166  
3167  But being in a great hurry to resume scolding the man in the purple
3168  Shirt, who was waiting for it in the entry, and seeming to hear nothing
3169  but the word “clam,” Mrs. Hussey hurried towards an open door leading
3170  to the kitchen, and bawling out “clam for two,” disappeared.
3171  
3172  “Queequeg,” said I, “do you think that we can make out a supper for us
3173  both on one clam?”
3174  
3175  However, a warm savory steam from the kitchen served to belie the
3176  apparently cheerless prospect before us. But when that smoking chowder
3177  came in, the mystery was delightfully explained. Oh, sweet friends!
3178  hearken to me. It was made of small juicy clams, scarcely bigger than
3179  hazel nuts, mixed with pounded ship biscuit, and salted pork cut up
3180  into little flakes; the whole enriched with butter, and plentifully
3181  seasoned with pepper and salt. Our appetites being sharpened by the
3182  frosty voyage, and in particular, Queequeg seeing his favourite fishing
3183  food before him, and the chowder being surpassingly excellent, we
3184  despatched it with great expedition: when leaning back a moment and
3185  bethinking me of Mrs. Hussey’s clam and cod announcement, I thought I
3186  would try a little experiment. Stepping to the kitchen door, I uttered
3187  the word “cod” with great emphasis, and resumed my seat. In a few
3188  moments the savoury steam came forth again, but with a different
3189  flavor, and in good time a fine cod-chowder was placed before us.
3190  
3191  We resumed business; and while plying our spoons in the bowl, thinks I
3192  to myself, I wonder now if this here has any effect on the head? What’s
3193  that stultifying saying about chowder-headed people? “But look,
3194  Queequeg, ain’t that a live eel in your bowl? Where’s your harpoon?”
3195  
3196  Fishiest of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserved its
3197  name; for the pots there were always boiling chowders. Chowder for
3198  breakfast, and chowder for dinner, and chowder for supper, till you
3199  began to look for fish-bones coming through your clothes. The area
3200  before the house was paved with clam-shells. Mrs. Hussey wore a
3201  polished necklace of codfish vertebra; and Hosea Hussey had his account
3202  books bound in superior old shark-skin. There was a fishy flavor to the
3203  milk, too, which I could not at all account for, till one morning
3204  happening to take a stroll along the beach among some fishermen’s
3205  boats, I saw Hosea’s brindled cow feeding on fish remnants, and
3206  marching along the sand with each foot in a cod’s decapitated head,
3207  looking very slip-shod, I assure ye.
3208  
3209  Supper concluded, we received a lamp, and directions from Mrs. Hussey
3210  concerning the nearest way to bed; but, as Queequeg was about to
3211  precede me up the stairs, the lady reached forth her arm, and demanded
3212  his harpoon; she allowed no harpoon in her chambers. “Why not?” said I;
3213  “every true whaleman sleeps with his harpoon—but why not?” “Because
3214  it’s dangerous,” says she. “Ever since young Stiggs coming from that
3215  unfort’nt v’y’ge of his, when he was gone four years and a half, with
3216  only three barrels of _ile_, was found dead in my first floor back,
3217  with his harpoon in his side; ever since then I allow no boarders to
3218  take sich dangerous weepons in their rooms at night. So, Mr. Queequeg”
3219  (for she had learned his name), “I will just take this here iron, and
3220  keep it for you till morning. But the chowder; clam or cod to-morrow
3221  for breakfast, men?”
3222  
3223  “Both,” says I; “and let’s have a couple of smoked herring by way of
3224  variety.”
3225  
3226  
3227  CHAPTER 16. The Ship.
3228  
3229  In bed we concocted our plans for the morrow. But to my surprise and no
3230  small concern, Queequeg now gave me to understand, that he had been
3231  diligently consulting Yojo—the name of his black little god—and Yojo
3232  had told him two or three times over, and strongly insisted upon it
3233  everyway, that instead of our going together among the whaling-fleet in
3234  harbor, and in concert selecting our craft; instead of this, I say,
3235  Yojo earnestly enjoined that the selection of the ship should rest
3236  wholly with me, inasmuch as Yojo purposed befriending us; and, in order
3237  to do so, had already pitched upon a vessel, which, if left to myself,
3238  I, Ishmael, should infallibly light upon, for all the world as though
3239  it had turned out by chance; and in that vessel I must immediately ship
3240  myself, for the present irrespective of Queequeg.
3241  
3242  I have forgotten to mention that, in many things, Queequeg placed great
3243  confidence in the excellence of Yojo’s judgment and surprising forecast
3244  of things; and cherished Yojo with considerable esteem, as a rather
3245  good sort of god, who perhaps meant well enough upon the whole, but in
3246  all cases did not succeed in his benevolent designs.
3247  
3248  Now, this plan of Queequeg’s, or rather Yojo’s, touching the selection
3249  of our craft; I did not like that plan at all. I had not a little
3250  relied upon Queequeg’s sagacity to point out the whaler best fitted to
3251  carry us and our fortunes securely. But as all my remonstrances
3252  produced no effect upon Queequeg, I was obliged to acquiesce; and
3253  accordingly prepared to set about this business with a determined
3254  rushing sort of energy and vigor, that should quickly settle that
3255  trifling little affair. Next morning early, leaving Queequeg shut up
3256  with Yojo in our little bedroom—for it seemed that it was some sort of
3257  Lent or Ramadan, or day of fasting, humiliation, and prayer with
3258  Queequeg and Yojo that day; _how_ it was I never could find out, for,
3259  though I applied myself to it several times, I never could master his
3260  liturgies and XXXIX Articles—leaving Queequeg, then, fasting on his
3261  tomahawk pipe, and Yojo warming himself at his sacrificial fire of
3262  shavings, I sallied out among the shipping. After much prolonged
3263  sauntering and many random inquiries, I learnt that there were three
3264  ships up for three-years’ voyages—The Devil-dam, the Tit-bit, and the
3265  Pequod. _Devil-Dam_, I do not know the origin of; _Tit-bit_ is obvious;
3266  _Pequod_, you will no doubt remember, was the name of a celebrated
3267  tribe of Massachusetts Indians; now extinct as the ancient Medes. I
3268  peered and pryed about the Devil-dam; from her, hopped over to the
3269  Tit-bit; and finally, going on board the Pequod, looked around her for
3270  a moment, and then decided that this was the very ship for us.
3271  
3272  You may have seen many a quaint craft in your day, for aught I
3273  know;—square-toed luggers; mountainous Japanese junks; butter-box
3274  galliots, and what not; but take my word for it, you never saw such a
3275  rare old craft as this same rare old Pequod. She was a ship of the old
3276  school, rather small if anything; with an old-fashioned claw-footed
3277  look about her. Long seasoned and weather-stained in the typhoons and
3278  calms of all four oceans, her old hull’s complexion was darkened like a
3279  French grenadier’s, who has alike fought in Egypt and Siberia. Her
3280  venerable bows looked bearded. Her masts—cut somewhere on the coast of
3281  Japan, where her original ones were lost overboard in a gale—her masts
3282  stood stiffly up like the spines of the three old kings of Cologne. Her
3283  ancient decks were worn and wrinkled, like the pilgrim-worshipped
3284  flag-stone in Canterbury Cathedral where Becket bled. But to all these
3285  her old antiquities, were added new and marvellous features, pertaining
3286  to the wild business that for more than half a century she had
3287  followed. Old Captain Peleg, many years her chief-mate, before he
3288  commanded another vessel of his own, and now a retired seaman, and one
3289  of the principal owners of the Pequod,—this old Peleg, during the term
3290  of his chief-mateship, had built upon her original grotesqueness, and
3291  inlaid it, all over, with a quaintness both of material and device,
3292  unmatched by anything except it be Thorkill-Hake’s carved buckler or
3293  bedstead. She was apparelled like any barbaric Ethiopian emperor, his
3294  neck heavy with pendants of polished ivory. She was a thing of
3295  trophies. A cannibal of a craft, tricking herself forth in the chased
3296  bones of her enemies. All round, her unpanelled, open bulwarks were
3297  garnished like one continuous jaw, with the long sharp teeth of the
3298  sperm whale, inserted there for pins, to fasten her old hempen thews
3299  and tendons to. Those thews ran not through base blocks of land wood,
3300  but deftly travelled over sheaves of sea-ivory. Scorning a turnstile
3301  wheel at her reverend helm, she sported there a tiller; and that tiller
3302  was in one mass, curiously carved from the long narrow lower jaw of her
3303  hereditary foe. The helmsman who steered by that tiller in a tempest,
3304  felt like the Tartar, when he holds back his fiery steed by clutching
3305  its jaw. A noble craft, but somehow a most melancholy! All noble things
3306  are touched with that.
3307  
3308  Now when I looked about the quarter-deck, for some one having
3309  authority, in order to propose myself as a candidate for the voyage, at
3310  first I saw nobody; but I could not well overlook a strange sort of
3311  tent, or rather wigwam, pitched a little behind the main-mast. It
3312  seemed only a temporary erection used in port. It was of a conical
3313  shape, some ten feet high; consisting of the long, huge slabs of limber
3314  black bone taken from the middle and highest part of the jaws of the
3315  right-whale. Planted with their broad ends on the deck, a circle of
3316  these slabs laced together, mutually sloped towards each other, and at
3317  the apex united in a tufted point, where the loose hairy fibres waved
3318  to and fro like the top-knot on some old Pottowottamie Sachem’s head. A
3319  triangular opening faced towards the bows of the ship, so that the
3320  insider commanded a complete view forward.
3321  
3322  And half concealed in this queer tenement, I at length found one who by
3323  his aspect seemed to have authority; and who, it being noon, and the
3324  ship’s work suspended, was now enjoying respite from the burden of
3325  command. He was seated on an old-fashioned oaken chair, wriggling all
3326  over with curious carving; and the bottom of which was formed of a
3327  stout interlacing of the same elastic stuff of which the wigwam was
3328  constructed.
3329  
3330  There was nothing so very particular, perhaps, about the appearance of
3331  the elderly man I saw; he was brown and brawny, like most old seamen,
3332  and heavily rolled up in blue pilot-cloth, cut in the Quaker style;
3333  only there was a fine and almost microscopic net-work of the minutest
3334  wrinkles interlacing round his eyes, which must have arisen from his
3335  continual sailings in many hard gales, and always looking to
3336  windward;—for this causes the muscles about the eyes to become pursed
3337  together. Such eye-wrinkles are very effectual in a scowl.
3338  
3339  “Is this the Captain of the Pequod?” said I, advancing to the door of
3340  the tent.
3341  
3342  “Supposing it be the captain of the Pequod, what dost thou want of
3343  him?” he demanded.
3344  
3345  “I was thinking of shipping.”
3346  
3347  “Thou wast, wast thou? I see thou art no Nantucketer—ever been in a
3348  stove boat?”
3349  
3350  “No, Sir, I never have.”
3351  
3352  “Dost know nothing at all about whaling, I dare say—eh?
3353  
3354  “Nothing, Sir; but I have no doubt I shall soon learn. I’ve been
3355  several voyages in the merchant service, and I think that—”
3356  
3357  “Merchant service be damned. Talk not that lingo to me. Dost see that
3358  leg?—I’ll take that leg away from thy stern, if ever thou talkest of
3359  the marchant service to me again. Marchant service indeed! I suppose
3360  now ye feel considerable proud of having served in those marchant
3361  ships. But flukes! man, what makes thee want to go a whaling, eh?—it
3362  looks a little suspicious, don’t it, eh?—Hast not been a pirate, hast
3363  thou?—Didst not rob thy last Captain, didst thou?—Dost not think of
3364  murdering the officers when thou gettest to sea?”
3365  
3366  I protested my innocence of these things. I saw that under the mask of
3367  these half humorous innuendoes, this old seaman, as an insulated
3368  Quakerish Nantucketer, was full of his insular prejudices, and rather
3369  distrustful of all aliens, unless they hailed from Cape Cod or the
3370  Vineyard.
3371  
3372  “But what takes thee a-whaling? I want to know that before I think of
3373  shipping ye.”
3374  
3375  “Well, sir, I want to see what whaling is. I want to see the world.”
3376  
3377  “Want to see what whaling is, eh? Have ye clapped eye on Captain Ahab?”
3378  
3379  “Who is Captain Ahab, sir?”
3380  
3381  “Aye, aye, I thought so. Captain Ahab is the Captain of this ship.”
3382  
3383  “I am mistaken then. I thought I was speaking to the Captain himself.”
3384  
3385  “Thou art speaking to Captain Peleg—that’s who ye are speaking to,
3386  young man. It belongs to me and Captain Bildad to see the Pequod fitted
3387  out for the voyage, and supplied with all her needs, including crew. We
3388  are part owners and agents. But as I was going to say, if thou wantest
3389  to know what whaling is, as thou tellest ye do, I can put ye in a way
3390  of finding it out before ye bind yourself to it, past backing out. Clap
3391  eye on Captain Ahab, young man, and thou wilt find that he has only one
3392  leg.”
3393  
3394  “What do you mean, sir? Was the other one lost by a whale?”
3395  
3396  “Lost by a whale! Young man, come nearer to me: it was devoured, chewed
3397  up, crunched by the monstrousest parmacetty that ever chipped a
3398  boat!—ah, ah!”
3399  
3400  I was a little alarmed by his energy, perhaps also a little touched at
3401  the hearty grief in his concluding exclamation, but said as calmly as I
3402  could, “What you say is no doubt true enough, sir; but how could I know
3403  there was any peculiar ferocity in that particular whale, though indeed
3404  I might have inferred as much from the simple fact of the accident.”
3405  
3406  “Look ye now, young man, thy lungs are a sort of soft, d’ye see; thou
3407  dost not talk shark a bit. _Sure_, ye’ve been to sea before now; sure
3408  of that?”
3409  
3410  “Sir,” said I, “I thought I told you that I had been four voyages in
3411  the merchant—”
3412  
3413  “Hard down out of that! Mind what I said about the marchant
3414  service—don’t aggravate me—I won’t have it. But let us understand each
3415  other. I have given thee a hint about what whaling is; do ye yet feel
3416  inclined for it?”
3417  
3418  “I do, sir.”
3419  
3420  “Very good. Now, art thou the man to pitch a harpoon down a live
3421  whale’s throat, and then jump after it? Answer, quick!”
3422  
3423  “I am, sir, if it should be positively indispensable to do so; not to
3424  be got rid of, that is; which I don’t take to be the fact.”
3425  
3426  “Good again. Now then, thou not only wantest to go a-whaling, to find
3427  out by experience what whaling is, but ye also want to go in order to
3428  see the world? Was not that what ye said? I thought so. Well then, just
3429  step forward there, and take a peep over the weather-bow, and then back
3430  to me and tell me what ye see there.”
3431  
3432  For a moment I stood a little puzzled by this curious request, not
3433  knowing exactly how to take it, whether humorously or in earnest. But
3434  concentrating all his crow’s feet into one scowl, Captain Peleg started
3435  me on the errand.
3436  
3437  Going forward and glancing over the weather bow, I perceived that the
3438  ship swinging to her anchor with the flood-tide, was now obliquely
3439  pointing towards the open ocean. The prospect was unlimited, but
3440  exceedingly monotonous and forbidding; not the slightest variety that I
3441  could see.
3442  
3443  “Well, what’s the report?” said Peleg when I came back; “what did ye
3444  see?”
3445  
3446  “Not much,” I replied—“nothing but water; considerable horizon though,
3447  and there’s a squall coming up, I think.”
3448  
3449  “Well, what does thou think then of seeing the world? Do ye wish to go
3450  round Cape Horn to see any more of it, eh? Can’t ye see the world where
3451  you stand?”
3452  
3453  I was a little staggered, but go a-whaling I must, and I would; and the
3454  Pequod was as good a ship as any—I thought the best—and all this I now
3455  repeated to Peleg. Seeing me so determined, he expressed his
3456  willingness to ship me.
3457  
3458  “And thou mayest as well sign the papers right off,” he added—“come
3459  along with ye.” And so saying, he led the way below deck into the
3460  cabin.
3461  
3462  Seated on the transom was what seemed to me a most uncommon and
3463  surprising figure. It turned out to be Captain Bildad, who along with
3464  Captain Peleg was one of the largest owners of the vessel; the other
3465  shares, as is sometimes the case in these ports, being held by a crowd
3466  of old annuitants; widows, fatherless children, and chancery wards;
3467  each owning about the value of a timber head, or a foot of plank, or a
3468  nail or two in the ship. People in Nantucket invest their money in
3469  whaling vessels, the same way that you do yours in approved state
3470  stocks bringing in good interest.
3471  
3472  Now, Bildad, like Peleg, and indeed many other Nantucketers, was a
3473  Quaker, the island having been originally settled by that sect; and to
3474  this day its inhabitants in general retain in an uncommon measure the
3475  peculiarities of the Quaker, only variously and anomalously modified by
3476  things altogether alien and heterogeneous. For some of these same
3477  Quakers are the most sanguinary of all sailors and whale-hunters. They
3478  are fighting Quakers; they are Quakers with a vengeance.
3479  
3480  So that there are instances among them of men, who, named with
3481  Scripture names—a singularly common fashion on the island—and in
3482  childhood naturally imbibing the stately dramatic thee and thou of the
3483  Quaker idiom; still, from the audacious, daring, and boundless
3484  adventure of their subsequent lives, strangely blend with these
3485  unoutgrown peculiarities, a thousand bold dashes of character, not
3486  unworthy a Scandinavian sea-king, or a poetical Pagan Roman. And when
3487  these things unite in a man of greatly superior natural force, with a
3488  globular brain and a ponderous heart; who has also by the stillness and
3489  seclusion of many long night-watches in the remotest waters, and
3490  beneath constellations never seen here at the north, been led to think
3491  untraditionally and independently; receiving all nature’s sweet or
3492  savage impressions fresh from her own virgin voluntary and confiding
3493  breast, and thereby chiefly, but with some help from accidental
3494  advantages, to learn a bold and nervous lofty language—that man makes
3495  one in a whole nation’s census—a mighty pageant creature, formed for
3496  noble tragedies. Nor will it at all detract from him, dramatically
3497  regarded, if either by birth or other circumstances, he have what seems
3498  a half wilful overruling morbidness at the bottom of his nature. For
3499  all men tragically great are made so through a certain morbidness. Be
3500  sure of this, O young ambition, all mortal greatness is but disease.
3501  But, as yet we have not to do with such an one, but with quite another;
3502  and still a man, who, if indeed peculiar, it only results again from
3503  another phase of the Quaker, modified by individual circumstances.
3504  
3505  Like Captain Peleg, Captain Bildad was a well-to-do, retired whaleman.
3506  But unlike Captain Peleg—who cared not a rush for what are called
3507  serious things, and indeed deemed those self-same serious things the
3508  veriest of all trifles—Captain Bildad had not only been originally
3509  educated according to the strictest sect of Nantucket Quakerism, but
3510  all his subsequent ocean life, and the sight of many unclad, lovely
3511  island creatures, round the Horn—all that had not moved this native
3512  born Quaker one single jot, had not so much as altered one angle of his
3513  vest. Still, for all this immutableness, was there some lack of common
3514  consistency about worthy Captain Bildad. Though refusing, from
3515  conscientious scruples, to bear arms against land invaders, yet himself
3516  had illimitably invaded the Atlantic and Pacific; and though a sworn
3517  foe to human bloodshed, yet had he in his straight-bodied coat, spilled
3518  tuns upon tuns of leviathan gore. How now in the contemplative evening
3519  of his days, the pious Bildad reconciled these things in the
3520  reminiscence, I do not know; but it did not seem to concern him much,
3521  and very probably he had long since come to the sage and sensible
3522  conclusion that a man’s religion is one thing, and this practical world
3523  quite another. This world pays dividends. Rising from a little
3524  cabin-boy in short clothes of the drabbest drab, to a harpooneer in a
3525  broad shad-bellied waistcoat; from that becoming boat-header,
3526  chief-mate, and captain, and finally a ship owner; Bildad, as I hinted
3527  before, had concluded his adventurous career by wholly retiring from
3528  active life at the goodly age of sixty, and dedicating his remaining
3529  days to the quiet receiving of his well-earned income.
3530  
3531  Now, Bildad, I am sorry to say, had the reputation of being an
3532  incorrigible old hunks, and in his sea-going days, a bitter, hard
3533  task-master. They told me in Nantucket, though it certainly seems a
3534  curious story, that when he sailed the old Categut whaleman, his crew,
3535  upon arriving home, were mostly all carried ashore to the hospital,
3536  sore exhausted and worn out. For a pious man, especially for a Quaker,
3537  he was certainly rather hard-hearted, to say the least. He never used
3538  to swear, though, at his men, they said; but somehow he got an
3539  inordinate quantity of cruel, unmitigated hard work out of them. When
3540  Bildad was a chief-mate, to have his drab-coloured eye intently looking
3541  at you, made you feel completely nervous, till you could clutch
3542  something—a hammer or a marling-spike, and go to work like mad, at
3543  something or other, never mind what. Indolence and idleness perished
3544  before him. His own person was the exact embodiment of his utilitarian
3545  character. On his long, gaunt body, he carried no spare flesh, no
3546  superfluous beard, his chin having a soft, economical nap to it, like
3547  the worn nap of his broad-brimmed hat.
3548  
3549  Such, then, was the person that I saw seated on the transom when I
3550  followed Captain Peleg down into the cabin. The space between the decks
3551  was small; and there, bolt-upright, sat old Bildad, who always sat so,
3552  and never leaned, and this to save his coat tails. His broad-brim was
3553  placed beside him; his legs were stiffly crossed; his drab vesture was
3554  buttoned up to his chin; and spectacles on nose, he seemed absorbed in
3555  reading from a ponderous volume.
3556  
3557  “Bildad,” cried Captain Peleg, “at it again, Bildad, eh? Ye have been
3558  studying those Scriptures, now, for the last thirty years, to my
3559  certain knowledge. How far ye got, Bildad?”
3560  
3561  As if long habituated to such profane talk from his old shipmate,
3562  Bildad, without noticing his present irreverence, quietly looked up,
3563  and seeing me, glanced again inquiringly towards Peleg.
3564  
3565  “He says he’s our man, Bildad,” said Peleg, “he wants to ship.”
3566  
3567  “Dost thee?” said Bildad, in a hollow tone, and turning round to me.
3568  
3569  “I _dost_,” said I unconsciously, he was so intense a Quaker.
3570  
3571  “What do ye think of him, Bildad?” said Peleg.
3572  
3573  “He’ll do,” said Bildad, eyeing me, and then went on spelling away at
3574  his book in a mumbling tone quite audible.
3575  
3576  I thought him the queerest old Quaker I ever saw, especially as Peleg,
3577  his friend and old shipmate, seemed such a blusterer. But I said
3578  nothing, only looking round me sharply. Peleg now threw open a chest,
3579  and drawing forth the ship’s articles, placed pen and ink before him,
3580  and seated himself at a little table. I began to think it was high time
3581  to settle with myself at what terms I would be willing to engage for
3582  the voyage. I was already aware that in the whaling business they paid
3583  no wages; but all hands, including the captain, received certain shares
3584  of the profits called _lays_, and that these lays were proportioned to
3585  the degree of importance pertaining to the respective duties of the
3586  ship’s company. I was also aware that being a green hand at whaling, my
3587  own lay would not be very large; but considering that I was used to the
3588  sea, could steer a ship, splice a rope, and all that, I made no doubt
3589  that from all I had heard I should be offered at least the 275th
3590  lay—that is, the 275th part of the clear net proceeds of the voyage,
3591  whatever that might eventually amount to. And though the 275th lay was
3592  what they call a rather _long lay_, yet it was better than nothing; and
3593  if we had a lucky voyage, might pretty nearly pay for the clothing I
3594  would wear out on it, not to speak of my three years’ beef and board,
3595  for which I would not have to pay one stiver.
3596  
3597  It might be thought that this was a poor way to accumulate a princely
3598  fortune—and so it was, a very poor way indeed. But I am one of those
3599  that never take on about princely fortunes, and am quite content if the
3600  world is ready to board and lodge me, while I am putting up at this
3601  grim sign of the Thunder Cloud. Upon the whole, I thought that the
3602  275th lay would be about the fair thing, but would not have been
3603  surprised had I been offered the 200th, considering I was of a
3604  broad-shouldered make.
3605  
3606  But one thing, nevertheless, that made me a little distrustful about
3607  receiving a generous share of the profits was this: Ashore, I had heard
3608  something of both Captain Peleg and his unaccountable old crony Bildad;
3609  how that they being the principal proprietors of the Pequod, therefore
3610  the other and more inconsiderable and scattered owners, left nearly the
3611  whole management of the ship’s affairs to these two. And I did not know
3612  but what the stingy old Bildad might have a mighty deal to say about
3613  shipping hands, especially as I now found him on board the Pequod,
3614  quite at home there in the cabin, and reading his Bible as if at his
3615  own fireside. Now while Peleg was vainly trying to mend a pen with his
3616  jack-knife, old Bildad, to my no small surprise, considering that he
3617  was such an interested party in these proceedings; Bildad never heeded
3618  us, but went on mumbling to himself out of his book, “_Lay_ not up for
3619  yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth—”
3620  
3621  “Well, Captain Bildad,” interrupted Peleg, “what d’ye say, what lay
3622  shall we give this young man?”
3623  
3624  “Thou knowest best,” was the sepulchral reply, “the seven hundred and
3625  seventy-seventh wouldn’t be too much, would it?—‘where moth and rust do
3626  corrupt, but _lay_—’”
3627  
3628  _Lay_, indeed, thought I, and such a lay! the seven hundred and
3629  seventy-seventh! Well, old Bildad, you are determined that I, for one,
3630  shall not _lay_ up many _lays_ here below, where moth and rust do
3631  corrupt. It was an exceedingly _long lay_ that, indeed; and though from
3632  the magnitude of the figure it might at first deceive a landsman, yet
3633  the slightest consideration will show that though seven hundred and
3634  seventy-seven is a pretty large number, yet, when you come to make a
3635  _teenth_ of it, you will then see, I say, that the seven hundred and
3636  seventy-seventh part of a farthing is a good deal less than seven
3637  hundred and seventy-seven gold doubloons; and so I thought at the time.
3638  
3639  “Why, blast your eyes, Bildad,” cried Peleg, “thou dost not want to
3640  swindle this young man! he must have more than that.”
3641  
3642  “Seven hundred and seventy-seventh,” again said Bildad, without lifting
3643  his eyes; and then went on mumbling—“for where your treasure is, there
3644  will your heart be also.”
3645  
3646  “I am going to put him down for the three hundredth,” said Peleg, “do
3647  ye hear that, Bildad! The three hundredth lay, I say.”
3648  
3649  Bildad laid down his book, and turning solemnly towards him said,
3650  “Captain Peleg, thou hast a generous heart; but thou must consider the
3651  duty thou owest to the other owners of this ship—widows and orphans,
3652  many of them—and that if we too abundantly reward the labors of this
3653  young man, we may be taking the bread from those widows and those
3654  orphans. The seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay, Captain Peleg.”
3655  
3656  “Thou Bildad!” roared Peleg, starting up and clattering about the
3657  cabin. “Blast ye, Captain Bildad, if I had followed thy advice in these
3658  matters, I would afore now had a conscience to lug about that would be
3659  heavy enough to founder the largest ship that ever sailed round Cape
3660  Horn.”
3661  
3662  “Captain Peleg,” said Bildad steadily, “thy conscience may be drawing
3663  ten inches of water, or ten fathoms, I can’t tell; but as thou art
3664  still an impenitent man, Captain Peleg, I greatly fear lest thy
3665  conscience be but a leaky one; and will in the end sink thee foundering
3666  down to the fiery pit, Captain Peleg.”
3667  
3668  “Fiery pit! fiery pit! ye insult me, man; past all natural bearing, ye
3669  insult me. It’s an all-fired outrage to tell any human creature that
3670  he’s bound to hell. Flukes and flames! Bildad, say that again to me,
3671  and start my soul-bolts, but I’ll—I’ll—yes, I’ll swallow a live goat
3672  with all his hair and horns on. Out of the cabin, ye canting,
3673  drab-coloured son of a wooden gun—a straight wake with ye!”
3674  
3675  As he thundered out this he made a rush at Bildad, but with a
3676  marvellous oblique, sliding celerity, Bildad for that time eluded him.
3677  
3678  Alarmed at this terrible outburst between the two principal and
3679  responsible owners of the ship, and feeling half a mind to give up all
3680  idea of sailing in a vessel so questionably owned and temporarily
3681  commanded, I stepped aside from the door to give egress to Bildad, who,
3682  I made no doubt, was all eagerness to vanish from before the awakened
3683  wrath of Peleg. But to my astonishment, he sat down again on the
3684  transom very quietly, and seemed to have not the slightest intention of
3685  withdrawing. He seemed quite used to impenitent Peleg and his ways. As
3686  for Peleg, after letting off his rage as he had, there seemed no more
3687  left in him, and he, too, sat down like a lamb, though he twitched a
3688  little as if still nervously agitated. “Whew!” he whistled at last—“the
3689  squall’s gone off to leeward, I think. Bildad, thou used to be good at
3690  sharpening a lance, mend that pen, will ye. My jack-knife here needs
3691  the grindstone. That’s he; thank ye, Bildad. Now then, my young man,
3692  Ishmael’s thy name, didn’t ye say? Well then, down ye go here, Ishmael,
3693  for the three hundredth lay.”
3694  
3695  “Captain Peleg,” said I, “I have a friend with me who wants to ship
3696  too—shall I bring him down to-morrow?”
3697  
3698  “To be sure,” said Peleg. “Fetch him along, and we’ll look at him.”
3699  
3700  “What lay does he want?” groaned Bildad, glancing up from the book in
3701  which he had again been burying himself.
3702  
3703  “Oh! never thee mind about that, Bildad,” said Peleg. “Has he ever
3704  whaled it any?” turning to me.
3705  
3706  “Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg.”
3707  
3708  “Well, bring him along then.”
3709  
3710  And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that I
3711  had done a good morning’s work, and that the Pequod was the identical
3712  ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round the Cape.
3713  
3714  But I had not proceeded far, when I began to bethink me that the
3715  Captain with whom I was to sail yet remained unseen by me; though,
3716  indeed, in many cases, a whale-ship will be completely fitted out, and
3717  receive all her crew on board, ere the captain makes himself visible by
3718  arriving to take command; for sometimes these voyages are so prolonged,
3719  and the shore intervals at home so exceedingly brief, that if the
3720  captain have a family, or any absorbing concernment of that sort, he
3721  does not trouble himself much about his ship in port, but leaves her to
3722  the owners till all is ready for sea. However, it is always as well to
3723  have a look at him before irrevocably committing yourself into his
3724  hands. Turning back I accosted Captain Peleg, inquiring where Captain
3725  Ahab was to be found.
3726  
3727  “And what dost thou want of Captain Ahab? It’s all right enough; thou
3728  art shipped.”
3729  
3730  “Yes, but I should like to see him.”
3731  
3732  “But I don’t think thou wilt be able to at present. I don’t know
3733  exactly what’s the matter with him; but he keeps close inside the
3734  house; a sort of sick, and yet he don’t look so. In fact, he ain’t
3735  sick; but no, he isn’t well either. Any how, young man, he won’t always
3736  see me, so I don’t suppose he will thee. He’s a queer man, Captain
3737  Ahab—so some think—but a good one. Oh, thou’lt like him well enough; no
3738  fear, no fear. He’s a grand, ungodly, god-like man, Captain Ahab;
3739  doesn’t speak much; but, when he does speak, then you may well listen.
3740  Mark ye, be forewarned; Ahab’s above the common; Ahab’s been in
3741  colleges, as well as ’mong the cannibals; been used to deeper wonders
3742  than the waves; fixed his fiery lance in mightier, stranger foes than
3743  whales. His lance! aye, the keenest and the surest that out of all our
3744  isle! Oh! he ain’t Captain Bildad; no, and he ain’t Captain Peleg;
3745  _he’s Ahab_, boy; and Ahab of old, thou knowest, was a crowned king!”
3746  
3747  “And a very vile one. When that wicked king was slain, the dogs, did
3748  they not lick his blood?”
3749  
3750  “Come hither to me—hither, hither,” said Peleg, with a significance in
3751  his eye that almost startled me. “Look ye, lad; never say that on board
3752  the Pequod. Never say it anywhere. Captain Ahab did not name himself.
3753  ’Twas a foolish, ignorant whim of his crazy, widowed mother, who died
3754  when he was only a twelvemonth old. And yet the old squaw Tistig, at
3755  Gayhead, said that the name would somehow prove prophetic. And,
3756  perhaps, other fools like her may tell thee the same. I wish to warn
3757  thee. It’s a lie. I know Captain Ahab well; I’ve sailed with him as
3758  mate years ago; I know what he is—a good man—not a pious, good man,
3759  like Bildad, but a swearing good man—something like me—only there’s a
3760  good deal more of him. Aye, aye, I know that he was never very jolly;
3761  and I know that on the passage home, he was a little out of his mind
3762  for a spell; but it was the sharp shooting pains in his bleeding stump
3763  that brought that about, as any one might see. I know, too, that ever
3764  since he lost his leg last voyage by that accursed whale, he’s been a
3765  kind of moody—desperate moody, and savage sometimes; but that will all
3766  pass off. And once for all, let me tell thee and assure thee, young
3767  man, it’s better to sail with a moody good captain than a laughing bad
3768  one. So good-bye to thee—and wrong not Captain Ahab, because he happens
3769  to have a wicked name. Besides, my boy, he has a wife—not three voyages
3770  wedded—a sweet, resigned girl. Think of that; by that sweet girl that
3771  old man has a child: hold ye then there can be any utter, hopeless harm
3772  in Ahab? No, no, my lad; stricken, blasted, if he be, Ahab has his
3773  humanities!”
3774  
3775  As I walked away, I was full of thoughtfulness; what had been
3776  incidentally revealed to me of Captain Ahab, filled me with a certain
3777  wild vagueness of painfulness concerning him. And somehow, at the time,
3778  I felt a sympathy and a sorrow for him, but for I don’t know what,
3779  unless it was the cruel loss of his leg. And yet I also felt a strange
3780  awe of him; but that sort of awe, which I cannot at all describe, was
3781  not exactly awe; I do not know what it was. But I felt it; and it did
3782  not disincline me towards him; though I felt impatience at what seemed
3783  like mystery in him, so imperfectly as he was known to me then.
3784  However, my thoughts were at length carried in other directions, so
3785  that for the present dark Ahab slipped my mind.
3786  
3787  
3788  CHAPTER 17. The Ramadan.
3789  
3790  As Queequeg’s Ramadan, or Fasting and Humiliation, was to continue all
3791  day, I did not choose to disturb him till towards night-fall; for I
3792  cherish the greatest respect towards everybody’s religious obligations,
3793  never mind how comical, and could not find it in my heart to undervalue
3794  even a congregation of ants worshipping a toad-stool; or those other
3795  creatures in certain parts of our earth, who with a degree of
3796  footmanism quite unprecedented in other planets, bow down before the
3797  torso of a deceased landed proprietor merely on account of the
3798  inordinate possessions yet owned and rented in his name.
3799  
3800  I say, we good Presbyterian Christians should be charitable in these
3801  things, and not fancy ourselves so vastly superior to other mortals,
3802  pagans and what not, because of their half-crazy conceits on these
3803  subjects. There was Queequeg, now, certainly entertaining the most
3804  absurd notions about Yojo and his Ramadan;—but what of that? Queequeg
3805  thought he knew what he was about, I suppose; he seemed to be content;
3806  and there let him rest. All our arguing with him would not avail; let
3807  him be, I say: and Heaven have mercy on us all—Presbyterians and Pagans
3808  alike—for we are all somehow dreadfully cracked about the head, and
3809  sadly need mending.
3810  
3811  Towards evening, when I felt assured that all his performances and
3812  rituals must be over, I went up to his room and knocked at the door;
3813  but no answer. I tried to open it, but it was fastened inside.
3814  “Queequeg,” said I softly through the key-hole:—all silent. “I say,
3815  Queequeg! why don’t you speak? It’s I—Ishmael.” But all remained still
3816  as before. I began to grow alarmed. I had allowed him such abundant
3817  time; I thought he might have had an apoplectic fit. I looked through
3818  the key-hole; but the door opening into an odd corner of the room, the
3819  key-hole prospect was but a crooked and sinister one. I could only see
3820  part of the foot-board of the bed and a line of the wall, but nothing
3821  more. I was surprised to behold resting against the wall the wooden
3822  shaft of Queequeg’s harpoon, which the landlady the evening previous
3823  had taken from him, before our mounting to the chamber. That’s strange,
3824  thought I; but at any rate, since the harpoon stands yonder, and he
3825  seldom or never goes abroad without it, therefore he must be inside
3826  here, and no possible mistake.
3827  
3828  “Queequeg!—Queequeg!”—all still. Something must have happened.
3829  Apoplexy! I tried to burst open the door; but it stubbornly resisted.
3830  Running down stairs, I quickly stated my suspicions to the first person
3831  I met—the chamber-maid. “La! la!” she cried, “I thought something must
3832  be the matter. I went to make the bed after breakfast, and the door was
3833  locked; and not a mouse to be heard; and it’s been just so silent ever
3834  since. But I thought, may be, you had both gone off and locked your
3835  baggage in for safe keeping. La! la, ma’am!—Mistress! murder! Mrs.
3836  Hussey! apoplexy!”—and with these cries, she ran towards the kitchen, I
3837  following.
3838  
3839  Mrs. Hussey soon appeared, with a mustard-pot in one hand and a
3840  vinegar-cruet in the other, having just broken away from the occupation
3841  of attending to the castors, and scolding her little black boy
3842  meantime.
3843  
3844  “Wood-house!” cried I, “which way to it? Run for God’s sake, and fetch
3845  something to pry open the door—the axe!—the axe! he’s had a stroke;
3846  depend upon it!”—and so saying I was unmethodically rushing up stairs
3847  again empty-handed, when Mrs. Hussey interposed the mustard-pot and
3848  vinegar-cruet, and the entire castor of her countenance.
3849  
3850  “What’s the matter with you, young man?”
3851  
3852  “Get the axe! For God’s sake, run for the doctor, some one, while I pry
3853  it open!”
3854  
3855  “Look here,” said the landlady, quickly putting down the vinegar-cruet,
3856  so as to have one hand free; “look here; are you talking about prying
3857  open any of my doors?”—and with that she seized my arm. “What’s the
3858  matter with you? What’s the matter with you, shipmate?”
3859  
3860  In as calm, but rapid a manner as possible, I gave her to understand
3861  the whole case. Unconsciously clapping the vinegar-cruet to one side of
3862  her nose, she ruminated for an instant; then exclaimed—“No! I haven’t
3863  seen it since I put it there.” Running to a little closet under the
3864  landing of the stairs, she glanced in, and returning, told me that
3865  Queequeg’s harpoon was missing. “He’s killed himself,” she cried. “It’s
3866  unfort’nate Stiggs done over again—there goes another counterpane—God
3867  pity his poor mother!—it will be the ruin of my house. Has the poor lad
3868  a sister? Where’s that girl?—there, Betty, go to Snarles the Painter,
3869  and tell him to paint me a sign, with—“no suicides permitted here, and
3870  no smoking in the parlor;”—might as well kill both birds at once. Kill?
3871  The Lord be merciful to his ghost! What’s that noise there? You, young
3872  man, avast there!”
3873  
3874  And running up after me, she caught me as I was again trying to force
3875  open the door.
3876  
3877  “I don’t allow it; I won’t have my premises spoiled. Go for the
3878  locksmith, there’s one about a mile from here. But avast!” putting her
3879  hand in her side-pocket, “here’s a key that’ll fit, I guess; let’s
3880  see.” And with that, she turned it in the lock; but, alas! Queequeg’s
3881  supplemental bolt remained unwithdrawn within.
3882  
3883  “Have to burst it open,” said I, and was running down the entry a
3884  little, for a good start, when the landlady caught at me, again vowing
3885  I should not break down her premises; but I tore from her, and with a
3886  sudden bodily rush dashed myself full against the mark.
3887  
3888  With a prodigious noise the door flew open, and the knob slamming
3889  against the wall, sent the plaster to the ceiling; and there, good
3890  heavens! there sat Queequeg, altogether cool and self-collected; right
3891  in the middle of the room; squatting on his hams, and holding Yojo on
3892  top of his head. He looked neither one way nor the other way, but sat
3893  like a carved image with scarce a sign of active life.
3894  
3895  “Queequeg,” said I, going up to him, “Queequeg, what’s the matter with
3896  you?”
3897  
3898  “He hain’t been a sittin’ so all day, has he?” said the landlady.
3899  
3900  But all we said, not a word could we drag out of him; I almost felt
3901  like pushing him over, so as to change his position, for it was almost
3902  intolerable, it seemed so painfully and unnaturally constrained;
3903  especially, as in all probability he had been sitting so for upwards of
3904  eight or ten hours, going too without his regular meals.
3905  
3906  “Mrs. Hussey,” said I, “he’s _alive_ at all events; so leave us, if you
3907  please, and I will see to this strange affair myself.”
3908  
3909  Closing the door upon the landlady, I endeavored to prevail upon
3910  Queequeg to take a chair; but in vain. There he sat; and all he could
3911  do—for all my polite arts and blandishments—he would not move a peg,
3912  nor say a single word, nor even look at me, nor notice my presence in
3913  the slightest way.
3914  
3915  I wonder, thought I, if this can possibly be a part of his Ramadan; do
3916  they fast on their hams that way in his native island. It must be so;
3917  yes, it’s part of his creed, I suppose; well, then, let him rest; he’ll
3918  get up sooner or later, no doubt. It can’t last for ever, thank God,
3919  and his Ramadan only comes once a year; and I don’t believe it’s very
3920  punctual then.
3921  
3922  I went down to supper. After sitting a long time listening to the long
3923  stories of some sailors who had just come from a plum-pudding voyage,
3924  as they called it (that is, a short whaling-voyage in a schooner or
3925  brig, confined to the north of the line, in the Atlantic Ocean only);
3926  after listening to these plum-puddingers till nearly eleven o’clock, I
3927  went up stairs to go to bed, feeling quite sure by this time Queequeg
3928  must certainly have brought his Ramadan to a termination. But no; there
3929  he was just where I had left him; he had not stirred an inch. I began
3930  to grow vexed with him; it seemed so downright senseless and insane to
3931  be sitting there all day and half the night on his hams in a cold room,
3932  holding a piece of wood on his head.
3933  
3934  “For heaven’s sake, Queequeg, get up and shake yourself; get up and
3935  have some supper. You’ll starve; you’ll kill yourself, Queequeg.” But
3936  not a word did he reply.
3937  
3938  Despairing of him, therefore, I determined to go to bed and to sleep;
3939  and no doubt, before a great while, he would follow me. But previous to
3940  turning in, I took my heavy bearskin jacket, and threw it over him, as
3941  it promised to be a very cold night; and he had nothing but his
3942  ordinary round jacket on. For some time, do all I would, I could not
3943  get into the faintest doze. I had blown out the candle; and the mere
3944  thought of Queequeg—not four feet off—sitting there in that uneasy
3945  position, stark alone in the cold and dark; this made me really
3946  wretched. Think of it; sleeping all night in the same room with a wide
3947  awake pagan on his hams in this dreary, unaccountable Ramadan!
3948  
3949  But somehow I dropped off at last, and knew nothing more till break of
3950  day; when, looking over the bedside, there squatted Queequeg, as if he
3951  had been screwed down to the floor. But as soon as the first glimpse of
3952  sun entered the window, up he got, with stiff and grating joints, but
3953  with a cheerful look; limped towards me where I lay; pressed his
3954  forehead again against mine; and said his Ramadan was over.
3955  
3956  Now, as I before hinted, I have no objection to any person’s religion,
3957  be it what it may, so long as that person does not kill or insult any
3958  other person, because that other person don’t believe it also. But when
3959  a man’s religion becomes really frantic; when it is a positive torment
3960  to him; and, in fine, makes this earth of ours an uncomfortable inn to
3961  lodge in; then I think it high time to take that individual aside and
3962  argue the point with him.
3963  
3964  And just so I now did with Queequeg. “Queequeg,” said I, “get into bed
3965  now, and lie and listen to me.” I then went on, beginning with the rise
3966  and progress of the primitive religions, and coming down to the various
3967  religions of the present time, during which time I labored to show
3968  Queequeg that all these Lents, Ramadans, and prolonged ham-squattings
3969  in cold, cheerless rooms were stark nonsense; bad for the health;
3970  useless for the soul; opposed, in short, to the obvious laws of Hygiene
3971  and common sense. I told him, too, that he being in other things such
3972  an extremely sensible and sagacious savage, it pained me, very badly
3973  pained me, to see him now so deplorably foolish about this ridiculous
3974  Ramadan of his. Besides, argued I, fasting makes the body cave in;
3975  hence the spirit caves in; and all thoughts born of a fast must
3976  necessarily be half-starved. This is the reason why most dyspeptic
3977  religionists cherish such melancholy notions about their hereafters. In
3978  one word, Queequeg, said I, rather digressively; hell is an idea first
3979  born on an undigested apple-dumpling; and since then perpetuated
3980  through the hereditary dyspepsias nurtured by Ramadans.
3981  
3982  I then asked Queequeg whether he himself was ever troubled with
3983  dyspepsia; expressing the idea very plainly, so that he could take it
3984  in. He said no; only upon one memorable occasion. It was after a great
3985  feast given by his father the king, on the gaining of a great battle
3986  wherein fifty of the enemy had been killed by about two o’clock in the
3987  afternoon, and all cooked and eaten that very evening.
3988  
3989  “No more, Queequeg,” said I, shuddering; “that will do;” for I knew the
3990  inferences without his further hinting them. I had seen a sailor who
3991  had visited that very island, and he told me that it was the custom,
3992  when a great battle had been gained there, to barbecue all the slain in
3993  the yard or garden of the victor; and then, one by one, they were
3994  placed in great wooden trenchers, and garnished round like a pilau,
3995  with breadfruit and cocoanuts; and with some parsley in their mouths,
3996  were sent round with the victor’s compliments to all his friends, just
3997  as though these presents were so many Christmas turkeys.
3998  
3999  After all, I do not think that my remarks about religion made much
4000  impression upon Queequeg. Because, in the first place, he somehow
4001  seemed dull of hearing on that important subject, unless considered
4002  from his own point of view; and, in the second place, he did not more
4003  than one third understand me, couch my ideas simply as I would; and,
4004  finally, he no doubt thought he knew a good deal more about the true
4005  religion than I did. He looked at me with a sort of condescending
4006  concern and compassion, as though he thought it a great pity that such
4007  a sensible young man should be so hopelessly lost to evangelical pagan
4008  piety.
4009  
4010  At last we rose and dressed; and Queequeg, taking a prodigiously hearty
4011  breakfast of chowders of all sorts, so that the landlady should not
4012  make much profit by reason of his Ramadan, we sallied out to board the
4013  Pequod, sauntering along, and picking our teeth with halibut bones.
4014  
4015  
4016  CHAPTER 18. His Mark.
4017  
4018  As we were walking down the end of the wharf towards the ship, Queequeg
4019  carrying his harpoon, Captain Peleg in his gruff voice loudly hailed us
4020  from his wigwam, saying he had not suspected my friend was a cannibal,
4021  and furthermore announcing that he let no cannibals on board that
4022  craft, unless they previously produced their papers.
4023  
4024  “What do you mean by that, Captain Peleg?” said I, now jumping on the
4025  bulwarks, and leaving my comrade standing on the wharf.
4026  
4027  “I mean,” he replied, “he must show his papers.”
4028  
4029  “Yes,” said Captain Bildad in his hollow voice, sticking his head from
4030  behind Peleg’s, out of the wigwam. “He must show that he’s converted.
4031  Son of darkness,” he added, turning to Queequeg, “art thou at present
4032  in communion with any Christian church?”
4033  
4034  “Why,” said I, “he’s a member of the first Congregational Church.” Here
4035  be it said, that many tattooed savages sailing in Nantucket ships at
4036  last come to be converted into the churches.
4037  
4038  “First Congregational Church,” cried Bildad, “what! that worships in
4039  Deacon Deuteronomy Coleman’s meeting-house?” and so saying, taking out
4040  his spectacles, he rubbed them with his great yellow bandana
4041  handkerchief, and putting them on very carefully, came out of the
4042  wigwam, and leaning stiffly over the bulwarks, took a good long look at
4043  Queequeg.
4044  
4045  “How long hath he been a member?” he then said, turning to me; “not
4046  very long, I rather guess, young man.”
4047  
4048  “No,” said Peleg, “and he hasn’t been baptized right either, or it
4049  would have washed some of that devil’s blue off his face.”
4050  
4051  “Do tell, now,” cried Bildad, “is this Philistine a regular member of
4052  Deacon Deuteronomy’s meeting? I never saw him going there, and I pass
4053  it every Lord’s day.”
4054  
4055  “I don’t know anything about Deacon Deuteronomy or his meeting,” said
4056  I; “all I know is, that Queequeg here is a born member of the First
4057  Congregational Church. He is a deacon himself, Queequeg is.”
4058  
4059  “Young man,” said Bildad sternly, “thou art skylarking with me—explain
4060  thyself, thou young Hittite. What church dost thee mean? answer me.”
4061  
4062  Finding myself thus hard pushed, I replied. “I mean, sir, the same
4063  ancient Catholic Church to which you and I, and Captain Peleg there,
4064  and Queequeg here, and all of us, and every mother’s son and soul of us
4065  belong; the great and everlasting First Congregation of this whole
4066  worshipping world; we all belong to that; only some of us cherish some
4067  queer crotchets no ways touching the grand belief; in _that_ we all
4068  join hands.”
4069  
4070  “Splice, thou mean’st _splice_ hands,” cried Peleg, drawing nearer.
4071  “Young man, you’d better ship for a missionary, instead of a fore-mast
4072  hand; I never heard a better sermon. Deacon Deuteronomy—why Father
4073  Mapple himself couldn’t beat it, and he’s reckoned something. Come
4074  aboard, come aboard; never mind about the papers. I say, tell Quohog
4075  there—what’s that you call him? tell Quohog to step along. By the great
4076  anchor, what a harpoon he’s got there! looks like good stuff that; and
4077  he handles it about right. I say, Quohog, or whatever your name is, did
4078  you ever stand in the head of a whale-boat? did you ever strike a
4079  fish?”
4080  
4081  Without saying a word, Queequeg, in his wild sort of way, jumped upon
4082  the bulwarks, from thence into the bows of one of the whale-boats
4083  hanging to the side; and then bracing his left knee, and poising his
4084  harpoon, cried out in some such way as this:—
4085  
4086  “Cap’ain, you see him small drop tar on water dere? You see him? well,
4087  spose him one whale eye, well, den!” and taking sharp aim at it, he
4088  darted the iron right over old Bildad’s broad brim, clean across the
4089  ship’s decks, and struck the glistening tar spot out of sight.
4090  
4091  “Now,” said Queequeg, quietly hauling in the line, “spos-ee him whale-e
4092  eye; why, dad whale dead.”
4093  
4094  “Quick, Bildad,” said Peleg, his partner, who, aghast at the close
4095  vicinity of the flying harpoon, had retreated towards the cabin
4096  gangway. “Quick, I say, you Bildad, and get the ship’s papers. We must
4097  have Hedgehog there, I mean Quohog, in one of our boats. Look ye,
4098  Quohog, we’ll give ye the ninetieth lay, and that’s more than ever was
4099  given a harpooneer yet out of Nantucket.”
4100  
4101  So down we went into the cabin, and to my great joy Queequeg was soon
4102  enrolled among the same ship’s company to which I myself belonged.
4103  
4104  When all preliminaries were over and Peleg had got everything ready for
4105  signing, he turned to me and said, “I guess, Quohog there don’t know
4106  how to write, does he? I say, Quohog, blast ye! dost thou sign thy name
4107  or make thy mark?”
4108  
4109  But at this question, Queequeg, who had twice or thrice before taken
4110  part in similar ceremonies, looked no ways abashed; but taking the
4111  offered pen, copied upon the paper, in the proper place, an exact
4112  counterpart of a queer round figure which was tattooed upon his arm; so
4113  that through Captain Peleg’s obstinate mistake touching his
4114  appellative, it stood something like this:—
4115  
4116  Quohog. his X mark.
4117  
4118  Meanwhile Captain Bildad sat earnestly and steadfastly eyeing Queequeg,
4119  and at last rising solemnly and fumbling in the huge pockets of his
4120  broad-skirted drab coat, took out a bundle of tracts, and selecting one
4121  entitled “The Latter Day Coming; or No Time to Lose,” placed it in
4122  Queequeg’s hands, and then grasping them and the book with both his,
4123  looked earnestly into his eyes, and said, “Son of darkness, I must do
4124  my duty by thee; I am part owner of this ship, and feel concerned for
4125  the souls of all its crew; if thou still clingest to thy Pagan ways,
4126  which I sadly fear, I beseech thee, remain not for aye a Belial
4127  bondsman. Spurn the idol Bell, and the hideous dragon; turn from the
4128  wrath to come; mind thine eye, I say; oh! goodness gracious! steer
4129  clear of the fiery pit!”
4130  
4131  Something of the salt sea yet lingered in old Bildad’s language,
4132  heterogeneously mixed with Scriptural and domestic phrases.
4133  
4134  “Avast there, avast there, Bildad, avast now spoiling our harpooneer,”
4135  cried Peleg. “Pious harpooneers never make good voyagers—it takes the
4136  shark out of ’em; no harpooneer is worth a straw who aint pretty
4137  sharkish. There was young Nat Swaine, once the bravest boat-header out
4138  of all Nantucket and the Vineyard; he joined the meeting, and never
4139  came to good. He got so frightened about his plaguy soul, that he
4140  shrinked and sheered away from whales, for fear of after-claps, in case
4141  he got stove and went to Davy Jones.”
4142  
4143  “Peleg! Peleg!” said Bildad, lifting his eyes and hands, “thou thyself,
4144  as I myself, hast seen many a perilous time; thou knowest, Peleg, what
4145  it is to have the fear of death; how, then, can’st thou prate in this
4146  ungodly guise. Thou beliest thine own heart, Peleg. Tell me, when this
4147  same Pequod here had her three masts overboard in that typhoon on
4148  Japan, that same voyage when thou went mate with Captain Ahab, did’st
4149  thou not think of Death and the Judgment then?”
4150  
4151  “Hear him, hear him now,” cried Peleg, marching across the cabin, and
4152  thrusting his hands far down into his pockets,—“hear him, all of ye.
4153  Think of that! When every moment we thought the ship would sink! Death
4154  and the Judgment then? What? With all three masts making such an
4155  everlasting thundering against the side; and every sea breaking over
4156  us, fore and aft. Think of Death and the Judgment then? No! no time to
4157  think about Death then. Life was what Captain Ahab and I was thinking
4158  of; and how to save all hands—how to rig jury-masts—how to get into the
4159  nearest port; that was what I was thinking of.”
4160  
4161  Bildad said no more, but buttoning up his coat, stalked on deck, where
4162  we followed him. There he stood, very quietly overlooking some
4163  sailmakers who were mending a top-sail in the waist. Now and then he
4164  stooped to pick up a patch, or save an end of tarred twine, which
4165  otherwise might have been wasted.
4166  
4167  
4168  CHAPTER 19. The Prophet.
4169  
4170  “Shipmates, have ye shipped in that ship?”
4171  
4172  Queequeg and I had just left the Pequod, and were sauntering away from
4173  the water, for the moment each occupied with his own thoughts, when the
4174  above words were put to us by a stranger, who, pausing before us,
4175  levelled his massive forefinger at the vessel in question. He was but
4176  shabbily apparelled in faded jacket and patched trowsers; a rag of a
4177  black handkerchief investing his neck. A confluent small-pox had in all
4178  directions flowed over his face, and left it like the complicated
4179  ribbed bed of a torrent, when the rushing waters have been dried up.
4180  
4181  “Have ye shipped in her?” he repeated.
4182  
4183  “You mean the ship Pequod, I suppose,” said I, trying to gain a little
4184  more time for an uninterrupted look at him.
4185  
4186  “Aye, the Pequod—that ship there,” he said, drawing back his whole arm,
4187  and then rapidly shoving it straight out from him, with the fixed
4188  bayonet of his pointed finger darted full at the object.
4189  
4190  “Yes,” said I, “we have just signed the articles.”
4191  
4192  “Anything down there about your souls?”
4193  
4194  “About what?”
4195  
4196  “Oh, perhaps you hav’n’t got any,” he said quickly. “No matter though,
4197  I know many chaps that hav’n’t got any,—good luck to ’em; and they are
4198  all the better off for it. A soul’s a sort of a fifth wheel to a
4199  wagon.”
4200  
4201  “What are you jabbering about, shipmate?” said I.
4202  
4203  “_He’s_ got enough, though, to make up for all deficiencies of that
4204  sort in other chaps,” abruptly said the stranger, placing a nervous
4205  emphasis upon the word _he_.
4206  
4207  “Queequeg,” said I, “let’s go; this fellow has broken loose from
4208  somewhere; he’s talking about something and somebody we don’t know.”
4209  
4210  “Stop!” cried the stranger. “Ye said true—ye hav’n’t seen Old Thunder
4211  yet, have ye?”
4212  
4213  “Who’s Old Thunder?” said I, again riveted with the insane earnestness
4214  of his manner.
4215  
4216  “Captain Ahab.”
4217  
4218  “What! the captain of our ship, the Pequod?”
4219  
4220  “Aye, among some of us old sailor chaps, he goes by that name. Ye
4221  hav’n’t seen him yet, have ye?”
4222  
4223  “No, we hav’n’t. He’s sick they say, but is getting better, and will be
4224  all right again before long.”
4225  
4226  “All right again before long!” laughed the stranger, with a solemnly
4227  derisive sort of laugh. “Look ye; when Captain Ahab is all right, then
4228  this left arm of mine will be all right; not before.”
4229  
4230  “What do you know about him?”
4231  
4232  “What did they _tell_ you about him? Say that!”
4233  
4234  “They didn’t tell much of anything about him; only I’ve heard that he’s
4235  a good whale-hunter, and a good captain to his crew.”
4236  
4237  “That’s true, that’s true—yes, both true enough. But you must jump when
4238  he gives an order. Step and growl; growl and go—that’s the word with
4239  Captain Ahab. But nothing about that thing that happened to him off
4240  Cape Horn, long ago, when he lay like dead for three days and nights;
4241  nothing about that deadly skrimmage with the Spaniard afore the altar
4242  in Santa?—heard nothing about that, eh? Nothing about the silver
4243  calabash he spat into? And nothing about his losing his leg last
4244  voyage, according to the prophecy. Didn’t ye hear a word about them
4245  matters and something more, eh? No, I don’t think ye did; how could ye?
4246  Who knows it? Not all Nantucket, I guess. But hows’ever, mayhap, ye’ve
4247  heard tell about the leg, and how he lost it; aye, ye have heard of
4248  that, I dare say. Oh yes, _that_ every one knows a’most—I mean they
4249  know he’s only one leg; and that a parmacetti took the other off.”
4250  
4251  “My friend,” said I, “what all this gibberish of yours is about, I
4252  don’t know, and I don’t much care; for it seems to me that you must be
4253  a little damaged in the head. But if you are speaking of Captain Ahab,
4254  of that ship there, the Pequod, then let me tell you, that I know all
4255  about the loss of his leg.”
4256  
4257  “_All_ about it, eh—sure you do?—all?”
4258  
4259  “Pretty sure.”
4260  
4261  With finger pointed and eye levelled at the Pequod, the beggar-like
4262  stranger stood a moment, as if in a troubled reverie; then starting a
4263  little, turned and said:—“Ye’ve shipped, have ye? Names down on the
4264  papers? Well, well, what’s signed, is signed; and what’s to be, will
4265  be; and then again, perhaps it won’t be, after all. Anyhow, it’s all
4266  fixed and arranged a’ready; and some sailors or other must go with him,
4267  I suppose; as well these as any other men, God pity ’em! Morning to ye,
4268  shipmates, morning; the ineffable heavens bless ye; I’m sorry I stopped
4269  ye.”
4270  
4271  “Look here, friend,” said I, “if you have anything important to tell
4272  us, out with it; but if you are only trying to bamboozle us, you are
4273  mistaken in your game; that’s all I have to say.”
4274  
4275  “And it’s said very well, and I like to hear a chap talk up that way;
4276  you are just the man for him—the likes of ye. Morning to ye, shipmates,
4277  morning! Oh! when ye get there, tell ’em I’ve concluded not to make one
4278  of ’em.”
4279  
4280  “Ah, my dear fellow, you can’t fool us that way—you can’t fool us. It
4281  is the easiest thing in the world for a man to look as if he had a
4282  great secret in him.”
4283  
4284  “Morning to ye, shipmates, morning.”
4285  
4286  “Morning it is,” said I. “Come along, Queequeg, let’s leave this crazy
4287  man. But stop, tell me your name, will you?”
4288  
4289  “Elijah.”
4290  
4291  Elijah! thought I, and we walked away, both commenting, after each
4292  other’s fashion, upon this ragged old sailor; and agreed that he was
4293  nothing but a humbug, trying to be a bugbear. But we had not gone
4294  perhaps above a hundred yards, when chancing to turn a corner, and
4295  looking back as I did so, who should be seen but Elijah following us,
4296  though at a distance. Somehow, the sight of him struck me so, that I
4297  said nothing to Queequeg of his being behind, but passed on with my
4298  comrade, anxious to see whether the stranger would turn the same corner
4299  that we did. He did; and then it seemed to me that he was dogging us,
4300  but with what intent I could not for the life of me imagine. This
4301  circumstance, coupled with his ambiguous, half-hinting, half-revealing,
4302  shrouded sort of talk, now begat in me all kinds of vague wonderments
4303  and half-apprehensions, and all connected with the Pequod; and Captain
4304  Ahab; and the leg he had lost; and the Cape Horn fit; and the silver
4305  calabash; and what Captain Peleg had said of him, when I left the ship
4306  the day previous; and the prediction of the squaw Tistig; and the
4307  voyage we had bound ourselves to sail; and a hundred other shadowy
4308  things.
4309  
4310  I was resolved to satisfy myself whether this ragged Elijah was really
4311  dogging us or not, and with that intent crossed the way with Queequeg,
4312  and on that side of it retraced our steps. But Elijah passed on,
4313  without seeming to notice us. This relieved me; and once more, and
4314  finally as it seemed to me, I pronounced him in my heart, a humbug.
4315  
4316  
4317  CHAPTER 20. All Astir.
4318  
4319  A day or two passed, and there was great activity aboard the Pequod.
4320  Not only were the old sails being mended, but new sails were coming on
4321  board, and bolts of canvas, and coils of rigging; in short, everything
4322  betokened that the ship’s preparations were hurrying to a close.
4323  Captain Peleg seldom or never went ashore, but sat in his wigwam
4324  keeping a sharp look-out upon the hands: Bildad did all the purchasing
4325  and providing at the stores; and the men employed in the hold and on
4326  the rigging were working till long after night-fall.
4327  
4328  On the day following Queequeg’s signing the articles, word was given at
4329  all the inns where the ship’s company were stopping, that their chests
4330  must be on board before night, for there was no telling how soon the
4331  vessel might be sailing. So Queequeg and I got down our traps,
4332  resolving, however, to sleep ashore till the last. But it seems they
4333  always give very long notice in these cases, and the ship did not sail
4334  for several days. But no wonder; there was a good deal to be done, and
4335  there is no telling how many things to be thought of, before the Pequod
4336  was fully equipped.
4337  
4338  Every one knows what a multitude of things—beds, sauce-pans, knives and
4339  forks, shovels and tongs, napkins, nut-crackers, and what not, are
4340  indispensable to the business of housekeeping. Just so with whaling,
4341  which necessitates a three-years’ housekeeping upon the wide ocean, far
4342  from all grocers, costermongers, doctors, bakers, and bankers. And
4343  though this also holds true of merchant vessels, yet not by any means
4344  to the same extent as with whalemen. For besides the great length of
4345  the whaling voyage, the numerous articles peculiar to the prosecution
4346  of the fishery, and the impossibility of replacing them at the remote
4347  harbors usually frequented, it must be remembered, that of all ships,
4348  whaling vessels are the most exposed to accidents of all kinds, and
4349  especially to the destruction and loss of the very things upon which
4350  the success of the voyage most depends. Hence, the spare boats, spare
4351  spars, and spare lines and harpoons, and spare everythings, almost, but
4352  a spare Captain and duplicate ship.
4353  
4354  At the period of our arrival at the Island, the heaviest storage of the
4355  Pequod had been almost completed; comprising her beef, bread, water,
4356  fuel, and iron hoops and staves. But, as before hinted, for some time
4357  there was a continual fetching and carrying on board of divers odds and
4358  ends of things, both large and small.
4359  
4360  Chief among those who did this fetching and carrying was Captain
4361  Bildad’s sister, a lean old lady of a most determined and indefatigable
4362  spirit, but withal very kindhearted, who seemed resolved that, if _she_
4363  could help it, nothing should be found wanting in the Pequod, after
4364  once fairly getting to sea. At one time she would come on board with a
4365  jar of pickles for the steward’s pantry; another time with a bunch of
4366  quills for the chief mate’s desk, where he kept his log; a third time
4367  with a roll of flannel for the small of some one’s rheumatic back.
4368  Never did any woman better deserve her name, which was Charity—Aunt
4369  Charity, as everybody called her. And like a sister of charity did this
4370  charitable Aunt Charity bustle about hither and thither, ready to turn
4371  her hand and heart to anything that promised to yield safety, comfort,
4372  and consolation to all on board a ship in which her beloved brother
4373  Bildad was concerned, and in which she herself owned a score or two of
4374  well-saved dollars.
4375  
4376  But it was startling to see this excellent hearted Quakeress coming on
4377  board, as she did the last day, with a long oil-ladle in one hand, and
4378  a still longer whaling lance in the other. Nor was Bildad himself nor
4379  Captain Peleg at all backward. As for Bildad, he carried about with him
4380  a long list of the articles needed, and at every fresh arrival, down
4381  went his mark opposite that article upon the paper. Every once in a
4382  while Peleg came hobbling out of his whalebone den, roaring at the men
4383  down the hatchways, roaring up to the riggers at the mast-head, and
4384  then concluded by roaring back into his wigwam.
4385  
4386  During these days of preparation, Queequeg and I often visited the
4387  craft, and as often I asked about Captain Ahab, and how he was, and
4388  when he was going to come on board his ship. To these questions they
4389  would answer, that he was getting better and better, and was expected
4390  aboard every day; meantime, the two captains, Peleg and Bildad, could
4391  attend to everything necessary to fit the vessel for the voyage. If I
