4392  had been downright honest with myself, I would have seen very plainly
4393  in my heart that I did but half fancy being committed this way to so
4394  long a voyage, without once laying my eyes on the man who was to be the
4395  absolute dictator of it, so soon as the ship sailed out upon the open
4396  sea. But when a man suspects any wrong, it sometimes happens that if he
4397  be already involved in the matter, he insensibly strives to cover up
4398  his suspicions even from himself. And much this way it was with me. I
4399  said nothing, and tried to think nothing.
4400  
4401  At last it was given out that some time next day the ship would
4402  certainly sail. So next morning, Queequeg and I took a very early
4403  start.
4404  
4405  
4406  CHAPTER 21. Going Aboard.
4407  
4408  It was nearly six o’clock, but only grey imperfect misty dawn, when we
4409  drew nigh the wharf.
4410  
4411  “There are some sailors running ahead there, if I see right,” said I to
4412  Queequeg, “it can’t be shadows; she’s off by sunrise, I guess; come
4413  on!”
4414  
4415  “Avast!” cried a voice, whose owner at the same time coming close
4416  behind us, laid a hand upon both our shoulders, and then insinuating
4417  himself between us, stood stooping forward a little, in the uncertain
4418  twilight, strangely peering from Queequeg to me. It was Elijah.
4419  
4420  “Going aboard?”
4421  
4422  “Hands off, will you,” said I.
4423  
4424  “Lookee here,” said Queequeg, shaking himself, “go ’way!”
4425  
4426  “Ain’t going aboard, then?”
4427  
4428  “Yes, we are,” said I, “but what business is that of yours? Do you
4429  know, Mr. Elijah, that I consider you a little impertinent?”
4430  
4431  “No, no, no; I wasn’t aware of that,” said Elijah, slowly and
4432  wonderingly looking from me to Queequeg, with the most unaccountable
4433  glances.
4434  
4435  “Elijah,” said I, “you will oblige my friend and me by withdrawing. We
4436  are going to the Indian and Pacific Oceans, and would prefer not to be
4437  detained.”
4438  
4439  “Ye be, be ye? Coming back afore breakfast?”
4440  
4441  “He’s cracked, Queequeg,” said I, “come on.”
4442  
4443  “Holloa!” cried stationary Elijah, hailing us when we had removed a few
4444  paces.
4445  
4446  “Never mind him,” said I, “Queequeg, come on.”
4447  
4448  But he stole up to us again, and suddenly clapping his hand on my
4449  shoulder, said—“Did ye see anything looking like men going towards that
4450  ship a while ago?”
4451  
4452  Struck by this plain matter-of-fact question, I answered, saying, “Yes,
4453  I thought I did see four or five men; but it was too dim to be sure.”
4454  
4455  “Very dim, very dim,” said Elijah. “Morning to ye.”
4456  
4457  Once more we quitted him; but once more he came softly after us; and
4458  touching my shoulder again, said, “See if you can find ’em now, will
4459  ye?
4460  
4461  “Find who?”
4462  
4463  “Morning to ye! morning to ye!” he rejoined, again moving off. “Oh! I
4464  was going to warn ye against—but never mind, never mind—it’s all one,
4465  all in the family too;—sharp frost this morning, ain’t it? Good-bye to
4466  ye. Shan’t see ye again very soon, I guess; unless it’s before the
4467  Grand Jury.” And with these cracked words he finally departed, leaving
4468  me, for the moment, in no small wonderment at his frantic impudence.
4469  
4470  At last, stepping on board the Pequod, we found everything in profound
4471  quiet, not a soul moving. The cabin entrance was locked within; the
4472  hatches were all on, and lumbered with coils of rigging. Going forward
4473  to the forecastle, we found the slide of the scuttle open. Seeing a
4474  light, we went down, and found only an old rigger there, wrapped in a
4475  tattered pea-jacket. He was thrown at whole length upon two chests, his
4476  face downwards and inclosed in his folded arms. The profoundest slumber
4477  slept upon him.
4478  
4479  “Those sailors we saw, Queequeg, where can they have gone to?” said I,
4480  looking dubiously at the sleeper. But it seemed that, when on the
4481  wharf, Queequeg had not at all noticed what I now alluded to; hence I
4482  would have thought myself to have been optically deceived in that
4483  matter, were it not for Elijah’s otherwise inexplicable question. But I
4484  beat the thing down; and again marking the sleeper, jocularly hinted to
4485  Queequeg that perhaps we had best sit up with the body; telling him to
4486  establish himself accordingly. He put his hand upon the sleeper’s rear,
4487  as though feeling if it was soft enough; and then, without more ado,
4488  sat quietly down there.
4489  
4490  “Gracious! Queequeg, don’t sit there,” said I.
4491  
4492  “Oh! perry dood seat,” said Queequeg, “my country way; won’t hurt him
4493  face.”
4494  
4495  “Face!” said I, “call that his face? very benevolent countenance then;
4496  but how hard he breathes, he’s heaving himself; get off, Queequeg, you
4497  are heavy, it’s grinding the face of the poor. Get off, Queequeg! Look,
4498  he’ll twitch you off soon. I wonder he don’t wake.”
4499  
4500  Queequeg removed himself to just beyond the head of the sleeper, and
4501  lighted his tomahawk pipe. I sat at the feet. We kept the pipe passing
4502  over the sleeper, from one to the other. Meanwhile, upon questioning
4503  him in his broken fashion, Queequeg gave me to understand that, in his
4504  land, owing to the absence of settees and sofas of all sorts, the king,
4505  chiefs, and great people generally, were in the custom of fattening
4506  some of the lower orders for ottomans; and to furnish a house
4507  comfortably in that respect, you had only to buy up eight or ten lazy
4508  fellows, and lay them round in the piers and alcoves. Besides, it was
4509  very convenient on an excursion; much better than those garden-chairs
4510  which are convertible into walking-sticks; upon occasion, a chief
4511  calling his attendant, and desiring him to make a settee of himself
4512  under a spreading tree, perhaps in some damp marshy place.
4513  
4514  While narrating these things, every time Queequeg received the tomahawk
4515  from me, he flourished the hatchet-side of it over the sleeper’s head.
4516  
4517  “What’s that for, Queequeg?”
4518  
4519  “Perry easy, kill-e; oh! perry easy!”
4520  
4521  He was going on with some wild reminiscences about his tomahawk-pipe,
4522  which, it seemed, had in its two uses both brained his foes and soothed
4523  his soul, when we were directly attracted to the sleeping rigger. The
4524  strong vapor now completely filling the contracted hole, it began to
4525  tell upon him. He breathed with a sort of muffledness; then seemed
4526  troubled in the nose; then revolved over once or twice; then sat up and
4527  rubbed his eyes.
4528  
4529  “Holloa!” he breathed at last, “who be ye smokers?”
4530  
4531  “Shipped men,” answered I, “when does she sail?”
4532  
4533  “Aye, aye, ye are going in her, be ye? She sails to-day. The Captain
4534  came aboard last night.”
4535  
4536  “What Captain?—Ahab?”
4537  
4538  “Who but him indeed?”
4539  
4540  I was going to ask him some further questions concerning Ahab, when we
4541  heard a noise on deck.
4542  
4543  “Holloa! Starbuck’s astir,” said the rigger. “He’s a lively chief mate,
4544  that; good man, and a pious; but all alive now, I must turn to.” And so
4545  saying he went on deck, and we followed.
4546  
4547  It was now clear sunrise. Soon the crew came on board in twos and
4548  threes; the riggers bestirred themselves; the mates were actively
4549  engaged; and several of the shore people were busy in bringing various
4550  last things on board. Meanwhile Captain Ahab remained invisibly
4551  enshrined within his cabin.
4552  
4553  
4554  CHAPTER 22. Merry Christmas.
4555  
4556  At length, towards noon, upon the final dismissal of the ship’s
4557  riggers, and after the Pequod had been hauled out from the wharf, and
4558  after the ever-thoughtful Charity had come off in a whale-boat, with
4559  her last gift—a night-cap for Stubb, the second mate, her
4560  brother-in-law, and a spare Bible for the steward—after all this, the
4561  two Captains, Peleg and Bildad, issued from the cabin, and turning to
4562  the chief mate, Peleg said:
4563  
4564  “Now, Mr. Starbuck, are you sure everything is right? Captain Ahab is
4565  all ready—just spoke to him—nothing more to be got from shore, eh?
4566  Well, call all hands, then. Muster ’em aft here—blast ’em!”
4567  
4568  “No need of profane words, however great the hurry, Peleg,” said
4569  Bildad, “but away with thee, friend Starbuck, and do our bidding.”
4570  
4571  How now! Here upon the very point of starting for the voyage, Captain
4572  Peleg and Captain Bildad were going it with a high hand on the
4573  quarter-deck, just as if they were to be joint-commanders at sea, as
4574  well as to all appearances in port. And, as for Captain Ahab, no sign
4575  of him was yet to be seen; only, they said he was in the cabin. But
4576  then, the idea was, that his presence was by no means necessary in
4577  getting the ship under weigh, and steering her well out to sea. Indeed,
4578  as that was not at all his proper business, but the pilot’s; and as he
4579  was not yet completely recovered—so they said—therefore, Captain Ahab
4580  stayed below. And all this seemed natural enough; especially as in the
4581  merchant service many captains never show themselves on deck for a
4582  considerable time after heaving up the anchor, but remain over the
4583  cabin table, having a farewell merry-making with their shore friends,
4584  before they quit the ship for good with the pilot.
4585  
4586  But there was not much chance to think over the matter, for Captain
4587  Peleg was now all alive. He seemed to do most of the talking and
4588  commanding, and not Bildad.
4589  
4590  “Aft here, ye sons of bachelors,” he cried, as the sailors lingered at
4591  the main-mast. “Mr. Starbuck, drive ’em aft.”
4592  
4593  “Strike the tent there!”—was the next order. As I hinted before, this
4594  whalebone marquee was never pitched except in port; and on board the
4595  Pequod, for thirty years, the order to strike the tent was well known
4596  to be the next thing to heaving up the anchor.
4597  
4598  “Man the capstan! Blood and thunder!—jump!”—was the next command, and
4599  the crew sprang for the handspikes.
4600  
4601  Now in getting under weigh, the station generally occupied by the pilot
4602  is the forward part of the ship. And here Bildad, who, with Peleg, be
4603  it known, in addition to his other officers, was one of the licensed
4604  pilots of the port—he being suspected to have got himself made a pilot
4605  in order to save the Nantucket pilot-fee to all the ships he was
4606  concerned in, for he never piloted any other craft—Bildad, I say, might
4607  now be seen actively engaged in looking over the bows for the
4608  approaching anchor, and at intervals singing what seemed a dismal stave
4609  of psalmody, to cheer the hands at the windlass, who roared forth some
4610  sort of a chorus about the girls in Booble Alley, with hearty good
4611  will. Nevertheless, not three days previous, Bildad had told them that
4612  no profane songs would be allowed on board the Pequod, particularly in
4613  getting under weigh; and Charity, his sister, had placed a small choice
4614  copy of Watts in each seaman’s berth.
4615  
4616  Meantime, overseeing the other part of the ship, Captain Peleg ripped
4617  and swore astern in the most frightful manner. I almost thought he
4618  would sink the ship before the anchor could be got up; involuntarily I
4619  paused on my handspike, and told Queequeg to do the same, thinking of
4620  the perils we both ran, in starting on the voyage with such a devil for
4621  a pilot. I was comforting myself, however, with the thought that in
4622  pious Bildad might be found some salvation, spite of his seven hundred
4623  and seventy-seventh lay; when I felt a sudden sharp poke in my rear,
4624  and turning round, was horrified at the apparition of Captain Peleg in
4625  the act of withdrawing his leg from my immediate vicinity. That was my
4626  first kick.
4627  
4628  “Is that the way they heave in the marchant service?” he roared.
4629  “Spring, thou sheep-head; spring, and break thy backbone! Why don’t ye
4630  spring, I say, all of ye—spring! Quohog! spring, thou chap with the red
4631  whiskers; spring there, Scotch-cap; spring, thou green pants. Spring, I
4632  say, all of ye, and spring your eyes out!” And so saying, he moved
4633  along the windlass, here and there using his leg very freely, while
4634  imperturbable Bildad kept leading off with his psalmody. Thinks I,
4635  Captain Peleg must have been drinking something to-day.
4636  
4637  At last the anchor was up, the sails were set, and off we glided. It
4638  was a short, cold Christmas; and as the short northern day merged into
4639  night, we found ourselves almost broad upon the wintry ocean, whose
4640  freezing spray cased us in ice, as in polished armor. The long rows of
4641  teeth on the bulwarks glistened in the moonlight; and like the white
4642  ivory tusks of some huge elephant, vast curving icicles depended from
4643  the bows.
4644  
4645  Lank Bildad, as pilot, headed the first watch, and ever and anon, as
4646  the old craft deep dived into the green seas, and sent the shivering
4647  frost all over her, and the winds howled, and the cordage rang, his
4648  steady notes were heard,—
4649  
4650  
4651  _“Sweet fields beyond the swelling flood, Stand dressed in living
4652  green. So to the Jews old Canaan stood, While Jordan rolled between.”_
4653  
4654  
4655  
4656  Never did those sweet words sound more sweetly to me than then. They
4657  were full of hope and fruition. Spite of this frigid winter night in
4658  the boisterous Atlantic, spite of my wet feet and wetter jacket, there
4659  was yet, it then seemed to me, many a pleasant haven in store; and
4660  meads and glades so eternally vernal, that the grass shot up by the
4661  spring, untrodden, unwilted, remains at midsummer.
4662  
4663  At last we gained such an offing, that the two pilots were needed no
4664  longer. The stout sail-boat that had accompanied us began ranging
4665  alongside.
4666  
4667  It was curious and not unpleasing, how Peleg and Bildad were affected
4668  at this juncture, especially Captain Bildad. For loath to depart, yet;
4669  very loath to leave, for good, a ship bound on so long and perilous a
4670  voyage—beyond both stormy Capes; a ship in which some thousands of his
4671  hard earned dollars were invested; a ship, in which an old shipmate
4672  sailed as captain; a man almost as old as he, once more starting to
4673  encounter all the terrors of the pitiless jaw; loath to say good-bye to
4674  a thing so every way brimful of every interest to him,—poor old Bildad
4675  lingered long; paced the deck with anxious strides; ran down into the
4676  cabin to speak another farewell word there; again came on deck, and
4677  looked to windward; looked towards the wide and endless waters, only
4678  bounded by the far-off unseen Eastern Continents; looked towards the
4679  land; looked aloft; looked right and left; looked everywhere and
4680  nowhere; and at last, mechanically coiling a rope upon its pin,
4681  convulsively grasped stout Peleg by the hand, and holding up a lantern,
4682  for a moment stood gazing heroically in his face, as much as to say,
4683  “Nevertheless, friend Peleg, I can stand it; yes, I can.”
4684  
4685  As for Peleg himself, he took it more like a philosopher; but for all
4686  his philosophy, there was a tear twinkling in his eye, when the lantern
4687  came too near. And he, too, did not a little run from cabin to deck—now
4688  a word below, and now a word with Starbuck, the chief mate.
4689  
4690  But, at last, he turned to his comrade, with a final sort of look about
4691  him,—“Captain Bildad—come, old shipmate, we must go. Back the main-yard
4692  there! Boat ahoy! Stand by to come close alongside, now! Careful,
4693  careful!—come, Bildad, boy—say your last. Luck to ye, Starbuck—luck to
4694  ye, Mr. Stubb—luck to ye, Mr. Flask—good-bye and good luck to ye
4695  all—and this day three years I’ll have a hot supper smoking for ye in
4696  old Nantucket. Hurrah and away!”
4697  
4698  “God bless ye, and have ye in His holy keeping, men,” murmured old
4699  Bildad, almost incoherently. “I hope ye’ll have fine weather now, so
4700  that Captain Ahab may soon be moving among ye—a pleasant sun is all he
4701  needs, and ye’ll have plenty of them in the tropic voyage ye go. Be
4702  careful in the hunt, ye mates. Don’t stave the boats needlessly, ye
4703  harpooneers; good white cedar plank is raised full three per cent.
4704  within the year. Don’t forget your prayers, either. Mr. Starbuck, mind
4705  that cooper don’t waste the spare staves. Oh! the sail-needles are in
4706  the green locker! Don’t whale it too much a’ Lord’s days, men; but
4707  don’t miss a fair chance either, that’s rejecting Heaven’s good gifts.
4708  Have an eye to the molasses tierce, Mr. Stubb; it was a little leaky, I
4709  thought. If ye touch at the islands, Mr. Flask, beware of fornication.
4710  Good-bye, good-bye! Don’t keep that cheese too long down in the hold,
4711  Mr. Starbuck; it’ll spoil. Be careful with the butter—twenty cents the
4712  pound it was, and mind ye, if—”
4713  
4714  “Come, come, Captain Bildad; stop palavering,—away!” and with that,
4715  Peleg hurried him over the side, and both dropt into the boat.
4716  
4717  Ship and boat diverged; the cold, damp night breeze blew between; a
4718  screaming gull flew overhead; the two hulls wildly rolled; we gave
4719  three heavy-hearted cheers, and blindly plunged like fate into the lone
4720  Atlantic.
4721  
4722  
4723  CHAPTER 23. The Lee Shore.
4724  
4725  Some chapters back, one Bulkington was spoken of, a tall, newlanded
4726  mariner, encountered in New Bedford at the inn.
4727  
4728  When on that shivering winter’s night, the Pequod thrust her vindictive
4729  bows into the cold malicious waves, who should I see standing at her
4730  helm but Bulkington! I looked with sympathetic awe and fearfulness upon
4731  the man, who in mid-winter just landed from a four years’ dangerous
4732  voyage, could so unrestingly push off again for still another
4733  tempestuous term. The land seemed scorching to his feet. Wonderfullest
4734  things are ever the unmentionable; deep memories yield no epitaphs;
4735  this six-inch chapter is the stoneless grave of Bulkington. Let me only
4736  say that it fared with him as with the storm-tossed ship, that
4737  miserably drives along the leeward land. The port would fain give
4738  succor; the port is pitiful; in the port is safety, comfort,
4739  hearthstone, supper, warm blankets, friends, all that’s kind to our
4740  mortalities. But in that gale, the port, the land, is that ship’s
4741  direst jeopardy; she must fly all hospitality; one touch of land,
4742  though it but graze the keel, would make her shudder through and
4743  through. With all her might she crowds all sail off shore; in so doing,
4744  fights ’gainst the very winds that fain would blow her homeward; seeks
4745  all the lashed sea’s landlessness again; for refuge’s sake forlornly
4746  rushing into peril; her only friend her bitterest foe!
4747  
4748  Know ye now, Bulkington? Glimpses do ye seem to see of that mortally
4749  intolerable truth; that all deep, earnest thinking is but the intrepid
4750  effort of the soul to keep the open independence of her sea; while the
4751  wildest winds of heaven and earth conspire to cast her on the
4752  treacherous, slavish shore?
4753  
4754  But as in landlessness alone resides highest truth, shoreless,
4755  indefinite as God—so, better is it to perish in that howling infinite,
4756  than be ingloriously dashed upon the lee, even if that were safety! For
4757  worm-like, then, oh! who would craven crawl to land! Terrors of the
4758  terrible! is all this agony so vain? Take heart, take heart, O
4759  Bulkington! Bear thee grimly, demigod! Up from the spray of thy
4760  ocean-perishing—straight up, leaps thy apotheosis!
4761  
4762  
4763  CHAPTER 24. The Advocate.
4764  
4765  As Queequeg and I are now fairly embarked in this business of whaling;
4766  and as this business of whaling has somehow come to be regarded among
4767  landsmen as a rather unpoetical and disreputable pursuit; therefore, I
4768  am all anxiety to convince ye, ye landsmen, of the injustice hereby
4769  done to us hunters of whales.
4770  
4771  In the first place, it may be deemed almost superfluous to establish
4772  the fact, that among people at large, the business of whaling is not
4773  accounted on a level with what are called the liberal professions. If a
4774  stranger were introduced into any miscellaneous metropolitan society,
4775  it would but slightly advance the general opinion of his merits, were
4776  he presented to the company as a harpooneer, say; and if in emulation
4777  of the naval officers he should append the initials S.W.F. (Sperm Whale
4778  Fishery) to his visiting card, such a procedure would be deemed
4779  pre-eminently presuming and ridiculous.
4780  
4781  Doubtless one leading reason why the world declines honoring us
4782  whalemen, is this: they think that, at best, our vocation amounts to a
4783  butchering sort of business; and that when actively engaged therein, we
4784  are surrounded by all manner of defilements. Butchers we are, that is
4785  true. But butchers, also, and butchers of the bloodiest badge have been
4786  all Martial Commanders whom the world invariably delights to honor. And
4787  as for the matter of the alleged uncleanliness of our business, ye
4788  shall soon be initiated into certain facts hitherto pretty generally
4789  unknown, and which, upon the whole, will triumphantly plant the sperm
4790  whale-ship at least among the cleanliest things of this tidy earth. But
4791  even granting the charge in question to be true; what disordered
4792  slippery decks of a whale-ship are comparable to the unspeakable
4793  carrion of those battle-fields from which so many soldiers return to
4794  drink in all ladies’ plaudits? And if the idea of peril so much
4795  enhances the popular conceit of the soldier’s profession; let me assure
4796  ye that many a veteran who has freely marched up to a battery, would
4797  quickly recoil at the apparition of the sperm whale’s vast tail,
4798  fanning into eddies the air over his head. For what are the
4799  comprehensible terrors of man compared with the interlinked terrors and
4800  wonders of God!
4801  
4802  But, though the world scouts at us whale hunters, yet does it
4803  unwittingly pay us the profoundest homage; yea, an all-abounding
4804  adoration! for almost all the tapers, lamps, and candles that burn
4805  round the globe, burn, as before so many shrines, to our glory!
4806  
4807  But look at this matter in other lights; weigh it in all sorts of
4808  scales; see what we whalemen are, and have been.
4809  
4810  Why did the Dutch in De Witt’s time have admirals of their whaling
4811  fleets? Why did Louis XVI. of France, at his own personal expense, fit
4812  out whaling ships from Dunkirk, and politely invite to that town some
4813  score or two of families from our own island of Nantucket? Why did
4814  Britain between the years 1750 and 1788 pay to her whalemen in bounties
4815  upwards of £1,000,000? And lastly, how comes it that we whalemen of
4816  America now outnumber all the rest of the banded whalemen in the world;
4817  sail a navy of upwards of seven hundred vessels; manned by eighteen
4818  thousand men; yearly consuming 4,000,000 of dollars; the ships worth,
4819  at the time of sailing, $20,000,000! and every year importing into our
4820  harbors a well reaped harvest of $7,000,000. How comes all this, if
4821  there be not something puissant in whaling?
4822  
4823  But this is not the half; look again.
4824  
4825  I freely assert, that the cosmopolite philosopher cannot, for his life,
4826  point out one single peaceful influence, which within the last sixty
4827  years has operated more potentially upon the whole broad world, taken
4828  in one aggregate, than the high and mighty business of whaling. One way
4829  and another, it has begotten events so remarkable in themselves, and so
4830  continuously momentous in their sequential issues, that whaling may
4831  well be regarded as that Egyptian mother, who bore offspring themselves
4832  pregnant from her womb. It would be a hopeless, endless task to
4833  catalogue all these things. Let a handful suffice. For many years past
4834  the whale-ship has been the pioneer in ferreting out the remotest and
4835  least known parts of the earth. She has explored seas and archipelagoes
4836  which had no chart, where no Cook or Vancouver had ever sailed. If
4837  American and European men-of-war now peacefully ride in once savage
4838  harbors, let them fire salutes to the honor and glory of the
4839  whale-ship, which originally showed them the way, and first interpreted
4840  between them and the savages. They may celebrate as they will the
4841  heroes of Exploring Expeditions, your Cooks, your Krusensterns; but I
4842  say that scores of anonymous Captains have sailed out of Nantucket,
4843  that were as great, and greater than your Cook and your Krusenstern.
4844  For in their succourless empty-handedness, they, in the heathenish
4845  sharked waters, and by the beaches of unrecorded, javelin islands,
4846  battled with virgin wonders and terrors that Cook with all his marines
4847  and muskets would not willingly have dared. All that is made such a
4848  flourish of in the old South Sea Voyages, those things were but the
4849  life-time commonplaces of our heroic Nantucketers. Often, adventures
4850  which Vancouver dedicates three chapters to, these men accounted
4851  unworthy of being set down in the ship’s common log. Ah, the world! Oh,
4852  the world!
4853  
4854  Until the whale fishery rounded Cape Horn, no commerce but colonial,
4855  scarcely any intercourse but colonial, was carried on between Europe
4856  and the long line of the opulent Spanish provinces on the Pacific
4857  coast. It was the whaleman who first broke through the jealous policy
4858  of the Spanish crown, touching those colonies; and, if space permitted,
4859  it might be distinctly shown how from those whalemen at last eventuated
4860  the liberation of Peru, Chili, and Bolivia from the yoke of Old Spain,
4861  and the establishment of the eternal democracy in those parts.
4862  
4863  That great America on the other side of the sphere, Australia, was
4864  given to the enlightened world by the whaleman. After its first
4865  blunder-born discovery by a Dutchman, all other ships long shunned
4866  those shores as pestiferously barbarous; but the whale-ship touched
4867  there. The whale-ship is the true mother of that now mighty colony.
4868  Moreover, in the infancy of the first Australian settlement, the
4869  emigrants were several times saved from starvation by the benevolent
4870  biscuit of the whale-ship luckily dropping an anchor in their waters.
4871  The uncounted isles of all Polynesia confess the same truth, and do
4872  commercial homage to the whale-ship, that cleared the way for the
4873  missionary and the merchant, and in many cases carried the primitive
4874  missionaries to their first destinations. If that double-bolted land,
4875  Japan, is ever to become hospitable, it is the whale-ship alone to whom
4876  the credit will be due; for already she is on the threshold.
4877  
4878  But if, in the face of all this, you still declare that whaling has no
4879  æsthetically noble associations connected with it, then am I ready to
4880  shiver fifty lances with you there, and unhorse you with a split helmet
4881  every time.
4882  
4883  The whale has no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler, you
4884  will say.
4885  
4886  _The whale no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler?_ Who
4887  wrote the first account of our Leviathan? Who but mighty Job! And who
4888  composed the first narrative of a whaling-voyage? Who, but no less a
4889  prince than Alfred the Great, who, with his own royal pen, took down
4890  the words from Other, the Norwegian whale-hunter of those times! And
4891  who pronounced our glowing eulogy in Parliament? Who, but Edmund Burke!
4892  
4893  True enough, but then whalemen themselves are poor devils; they have no
4894  good blood in their veins.
4895  
4896  _No good blood in their veins?_ They have something better than royal
4897  blood there. The grandmother of Benjamin Franklin was Mary Morrel;
4898  afterwards, by marriage, Mary Folger, one of the old settlers of
4899  Nantucket, and the ancestress to a long line of Folgers and
4900  harpooneers—all kith and kin to noble Benjamin—this day darting the
4901  barbed iron from one side of the world to the other.
4902  
4903  Good again; but then all confess that somehow whaling is not
4904  respectable.
4905  
4906  _Whaling not respectable?_ Whaling is imperial! By old English
4907  statutory law, the whale is declared “a royal fish.” *
4908  
4909  Oh, that’s only nominal! The whale himself has never figured in any
4910  grand imposing way.
4911  
4912  _The whale never figured in any grand imposing way?_ In one of the
4913  mighty triumphs given to a Roman general upon his entering the world’s
4914  capital, the bones of a whale, brought all the way from the Syrian
4915  coast, were the most conspicuous object in the cymballed procession.*
4916  
4917  *See subsequent chapters for something more on this head.
4918  
4919  Grant it, since you cite it; but, say what you will, there is no real
4920  dignity in whaling.
4921  
4922  _No dignity in whaling?_ The dignity of our calling the very heavens
4923  attest. Cetus is a constellation in the South! No more! Drive down your
4924  hat in presence of the Czar, and take it off to Queequeg! No more! I
4925  know a man that, in his lifetime, has taken three hundred and fifty
4926  whales. I account that man more honorable than that great captain of
4927  antiquity who boasted of taking as many walled towns.
4928  
4929  And, as for me, if, by any possibility, there be any as yet
4930  undiscovered prime thing in me; if I shall ever deserve any real repute
4931  in that small but high hushed world which I might not be unreasonably
4932  ambitious of; if hereafter I shall do anything that, upon the whole, a
4933  man might rather have done than to have left undone; if, at my death,
4934  my executors, or more properly my creditors, find any precious MSS. in
4935  my desk, then here I prospectively ascribe all the honor and the glory
4936  to whaling; for a whale-ship was my Yale College and my Harvard.
4937  
4938  
4939  CHAPTER 25. Postscript.
4940  
4941  In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but
4942  substantiated facts. But after embattling his facts, an advocate who
4943  should wholly suppress a not unreasonable surmise, which might tell
4944  eloquently upon his cause—such an advocate, would he not be
4945  blameworthy?
4946  
4947  It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even
4948  modern ones, a certain curious process of seasoning them for their
4949  functions is gone through. There is a saltcellar of state, so called,
4950  and there may be a castor of state. How they use the salt,
4951  precisely—who knows? Certain I am, however, that a king’s head is
4952  solemnly oiled at his coronation, even as a head of salad. Can it be,
4953  though, that they anoint it with a view of making its interior run
4954  well, as they anoint machinery? Much might be ruminated here,
4955  concerning the essential dignity of this regal process, because in
4956  common life we esteem but meanly and contemptibly a fellow who anoints
4957  his hair, and palpably smells of that anointing. In truth, a mature man
4958  who uses hair-oil, unless medicinally, that man has probably got a
4959  quoggy spot in him somewhere. As a general rule, he can’t amount to
4960  much in his totality.
4961  
4962  But the only thing to be considered here, is this—what kind of oil is
4963  used at coronations? Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor macassar
4964  oil, nor castor oil, nor bear’s oil, nor train oil, nor cod-liver oil.
4965  What then can it possibly be, but sperm oil in its unmanufactured,
4966  unpolluted state, the sweetest of all oils?
4967  
4968  Think of that, ye loyal Britons! we whalemen supply your kings and
4969  queens with coronation stuff!
4970  
4971  
4972  CHAPTER 26. Knights and Squires.
4973  
4974  The chief mate of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and a
4975  Quaker by descent. He was a long, earnest man, and though born on an
4976  icy coast, seemed well adapted to endure hot latitudes, his flesh being
4977  hard as twice-baked biscuit. Transported to the Indies, his live blood
4978  would not spoil like bottled ale. He must have been born in some time
4979  of general drought and famine, or upon one of those fast days for which
4980  his state is famous. Only some thirty arid summers had he seen; those
4981  summers had dried up all his physical superfluousness. But this, his
4982  thinness, so to speak, seemed no more the token of wasting anxieties
4983  and cares, than it seemed the indication of any bodily blight. It was
4984  merely the condensation of the man. He was by no means ill-looking;
4985  quite the contrary. His pure tight skin was an excellent fit; and
4986  closely wrapped up in it, and embalmed with inner health and strength,
4987  like a revivified Egyptian, this Starbuck seemed prepared to endure for
4988  long ages to come, and to endure always, as now; for be it Polar snow
4989  or torrid sun, like a patent chronometer, his interior vitality was
4990  warranted to do well in all climates. Looking into his eyes, you seemed
4991  to see there the yet lingering images of those thousand-fold perils he
4992  had calmly confronted through life. A staid, steadfast man, whose life
4993  for the most part was a telling pantomime of action, and not a tame
4994  chapter of sounds. Yet, for all his hardy sobriety and fortitude, there
4995  were certain qualities in him which at times affected, and in some
4996  cases seemed well nigh to overbalance all the rest. Uncommonly
4997  conscientious for a seaman, and endued with a deep natural reverence,
4998  the wild watery loneliness of his life did therefore strongly incline
4999  him to superstition; but to that sort of superstition, which in some
5000  organizations seems rather to spring, somehow, from intelligence than
5001  from ignorance. Outward portents and inward presentiments were his. And
5002  if at times these things bent the welded iron of his soul, much more
5003  did his far-away domestic memories of his young Cape wife and child,
5004  tend to bend him still more from the original ruggedness of his nature,
5005  and open him still further to those latent influences which, in some
5006  honest-hearted men, restrain the gush of dare-devil daring, so often
5007  evinced by others in the more perilous vicissitudes of the fishery. “I
5008  will have no man in my boat,” said Starbuck, “who is not afraid of a
5009  whale.” By this, he seemed to mean, not only that the most reliable and
5010  useful courage was that which arises from the fair estimation of the
5011  encountered peril, but that an utterly fearless man is a far more
5012  dangerous comrade than a coward.
5013  
5014  “Aye, aye,” said Stubb, the second mate, “Starbuck, there, is as
5015  careful a man as you’ll find anywhere in this fishery.” But we shall
5016  ere long see what that word “careful” precisely means when used by a
5017  man like Stubb, or almost any other whale hunter.
5018  
5019  Starbuck was no crusader after perils; in him courage was not a
5020  sentiment; but a thing simply useful to him, and always at hand upon
5021  all mortally practical occasions. Besides, he thought, perhaps, that in
5022  this business of whaling, courage was one of the great staple outfits
5023  of the ship, like her beef and her bread, and not to be foolishly
5024  wasted. Wherefore he had no fancy for lowering for whales after
5025  sun-down; nor for persisting in fighting a fish that too much persisted
5026  in fighting him. For, thought Starbuck, I am here in this critical
5027  ocean to kill whales for my living, and not to be killed by them for
5028  theirs; and that hundreds of men had been so killed Starbuck well knew.
5029  What doom was his own father’s? Where, in the bottomless deeps, could
5030  he find the torn limbs of his brother?
5031  
5032  With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain
5033  superstitiousness, as has been said; the courage of this Starbuck which
5034  could, nevertheless, still flourish, must indeed have been extreme. But
5035  it was not in reasonable nature that a man so organized, and with such
5036  terrible experiences and remembrances as he had; it was not in nature
5037  that these things should fail in latently engendering an element in
5038  him, which, under suitable circumstances, would break out from its
5039  confinement, and burn all his courage up. And brave as he might be, it
5040  was that sort of bravery chiefly, visible in some intrepid men, which,
5041  while generally abiding firm in the conflict with seas, or winds, or
5042  whales, or any of the ordinary irrational horrors of the world, yet
5043  cannot withstand those more terrific, because more spiritual terrors,
5044  which sometimes menace you from the concentrating brow of an enraged
5045  and mighty man.
5046  
5047  But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete
5048  abasement of poor Starbuck’s fortitude, scarce might I have the heart
5049  to write it; for it is a thing most sorrowful, nay shocking, to expose
5050  the fall of valour in the soul. Men may seem detestable as joint
5051  stock-companies and nations; knaves, fools, and murderers there may be;
5052  men may have mean and meagre faces; but man, in the ideal, is so noble
5053  and so sparkling, such a grand and glowing creature, that over any
5054  ignominious blemish in him all his fellows should run to throw their
5055  costliest robes. That immaculate manliness we feel within ourselves, so
5056  far within us, that it remains intact though all the outer character
5057  seem gone; bleeds with keenest anguish at the undraped spectacle of a
5058  valor-ruined man. Nor can piety itself, at such a shameful sight,
5059  completely stifle her upbraidings against the permitting stars. But
5060  this august dignity I treat of, is not the dignity of kings and robes,
5061  but that abounding dignity which has no robed investiture. Thou shalt
5062  see it shining in the arm that wields a pick or drives a spike; that
5063  democratic dignity which, on all hands, radiates without end from God;
5064  Himself! The great God absolute! The centre and circumference of all
5065  democracy! His omnipresence, our divine equality!
5066  
5067  If, then, to meanest mariners, and renegades and castaways, I shall
5068  hereafter ascribe high qualities, though dark; weave round them tragic
5069  graces; if even the most mournful, perchance the most abased, among
5070  them all, shall at times lift himself to the exalted mounts; if I shall
5071  touch that workman’s arm with some ethereal light; if I shall spread a
5072  rainbow over his disastrous set of sun; then against all mortal critics
5073  bear me out in it, thou just Spirit of Equality, which hast spread one
5074  royal mantle of humanity over all my kind! Bear me out in it, thou
5075  great democratic God! who didst not refuse to the swart convict,
5076  Bunyan, the pale, poetic pearl; Thou who didst clothe with doubly
5077  hammered leaves of finest gold, the stumped and paupered arm of old
5078  Cervantes; Thou who didst pick up Andrew Jackson from the pebbles; who
5079  didst hurl him upon a war-horse; who didst thunder him higher than a
5080  throne! Thou who, in all Thy mighty, earthly marchings, ever cullest
5081  Thy selectest champions from the kingly commons; bear me out in it, O
5082  God!
5083  
5084  
5085  CHAPTER 27. Knights and Squires.
5086  
5087  Stubb was the second mate. He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,
5088  according to local usage, was called a Cape-Cod-man. A happy-go-lucky;
5089  neither craven nor valiant; taking perils as they came with an
5090  indifferent air; and while engaged in the most imminent crisis of the
5091  chase, toiling away, calm and collected as a journeyman joiner engaged
5092  for the year. Good-humored, easy, and careless, he presided over his
5093  whale-boat as if the most deadly encounter were but a dinner, and his
5094  crew all invited guests. He was as particular about the comfortable
5095  arrangement of his part of the boat, as an old stage-driver is about
5096  the snugness of his box. When close to the whale, in the very
5097  death-lock of the fight, he handled his unpitying lance coolly and
5098  off-handedly, as a whistling tinker his hammer. He would hum over his
5099  old rigadig tunes while flank and flank with the most exasperated
5100  monster. Long usage had, for this Stubb, converted the jaws of death
5101  into an easy chair. What he thought of death itself, there is no
5102  telling. Whether he ever thought of it at all, might be a question;
5103  but, if he ever did chance to cast his mind that way after a
5104  comfortable dinner, no doubt, like a good sailor, he took it to be a
5105  sort of call of the watch to tumble aloft, and bestir themselves there,
5106  about something which he would find out when he obeyed the order, and
5107  not sooner.
5108  
5109  What, perhaps, with other things, made Stubb such an easy-going,
5110  unfearing man, so cheerily trudging off with the burden of life in a
5111  world full of grave pedlars, all bowed to the ground with their packs;
5112  what helped to bring about that almost impious good-humor of his; that
5113  thing must have been his pipe. For, like his nose, his short, black
5114  little pipe was one of the regular features of his face. You would
5115  almost as soon have expected him to turn out of his bunk without his
5116  nose as without his pipe. He kept a whole row of pipes there ready
5117  loaded, stuck in a rack, within easy reach of his hand; and, whenever
5118  he turned in, he smoked them all out in succession, lighting one from
5119  the other to the end of the chapter; then loading them again to be in
5120  readiness anew. For, when Stubb dressed, instead of first putting his
5121  legs into his trowsers, he put his pipe into his mouth.
5122  
5123  I say this continual smoking must have been one cause, at least, of his
5124  peculiar disposition; for every one knows that this earthly air,
5125  whether ashore or afloat, is terribly infected with the nameless
5126  miseries of the numberless mortals who have died exhaling it; and as in
5127  time of the cholera, some people go about with a camphorated
5128  handkerchief to their mouths; so, likewise, against all mortal
5129  tribulations, Stubb’s tobacco smoke might have operated as a sort of
5130  disinfecting agent.
5131  
5132  The third mate was Flask, a native of Tisbury, in Martha’s Vineyard. A
5133  short, stout, ruddy young fellow, very pugnacious concerning whales,
5134  who somehow seemed to think that the great leviathans had personally
5135  and hereditarily affronted him; and therefore it was a sort of point of
5136  honor with him, to destroy them whenever encountered. So utterly lost
5137  was he to all sense of reverence for the many marvels of their majestic
5138  bulk and mystic ways; and so dead to anything like an apprehension of
5139  any possible danger from encountering them; that in his poor opinion,
5140  the wondrous whale was but a species of magnified mouse, or at least
5141  water-rat, requiring only a little circumvention and some small
5142  application of time and trouble in order to kill and boil. This
5143  ignorant, unconscious fearlessness of his made him a little waggish in
5144  the matter of whales; he followed these fish for the fun of it; and a
5145  three years’ voyage round Cape Horn was only a jolly joke that lasted
5146  that length of time. As a carpenter’s nails are divided into wrought
5147  nails and cut nails; so mankind may be similarly divided. Little Flask
5148  was one of the wrought ones; made to clinch tight and last long. They
5149  called him King-Post on board of the Pequod; because, in form, he could
5150  be well likened to the short, square timber known by that name in
5151  Arctic whalers; and which by the means of many radiating side timbers
5152  inserted into it, serves to brace the ship against the icy concussions
5153  of those battering seas.
5154  
5155  Now these three mates—Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, were momentous men.
5156  They it was who by universal prescription commanded three of the
5157  Pequod’s boats as headsmen. In that grand order of battle in which
5158  Captain Ahab would probably marshal his forces to descend on the
5159  whales, these three headsmen were as captains of companies. Or, being
5160  armed with their long keen whaling spears, they were as a picked trio
5161  of lancers; even as the harpooneers were flingers of javelins.
5162  
5163  And since in this famous fishery, each mate or headsman, like a Gothic
5164  Knight of old, is always accompanied by his boat-steerer or harpooneer,
5165  who in certain conjunctures provides him with a fresh lance, when the
5166  former one has been badly twisted, or elbowed in the assault; and
5167  moreover, as there generally subsists between the two, a close intimacy
5168  and friendliness; it is therefore but meet, that in this place we set
5169  down who the Pequod’s harpooneers were, and to what headsman each of
5170  them belonged.
5171  
5172  First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had selected
5173  for his squire. But Queequeg is already known.
5174  
5175  Next was Tashtego, an unmixed Indian from Gay Head, the most westerly
5176  promontory of Martha’s Vineyard, where there still exists the last
5177  remnant of a village of red men, which has long supplied the
5178  neighboring island of Nantucket with many of her most daring
5179  harpooneers. In the fishery, they usually go by the generic name of
5180  Gay-Headers. Tashtego’s long, lean, sable hair, his high cheek bones,
5181  and black rounding eyes—for an Indian, Oriental in their largeness, but
5182  Antarctic in their glittering expression—all this sufficiently
5183  proclaimed him an inheritor of the unvitiated blood of those proud
5184  warrior hunters, who, in quest of the great New England moose, had
5185  scoured, bow in hand, the aboriginal forests of the main. But no longer
5186  snuffing in the trail of the wild beasts of the woodland, Tashtego now
5187  hunted in the wake of the great whales of the sea; the unerring harpoon
5188  of the son fitly replacing the infallible arrow of the sires. To look
5189  at the tawny brawn of his lithe snaky limbs, you would almost have
5190  credited the superstitions of some of the earlier Puritans, and
5191  half-believed this wild Indian to be a son of the Prince of the Powers
5192  of the Air. Tashtego was Stubb the second mate’s squire.
5193  
5194  Third among the harpooneers was Daggoo, a gigantic, coal-black
5195  negro-savage, with a lion-like tread—an Ahasuerus to behold. Suspended
5196  from his ears were two golden hoops, so large that the sailors called
5197  them ring-bolts, and would talk of securing the top-sail halyards to
5198  them. In his youth Daggoo had voluntarily shipped on board of a whaler,
5199  lying in a lonely bay on his native coast. And never having been
5200  anywhere in the world but in Africa, Nantucket, and the pagan harbors
5201  most frequented by whalemen; and having now led for many years the bold
5202  life of the fishery in the ships of owners uncommonly heedful of what
5203  manner of men they shipped; Daggoo retained all his barbaric virtues,
5204  and erect as a giraffe, moved about the decks in all the pomp of six
5205  feet five in his socks. There was a corporeal humility in looking up at
5206  him; and a white man standing before him seemed a white flag come to
5207  beg truce of a fortress. Curious to tell, this imperial negro,
5208  Ahasuerus Daggoo, was the Squire of little Flask, who looked like a
5209  chess-man beside him. As for the residue of the Pequod’s company, be it
5210  said, that at the present day not one in two of the many thousand men
5211  before the mast employed in the American whale fishery, are Americans
5212  born, though pretty nearly all the officers are. Herein it is the same
5213  with the American whale fishery as with the American army and military
5214  and merchant navies, and the engineering forces employed in the
5215  construction of the American Canals and Railroads. The same, I say,
5216  because in all these cases the native American liberally provides the
5217  brains, the rest of the world as generously supplying the muscles. No
5218  small number of these whaling seamen belong to the Azores, where the
5219  outward bound Nantucket whalers frequently touch to augment their crews
5220  from the hardy peasants of those rocky shores. In like manner, the
5221  Greenland whalers sailing out of Hull or London, put in at the Shetland
5222  Islands, to receive the full complement of their crew. Upon the passage
5223  homewards, they drop them there again. How it is, there is no telling,
5224  but Islanders seem to make the best whalemen. They were nearly all
5225  Islanders in the Pequod, _Isolatoes_ too, I call such, not
5226  acknowledging the common continent of men, but each _Isolato_ living on
5227  a separate continent of his own. Yet now, federated along one keel,
5228  what a set these Isolatoes were! An Anacharsis Clootz deputation from
5229  all the isles of the sea, and all the ends of the earth, accompanying
5230  Old Ahab in the Pequod to lay the world’s grievances before that bar
5231  from which not very many of them ever come back. Black Little Pip—he
5232  never did—oh, no! he went before. Poor Alabama boy! On the grim
5233  Pequod’s forecastle, ye shall ere long see him, beating his tambourine;
5234  prelusive of the eternal time, when sent for, to the great quarter-deck
5235  on high, he was bid strike in with angels, and beat his tambourine in
5236  glory; called a coward here, hailed a hero there!
5237  
5238  
5239  CHAPTER 28. Ahab.
5240  
5241  For several days after leaving Nantucket, nothing above hatches was
5242  seen of Captain Ahab. The mates regularly relieved each other at the
5243  watches, and for aught that could be seen to the contrary, they seemed
5244  to be the only commanders of the ship; only they sometimes issued from
5245  the cabin with orders so sudden and peremptory, that after all it was
5246  plain they but commanded vicariously. Yes, their supreme lord and
5247  dictator was there, though hitherto unseen by any eyes not permitted to
5248  penetrate into the now sacred retreat of the cabin.
5249  
5250  Every time I ascended to the deck from my watches below, I instantly
5251  gazed aft to mark if any strange face were visible; for my first vague
5252  disquietude touching the unknown captain, now in the seclusion of the
5253  sea, became almost a perturbation. This was strangely heightened at
5254  times by the ragged Elijah’s diabolical incoherences uninvitedly
5255  recurring to me, with a subtle energy I could not have before conceived
5256  of. But poorly could I withstand them, much as in other moods I was
5257  almost ready to smile at the solemn whimsicalities of that outlandish
5258  prophet of the wharves. But whatever it was of apprehensiveness or
5259  uneasiness—to call it so—which I felt, yet whenever I came to look
5260  about me in the ship, it seemed against all warrantry to cherish such
5261  emotions. For though the harpooneers, with the great body of the crew,
5262  were a far more barbaric, heathenish, and motley set than any of the
5263  tame merchant-ship companies which my previous experiences had made me
5264  acquainted with, still I ascribed this—and rightly ascribed it—to the
5265  fierce uniqueness of the very nature of that wild Scandinavian vocation
5266  in which I had so abandonedly embarked. But it was especially the
5267  aspect of the three chief officers of the ship, the mates, which was
5268  most forcibly calculated to allay these colourless misgivings, and
5269  induce confidence and cheerfulness in every presentment of the voyage.
5270  Three better, more likely sea-officers and men, each in his own
5271  different way, could not readily be found, and they were every one of
5272  them Americans; a Nantucketer, a Vineyarder, a Cape man. Now, it being
5273  Christmas when the ship shot from out her harbor, for a space we had
5274  biting Polar weather, though all the time running away from it to the
5275  southward; and by every degree and minute of latitude which we sailed,
5276  gradually leaving that merciless winter, and all its intolerable
5277  weather behind us. It was one of those less lowering, but still grey
5278  and gloomy enough mornings of the transition, when with a fair wind the
5279  ship was rushing through the water with a vindictive sort of leaping
5280  and melancholy rapidity, that as I mounted to the deck at the call of
5281  the forenoon watch, so soon as I levelled my glance towards the
5282  taffrail, foreboding shivers ran over me. Reality outran apprehension;
5283  Captain Ahab stood upon his quarter-deck.
5284  
5285  There seemed no sign of common bodily illness about him, nor of the
5286  recovery from any. He looked like a man cut away from the stake, when
5287  the fire has overrunningly wasted all the limbs without consuming them,
5288  or taking away one particle from their compacted aged robustness. His
5289  whole high, broad form, seemed made of solid bronze, and shaped in an
5290  unalterable mould, like Cellini’s cast Perseus. Threading its way out
5291  from among his grey hairs, and continuing right down one side of his
5292  tawny scorched face and neck, till it disappeared in his clothing, you
5293  saw a slender rod-like mark, lividly whitish. It resembled that
5294  perpendicular seam sometimes made in the straight, lofty trunk of a
5295  great tree, when the upper lightning tearingly darts down it, and
5296  without wrenching a single twig, peels and grooves out the bark from
5297  top to bottom, ere running off into the soil, leaving the tree still
5298  greenly alive, but branded. Whether that mark was born with him, or
5299  whether it was the scar left by some desperate wound, no one could
5300  certainly say. By some tacit consent, throughout the voyage little or
5301  no allusion was made to it, especially by the mates. But once
5302  Tashtego’s senior, an old Gay-Head Indian among the crew,
5303  superstitiously asserted that not till he was full forty years old did
5304  Ahab become that way branded, and then it came upon him, not in the
5305  fury of any mortal fray, but in an elemental strife at sea. Yet, this
5306  wild hint seemed inferentially negatived, by what a grey Manxman
5307  insinuated, an old sepulchral man, who, having never before sailed out
5308  of Nantucket, had never ere this laid eye upon wild Ahab. Nevertheless,
5309  the old sea-traditions, the immemorial credulities, popularly invested
5310  this old Manxman with preternatural powers of discernment. So that no
5311  white sailor seriously contradicted him when he said that if ever
5312  Captain Ahab should be tranquilly laid out—which might hardly come to
5313  pass, so he muttered—then, whoever should do that last office for the
5314  dead, would find a birth-mark on him from crown to sole.
5315  
5316  So powerfully did the whole grim aspect of Ahab affect me, and the
5317  livid brand which streaked it, that for the first few moments I hardly
5318  noted that not a little of this overbearing grimness was owing to the
5319  barbaric white leg upon which he partly stood. It had previously come
5320  to me that this ivory leg had at sea been fashioned from the polished
5321  bone of the sperm whale’s jaw. “Aye, he was dismasted off Japan,” said
5322  the old Gay-Head Indian once; “but like his dismasted craft, he shipped
5323  another mast without coming home for it. He has a quiver of ’em.”
5324  
5325  I was struck with the singular posture he maintained. Upon each side of
5326  the Pequod’s quarter deck, and pretty close to the mizzen shrouds,
5327  there was an auger hole, bored about half an inch or so, into the
5328  plank. His bone leg steadied in that hole; one arm elevated, and
5329  holding by a shroud; Captain Ahab stood erect, looking straight out
5330  beyond the ship’s ever-pitching prow. There was an infinity of firmest
5331  fortitude, a determinate, unsurrenderable wilfulness, in the fixed and
5332  fearless, forward dedication of that glance. Not a word he spoke; nor
5333  did his officers say aught to him; though by all their minutest
5334  gestures and expressions, they plainly showed the uneasy, if not
5335  painful, consciousness of being under a troubled master-eye. And not
5336  only that, but moody stricken Ahab stood before them with a crucifixion
5337  in his face; in all the nameless regal overbearing dignity of some
5338  mighty woe.
5339  
5340  Ere long, from his first visit in the air, he withdrew into his cabin.
5341  But after that morning, he was every day visible to the crew; either
5342  standing in his pivot-hole, or seated upon an ivory stool he had; or
5343  heavily walking the deck. As the sky grew less gloomy; indeed, began to
5344  grow a little genial, he became still less and less a recluse; as if,
5345  when the ship had sailed from home, nothing but the dead wintry
5346  bleakness of the sea had then kept him so secluded. And, by and by, it
5347  came to pass, that he was almost continually in the air; but, as yet,
5348  for all that he said, or perceptibly did, on the at last sunny deck, he
5349  seemed as unnecessary there as another mast. But the Pequod was only
5350  making a passage now; not regularly cruising; nearly all whaling
5351  preparatives needing supervision the mates were fully competent to, so
5352  that there was little or nothing, out of himself, to employ or excite
5353  Ahab, now; and thus chase away, for that one interval, the clouds that
5354  layer upon layer were piled upon his brow, as ever all clouds choose
5355  the loftiest peaks to pile themselves upon.
5356  
5357  Nevertheless, ere long, the warm, warbling persuasiveness of the
5358  pleasant, holiday weather we came to, seemed gradually to charm him
5359  from his mood. For, as when the red-cheeked, dancing girls, April and
5360  May, trip home to the wintry, misanthropic woods; even the barest,
5361  ruggedest, most thunder-cloven old oak will at least send forth some
5362  few green sprouts, to welcome such glad-hearted visitants; so Ahab did,
5363  in the end, a little respond to the playful allurings of that girlish
5364  air. More than once did he put forth the faint blossom of a look,
5365  which, in any other man, would have soon flowered out in a smile.
5366  
5367  
5368  CHAPTER 29. Enter Ahab; to Him, Stubb.
5369  
5370  Some days elapsed, and ice and icebergs all astern, the Pequod now went
5371  rolling through the bright Quito spring, which, at sea, almost
5372  perpetually reigns on the threshold of the eternal August of the
5373  Tropic. The warmly cool, clear, ringing, perfumed, overflowing,
5374  redundant days, were as crystal goblets of Persian sherbet, heaped
5375  up—flaked up, with rose-water snow. The starred and stately nights
5376  seemed haughty dames in jewelled velvets, nursing at home in lonely
5377  pride, the memory of their absent conquering Earls, the golden helmeted
5378  suns! For sleeping man, ’twas hard to choose between such winsome days
5379  and such seducing nights. But all the witcheries of that unwaning
5380  weather did not merely lend new spells and potencies to the outward
5381  world. Inward they turned upon the soul, especially when the still mild
5382  hours of eve came on; then, memory shot her crystals as the clear ice
5383  most forms of noiseless twilights. And all these subtle agencies, more
5384  and more they wrought on Ahab’s texture.
5385  
5386  Old age is always wakeful; as if, the longer linked with life, the less
5387  man has to do with aught that looks like death. Among sea-commanders,
5388  the old greybeards will oftenest leave their berths to visit the
5389  night-cloaked deck. It was so with Ahab; only that now, of late, he
5390  seemed so much to live in the open air, that truly speaking, his visits
5391  were more to the cabin, than from the cabin to the planks. “It feels
5392  like going down into one’s tomb,”—he would mutter to himself—“for an
5393  old captain like me to be descending this narrow scuttle, to go to my
5394  grave-dug berth.”
5395  
5396  So, almost every twenty-four hours, when the watches of the night were
5397  set, and the band on deck sentinelled the slumbers of the band below;
5398  and when if a rope was to be hauled upon the forecastle, the sailors
5399  flung it not rudely down, as by day, but with some cautiousness dropt
5400  it to its place for fear of disturbing their slumbering shipmates; when
5401  this sort of steady quietude would begin to prevail, habitually, the
5402  silent steersman would watch the cabin-scuttle; and ere long the old
5403  man would emerge, gripping at the iron banister, to help his crippled
5404  way. Some considering touch of humanity was in him; for at times like
5405  these, he usually abstained from patrolling the quarter-deck; because
5406  to his wearied mates, seeking repose within six inches of his ivory
5407  heel, such would have been the reverberating crack and din of that bony
5408  step, that their dreams would have been on the crunching teeth of
5409  sharks. But once, the mood was on him too deep for common regardings;
5410  and as with heavy, lumber-like pace he was measuring the ship from
5411  taffrail to mainmast, Stubb, the old second mate, came up from below,
5412  with a certain unassured, deprecating humorousness, hinted that if
5413  Captain Ahab was pleased to walk the planks, then, no one could say
5414  nay; but there might be some way of muffling the noise; hinting
5415  something indistinctly and hesitatingly about a globe of tow, and the
5416  insertion into it, of the ivory heel. Ah! Stubb, thou didst not know
5417  Ahab then.
5418  
5419  “Am I a cannon-ball, Stubb,” said Ahab, “that thou wouldst wad me that
5420  fashion? But go thy ways; I had forgot. Below to thy nightly grave;
5421  where such as ye sleep between shrouds, to use ye to the filling one at
5422  last.—Down, dog, and kennel!”
5423  
5424  Starting at the unforseen concluding exclamation of the so suddenly
5425  scornful old man, Stubb was speechless a moment; then said excitedly,
5426  “I am not used to be spoken to that way, sir; I do but less than half
5427  like it, sir.”
5428  
5429  “Avast! gritted Ahab between his set teeth, and violently moving away,
5430  as if to avoid some passionate temptation.
5431  
5432  “No, sir; not yet,” said Stubb, emboldened, “I will not tamely be
5433  called a dog, sir.”
5434  
5435  “Then be called ten times a donkey, and a mule, and an ass, and begone,
5436  or I’ll clear the world of thee!”
5437  
5438  As he said this, Ahab advanced upon him with such overbearing terrors
5439  in his aspect, that Stubb involuntarily retreated.
5440  
5441  “I was never served so before without giving a hard blow for it,”
5442  muttered Stubb, as he found himself descending the cabin-scuttle. “It’s
5443  very queer. Stop, Stubb; somehow, now, I don’t well know whether to go
5444  back and strike him, or—what’s that?—down here on my knees and pray for
5445  him? Yes, that was the thought coming up in me; but it would be the
5446  first time I ever _did_ pray. It’s queer; very queer; and he’s queer
5447  too; aye, take him fore and aft, he’s about the queerest old man Stubb
5448  ever sailed with. How he flashed at me!—his eyes like powder-pans! is
5449  he mad? Anyway there’s something on his mind, as sure as there must be
5450  something on a deck when it cracks. He aint in his bed now, either,
5451  more than three hours out of the twenty-four; and he don’t sleep then.
5452  Didn’t that Dough-Boy, the steward, tell me that of a morning he always
5453  finds the old man’s hammock clothes all rumpled and tumbled, and the
5454  sheets down at the foot, and the coverlid almost tied into knots, and
5455  the pillow a sort of frightful hot, as though a baked brick had been on
5456  it? A hot old man! I guess he’s got what some folks ashore call a
5457  conscience; it’s a kind of Tic-Dolly-row they say—worse nor a
5458  toothache. Well, well; I don’t know what it is, but the Lord keep me
5459  from catching it. He’s full of riddles; I wonder what he goes into the
5460  after hold for, every night, as Dough-Boy tells me he suspects; what’s
5461  that for, I should like to know? Who’s made appointments with him in
5462  the hold? Ain’t that queer, now? But there’s no telling, it’s the old
5463  game—Here goes for a snooze. Damn me, it’s worth a fellow’s while to be
5464  born into the world, if only to fall right asleep. And now that I think
5465  of it, that’s about the first thing babies do, and that’s a sort of
5466  queer, too. Damn me, but all things are queer, come to think of ’em.
5467  But that’s against my principles. Think not, is my eleventh
5468  commandment; and sleep when you can, is my twelfth—So here goes again.
5469  But how’s that? didn’t he call me a dog? blazes! he called me ten times
5470  a donkey, and piled a lot of jackasses on top of _that!_ He might as
5471  well have kicked me, and done with it. Maybe he _did_ kick me, and I
5472  didn’t observe it, I was so taken all aback with his brow, somehow. It
5473  flashed like a bleached bone. What the devil’s the matter with me? I
5474  don’t stand right on my legs. Coming afoul of that old man has a sort
5475  of turned me wrong side out. By the Lord, I must have been dreaming,
5476  though—How? how? how?—but the only way’s to stash it; so here goes to
5477  hammock again; and in the morning, I’ll see how this plaguey juggling
5478  thinks over by daylight.”
5479  
5480  
5481  CHAPTER 30. The Pipe.
5482  
5483  When Stubb had departed, Ahab stood for a while leaning over the
5484  bulwarks; and then, as had been usual with him of late, calling a
5485  sailor of the watch, he sent him below for his ivory stool, and also
5486  his pipe. Lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp and planting the stool
5487  on the weather side of the deck, he sat and smoked.
5488  
5489  In old Norse times, the thrones of the sea-loving Danish kings were
5490  fabricated, saith tradition, of the tusks of the narwhale. How could
5491  one look at Ahab then, seated on that tripod of bones, without
5492  bethinking him of the royalty it symbolized? For a Khan of the plank,
5493  and a king of the sea, and a great lord of Leviathans was Ahab.
5494  
5495  Some moments passed, during which the thick vapor came from his mouth
5496  in quick and constant puffs, which blew back again into his face. “How
5497  now,” he soliloquized at last, withdrawing the tube, “this smoking no
5498  longer soothes. Oh, my pipe! hard must it go with me if thy charm be
5499  gone! Here have I been unconsciously toiling, not pleasuring—aye, and
5500  ignorantly smoking to windward all the while; to windward, and with
5501  such nervous whiffs, as if, like the dying whale, my final jets were
5502  the strongest and fullest of trouble. What business have I with this
5503  pipe? This thing that is meant for sereneness, to send up mild white
5504  vapors among mild white hairs, not among torn iron-grey locks like
5505  mine. I’ll smoke no more—”
5506  
5507  He tossed the still lighted pipe into the sea. The fire hissed in the
5508  waves; the same instant the ship shot by the bubble the sinking pipe
5509  made. With slouched hat, Ahab lurchingly paced the planks.
5510  
5511  
5512  CHAPTER 31. Queen Mab.
5513  
5514  Next morning Stubb accosted Flask.
5515  
5516  “Such a queer dream, King-Post, I never had. You know the old man’s
5517  ivory leg, well I dreamed he kicked me with it; and when I tried to
5518  kick back, upon my soul, my little man, I kicked my leg right off! And
5519  then, presto! Ahab seemed a pyramid, and I, like a blazing fool, kept
5520  kicking at it. But what was still more curious, Flask—you know how
5521  curious all dreams are—through all this rage that I was in, I somehow
5522  seemed to be thinking to myself, that after all, it was not much of an
5523  insult, that kick from Ahab. ‘Why,’ thinks I, ‘what’s the row? It’s not
5524  a real leg, only a false leg.’ And there’s a mighty difference between
5525  a living thump and a dead thump. That’s what makes a blow from the
5526  hand, Flask, fifty times more savage to bear than a blow from a cane.
5527  The living member—that makes the living insult, my little man. And
5528  thinks I to myself all the while, mind, while I was stubbing my silly
5529  toes against that cursed pyramid—so confoundedly contradictory was it
5530  all, all the while, I say, I was thinking to myself, ‘what’s his leg
5531  now, but a cane—a whalebone cane. Yes,’ thinks I, ‘it was only a
5532  playful cudgelling—in fact, only a whaleboning that he gave me—not a
5533  base kick. Besides,’ thinks I, ‘look at it once; why, the end of it—the
5534  foot part—what a small sort of end it is; whereas, if a broad footed
5535  farmer kicked me, _there’s_ a devilish broad insult. But this insult is
5536  whittled down to a point only.’ But now comes the greatest joke of the
5537  dream, Flask. While I was battering away at the pyramid, a sort of
5538  badger-haired old merman, with a hump on his back, takes me by the
5539  shoulders, and slews me round. ‘What are you ’bout?’ says he. Slid!
5540  man, but I was frightened. Such a phiz! But, somehow, next moment I was
5541  over the fright. ‘What am I about?’ says I at last. ‘And what business
5542  is that of yours, I should like to know, Mr. Humpback? Do _you_ want a
5543  kick?’ By the lord, Flask, I had no sooner said that, than he turned
5544  round his stern to me, bent over, and dragging up a lot of seaweed he
5545  had for a clout—what do you think, I saw?—why thunder alive, man, his
5546  stern was stuck full of marlinspikes, with the points out. Says I, on
5547  second thoughts, ‘I guess I won’t kick you, old fellow.’ ‘Wise Stubb,’
5548  said he, ‘wise Stubb;’ and kept muttering it all the time, a sort of
5549  eating of his own gums like a chimney hag. Seeing he wasn’t going to
5550  stop saying over his ‘wise Stubb, wise Stubb,’ I thought I might as
5551  well fall to kicking the pyramid again. But I had only just lifted my
5552  foot for it, when he roared out, ‘Stop that kicking!’ ‘Halloa,’ says I,
5553  ‘what’s the matter now, old fellow?’ ‘Look ye here,’ says he; ‘let’s
5554  argue the insult. Captain Ahab kicked ye, didn’t he?’ ‘Yes, he did,’
5555  says I—‘right _here_ it was.’ ‘Very good,’ says he—‘he used his ivory
5556  leg, didn’t he?’ ‘Yes, he did,’ says I. ‘Well then,’ says he, ‘wise
5557  Stubb, what have you to complain of? Didn’t he kick with right good
5558  will? it wasn’t a common pitch pine leg he kicked with, was it? No, you
5559  were kicked by a great man, and with a beautiful ivory leg, Stubb. It’s
5560  an honor; I consider it an honor. Listen, wise Stubb. In old England
5561  the greatest lords think it great glory to be slapped by a queen, and
5562  made garter-knights of; but, be _your_ boast, Stubb, that ye were
5563  kicked by old Ahab, and made a wise man of. Remember what I say; _be_
5564  kicked by him; account his kicks honors; and on no account kick back;
5565  for you can’t help yourself, wise Stubb. Don’t you see that pyramid?’
5566  With that, he all of a sudden seemed somehow, in some queer fashion, to
5567  swim off into the air. I snored; rolled over; and there I was in my
5568  hammock! Now, what do you think of that dream, Flask?”
5569  
5570  “I don’t know; it seems a sort of foolish to me, tho.’”
5571  
5572  “May be; may be. But it’s made a wise man of me, Flask. D’ye see Ahab
5573  standing there, sideways looking over the stern? Well, the best thing
5574  you can do, Flask, is to let the old man alone; never speak to him,
5575  whatever he says. Halloa! What’s that he shouts? Hark!”
5576  
5577  “Mast-head, there! Look sharp, all of ye! There are whales hereabouts!
5578  
5579  “If ye see a white one, split your lungs for him!
5580  
5581  “What do you think of that now, Flask? ain’t there a small drop of
5582  something queer about that, eh? A white whale—did ye mark that, man?
5583  Look ye—there’s something special in the wind. Stand by for it, Flask.
5584  Ahab has that that’s bloody on his mind. But, mum; he comes this way.”
5585  
5586  
5587  CHAPTER 32. Cetology.
5588  
5589  Already we are boldly launched upon the deep; but soon we shall be lost
5590  in its unshored, harbourless immensities. Ere that come to pass; ere
5591  the Pequod’s weedy hull rolls side by side with the barnacled hulls of
5592  the leviathan; at the outset it is but well to attend to a matter
5593  almost indispensable to a thorough appreciative understanding of the
5594  more special leviathanic revelations and allusions of all sorts which
5595  are to follow.
5596  
5597  It is some systematized exhibition of the whale in his broad genera,
5598  that I would now fain put before you. Yet is it no easy task. The
5599  classification of the constituents of a chaos, nothing less is here
5600  essayed. Listen to what the best and latest authorities have laid down.
5601  
5602  “No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is entitled
5603  Cetology,” says Captain Scoresby, A.D. 1820.
5604  
5605  “It is not my intention, were it in my power, to enter into the inquiry
5606  as to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and families.
5607  * * * Utter confusion exists among the historians of this animal”
5608  (sperm whale), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. 1839.
5609  
5610  “Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters.”
5611  “Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea.” “A field
5612  strewn with thorns.” “All these incomplete indications but serve to
5613  torture us naturalists.”
5614  
5615  Thus speak of the whale, the great Cuvier, and John Hunter, and Lesson,
5616  those lights of zoology and anatomy. Nevertheless, though of real
5617  knowledge there be little, yet of books there are a plenty; and so in
5618  some small degree, with cetology, or the science of whales. Many are
5619  the men, small and great, old and new, landsmen and seamen, who have at
5620  large or in little, written of the whale. Run over a few:—The Authors
5621  of the Bible; Aristotle; Pliny; Aldrovandi; Sir Thomas Browne; Gesner;
5622  Ray; Linnæus; Rondeletius; Willoughby; Green; Artedi; Sibbald; Brisson;
5623  Marten; Lacépède; Bonneterre; Desmarest; Baron Cuvier; Frederick
5624  Cuvier; John Hunter; Owen; Scoresby; Beale; Bennett; J. Ross Browne;
5625  the Author of Miriam Coffin; Olmstead; and the Rev. T. Cheever. But to
5626  what ultimate generalizing purpose all these have written, the above
5627  cited extracts will show.
5628  
5629  Of the names in this list of whale authors, only those following Owen
5630  ever saw living whales; and but one of them was a real professional
5631  harpooneer and whaleman. I mean Captain Scoresby. On the separate
5632  subject of the Greenland or right-whale, he is the best existing
5633  authority. But Scoresby knew nothing and says nothing of the great
5634  sperm whale, compared with which the Greenland whale is almost unworthy
5635  mentioning. And here be it said, that the Greenland whale is an usurper
5636  upon the throne of the seas. He is not even by any means the largest of
5637  the whales. Yet, owing to the long priority of his claims, and the
5638  profound ignorance which, till some seventy years back, invested the
5639  then fabulous or utterly unknown sperm-whale, and which ignorance to
5640  this present day still reigns in all but some few scientific retreats
5641  and whale-ports; this usurpation has been every way complete. Reference
5642  to nearly all the leviathanic allusions in the great poets of past
5643  days, will satisfy you that the Greenland whale, without one rival, was
5644  to them the monarch of the seas. But the time has at last come for a
5645  new proclamation. This is Charing Cross; hear ye! good people all,—the
5646  Greenland whale is deposed,—the great sperm whale now reigneth!
5647  
5648  There are only two books in being which at all pretend to put the
5649  living sperm whale before you, and at the same time, in the remotest
5650  degree succeed in the attempt. Those books are Beale’s and Bennett’s;
5651  both in their time surgeons to English South-Sea whale-ships, and both
5652  exact and reliable men. The original matter touching the sperm whale to
5653  be found in their volumes is necessarily small; but so far as it goes,
5654  it is of excellent quality, though mostly confined to scientific
5655  description. As yet, however, the sperm whale, scientific or poetic,
5656  lives not complete in any literature. Far above all other hunted
5657  whales, his is an unwritten life.
5658  
5659  Now the various species of whales need some sort of popular
5660  comprehensive classification, if only an easy outline one for the
5661  present, hereafter to be filled in all its departments by subsequent
5662  laborers. As no better man advances to take this matter in hand, I
5663  hereupon offer my own poor endeavors. I promise nothing complete;
5664  because any human thing supposed to be complete, must for that very
5665  reason infallibly be faulty. I shall not pretend to a minute anatomical
5666  description of the various species, or—in this place at least—to much
5667  of any description. My object here is simply to project the draught of
5668  a systematization of cetology. I am the architect, not the builder.
5669  
5670  But it is a ponderous task; no ordinary letter-sorter in the
5671  Post-Office is equal to it. To grope down into the bottom of the sea
5672  after them; to have one’s hands among the unspeakable foundations,
5673  ribs, and very pelvis of the world; this is a fearful thing. What am I
5674  that I should essay to hook the nose of this leviathan! The awful
5675  tauntings in Job might well appal me. Will he (the leviathan) make a
5676  covenant with thee? Behold the hope of him is vain! But I have swam
5677  through libraries and sailed through oceans; I have had to do with
5678  whales with these visible hands; I am in earnest; and I will try. There
5679  are some preliminaries to settle.
5680
