5681  First: The uncertain, unsettled condition of this science of Cetology
5682  is in the very vestibule attested by the fact, that in some quarters it
5683  still remains a moot point whether a whale be a fish. In his System of
5684  Nature, A.D. 1776, Linnæus declares, “I hereby separate the whales from
5685  the fish.” But of my own knowledge, I know that down to the year 1850,
5686  sharks and shad, alewives and herring, against Linnæus’s express edict,
5687  were still found dividing the possession of the same seas with the
5688  Leviathan.
5689  
5690  The grounds upon which Linnæus would fain have banished the whales from
5691  the waters, he states as follows: “On account of their warm bilocular
5692  heart, their lungs, their movable eyelids, their hollow ears, penem
5693  intrantem feminam mammis lactantem,” and finally, “ex lege naturæ jure
5694  meritoque.” I submitted all this to my friends Simeon Macey and Charley
5695  Coffin, of Nantucket, both messmates of mine in a certain voyage, and
5696  they united in the opinion that the reasons set forth were altogether
5697  insufficient. Charley profanely hinted they were humbug.
5698  
5699  Be it known that, waiving all argument, I take the good old fashioned
5700  ground that the whale is a fish, and call upon holy Jonah to back me.
5701  This fundamental thing settled, the next point is, in what internal
5702  respect does the whale differ from other fish. Above, Linnæus has given
5703  you those items. But in brief, they are these: lungs and warm blood;
5704  whereas, all other fish are lungless and cold blooded.
5705  
5706  Next: how shall we define the whale, by his obvious externals, so as
5707  conspicuously to label him for all time to come? To be short, then, a
5708  whale is _a spouting fish with a horizontal tail_. There you have him.
5709  However contracted, that definition is the result of expanded
5710  meditation. A walrus spouts much like a whale, but the walrus is not a
5711  fish, because he is amphibious. But the last term of the definition is
5712  still more cogent, as coupled with the first. Almost any one must have
5713  noticed that all the fish familiar to landsmen have not a flat, but a
5714  vertical, or up-and-down tail. Whereas, among spouting fish the tail,
5715  though it may be similarly shaped, invariably assumes a horizontal
5716  position.
5717  
5718  By the above definition of what a whale is, I do by no means exclude
5719  from the leviathanic brotherhood any sea creature hitherto identified
5720  with the whale by the best informed Nantucketers; nor, on the other
5721  hand, link with it any fish hitherto authoritatively regarded as
5722  alien.* Hence, all the smaller, spouting, and horizontal tailed fish
5723  must be included in this ground-plan of Cetology. Now, then, come the
5724  grand divisions of the entire whale host.
5725  
5726  *I am aware that down to the present time, the fish styled Lamatins and
5727  Dugongs (Pig-fish and Sow-fish of the Coffins of Nantucket) are
5728  included by many naturalists among the whales. But as these pig-fish
5729  are a noisy, contemptible set, mostly lurking in the mouths of rivers,
5730  and feeding on wet hay, and especially as they do not spout, I deny
5731  their credentials as whales; and have presented them with their
5732  passports to quit the Kingdom of Cetology.
5733  
5734  First: According to magnitude I divide the whales into three primary
5735  BOOKS (subdivisible into CHAPTERS), and these shall comprehend them
5736  all, both small and large.
5737  
5738  I. THE FOLIO WHALE; II. the OCTAVO WHALE; III. the DUODECIMO WHALE.
5739  
5740  As the type of the FOLIO I present the _Sperm Whale_; of the OCTAVO,
5741  the _Grampus_; of the DUODECIMO, the _Porpoise_.
5742  
5743  FOLIOS. Among these I here include the following chapters:—I. The
5744  _Sperm Whale_; II. the _Right Whale_; III. the _Fin-Back Whale_; IV.
5745  the _Hump-backed Whale_; V. the _Razor Back Whale_; VI. the _Sulphur
5746  Bottom Whale_.
5747  
5748  BOOK I. (_Folio_), CHAPTER I. (_Sperm Whale_).—This whale, among the
5749  English of old vaguely known as the Trumpa whale, and the Physeter
5750  whale, and the Anvil Headed whale, is the present Cachalot of the
5751  French, and the Pottsfich of the Germans, and the Macrocephalus of the
5752  Long Words. He is, without doubt, the largest inhabitant of the globe;
5753  the most formidable of all whales to encounter; the most majestic in
5754  aspect; and lastly, by far the most valuable in commerce; he being the
5755  only creature from which that valuable substance, spermaceti, is
5756  obtained. All his peculiarities will, in many other places, be enlarged
5757  upon. It is chiefly with his name that I now have to do. Philologically
5758  considered, it is absurd. Some centuries ago, when the Sperm whale was
5759  almost wholly unknown in his own proper individuality, and when his oil
5760  was only accidentally obtained from the stranded fish; in those days
5761  spermaceti, it would seem, was popularly supposed to be derived from a
5762  creature identical with the one then known in England as the Greenland
5763  or Right Whale. It was the idea also, that this same spermaceti was
5764  that quickening humor of the Greenland Whale which the first syllable
5765  of the word literally expresses. In those times, also, spermaceti was
5766  exceedingly scarce, not being used for light, but only as an ointment
5767  and medicament. It was only to be had from the druggists as you
5768  nowadays buy an ounce of rhubarb. When, as I opine, in the course of
5769  time, the true nature of spermaceti became known, its original name was
5770  still retained by the dealers; no doubt to enhance its value by a
5771  notion so strangely significant of its scarcity. And so the appellation
5772  must at last have come to be bestowed upon the whale from which this
5773  spermaceti was really derived.
5774  
5775  BOOK I. (_Folio_), CHAPTER II. (_Right Whale_).—In one respect this is
5776  the most venerable of the leviathans, being the one first regularly
5777  hunted by man. It yields the article commonly known as whalebone or
5778  baleen; and the oil specially known as “whale oil,” an inferior article
5779  in commerce. Among the fishermen, he is indiscriminately designated by
5780  all the following titles: The Whale; the Greenland Whale; the Black
5781  Whale; the Great Whale; the True Whale; the Right Whale. There is a
5782  deal of obscurity concerning the identity of the species thus
5783  multitudinously baptised. What then is the whale, which I include in
5784  the second species of my Folios? It is the Great Mysticetus of the
5785  English naturalists; the Greenland Whale of the English whalemen; the
5786  Baleine Ordinaire of the French whalemen; the Growlands Walfish of the
5787  Swedes. It is the whale which for more than two centuries past has been
5788  hunted by the Dutch and English in the Arctic seas; it is the whale
5789  which the American fishermen have long pursued in the Indian ocean, on
5790  the Brazil Banks, on the Nor’ West Coast, and various other parts of
5791  the world, designated by them Right Whale Cruising Grounds.
5792  
5793  Some pretend to see a difference between the Greenland whale of the
5794  English and the right whale of the Americans. But they precisely agree
5795  in all their grand features; nor has there yet been presented a single
5796  determinate fact upon which to ground a radical distinction. It is by
5797  endless subdivisions based upon the most inconclusive differences, that
5798  some departments of natural history become so repellingly intricate.
5799  The right whale will be elsewhere treated of at some length, with
5800  reference to elucidating the sperm whale.
5801  
5802  BOOK I. (_Folio_), CHAPTER III. (_Fin-Back_).—Under this head I reckon
5803  a monster which, by the various names of Fin-Back, Tall-Spout, and
5804  Long-John, has been seen almost in every sea and is commonly the whale
5805  whose distant jet is so often descried by passengers crossing the
5806  Atlantic, in the New York packet-tracks. In the length he attains, and
5807  in his baleen, the Fin-back resembles the right whale, but is of a less
5808  portly girth, and a lighter colour, approaching to olive. His great
5809  lips present a cable-like aspect, formed by the intertwisting, slanting
5810  folds of large wrinkles. His grand distinguishing feature, the fin,
5811  from which he derives his name, is often a conspicuous object. This fin
5812  is some three or four feet long, growing vertically from the hinder
5813  part of the back, of an angular shape, and with a very sharp pointed
5814  end. Even if not the slightest other part of the creature be visible,
5815  this isolated fin will, at times, be seen plainly projecting from the
5816  surface. When the sea is moderately calm, and slightly marked with
5817  spherical ripples, and this gnomon-like fin stands up and casts shadows
5818  upon the wrinkled surface, it may well be supposed that the watery
5819  circle surrounding it somewhat resembles a dial, with its style and
5820  wavy hour-lines graved on it. On that Ahaz-dial the shadow often goes
5821  back. The Fin-Back is not gregarious. He seems a whale-hater, as some
5822  men are man-haters. Very shy; always going solitary; unexpectedly
5823  rising to the surface in the remotest and most sullen waters; his
5824  straight and single lofty jet rising like a tall misanthropic spear
5825  upon a barren plain; gifted with such wondrous power and velocity in
5826  swimming, as to defy all present pursuit from man; this leviathan seems
5827  the banished and unconquerable Cain of his race, bearing for his mark
5828  that style upon his back. From having the baleen in his mouth, the
5829  Fin-Back is sometimes included with the right whale, among a theoretic
5830  species denominated _Whalebone whales_, that is, whales with baleen. Of
5831  these so called Whalebone whales, there would seem to be several
5832  varieties, most of which, however, are little known. Broad-nosed whales
5833  and beaked whales; pike-headed whales; bunched whales; under-jawed
5834  whales and rostrated whales, are the fishermen’s names for a few sorts.
5835  
5836  In connection with this appellative of “Whalebone whales,” it is of
5837  great importance to mention, that however such a nomenclature may be
5838  convenient in facilitating allusions to some kind of whales, yet it is
5839  in vain to attempt a clear classification of the Leviathan, founded
5840  upon either his baleen, or hump, or fin, or teeth; notwithstanding that
5841  those marked parts or features very obviously seem better adapted to
5842  afford the basis for a regular system of Cetology than any other
5843  detached bodily distinctions, which the whale, in his kinds, presents.
5844  How then? The baleen, hump, back-fin, and teeth; these are things whose
5845  peculiarities are indiscriminately dispersed among all sorts of whales,
5846  without any regard to what may be the nature of their structure in
5847  other and more essential particulars. Thus, the sperm whale and the
5848  humpbacked whale, each has a hump; but there the similitude ceases.
5849  Then, this same humpbacked whale and the Greenland whale, each of these
5850  has baleen; but there again the similitude ceases. And it is just the
5851  same with the other parts above mentioned. In various sorts of whales,
5852  they form such irregular combinations; or, in the case of any one of
5853  them detached, such an irregular isolation; as utterly to defy all
5854  general methodization formed upon such a basis. On this rock every one
5855  of the whale-naturalists has split.
5856  
5857  But it may possibly be conceived that, in the internal parts of the
5858  whale, in his anatomy—there, at least, we shall be able to hit the
5859  right classification. Nay; what thing, for example, is there in the
5860  Greenland whale’s anatomy more striking than his baleen? Yet we have
5861  seen that by his baleen it is impossible correctly to classify the
5862  Greenland whale. And if you descend into the bowels of the various
5863  leviathans, why there you will not find distinctions a fiftieth part as
5864  available to the systematizer as those external ones already
5865  enumerated. What then remains? nothing but to take hold of the whales
5866  bodily, in their entire liberal volume, and boldly sort them that way.
5867  And this is the Bibliographical system here adopted; and it is the only
5868  one that can possibly succeed, for it alone is practicable. To proceed.
5869  
5870  BOOK I. (_Folio_) CHAPTER IV. (_Hump Back_).—This whale is often seen
5871  on the northern American coast. He has been frequently captured there,
5872  and towed into harbor. He has a great pack on him like a peddler; or
5873  you might call him the Elephant and Castle whale. At any rate, the
5874  popular name for him does not sufficiently distinguish him, since the
5875  sperm whale also has a hump though a smaller one. His oil is not very
5876  valuable. He has baleen. He is the most gamesome and light-hearted of
5877  all the whales, making more gay foam and white water generally than any
5878  other of them.
5879  
5880  BOOK I. (_Folio_), CHAPTER V. (_Razor Back_).—Of this whale little is
5881  known but his name. I have seen him at a distance off Cape Horn. Of a
5882  retiring nature, he eludes both hunters and philosophers. Though no
5883  coward, he has never yet shown any part of him but his back, which
5884  rises in a long sharp ridge. Let him go. I know little more of him, nor
5885  does anybody else.
5886  
5887  BOOK I. (_Folio_), CHAPTER VI. (_Sulphur Bottom_).—Another retiring
5888  gentleman, with a brimstone belly, doubtless got by scraping along the
5889  Tartarian tiles in some of his profounder divings. He is seldom seen;
5890  at least I have never seen him except in the remoter southern seas, and
5891  then always at too great a distance to study his countenance. He is
5892  never chased; he would run away with rope-walks of line. Prodigies are
5893  told of him. Adieu, Sulphur Bottom! I can say nothing more that is true
5894  of ye, nor can the oldest Nantucketer.
5895  
5896  Thus ends BOOK I. (_Folio_), and now begins BOOK II. (_Octavo_).
5897  
5898  OCTAVOES.*—These embrace the whales of middling magnitude, among which
5899  present may be numbered:—I., the _Grampus_; II., the _Black Fish_;
5900  III., the _Narwhale_; IV., the _Thrasher_; V., the _Killer_.
5901  
5902  *Why this book of whales is not denominated the Quarto is very plain.
5903  Because, while the whales of this order, though smaller than those of
5904  the former order, nevertheless retain a proportionate likeness to them
5905  in figure, yet the bookbinder’s Quarto volume in its dimensioned form
5906  does not preserve the shape of the Folio volume, but the Octavo volume
5907  does.
5908  
5909  BOOK II. (_Octavo_), CHAPTER I. (_Grampus_).—Though this fish, whose
5910  loud sonorous breathing, or rather blowing, has furnished a proverb to
5911  landsmen, is so well known a denizen of the deep, yet is he not
5912  popularly classed among whales. But possessing all the grand
5913  distinctive features of the leviathan, most naturalists have recognised
5914  him for one. He is of moderate octavo size, varying from fifteen to
5915  twenty-five feet in length, and of corresponding dimensions round the
5916  waist. He swims in herds; he is never regularly hunted, though his oil
5917  is considerable in quantity, and pretty good for light. By some
5918  fishermen his approach is regarded as premonitory of the advance of the
5919  great sperm whale.
5920  
5921  BOOK II. (_Octavo_), CHAPTER II. (_Black Fish_).—I give the popular
5922  fishermen’s names for all these fish, for generally they are the best.
5923  Where any name happens to be vague or inexpressive, I shall say so, and
5924  suggest another. I do so now, touching the Black Fish, so-called,
5925  because blackness is the rule among almost all whales. So, call him the
5926  Hyena Whale, if you please. His voracity is well known, and from the
5927  circumstance that the inner angles of his lips are curved upwards, he
5928  carries an everlasting Mephistophelean grin on his face. This whale
5929  averages some sixteen or eighteen feet in length. He is found in almost
5930  all latitudes. He has a peculiar way of showing his dorsal hooked fin
5931  in swimming, which looks something like a Roman nose. When not more
5932  profitably employed, the sperm whale hunters sometimes capture the
5933  Hyena whale, to keep up the supply of cheap oil for domestic
5934  employment—as some frugal housekeepers, in the absence of company, and
5935  quite alone by themselves, burn unsavory tallow instead of odorous wax.
5936  Though their blubber is very thin, some of these whales will yield you
5937  upwards of thirty gallons of oil.
5938  
5939  BOOK II. (_Octavo_), CHAPTER III. (_Narwhale_), that is, _Nostril
5940  whale_.—Another instance of a curiously named whale, so named I suppose
5941  from his peculiar horn being originally mistaken for a peaked nose. The
5942  creature is some sixteen feet in length, while its horn averages five
5943  feet, though some exceed ten, and even attain to fifteen feet. Strictly
5944  speaking, this horn is but a lengthened tusk, growing out from the jaw
5945  in a line a little depressed from the horizontal. But it is only found
5946  on the sinister side, which has an ill effect, giving its owner
5947  something analogous to the aspect of a clumsy left-handed man. What
5948  precise purpose this ivory horn or lance answers, it would be hard to
5949  say. It does not seem to be used like the blade of the sword-fish and
5950  bill-fish; though some sailors tell me that the Narwhale employs it for
5951  a rake in turning over the bottom of the sea for food. Charley Coffin
5952  said it was used for an ice-piercer; for the Narwhale, rising to the
5953  surface of the Polar Sea, and finding it sheeted with ice, thrusts his
5954  horn up, and so breaks through. But you cannot prove either of these
5955  surmises to be correct. My own opinion is, that however this one-sided
5956  horn may really be used by the Narwhale—however that may be—it would
5957  certainly be very convenient to him for a folder in reading pamphlets.
5958  The Narwhale I have heard called the Tusked whale, the Horned whale,
5959  and the Unicorn whale. He is certainly a curious example of the
5960  Unicornism to be found in almost every kingdom of animated nature. From
5961  certain cloistered old authors I have gathered that this same
5962  sea-unicorn’s horn was in ancient days regarded as the great antidote
5963  against poison, and as such, preparations of it brought immense prices.
5964  It was also distilled to a volatile salts for fainting ladies, the same
5965  way that the horns of the male deer are manufactured into hartshorn.
5966  Originally it was in itself accounted an object of great curiosity.
5967  Black Letter tells me that Sir Martin Frobisher on his return from that
5968  voyage, when Queen Bess did gallantly wave her jewelled hand to him
5969  from a window of Greenwich Palace, as his bold ship sailed down the
5970  Thames; “when Sir Martin returned from that voyage,” saith Black
5971  Letter, “on bended knees he presented to her highness a prodigious long
5972  horn of the Narwhale, which for a long period after hung in the castle
5973  at Windsor.” An Irish author avers that the Earl of Leicester, on
5974  bended knees, did likewise present to her highness another horn,
5975  pertaining to a land beast of the unicorn nature.
5976  
5977  The Narwhale has a very picturesque, leopard-like look, being of a
5978  milk-white ground colour, dotted with round and oblong spots of black.
5979  His oil is very superior, clear and fine; but there is little of it,
5980  and he is seldom hunted. He is mostly found in the circumpolar seas.
5981  
5982  BOOK II. (_Octavo_), CHAPTER IV. (_Killer_).—Of this whale little is
5983  precisely known to the Nantucketer, and nothing at all to the professed
5984  naturalist. From what I have seen of him at a distance, I should say
5985  that he was about the bigness of a grampus. He is very savage—a sort of
5986  Feegee fish. He sometimes takes the great Folio whales by the lip, and
5987  hangs there like a leech, till the mighty brute is worried to death.
5988  The Killer is never hunted. I never heard what sort of oil he has.
5989  Exception might be taken to the name bestowed upon this whale, on the
5990  ground of its indistinctness. For we are all killers, on land and on
5991  sea; Bonapartes and Sharks included.
5992  
5993  BOOK II. (_Octavo_), CHAPTER V. (_Thrasher_).—This gentleman is famous
5994  for his tail, which he uses for a ferule in thrashing his foes. He
5995  mounts the Folio whale’s back, and as he swims, he works his passage by
5996  flogging him; as some schoolmasters get along in the world by a similar
5997  process. Still less is known of the Thrasher than of the Killer. Both
5998  are outlaws, even in the lawless seas.
5999  
6000   Thus ends BOOK II. (_Octavo_), and begins BOOK III. (_Duodecimo_).
6001  
6002  DUODECIMOES.—These include the smaller whales. I. The Huzza Porpoise.
6003  II. The Algerine Porpoise. III. The Mealy-mouthed Porpoise.
6004  
6005  To those who have not chanced specially to study the subject, it may
6006  possibly seem strange, that fishes not commonly exceeding four or five
6007  feet should be marshalled among WHALES—a word, which, in the popular
6008  sense, always conveys an idea of hugeness. But the creatures set down
6009  above as Duodecimoes are infallibly whales, by the terms of my
6010  definition of what a whale is—_i.e._ a spouting fish, with a horizontal
6011  tail.
6012  
6013  BOOK III. (_Duodecimo_), CHAPTER 1. (_Huzza Porpoise_).—This is the
6014  common porpoise found almost all over the globe. The name is of my own
6015  bestowal; for there are more than one sort of porpoises, and something
6016  must be done to distinguish them. I call him thus, because he always
6017  swims in hilarious shoals, which upon the broad sea keep tossing
6018  themselves to heaven like caps in a Fourth-of-July crowd. Their
6019  appearance is generally hailed with delight by the mariner. Full of
6020  fine spirits, they invariably come from the breezy billows to windward.
6021  They are the lads that always live before the wind. They are accounted
6022  a lucky omen. If you yourself can withstand three cheers at beholding
6023  these vivacious fish, then heaven help ye; the spirit of godly
6024  gamesomeness is not in ye. A well-fed, plump Huzza Porpoise will yield
6025  you one good gallon of good oil. But the fine and delicate fluid
6026  extracted from his jaws is exceedingly valuable. It is in request among
6027  jewellers and watchmakers. Sailors put it on their hones. Porpoise meat
6028  is good eating, you know. It may never have occurred to you that a
6029  porpoise spouts. Indeed, his spout is so small that it is not very
6030  readily discernible. But the next time you have a chance, watch him;
6031  and you will then see the great Sperm whale himself in miniature.
6032  
6033  BOOK III. (_Duodecimo_), CHAPTER II. (_Algerine Porpoise_).—A pirate.
6034  Very savage. He is only found, I think, in the Pacific. He is somewhat
6035  larger than the Huzza Porpoise, but much of the same general make.
6036  Provoke him, and he will buckle to a shark. I have lowered for him many
6037  times, but never yet saw him captured.
6038  
6039  BOOK III. (_Duodecimo_), CHAPTER III. (_Mealy-mouthed Porpoise_).—The
6040  largest kind of Porpoise; and only found in the Pacific, so far as it
6041  is known. The only English name, by which he has hitherto been
6042  designated, is that of the fishers—Right-Whale Porpoise, from the
6043  circumstance that he is chiefly found in the vicinity of that Folio. In
6044  shape, he differs in some degree from the Huzza Porpoise, being of a
6045  less rotund and jolly girth; indeed, he is of quite a neat and
6046  gentleman-like figure. He has no fins on his back (most other porpoises
6047  have), he has a lovely tail, and sentimental Indian eyes of a hazel
6048  hue. But his mealy-mouth spoils all. Though his entire back down to his
6049  side fins is of a deep sable, yet a boundary line, distinct as the mark
6050  in a ship’s hull, called the “bright waist,” that line streaks him from
6051  stem to stern, with two separate colours, black above and white below.
6052  The white comprises part of his head, and the whole of his mouth, which
6053  makes him look as if he had just escaped from a felonious visit to a
6054  meal-bag. A most mean and mealy aspect! His oil is much like that of
6055  the common porpoise.
6056  
6057    * * * * * *
6058  
6059  Beyond the DUODECIMO, this system does not proceed, inasmuch as the
6060  Porpoise is the smallest of the whales. Above, you have all the
6061  Leviathans of note. But there are a rabble of uncertain, fugitive,
6062  half-fabulous whales, which, as an American whaleman, I know by
6063  reputation, but not personally. I shall enumerate them by their
6064  fore-castle appellations; for possibly such a list may be valuable to
6065  future investigators, who may complete what I have here but begun. If
6066  any of the following whales, shall hereafter be caught and marked, then
6067  he can readily be incorporated into this System, according to his
6068  Folio, Octavo, or Duodecimo magnitude:—The Bottle-Nose Whale; the Junk
6069  Whale; the Pudding-Headed Whale; the Cape Whale; the Leading Whale; the
6070  Cannon Whale; the Scragg Whale; the Coppered Whale; the Elephant Whale;
6071  the Iceberg Whale; the Quog Whale; the Blue Whale; etc. From Icelandic,
6072  Dutch, and old English authorities, there might be quoted other lists
6073  of uncertain whales, blessed with all manner of uncouth names. But I
6074  omit them as altogether obsolete; and can hardly help suspecting them
6075  for mere sounds, full of Leviathanism, but signifying nothing.
6076  
6077  Finally: It was stated at the outset, that this system would not be
6078  here, and at once, perfected. You cannot but plainly see that I have
6079  kept my word. But I now leave my cetological System standing thus
6080  unfinished, even as the great Cathedral of Cologne was left, with the
6081  crane still standing upon the top of the uncompleted tower. For small
6082  erections may be finished by their first architects; grand ones, true
6083  ones, ever leave the copestone to posterity. God keep me from ever
6084  completing anything. This whole book is but a draught—nay, but the
6085  draught of a draught. Oh, Time, Strength, Cash, and Patience!
6086  
6087  
6088  CHAPTER 33. The Specksnyder.
6089  
6090  Concerning the officers of the whale-craft, this seems as good a place
6091  as any to set down a little domestic peculiarity on ship-board, arising
6092  from the existence of the harpooneer class of officers, a class unknown
6093  of course in any other marine than the whale-fleet.
6094  
6095  The large importance attached to the harpooneer’s vocation is evinced
6096  by the fact, that originally in the old Dutch Fishery, two centuries
6097  and more ago, the command of a whale ship was not wholly lodged in the
6098  person now called the captain, but was divided between him and an
6099  officer called the Specksnyder. Literally this word means Fat-Cutter;
6100  usage, however, in time made it equivalent to Chief Harpooneer. In
6101  those days, the captain’s authority was restricted to the navigation
6102  and general management of the vessel; while over the whale-hunting
6103  department and all its concerns, the Specksnyder or Chief Harpooneer
6104  reigned supreme. In the British Greenland Fishery, under the corrupted
6105  title of Specksioneer, this old Dutch official is still retained, but
6106  his former dignity is sadly abridged. At present he ranks simply as
6107  senior Harpooneer; and as such, is but one of the captain’s more
6108  inferior subalterns. Nevertheless, as upon the good conduct of the
6109  harpooneers the success of a whaling voyage largely depends, and since
6110  in the American Fishery he is not only an important officer in the
6111  boat, but under certain circumstances (night watches on a whaling
6112  ground) the command of the ship’s deck is also his; therefore the grand
6113  political maxim of the sea demands, that he should nominally live apart
6114  from the men before the mast, and be in some way distinguished as their
6115  professional superior; though always, by them, familiarly regarded as
6116  their social equal.
6117  
6118  Now, the grand distinction drawn between officer and man at sea, is
6119  this—the first lives aft, the last forward. Hence, in whale-ships and
6120  merchantmen alike, the mates have their quarters with the captain; and
6121  so, too, in most of the American whalers the harpooneers are lodged in
6122  the after part of the ship. That is to say, they take their meals in
6123  the captain’s cabin, and sleep in a place indirectly communicating with
6124  it.
6125  
6126  Though the long period of a Southern whaling voyage (by far the longest
6127  of all voyages now or ever made by man), the peculiar perils of it, and
6128  the community of interest prevailing among a company, all of whom, high
6129  or low, depend for their profits, not upon fixed wages, but upon their
6130  common luck, together with their common vigilance, intrepidity, and
6131  hard work; though all these things do in some cases tend to beget a
6132  less rigorous discipline than in merchantmen generally; yet, never mind
6133  how much like an old Mesopotamian family these whalemen may, in some
6134  primitive instances, live together; for all that, the punctilious
6135  externals, at least, of the quarter-deck are seldom materially relaxed,
6136  and in no instance done away. Indeed, many are the Nantucket ships in
6137  which you will see the skipper parading his quarter-deck with an elated
6138  grandeur not surpassed in any military navy; nay, extorting almost as
6139  much outward homage as if he wore the imperial purple, and not the
6140  shabbiest of pilot-cloth.
6141  
6142  And though of all men the moody captain of the Pequod was the least
6143  given to that sort of shallowest assumption; and though the only homage
6144  he ever exacted, was implicit, instantaneous obedience; though he
6145  required no man to remove the shoes from his feet ere stepping upon the
6146  quarter-deck; and though there were times when, owing to peculiar
6147  circumstances connected with events hereafter to be detailed, he
6148  addressed them in unusual terms, whether of condescension or _in
6149  terrorem_, or otherwise; yet even Captain Ahab was by no means
6150  unobservant of the paramount forms and usages of the sea.
6151  
6152  Nor, perhaps, will it fail to be eventually perceived, that behind
6153  those forms and usages, as it were, he sometimes masked himself;
6154  incidentally making use of them for other and more private ends than
6155  they were legitimately intended to subserve. That certain sultanism of
6156  his brain, which had otherwise in a good degree remained unmanifested;
6157  through those forms that same sultanism became incarnate in an
6158  irresistible dictatorship. For be a man’s intellectual superiority what
6159  it will, it can never assume the practical, available supremacy over
6160  other men, without the aid of some sort of external arts and
6161  entrenchments, always, in themselves, more or less paltry and base.
6162  This it is, that for ever keeps God’s true princes of the Empire from
6163  the world’s hustings; and leaves the highest honors that this air can
6164  give, to those men who become famous more through their infinite
6165  inferiority to the choice hidden handful of the Divine Inert, than
6166  through their undoubted superiority over the dead level of the mass.
6167  Such large virtue lurks in these small things when extreme political
6168  superstitions invest them, that in some royal instances even to idiot
6169  imbecility they have imparted potency. But when, as in the case of
6170  Nicholas the Czar, the ringed crown of geographical empire encircles an
6171  imperial brain; then, the plebeian herds crouch abased before the
6172  tremendous centralization. Nor, will the tragic dramatist who would
6173  depict mortal indomitableness in its fullest sweep and direct swing,
6174  ever forget a hint, incidentally so important in his art, as the one
6175  now alluded to.
6176  
6177  But Ahab, my Captain, still moves before me in all his Nantucket
6178  grimness and shagginess; and in this episode touching Emperors and
6179  Kings, I must not conceal that I have only to do with a poor old
6180  whale-hunter like him; and, therefore, all outward majestical trappings
6181  and housings are denied me. Oh, Ahab! what shall be grand in thee, it
6182  must needs be plucked at from the skies, and dived for in the deep, and
6183  featured in the unbodied air!
6184  
6185  
6186  CHAPTER 34. The Cabin-Table.
6187  
6188  It is noon; and Dough-Boy, the steward, thrusting his pale
6189  loaf-of-bread face from the cabin-scuttle, announces dinner to his lord
6190  and master; who, sitting in the lee quarter-boat, has just been taking
6191  an observation of the sun; and is now mutely reckoning the latitude on
6192  the smooth, medallion-shaped tablet, reserved for that daily purpose on
6193  the upper part of his ivory leg. From his complete inattention to the
6194  tidings, you would think that moody Ahab had not heard his menial. But
6195  presently, catching hold of the mizen shrouds, he swings himself to the
6196  deck, and in an even, unexhilarated voice, saying, “Dinner, Mr.
6197  Starbuck,” disappears into the cabin.
6198  
6199  When the last echo of his sultan’s step has died away, and Starbuck,
6200  the first Emir, has every reason to suppose that he is seated, then
6201  Starbuck rouses from his quietude, takes a few turns along the planks,
6202  and, after a grave peep into the binnacle, says, with some touch of
6203  pleasantness, “Dinner, Mr. Stubb,” and descends the scuttle. The second
6204  Emir lounges about the rigging awhile, and then slightly shaking the
6205  main brace, to see whether it will be all right with that important
6206  rope, he likewise takes up the old burden, and with a rapid “Dinner,
6207  Mr. Flask,” follows after his predecessors.
6208  
6209  But the third Emir, now seeing himself all alone on the quarter-deck,
6210  seems to feel relieved from some curious restraint; for, tipping all
6211  sorts of knowing winks in all sorts of directions, and kicking off his
6212  shoes, he strikes into a sharp but noiseless squall of a hornpipe right
6213  over the Grand Turk’s head; and then, by a dexterous sleight, pitching
6214  his cap up into the mizentop for a shelf, he goes down rollicking so
6215  far at least as he remains visible from the deck, reversing all other
6216  processions, by bringing up the rear with music. But ere stepping into
6217  the cabin doorway below, he pauses, ships a new face altogether, and,
6218  then, independent, hilarious little Flask enters King Ahab’s presence,
6219  in the character of Abjectus, or the Slave.
6220  
6221  It is not the least among the strange things bred by the intense
6222  artificialness of sea-usages, that while in the open air of the deck
6223  some officers will, upon provocation, bear themselves boldly and
6224  defyingly enough towards their commander; yet, ten to one, let those
6225  very officers the next moment go down to their customary dinner in that
6226  same commander’s cabin, and straightway their inoffensive, not to say
6227  deprecatory and humble air towards him, as he sits at the head of the
6228  table; this is marvellous, sometimes most comical. Wherefore this
6229  difference? A problem? Perhaps not. To have been Belshazzar, King of
6230  Babylon; and to have been Belshazzar, not haughtily but courteously,
6231  therein certainly must have been some touch of mundane grandeur. But he
6232  who in the rightly regal and intelligent spirit presides over his own
6233  private dinner-table of invited guests, that man’s unchallenged power
6234  and dominion of individual influence for the time; that man’s royalty
6235  of state transcends Belshazzar’s, for Belshazzar was not the greatest.
6236  Who has but once dined his friends, has tasted what it is to be Cæsar.
6237  It is a witchery of social czarship which there is no withstanding.
6238  Now, if to this consideration you superadd the official supremacy of a
6239  ship-master, then, by inference, you will derive the cause of that
6240  peculiarity of sea-life just mentioned.
6241  
6242  Over his ivory-inlaid table, Ahab presided like a mute, maned sea-lion
6243  on the white coral beach, surrounded by his warlike but still
6244  deferential cubs. In his own proper turn, each officer waited to be
6245  served. They were as little children before Ahab; and yet, in Ahab,
6246  there seemed not to lurk the smallest social arrogance. With one mind,
6247  their intent eyes all fastened upon the old man’s knife, as he carved
6248  the chief dish before him. I do not suppose that for the world they
6249  would have profaned that moment with the slightest observation, even
6250  upon so neutral a topic as the weather. No! And when reaching out his
6251  knife and fork, between which the slice of beef was locked, Ahab
6252  thereby motioned Starbuck’s plate towards him, the mate received his
6253  meat as though receiving alms; and cut it tenderly; and a little
6254  started if, perchance, the knife grazed against the plate; and chewed
6255  it noiselessly; and swallowed it, not without circumspection. For, like
6256  the Coronation banquet at Frankfort, where the German Emperor
6257  profoundly dines with the seven Imperial Electors, so these cabin meals
6258  were somehow solemn meals, eaten in awful silence; and yet at table old
6259  Ahab forbade not conversation; only he himself was dumb. What a relief
6260  it was to choking Stubb, when a rat made a sudden racket in the hold
6261  below. And poor little Flask, he was the youngest son, and little boy
6262  of this weary family party. His were the shinbones of the saline beef;
6263  his would have been the drumsticks. For Flask to have presumed to help
6264  himself, this must have seemed to him tantamount to larceny in the
6265  first degree. Had he helped himself at that table, doubtless, never
6266  more would he have been able to hold his head up in this honest world;
6267  nevertheless, strange to say, Ahab never forbade him. And had Flask
6268  helped himself, the chances were Ahab had never so much as noticed it.
6269  Least of all, did Flask presume to help himself to butter. Whether he
6270  thought the owners of the ship denied it to him, on account of its
6271  clotting his clear, sunny complexion; or whether he deemed that, on so
6272  long a voyage in such marketless waters, butter was at a premium, and
6273  therefore was not for him, a subaltern; however it was, Flask, alas!
6274  was a butterless man!
6275  
6276  Another thing. Flask was the last person down at the dinner, and Flask
6277  is the first man up. Consider! For hereby Flask’s dinner was badly
6278  jammed in point of time. Starbuck and Stubb both had the start of him;
6279  and yet they also have the privilege of lounging in the rear. If Stubb
6280  even, who is but a peg higher than Flask, happens to have but a small
6281  appetite, and soon shows symptoms of concluding his repast, then Flask
6282  must bestir himself, he will not get more than three mouthfuls that
6283  day; for it is against holy usage for Stubb to precede Flask to the
6284  deck. Therefore it was that Flask once admitted in private, that ever
6285  since he had arisen to the dignity of an officer, from that moment he
6286  had never known what it was to be otherwise than hungry, more or less.
6287  For what he ate did not so much relieve his hunger, as keep it immortal
6288  in him. Peace and satisfaction, thought Flask, have for ever departed
6289  from my stomach. I am an officer; but, how I wish I could fish a bit of
6290  old-fashioned beef in the forecastle, as I used to when I was before
6291  the mast. There’s the fruits of promotion now; there’s the vanity of
6292  glory: there’s the insanity of life! Besides, if it were so that any
6293  mere sailor of the Pequod had a grudge against Flask in Flask’s
6294  official capacity, all that sailor had to do, in order to obtain ample
6295  vengeance, was to go aft at dinner-time, and get a peep at Flask
6296  through the cabin sky-light, sitting silly and dumfoundered before
6297  awful Ahab.
6298  
6299  Now, Ahab and his three mates formed what may be called the first table
6300  in the Pequod’s cabin. After their departure, taking place in inverted
6301  order to their arrival, the canvas cloth was cleared, or rather was
6302  restored to some hurried order by the pallid steward. And then the
6303  three harpooneers were bidden to the feast, they being its residuary
6304  legatees. They made a sort of temporary servants’ hall of the high and
6305  mighty cabin.
6306  
6307  In strange contrast to the hardly tolerable constraint and nameless
6308  invisible domineerings of the captain’s table, was the entire care-free
6309  license and ease, the almost frantic democracy of those inferior
6310  fellows the harpooneers. While their masters, the mates, seemed afraid
6311  of the sound of the hinges of their own jaws, the harpooneers chewed
6312  their food with such a relish that there was a report to it. They dined
6313  like lords; they filled their bellies like Indian ships all day loading
6314  with spices. Such portentous appetites had Queequeg and Tashtego, that
6315  to fill out the vacancies made by the previous repast, often the pale
6316  Dough-Boy was fain to bring on a great baron of salt-junk, seemingly
6317  quarried out of the solid ox. And if he were not lively about it, if he
6318  did not go with a nimble hop-skip-and-jump, then Tashtego had an
6319  ungentlemanly way of accelerating him by darting a fork at his back,
6320  harpoon-wise. And once Daggoo, seized with a sudden humor, assisted
6321  Dough-Boy’s memory by snatching him up bodily, and thrusting his head
6322  into a great empty wooden trencher, while Tashtego, knife in hand,
6323  began laying out the circle preliminary to scalping him. He was
6324  naturally a very nervous, shuddering sort of little fellow, this
6325  bread-faced steward; the progeny of a bankrupt baker and a hospital
6326  nurse. And what with the standing spectacle of the black terrific Ahab,
6327  and the periodical tumultuous visitations of these three savages,
6328  Dough-Boy’s whole life was one continual lip-quiver. Commonly, after
6329  seeing the harpooneers furnished with all things they demanded, he
6330  would escape from their clutches into his little pantry adjoining, and
6331  fearfully peep out at them through the blinds of its door, till all was
6332  over.
6333  
6334  It was a sight to see Queequeg seated over against Tashtego, opposing
6335  his filed teeth to the Indian’s: crosswise to them, Daggoo seated on
6336  the floor, for a bench would have brought his hearse-plumed head to the
6337  low carlines; at every motion of his colossal limbs, making the low
6338  cabin framework to shake, as when an African elephant goes passenger in
6339  a ship. But for all this, the great negro was wonderfully abstemious,
6340  not to say dainty. It seemed hardly possible that by such comparatively
6341  small mouthfuls he could keep up the vitality diffused through so
6342  broad, baronial, and superb a person. But, doubtless, this noble savage
6343  fed strong and drank deep of the abounding element of air; and through
6344  his dilated nostrils snuffed in the sublime life of the worlds. Not by
6345  beef or by bread, are giants made or nourished. But Queequeg, he had a
6346  mortal, barbaric smack of the lip in eating—an ugly sound enough—so
6347  much so, that the trembling Dough-Boy almost looked to see whether any
6348  marks of teeth lurked in his own lean arms. And when he would hear
6349  Tashtego singing out for him to produce himself, that his bones might
6350  be picked, the simple-witted steward all but shattered the crockery
6351  hanging round him in the pantry, by his sudden fits of the palsy. Nor
6352  did the whetstone which the harpooneers carried in their pockets, for
6353  their lances and other weapons; and with which whetstones, at dinner,
6354  they would ostentatiously sharpen their knives; that grating sound did
6355  not at all tend to tranquillize poor Dough-Boy. How could he forget
6356  that in his Island days, Queequeg, for one, must certainly have been
6357  guilty of some murderous, convivial indiscretions. Alas! Dough-Boy!
6358  hard fares the white waiter who waits upon cannibals. Not a napkin
6359  should he carry on his arm, but a buckler. In good time, though, to his
6360  great delight, the three salt-sea warriors would rise and depart; to
6361  his credulous, fable-mongering ears, all their martial bones jingling
6362  in them at every step, like Moorish scimetars in scabbards.
6363  
6364  But, though these barbarians dined in the cabin, and nominally lived
6365  there; still, being anything but sedentary in their habits, they were
6366  scarcely ever in it except at mealtimes, and just before sleeping-time,
6367  when they passed through it to their own peculiar quarters.
6368  
6369  In this one matter, Ahab seemed no exception to most American whale
6370  captains, who, as a set, rather incline to the opinion that by rights
6371  the ship’s cabin belongs to them; and that it is by courtesy alone that
6372  anybody else is, at any time, permitted there. So that, in real truth,
6373  the mates and harpooneers of the Pequod might more properly be said to
6374  have lived out of the cabin than in it. For when they did enter it, it
6375  was something as a street-door enters a house; turning inwards for a
6376  moment, only to be turned out the next; and, as a permanent thing,
6377  residing in the open air. Nor did they lose much hereby; in the cabin
6378  was no companionship; socially, Ahab was inaccessible. Though nominally
6379  included in the census of Christendom, he was still an alien to it. He
6380  lived in the world, as the last of the Grisly Bears lived in settled
6381  Missouri. And as when Spring and Summer had departed, that wild Logan
6382  of the woods, burying himself in the hollow of a tree, lived out the
6383  winter there, sucking his own paws; so, in his inclement, howling old
6384  age, Ahab’s soul, shut up in the caved trunk of his body, there fed
6385  upon the sullen paws of its gloom!
6386  
6387  
6388  CHAPTER 35. The Mast-Head.
6389  
6390  It was during the more pleasant weather, that in due rotation with the
6391  other seamen my first mast-head came round.
6392  
6393  In most American whalemen the mast-heads are manned almost
6394  simultaneously with the vessel’s leaving her port; even though she may
6395  have fifteen thousand miles, and more, to sail ere reaching her proper
6396  cruising ground. And if, after a three, four, or five years’ voyage she
6397  is drawing nigh home with anything empty in her—say, an empty vial
6398  even—then, her mast-heads are kept manned to the last; and not till her
6399  skysail-poles sail in among the spires of the port, does she altogether
6400  relinquish the hope of capturing one whale more.
6401  
6402  Now, as the business of standing mast-heads, ashore or afloat, is a
6403  very ancient and interesting one, let us in some measure expatiate
6404  here. I take it, that the earliest standers of mast-heads were the old
6405  Egyptians; because, in all my researches, I find none prior to them.
6406  For though their progenitors, the builders of Babel, must doubtless, by
6407  their tower, have intended to rear the loftiest mast-head in all Asia,
6408  or Africa either; yet (ere the final truck was put to it) as that great
6409  stone mast of theirs may be said to have gone by the board, in the
6410  dread gale of God’s wrath; therefore, we cannot give these Babel
6411  builders priority over the Egyptians. And that the Egyptians were a
6412  nation of mast-head standers, is an assertion based upon the general
6413  belief among archæologists, that the first pyramids were founded for
6414  astronomical purposes: a theory singularly supported by the peculiar
6415  stair-like formation of all four sides of those edifices; whereby, with
6416  prodigious long upliftings of their legs, those old astronomers were
6417  wont to mount to the apex, and sing out for new stars; even as the
6418  look-outs of a modern ship sing out for a sail, or a whale just bearing
6419  in sight. In Saint Stylites, the famous Christian hermit of old times,
6420  who built him a lofty stone pillar in the desert and spent the whole
6421  latter portion of his life on its summit, hoisting his food from the
6422  ground with a tackle; in him we have a remarkable instance of a
6423  dauntless stander-of-mast-heads; who was not to be driven from his
6424  place by fogs or frosts, rain, hail, or sleet; but valiantly facing
6425  everything out to the last, literally died at his post. Of modern
6426  standers-of-mast-heads we have but a lifeless set; mere stone, iron,
6427  and bronze men; who, though well capable of facing out a stiff gale,
6428  are still entirely incompetent to the business of singing out upon
6429  discovering any strange sight. There is Napoleon; who, upon the top of
6430  the column of Vendome, stands with arms folded, some one hundred and
6431  fifty feet in the air; careless, now, who rules the decks below;
6432  whether Louis Philippe, Louis Blanc, or Louis the Devil. Great
6433  Washington, too, stands high aloft on his towering main-mast in
6434  Baltimore, and like one of Hercules’ pillars, his column marks that
6435  point of human grandeur beyond which few mortals will go. Admiral
6436  Nelson, also, on a capstan of gun-metal, stands his mast-head in
6437  Trafalgar Square; and ever when most obscured by that London smoke,
6438  token is yet given that a hidden hero is there; for where there is
6439  smoke, must be fire. But neither great Washington, nor Napoleon, nor
6440  Nelson, will answer a single hail from below, however madly invoked to
6441  befriend by their counsels the distracted decks upon which they gaze;
6442  however it may be surmised, that their spirits penetrate through the
6443  thick haze of the future, and descry what shoals and what rocks must be
6444  shunned.
6445  
6446  It may seem unwarrantable to couple in any respect the mast-head
6447  standers of the land with those of the sea; but that in truth it is not
6448  so, is plainly evinced by an item for which Obed Macy, the sole
6449  historian of Nantucket, stands accountable. The worthy Obed tells us,
6450  that in the early times of the whale fishery, ere ships were regularly
6451  launched in pursuit of the game, the people of that island erected
6452  lofty spars along the sea-coast, to which the look-outs ascended by
6453  means of nailed cleats, something as fowls go upstairs in a hen-house.
6454  A few years ago this same plan was adopted by the Bay whalemen of New
6455  Zealand, who, upon descrying the game, gave notice to the ready-manned
6456  boats nigh the beach. But this custom has now become obsolete; turn we
6457  then to the one proper mast-head, that of a whale-ship at sea. The
6458  three mast-heads are kept manned from sun-rise to sun-set; the seamen
6459  taking their regular turns (as at the helm), and relieving each other
6460  every two hours. In the serene weather of the tropics it is exceedingly
6461  pleasant the mast-head; nay, to a dreamy meditative man it is
6462  delightful. There you stand, a hundred feet above the silent decks,
6463  striding along the deep, as if the masts were gigantic stilts, while
6464  beneath you and between your legs, as it were, swim the hugest monsters
6465  of the sea, even as ships once sailed between the boots of the famous
6466  Colossus at old Rhodes. There you stand, lost in the infinite series of
6467  the sea, with nothing ruffled but the waves. The tranced ship
6468  indolently rolls; the drowsy trade winds blow; everything resolves you
6469  into languor. For the most part, in this tropic whaling life, a sublime
6470  uneventfulness invests you; you hear no news; read no gazettes; extras
6471  with startling accounts of commonplaces never delude you into
6472  unnecessary excitements; you hear of no domestic afflictions; bankrupt
6473  securities; fall of stocks; are never troubled with the thought of what
6474  you shall have for dinner—for all your meals for three years and more
6475  are snugly stowed in casks, and your bill of fare is immutable.
6476  
6477  In one of those southern whalesmen, on a long three or four years’
6478  voyage, as often happens, the sum of the various hours you spend at the
6479  mast-head would amount to several entire months. And it is much to be
6480  deplored that the place to which you devote so considerable a portion
6481  of the whole term of your natural life, should be so sadly destitute of
6482  anything approaching to a cosy inhabitiveness, or adapted to breed a
6483  comfortable localness of feeling, such as pertains to a bed, a hammock,
6484  a hearse, a sentry box, a pulpit, a coach, or any other of those small
6485  and snug contrivances in which men temporarily isolate themselves. Your
6486  most usual point of perch is the head of the t’ gallant-mast, where you
6487  stand upon two thin parallel sticks (almost peculiar to whalemen)
6488  called the t’ gallant cross-trees. Here, tossed about by the sea, the
6489  beginner feels about as cosy as he would standing on a bull’s horns. To
6490  be sure, in cold weather you may carry your house aloft with you, in
6491  the shape of a watch-coat; but properly speaking the thickest
6492  watch-coat is no more of a house than the unclad body; for as the soul
6493  is glued inside of its fleshy tabernacle, and cannot freely move about
6494  in it, nor even move out of it, without running great risk of perishing
6495  (like an ignorant pilgrim crossing the snowy Alps in winter); so a
6496  watch-coat is not so much of a house as it is a mere envelope, or
6497  additional skin encasing you. You cannot put a shelf or chest of
6498  drawers in your body, and no more can you make a convenient closet of
6499  your watch-coat.
6500  
6501  Concerning all this, it is much to be deplored that the mast-heads of a
6502  southern whale ship are unprovided with those enviable little tents or
6503  pulpits, called _crow’s-nests_, in which the look-outs of a Greenland
6504  whaler are protected from the inclement weather of the frozen seas. In
6505  the fireside narrative of Captain Sleet, entitled “A Voyage among the
6506  Icebergs, in quest of the Greenland Whale, and incidentally for the
6507  re-discovery of the Lost Icelandic Colonies of Old Greenland;” in this
6508  admirable volume, all standers of mast-heads are furnished with a
6509  charmingly circumstantial account of the then recently invented
6510  _crow’s-nest_ of the Glacier, which was the name of Captain Sleet’s
6511  good craft. He called it the _Sleet’s crow’s-nest_, in honor of
6512  himself; he being the original inventor and patentee, and free from all
6513  ridiculous false delicacy, and holding that if we call our own children
6514  after our own names (we fathers being the original inventors and
6515  patentees), so likewise should we denominate after ourselves any other
6516  apparatus we may beget. In shape, the Sleet’s crow’s-nest is something
6517  like a large tierce or pipe; it is open above, however, where it is
6518  furnished with a movable side-screen to keep to windward of your head
6519  in a hard gale. Being fixed on the summit of the mast, you ascend into
6520  it through a little trap-hatch in the bottom. On the after side, or
6521  side next the stern of the ship, is a comfortable seat, with a locker
6522  underneath for umbrellas, comforters, and coats. In front is a leather
6523  rack, in which to keep your speaking trumpet, pipe, telescope, and
6524  other nautical conveniences. When Captain Sleet in person stood his
6525  mast-head in this crow’s-nest of his, he tells us that he always had a
6526  rifle with him (also fixed in the rack), together with a powder flask
6527  and shot, for the purpose of popping off the stray narwhales, or
6528  vagrant sea unicorns infesting those waters; for you cannot
6529  successfully shoot at them from the deck owing to the resistance of the
6530  water, but to shoot down upon them is a very different thing. Now, it
6531  was plainly a labor of love for Captain Sleet to describe, as he does,
6532  all the little detailed conveniences of his crow’s-nest; but though he
6533  so enlarges upon many of these, and though he treats us to a very
6534  scientific account of his experiments in this crow’s-nest, with a small
6535  compass he kept there for the purpose of counteracting the errors
6536  resulting from what is called the “local attraction” of all binnacle
6537  magnets; an error ascribable to the horizontal vicinity of the iron in
6538  the ship’s planks, and in the Glacier’s case, perhaps, to there having
6539  been so many broken-down blacksmiths among her crew; I say, that though
6540  the Captain is very discreet and scientific here, yet, for all his
6541  learned “binnacle deviations,” “azimuth compass observations,” and
6542  “approximate errors,” he knows very well, Captain Sleet, that he was
6543  not so much immersed in those profound magnetic meditations, as to fail
6544  being attracted occasionally towards that well replenished little
6545  case-bottle, so nicely tucked in on one side of his crow’s nest, within
6546  easy reach of his hand. Though, upon the whole, I greatly admire and
6547  even love the brave, the honest, and learned Captain; yet I take it
6548  very ill of him that he should so utterly ignore that case-bottle,
6549  seeing what a faithful friend and comforter it must have been, while
6550  with mittened fingers and hooded head he was studying the mathematics
6551  aloft there in that bird’s nest within three or four perches of the
6552  pole.
6553  
6554  But if we Southern whale-fishers are not so snugly housed aloft as
6555  Captain Sleet and his Greenlandmen were; yet that disadvantage is
6556  greatly counter-balanced by the widely contrasting serenity of those
6557  seductive seas in which we South fishers mostly float. For one, I used
6558  to lounge up the rigging very leisurely, resting in the top to have a
6559  chat with Queequeg, or any one else off duty whom I might find there;
6560  then ascending a little way further, and throwing a lazy leg over the
6561  top-sail yard, take a preliminary view of the watery pastures, and so
6562  at last mount to my ultimate destination.
6563  
6564  Let me make a clean breast of it here, and frankly admit that I kept
6565  but sorry guard. With the problem of the universe revolving in me, how
6566  could I—being left completely to myself at such a thought-engendering
6567  altitude—how could I but lightly hold my obligations to observe all
6568  whale-ships’ standing orders, “Keep your weather eye open, and sing out
6569  every time.”
6570  
6571  And let me in this place movingly admonish you, ye ship-owners of
6572  Nantucket! Beware of enlisting in your vigilant fisheries any lad with
6573  lean brow and hollow eye; given to unseasonable meditativeness; and who
6574  offers to ship with the Phædon instead of Bowditch in his head. Beware
6575  of such an one, I say; your whales must be seen before they can be
6576  killed; and this sunken-eyed young Platonist will tow you ten wakes
6577  round the world, and never make you one pint of sperm the richer. Nor
6578  are these monitions at all unneeded. For nowadays, the whale-fishery
6579  furnishes an asylum for many romantic, melancholy, and absent-minded
6580  young men, disgusted with the carking cares of earth, and seeking
6581  sentiment in tar and blubber. Childe Harold not unfrequently perches
6582  himself upon the mast-head of some luckless disappointed whale-ship,
6583  and in moody phrase ejaculates:—
6584  
6585  
6586  “Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean, roll! Ten thousand
6587  blubber-hunters sweep over thee in vain.”
6588  
6589  
6590  
6591  Very often do the captains of such ships take those absent-minded young
6592  philosophers to task, upbraiding them with not feeling sufficient
6593  “interest” in the voyage; half-hinting that they are so hopelessly lost
6594  to all honorable ambition, as that in their secret souls they would
6595  rather not see whales than otherwise. But all in vain; those young
6596  Platonists have a notion that their vision is imperfect; they are
6597  short-sighted; what use, then, to strain the visual nerve? They have
6598  left their opera-glasses at home.
6599  
6600  “Why, thou monkey,” said a harpooneer to one of these lads, “we’ve been
6601  cruising now hard upon three years, and thou hast not raised a whale
6602  yet. Whales are scarce as hen’s teeth whenever thou art up here.”
6603  Perhaps they were; or perhaps there might have been shoals of them in
6604  the far horizon; but lulled into such an opium-like listlessness of
6605  vacant, unconscious reverie is this absent-minded youth by the blending
6606  cadence of waves with thoughts, that at last he loses his identity;
6607  takes the mystic ocean at his feet for the visible image of that deep,
6608  blue, bottomless soul, pervading mankind and nature; and every strange,
6609  half-seen, gliding, beautiful thing that eludes him; every
6610  dimly-discovered, uprising fin of some undiscernible form, seems to him
6611  the embodiment of those elusive thoughts that only people the soul by
6612  continually flitting through it. In this enchanted mood, thy spirit
6613  ebbs away to whence it came; becomes diffused through time and space;
6614  like Cranmer’s sprinkled Pantheistic ashes, forming at last a part of
6615  every shore the round globe over.
6616  
6617  There is no life in thee, now, except that rocking life imparted by a
6618  gently rolling ship; by her, borrowed from the sea; by the sea, from
6619  the inscrutable tides of God. But while this sleep, this dream is on
6620  ye, move your foot or hand an inch; slip your hold at all; and your
6621  identity comes back in horror. Over Descartian vortices you hover. And
6622  perhaps, at mid-day, in the fairest weather, with one half-throttled
6623  shriek you drop through that transparent air into the summer sea, no
6624  more to rise for ever. Heed it well, ye Pantheists!
6625  
6626  
6627  CHAPTER 36. The Quarter-Deck.
6628  
6629  (_Enter Ahab: Then, all._)
6630  
6631  It was not a great while after the affair of the pipe, that one morning
6632  shortly after breakfast, Ahab, as was his wont, ascended the
6633  cabin-gangway to the deck. There most sea-captains usually walk at that
6634  hour, as country gentlemen, after the same meal, take a few turns in
6635  the garden.
6636  
6637  Soon his steady, ivory stride was heard, as to and fro he paced his old
6638  rounds, upon planks so familiar to his tread, that they were all over
6639  dented, like geological stones, with the peculiar mark of his walk. Did
6640  you fixedly gaze, too, upon that ribbed and dented brow; there also,
6641  you would see still stranger foot-prints—the foot-prints of his one
6642  unsleeping, ever-pacing thought.
6643  
6644  But on the occasion in question, those dents looked deeper, even as his
6645  nervous step that morning left a deeper mark. And, so full of his
6646  thought was Ahab, that at every uniform turn that he made, now at the
6647  main-mast and now at the binnacle, you could almost see that thought
6648  turn in him as he turned, and pace in him as he paced; so completely
6649  possessing him, indeed, that it all but seemed the inward mould of
6650  every outer movement.
6651  
6652  “D’ye mark him, Flask?” whispered Stubb; “the chick that’s in him pecks
6653  the shell. ’Twill soon be out.”
6654  
6655  The hours wore on;—Ahab now shut up within his cabin; anon, pacing the
6656  deck, with the same intense bigotry of purpose in his aspect.
6657  
6658  It drew near the close of day. Suddenly he came to a halt by the
6659  bulwarks, and inserting his bone leg into the auger-hole there, and
6660  with one hand grasping a shroud, he ordered Starbuck to send everybody
6661  aft.
6662  
6663  “Sir!” said the mate, astonished at an order seldom or never given on
6664  ship-board except in some extraordinary case.
6665  
6666  “Send everybody aft,” repeated Ahab. “Mast-heads, there! come down!”
6667  
6668  When the entire ship’s company were assembled, and with curious and not
6669  wholly unapprehensive faces, were eyeing him, for he looked not unlike
6670  the weather horizon when a storm is coming up, Ahab, after rapidly
6671  glancing over the bulwarks, and then darting his eyes among the crew,
6672  started from his standpoint; and as though not a soul were nigh him
6673  resumed his heavy turns upon the deck. With bent head and half-slouched
6674  hat he continued to pace, unmindful of the wondering whispering among
6675  the men; till Stubb cautiously whispered to Flask, that Ahab must have
6676  summoned them there for the purpose of witnessing a pedestrian feat.
6677  But this did not last long. Vehemently pausing, he cried:—
6678  
6679  “What do ye do when ye see a whale, men?”
6680  
6681  “Sing out for him!” was the impulsive rejoinder from a score of clubbed
6682  voices.
6683  
6684  “Good!” cried Ahab, with a wild approval in his tones; observing the
6685  hearty animation into which his unexpected question had so magnetically
6686  thrown them.
6687  
6688  “And what do ye next, men?”
6689  
6690  “Lower away, and after him!”
6691  
6692  “And what tune is it ye pull to, men?”
6693  
6694  “A dead whale or a stove boat!”
6695  
6696  More and more strangely and fiercely glad and approving, grew the
6697  countenance of the old man at every shout; while the mariners began to
6698  gaze curiously at each other, as if marvelling how it was that they
6699  themselves became so excited at such seemingly purposeless questions.
6700  
6701  But, they were all eagerness again, as Ahab, now half-revolving in his
6702  pivot-hole, with one hand reaching high up a shroud, and tightly,
6703  almost convulsively grasping it, addressed them thus:—
6704  
6705  “All ye mast-headers have before now heard me give orders about a white
6706  whale. Look ye! d’ye see this Spanish ounce of gold?”—holding up a
6707  broad bright coin to the sun—“it is a sixteen dollar piece, men. D’ye
6708  see it? Mr. Starbuck, hand me yon top-maul.”
6709  
6710  While the mate was getting the hammer, Ahab, without speaking, was
6711  slowly rubbing the gold piece against the skirts of his jacket, as if
6712  to heighten its lustre, and without using any words was meanwhile lowly
6713  humming to himself, producing a sound so strangely muffled and
6714  inarticulate that it seemed the mechanical humming of the wheels of his
6715  vitality in him.
6716  
6717  Receiving the top-maul from Starbuck, he advanced towards the main-mast
6718  with the hammer uplifted in one hand, exhibiting the gold with the
6719  other, and with a high raised voice exclaiming: “Whosoever of ye raises
6720  me a white-headed whale with a wrinkled brow and a crooked jaw;
6721  whosoever of ye raises me that white-headed whale, with three holes
6722  punctured in his starboard fluke—look ye, whosoever of ye raises me
6723  that same white whale, he shall have this gold ounce, my boys!”
6724  
6725  “Huzza! huzza!” cried the seamen, as with swinging tarpaulins they
6726  hailed the act of nailing the gold to the mast.
6727  
6728  “It’s a white whale, I say,” resumed Ahab, as he threw down the
6729  topmaul: “a white whale. Skin your eyes for him, men; look sharp for
6730  white water; if ye see but a bubble, sing out.”
6731  
6732  All this while Tashtego, Daggoo, and Queequeg had looked on with even
6733  more intense interest and surprise than the rest, and at the mention of
6734  the wrinkled brow and crooked jaw they had started as if each was
6735  separately touched by some specific recollection.
6736  
6737  “Captain Ahab,” said Tashtego, “that white whale must be the same that
6738  some call Moby Dick.”
6739  
6740  “Moby Dick?” shouted Ahab. “Do ye know the white whale then, Tash?”
6741  
6742  “Does he fan-tail a little curious, sir, before he goes down?” said the
6743  Gay-Header deliberately.
6744  
6745  “And has he a curious spout, too,” said Daggoo, “very bushy, even for a
6746  parmacetty, and mighty quick, Captain Ahab?”
6747  
6748  “And he have one, two, three—oh! good many iron in him hide, too,
6749  Captain,” cried Queequeg disjointedly, “all twiske-tee be-twisk, like
6750  him—him—” faltering hard for a word, and screwing his hand round and
6751  round as though uncorking a bottle—“like him—him—”
6752  
6753  “Corkscrew!” cried Ahab, “aye, Queequeg, the harpoons lie all twisted
6754  and wrenched in him; aye, Daggoo, his spout is a big one, like a whole
6755  shock of wheat, and white as a pile of our Nantucket wool after the
6756  great annual sheep-shearing; aye, Tashtego, and he fan-tails like a
6757  split jib in a squall. Death and devils! men, it is Moby Dick ye have
6758  seen—Moby Dick—Moby Dick!”
6759  
6760  “Captain Ahab,” said Starbuck, who, with Stubb and Flask, had thus far
6761  been eyeing his superior with increasing surprise, but at last seemed
6762  struck with a thought which somewhat explained all the wonder. “Captain
6763  Ahab, I have heard of Moby Dick—but it was not Moby Dick that took off
6764  thy leg?”
6765  
6766  “Who told thee that?” cried Ahab; then pausing, “Aye, Starbuck; aye, my
6767  hearties all round; it was Moby Dick that dismasted me; Moby Dick that
6768  brought me to this dead stump I stand on now. Aye, aye,” he shouted
6769  with a terrific, loud, animal sob, like that of a heart-stricken moose;
6770  “Aye, aye! it was that accursed white whale that razed me; made a poor
6771  pegging lubber of me for ever and a day!” Then tossing both arms, with
6772  measureless imprecations he shouted out: “Aye, aye! and I’ll chase him
6773  round Good Hope, and round the Horn, and round the Norway Maelstrom,
6774  and round perdition’s flames before I give him up. And this is what ye
6775  have shipped for, men! to chase that white whale on both sides of land,
6776  and over all sides of earth, till he spouts black blood and rolls fin
6777  out. What say ye, men, will ye splice hands on it, now? I think ye do
6778  look brave.”
6779  
6780  “Aye, aye!” shouted the harpooneers and seamen, running closer to the
6781  excited old man: “A sharp eye for the white whale; a sharp lance for
6782  Moby Dick!”
6783  
6784  “God bless ye,” he seemed to half sob and half shout. “God bless ye,
6785  men. Steward! go draw the great measure of grog. But what’s this long
6786  face about, Mr. Starbuck; wilt thou not chase the white whale? art not
6787  game for Moby Dick?”
6788  
6789  “I am game for his crooked jaw, and for the jaws of Death too, Captain
6790  Ahab, if it fairly comes in the way of the business we follow; but I
6791  came here to hunt whales, not my commander’s vengeance. How many
6792  barrels will thy vengeance yield thee even if thou gettest it, Captain
6793  Ahab? it will not fetch thee much in our Nantucket market.”
6794  
6795  “Nantucket market! Hoot! But come closer, Starbuck; thou requirest a
6796  little lower layer. If money’s to be the measurer, man, and the
6797  accountants have computed their great counting-house the globe, by
6798  girdling it with guineas, one to every three parts of an inch; then,
6799  let me tell thee, that my vengeance will fetch a great premium _here!_”
6800  
6801  “He smites his chest,” whispered Stubb, “what’s that for? methinks it
6802  rings most vast, but hollow.”
6803  
6804  “Vengeance on a dumb brute!” cried Starbuck, “that simply smote thee
6805  from blindest instinct! Madness! To be enraged with a dumb thing,
6806  Captain Ahab, seems blasphemous.”
6807  
6808  “Hark ye yet again—the little lower layer. All visible objects, man,
6809  are but as pasteboard masks. But in each event—in the living act, the
6810  undoubted deed—there, some unknown but still reasoning thing puts forth
6811  the mouldings of its features from behind the unreasoning mask. If man
6812  will strike, strike through the mask! How can the prisoner reach
6813  outside except by thrusting through the wall? To me, the white whale is
6814  that wall, shoved near to me. Sometimes I think there’s naught beyond.
6815  But ’tis enough. He tasks me; he heaps me; I see in him outrageous
6816  strength, with an inscrutable malice sinewing it. That inscrutable
6817  thing is chiefly what I hate; and be the white whale agent, or be the
6818  white whale principal, I will wreak that hate upon him. Talk not to me
6819  of blasphemy, man; I’d strike the sun if it insulted me. For could the
6820  sun do that, then could I do the other; since there is ever a sort of
6821  fair play herein, jealousy presiding over all creations. But not my
6822  master, man, is even that fair play. Who’s over me? Truth hath no
6823  confines. Take off thine eye! more intolerable than fiends’ glarings is
6824  a doltish stare! So, so; thou reddenest and palest; my heat has melted
6825  thee to anger-glow. But look ye, Starbuck, what is said in heat, that
6826  thing unsays itself. There are men from whom warm words are small
6827  indignity. I meant not to incense thee. Let it go. Look! see yonder
6828  Turkish cheeks of spotted tawn—living, breathing pictures painted by
6829  the sun. The Pagan leopards—the unrecking and unworshipping things,
6830  that live; and seek, and give no reasons for the torrid life they feel!
6831  The crew, man, the crew! Are they not one and all with Ahab, in this
6832  matter of the whale? See Stubb! he laughs! See yonder Chilian! he
6833  snorts to think of it. Stand up amid the general hurricane, thy one
6834  tost sapling cannot, Starbuck! And what is it? Reckon it. ’Tis but to
6835  help strike a fin; no wondrous feat for Starbuck. What is it more? From
6836  this one poor hunt, then, the best lance out of all Nantucket, surely
6837  he will not hang back, when every foremast-hand has clutched a
6838  whetstone? Ah! constrainings seize thee; I see! the billow lifts thee!
6839  Speak, but speak!—Aye, aye! thy silence, then, _that_ voices thee.
6840  (_Aside_) Something shot from my dilated nostrils, he has inhaled it in
6841  his lungs. Starbuck now is mine; cannot oppose me now, without
6842  rebellion.”
6843  
6844  “God keep me!—keep us all!” murmured Starbuck, lowly.
6845  
6846  But in his joy at the enchanted, tacit acquiescence of the mate, Ahab
6847  did not hear his foreboding invocation; nor yet the low laugh from the
6848  hold; nor yet the presaging vibrations of the winds in the cordage; nor
6849  yet the hollow flap of the sails against the masts, as for a moment
6850  their hearts sank in. For again Starbuck’s downcast eyes lighted up
6851  with the stubbornness of life; the subterranean laugh died away; the
6852  winds blew on; the sails filled out; the ship heaved and rolled as
6853  before. Ah, ye admonitions and warnings! why stay ye not when ye come?
6854  But rather are ye predictions than warnings, ye shadows! Yet not so
6855  much predictions from without, as verifications of the foregoing things
6856  within. For with little external to constrain us, the innermost
6857  necessities in our being, these still drive us on.
6858  
6859  “The measure! the measure!” cried Ahab.
6860  
6861  Receiving the brimming pewter, and turning to the harpooneers, he
6862  ordered them to produce their weapons. Then ranging them before him
6863  near the capstan, with their harpoons in their hands, while his three
6864  mates stood at his side with their lances, and the rest of the ship’s
6865  company formed a circle round the group; he stood for an instant
6866  searchingly eyeing every man of his crew. But those wild eyes met his,
6867  as the bloodshot eyes of the prairie wolves meet the eye of their
6868  leader, ere he rushes on at their head in the trail of the bison; but,
6869  alas! only to fall into the hidden snare of the Indian.
6870  
6871  “Drink and pass!” he cried, handing the heavy charged flagon to the
6872  nearest seaman. “The crew alone now drink. Round with it, round! Short
6873  draughts—long swallows, men; ’tis hot as Satan’s hoof. So, so; it goes
6874  round excellently. It spiralizes in ye; forks out at the
6875  serpent-snapping eye. Well done; almost drained. That way it went, this
6876  way it comes. Hand it me—here’s a hollow! Men, ye seem the years; so
6877  brimming life is gulped and gone. Steward, refill!
6878  
6879  “Attend now, my braves. I have mustered ye all round this capstan; and
6880  ye mates, flank me with your lances; and ye harpooneers, stand there
6881  with your irons; and ye, stout mariners, ring me in, that I may in some
6882  sort revive a noble custom of my fisherman fathers before me. O men,
6883  you will yet see that—Ha! boy, come back? bad pennies come not sooner.
6884  Hand it me. Why, now, this pewter had run brimming again, wer’t not
6885  thou St. Vitus’ imp—away, thou ague!
6886  
6887  “Advance, ye mates! Cross your lances full before me. Well done! Let me
6888  touch the axis.” So saying, with extended arm, he grasped the three
6889  level, radiating lances at their crossed centre; while so doing,
6890  suddenly and nervously twitched them; meanwhile, glancing intently from
6891  Starbuck to Stubb; from Stubb to Flask. It seemed as though, by some
6892  nameless, interior volition, he would fain have shocked into them the
6893  same fiery emotion accumulated within the Leyden jar of his own
6894  magnetic life. The three mates quailed before his strong, sustained,
6895  and mystic aspect. Stubb and Flask looked sideways from him; the honest
6896  eye of Starbuck fell downright.
6897  
6898  “In vain!” cried Ahab; “but, maybe, ’tis well. For did ye three but
6899  once take the full-forced shock, then mine own electric thing, _that_
6900  had perhaps expired from out me. Perchance, too, it would have dropped
6901  ye dead. Perchance ye need it not. Down lances! And now, ye mates, I do
6902  appoint ye three cupbearers to my three pagan kinsmen there—yon three
6903  most honorable gentlemen and noblemen, my valiant harpooneers. Disdain
6904  the task? What, when the great Pope washes the feet of beggars, using
6905  his tiara for ewer? Oh, my sweet cardinals! your own condescension,
6906  _that_ shall bend ye to it. I do not order ye; ye will it. Cut your
6907  seizings and draw the poles, ye harpooneers!”
6908  
6909  Silently obeying the order, the three harpooneers now stood with the
