6910  detached iron part of their harpoons, some three feet long, held, barbs
6911  up, before him.
6912  
6913  “Stab me not with that keen steel! Cant them; cant them over! know ye
6914  not the goblet end? Turn up the socket! So, so; now, ye cup-bearers,
6915  advance. The irons! take them; hold them while I fill!” Forthwith,
6916  slowly going from one officer to the other, he brimmed the harpoon
6917  sockets with the fiery waters from the pewter.
6918  
6919  “Now, three to three, ye stand. Commend the murderous chalices! Bestow
6920  them, ye who are now made parties to this indissoluble league. Ha!
6921  Starbuck! but the deed is done! Yon ratifying sun now waits to sit upon
6922  it. Drink, ye harpooneers! drink and swear, ye men that man the
6923  deathful whaleboat’s bow—Death to Moby Dick! God hunt us all, if we do
6924  not hunt Moby Dick to his death!” The long, barbed steel goblets were
6925  lifted; and to cries and maledictions against the white whale, the
6926  spirits were simultaneously quaffed down with a hiss. Starbuck paled,
6927  and turned, and shivered. Once more, and finally, the replenished
6928  pewter went the rounds among the frantic crew; when, waving his free
6929  hand to them, they all dispersed; and Ahab retired within his cabin.
6930  
6931  
6932  CHAPTER 37. Sunset.
6933  
6934  _The cabin; by the stern windows; Ahab sitting alone, and gazing out_.
6935  
6936  I leave a white and turbid wake; pale waters, paler cheeks, where’er I
6937  sail. The envious billows sidelong swell to whelm my track; let them;
6938  but first I pass.
6939  
6940  Yonder, by ever-brimming goblet’s rim, the warm waves blush like wine.
6941  The gold brow plumbs the blue. The diver sun—slow dived from noon—goes
6942  down; my soul mounts up! she wearies with her endless hill. Is, then,
6943  the crown too heavy that I wear? this Iron Crown of Lombardy. Yet is it
6944  bright with many a gem; I the wearer, see not its far flashings; but
6945  darkly feel that I wear that, that dazzlingly confounds. ’Tis iron—that
6946  I know—not gold. ’Tis split, too—that I feel; the jagged edge galls me
6947  so, my brain seems to beat against the solid metal; aye, steel skull,
6948  mine; the sort that needs no helmet in the most brain-battering fight!
6949  
6950  Dry heat upon my brow? Oh! time was, when as the sunrise nobly spurred
6951  me, so the sunset soothed. No more. This lovely light, it lights not
6952  me; all loveliness is anguish to me, since I can ne’er enjoy. Gifted
6953  with the high perception, I lack the low, enjoying power; damned, most
6954  subtly and most malignantly! damned in the midst of Paradise! Good
6955  night—good night! (_waving his hand, he moves from the window_.)
6956  
6957  ’Twas not so hard a task. I thought to find one stubborn, at the least;
6958  but my one cogged circle fits into all their various wheels, and they
6959  revolve. Or, if you will, like so many ant-hills of powder, they all
6960  stand before me; and I their match. Oh, hard! that to fire others, the
6961  match itself must needs be wasting! What I’ve dared, I’ve willed; and
6962  what I’ve willed, I’ll do! They think me mad—Starbuck does; but I’m
6963  demoniac, I am madness maddened! That wild madness that’s only calm to
6964  comprehend itself! The prophecy was that I should be dismembered;
6965  and—Aye! I lost this leg. I now prophesy that I will dismember my
6966  dismemberer. Now, then, be the prophet and the fulfiller one. That’s
6967  more than ye, ye great gods, ever were. I laugh and hoot at ye, ye
6968  cricket-players, ye pugilists, ye deaf Burkes and blinded Bendigoes! I
6969  will not say as schoolboys do to bullies—Take some one of your own
6970  size; don’t pommel _me!_ No, ye’ve knocked me down, and I am up again;
6971  but _ye_ have run and hidden. Come forth from behind your cotton bags!
6972  I have no long gun to reach ye. Come, Ahab’s compliments to ye; come
6973  and see if ye can swerve me. Swerve me? ye cannot swerve me, else ye
6974  swerve yourselves! man has ye there. Swerve me? The path to my fixed
6975  purpose is laid with iron rails, whereon my soul is grooved to run.
6976  Over unsounded gorges, through the rifled hearts of mountains, under
6977  torrents’ beds, unerringly I rush! Naught’s an obstacle, naught’s an
6978  angle to the iron way!
6979  
6980  
6981  CHAPTER 38. Dusk.
6982  
6983  _By the Mainmast; Starbuck leaning against it_.
6984  
6985  My soul is more than matched; she’s overmanned; and by a madman!
6986  Insufferable sting, that sanity should ground arms on such a field! But
6987  he drilled deep down, and blasted all my reason out of me! I think I
6988  see his impious end; but feel that I must help him to it. Will I, nill
6989  I, the ineffable thing has tied me to him; tows me with a cable I have
6990  no knife to cut. Horrible old man! Who’s over him, he cries;—aye, he
6991  would be a democrat to all above; look, how he lords it over all below!
6992  Oh! I plainly see my miserable office,—to obey, rebelling; and worse
6993  yet, to hate with touch of pity! For in his eyes I read some lurid woe
6994  would shrivel me up, had I it. Yet is there hope. Time and tide flow
6995  wide. The hated whale has the round watery world to swim in, as the
6996  small gold-fish has its glassy globe. His heaven-insulting purpose, God
6997  may wedge aside. I would up heart, were it not like lead. But my whole
6998  clock’s run down; my heart the all-controlling weight, I have no key to
6999  lift again.
7000  
7001  [_A burst of revelry from the forecastle_.]
7002  
7003  Oh, God! to sail with such a heathen crew that have small touch of
7004  human mothers in them! Whelped somewhere by the sharkish sea. The white
7005  whale is their demigorgon. Hark! the infernal orgies! that revelry is
7006  forward! mark the unfaltering silence aft! Methinks it pictures life.
7007  Foremost through the sparkling sea shoots on the gay, embattled,
7008  bantering bow, but only to drag dark Ahab after it, where he broods
7009  within his sternward cabin, builded over the dead water of the wake,
7010  and further on, hunted by its wolfish gurglings. The long howl thrills
7011  me through! Peace! ye revellers, and set the watch! Oh, life! ’tis in
7012  an hour like this, with soul beat down and held to knowledge,—as wild,
7013  untutored things are forced to feed—Oh, life! ’tis now that I do feel
7014  the latent horror in thee! but ’tis not me! that horror’s out of me!
7015  and with the soft feeling of the human in me, yet will I try to fight
7016  ye, ye grim, phantom futures! Stand by me, hold me, bind me, O ye
7017  blessed influences!
7018  
7019  
7020  CHAPTER 39. First Night-Watch.
7021  
7022  Fore-Top.
7023  
7024  (_Stubb solus, and mending a brace_.)
7025  
7026  Ha! ha! ha! ha! hem! clear my throat!—I’ve been thinking over it ever
7027  since, and that ha, ha’s the final consequence. Why so? Because a
7028  laugh’s the wisest, easiest answer to all that’s queer; and come what
7029  will, one comfort’s always left—that unfailing comfort is, it’s all
7030  predestinated. I heard not all his talk with Starbuck; but to my poor
7031  eye Starbuck then looked something as I the other evening felt. Be sure
7032  the old Mogul has fixed him, too. I twigged it, knew it; had had the
7033  gift, might readily have prophesied it—for when I clapped my eye upon
7034  his skull I saw it. Well, Stubb, _wise_ Stubb—that’s my title—well,
7035  Stubb, what of it, Stubb? Here’s a carcase. I know not all that may be
7036  coming, but be it what it will, I’ll go to it laughing. Such a waggish
7037  leering as lurks in all your horribles! I feel funny. Fa, la! lirra,
7038  skirra! What’s my juicy little pear at home doing now? Crying its eyes
7039  out?—Giving a party to the last arrived harpooneers, I dare say, gay as
7040  a frigate’s pennant, and so am I—fa, la! lirra, skirra! Oh—
7041  
7042  
7043  We’ll drink to-night with hearts as light, To love, as gay and fleeting
7044  As bubbles that swim, on the beaker’s brim, And break on the lips while
7045  meeting.
7046  
7047  
7048  
7049  A brave stave that—who calls? Mr. Starbuck? Aye, aye, sir—(_Aside_)
7050  he’s my superior, he has his too, if I’m not mistaken.—Aye, aye, sir,
7051  just through with this job—coming.
7052  
7053  
7054  CHAPTER 40. Midnight, Forecastle.
7055  
7056  HARPOONEERS AND SAILORS.
7057  
7058  (_Foresail rises and discovers the watch standing, lounging, leaning,
7059  and lying in various attitudes, all singing in chorus_.)
7060  
7061  
7062    Farewell and adieu to you, Spanish ladies! Farewell and adieu to you,
7063    ladies of Spain! Our captain’s commanded.—
7064  
7065  
7066  
7067  1ST NANTUCKET SAILOR. Oh, boys, don’t be sentimental; it’s bad for the
7068  digestion! Take a tonic, follow me!
7069  
7070  (_Sings, and all follow._)
7071  
7072  
7073   Our captain stood upon the deck, A spy-glass in his hand, A viewing of
7074   those gallant whales That blew at every strand. Oh, your tubs in your
7075   boats, my boys, And by your braces stand, And we’ll have one of those
7076   fine whales, Hand, boys, over hand! So, be cheery, my lads! may your
7077   hearts never fail! While the bold harpooner is striking the whale!
7078  
7079  
7080  
7081  MATE’S VOICE FROM THE QUARTER-DECK. Eight bells there, forward!
7082  
7083  2ND NANTUCKET SAILOR. Avast the chorus! Eight bells there! d’ye hear,
7084  bell-boy? Strike the bell eight, thou Pip! thou blackling! and let me
7085  call the watch. I’ve the sort of mouth for that—the hogshead mouth. So,
7086  so, (_thrusts his head down the scuttle_,) Star-bo-l-e-e-n-s, a-h-o-y!
7087  Eight bells there below! Tumble up!
7088  
7089  DUTCH SAILOR. Grand snoozing to-night, maty; fat night for that. I mark
7090  this in our old Mogul’s wine; it’s quite as deadening to some as
7091  filliping to others. We sing; they sleep—aye, lie down there, like
7092  ground-tier butts. At ’em again! There, take this copper-pump, and hail
7093  ’em through it. Tell ’em to avast dreaming of their lasses. Tell ’em
7094  it’s the resurrection; they must kiss their last, and come to judgment.
7095  That’s the way—_that’s_ it; thy throat ain’t spoiled with eating
7096  Amsterdam butter.
7097  
7098  FRENCH SAILOR. Hist, boys! let’s have a jig or two before we ride to
7099  anchor in Blanket Bay. What say ye? There comes the other watch. Stand
7100  by all legs! Pip! little Pip! hurrah with your tambourine!
7101  
7102  PIP. (_Sulky and sleepy._) Don’t know where it is.
7103  
7104  FRENCH SAILOR. Beat thy belly, then, and wag thy ears. Jig it, men, I
7105  say; merry’s the word; hurrah! Damn me, won’t you dance? Form, now,
7106  Indian-file, and gallop into the double-shuffle? Throw yourselves!
7107  Legs! legs!
7108  
7109  ICELAND SAILOR. I don’t like your floor, maty; it’s too springy to my
7110  taste. I’m used to ice-floors. I’m sorry to throw cold water on the
7111  subject; but excuse me.
7112  
7113  MALTESE SAILOR. Me too; where’s your girls? Who but a fool would take
7114  his left hand by his right, and say to himself, how d’ye do? Partners!
7115  I must have partners!
7116  
7117  SICILIAN SAILOR. Aye; girls and a green!—then I’ll hop with ye; yea,
7118  turn grasshopper!
7119  
7120  LONG-ISLAND SAILOR. Well, well, ye sulkies, there’s plenty more of us.
7121  Hoe corn when you may, say I. All legs go to harvest soon. Ah! here
7122  comes the music; now for it!
7123  
7124  AZORE SAILOR. (_Ascending, and pitching the tambourine up the
7125  scuttle_.) Here you are, Pip; and there’s the windlass-bitts; up you
7126  mount! Now, boys! (_The half of them dance to the tambourine; some go
7127  below; some sleep or lie among the coils of rigging. Oaths a-plenty_.)
7128  
7129  AZORE SAILOR. (_Dancing_) Go it, Pip! Bang it, bell-boy! Rig it, dig
7130  it, stig it, quig it, bell-boy! Make fire-flies; break the jinglers!
7131  
7132  PIP. Jinglers, you say?—there goes another, dropped off; I pound it so.
7133  
7134  CHINA SAILOR. Rattle thy teeth, then, and pound away; make a pagoda of
7135  thyself.
7136  
7137  FRENCH SAILOR. Merry-mad! Hold up thy hoop, Pip, till I jump through
7138  it! Split jibs! tear yourselves!
7139  
7140  TASHTEGO. (_Quietly smoking._) That’s a white man; he calls that fun:
7141  humph! I save my sweat.
7142  
7143  OLD MANX SAILOR. I wonder whether those jolly lads bethink them of what
7144  they are dancing over. I’ll dance over your grave, I will—that’s the
7145  bitterest threat of your night-women, that beat head-winds round
7146  corners. O Christ! to think of the green navies and the green-skulled
7147  crews! Well, well; belike the whole world’s a ball, as you scholars
7148  have it; and so ’tis right to make one ballroom of it. Dance on, lads,
7149  you’re young; I was once.
7150  
7151  3D NANTUCKET SAILOR. Spell oh!—whew! this is worse than pulling after
7152  whales in a calm—give us a whiff, Tash.
7153  
7154  (_They cease dancing, and gather in clusters. Meantime the sky
7155  darkens—the wind rises_.)
7156  
7157  LASCAR SAILOR. By Brahma! boys, it’ll be douse sail soon. The sky-born,
7158  high-tide Ganges turned to wind! Thou showest thy black brow, Seeva!
7159  
7160  MALTESE SAILOR. (_Reclining and shaking his cap_.) It’s the waves—the
7161  snow’s caps turn to jig it now. They’ll shake their tassels soon. Now
7162  would all the waves were women, then I’d go drown, and chassee with
7163  them evermore! There’s naught so sweet on earth—heaven may not match
7164  it!—as those swift glances of warm, wild bosoms in the dance, when the
7165  over-arboring arms hide such ripe, bursting grapes.
7166  
7167  SICILIAN SAILOR. (_Reclining_.) Tell me not of it! Hark ye, lad—fleet
7168  interlacings of the limbs—lithe swayings—coyings—flutterings! lip!
7169  heart! hip! all graze: unceasing touch and go! not taste, observe ye,
7170  else come satiety. Eh, Pagan? (_Nudging_.)
7171  
7172  TAHITAN SAILOR. (_Reclining on a mat_.) Hail, holy nakedness of our
7173  dancing girls!—the Heeva-Heeva! Ah! low veiled, high palmed Tahiti! I
7174  still rest me on thy mat, but the soft soil has slid! I saw thee woven
7175  in the wood, my mat! green the first day I brought ye thence; now worn
7176  and wilted quite. Ah me!—not thou nor I can bear the change! How then,
7177  if so be transplanted to yon sky? Hear I the roaring streams from
7178  Pirohitee’s peak of spears, when they leap down the crags and drown the
7179  villages?—The blast! the blast! Up, spine, and meet it! (_Leaps to his
7180  feet_.)
7181  
7182  PORTUGUESE SAILOR. How the sea rolls swashing ’gainst the side! Stand
7183  by for reefing, hearties! the winds are just crossing swords, pell-mell
7184  they’ll go lunging presently.
7185  
7186  DANISH SAILOR. Crack, crack, old ship! so long as thou crackest, thou
7187  holdest! Well done! The mate there holds ye to it stiffly. He’s no more
7188  afraid than the isle fort at Cattegat, put there to fight the Baltic
7189  with storm-lashed guns, on which the sea-salt cakes!
7190  
7191  4TH NANTUCKET SAILOR. He has his orders, mind ye that. I heard old Ahab
7192  tell him he must always kill a squall, something as they burst a
7193  waterspout with a pistol—fire your ship right into it!
7194  
7195  ENGLISH SAILOR. Blood! but that old man’s a grand old cove! We are the
7196  lads to hunt him up his whale!
7197  
7198  ALL. Aye! aye!
7199  
7200  OLD MANX SAILOR. How the three pines shake! Pines are the hardest sort
7201  of tree to live when shifted to any other soil, and here there’s none
7202  but the crew’s cursed clay. Steady, helmsman! steady. This is the sort
7203  of weather when brave hearts snap ashore, and keeled hulls split at
7204  sea. Our captain has his birthmark; look yonder, boys, there’s another
7205  in the sky—lurid-like, ye see, all else pitch black.
7206  
7207  DAGGOO. What of that? Who’s afraid of black’s afraid of me! I’m
7208  quarried out of it!
7209  
7210  SPANISH SAILOR. (_Aside_.) He wants to bully, ah!—the old grudge makes
7211  me touchy (_Advancing_.) Aye, harpooneer, thy race is the undeniable
7212  dark side of mankind—devilish dark at that. No offence.
7213  
7214  DAGGOO (_grimly_). None.
7215  
7216  ST. JAGO’S SAILOR. That Spaniard’s mad or drunk. But that can’t be, or
7217  else in his one case our old Mogul’s fire-waters are somewhat long in
7218  working.
7219  
7220  5TH NANTUCKET SAILOR. What’s that I saw—lightning? Yes.
7221  
7222  SPANISH SAILOR. No; Daggoo showing his teeth.
7223  
7224  DAGGOO (_springing_). Swallow thine, mannikin! White skin, white liver!
7225  
7226  SPANISH SAILOR (_meeting him_). Knife thee heartily! big frame, small
7227  spirit!
7228  
7229  ALL. A row! a row! a row!
7230  
7231  TASHTEGO (_with a whiff_). A row a’low, and a row aloft—Gods and
7232  men—both brawlers! Humph!
7233  
7234  BELFAST SAILOR. A row! arrah a row! The Virgin be blessed, a row!
7235  Plunge in with ye!
7236  
7237  ENGLISH SAILOR. Fair play! Snatch the Spaniard’s knife! A ring, a ring!
7238  
7239  OLD MANX SAILOR. Ready formed. There! the ringed horizon. In that ring
7240  Cain struck Abel. Sweet work, right work! No? Why then, God, mad’st
7241  thou the ring?
7242  
7243  MATE’S VOICE FROM THE QUARTER-DECK. Hands by the halyards! in
7244  top-gallant sails! Stand by to reef topsails!
7245  
7246  ALL. The squall! the squall! jump, my jollies! (_They scatter_.)
7247  
7248  PIP (_shrinking under the windlass_). Jollies? Lord help such jollies!
7249  Crish, crash! there goes the jib-stay! Blang-whang! God! Duck lower,
7250  Pip, here comes the royal yard! It’s worse than being in the whirled
7251  woods, the last day of the year! Who’d go climbing after chestnuts now?
7252  But there they go, all cursing, and here I don’t. Fine prospects to
7253  ’em; they’re on the road to heaven. Hold on hard! Jimmini, what a
7254  squall! But those chaps there are worse yet—they are your white
7255  squalls, they. White squalls? white whale, shirr! shirr! Here have I
7256  heard all their chat just now, and the white whale—shirr! shirr!—but
7257  spoken of once! and only this evening—it makes me jingle all over like
7258  my tambourine—that anaconda of an old man swore ’em in to hunt him! Oh,
7259  thou big white God aloft there somewhere in yon darkness, have mercy on
7260  this small black boy down here; preserve him from all men that have no
7261  bowels to feel fear!
7262  
7263  
7264  CHAPTER 41. Moby Dick.
7265  
7266  I, Ishmael, was one of that crew; my shouts had gone up with the rest;
7267  my oath had been welded with theirs; and stronger I shouted, and more
7268  did I hammer and clinch my oath, because of the dread in my soul. A
7269  wild, mystical, sympathetical feeling was in me; Ahab’s quenchless feud
7270  seemed mine. With greedy ears I learned the history of that murderous
7271  monster against whom I and all the others had taken our oaths of
7272  violence and revenge.
7273  
7274  For some time past, though at intervals only, the unaccompanied,
7275  secluded White Whale had haunted those uncivilized seas mostly
7276  frequented by the Sperm Whale fishermen. But not all of them knew of
7277  his existence; only a few of them, comparatively, had knowingly seen
7278  him; while the number who as yet had actually and knowingly given
7279  battle to him, was small indeed. For, owing to the large number of
7280  whale-cruisers; the disorderly way they were sprinkled over the entire
7281  watery circumference, many of them adventurously pushing their quest
7282  along solitary latitudes, so as seldom or never for a whole twelvemonth
7283  or more on a stretch, to encounter a single news-telling sail of any
7284  sort; the inordinate length of each separate voyage; the irregularity
7285  of the times of sailing from home; all these, with other circumstances,
7286  direct and indirect, long obstructed the spread through the whole
7287  world-wide whaling-fleet of the special individualizing tidings
7288  concerning Moby Dick. It was hardly to be doubted, that several vessels
7289  reported to have encountered, at such or such a time, or on such or
7290  such a meridian, a Sperm Whale of uncommon magnitude and malignity,
7291  which whale, after doing great mischief to his assailants, had
7292  completely escaped them; to some minds it was not an unfair
7293  presumption, I say, that the whale in question must have been no other
7294  than Moby Dick. Yet as of late the Sperm Whale fishery had been marked
7295  by various and not unfrequent instances of great ferocity, cunning, and
7296  malice in the monster attacked; therefore it was, that those who by
7297  accident ignorantly gave battle to Moby Dick; such hunters, perhaps,
7298  for the most part, were content to ascribe the peculiar terror he bred,
7299  more, as it were, to the perils of the Sperm Whale fishery at large,
7300  than to the individual cause. In that way, mostly, the disastrous
7301  encounter between Ahab and the whale had hitherto been popularly
7302  regarded.
7303  
7304  And as for those who, previously hearing of the White Whale, by chance
7305  caught sight of him; in the beginning of the thing they had every one
7306  of them, almost, as boldly and fearlessly lowered for him, as for any
7307  other whale of that species. But at length, such calamities did ensue
7308  in these assaults—not restricted to sprained wrists and ankles, broken
7309  limbs, or devouring amputations—but fatal to the last degree of
7310  fatality; those repeated disastrous repulses, all accumulating and
7311  piling their terrors upon Moby Dick; those things had gone far to shake
7312  the fortitude of many brave hunters, to whom the story of the White
7313  Whale had eventually come.
7314  
7315  Nor did wild rumors of all sorts fail to exaggerate, and still the more
7316  horrify the true histories of these deadly encounters. For not only do
7317  fabulous rumors naturally grow out of the very body of all surprising
7318  terrible events,—as the smitten tree gives birth to its fungi; but, in
7319  maritime life, far more than in that of terra firma, wild rumors
7320  abound, wherever there is any adequate reality for them to cling to.
7321  And as the sea surpasses the land in this matter, so the whale fishery
7322  surpasses every other sort of maritime life, in the wonderfulness and
7323  fearfulness of the rumors which sometimes circulate there. For not only
7324  are whalemen as a body unexempt from that ignorance and
7325  superstitiousness hereditary to all sailors; but of all sailors, they
7326  are by all odds the most directly brought into contact with whatever is
7327  appallingly astonishing in the sea; face to face they not only eye its
7328  greatest marvels, but, hand to jaw, give battle to them. Alone, in such
7329  remotest waters, that though you sailed a thousand miles, and passed a
7330  thousand shores, you would not come to any chiseled hearth-stone, or
7331  aught hospitable beneath that part of the sun; in such latitudes and
7332  longitudes, pursuing too such a calling as he does, the whaleman is
7333  wrapped by influences all tending to make his fancy pregnant with many
7334  a mighty birth.
7335  
7336  No wonder, then, that ever gathering volume from the mere transit over
7337  the widest watery spaces, the outblown rumors of the White Whale did in
7338  the end incorporate with themselves all manner of morbid hints, and
7339  half-formed fœtal suggestions of supernatural agencies, which
7340  eventually invested Moby Dick with new terrors unborrowed from anything
7341  that visibly appears. So that in many cases such a panic did he finally
7342  strike, that few who by those rumors, at least, had heard of the White
7343  Whale, few of those hunters were willing to encounter the perils of his
7344  jaw.
7345  
7346  But there were still other and more vital practical influences at work.
7347  Not even at the present day has the original prestige of the Sperm
7348  Whale, as fearfully distinguished from all other species of the
7349  leviathan, died out of the minds of the whalemen as a body. There are
7350  those this day among them, who, though intelligent and courageous
7351  enough in offering battle to the Greenland or Right whale, would
7352  perhaps—either from professional inexperience, or incompetency, or
7353  timidity, decline a contest with the Sperm Whale; at any rate, there
7354  are plenty of whalemen, especially among those whaling nations not
7355  sailing under the American flag, who have never hostilely encountered
7356  the Sperm Whale, but whose sole knowledge of the leviathan is
7357  restricted to the ignoble monster primitively pursued in the North;
7358  seated on their hatches, these men will hearken with a childish
7359  fireside interest and awe, to the wild, strange tales of Southern
7360  whaling. Nor is the pre-eminent tremendousness of the great Sperm Whale
7361  anywhere more feelingly comprehended, than on board of those prows
7362  which stem him.
7363  
7364  And as if the now tested reality of his might had in former legendary
7365  times thrown its shadow before it; we find some book
7366  naturalists—Olassen and Povelson—declaring the Sperm Whale not only to
7367  be a consternation to every other creature in the sea, but also to be
7368  so incredibly ferocious as continually to be athirst for human blood.
7369  Nor even down to so late a time as Cuvier’s, were these or almost
7370  similar impressions effaced. For in his Natural History, the Baron
7371  himself affirms that at sight of the Sperm Whale, all fish (sharks
7372  included) are “struck with the most lively terrors,” and “often in the
7373  precipitancy of their flight dash themselves against the rocks with
7374  such violence as to cause instantaneous death.” And however the general
7375  experiences in the fishery may amend such reports as these; yet in
7376  their full terribleness, even to the bloodthirsty item of Povelson, the
7377  superstitious belief in them is, in some vicissitudes of their
7378  vocation, revived in the minds of the hunters.
7379  
7380  So that overawed by the rumors and portents concerning him, not a few
7381  of the fishermen recalled, in reference to Moby Dick, the earlier days
7382  of the Sperm Whale fishery, when it was oftentimes hard to induce long
7383  practised Right whalemen to embark in the perils of this new and daring
7384  warfare; such men protesting that although other leviathans might be
7385  hopefully pursued, yet to chase and point lance at such an apparition
7386  as the Sperm Whale was not for mortal man. That to attempt it, would be
7387  inevitably to be torn into a quick eternity. On this head, there are
7388  some remarkable documents that may be consulted.
7389  
7390  Nevertheless, some there were, who even in the face of these things
7391  were ready to give chase to Moby Dick; and a still greater number who,
7392  chancing only to hear of him distantly and vaguely, without the
7393  specific details of any certain calamity, and without superstitious
7394  accompaniments, were sufficiently hardy not to flee from the battle if
7395  offered.
7396  
7397  One of the wild suggestions referred to, as at last coming to be linked
7398  with the White Whale in the minds of the superstitiously inclined, was
7399  the unearthly conceit that Moby Dick was ubiquitous; that he had
7400  actually been encountered in opposite latitudes at one and the same
7401  instant of time.
7402  
7403  Nor, credulous as such minds must have been, was this conceit
7404  altogether without some faint show of superstitious probability. For as
7405  the secrets of the currents in the seas have never yet been divulged,
7406  even to the most erudite research; so the hidden ways of the Sperm
7407  Whale when beneath the surface remain, in great part, unaccountable to
7408  his pursuers; and from time to time have originated the most curious
7409  and contradictory speculations regarding them, especially concerning
7410  the mystic modes whereby, after sounding to a great depth, he
7411  transports himself with such vast swiftness to the most widely distant
7412  points.
7413  
7414  It is a thing well known to both American and English whale-ships, and
7415  as well a thing placed upon authoritative record years ago by Scoresby,
7416  that some whales have been captured far north in the Pacific, in whose
7417  bodies have been found the barbs of harpoons darted in the Greenland
7418  seas. Nor is it to be gainsaid, that in some of these instances it has
7419  been declared that the interval of time between the two assaults could
7420  not have exceeded very many days. Hence, by inference, it has been
7421  believed by some whalemen, that the Nor’ West Passage, so long a
7422  problem to man, was never a problem to the whale. So that here, in the
7423  real living experience of living men, the prodigies related in old
7424  times of the inland Strello mountain in Portugal (near whose top there
7425  was said to be a lake in which the wrecks of ships floated up to the
7426  surface); and that still more wonderful story of the Arethusa fountain
7427  near Syracuse (whose waters were believed to have come from the Holy
7428  Land by an underground passage); these fabulous narrations are almost
7429  fully equalled by the realities of the whalemen.
7430  
7431  Forced into familiarity, then, with such prodigies as these; and
7432  knowing that after repeated, intrepid assaults, the White Whale had
7433  escaped alive; it cannot be much matter of surprise that some whalemen
7434  should go still further in their superstitions; declaring Moby Dick not
7435  only ubiquitous, but immortal (for immortality is but ubiquity in
7436  time); that though groves of spears should be planted in his flanks, he
7437  would still swim away unharmed; or if indeed he should ever be made to
7438  spout thick blood, such a sight would be but a ghastly deception; for
7439  again in unensanguined billows hundreds of leagues away, his unsullied
7440  jet would once more be seen.
7441  
7442  But even stripped of these supernatural surmisings, there was enough in
7443  the earthly make and incontestable character of the monster to strike
7444  the imagination with unwonted power. For, it was not so much his
7445  uncommon bulk that so much distinguished him from other sperm whales,
7446  but, as was elsewhere thrown out—a peculiar snow-white wrinkled
7447  forehead, and a high, pyramidical white hump. These were his prominent
7448  features; the tokens whereby, even in the limitless, uncharted seas, he
7449  revealed his identity, at a long distance, to those who knew him.
7450  
7451  The rest of his body was so streaked, and spotted, and marbled with the
7452  same shrouded hue, that, in the end, he had gained his distinctive
7453  appellation of the White Whale; a name, indeed, literally justified by
7454  his vivid aspect, when seen gliding at high noon through a dark blue
7455  sea, leaving a milky-way wake of creamy foam, all spangled with golden
7456  gleamings.
7457  
7458  Nor was it his unwonted magnitude, nor his remarkable hue, nor yet his
7459  deformed lower jaw, that so much invested the whale with natural
7460  terror, as that unexampled, intelligent malignity which, according to
7461  specific accounts, he had over and over again evinced in his assaults.
7462  More than all, his treacherous retreats struck more of dismay than
7463  perhaps aught else. For, when swimming before his exulting pursuers,
7464  with every apparent symptom of alarm, he had several times been known
7465  to turn round suddenly, and, bearing down upon them, either stave their
7466  boats to splinters, or drive them back in consternation to their ship.
7467  
7468  Already several fatalities had attended his chase. But though similar
7469  disasters, however little bruited ashore, were by no means unusual in
7470  the fishery; yet, in most instances, such seemed the White Whale’s
7471  infernal aforethought of ferocity, that every dismembering or death
7472  that he caused, was not wholly regarded as having been inflicted by an
7473  unintelligent agent.
7474  
7475  Judge, then, to what pitches of inflamed, distracted fury the minds of
7476  his more desperate hunters were impelled, when amid the chips of chewed
7477  boats, and the sinking limbs of torn comrades, they swam out of the
7478  white curds of the whale’s direful wrath into the serene, exasperating
7479  sunlight, that smiled on, as if at a birth or a bridal.
7480  
7481  His three boats stove around him, and oars and men both whirling in the
7482  eddies; one captain, seizing the line-knife from his broken prow, had
7483  dashed at the whale, as an Arkansas duellist at his foe, blindly
7484  seeking with a six inch blade to reach the fathom-deep life of the
7485  whale. That captain was Ahab. And then it was, that suddenly sweeping
7486  his sickle-shaped lower jaw beneath him, Moby Dick had reaped away
7487  Ahab’s leg, as a mower a blade of grass in the field. No turbaned Turk,
7488  no hired Venetian or Malay, could have smote him with more seeming
7489  malice. Small reason was there to doubt, then, that ever since that
7490  almost fatal encounter, Ahab had cherished a wild vindictiveness
7491  against the whale, all the more fell for that in his frantic morbidness
7492  he at last came to identify with him, not only all his bodily woes, but
7493  all his intellectual and spiritual exasperations. The White Whale swam
7494  before him as the monomaniac incarnation of all those malicious
7495  agencies which some deep men feel eating in them, till they are left
7496  living on with half a heart and half a lung. That intangible malignity
7497  which has been from the beginning; to whose dominion even the modern
7498  Christians ascribe one-half of the worlds; which the ancient Ophites of
7499  the east reverenced in their statue devil;—Ahab did not fall down and
7500  worship it like them; but deliriously transferring its idea to the
7501  abhorred white whale, he pitted himself, all mutilated, against it. All
7502  that most maddens and torments; all that stirs up the lees of things;
7503  all truth with malice in it; all that cracks the sinews and cakes the
7504  brain; all the subtle demonisms of life and thought; all evil, to crazy
7505  Ahab, were visibly personified, and made practically assailable in Moby
7506  Dick. He piled upon the whale’s white hump the sum of all the general
7507  rage and hate felt by his whole race from Adam down; and then, as if
7508  his chest had been a mortar, he burst his hot heart’s shell upon it.
7509  
7510  It is not probable that this monomania in him took its instant rise at
7511  the precise time of his bodily dismemberment. Then, in darting at the
7512  monster, knife in hand, he had but given loose to a sudden, passionate,
7513  corporal animosity; and when he received the stroke that tore him, he
7514  probably but felt the agonizing bodily laceration, but nothing more.
7515  Yet, when by this collision forced to turn towards home, and for long
7516  months of days and weeks, Ahab and anguish lay stretched together in
7517  one hammock, rounding in mid winter that dreary, howling Patagonian
7518  Cape; then it was, that his torn body and gashed soul bled into one
7519  another; and so interfusing, made him mad. That it was only then, on
7520  the homeward voyage, after the encounter, that the final monomania
7521  seized him, seems all but certain from the fact that, at intervals
7522  during the passage, he was a raving lunatic; and, though unlimbed of a
7523  leg, yet such vital strength yet lurked in his Egyptian chest, and was
7524  moreover intensified by his delirium, that his mates were forced to
7525  lace him fast, even there, as he sailed, raving in his hammock. In a
7526  strait-jacket, he swung to the mad rockings of the gales. And, when
7527  running into more sufferable latitudes, the ship, with mild stun’sails
7528  spread, floated across the tranquil tropics, and, to all appearances,
7529  the old man’s delirium seemed left behind him with the Cape Horn
7530  swells, and he came forth from his dark den into the blessed light and
7531  air; even then, when he bore that firm, collected front, however pale,
7532  and issued his calm orders once again; and his mates thanked God the
7533  direful madness was now gone; even then, Ahab, in his hidden self,
7534  raved on. Human madness is oftentimes a cunning and most feline thing.
7535  When you think it fled, it may have but become transfigured into some
7536  still subtler form. Ahab’s full lunacy subsided not, but deepeningly
7537  contracted; like the unabated Hudson, when that noble Northman flows
7538  narrowly, but unfathomably through the Highland gorge. But, as in his
7539  narrow-flowing monomania, not one jot of Ahab’s broad madness had been
7540  left behind; so in that broad madness, not one jot of his great natural
7541  intellect had perished. That before living agent, now became the living
7542  instrument. If such a furious trope may stand, his special lunacy
7543  stormed his general sanity, and carried it, and turned all its
7544  concentred cannon upon its own mad mark; so that far from having lost
7545  his strength, Ahab, to that one end, did now possess a thousand fold
7546  more potency than ever he had sanely brought to bear upon any one
7547  reasonable object.
7548  
7549  This is much; yet Ahab’s larger, darker, deeper part remains unhinted.
7550  But vain to popularize profundities, and all truth is profound. Winding
7551  far down from within the very heart of this spiked Hotel de Cluny where
7552  we here stand—however grand and wonderful, now quit it;—and take your
7553  way, ye nobler, sadder souls, to those vast Roman halls of Thermes;
7554  where far beneath the fantastic towers of man’s upper earth, his root
7555  of grandeur, his whole awful essence sits in bearded state; an antique
7556  buried beneath antiquities, and throned on torsoes! So with a broken
7557  throne, the great gods mock that captive king; so like a Caryatid, he
7558  patient sits, upholding on his frozen brow the piled entablatures of
7559  ages. Wind ye down there, ye prouder, sadder souls! question that
7560  proud, sad king! A family likeness! aye, he did beget ye, ye young
7561  exiled royalties; and from your grim sire only will the old
7562  State-secret come.
7563  
7564  Now, in his heart, Ahab had some glimpse of this, namely: all my means
7565  are sane, my motive and my object mad. Yet without power to kill, or
7566  change, or shun the fact; he likewise knew that to mankind he did long
7567  dissemble; in some sort, did still. But that thing of his dissembling
7568  was only subject to his perceptibility, not to his will determinate.
7569  Nevertheless, so well did he succeed in that dissembling, that when
7570  with ivory leg he stepped ashore at last, no Nantucketer thought him
7571  otherwise than but naturally grieved, and that to the quick, with the
7572  terrible casualty which had overtaken him.
7573  
7574  The report of his undeniable delirium at sea was likewise popularly
7575  ascribed to a kindred cause. And so too, all the added moodiness which
7576  always afterwards, to the very day of sailing in the Pequod on the
7577  present voyage, sat brooding on his brow. Nor is it so very unlikely,
7578  that far from distrusting his fitness for another whaling voyage, on
7579  account of such dark symptoms, the calculating people of that prudent
7580  isle were inclined to harbor the conceit, that for those very reasons
7581  he was all the better qualified and set on edge, for a pursuit so full
7582  of rage and wildness as the bloody hunt of whales. Gnawed within and
7583  scorched without, with the infixed, unrelenting fangs of some incurable
7584  idea; such an one, could he be found, would seem the very man to dart
7585  his iron and lift his lance against the most appalling of all brutes.
7586  Or, if for any reason thought to be corporeally incapacitated for that,
7587  yet such an one would seem superlatively competent to cheer and howl on
7588  his underlings to the attack. But be all this as it may, certain it is,
7589  that with the mad secret of his unabated rage bolted up and keyed in
7590  him, Ahab had purposely sailed upon the present voyage with the one
7591  only and all-engrossing object of hunting the White Whale. Had any one
7592  of his old acquaintances on shore but half dreamed of what was lurking
7593  in him then, how soon would their aghast and righteous souls have
7594  wrenched the ship from such a fiendish man! They were bent on
7595  profitable cruises, the profit to be counted down in dollars from the
7596  mint. He was intent on an audacious, immitigable, and supernatural
7597  revenge.
7598  
7599  Here, then, was this grey-headed, ungodly old man, chasing with curses
7600  a Job’s whale round the world, at the head of a crew, too, chiefly made
7601  up of mongrel renegades, and castaways, and cannibals—morally enfeebled
7602  also, by the incompetence of mere unaided virtue or right-mindedness in
7603  Starbuck, the invulnerable jollity of indifference and recklessness in
7604  Stubb, and the pervading mediocrity in Flask. Such a crew, so
7605  officered, seemed specially picked and packed by some infernal fatality
7606  to help him to his monomaniac revenge. How it was that they so
7607  aboundingly responded to the old man’s ire—by what evil magic their
7608  souls were possessed, that at times his hate seemed almost theirs; the
7609  White Whale as much their insufferable foe as his; how all this came to
7610  be—what the White Whale was to them, or how to their unconscious
7611  understandings, also, in some dim, unsuspected way, he might have
7612  seemed the gliding great demon of the seas of life,—all this to
7613  explain, would be to dive deeper than Ishmael can go. The subterranean
7614  miner that works in us all, how can one tell whither leads his shaft by
7615  the ever shifting, muffled sound of his pick? Who does not feel the
7616  irresistible arm drag? What skiff in tow of a seventy-four can stand
7617  still? For one, I gave myself up to the abandonment of the time and the
7618  place; but while yet all a-rush to encounter the whale, could see
7619  naught in that brute but the deadliest ill.
7620  
7621  
7622  CHAPTER 42. The Whiteness of the Whale.
7623  
7624  What the white whale was to Ahab, has been hinted; what, at times, he
7625  was to me, as yet remains unsaid.
7626  
7627  Aside from those more obvious considerations touching Moby Dick, which
7628  could not but occasionally awaken in any man’s soul some alarm, there
7629  was another thought, or rather vague, nameless horror concerning him,
7630  which at times by its intensity completely overpowered all the rest;
7631  and yet so mystical and well nigh ineffable was it, that I almost
7632  despair of putting it in a comprehensible form. It was the whiteness of
7633  the whale that above all things appalled me. But how can I hope to
7634  explain myself here; and yet, in some dim, random way, explain myself I
7635  must, else all these chapters might be naught.
7636  
7637  Though in many natural objects, whiteness refiningly enhances beauty,
7638  as if imparting some special virtue of its own, as in marbles,
7639  japonicas, and pearls; and though various nations have in some way
7640  recognised a certain royal preeminence in this hue; even the barbaric,
7641  grand old kings of Pegu placing the title “Lord of the White Elephants”
7642  above all their other magniloquent ascriptions of dominion; and the
7643  modern kings of Siam unfurling the same snow-white quadruped in the
7644  royal standard; and the Hanoverian flag bearing the one figure of a
7645  snow-white charger; and the great Austrian Empire, Cæsarian, heir to
7646  overlording Rome, having for the imperial colour the same imperial hue;
7647  and though this pre-eminence in it applies to the human race itself,
7648  giving the white man ideal mastership over every dusky tribe; and
7649  though, besides, all this, whiteness has been even made significant of
7650  gladness, for among the Romans a white stone marked a joyful day; and
7651  though in other mortal sympathies and symbolizings, this same hue is
7652  made the emblem of many touching, noble things—the innocence of brides,
7653  the benignity of age; though among the Red Men of America the giving of
7654  the white belt of wampum was the deepest pledge of honor; though in
7655  many climes, whiteness typifies the majesty of Justice in the ermine of
7656  the Judge, and contributes to the daily state of kings and queens drawn
7657  by milk-white steeds; though even in the higher mysteries of the most
7658  august religions it has been made the symbol of the divine spotlessness
7659  and power; by the Persian fire worshippers, the white forked flame
7660  being held the holiest on the altar; and in the Greek mythologies,
7661  Great Jove himself being made incarnate in a snow-white bull; and
7662  though to the noble Iroquois, the midwinter sacrifice of the sacred
7663  White Dog was by far the holiest festival of their theology, that
7664  spotless, faithful creature being held the purest envoy they could send
7665  to the Great Spirit with the annual tidings of their own fidelity; and
7666  though directly from the Latin word for white, all Christian priests
7667  derive the name of one part of their sacred vesture, the alb or tunic,
7668  worn beneath the cassock; and though among the holy pomps of the Romish
7669  faith, white is specially employed in the celebration of the Passion of
7670  our Lord; though in the Vision of St. John, white robes are given to
7671  the redeemed, and the four-and-twenty elders stand clothed in white
7672  before the great white throne, and the Holy One that sitteth there
7673  white like wool; yet for all these accumulated associations, with
7674  whatever is sweet, and honorable, and sublime, there yet lurks an
7675  elusive something in the innermost idea of this hue, which strikes more
7676  of panic to the soul than that redness which affrights in blood.
7677  
7678  This elusive quality it is, which causes the thought of whiteness, when
7679  divorced from more kindly associations, and coupled with any object
7680  terrible in itself, to heighten that terror to the furthest bounds.
7681  Witness the white bear of the poles, and the white shark of the
7682  tropics; what but their smooth, flaky whiteness makes them the
7683  transcendent horrors they are? That ghastly whiteness it is which
7684  imparts such an abhorrent mildness, even more loathsome than terrific,
7685  to the dumb gloating of their aspect. So that not the fierce-fanged
7686  tiger in his heraldic coat can so stagger courage as the white-shrouded
7687  bear or shark.*
7688  
7689  *With reference to the Polar bear, it may possibly be urged by him who
7690  would fain go still deeper into this matter, that it is not the
7691  whiteness, separately regarded, which heightens the intolerable
7692  hideousness of that brute; for, analysed, that heightened hideousness,
7693  it might be said, only rises from the circumstance, that the
7694  irresponsible ferociousness of the creature stands invested in the
7695  fleece of celestial innocence and love; and hence, by bringing together
7696  two such opposite emotions in our minds, the Polar bear frightens us
7697  with so unnatural a contrast. But even assuming all this to be true;
7698  yet, were it not for the whiteness, you would not have that intensified
7699  terror.
7700  
7701  As for the white shark, the white gliding ghostliness of repose in that
7702  creature, when beheld in his ordinary moods, strangely tallies with the
7703  same quality in the Polar quadruped. This peculiarity is most vividly
7704  hit by the French in the name they bestow upon that fish. The Romish
7705  mass for the dead begins with “Requiem eternam” (eternal rest), whence
7706  _Requiem_ denominating the mass itself, and any other funeral music.
7707  Now, in allusion to the white, silent stillness of death in this shark,
7708  and the mild deadliness of his habits, the French call him _Requin_.
7709  
7710  Bethink thee of the albatross, whence come those clouds of spiritual
7711  wonderment and pale dread, in which that white phantom sails in all
7712  imaginations? Not Coleridge first threw that spell; but God’s great,
7713  unflattering laureate, Nature.*
7714  
7715  *I remember the first albatross I ever saw. It was during a prolonged
7716  gale, in waters hard upon the Antarctic seas. From my forenoon watch
7717  below, I ascended to the overclouded deck; and there, dashed upon the
7718  main hatches, I saw a regal, feathery thing of unspotted whiteness, and
7719  with a hooked, Roman bill sublime. At intervals, it arched forth its
7720  vast archangel wings, as if to embrace some holy ark. Wondrous
7721  flutterings and throbbings shook it. Though bodily unharmed, it uttered
7722  cries, as some king’s ghost in supernatural distress. Through its
7723  inexpressible, strange eyes, methought I peeped to secrets which took
7724  hold of God. As Abraham before the angels, I bowed myself; the white
7725  thing was so white, its wings so wide, and in those for ever exiled
7726  waters, I had lost the miserable warping memories of traditions and of
7727  towns. Long I gazed at that prodigy of plumage. I cannot tell, can only
7728  hint, the things that darted through me then. But at last I awoke; and
7729  turning, asked a sailor what bird was this. A goney, he replied. Goney!
7730  never had heard that name before; is it conceivable that this glorious
7731  thing is utterly unknown to men ashore! never! But some time after, I
7732  learned that goney was some seaman’s name for albatross. So that by no
7733  possibility could Coleridge’s wild Rhyme have had aught to do with
7734  those mystical impressions which were mine, when I saw that bird upon
7735  our deck. For neither had I then read the Rhyme, nor knew the bird to
7736  be an albatross. Yet, in saying this, I do but indirectly burnish a
7737  little brighter the noble merit of the poem and the poet.
7738  
7739  I assert, then, that in the wondrous bodily whiteness of the bird
7740  chiefly lurks the secret of the spell; a truth the more evinced in
7741  this, that by a solecism of terms there are birds called grey
7742  albatrosses; and these I have frequently seen, but never with such
7743  emotions as when I beheld the Antarctic fowl.
7744  
7745  But how had the mystic thing been caught? Whisper it not, and I will
7746  tell; with a treacherous hook and line, as the fowl floated on the sea.
7747  At last the Captain made a postman of it; tying a lettered, leathern
7748  tally round its neck, with the ship’s time and place; and then letting
7749  it escape. But I doubt not, that leathern tally, meant for man, was
7750  taken off in Heaven, when the white fowl flew to join the wing-folding,
7751  the invoking, and adoring cherubim!
7752  
7753  Most famous in our Western annals and Indian traditions is that of the
7754  White Steed of the Prairies; a magnificent milk-white charger,
7755  large-eyed, small-headed, bluff-chested, and with the dignity of a
7756  thousand monarchs in his lofty, overscorning carriage. He was the
7757  elected Xerxes of vast herds of wild horses, whose pastures in those
7758  days were only fenced by the Rocky Mountains and the Alleghanies. At
7759  their flaming head he westward trooped it like that chosen star which
7760  every evening leads on the hosts of light. The flashing cascade of his
7761  mane, the curving comet of his tail, invested him with housings more
7762  resplendent than gold and silver-beaters could have furnished him. A
7763  most imperial and archangelical apparition of that unfallen, western
7764  world, which to the eyes of the old trappers and hunters revived the
7765  glories of those primeval times when Adam walked majestic as a god,
7766  bluff-browed and fearless as this mighty steed. Whether marching amid
7767  his aides and marshals in the van of countless cohorts that endlessly
7768  streamed it over the plains, like an Ohio; or whether with his
7769  circumambient subjects browsing all around at the horizon, the White
7770  Steed gallopingly reviewed them with warm nostrils reddening through
7771  his cool milkiness; in whatever aspect he presented himself, always to
7772  the bravest Indians he was the object of trembling reverence and awe.
7773  Nor can it be questioned from what stands on legendary record of this
7774  noble horse, that it was his spiritual whiteness chiefly, which so
7775  clothed him with divineness; and that this divineness had that in it
7776  which, though commanding worship, at the same time enforced a certain
7777  nameless terror.
7778  
7779  But there are other instances where this whiteness loses all that
7780  accessory and strange glory which invests it in the White Steed and
7781  Albatross.
7782  
7783  What is it that in the Albino man so peculiarly repels and often shocks
7784  the eye, as that sometimes he is loathed by his own kith and kin! It is
7785  that whiteness which invests him, a thing expressed by the name he
7786  bears. The Albino is as well made as other men—has no substantive
7787  deformity—and yet this mere aspect of all-pervading whiteness makes him
7788  more strangely hideous than the ugliest abortion. Why should this be
7789  so?
7790  
7791  Nor, in quite other aspects, does Nature in her least palpable but not
7792  the less malicious agencies, fail to enlist among her forces this
7793  crowning attribute of the terrible. From its snowy aspect, the
7794  gauntleted ghost of the Southern Seas has been denominated the White
7795  Squall. Nor, in some historic instances, has the art of human malice
7796  omitted so potent an auxiliary. How wildly it heightens the effect of
7797  that passage in Froissart, when, masked in the snowy symbol of their
7798  faction, the desperate White Hoods of Ghent murder their bailiff in the
7799  market-place!
7800  
7801  Nor, in some things, does the common, hereditary experience of all
7802  mankind fail to bear witness to the supernaturalism of this hue. It
7803  cannot well be doubted, that the one visible quality in the aspect of
7804  the dead which most appals the gazer, is the marble pallor lingering
7805  there; as if indeed that pallor were as much like the badge of
7806  consternation in the other world, as of mortal trepidation here. And
7807  from that pallor of the dead, we borrow the expressive hue of the
7808  shroud in which we wrap them. Nor even in our superstitions do we fail
7809  to throw the same snowy mantle round our phantoms; all ghosts rising in
7810  a milk-white fog—Yea, while these terrors seize us, let us add, that
7811  even the king of terrors, when personified by the evangelist, rides on
7812  his pallid horse.
7813  
7814  Therefore, in his other moods, symbolize whatever grand or gracious
7815  thing he will by whiteness, no man can deny that in its profoundest
7816  idealized significance it calls up a peculiar apparition to the soul.
7817  
7818  But though without dissent this point be fixed, how is mortal man to
7819  account for it? To analyse it, would seem impossible. Can we, then, by
7820  the citation of some of those instances wherein this thing of
7821  whiteness—though for the time either wholly or in great part stripped
7822  of all direct associations calculated to impart to it aught fearful,
7823  but nevertheless, is found to exert over us the same sorcery, however
7824  modified;—can we thus hope to light upon some chance clue to conduct us
7825  to the hidden cause we seek?
7826  
7827  Let us try. But in a matter like this, subtlety appeals to subtlety,
7828  and without imagination no man can follow another into these halls. And
7829  though, doubtless, some at least of the imaginative impressions about
7830  to be presented may have been shared by most men, yet few perhaps were
7831  entirely conscious of them at the time, and therefore may not be able
7832  to recall them now.
7833  
7834  Why to the man of untutored ideality, who happens to be but loosely
7835  acquainted with the peculiar character of the day, does the bare
7836  mention of Whitsuntide marshal in the fancy such long, dreary,
7837  speechless processions of slow-pacing pilgrims, down-cast and hooded
7838  with new-fallen snow? Or, to the unread, unsophisticated Protestant of
7839  the Middle American States, why does the passing mention of a White
7840  Friar or a White Nun, evoke such an eyeless statue in the soul?
7841  
7842  Or what is there apart from the traditions of dungeoned warriors and
7843  kings (which will not wholly account for it) that makes the White Tower
7844  of London tell so much more strongly on the imagination of an
7845  untravelled American, than those other storied structures, its
7846  neighbors—the Byward Tower, or even the Bloody? And those sublimer
7847  towers, the White Mountains of New Hampshire, whence, in peculiar
7848  moods, comes that gigantic ghostliness over the soul at the bare
7849  mention of that name, while the thought of Virginia’s Blue Ridge is
7850  full of a soft, dewy, distant dreaminess? Or why, irrespective of all
7851  latitudes and longitudes, does the name of the White Sea exert such a
7852  spectralness over the fancy, while that of the Yellow Sea lulls us with
7853  mortal thoughts of long lacquered mild afternoons on the waves,
7854  followed by the gaudiest and yet sleepiest of sunsets? Or, to choose a
7855  wholly unsubstantial instance, purely addressed to the fancy, why, in
7856  reading the old fairy tales of Central Europe, does “the tall pale man”
7857  of the Hartz forests, whose changeless pallor unrustlingly glides
7858  through the green of the groves—why is this phantom more terrible than
7859  all the whooping imps of the Blocksburg?
7860  
7861  Nor is it, altogether, the remembrance of her cathedral-toppling
7862  earthquakes; nor the stampedoes of her frantic seas; nor the
7863  tearlessness of arid skies that never rain; nor the sight of her wide
7864  field of leaning spires, wrenched cope-stones, and crosses all adroop
7865  (like canted yards of anchored fleets); and her suburban avenues of
7866  house-walls lying over upon each other, as a tossed pack of cards;—it
7867  is not these things alone which make tearless Lima, the strangest,
7868  saddest city thou can’st see. For Lima has taken the white veil; and
7869  there is a higher horror in this whiteness of her woe. Old as Pizarro,
7870  this whiteness keeps her ruins for ever new; admits not the cheerful
7871  greenness of complete decay; spreads over her broken ramparts the rigid
7872  pallor of an apoplexy that fixes its own distortions.
7873  
7874  I know that, to the common apprehension, this phenomenon of whiteness
7875  is not confessed to be the prime agent in exaggerating the terror of
7876  objects otherwise terrible; nor to the unimaginative mind is there
7877  aught of terror in those appearances whose awfulness to another mind
7878  almost solely consists in this one phenomenon, especially when
7879  exhibited under any form at all approaching to muteness or
7880  universality. What I mean by these two statements may perhaps be
7881  respectively elucidated by the following examples.
7882  
7883  First: The mariner, when drawing nigh the coasts of foreign lands, if
7884  by night he hear the roar of breakers, starts to vigilance, and feels
7885  just enough of trepidation to sharpen all his faculties; but under
7886  precisely similar circumstances, let him be called from his hammock to
7887  view his ship sailing through a midnight sea of milky whiteness—as if
7888  from encircling headlands shoals of combed white bears were swimming
7889  round him, then he feels a silent, superstitious dread; the shrouded
7890  phantom of the whitened waters is horrible to him as a real ghost; in
7891  vain the lead assures him he is still off soundings; heart and helm
7892  they both go down; he never rests till blue water is under him again.
7893  Yet where is the mariner who will tell thee, “Sir, it was not so much
7894  the fear of striking hidden rocks, as the fear of that hideous
7895  whiteness that so stirred me?”
7896  
7897  Second: To the native Indian of Peru, the continual sight of the
7898  snow-howdahed Andes conveys naught of dread, except, perhaps, in the
7899  mere fancying of the eternal frosted desolateness reigning at such vast
7900  altitudes, and the natural conceit of what a fearfulness it would be to
7901  lose oneself in such inhuman solitudes. Much the same is it with the
7902  backwoodsman of the West, who with comparative indifference views an
7903  unbounded prairie sheeted with driven snow, no shadow of tree or twig
7904  to break the fixed trance of whiteness. Not so the sailor, beholding
7905  the scenery of the Antarctic seas; where at times, by some infernal
7906  trick of legerdemain in the powers of frost and air, he, shivering and
7907  half shipwrecked, instead of rainbows speaking hope and solace to his
7908  misery, views what seems a boundless churchyard grinning upon him with
7909  its lean ice monuments and splintered crosses.
7910  
7911  But thou sayest, methinks that white-lead chapter about whiteness is
7912  but a white flag hung out from a craven soul; thou surrenderest to a
7913  hypo, Ishmael.
7914  
7915  Tell me, why this strong young colt, foaled in some peaceful valley of
7916  Vermont, far removed from all beasts of prey—why is it that upon the
7917  sunniest day, if you but shake a fresh buffalo robe behind him, so that
7918  he cannot even see it, but only smells its wild animal muskiness—why
7919  will he start, snort, and with bursting eyes paw the ground in
7920  phrensies of affright? There is no remembrance in him of any gorings of
7921  wild creatures in his green northern home, so that the strange
7922  muskiness he smells cannot recall to him anything associated with the
7923  experience of former perils; for what knows he, this New England colt,
7924  of the black bisons of distant Oregon?
7925  
7926  No: but here thou beholdest even in a dumb brute, the instinct of the
7927  knowledge of the demonism in the world. Though thousands of miles from
7928  Oregon, still when he smells that savage musk, the rending, goring
7929  bison herds are as present as to the deserted wild foal of the
7930  prairies, which this instant they may be trampling into dust.
7931  
7932  Thus, then, the muffled rollings of a milky sea; the bleak rustlings of
7933  the festooned frosts of mountains; the desolate shiftings of the
7934  windrowed snows of prairies; all these, to Ishmael, are as the shaking
7935  of that buffalo robe to the frightened colt!
7936  
7937  Though neither knows where lie the nameless things of which the mystic
7938  sign gives forth such hints; yet with me, as with the colt, somewhere
7939  those things must exist. Though in many of its aspects this visible
7940  world seems formed in love, the invisible spheres were formed in
7941  fright.
7942  
7943  But not yet have we solved the incantation of this whiteness, and
7944  learned why it appeals with such power to the soul; and more strange
7945  and far more portentous—why, as we have seen, it is at once the most
7946  meaning symbol of spiritual things, nay, the very veil of the
7947  Christian’s Deity; and yet should be as it is, the intensifying agent
7948  in things the most appalling to mankind.
7949  
7950  Is it that by its indefiniteness it shadows forth the heartless voids
7951  and immensities of the universe, and thus stabs us from behind with the
7952  thought of annihilation, when beholding the white depths of the milky
7953  way? Or is it, that as in essence whiteness is not so much a colour as
7954  the visible absence of colour; and at the same time the concrete of all
7955  colours; is it for these reasons that there is such a dumb blankness,
7956  full of meaning, in a wide landscape of snows—a colourless, all-colour
7957  of atheism from which we shrink? And when we consider that other theory
7958  of the natural philosophers, that all other earthly hues—every stately
7959  or lovely emblazoning—the sweet tinges of sunset skies and woods; yea,
7960  and the gilded velvets of butterflies, and the butterfly cheeks of
7961  young girls; all these are but subtile deceits, not actually inherent
7962  in substances, but only laid on from without; so that all deified
7963  Nature absolutely paints like the harlot, whose allurements cover
7964  nothing but the charnel-house within; and when we proceed further, and
7965  consider that the mystical cosmetic which produces every one of her
7966  hues, the great principle of light, for ever remains white or colorless
7967  in itself, and if operating without medium upon matter, would touch all
7968  objects, even tulips and roses, with its own blank tinge—pondering all
7969  this, the palsied universe lies before us a leper; and like wilful
7970  travellers in Lapland, who refuse to wear coloured and colouring
7971  glasses upon their eyes, so the wretched infidel gazes himself blind at
7972  the monumental white shroud that wraps all the prospect around him. And
7973  of all these things the Albino whale was the symbol. Wonder ye then at
7974  the fiery hunt?
7975  
7976  
7977  CHAPTER 43. Hark!
7978  
7979  “HIST! Did you hear that noise, Cabaco?”
7980  
7981  It was the middle-watch: a fair moonlight; the seamen were standing in
7982  a cordon, extending from one of the fresh-water butts in the waist, to
7983  the scuttle-butt near the taffrail. In this manner, they passed the
7984  buckets to fill the scuttle-butt. Standing, for the most part, on the
7985  hallowed precincts of the quarter-deck, they were careful not to speak
7986  or rustle their feet. From hand to hand, the buckets went in the
7987  deepest silence, only broken by the occasional flap of a sail, and the
7988  steady hum of the unceasingly advancing keel.
7989  
7990  It was in the midst of this repose, that Archy, one of the cordon,
7991  whose post was near the after-hatches, whispered to his neighbor, a
7992  Cholo, the words above.
7993  
7994  “Hist! did you hear that noise, Cabaco?”
7995  
7996  “Take the bucket, will ye, Archy? what noise d’ye mean?”
7997  
7998  “There it is again—under the hatches—don’t you hear it—a cough—it
7999  sounded like a cough.”
8000  
8001  “Cough be damned! Pass along that return bucket.”
8002  
8003  “There again—there it is!—it sounds like two or three sleepers turning
8004  over, now!”
8005  
8006  “Caramba! have done, shipmate, will ye? It’s the three soaked biscuits
8007  ye eat for supper turning over inside of ye—nothing else. Look to the
8008  bucket!”
8009  
8010  “Say what ye will, shipmate; I’ve sharp ears.”
8011  
8012  “Aye, you are the chap, ain’t ye, that heard the hum of the old
8013  Quakeress’s knitting-needles fifty miles at sea from Nantucket; you’re
8014  the chap.”
8015  
8016  “Grin away; we’ll see what turns up. Hark ye, Cabaco, there is somebody
8017  down in the after-hold that has not yet been seen on deck; and I
8018  suspect our old Mogul knows something of it too. I heard Stubb tell
8019  Flask, one morning watch, that there was something of that sort in the
8020  wind.”
8021  
8022  “Tish! the bucket!”
8023  
8024  
8025  CHAPTER 44. The Chart.
8026  
8027  Had you followed Captain Ahab down into his cabin after the squall that
8028  took place on the night succeeding that wild ratification of his
8029  purpose with his crew, you would have seen him go to a locker in the
8030  transom, and bringing out a large wrinkled roll of yellowish sea
8031  charts, spread them before him on his screwed-down table. Then seating
8032  himself before it, you would have seen him intently study the various
8033  lines and shadings which there met his eye; and with slow but steady
8034  pencil trace additional courses over spaces that before were blank. At
8035  intervals, he would refer to piles of old log-books beside him, wherein
8036  were set down the seasons and places in which, on various former
8037  voyages of various ships, sperm whales had been captured or seen.
8038  
8039  While thus employed, the heavy pewter lamp suspended in chains over his
8040  head, continually rocked with the motion of the ship, and for ever
8041  threw shifting gleams and shadows of lines upon his wrinkled brow, till
8042  it almost seemed that while he himself was marking out lines and
8043  courses on the wrinkled charts, some invisible pencil was also tracing
8044  lines and courses upon the deeply marked chart of his forehead.
8045  
8046  But it was not this night in particular that, in the solitude of his
8047  cabin, Ahab thus pondered over his charts. Almost every night they were
8048  brought out; almost every night some pencil marks were effaced, and
8049  others were substituted. For with the charts of all four oceans before
8050  him, Ahab was threading a maze of currents and eddies, with a view to
8051  the more certain accomplishment of that monomaniac thought of his soul.
8052  
8053  Now, to any one not fully acquainted with the ways of the leviathans,
8054  it might seem an absurdly hopeless task thus to seek out one solitary
8055  creature in the unhooped oceans of this planet. But not so did it seem
8056  to Ahab, who knew the sets of all tides and currents; and thereby
8057  calculating the driftings of the sperm whale’s food; and, also, calling
8058  to mind the regular, ascertained seasons for hunting him in particular
8059  latitudes; could arrive at reasonable surmises, almost approaching to
8060  certainties, concerning the timeliest day to be upon this or that
8061  ground in search of his prey.
8062  
8063  So assured, indeed, is the fact concerning the periodicalness of the
8064  sperm whale’s resorting to given waters, that many hunters believe
8065  that, could he be closely observed and studied throughout the world;
8066  were the logs for one voyage of the entire whale fleet carefully
8067  collated, then the migrations of the sperm whale would be found to
8068  correspond in invariability to those of the herring-shoals or the
8069  flights of swallows. On this hint, attempts have been made to construct
8070  elaborate migratory charts of the sperm whale.*
8071  
8072  
8073    *Since the above was written, the statement is happily borne out by
8074    an official circular, issued by Lieutenant Maury, of the National
8075    Observatory, Washington, April 16th, 1851. By that circular, it
8076    appears that precisely such a chart is in course of completion; and
8077    portions of it are presented in the circular. “This chart divides the
8078    ocean into districts of five degrees of latitude by five degrees of
8079    longitude; perpendicularly through each of which districts are twelve
8080    columns for the twelve months; and horizontally through each of which
8081    districts are three lines; one to show the number of days that have
8082    been spent in each month in every district, and the two others to
8083    show the number of days in which whales, sperm or right, have been
8084    seen.”
8085  
8086  
8087  
8088  
8089  Besides, when making a passage from one feeding-ground to another, the
8090  sperm whales, guided by some infallible instinct—say, rather, secret
8091  intelligence from the Deity—mostly swim in _veins_, as they are called;
8092  continuing their way along a given ocean-line with such undeviating
8093  exactitude, that no ship ever sailed her course, by any chart, with one
8094  tithe of such marvellous precision. Though, in these cases, the
8095  direction taken by any one whale be straight as a surveyor’s parallel,
8096  and though the line of advance be strictly confined to its own
8097  unavoidable, straight wake, yet the arbitrary _vein_ in which at these
8098  times he is said to swim, generally embraces some few miles in width
8099  (more or less, as the vein is presumed to expand or contract); but
8100  never exceeds the visual sweep from the whale-ship’s mast-heads, when
8101  circumspectly gliding along this magic zone. The sum is, that at
8102  particular seasons within that breadth and along that path, migrating
8103  whales may with great confidence be looked for.
8104  
8105  And hence not only at substantiated times, upon well known separate
8106  feeding-grounds, could Ahab hope to encounter his prey; but in crossing
8107  the widest expanses of water between those grounds he could, by his
8108  art, so place and time himself on his way, as even then not to be
8109  wholly without prospect of a meeting.
8110  
8111  There was a circumstance which at first sight seemed to entangle his
8112  delirious but still methodical scheme. But not so in the reality,
8113  perhaps. Though the gregarious sperm whales have their regular seasons
8114  for particular grounds, yet in general you cannot conclude that the
8115  herds which haunted such and such a latitude or longitude this year,
8116  say, will turn out to be identically the same with those that were
8117  found there the preceding season; though there are peculiar and
8118  unquestionable instances where the contrary of this has proved true. In
8119  general, the same remark, only within a less wide limit, applies to the
8120  solitaries and hermits among the matured, aged sperm whales. So that
8121  though Moby Dick had in a former year been seen, for example, on what
8122  is called the Seychelle ground in the Indian ocean, or Volcano Bay on
8123  the Japanese Coast; yet it did not follow, that were the Pequod to
8124  visit either of those spots at any subsequent corresponding season, she
8125  would infallibly encounter him there. So, too, with some other feeding
8126  grounds, where he had at times revealed himself. But all these seemed
8127  only his casual stopping-places and ocean-inns, so to speak, not his
8128  places of prolonged abode. And where Ahab’s chances of accomplishing
8129  his object have hitherto been spoken of, allusion has only been made to
8130  whatever way-side, antecedent, extra prospects were his, ere a
8131  particular set time or place were attained, when all possibilities
8132  would become probabilities, and, as Ahab fondly thought, every
8133  possibility the next thing to a certainty. That particular set time and
8134  place were conjoined in the one technical phrase—the
8135  Season-on-the-Line. For there and then, for several consecutive years,
8136  Moby Dick had been periodically descried, lingering in those waters for
8137  awhile, as the sun, in its annual round, loiters for a predicted
8138  interval in any one sign of the Zodiac. There it was, too, that most of
8139  the deadly encounters with the white whale had taken place; there the
8140  waves were storied with his deeds; there also was that tragic spot
8141  where the monomaniac old man had found the awful motive to his
8142  vengeance. But in the cautious comprehensiveness and unloitering
8143  vigilance with which Ahab threw his brooding soul into this unfaltering
8144  hunt, he would not permit himself to rest all his hopes upon the one
8145  crowning fact above mentioned, however flattering it might be to those
8146  hopes; nor in the sleeplessness of his vow could he so tranquillize his
8147  unquiet heart as to postpone all intervening quest.
8148  
8149  Now, the Pequod had sailed from Nantucket at the very beginning of the
8150  Season-on-the-Line. No possible endeavor then could enable her
8151  commander to make the great passage southwards, double Cape Horn, and
8152  then running down sixty degrees of latitude arrive in the equatorial
8153  Pacific in time to cruise there. Therefore, he must wait for the next
8154  ensuing season. Yet the premature hour of the Pequod’s sailing had,
8155  perhaps, been correctly selected by Ahab, with a view to this very
8156  complexion of things. Because, an interval of three hundred and
8157  sixty-five days and nights was before him; an interval which, instead
8158  of impatiently enduring ashore, he would spend in a miscellaneous hunt;
8159  if by chance the White Whale, spending his vacation in seas far remote
8160  from his periodical feeding-grounds, should turn up his wrinkled brow
8161  off the Persian Gulf, or in the Bengal Bay, or China Seas, or in any
8162  other waters haunted by his race. So that Monsoons, Pampas,
8163  Nor’-Westers, Harmattans, Trades; any wind but the Levanter and Simoon,
8164  might blow Moby Dick into the devious zig-zag world-circle of the
8165  Pequod’s circumnavigating wake.
8166  
8167  But granting all this; yet, regarded discreetly and coolly, seems it
8168  not but a mad idea, this; that in the broad boundless ocean, one
8169  solitary whale, even if encountered, should be thought capable of
8170  individual recognition from his hunter, even as a white-bearded Mufti
8171  in the thronged thoroughfares of Constantinople? Yes. For the peculiar
8172  snow-white brow of Moby Dick, and his snow-white hump, could not but be
8173  unmistakable. And have I not tallied the whale, Ahab would mutter to
8174  himself, as after poring over his charts till long after midnight he
8175  would throw himself back in reveries—tallied him, and shall he escape?
8176  His broad fins are bored, and scalloped out like a lost sheep’s ear!
8177  And here, his mad mind would run on in a breathless race; till a
8178  weariness and faintness of pondering came over him; and in the open air
8179  of the deck he would seek to recover his strength. Ah, God! what
8180  trances of torments does that man endure who is consumed with one
8181  unachieved revengeful desire. He sleeps with clenched hands; and wakes
8182  with his own bloody nails in his palms.
8183  
8184  Often, when forced from his hammock by exhausting and intolerably vivid
8185  dreams of the night, which, resuming his own intense thoughts through
8186  the day, carried them on amid a clashing of phrensies, and whirled them
8187  round and round and round in his blazing brain, till the very throbbing
8188  of his life-spot became insufferable anguish; and when, as was
8189  sometimes the case, these spiritual throes in him heaved his being up
8190  from its base, and a chasm seemed opening in him, from which forked
8191  flames and lightnings shot up, and accursed fiends beckoned him to leap
8192  down among them; when this hell in himself yawned beneath him, a wild
8193  cry would be heard through the ship; and with glaring eyes Ahab would
8194  burst from his state room, as though escaping from a bed that was on
8195  fire. Yet these, perhaps, instead of being the unsuppressable symptoms
8196  of some latent weakness, or fright at his own resolve, were but the
8197  plainest tokens of its intensity. For, at such times, crazy Ahab, the
8198  scheming, unappeasedly steadfast hunter of the white whale; this Ahab
8199  that had gone to his hammock, was not the agent that so caused him to
8200  burst from it in horror again. The latter was the eternal, living
8201  principle or soul in him; and in sleep, being for the time dissociated
8202  from the characterizing mind, which at other times employed it for its
8203  outer vehicle or agent, it spontaneously sought escape from the
