8204  scorching contiguity of the frantic thing, of which, for the time, it
8205  was no longer an integral. But as the mind does not exist unless
8206  leagued with the soul, therefore it must have been that, in Ahab’s
8207  case, yielding up all his thoughts and fancies to his one supreme
8208  purpose; that purpose, by its own sheer inveteracy of will, forced
8209  itself against gods and devils into a kind of self-assumed, independent
8210  being of its own. Nay, could grimly live and burn, while the common
8211  vitality to which it was conjoined, fled horror-stricken from the
8212  unbidden and unfathered birth. Therefore, the tormented spirit that
8213  glared out of bodily eyes, when what seemed Ahab rushed from his room,
8214  was for the time but a vacated thing, a formless somnambulistic being,
8215  a ray of living light, to be sure, but without an object to colour, and
8216  therefore a blankness in itself. God help thee, old man, thy thoughts
8217  have created a creature in thee; and he whose intense thinking thus
8218  makes him a Prometheus; a vulture feeds upon that heart for ever; that
8219  vulture the very creature he creates.
8220  
8221  
8222  CHAPTER 45. The Affidavit.
8223  
8224  So far as what there may be of a narrative in this book; and, indeed,
8225  as indirectly touching one or two very interesting and curious
8226  particulars in the habits of sperm whales, the foregoing chapter, in
8227  its earlier part, is as important a one as will be found in this
8228  volume; but the leading matter of it requires to be still further and
8229  more familiarly enlarged upon, in order to be adequately understood,
8230  and moreover to take away any incredulity which a profound ignorance of
8231  the entire subject may induce in some minds, as to the natural verity
8232  of the main points of this affair.
8233  
8234  I care not to perform this part of my task methodically; but shall be
8235  content to produce the desired impression by separate citations of
8236  items, practically or reliably known to me as a whaleman; and from
8237  these citations, I take it—the conclusion aimed at will naturally
8238  follow of itself.
8239  
8240  First: I have personally known three instances where a whale, after
8241  receiving a harpoon, has effected a complete escape; and, after an
8242  interval (in one instance of three years), has been again struck by the
8243  same hand, and slain; when the two irons, both marked by the same
8244  private cypher, have been taken from the body. In the instance where
8245  three years intervened between the flinging of the two harpoons; and I
8246  think it may have been something more than that; the man who darted
8247  them happening, in the interval, to go in a trading ship on a voyage to
8248  Africa, went ashore there, joined a discovery party, and penetrated far
8249  into the interior, where he travelled for a period of nearly two years,
8250  often endangered by serpents, savages, tigers, poisonous miasmas, with
8251  all the other common perils incident to wandering in the heart of
8252  unknown regions. Meanwhile, the whale he had struck must also have been
8253  on its travels; no doubt it had thrice circumnavigated the globe,
8254  brushing with its flanks all the coasts of Africa; but to no purpose.
8255  This man and this whale again came together, and the one vanquished the
8256  other. I say I, myself, have known three instances similar to this;
8257  that is in two of them I saw the whales struck; and, upon the second
8258  attack, saw the two irons with the respective marks cut in them,
8259  afterwards taken from the dead fish. In the three-year instance, it so
8260  fell out that I was in the boat both times, first and last, and the
8261  last time distinctly recognised a peculiar sort of huge mole under the
8262  whale’s eye, which I had observed there three years previous. I say
8263  three years, but I am pretty sure it was more than that. Here are three
8264  instances, then, which I personally know the truth of; but I have heard
8265  of many other instances from persons whose veracity in the matter there
8266  is no good ground to impeach.
8267  
8268  Secondly: It is well known in the Sperm Whale Fishery, however ignorant
8269  the world ashore may be of it, that there have been several memorable
8270  historical instances where a particular whale in the ocean has been at
8271  distant times and places popularly cognisable. Why such a whale became
8272  thus marked was not altogether and originally owing to his bodily
8273  peculiarities as distinguished from other whales; for however peculiar
8274  in that respect any chance whale may be, they soon put an end to his
8275  peculiarities by killing him, and boiling him down into a peculiarly
8276  valuable oil. No: the reason was this: that from the fatal experiences
8277  of the fishery there hung a terrible prestige of perilousness about
8278  such a whale as there did about Rinaldo Rinaldini, insomuch that most
8279  fishermen were content to recognise him by merely touching their
8280  tarpaulins when he would be discovered lounging by them on the sea,
8281  without seeking to cultivate a more intimate acquaintance. Like some
8282  poor devils ashore that happen to know an irascible great man, they
8283  make distant unobtrusive salutations to him in the street, lest if they
8284  pursued the acquaintance further, they might receive a summary thump
8285  for their presumption.
8286  
8287  But not only did each of these famous whales enjoy great individual
8288  celebrity—Nay, you may call it an ocean-wide renown; not only was he
8289  famous in life and now is immortal in forecastle stories after death,
8290  but he was admitted into all the rights, privileges, and distinctions
8291  of a name; had as much a name indeed as Cambyses or Cæsar. Was it not
8292  so, O Timor Tom! thou famed leviathan, scarred like an iceberg, who so
8293  long did’st lurk in the Oriental straits of that name, whose spout was
8294  oft seen from the palmy beach of Ombay? Was it not so, O New Zealand
8295  Jack! thou terror of all cruisers that crossed their wakes in the
8296  vicinity of the Tattoo Land? Was it not so, O Morquan! King of Japan,
8297  whose lofty jet they say at times assumed the semblance of a snow-white
8298  cross against the sky? Was it not so, O Don Miguel! thou Chilian whale,
8299  marked like an old tortoise with mystic hieroglyphics upon the back! In
8300  plain prose, here are four whales as well known to the students of
8301  Cetacean History as Marius or Sylla to the classic scholar.
8302  
8303  But this is not all. New Zealand Tom and Don Miguel, after at various
8304  times creating great havoc among the boats of different vessels, were
8305  finally gone in quest of, systematically hunted out, chased and killed
8306  by valiant whaling captains, who heaved up their anchors with that
8307  express object as much in view, as in setting out through the
8308  Narragansett Woods, Captain Butler of old had it in his mind to capture
8309  that notorious murderous savage Annawon, the headmost warrior of the
8310  Indian King Philip.
8311  
8312  I do not know where I can find a better place than just here, to make
8313  mention of one or two other things, which to me seem important, as in
8314  printed form establishing in all respects the reasonableness of the
8315  whole story of the White Whale, more especially the catastrophe. For
8316  this is one of those disheartening instances where truth requires full
8317  as much bolstering as error. So ignorant are most landsmen of some of
8318  the plainest and most palpable wonders of the world, that without some
8319  hints touching the plain facts, historical and otherwise, of the
8320  fishery, they might scout at Moby Dick as a monstrous fable, or still
8321  worse and more detestable, a hideous and intolerable allegory.
8322  
8323  First: Though most men have some vague flitting ideas of the general
8324  perils of the grand fishery, yet they have nothing like a fixed, vivid
8325  conception of those perils, and the frequency with which they recur.
8326  One reason perhaps is, that not one in fifty of the actual disasters
8327  and deaths by casualties in the fishery, ever finds a public record at
8328  home, however transient and immediately forgotten that record. Do you
8329  suppose that that poor fellow there, who this moment perhaps caught by
8330  the whale-line off the coast of New Guinea, is being carried down to
8331  the bottom of the sea by the sounding leviathan—do you suppose that
8332  that poor fellow’s name will appear in the newspaper obituary you will
8333  read to-morrow at your breakfast? No: because the mails are very
8334  irregular between here and New Guinea. In fact, did you ever hear what
8335  might be called regular news direct or indirect from New Guinea? Yet I
8336  tell you that upon one particular voyage which I made to the Pacific,
8337  among many others we spoke thirty different ships, every one of which
8338  had had a death by a whale, some of them more than one, and three that
8339  had each lost a boat’s crew. For God’s sake, be economical with your
8340  lamps and candles! not a gallon you burn, but at least one drop of
8341  man’s blood was spilled for it.
8342  
8343  Secondly: People ashore have indeed some indefinite idea that a whale
8344  is an enormous creature of enormous power; but I have ever found that
8345  when narrating to them some specific example of this two-fold
8346  enormousness, they have significantly complimented me upon my
8347  facetiousness; when, I declare upon my soul, I had no more idea of
8348  being facetious than Moses, when he wrote the history of the plagues of
8349  Egypt.
8350  
8351  But fortunately the special point I here seek can be established upon
8352  testimony entirely independent of my own. That point is this: The Sperm
8353  Whale is in some cases sufficiently powerful, knowing, and judiciously
8354  malicious, as with direct aforethought to stave in, utterly destroy,
8355  and sink a large ship; and what is more, the Sperm Whale _has_ done it.
8356  
8357  First: In the year 1820 the ship Essex, Captain Pollard, of Nantucket,
8358  was cruising in the Pacific Ocean. One day she saw spouts, lowered her
8359  boats, and gave chase to a shoal of sperm whales. Ere long, several of
8360  the whales were wounded; when, suddenly, a very large whale escaping
8361  from the boats, issued from the shoal, and bore directly down upon the
8362  ship. Dashing his forehead against her hull, he so stove her in, that
8363  in less than “ten minutes” she settled down and fell over. Not a
8364  surviving plank of her has been seen since. After the severest
8365  exposure, part of the crew reached the land in their boats. Being
8366  returned home at last, Captain Pollard once more sailed for the Pacific
8367  in command of another ship, but the gods shipwrecked him again upon
8368  unknown rocks and breakers; for the second time his ship was utterly
8369  lost, and forthwith forswearing the sea, he has never tempted it since.
8370  At this day Captain Pollard is a resident of Nantucket. I have seen
8371  Owen Chace, who was chief mate of the Essex at the time of the tragedy;
8372  I have read his plain and faithful narrative; I have conversed with his
8373  son; and all this within a few miles of the scene of the catastrophe.*
8374  
8375  *The following are extracts from Chace’s narrative: “Every fact seemed
8376  to warrant me in concluding that it was anything but chance which
8377  directed his operations; he made two several attacks upon the ship, at
8378  a short interval between them, both of which, according to their
8379  direction, were calculated to do us the most injury, by being made
8380  ahead, and thereby combining the speed of the two objects for the
8381  shock; to effect which, the exact manœuvres which he made were
8382  necessary. His aspect was most horrible, and such as indicated
8383  resentment and fury. He came directly from the shoal which we had just
8384  before entered, and in which we had struck three of his companions, as
8385  if fired with revenge for their sufferings.” Again: “At all events, the
8386  whole circumstances taken together, all happening before my own eyes,
8387  and producing, at the time, impressions in my mind of decided,
8388  calculating mischief, on the part of the whale (many of which
8389  impressions I cannot now recall), induce me to be satisfied that I am
8390  correct in my opinion.”
8391  
8392  Here are his reflections some time after quitting the ship, during a
8393  black night in an open boat, when almost despairing of reaching any
8394  hospitable shore. “The dark ocean and swelling waters were nothing; the
8395  fears of being swallowed up by some dreadful tempest, or dashed upon
8396  hidden rocks, with all the other ordinary subjects of fearful
8397  contemplation, seemed scarcely entitled to a moment’s thought; the
8398  dismal looking wreck, and _the horrid aspect and revenge of the whale_,
8399  wholly engrossed my reflections, until day again made its appearance.”
8400  
8401  In another place—p. 45,—he speaks of “_the mysterious and mortal attack
8402  of the animal_.”
8403  
8404  Secondly: The ship Union, also of Nantucket, was in the year 1807
8405  totally lost off the Azores by a similar onset, but the authentic
8406  particulars of this catastrophe I have never chanced to encounter,
8407  though from the whale hunters I have now and then heard casual
8408  allusions to it.
8409  
8410  Thirdly: Some eighteen or twenty years ago Commodore J——, then
8411  commanding an American sloop-of-war of the first class, happened to be
8412  dining with a party of whaling captains, on board a Nantucket ship in
8413  the harbor of Oahu, Sandwich Islands. Conversation turning upon whales,
8414  the Commodore was pleased to be sceptical touching the amazing strength
8415  ascribed to them by the professional gentlemen present. He peremptorily
8416  denied for example, that any whale could so smite his stout
8417  sloop-of-war as to cause her to leak so much as a thimbleful. Very
8418  good; but there is more coming. Some weeks after, the Commodore set
8419  sail in this impregnable craft for Valparaiso. But he was stopped on
8420  the way by a portly sperm whale, that begged a few moments’
8421  confidential business with him. That business consisted in fetching the
8422  Commodore’s craft such a thwack, that with all his pumps going he made
8423  straight for the nearest port to heave down and repair. I am not
8424  superstitious, but I consider the Commodore’s interview with that whale
8425  as providential. Was not Saul of Tarsus converted from unbelief by a
8426  similar fright? I tell you, the sperm whale will stand no nonsense.
8427  
8428  I will now refer you to Langsdorff’s Voyages for a little circumstance
8429  in point, peculiarly interesting to the writer hereof. Langsdorff, you
8430  must know by the way, was attached to the Russian Admiral Krusenstern’s
8431  famous Discovery Expedition in the beginning of the present century.
8432  Captain Langsdorff thus begins his seventeenth chapter:
8433  
8434  “By the thirteenth of May our ship was ready to sail, and the next day
8435  we were out in the open sea, on our way to Ochotsh. The weather was
8436  very clear and fine, but so intolerably cold that we were obliged to
8437  keep on our fur clothing. For some days we had very little wind; it was
8438  not till the nineteenth that a brisk gale from the northwest sprang up.
8439  An uncommon large whale, the body of which was larger than the ship
8440  itself, lay almost at the surface of the water, but was not perceived
8441  by any one on board till the moment when the ship, which was in full
8442  sail, was almost upon him, so that it was impossible to prevent its
8443  striking against him. We were thus placed in the most imminent danger,
8444  as this gigantic creature, setting up its back, raised the ship three
8445  feet at least out of the water. The masts reeled, and the sails fell
8446  altogether, while we who were below all sprang instantly upon the deck,
8447  concluding that we had struck upon some rock; instead of this we saw
8448  the monster sailing off with the utmost gravity and solemnity. Captain
8449  D’Wolf applied immediately to the pumps to examine whether or not the
8450  vessel had received any damage from the shock, but we found that very
8451  happily it had escaped entirely uninjured.”
8452  
8453  Now, the Captain D’Wolf here alluded to as commanding the ship in
8454  question, is a New Englander, who, after a long life of unusual
8455  adventures as a sea-captain, this day resides in the village of
8456  Dorchester near Boston. I have the honor of being a nephew of his. I
8457  have particularly questioned him concerning this passage in Langsdorff.
8458  He substantiates every word. The ship, however, was by no means a large
8459  one: a Russian craft built on the Siberian coast, and purchased by my
8460  uncle after bartering away the vessel in which he sailed from home.
8461  
8462  In that up and down manly book of old-fashioned adventure, so full,
8463  too, of honest wonders—the voyage of Lionel Wafer, one of ancient
8464  Dampier’s old chums—I found a little matter set down so like that just
8465  quoted from Langsdorff, that I cannot forbear inserting it here for a
8466  corroborative example, if such be needed.
8467  
8468  Lionel, it seems, was on his way to “John Ferdinando,” as he calls the
8469  modern Juan Fernandes. “In our way thither,” he says, “about four
8470  o’clock in the morning, when we were about one hundred and fifty
8471  leagues from the Main of America, our ship felt a terrible shock, which
8472  put our men in such consternation that they could hardly tell where
8473  they were or what to think; but every one began to prepare for death.
8474  And, indeed, the shock was so sudden and violent, that we took it for
8475  granted the ship had struck against a rock; but when the amazement was
8476  a little over, we cast the lead, and sounded, but found no ground. * *
8477  * * * The suddenness of the shock made the guns leap in their
8478  carriages, and several of the men were shaken out of their hammocks.
8479  Captain Davis, who lay with his head on a gun, was thrown out of his
8480  cabin!” Lionel then goes on to impute the shock to an earthquake, and
8481  seems to substantiate the imputation by stating that a great
8482  earthquake, somewhere about that time, did actually do great mischief
8483  along the Spanish land. But I should not much wonder if, in the
8484  darkness of that early hour of the morning, the shock was after all
8485  caused by an unseen whale vertically bumping the hull from beneath.
8486  
8487  I might proceed with several more examples, one way or another known to
8488  me, of the great power and malice at times of the sperm whale. In more
8489  than one instance, he has been known, not only to chase the assailing
8490  boats back to their ships, but to pursue the ship itself, and long
8491  withstand all the lances hurled at him from its decks. The English ship
8492  Pusie Hall can tell a story on that head; and, as for his strength, let
8493  me say, that there have been examples where the lines attached to a
8494  running sperm whale have, in a calm, been transferred to the ship, and
8495  secured there; the whale towing her great hull through the water, as a
8496  horse walks off with a cart. Again, it is very often observed that, if
8497  the sperm whale, once struck, is allowed time to rally, he then acts,
8498  not so often with blind rage, as with wilful, deliberate designs of
8499  destruction to his pursuers; nor is it without conveying some eloquent
8500  indication of his character, that upon being attacked he will
8501  frequently open his mouth, and retain it in that dread expansion for
8502  several consecutive minutes. But I must be content with only one more
8503  and a concluding illustration; a remarkable and most significant one,
8504  by which you will not fail to see, that not only is the most marvellous
8505  event in this book corroborated by plain facts of the present day, but
8506  that these marvels (like all marvels) are mere repetitions of the ages;
8507  so that for the millionth time we say amen with Solomon—Verily there is
8508  nothing new under the sun.
8509  
8510  In the sixth Christian century lived Procopius, a Christian magistrate
8511  of Constantinople, in the days when Justinian was Emperor and
8512  Belisarius general. As many know, he wrote the history of his own
8513  times, a work every way of uncommon value. By the best authorities, he
8514  has always been considered a most trustworthy and unexaggerating
8515  historian, except in some one or two particulars, not at all affecting
8516  the matter presently to be mentioned.
8517  
8518  Now, in this history of his, Procopius mentions that, during the term
8519  of his prefecture at Constantinople, a great sea-monster was captured
8520  in the neighboring Propontis, or Sea of Marmora, after having destroyed
8521  vessels at intervals in those waters for a period of more than fifty
8522  years. A fact thus set down in substantial history cannot easily be
8523  gainsaid. Nor is there any reason it should be. Of what precise species
8524  this sea-monster was, is not mentioned. But as he destroyed ships, as
8525  well as for other reasons, he must have been a whale; and I am strongly
8526  inclined to think a sperm whale. And I will tell you why. For a long
8527  time I fancied that the sperm whale had been always unknown in the
8528  Mediterranean and the deep waters connecting with it. Even now I am
8529  certain that those seas are not, and perhaps never can be, in the
8530  present constitution of things, a place for his habitual gregarious
8531  resort. But further investigations have recently proved to me, that in
8532  modern times there have been isolated instances of the presence of the
8533  sperm whale in the Mediterranean. I am told, on good authority, that on
8534  the Barbary coast, a Commodore Davis of the British navy found the
8535  skeleton of a sperm whale. Now, as a vessel of war readily passes
8536  through the Dardanelles, hence a sperm whale could, by the same route,
8537  pass out of the Mediterranean into the Propontis.
8538  
8539  In the Propontis, as far as I can learn, none of that peculiar
8540  substance called _brit_ is to be found, the aliment of the right whale.
8541  But I have every reason to believe that the food of the sperm
8542  whale—squid or cuttle-fish—lurks at the bottom of that sea, because
8543  large creatures, but by no means the largest of that sort, have been
8544  found at its surface. If, then, you properly put these statements
8545  together, and reason upon them a bit, you will clearly perceive that,
8546  according to all human reasoning, Procopius’s sea-monster, that for
8547  half a century stove the ships of a Roman Emperor, must in all
8548  probability have been a sperm whale.
8549  
8550  
8551  CHAPTER 46. Surmises.
8552  
8553  Though, consumed with the hot fire of his purpose, Ahab in all his
8554  thoughts and actions ever had in view the ultimate capture of Moby
8555  Dick; though he seemed ready to sacrifice all mortal interests to that
8556  one passion; nevertheless it may have been that he was by nature and
8557  long habituation far too wedded to a fiery whaleman’s ways, altogether
8558  to abandon the collateral prosecution of the voyage. Or at least if
8559  this were otherwise, there were not wanting other motives much more
8560  influential with him. It would be refining too much, perhaps, even
8561  considering his monomania, to hint that his vindictiveness towards the
8562  White Whale might have possibly extended itself in some degree to all
8563  sperm whales, and that the more monsters he slew by so much the more he
8564  multiplied the chances that each subsequently encountered whale would
8565  prove to be the hated one he hunted. But if such an hypothesis be
8566  indeed exceptionable, there were still additional considerations which,
8567  though not so strictly according with the wildness of his ruling
8568  passion, yet were by no means incapable of swaying him.
8569  
8570  To accomplish his object Ahab must use tools; and of all tools used in
8571  the shadow of the moon, men are most apt to get out of order. He knew,
8572  for example, that however magnetic his ascendency in some respects was
8573  over Starbuck, yet that ascendency did not cover the complete spiritual
8574  man any more than mere corporeal superiority involves intellectual
8575  mastership; for to the purely spiritual, the intellectual but stand in
8576  a sort of corporeal relation. Starbuck’s body and Starbuck’s coerced
8577  will were Ahab’s, so long as Ahab kept his magnet at Starbuck’s brain;
8578  still he knew that for all this the chief mate, in his soul, abhorred
8579  his captain’s quest, and could he, would joyfully disintegrate himself
8580  from it, or even frustrate it. It might be that a long interval would
8581  elapse ere the White Whale was seen. During that long interval Starbuck
8582  would ever be apt to fall into open relapses of rebellion against his
8583  captain’s leadership, unless some ordinary, prudential, circumstantial
8584  influences were brought to bear upon him. Not only that, but the subtle
8585  insanity of Ahab respecting Moby Dick was noways more significantly
8586  manifested than in his superlative sense and shrewdness in foreseeing
8587  that, for the present, the hunt should in some way be stripped of that
8588  strange imaginative impiousness which naturally invested it; that the
8589  full terror of the voyage must be kept withdrawn into the obscure
8590  background (for few men’s courage is proof against protracted
8591  meditation unrelieved by action); that when they stood their long night
8592  watches, his officers and men must have some nearer things to think of
8593  than Moby Dick. For however eagerly and impetuously the savage crew had
8594  hailed the announcement of his quest; yet all sailors of all sorts are
8595  more or less capricious and unreliable—they live in the varying outer
8596  weather, and they inhale its fickleness—and when retained for any
8597  object remote and blank in the pursuit, however promissory of life and
8598  passion in the end, it is above all things requisite that temporary
8599  interests and employments should intervene and hold them healthily
8600  suspended for the final dash.
8601  
8602  Nor was Ahab unmindful of another thing. In times of strong emotion
8603  mankind disdain all base considerations; but such times are evanescent.
8604  The permanent constitutional condition of the manufactured man, thought
8605  Ahab, is sordidness. Granting that the White Whale fully incites the
8606  hearts of this my savage crew, and playing round their savageness even
8607  breeds a certain generous knight-errantism in them, still, while for
8608  the love of it they give chase to Moby Dick, they must also have food
8609  for their more common, daily appetites. For even the high lifted and
8610  chivalric Crusaders of old times were not content to traverse two
8611  thousand miles of land to fight for their holy sepulchre, without
8612  committing burglaries, picking pockets, and gaining other pious
8613  perquisites by the way. Had they been strictly held to their one final
8614  and romantic object—that final and romantic object, too many would have
8615  turned from in disgust. I will not strip these men, thought Ahab, of
8616  all hopes of cash—aye, cash. They may scorn cash now; but let some
8617  months go by, and no perspective promise of it to them, and then this
8618  same quiescent cash all at once mutinying in them, this same cash would
8619  soon cashier Ahab.
8620  
8621  Nor was there wanting still another precautionary motive more related
8622  to Ahab personally. Having impulsively, it is probable, and perhaps
8623  somewhat prematurely revealed the prime but private purpose of the
8624  Pequod’s voyage, Ahab was now entirely conscious that, in so doing, he
8625  had indirectly laid himself open to the unanswerable charge of
8626  usurpation; and with perfect impunity, both moral and legal, his crew
8627  if so disposed, and to that end competent, could refuse all further
8628  obedience to him, and even violently wrest from him the command. From
8629  even the barely hinted imputation of usurpation, and the possible
8630  consequences of such a suppressed impression gaining ground, Ahab must
8631  of course have been most anxious to protect himself. That protection
8632  could only consist in his own predominating brain and heart and hand,
8633  backed by a heedful, closely calculating attention to every minute
8634  atmospheric influence which it was possible for his crew to be
8635  subjected to.
8636  
8637  For all these reasons then, and others perhaps too analytic to be
8638  verbally developed here, Ahab plainly saw that he must still in a good
8639  degree continue true to the natural, nominal purpose of the Pequod’s
8640  voyage; observe all customary usages; and not only that, but force
8641  himself to evince all his well known passionate interest in the general
8642  pursuit of his profession.
8643  
8644  Be all this as it may, his voice was now often heard hailing the three
8645  mast-heads and admonishing them to keep a bright look-out, and not omit
8646  reporting even a porpoise. This vigilance was not long without reward.
8647  
8648  
8649  CHAPTER 47. The Mat-Maker.
8650  
8651  It was a cloudy, sultry afternoon; the seamen were lazily lounging
8652  about the decks, or vacantly gazing over into the lead-coloured waters.
8653  Queequeg and I were mildly employed weaving what is called a sword-mat,
8654  for an additional lashing to our boat. So still and subdued and yet
8655  somehow preluding was all the scene, and such an incantation of reverie
8656  lurked in the air, that each silent sailor seemed resolved into his own
8657  invisible self.
8658  
8659  I was the attendant or page of Queequeg, while busy at the mat. As I
8660  kept passing and repassing the filling or woof of marline between the
8661  long yarns of the warp, using my own hand for the shuttle, and as
8662  Queequeg, standing sideways, ever and anon slid his heavy oaken sword
8663  between the threads, and idly looking off upon the water, carelessly
8664  and unthinkingly drove home every yarn: I say so strange a dreaminess
8665  did there then reign all over the ship and all over the sea, only
8666  broken by the intermitting dull sound of the sword, that it seemed as
8667  if this were the Loom of Time, and I myself were a shuttle mechanically
8668  weaving and weaving away at the Fates. There lay the fixed threads of
8669  the warp subject to but one single, ever returning, unchanging
8670  vibration, and that vibration merely enough to admit of the crosswise
8671  interblending of other threads with its own. This warp seemed
8672  necessity; and here, thought I, with my own hand I ply my own shuttle
8673  and weave my own destiny into these unalterable threads. Meantime,
8674  Queequeg’s impulsive, indifferent sword, sometimes hitting the woof
8675  slantingly, or crookedly, or strongly, or weakly, as the case might be;
8676  and by this difference in the concluding blow producing a corresponding
8677  contrast in the final aspect of the completed fabric; this savage’s
8678  sword, thought I, which thus finally shapes and fashions both warp and
8679  woof; this easy, indifferent sword must be chance—aye, chance, free
8680  will, and necessity—nowise incompatible—all interweavingly working
8681  together. The straight warp of necessity, not to be swerved from its
8682  ultimate course—its every alternating vibration, indeed, only tending
8683  to that; free will still free to ply her shuttle between given threads;
8684  and chance, though restrained in its play within the right lines of
8685  necessity, and sideways in its motions directed by free will, though
8686  thus prescribed to by both, chance by turns rules either, and has the
8687  last featuring blow at events.
8688  
8689  Thus we were weaving and weaving away when I started at a sound so
8690  strange, long drawn, and musically wild and unearthly, that the ball of
8691  free will dropped from my hand, and I stood gazing up at the clouds
8692  whence that voice dropped like a wing. High aloft in the cross-trees
8693  was that mad Gay-Header, Tashtego. His body was reaching eagerly
8694  forward, his hand stretched out like a wand, and at brief sudden
8695  intervals he continued his cries. To be sure the same sound was that
8696  very moment perhaps being heard all over the seas, from hundreds of
8697  whalemen’s look-outs perched as high in the air; but from few of those
8698  lungs could that accustomed old cry have derived such a marvellous
8699  cadence as from Tashtego the Indian’s.
8700  
8701  As he stood hovering over you half suspended in air, so wildly and
8702  eagerly peering towards the horizon, you would have thought him some
8703  prophet or seer beholding the shadows of Fate, and by those wild cries
8704  announcing their coming.
8705  
8706  “There she blows! there! there! there! she blows! she blows!”
8707  
8708  “Where-away?”
8709  
8710  “On the lee-beam, about two miles off! a school of them!”
8711  
8712  Instantly all was commotion.
8713  
8714  The Sperm Whale blows as a clock ticks, with the same undeviating and
8715  reliable uniformity. And thereby whalemen distinguish this fish from
8716  other tribes of his genus.
8717  
8718  “There go flukes!” was now the cry from Tashtego; and the whales
8719  disappeared.
8720  
8721  “Quick, steward!” cried Ahab. “Time! time!”
8722  
8723  Dough-Boy hurried below, glanced at the watch, and reported the exact
8724  minute to Ahab.
8725  
8726  The ship was now kept away from the wind, and she went gently rolling
8727  before it. Tashtego reporting that the whales had gone down heading to
8728  leeward, we confidently looked to see them again directly in advance of
8729  our bows. For that singular craft at times evinced by the Sperm Whale
8730  when, sounding with his head in one direction, he nevertheless, while
8731  concealed beneath the surface, mills round, and swiftly swims off in
8732  the opposite quarter—this deceitfulness of his could not now be in
8733  action; for there was no reason to suppose that the fish seen by
8734  Tashtego had been in any way alarmed, or indeed knew at all of our
8735  vicinity. One of the men selected for shipkeepers—that is, those not
8736  appointed to the boats, by this time relieved the Indian at the
8737  main-mast head. The sailors at the fore and mizzen had come down; the
8738  line tubs were fixed in their places; the cranes were thrust out; the
8739  mainyard was backed, and the three boats swung over the sea like three
8740  samphire baskets over high cliffs. Outside of the bulwarks their eager
8741  crews with one hand clung to the rail, while one foot was expectantly
8742  poised on the gunwale. So look the long line of man-of-war’s men about
8743  to throw themselves on board an enemy’s ship.
8744  
8745  But at this critical instant a sudden exclamation was heard that took
8746  every eye from the whale. With a start all glared at dark Ahab, who was
8747  surrounded by five dusky phantoms that seemed fresh formed out of air.
8748  
8749  
8750  CHAPTER 48. The First Lowering.
8751  
8752  The phantoms, for so they then seemed, were flitting on the other side
8753  of the deck, and, with a noiseless celerity, were casting loose the
8754  tackles and bands of the boat which swung there. This boat had always
8755  been deemed one of the spare boats, though technically called the
8756  captain’s, on account of its hanging from the starboard quarter. The
8757  figure that now stood by its bows was tall and swart, with one white
8758  tooth evilly protruding from its steel-like lips. A rumpled Chinese
8759  jacket of black cotton funereally invested him, with wide black
8760  trowsers of the same dark stuff. But strangely crowning this ebonness
8761  was a glistening white plaited turban, the living hair braided and
8762  coiled round and round upon his head. Less swart in aspect, the
8763  companions of this figure were of that vivid, tiger-yellow complexion
8764  peculiar to some of the aboriginal natives of the Manillas;—a race
8765  notorious for a certain diabolism of subtilty, and by some honest white
8766  mariners supposed to be the paid spies and secret confidential agents
8767  on the water of the devil, their lord, whose counting-room they suppose
8768  to be elsewhere.
8769  
8770  While yet the wondering ship’s company were gazing upon these
8771  strangers, Ahab cried out to the white-turbaned old man at their head,
8772  “All ready there, Fedallah?”
8773  
8774  “Ready,” was the half-hissed reply.
8775  
8776  “Lower away then; d’ye hear?” shouting across the deck. “Lower away
8777  there, I say.”
8778  
8779  Such was the thunder of his voice, that spite of their amazement the
8780  men sprang over the rail; the sheaves whirled round in the blocks; with
8781  a wallow, the three boats dropped into the sea; while, with a
8782  dexterous, off-handed daring, unknown in any other vocation, the
8783  sailors, goat-like, leaped down the rolling ship’s side into the tossed
8784  boats below.
8785  
8786  Hardly had they pulled out from under the ship’s lee, when a fourth
8787  keel, coming from the windward side, pulled round under the stern, and
8788  showed the five strangers rowing Ahab, who, standing erect in the
8789  stern, loudly hailed Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, to spread themselves
8790  widely, so as to cover a large expanse of water. But with all their
8791  eyes again riveted upon the swart Fedallah and his crew, the inmates of
8792  the other boats obeyed not the command.
8793  
8794  “Captain Ahab?—” said Starbuck.
8795  
8796  “Spread yourselves,” cried Ahab; “give way, all four boats. Thou,
8797  Flask, pull out more to leeward!”
8798  
8799  “Aye, aye, sir,” cheerily cried little King-Post, sweeping round his
8800  great steering oar. “Lay back!” addressing his crew.
8801  “There!—there!—there again! There she blows right ahead, boys!—lay
8802  back!”
8803  
8804  “Never heed yonder yellow boys, Archy.”
8805  
8806  “Oh, I don’t mind ’em, sir,” said Archy; “I knew it all before now.
8807  Didn’t I hear ’em in the hold? And didn’t I tell Cabaco here of it?
8808  What say ye, Cabaco? They are stowaways, Mr. Flask.”
8809  
8810  “Pull, pull, my fine hearts-alive; pull, my children; pull, my little
8811  ones,” drawlingly and soothingly sighed Stubb to his crew, some of whom
8812  still showed signs of uneasiness. “Why don’t you break your backbones,
8813  my boys? What is it you stare at? Those chaps in yonder boat? Tut! They
8814  are only five more hands come to help us—never mind from where—the more
8815  the merrier. Pull, then, do pull; never mind the brimstone—devils are
8816  good fellows enough. So, so; there you are now; that’s the stroke for a
8817  thousand pounds; that’s the stroke to sweep the stakes! Hurrah for the
8818  gold cup of sperm oil, my heroes! Three cheers, men—all hearts alive!
8819  Easy, easy; don’t be in a hurry—don’t be in a hurry. Why don’t you snap
8820  your oars, you rascals? Bite something, you dogs! So, so, so,
8821  then:—softly, softly! That’s it—that’s it! long and strong. Give way
8822  there, give way! The devil fetch ye, ye ragamuffin rapscallions; ye are
8823  all asleep. Stop snoring, ye sleepers, and pull. Pull, will ye? pull,
8824  can’t ye? pull, won’t ye? Why in the name of gudgeons and ginger-cakes
8825  don’t ye pull?—pull and break something! pull, and start your eyes out!
8826  Here!” whipping out the sharp knife from his girdle; “every mother’s
8827  son of ye draw his knife, and pull with the blade between his teeth.
8828  That’s it—that’s it. Now ye do something; that looks like it, my
8829  steel-bits. Start her—start her, my silver-spoons! Start her,
8830  marling-spikes!”
8831  
8832  Stubb’s exordium to his crew is given here at large, because he had
8833  rather a peculiar way of talking to them in general, and especially in
8834  inculcating the religion of rowing. But you must not suppose from this
8835  specimen of his sermonizings that he ever flew into downright passions
8836  with his congregation. Not at all; and therein consisted his chief
8837  peculiarity. He would say the most terrific things to his crew, in a
8838  tone so strangely compounded of fun and fury, and the fury seemed so
8839  calculated merely as a spice to the fun, that no oarsman could hear
8840  such queer invocations without pulling for dear life, and yet pulling
8841  for the mere joke of the thing. Besides he all the time looked so easy
8842  and indolent himself, so loungingly managed his steering-oar, and so
8843  broadly gaped—open-mouthed at times—that the mere sight of such a
8844  yawning commander, by sheer force of contrast, acted like a charm upon
8845  the crew. Then again, Stubb was one of those odd sort of humorists,
8846  whose jollity is sometimes so curiously ambiguous, as to put all
8847  inferiors on their guard in the matter of obeying them.
8848  
8849  In obedience to a sign from Ahab, Starbuck was now pulling obliquely
8850  across Stubb’s bow; and when for a minute or so the two boats were
8851  pretty near to each other, Stubb hailed the mate.
8852  
8853  “Mr. Starbuck! larboard boat there, ahoy! a word with ye, sir, if ye
8854  please!”
8855  
8856  “Halloa!” returned Starbuck, turning round not a single inch as he
8857  spoke; still earnestly but whisperingly urging his crew; his face set
8858  like a flint from Stubb’s.
8859  
8860  “What think ye of those yellow boys, sir!”
8861  
8862  “Smuggled on board, somehow, before the ship sailed. (Strong, strong,
8863  boys!)” in a whisper to his crew, then speaking out loud again: “A sad
8864  business, Mr. Stubb! (seethe her, seethe her, my lads!) but never mind,
8865  Mr. Stubb, all for the best. Let all your crew pull strong, come what
8866  will. (Spring, my men, spring!) There’s hogsheads of sperm ahead, Mr.
8867  Stubb, and that’s what ye came for. (Pull, my boys!) Sperm, sperm’s the
8868  play! This at least is duty; duty and profit hand in hand.”
8869  
8870  “Aye, aye, I thought as much,” soliloquized Stubb, when the boats
8871  diverged, “as soon as I clapt eye on ’em, I thought so. Aye, and that’s
8872  what he went into the after hold for, so often, as Dough-Boy long
8873  suspected. They were hidden down there. The White Whale’s at the bottom
8874  of it. Well, well, so be it! Can’t be helped! All right! Give way, men!
8875  It ain’t the White Whale to-day! Give way!”
8876  
8877  Now the advent of these outlandish strangers at such a critical instant
8878  as the lowering of the boats from the deck, this had not unreasonably
8879  awakened a sort of superstitious amazement in some of the ship’s
8880  company; but Archy’s fancied discovery having some time previous got
8881  abroad among them, though indeed not credited then, this had in some
8882  small measure prepared them for the event. It took off the extreme edge
8883  of their wonder; and so what with all this and Stubb’s confident way of
8884  accounting for their appearance, they were for the time freed from
8885  superstitious surmisings; though the affair still left abundant room
8886  for all manner of wild conjectures as to dark Ahab’s precise agency in
8887  the matter from the beginning. For me, I silently recalled the
8888  mysterious shadows I had seen creeping on board the Pequod during the
8889  dim Nantucket dawn, as well as the enigmatical hintings of the
8890  unaccountable Elijah.
8891  
8892  Meantime, Ahab, out of hearing of his officers, having sided the
8893  furthest to windward, was still ranging ahead of the other boats; a
8894  circumstance bespeaking how potent a crew was pulling him. Those tiger
8895  yellow creatures of his seemed all steel and whalebone; like five
8896  trip-hammers they rose and fell with regular strokes of strength, which
8897  periodically started the boat along the water like a horizontal burst
8898  boiler out of a Mississippi steamer. As for Fedallah, who was seen
8899  pulling the harpooneer oar, he had thrown aside his black jacket, and
8900  displayed his naked chest with the whole part of his body above the
8901  gunwale, clearly cut against the alternating depressions of the watery
8902  horizon; while at the other end of the boat Ahab, with one arm, like a
8903  fencer’s, thrown half backward into the air, as if to counterbalance
8904  any tendency to trip; Ahab was seen steadily managing his steering oar
8905  as in a thousand boat lowerings ere the White Whale had torn him. All
8906  at once the outstretched arm gave a peculiar motion and then remained
8907  fixed, while the boat’s five oars were seen simultaneously peaked. Boat
8908  and crew sat motionless on the sea. Instantly the three spread boats in
8909  the rear paused on their way. The whales had irregularly settled bodily
8910  down into the blue, thus giving no distantly discernible token of the
8911  movement, though from his closer vicinity Ahab had observed it.
8912  
8913  “Every man look out along his oars!” cried Starbuck. “Thou, Queequeg,
8914  stand up!”
8915  
8916  Nimbly springing up on the triangular raised box in the bow, the savage
8917  stood erect there, and with intensely eager eyes gazed off towards the
8918  spot where the chase had last been descried. Likewise upon the extreme
8919  stern of the boat where it was also triangularly platformed level with
8920  the gunwale, Starbuck himself was seen coolly and adroitly balancing
8921  himself to the jerking tossings of his chip of a craft, and silently
8922  eyeing the vast blue eye of the sea.
8923  
8924  Not very far distant Flask’s boat was also lying breathlessly still;
8925  its commander recklessly standing upon the top of the loggerhead, a
8926  stout sort of post rooted in the keel, and rising some two feet above
8927  the level of the stern platform. It is used for catching turns with the
8928  whale line. Its top is not more spacious than the palm of a man’s hand,
8929  and standing upon such a base as that, Flask seemed perched at the
8930  mast-head of some ship which had sunk to all but her trucks. But little
8931  King-Post was small and short, and at the same time little King-Post
8932  was full of a large and tall ambition, so that this loggerhead
8933  stand-point of his did by no means satisfy King-Post.
8934  
8935  “I can’t see three seas off; tip us up an oar there, and let me on to
8936  that.”
8937  
8938  Upon this, Daggoo, with either hand upon the gunwale to steady his way,
8939  swiftly slid aft, and then erecting himself volunteered his lofty
8940  shoulders for a pedestal.
8941  
8942  “Good a mast-head as any, sir. Will you mount?”
8943  
8944  “That I will, and thank ye very much, my fine fellow; only I wish you
8945  fifty feet taller.”
8946  
8947  Whereupon planting his feet firmly against two opposite planks of the
8948  boat, the gigantic negro, stooping a little, presented his flat palm to
8949  Flask’s foot, and then putting Flask’s hand on his hearse-plumed head
8950  and bidding him spring as he himself should toss, with one dexterous
8951  fling landed the little man high and dry on his shoulders. And here was
8952  Flask now standing, Daggoo with one lifted arm furnishing him with a
8953  breastband to lean against and steady himself by.
8954  
8955  At any time it is a strange sight to the tyro to see with what wondrous
8956  habitude of unconscious skill the whaleman will maintain an erect
8957  posture in his boat, even when pitched about by the most riotously
8958  perverse and cross-running seas. Still more strange to see him giddily
8959  perched upon the loggerhead itself, under such circumstances. But the
8960  sight of little Flask mounted upon gigantic Daggoo was yet more
8961  curious; for sustaining himself with a cool, indifferent, easy,
8962  unthought of, barbaric majesty, the noble negro to every roll of the
8963  sea harmoniously rolled his fine form. On his broad back, flaxen-haired
8964  Flask seemed a snow-flake. The bearer looked nobler than the rider.
8965  Though truly vivacious, tumultuous, ostentatious little Flask would now
8966  and then stamp with impatience; but not one added heave did he thereby
8967  give to the negro’s lordly chest. So have I seen Passion and Vanity
8968  stamping the living magnanimous earth, but the earth did not alter her
8969  tides and her seasons for that.
8970  
8971  Meanwhile Stubb, the third mate, betrayed no such far-gazing
8972  solicitudes. The whales might have made one of their regular soundings,
8973  not a temporary dive from mere fright; and if that were the case,
8974  Stubb, as his wont in such cases, it seems, was resolved to solace the
8975  languishing interval with his pipe. He withdrew it from his hatband,
8976  where he always wore it aslant like a feather. He loaded it, and rammed
8977  home the loading with his thumb-end; but hardly had he ignited his
8978  match across the rough sandpaper of his hand, when Tashtego, his
8979  harpooneer, whose eyes had been setting to windward like two fixed
8980  stars, suddenly dropped like light from his erect attitude to his seat,
8981  crying out in a quick phrensy of hurry, “Down, down all, and give
8982  way!—there they are!”
8983  
8984  To a landsman, no whale, nor any sign of a herring, would have been
8985  visible at that moment; nothing but a troubled bit of greenish white
8986  water, and thin scattered puffs of vapor hovering over it, and
8987  suffusingly blowing off to leeward, like the confused scud from white
8988  rolling billows. The air around suddenly vibrated and tingled, as it
8989  were, like the air over intensely heated plates of iron. Beneath this
8990  atmospheric waving and curling, and partially beneath a thin layer of
8991  water, also, the whales were swimming. Seen in advance of all the other
8992  indications, the puffs of vapor they spouted, seemed their forerunning
8993  couriers and detached flying outriders.
8994  
8995  All four boats were now in keen pursuit of that one spot of troubled
8996  water and air. But it bade fair to outstrip them; it flew on and on, as
8997  a mass of interblending bubbles borne down a rapid stream from the
8998  hills.
8999  
9000  “Pull, pull, my good boys,” said Starbuck, in the lowest possible but
9001  intensest concentrated whisper to his men; while the sharp fixed glance
9002  from his eyes darted straight ahead of the bow, almost seemed as two
9003  visible needles in two unerring binnacle compasses. He did not say much
9004  to his crew, though, nor did his crew say anything to him. Only the
9005  silence of the boat was at intervals startlingly pierced by one of his
9006  peculiar whispers, now harsh with command, now soft with entreaty.
9007  
9008  How different the loud little King-Post. “Sing out and say something,
9009  my hearties. Roar and pull, my thunderbolts! Beach me, beach me on
9010  their black backs, boys; only do that for me, and I’ll sign over to you
9011  my Martha’s Vineyard plantation, boys; including wife and children,
9012  boys. Lay me on—lay me on! O Lord, Lord! but I shall go stark, staring
9013  mad! See! see that white water!” And so shouting, he pulled his hat
9014  from his head, and stamped up and down on it; then picking it up,
9015  flirted it far off upon the sea; and finally fell to rearing and
9016  plunging in the boat’s stern like a crazed colt from the prairie.
9017  
9018  “Look at that chap now,” philosophically drawled Stubb, who, with his
9019  unlighted short pipe, mechanically retained between his teeth, at a
9020  short distance, followed after—“He’s got fits, that Flask has. Fits?
9021  yes, give him fits—that’s the very word—pitch fits into ’em. Merrily,
9022  merrily, hearts-alive. Pudding for supper, you know;—merry’s the word.
9023  Pull, babes—pull, sucklings—pull, all. But what the devil are you
9024  hurrying about? Softly, softly, and steadily, my men. Only pull, and
9025  keep pulling; nothing more. Crack all your backbones, and bite your
9026  knives in two—that’s all. Take it easy—why don’t ye take it easy, I
9027  say, and burst all your livers and lungs!”
9028  
9029  But what it was that inscrutable Ahab said to that tiger-yellow crew of
9030  his—these were words best omitted here; for you live under the blessed
9031  light of the evangelical land. Only the infidel sharks in the audacious
9032  seas may give ear to such words, when, with tornado brow, and eyes of
9033  red murder, and foam-glued lips, Ahab leaped after his prey.
9034  
9035  Meanwhile, all the boats tore on. The repeated specific allusions of
9036  Flask to “that whale,” as he called the fictitious monster which he
9037  declared to be incessantly tantalizing his boat’s bow with its
9038  tail—these allusions of his were at times so vivid and life-like, that
9039  they would cause some one or two of his men to snatch a fearful look
9040  over the shoulder. But this was against all rule; for the oarsmen must
9041  put out their eyes, and ram a skewer through their necks; usage
9042  pronouncing that they must have no organs but ears, and no limbs but
9043  arms, in these critical moments.
9044  
9045  It was a sight full of quick wonder and awe! The vast swells of the
9046  omnipotent sea; the surging, hollow roar they made, as they rolled
9047  along the eight gunwales, like gigantic bowls in a boundless
9048  bowling-green; the brief suspended agony of the boat, as it would tip
9049  for an instant on the knife-like edge of the sharper waves, that almost
9050  seemed threatening to cut it in two; the sudden profound dip into the
9051  watery glens and hollows; the keen spurrings and goadings to gain the
9052  top of the opposite hill; the headlong, sled-like slide down its other
9053  side;—all these, with the cries of the headsmen and harpooneers, and
9054  the shuddering gasps of the oarsmen, with the wondrous sight of the
9055  ivory Pequod bearing down upon her boats with outstretched sails, like
9056  a wild hen after her screaming brood;—all this was thrilling.
9057  
9058  Not the raw recruit, marching from the bosom of his wife into the fever
9059  heat of his first battle; not the dead man’s ghost encountering the
9060  first unknown phantom in the other world;—neither of these can feel
9061  stranger and stronger emotions than that man does, who for the first
9062  time finds himself pulling into the charmed, churned circle of the
9063  hunted sperm whale.
9064  
9065  The dancing white water made by the chase was now becoming more and
9066  more visible, owing to the increasing darkness of the dun cloud-shadows
9067  flung upon the sea. The jets of vapor no longer blended, but tilted
9068  everywhere to right and left; the whales seemed separating their wakes.
9069  The boats were pulled more apart; Starbuck giving chase to three whales
9070  running dead to leeward. Our sail was now set, and, with the still
9071  rising wind, we rushed along; the boat going with such madness through
9072  the water, that the lee oars could scarcely be worked rapidly enough to
9073  escape being torn from the row-locks.
9074  
9075  Soon we were running through a suffusing wide veil of mist; neither
9076  ship nor boat to be seen.
9077  
9078  “Give way, men,” whispered Starbuck, drawing still further aft the
9079  sheet of his sail; “there is time to kill a fish yet before the squall
9080  comes. There’s white water again!—close to! Spring!”
9081  
9082  Soon after, two cries in quick succession on each side of us denoted
9083  that the other boats had got fast; but hardly were they overheard, when
9084  with a lightning-like hurtling whisper Starbuck said: “Stand up!” and
9085  Queequeg, harpoon in hand, sprang to his feet.
9086  
9087  Though not one of the oarsmen was then facing the life and death peril
9088  so close to them ahead, yet with their eyes on the intense countenance
9089  of the mate in the stern of the boat, they knew that the imminent
9090  instant had come; they heard, too, an enormous wallowing sound as of
9091  fifty elephants stirring in their litter. Meanwhile the boat was still
9092  booming through the mist, the waves curling and hissing around us like
9093  the erected crests of enraged serpents.
9094  
9095  “That’s his hump. _There_, _there_, give it to him!” whispered
9096  Starbuck.
9097  
9098  A short rushing sound leaped out of the boat; it was the darted iron of
9099  Queequeg. Then all in one welded commotion came an invisible push from
9100  astern, while forward the boat seemed striking on a ledge; the sail
9101  collapsed and exploded; a gush of scalding vapor shot up near by;
9102  something rolled and tumbled like an earthquake beneath us. The whole
9103  crew were half suffocated as they were tossed helter-skelter into the
9104  white curdling cream of the squall. Squall, whale, and harpoon had all
9105  blended together; and the whale, merely grazed by the iron, escaped.
9106  
9107  Though completely swamped, the boat was nearly unharmed. Swimming round
9108  it we picked up the floating oars, and lashing them across the gunwale,
9109  tumbled back to our places. There we sat up to our knees in the sea,
9110  the water covering every rib and plank, so that to our downward gazing
9111  eyes the suspended craft seemed a coral boat grown up to us from the
9112  bottom of the ocean.
9113  
9114  The wind increased to a howl; the waves dashed their bucklers together;
9115  the whole squall roared, forked, and crackled around us like a white
9116  fire upon the prairie, in which, unconsumed, we were burning; immortal
9117  in these jaws of death! In vain we hailed the other boats; as well roar
9118  to the live coals down the chimney of a flaming furnace as hail those
9119  boats in that storm. Meanwhile the driving scud, rack, and mist, grew
9120  darker with the shadows of night; no sign of the ship could be seen.
9121  The rising sea forbade all attempts to bale out the boat. The oars were
9122  useless as propellers, performing now the office of life-preservers.
9123  So, cutting the lashing of the waterproof match keg, after many
9124  failures Starbuck contrived to ignite the lamp in the lantern; then
9125  stretching it on a waif pole, handed it to Queequeg as the
9126  standard-bearer of this forlorn hope. There, then, he sat, holding up
9127  that imbecile candle in the heart of that almighty forlornness. There,
9128  then, he sat, the sign and symbol of a man without faith, hopelessly
9129  holding up hope in the midst of despair.
9130  
9131  Wet, drenched through, and shivering cold, despairing of ship or boat,
9132  we lifted up our eyes as the dawn came on. The mist still spread over
9133  the sea, the empty lantern lay crushed in the bottom of the boat.
9134  Suddenly Queequeg started to his feet, hollowing his hand to his ear.
9135  We all heard a faint creaking, as of ropes and yards hitherto muffled
9136  by the storm. The sound came nearer and nearer; the thick mists were
9137  dimly parted by a huge, vague form. Affrighted, we all sprang into the
9138  sea as the ship at last loomed into view, bearing right down upon us
9139  within a distance of not much more than its length.
9140  
9141  Floating on the waves we saw the abandoned boat, as for one instant it
9142  tossed and gaped beneath the ship’s bows like a chip at the base of a
9143  cataract; and then the vast hull rolled over it, and it was seen no
9144  more till it came up weltering astern. Again we swam for it, were
9145  dashed against it by the seas, and were at last taken up and safely
9146  landed on board. Ere the squall came close to, the other boats had cut
9147  loose from their fish and returned to the ship in good time. The ship
9148  had given us up, but was still cruising, if haply it might light upon
9149  some token of our perishing,—an oar or a lance pole.
9150  
9151  
9152  CHAPTER 49. The Hyena.
9153  
9154  There are certain queer times and occasions in this strange mixed
9155  affair we call life when a man takes this whole universe for a vast
9156  practical joke, though the wit thereof he but dimly discerns, and more
9157  than suspects that the joke is at nobody’s expense but his own.
9158  However, nothing dispirits, and nothing seems worth while disputing. He
9159  bolts down all events, all creeds, and beliefs, and persuasions, all
9160  hard things visible and invisible, never mind how knobby; as an ostrich
9161  of potent digestion gobbles down bullets and gun flints. And as for
9162  small difficulties and worryings, prospects of sudden disaster, peril
9163  of life and limb; all these, and death itself, seem to him only sly,
9164  good-natured hits, and jolly punches in the side bestowed by the unseen
9165  and unaccountable old joker. That odd sort of wayward mood I am
9166  speaking of, comes over a man only in some time of extreme tribulation;
9167  it comes in the very midst of his earnestness, so that what just before
9168  might have seemed to him a thing most momentous, now seems but a part
9169  of the general joke. There is nothing like the perils of whaling to
9170  breed this free and easy sort of genial, desperado philosophy; and with
9171  it I now regarded this whole voyage of the Pequod, and the great White
9172  Whale its object.
9173  
9174  “Queequeg,” said I, when they had dragged me, the last man, to the
9175  deck, and I was still shaking myself in my jacket to fling off the
9176  water; “Queequeg, my fine friend, does this sort of thing often
9177  happen?” Without much emotion, though soaked through just like me, he
9178  gave me to understand that such things did often happen.
9179  
9180  “Mr. Stubb,” said I, turning to that worthy, who, buttoned up in his
9181  oil-jacket, was now calmly smoking his pipe in the rain; “Mr. Stubb, I
9182  think I have heard you say that of all whalemen you ever met, our chief
9183  mate, Mr. Starbuck, is by far the most careful and prudent. I suppose
9184  then, that going plump on a flying whale with your sail set in a foggy
9185  squall is the height of a whaleman’s discretion?”
9186  
9187  “Certain. I’ve lowered for whales from a leaking ship in a gale off
9188  Cape Horn.”
9189  
9190  “Mr. Flask,” said I, turning to little King-Post, who was standing
9191  close by; “you are experienced in these things, and I am not. Will you
9192  tell me whether it is an unalterable law in this fishery, Mr. Flask,
9193  for an oarsman to break his own back pulling himself back-foremost into
9194  death’s jaws?”
9195  
9196  “Can’t you twist that smaller?” said Flask. “Yes, that’s the law. I
9197  should like to see a boat’s crew backing water up to a whale face
9198  foremost. Ha, ha! the whale would give them squint for squint, mind
9199  that!”
9200  
9201  Here then, from three impartial witnesses, I had a deliberate statement
9202  of the entire case. Considering, therefore, that squalls and capsizings
9203  in the water and consequent bivouacks on the deep, were matters of
9204  common occurrence in this kind of life; considering that at the
9205  superlatively critical instant of going on to the whale I must resign
9206  my life into the hands of him who steered the boat—oftentimes a fellow
9207  who at that very moment is in his impetuousness upon the point of
9208  scuttling the craft with his own frantic stampings; considering that
9209  the particular disaster to our own particular boat was chiefly to be
9210  imputed to Starbuck’s driving on to his whale almost in the teeth of a
9211  squall, and considering that Starbuck, notwithstanding, was famous for
9212  his great heedfulness in the fishery; considering that I belonged to
9213  this uncommonly prudent Starbuck’s boat; and finally considering in
9214  what a devil’s chase I was implicated, touching the White Whale: taking
9215  all things together, I say, I thought I might as well go below and make
9216  a rough draft of my will. “Queequeg,” said I, “come along, you shall be
9217  my lawyer, executor, and legatee.”
9218  
9219  It may seem strange that of all men sailors should be tinkering at
9220  their last wills and testaments, but there are no people in the world
9221  more fond of that diversion. This was the fourth time in my nautical
9222  life that I had done the same thing. After the ceremony was concluded
9223  upon the present occasion, I felt all the easier; a stone was rolled
9224  away from my heart. Besides, all the days I should now live would be as
9225  good as the days that Lazarus lived after his resurrection; a
9226  supplementary clean gain of so many months or weeks as the case might
9227  be. I survived myself; my death and burial were locked up in my chest.
9228  I looked round me tranquilly and contentedly, like a quiet ghost with a
9229  clean conscience sitting inside the bars of a snug family vault.
9230  
9231  Now then, thought I, unconsciously rolling up the sleeves of my frock,
9232  here goes for a cool, collected dive at death and destruction, and the
9233  devil fetch the hindmost.
9234  
9235  
9236  CHAPTER 50. Ahab’s Boat and Crew. Fedallah.
9237  
9238  “Who would have thought it, Flask!” cried Stubb; “if I had but one leg
9239  you would not catch me in a boat, unless maybe to stop the plug-hole
9240  with my timber toe. Oh! he’s a wonderful old man!”
9241  
9242  “I don’t think it so strange, after all, on that account,” said Flask.
9243  “If his leg were off at the hip, now, it would be a different thing.
9244  That would disable him; but he has one knee, and good part of the other
9245  left, you know.”
9246  
9247  “I don’t know that, my little man; I never yet saw him kneel.”
9248  
9249  Among whale-wise people it has often been argued whether, considering
9250  the paramount importance of his life to the success of the voyage, it
9251  is right for a whaling captain to jeopardize that life in the active
9252  perils of the chase. So Tamerlane’s soldiers often argued with tears in
9253  their eyes, whether that invaluable life of his ought to be carried
9254  into the thickest of the fight.
9255  
9256  But with Ahab the question assumed a modified aspect. Considering that
9257  with two legs man is but a hobbling wight in all times of danger;
9258  considering that the pursuit of whales is always under great and
9259  extraordinary difficulties; that every individual moment, indeed, then
9260  comprises a peril; under these circumstances is it wise for any maimed
9261  man to enter a whale-boat in the hunt? As a general thing, the
9262  joint-owners of the Pequod must have plainly thought not.
9263  
9264  Ahab well knew that although his friends at home would think little of
9265  his entering a boat in certain comparatively harmless vicissitudes of
9266  the chase, for the sake of being near the scene of action and giving
9267  his orders in person, yet for Captain Ahab to have a boat actually
9268  apportioned to him as a regular headsman in the hunt—above all for
9269  Captain Ahab to be supplied with five extra men, as that same boat’s
9270  crew, he well knew that such generous conceits never entered the heads
9271  of the owners of the Pequod. Therefore he had not solicited a boat’s
9272  crew from them, nor had he in any way hinted his desires on that head.
9273  Nevertheless he had taken private measures of his own touching all that
9274  matter. Until Cabaco’s published discovery, the sailors had little
9275  foreseen it, though to be sure when, after being a little while out of
9276  port, all hands had concluded the customary business of fitting the
9277  whaleboats for service; when some time after this Ahab was now and then
9278  found bestirring himself in the matter of making thole-pins with his
9279  own hands for what was thought to be one of the spare boats, and even
9280  solicitously cutting the small wooden skewers, which when the line is
9281  running out are pinned over the groove in the bow: when all this was
9282  observed in him, and particularly his solicitude in having an extra
9283  coat of sheathing in the bottom of the boat, as if to make it better
9284  withstand the pointed pressure of his ivory limb; and also the anxiety
9285  he evinced in exactly shaping the thigh board, or clumsy cleat, as it
9286  is sometimes called, the horizontal piece in the boat’s bow for bracing
9287  the knee against in darting or stabbing at the whale; when it was
9288  observed how often he stood up in that boat with his solitary knee
9289  fixed in the semi-circular depression in the cleat, and with the
9290  carpenter’s chisel gouged out a little here and straightened it a
9291  little there; all these things, I say, had awakened much interest and
9292  curiosity at the time. But almost everybody supposed that this
9293  particular preparative heedfulness in Ahab must only be with a view to
9294  the ultimate chase of Moby Dick; for he had already revealed his
9295  intention to hunt that mortal monster in person. But such a supposition
9296  did by no means involve the remotest suspicion as to any boat’s crew
9297  being assigned to that boat.
9298  
9299  Now, with the subordinate phantoms, what wonder remained soon waned
9300  away; for in a whaler wonders soon wane. Besides, now and then such
9301  unaccountable odds and ends of strange nations come up from the unknown
9302  nooks and ash-holes of the earth to man these floating outlaws of
9303  whalers; and the ships themselves often pick up such queer castaway
9304  creatures found tossing about the open sea on planks, bits of wreck,
9305  oars, whaleboats, canoes, blown-off Japanese junks, and what not; that
9306  Beelzebub himself might climb up the side and step down into the cabin
9307  to chat with the captain, and it would not create any unsubduable
9308  excitement in the forecastle.
9309  
9310  But be all this as it may, certain it is that while the subordinate
9311  phantoms soon found their place among the crew, though still as it were
9312  somehow distinct from them, yet that hair-turbaned Fedallah remained a
9313  muffled mystery to the last. Whence he came in a mannerly world like
9314  this, by what sort of unaccountable tie he soon evinced himself to be
9315  linked with Ahab’s peculiar fortunes; nay, so far as to have some sort
9316  of a half-hinted influence; Heaven knows, but it might have been even
9317  authority over him; all this none knew. But one cannot sustain an
9318  indifferent air concerning Fedallah. He was such a creature as
9319  civilized, domestic people in the temperate zone only see in their
9320  dreams, and that but dimly; but the like of whom now and then glide
9321  among the unchanging Asiatic communities, especially the Oriental isles
9322  to the east of the continent—those insulated, immemorial, unalterable
9323  countries, which even in these modern days still preserve much of the
9324  ghostly aboriginalness of earth’s primal generations, when the memory
9325  of the first man was a distinct recollection, and all men his
9326  descendants, unknowing whence he came, eyed each other as real
9327  phantoms, and asked of the sun and the moon why they were created and
9328  to what end; when though, according to Genesis, the angels indeed
9329  consorted with the daughters of men, the devils also, add the
9330  uncanonical Rabbins, indulged in mundane amours.
9331  
9332  
9333  CHAPTER 51. The Spirit-Spout.
9334  
9335  Days, weeks passed, and under easy sail, the ivory Pequod had slowly
9336  swept across four several cruising-grounds; that off the Azores; off
9337  the Cape de Verdes; on the Plate (so called), being off the mouth of
9338  the Rio de la Plata; and the Carrol Ground, an unstaked, watery
9339  locality, southerly from St. Helena.
9340  
9341  It was while gliding through these latter waters that one serene and
9342  moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like scrolls of silver;
9343  and, by their soft, suffusing seethings, made what seemed a silvery
9344  silence, not a solitude; on such a silent night a silvery jet was seen
9345  far in advance of the white bubbles at the bow. Lit up by the moon, it
9346  looked celestial; seemed some plumed and glittering god uprising from
9347  the sea. Fedallah first descried this jet. For of these moonlight
9348  nights, it was his wont to mount to the main-mast head, and stand a
9349  look-out there, with the same precision as if it had been day. And yet,
9350  though herds of whales were seen by night, not one whaleman in a
9351  hundred would venture a lowering for them. You may think with what
9352  emotions, then, the seamen beheld this old Oriental perched aloft at
9353  such unusual hours; his turban and the moon, companions in one sky. But
9354  when, after spending his uniform interval there for several successive
9355  nights without uttering a single sound; when, after all this silence,
9356  his unearthly voice was heard announcing that silvery, moon-lit jet,
9357  every reclining mariner started to his feet as if some winged spirit
9358  had lighted in the rigging, and hailed the mortal crew. “There she
9359  blows!” Had the trump of judgment blown, they could not have quivered
9360  more; yet still they felt no terror; rather pleasure. For though it was
9361  a most unwonted hour, yet so impressive was the cry, and so deliriously
9362  exciting, that almost every soul on board instinctively desired a
9363  lowering.
9364  
9365  Walking the deck with quick, side-lunging strides, Ahab commanded the
9366  t’gallant sails and royals to be set, and every stunsail spread. The
9367  best man in the ship must take the helm. Then, with every mast-head
9368  manned, the piled-up craft rolled down before the wind. The strange,
9369  upheaving, lifting tendency of the taffrail breeze filling the hollows
9370  of so many sails, made the buoyant, hovering deck to feel like air
9371  beneath the feet; while still she rushed along, as if two antagonistic
9372  influences were struggling in her—one to mount direct to heaven, the
9373  other to drive yawingly to some horizontal goal. And had you watched
9374  Ahab’s face that night, you would have thought that in him also two
9375  different things were warring. While his one live leg made lively
9376  echoes along the deck, every stroke of his dead limb sounded like a
9377  coffin-tap. On life and death this old man walked. But though the ship
9378  so swiftly sped, and though from every eye, like arrows, the eager
9379  glances shot, yet the silvery jet was no more seen that night. Every
9380  sailor swore he saw it once, but not a second time.
9381  
9382  This midnight-spout had almost grown a forgotten thing, when, some days
9383  after, lo! at the same silent hour, it was again announced: again it
9384  was descried by all; but upon making sail to overtake it, once more it
9385  disappeared as if it had never been. And so it served us night after
9386  night, till no one heeded it but to wonder at it. Mysteriously jetted
9387  into the clear moonlight, or starlight, as the case might be;
9388  disappearing again for one whole day, or two days, or three; and
9389  somehow seeming at every distinct repetition to be advancing still
9390  further and further in our van, this solitary jet seemed for ever
9391  alluring us on.
9392  
9393  Nor with the immemorial superstition of their race, and in accordance
9394  with the preternaturalness, as it seemed, which in many things invested
9395  the Pequod, were there wanting some of the seamen who swore that
9396  whenever and wherever descried; at however remote times, or in however
9397  far apart latitudes and longitudes, that unnearable spout was cast by
9398  one self-same whale; and that whale, Moby Dick. For a time, there
9399  reigned, too, a sense of peculiar dread at this flitting apparition, as
9400  if it were treacherously beckoning us on and on, in order that the
9401  monster might turn round upon us, and rend us at last in the remotest
9402  and most savage seas.
9403  
9404  These temporary apprehensions, so vague but so awful, derived a
9405  wondrous potency from the contrasting serenity of the weather, in
9406  which, beneath all its blue blandness, some thought there lurked a
9407  devilish charm, as for days and days we voyaged along, through seas so
9408  wearily, lonesomely mild, that all space, in repugnance to our vengeful
9409  errand, seemed vacating itself of life before our urn-like prow.
9410  
9411  But, at last, when turning to the eastward, the Cape winds began
9412  howling around us, and we rose and fell upon the long, troubled seas
9413  that are there; when the ivory-tusked Pequod sharply bowed to the
9414  blast, and gored the dark waves in her madness, till, like showers of
9415  silver chips, the foam-flakes flew over her bulwarks; then all this
9416  desolate vacuity of life went away, but gave place to sights more
9417  dismal than before.
9418  
9419  Close to our bows, strange forms in the water darted hither and thither
9420  before us; while thick in our rear flew the inscrutable sea-ravens. And
9421  every morning, perched on our stays, rows of these birds were seen; and
9422  spite of our hootings, for a long time obstinately clung to the hemp,
9423  as though they deemed our ship some drifting, uninhabited craft; a
9424  thing appointed to desolation, and therefore fit roosting-place for
9425  their homeless selves. And heaved and heaved, still unrestingly heaved
9426  the black sea, as if its vast tides were a conscience; and the great
9427  mundane soul were in anguish and remorse for the long sin and suffering
9428  it had bred.
9429  
9430  Cape of Good Hope, do they call ye? Rather Cape Tormentoso, as called
9431  of yore; for long allured by the perfidious silences that before had
9432  attended us, we found ourselves launched into this tormented sea, where
9433  guilty beings transformed into those fowls and these fish, seemed
9434  condemned to swim on everlastingly without any haven in store, or beat
9435  that black air without any horizon. But calm, snow-white, and
9436  unvarying; still directing its fountain of feathers to the sky; still
9437  beckoning us on from before, the solitary jet would at times be
9438  descried.
9439  
9440  During all this blackness of the elements, Ahab, though assuming for
9441  the time the almost continual command of the drenched and dangerous
9442  deck, manifested the gloomiest reserve; and more seldom than ever
9443  addressed his mates. In tempestuous times like these, after everything
9444  above and aloft has been secured, nothing more can be done but
9445  passively to await the issue of the gale. Then Captain and crew become
9446  practical fatalists. So, with his ivory leg inserted into its
9447  accustomed hole, and with one hand firmly grasping a shroud, Ahab for
9448  hours and hours would stand gazing dead to windward, while an
9449  occasional squall of sleet or snow would all but congeal his very
9450  eyelashes together. Meantime, the crew driven from the forward part of
