9451  the ship by the perilous seas that burstingly broke over its bows,
9452  stood in a line along the bulwarks in the waist; and the better to
9453  guard against the leaping waves, each man had slipped himself into a
9454  sort of bowline secured to the rail, in which he swung as in a loosened
9455  belt. Few or no words were spoken; and the silent ship, as if manned by
9456  painted sailors in wax, day after day tore on through all the swift
9457  madness and gladness of the demoniac waves. By night the same muteness
9458  of humanity before the shrieks of the ocean prevailed; still in silence
9459  the men swung in the bowlines; still wordless Ahab stood up to the
9460  blast. Even when wearied nature seemed demanding repose he would not
9461  seek that repose in his hammock. Never could Starbuck forget the old
9462  man’s aspect, when one night going down into the cabin to mark how the
9463  barometer stood, he saw him with closed eyes sitting straight in his
9464  floor-screwed chair; the rain and half-melted sleet of the storm from
9465  which he had some time before emerged, still slowly dripping from the
9466  unremoved hat and coat. On the table beside him lay unrolled one of
9467  those charts of tides and currents which have previously been spoken
9468  of. His lantern swung from his tightly clenched hand. Though the body
9469  was erect, the head was thrown back so that the closed eyes were
9470  pointed towards the needle of the tell-tale that swung from a beam in
9471  the ceiling.*
9472  
9473  *The cabin-compass is called the tell-tale, because without going to
9474  the compass at the helm, the Captain, while below, can inform himself
9475  of the course of the ship.
9476  
9477  Terrible old man! thought Starbuck with a shudder, sleeping in this
9478  gale, still thou steadfastly eyest thy purpose.
9479  
9480  
9481  CHAPTER 52. The Albatross.
9482  
9483  South-eastward from the Cape, off the distant Crozetts, a good cruising
9484  ground for Right Whalemen, a sail loomed ahead, the Goney (Albatross)
9485  by name. As she slowly drew nigh, from my lofty perch at the
9486  fore-mast-head, I had a good view of that sight so remarkable to a tyro
9487  in the far ocean fisheries—a whaler at sea, and long absent from home.
9488  
9489  As if the waves had been fullers, this craft was bleached like the
9490  skeleton of a stranded walrus. All down her sides, this spectral
9491  appearance was traced with long channels of reddened rust, while all
9492  her spars and her rigging were like the thick branches of trees furred
9493  over with hoar-frost. Only her lower sails were set. A wild sight it
9494  was to see her long-bearded look-outs at those three mast-heads. They
9495  seemed clad in the skins of beasts, so torn and bepatched the raiment
9496  that had survived nearly four years of cruising. Standing in iron hoops
9497  nailed to the mast, they swayed and swung over a fathomless sea; and
9498  though, when the ship slowly glided close under our stern, we six men
9499  in the air came so nigh to each other that we might almost have leaped
9500  from the mast-heads of one ship to those of the other; yet, those
9501  forlorn-looking fishermen, mildly eyeing us as they passed, said not
9502  one word to our own look-outs, while the quarter-deck hail was being
9503  heard from below.
9504  
9505  “Ship ahoy! Have ye seen the White Whale?”
9506  
9507  But as the strange captain, leaning over the pallid bulwarks, was in
9508  the act of putting his trumpet to his mouth, it somehow fell from his
9509  hand into the sea; and the wind now rising amain, he in vain strove to
9510  make himself heard without it. Meantime his ship was still increasing
9511  the distance between. While in various silent ways the seamen of the
9512  Pequod were evincing their observance of this ominous incident at the
9513  first mere mention of the White Whale’s name to another ship, Ahab for
9514  a moment paused; it almost seemed as though he would have lowered a
9515  boat to board the stranger, had not the threatening wind forbade. But
9516  taking advantage of his windward position, he again seized his trumpet,
9517  and knowing by her aspect that the stranger vessel was a Nantucketer
9518  and shortly bound home, he loudly hailed—“Ahoy there! This is the
9519  Pequod, bound round the world! Tell them to address all future letters
9520  to the Pacific ocean! and this time three years, if I am not at home,
9521  tell them to address them to ——”
9522  
9523  At that moment the two wakes were fairly crossed, and instantly, then,
9524  in accordance with their singular ways, shoals of small harmless fish,
9525  that for some days before had been placidly swimming by our side,
9526  darted away with what seemed shuddering fins, and ranged themselves
9527  fore and aft with the stranger’s flanks. Though in the course of his
9528  continual voyagings Ahab must often before have noticed a similar
9529  sight, yet, to any monomaniac man, the veriest trifles capriciously
9530  carry meanings.
9531  
9532  “Swim away from me, do ye?” murmured Ahab, gazing over into the water.
9533  There seemed but little in the words, but the tone conveyed more of
9534  deep helpless sadness than the insane old man had ever before evinced.
9535  But turning to the steersman, who thus far had been holding the ship in
9536  the wind to diminish her headway, he cried out in his old lion
9537  voice,—“Up helm! Keep her off round the world!”
9538  
9539  Round the world! There is much in that sound to inspire proud feelings;
9540  but whereto does all that circumnavigation conduct? Only through
9541  numberless perils to the very point whence we started, where those that
9542  we left behind secure, were all the time before us.
9543  
9544  Were this world an endless plain, and by sailing eastward we could for
9545  ever reach new distances, and discover sights more sweet and strange
9546  than any Cyclades or Islands of King Solomon, then there were promise
9547  in the voyage. But in pursuit of those far mysteries we dream of, or in
9548  tormented chase of that demon phantom that, some time or other, swims
9549  before all human hearts; while chasing such over this round globe, they
9550  either lead us on in barren mazes or midway leave us whelmed.
9551  
9552  
9553  CHAPTER 53. The Gam.
9554  
9555  The ostensible reason why Ahab did not go on board of the whaler we had
9556  spoken was this: the wind and sea betokened storms. But even had this
9557  not been the case, he would not after all, perhaps, have boarded
9558  her—judging by his subsequent conduct on similar occasions—if so it had
9559  been that, by the process of hailing, he had obtained a negative answer
9560  to the question he put. For, as it eventually turned out, he cared not
9561  to consort, even for five minutes, with any stranger captain, except he
9562  could contribute some of that information he so absorbingly sought. But
9563  all this might remain inadequately estimated, were not something said
9564  here of the peculiar usages of whaling-vessels when meeting each other
9565  in foreign seas, and especially on a common cruising-ground.
9566  
9567  If two strangers crossing the Pine Barrens in New York State, or the
9568  equally desolate Salisbury Plain in England; if casually encountering
9569  each other in such inhospitable wilds, these twain, for the life of
9570  them, cannot well avoid a mutual salutation; and stopping for a moment
9571  to interchange the news; and, perhaps, sitting down for a while and
9572  resting in concert: then, how much more natural that upon the
9573  illimitable Pine Barrens and Salisbury Plains of the sea, two whaling
9574  vessels descrying each other at the ends of the earth—off lone
9575  Fanning’s Island, or the far away King’s Mills; how much more natural,
9576  I say, that under such circumstances these ships should not only
9577  interchange hails, but come into still closer, more friendly and
9578  sociable contact. And especially would this seem to be a matter of
9579  course, in the case of vessels owned in one seaport, and whose
9580  captains, officers, and not a few of the men are personally known to
9581  each other; and consequently, have all sorts of dear domestic things to
9582  talk about.
9583  
9584  For the long absent ship, the outward-bounder, perhaps, has letters on
9585  board; at any rate, she will be sure to let her have some papers of a
9586  date a year or two later than the last one on her blurred and
9587  thumb-worn files. And in return for that courtesy, the outward-bound
9588  ship would receive the latest whaling intelligence from the
9589  cruising-ground to which she may be destined, a thing of the utmost
9590  importance to her. And in degree, all this will hold true concerning
9591  whaling vessels crossing each other’s track on the cruising-ground
9592  itself, even though they are equally long absent from home. For one of
9593  them may have received a transfer of letters from some third, and now
9594  far remote vessel; and some of those letters may be for the people of
9595  the ship she now meets. Besides, they would exchange the whaling news,
9596  and have an agreeable chat. For not only would they meet with all the
9597  sympathies of sailors, but likewise with all the peculiar
9598  congenialities arising from a common pursuit and mutually shared
9599  privations and perils.
9600  
9601  Nor would difference of country make any very essential difference;
9602  that is, so long as both parties speak one language, as is the case
9603  with Americans and English. Though, to be sure, from the small number
9604  of English whalers, such meetings do not very often occur, and when
9605  they do occur there is too apt to be a sort of shyness between them;
9606  for your Englishman is rather reserved, and your Yankee, he does not
9607  fancy that sort of thing in anybody but himself. Besides, the English
9608  whalers sometimes affect a kind of metropolitan superiority over the
9609  American whalers; regarding the long, lean Nantucketer, with his
9610  nondescript provincialisms, as a sort of sea-peasant. But where this
9611  superiority in the English whalemen does really consist, it would be
9612  hard to say, seeing that the Yankees in one day, collectively, kill
9613  more whales than all the English, collectively, in ten years. But this
9614  is a harmless little foible in the English whale-hunters, which the
9615  Nantucketer does not take much to heart; probably, because he knows
9616  that he has a few foibles himself.
9617  
9618  So, then, we see that of all ships separately sailing the sea, the
9619  whalers have most reason to be sociable—and they are so. Whereas, some
9620  merchant ships crossing each other’s wake in the mid-Atlantic, will
9621  oftentimes pass on without so much as a single word of recognition,
9622  mutually cutting each other on the high seas, like a brace of dandies
9623  in Broadway; and all the time indulging, perhaps, in finical criticism
9624  upon each other’s rig. As for Men-of-War, when they chance to meet at
9625  sea, they first go through such a string of silly bowings and
9626  scrapings, such a ducking of ensigns, that there does not seem to be
9627  much right-down hearty good-will and brotherly love about it at all. As
9628  touching Slave-ships meeting, why, they are in such a prodigious hurry,
9629  they run away from each other as soon as possible. And as for Pirates,
9630  when they chance to cross each other’s cross-bones, the first hail
9631  is—“How many skulls?”—the same way that whalers hail—“How many
9632  barrels?” And that question once answered, pirates straightway steer
9633  apart, for they are infernal villains on both sides, and don’t like to
9634  see overmuch of each other’s villanous likenesses.
9635  
9636  But look at the godly, honest, unostentatious, hospitable, sociable,
9637  free-and-easy whaler! What does the whaler do when she meets another
9638  whaler in any sort of decent weather? She has a “_Gam_,” a thing so
9639  utterly unknown to all other ships that they never heard of the name
9640  even; and if by chance they should hear of it, they only grin at it,
9641  and repeat gamesome stuff about “spouters” and “blubber-boilers,” and
9642  such like pretty exclamations. Why it is that all Merchant-seamen, and
9643  also all Pirates and Man-of-War’s men, and Slave-ship sailors, cherish
9644  such a scornful feeling towards Whale-ships; this is a question it
9645  would be hard to answer. Because, in the case of pirates, say, I should
9646  like to know whether that profession of theirs has any peculiar glory
9647  about it. It sometimes ends in uncommon elevation, indeed; but only at
9648  the gallows. And besides, when a man is elevated in that odd fashion,
9649  he has no proper foundation for his superior altitude. Hence, I
9650  conclude, that in boasting himself to be high lifted above a whaleman,
9651  in that assertion the pirate has no solid basis to stand on.
9652  
9653  But what is a _Gam?_ You might wear out your index-finger running up
9654  and down the columns of dictionaries, and never find the word. Dr.
9655  Johnson never attained to that erudition; Noah Webster’s ark does not
9656  hold it. Nevertheless, this same expressive word has now for many years
9657  been in constant use among some fifteen thousand true born Yankees.
9658  Certainly, it needs a definition, and should be incorporated into the
9659  Lexicon. With that view, let me learnedly define it.
9660  
9661  GAM. NOUN—_A social meeting of two_ (_or more_) _Whaleships, generally
9662  on a cruising-ground; when, after exchanging hails, they exchange
9663  visits by boats’ crews: the two captains remaining, for the time, on
9664  board of one ship, and the two chief mates on the other._
9665  
9666  There is another little item about Gamming which must not be forgotten
9667  here. All professions have their own little peculiarities of detail; so
9668  has the whale fishery. In a pirate, man-of-war, or slave ship, when the
9669  captain is rowed anywhere in his boat, he always sits in the stern
9670  sheets on a comfortable, sometimes cushioned seat there, and often
9671  steers himself with a pretty little milliner’s tiller decorated with
9672  gay cords and ribbons. But the whale-boat has no seat astern, no sofa
9673  of that sort whatever, and no tiller at all. High times indeed, if
9674  whaling captains were wheeled about the water on castors like gouty old
9675  aldermen in patent chairs. And as for a tiller, the whale-boat never
9676  admits of any such effeminacy; and therefore as in gamming a complete
9677  boat’s crew must leave the ship, and hence as the boat steerer or
9678  harpooneer is of the number, that subordinate is the steersman upon the
9679  occasion, and the captain, having no place to sit in, is pulled off to
9680  his visit all standing like a pine tree. And often you will notice that
9681  being conscious of the eyes of the whole visible world resting on him
9682  from the sides of the two ships, this standing captain is all alive to
9683  the importance of sustaining his dignity by maintaining his legs. Nor
9684  is this any very easy matter; for in his rear is the immense projecting
9685  steering oar hitting him now and then in the small of his back, the
9686  after-oar reciprocating by rapping his knees in front. He is thus
9687  completely wedged before and behind, and can only expand himself
9688  sideways by settling down on his stretched legs; but a sudden, violent
9689  pitch of the boat will often go far to topple him, because length of
9690  foundation is nothing without corresponding breadth. Merely make a
9691  spread angle of two poles, and you cannot stand them up. Then, again,
9692  it would never do in plain sight of the world’s riveted eyes, it would
9693  never do, I say, for this straddling captain to be seen steadying
9694  himself the slightest particle by catching hold of anything with his
9695  hands; indeed, as token of his entire, buoyant self-command, he
9696  generally carries his hands in his trowsers’ pockets; but perhaps being
9697  generally very large, heavy hands, he carries them there for ballast.
9698  Nevertheless there have occurred instances, well authenticated ones
9699  too, where the captain has been known for an uncommonly critical moment
9700  or two, in a sudden squall say—to seize hold of the nearest oarsman’s
9701  hair, and hold on there like grim death.
9702  
9703  
9704  CHAPTER 54. The Town-Ho’s Story.
9705  
9706  (_As told at the Golden Inn._)
9707  
9708  The Cape of Good Hope, and all the watery region round about there, is
9709  much like some noted four corners of a great highway, where you meet
9710  more travellers than in any other part.
9711  
9712  It was not very long after speaking the Goney that another
9713  homeward-bound whaleman, the Town-Ho,* was encountered. She was manned
9714  almost wholly by Polynesians. In the short gam that ensued she gave us
9715  strong news of Moby Dick. To some the general interest in the White
9716  Whale was now wildly heightened by a circumstance of the Town-Ho’s
9717  story, which seemed obscurely to involve with the whale a certain
9718  wondrous, inverted visitation of one of those so called judgments of
9719  God which at times are said to overtake some men. This latter
9720  circumstance, with its own particular accompaniments, forming what may
9721  be called the secret part of the tragedy about to be narrated, never
9722  reached the ears of Captain Ahab or his mates. For that secret part of
9723  the story was unknown to the captain of the Town-Ho himself. It was the
9724  private property of three confederate white seamen of that ship, one of
9725  whom, it seems, communicated it to Tashtego with Romish injunctions of
9726  secrecy, but the following night Tashtego rambled in his sleep, and
9727  revealed so much of it in that way, that when he was wakened he could
9728  not well withhold the rest. Nevertheless, so potent an influence did
9729  this thing have on those seamen in the Pequod who came to the full
9730  knowledge of it, and by such a strange delicacy, to call it so, were
9731  they governed in this matter, that they kept the secret among
9732  themselves so that it never transpired abaft the Pequod’s main-mast.
9733  Interweaving in its proper place this darker thread with the story as
9734  publicly narrated on the ship, the whole of this strange affair I now
9735  proceed to put on lasting record.
9736  
9737  *The ancient whale-cry upon first sighting a whale from the mast-head,
9738  still used by whalemen in hunting the famous Gallipagos terrapin.
9739  
9740  For my humor’s sake, I shall preserve the style in which I once
9741  narrated it at Lima, to a lounging circle of my Spanish friends, one
9742  saint’s eve, smoking upon the thick-gilt tiled piazza of the Golden
9743  Inn. Of those fine cavaliers, the young Dons, Pedro and Sebastian, were
9744  on the closer terms with me; and hence the interluding questions they
9745  occasionally put, and which are duly answered at the time.
9746  
9747  “Some two years prior to my first learning the events which I am about
9748  rehearsing to you, gentlemen, the Town-Ho, Sperm Whaler of Nantucket,
9749  was cruising in your Pacific here, not very many days’ sail eastward
9750  from the eaves of this good Golden Inn. She was somewhere to the
9751  northward of the Line. One morning upon handling the pumps, according
9752  to daily usage, it was observed that she made more water in her hold
9753  than common. They supposed a sword-fish had stabbed her, gentlemen. But
9754  the captain, having some unusual reason for believing that rare good
9755  luck awaited him in those latitudes; and therefore being very averse to
9756  quit them, and the leak not being then considered at all dangerous,
9757  though, indeed, they could not find it after searching the hold as low
9758  down as was possible in rather heavy weather, the ship still continued
9759  her cruisings, the mariners working at the pumps at wide and easy
9760  intervals; but no good luck came; more days went by, and not only was
9761  the leak yet undiscovered, but it sensibly increased. So much so, that
9762  now taking some alarm, the captain, making all sail, stood away for the
9763  nearest harbor among the islands, there to have his hull hove out and
9764  repaired.
9765  
9766  “Though no small passage was before her, yet, if the commonest chance
9767  favoured, he did not at all fear that his ship would founder by the
9768  way, because his pumps were of the best, and being periodically
9769  relieved at them, those six-and-thirty men of his could easily keep the
9770  ship free; never mind if the leak should double on her. In truth, well
9771  nigh the whole of this passage being attended by very prosperous
9772  breezes, the Town-Ho had all but certainly arrived in perfect safety at
9773  her port without the occurrence of the least fatality, had it not been
9774  for the brutal overbearing of Radney, the mate, a Vineyarder, and the
9775  bitterly provoked vengeance of Steelkilt, a Lakeman and desperado from
9776  Buffalo.
9777  
9778  “‘Lakeman!—Buffalo! Pray, what is a Lakeman, and where is Buffalo?’
9779  said Don Sebastian, rising in his swinging mat of grass.
9780  
9781  “On the eastern shore of our Lake Erie, Don; but—I crave your
9782  courtesy—may be, you shall soon hear further of all that. Now,
9783  gentlemen, in square-sail brigs and three-masted ships, well-nigh as
9784  large and stout as any that ever sailed out of your old Callao to far
9785  Manilla; this Lakeman, in the land-locked heart of our America, had yet
9786  been nurtured by all those agrarian freebooting impressions popularly
9787  connected with the open ocean. For in their interflowing aggregate,
9788  those grand fresh-water seas of ours,—Erie, and Ontario, and Huron, and
9789  Superior, and Michigan,—possess an ocean-like expansiveness, with many
9790  of the ocean’s noblest traits; with many of its rimmed varieties of
9791  races and of climes. They contain round archipelagoes of romantic
9792  isles, even as the Polynesian waters do; in large part, are shored by
9793  two great contrasting nations, as the Atlantic is; they furnish long
9794  maritime approaches to our numerous territorial colonies from the East,
9795  dotted all round their banks; here and there are frowned upon by
9796  batteries, and by the goat-like craggy guns of lofty Mackinaw; they
9797  have heard the fleet thunderings of naval victories; at intervals, they
9798  yield their beaches to wild barbarians, whose red painted faces flash
9799  from out their peltry wigwams; for leagues and leagues are flanked by
9800  ancient and unentered forests, where the gaunt pines stand like serried
9801  lines of kings in Gothic genealogies; those same woods harboring wild
9802  Afric beasts of prey, and silken creatures whose exported furs give
9803  robes to Tartar Emperors; they mirror the paved capitals of Buffalo and
9804  Cleveland, as well as Winnebago villages; they float alike the
9805  full-rigged merchant ship, the armed cruiser of the State, the steamer,
9806  and the beech canoe; they are swept by Borean and dismasting blasts as
9807  direful as any that lash the salted wave; they know what shipwrecks
9808  are, for out of sight of land, however inland, they have drowned full
9809  many a midnight ship with all its shrieking crew. Thus, gentlemen,
9810  though an inlander, Steelkilt was wild-ocean born, and wild-ocean
9811  nurtured; as much of an audacious mariner as any. And for Radney,
9812  though in his infancy he may have laid him down on the lone Nantucket
9813  beach, to nurse at his maternal sea; though in after life he had long
9814  followed our austere Atlantic and your contemplative Pacific; yet was
9815  he quite as vengeful and full of social quarrel as the backwoods
9816  seaman, fresh from the latitudes of buck-horn handled Bowie-knives. Yet
9817  was this Nantucketer a man with some good-hearted traits; and this
9818  Lakeman, a mariner, who though a sort of devil indeed, might yet by
9819  inflexible firmness, only tempered by that common decency of human
9820  recognition which is the meanest slave’s right; thus treated, this
9821  Steelkilt had long been retained harmless and docile. At all events, he
9822  had proved so thus far; but Radney was doomed and made mad, and
9823  Steelkilt—but, gentlemen, you shall hear.
9824  
9825  “It was not more than a day or two at the furthest after pointing her
9826  prow for her island haven, that the Town-Ho’s leak seemed again
9827  increasing, but only so as to require an hour or more at the pumps
9828  every day. You must know that in a settled and civilized ocean like our
9829  Atlantic, for example, some skippers think little of pumping their
9830  whole way across it; though of a still, sleepy night, should the
9831  officer of the deck happen to forget his duty in that respect, the
9832  probability would be that he and his shipmates would never again
9833  remember it, on account of all hands gently subsiding to the bottom.
9834  Nor in the solitary and savage seas far from you to the westward,
9835  gentlemen, is it altogether unusual for ships to keep clanging at their
9836  pump-handles in full chorus even for a voyage of considerable length;
9837  that is, if it lie along a tolerably accessible coast, or if any other
9838  reasonable retreat is afforded them. It is only when a leaky vessel is
9839  in some very out of the way part of those waters, some really landless
9840  latitude, that her captain begins to feel a little anxious.
9841  
9842  “Much this way had it been with the Town-Ho; so when her leak was found
9843  gaining once more, there was in truth some small concern manifested by
9844  several of her company; especially by Radney the mate. He commanded the
9845  upper sails to be well hoisted, sheeted home anew, and every way
9846  expanded to the breeze. Now this Radney, I suppose, was as little of a
9847  coward, and as little inclined to any sort of nervous apprehensiveness
9848  touching his own person as any fearless, unthinking creature on land or
9849  on sea that you can conveniently imagine, gentlemen. Therefore when he
9850  betrayed this solicitude about the safety of the ship, some of the
9851  seamen declared that it was only on account of his being a part owner
9852  in her. So when they were working that evening at the pumps, there was
9853  on this head no small gamesomeness slily going on among them, as they
9854  stood with their feet continually overflowed by the rippling clear
9855  water; clear as any mountain spring, gentlemen—that bubbling from the
9856  pumps ran across the deck, and poured itself out in steady spouts at
9857  the lee scupper-holes.
9858  
9859  “Now, as you well know, it is not seldom the case in this conventional
9860  world of ours—watery or otherwise; that when a person placed in command
9861  over his fellow-men finds one of them to be very significantly his
9862  superior in general pride of manhood, straightway against that man he
9863  conceives an unconquerable dislike and bitterness; and if he have a
9864  chance he will pull down and pulverize that subaltern’s tower, and make
9865  a little heap of dust of it. Be this conceit of mine as it may,
9866  gentlemen, at all events Steelkilt was a tall and noble animal with a
9867  head like a Roman, and a flowing golden beard like the tasseled
9868  housings of your last viceroy’s snorting charger; and a brain, and a
9869  heart, and a soul in him, gentlemen, which had made Steelkilt
9870  Charlemagne, had he been born son to Charlemagne’s father. But Radney,
9871  the mate, was ugly as a mule; yet as hardy, as stubborn, as malicious.
9872  He did not love Steelkilt, and Steelkilt knew it.
9873  
9874  “Espying the mate drawing near as he was toiling at the pump with the
9875  rest, the Lakeman affected not to notice him, but unawed, went on with
9876  his gay banterings.
9877  
9878  “‘Aye, aye, my merry lads, it’s a lively leak this; hold a cannikin,
9879  one of ye, and let’s have a taste. By the Lord, it’s worth bottling! I
9880  tell ye what, men, old Rad’s investment must go for it! he had best cut
9881  away his part of the hull and tow it home. The fact is, boys, that
9882  sword-fish only began the job; he’s come back again with a gang of
9883  ship-carpenters, saw-fish, and file-fish, and what not; and the whole
9884  posse of ’em are now hard at work cutting and slashing at the bottom;
9885  making improvements, I suppose. If old Rad were here now, I’d tell him
9886  to jump overboard and scatter ’em. They’re playing the devil with his
9887  estate, I can tell him. But he’s a simple old soul,—Rad, and a beauty
9888  too. Boys, they say the rest of his property is invested in
9889  looking-glasses. I wonder if he’d give a poor devil like me the model
9890  of his nose.’
9891  
9892  “‘Damn your eyes! what’s that pump stopping for?’ roared Radney,
9893  pretending not to have heard the sailors’ talk. ‘Thunder away at it!’
9894  
9895  “‘Aye, aye, sir,’ said Steelkilt, merry as a cricket. ‘Lively, boys,
9896  lively, now!’ And with that the pump clanged like fifty fire-engines;
9897  the men tossed their hats off to it, and ere long that peculiar gasping
9898  of the lungs was heard which denotes the fullest tension of life’s
9899  utmost energies.
9900  
9901  “Quitting the pump at last, with the rest of his band, the Lakeman went
9902  forward all panting, and sat himself down on the windlass; his face
9903  fiery red, his eyes bloodshot, and wiping the profuse sweat from his
9904  brow. Now what cozening fiend it was, gentlemen, that possessed Radney
9905  to meddle with such a man in that corporeally exasperated state, I know
9906  not; but so it happened. Intolerably striding along the deck, the mate
9907  commanded him to get a broom and sweep down the planks, and also a
9908  shovel, and remove some offensive matters consequent upon allowing a
9909  pig to run at large.
9910  
9911  “Now, gentlemen, sweeping a ship’s deck at sea is a piece of household
9912  work which in all times but raging gales is regularly attended to every
9913  evening; it has been known to be done in the case of ships actually
9914  foundering at the time. Such, gentlemen, is the inflexibility of
9915  sea-usages and the instinctive love of neatness in seamen; some of whom
9916  would not willingly drown without first washing their faces. But in all
9917  vessels this broom business is the prescriptive province of the boys,
9918  if boys there be aboard. Besides, it was the stronger men in the
9919  Town-Ho that had been divided into gangs, taking turns at the pumps;
9920  and being the most athletic seaman of them all, Steelkilt had been
9921  regularly assigned captain of one of the gangs; consequently he should
9922  have been freed from any trivial business not connected with truly
9923  nautical duties, such being the case with his comrades. I mention all
9924  these particulars so that you may understand exactly how this affair
9925  stood between the two men.
9926  
9927  “But there was more than this: the order about the shovel was almost as
9928  plainly meant to sting and insult Steelkilt, as though Radney had spat
9929  in his face. Any man who has gone sailor in a whale-ship will
9930  understand this; and all this and doubtless much more, the Lakeman
9931  fully comprehended when the mate uttered his command. But as he sat
9932  still for a moment, and as he steadfastly looked into the mate’s
9933  malignant eye and perceived the stacks of powder-casks heaped up in him
9934  and the slow-match silently burning along towards them; as he
9935  instinctively saw all this, that strange forbearance and unwillingness
9936  to stir up the deeper passionateness in any already ireful being—a
9937  repugnance most felt, when felt at all, by really valiant men even when
9938  aggrieved—this nameless phantom feeling, gentlemen, stole over
9939  Steelkilt.
9940  
9941  “Therefore, in his ordinary tone, only a little broken by the bodily
9942  exhaustion he was temporarily in, he answered him saying that sweeping
9943  the deck was not his business, and he would not do it. And then,
9944  without at all alluding to the shovel, he pointed to three lads as the
9945  customary sweepers; who, not being billeted at the pumps, had done
9946  little or nothing all day. To this, Radney replied with an oath, in a
9947  most domineering and outrageous manner unconditionally reiterating his
9948  command; meanwhile advancing upon the still seated Lakeman, with an
9949  uplifted cooper’s club hammer which he had snatched from a cask near
9950  by.
9951  
9952  “Heated and irritated as he was by his spasmodic toil at the pumps, for
9953  all his first nameless feeling of forbearance the sweating Steelkilt
9954  could but ill brook this bearing in the mate; but somehow still
9955  smothering the conflagration within him, without speaking he remained
9956  doggedly rooted to his seat, till at last the incensed Radney shook the
9957  hammer within a few inches of his face, furiously commanding him to do
9958  his bidding.
9959  
9960  “Steelkilt rose, and slowly retreating round the windlass, steadily
9961  followed by the mate with his menacing hammer, deliberately repeated
9962  his intention not to obey. Seeing, however, that his forbearance had
9963  not the slightest effect, by an awful and unspeakable intimation with
9964  his twisted hand he warned off the foolish and infatuated man; but it
9965  was to no purpose. And in this way the two went once slowly round the
9966  windlass; when, resolved at last no longer to retreat, bethinking him
9967  that he had now forborne as much as comported with his humor, the
9968  Lakeman paused on the hatches and thus spoke to the officer:
9969  
9970  “‘Mr. Radney, I will not obey you. Take that hammer away, or look to
9971  yourself.’ But the predestinated mate coming still closer to him, where
9972  the Lakeman stood fixed, now shook the heavy hammer within an inch of
9973  his teeth; meanwhile repeating a string of insufferable maledictions.
9974  Retreating not the thousandth part of an inch; stabbing him in the eye
9975  with the unflinching poniard of his glance, Steelkilt, clenching his
9976  right hand behind him and creepingly drawing it back, told his
9977  persecutor that if the hammer but grazed his cheek he (Steelkilt) would
9978  murder him. But, gentlemen, the fool had been branded for the slaughter
9979  by the gods. Immediately the hammer touched the cheek; the next instant
9980  the lower jaw of the mate was stove in his head; he fell on the hatch
9981  spouting blood like a whale.
9982  
9983  “Ere the cry could go aft Steelkilt was shaking one of the backstays
9984  leading far aloft to where two of his comrades were standing their
9985  mastheads. They were both Canallers.
9986  
9987  “‘Canallers!’ cried Don Pedro. ‘We have seen many whale-ships in our
9988  harbours, but never heard of your Canallers. Pardon: who and what are
9989  they?’
9990  
9991  “‘Canallers, Don, are the boatmen belonging to our grand Erie Canal.
9992  You must have heard of it.’
9993  
9994  “‘Nay, Senor; hereabouts in this dull, warm, most lazy, and hereditary
9995  land, we know but little of your vigorous North.’
9996  
9997  “‘Aye? Well then, Don, refill my cup. Your chicha’s very fine; and ere
9998  proceeding further I will tell ye what our Canallers are; for such
9999  information may throw side-light upon my story.’
10000 
10001 “For three hundred and sixty miles, gentlemen, through the entire
10002 breadth of the state of New York; through numerous populous cities and
10003 most thriving villages; through long, dismal, uninhabited swamps, and
10004 affluent, cultivated fields, unrivalled for fertility; by billiard-room
10005 and bar-room; through the holy-of-holies of great forests; on Roman
10006 arches over Indian rivers; through sun and shade; by happy hearts or
10007 broken; through all the wide contrasting scenery of those noble Mohawk
10008 counties; and especially, by rows of snow-white chapels, whose spires
10009 stand almost like milestones, flows one continual stream of Venetianly
10010 corrupt and often lawless life. There’s your true Ashantee, gentlemen;
10011 there howl your pagans; where you ever find them, next door to you;
10012 under the long-flung shadow, and the snug patronising lee of churches.
10013 For by some curious fatality, as it is often noted of your metropolitan
10014 freebooters that they ever encamp around the halls of justice, so
10015 sinners, gentlemen, most abound in holiest vicinities.
10016 
10017 “‘Is that a friar passing?’ said Don Pedro, looking downwards into the
10018 crowded plazza, with humorous concern.
10019 
10020 “‘Well for our northern friend, Dame Isabella’s Inquisition wanes in
10021 Lima,’ laughed Don Sebastian. ‘Proceed, Senor.’
10022 
10023 “‘A moment! Pardon!’ cried another of the company. ‘In the name of all
10024 us Limeese, I but desire to express to you, sir sailor, that we have by
10025 no means overlooked your delicacy in not substituting present Lima for
10026 distant Venice in your corrupt comparison. Oh! do not bow and look
10027 surprised; you know the proverb all along this coast—“Corrupt as Lima.”
10028 It but bears out your saying, too; churches more plentiful than
10029 billiard-tables, and for ever open—and “Corrupt as Lima.” So, too,
10030 Venice; I have been there; the holy city of the blessed evangelist, St.
10031 Mark!—St. Dominic, purge it! Your cup! Thanks: here I refill; now, you
10032 pour out again.’
10033 
10034 “Freely depicted in his own vocation, gentlemen, the Canaller would
10035 make a fine dramatic hero, so abundantly and picturesquely wicked is
10036 he. Like Mark Antony, for days and days along his green-turfed, flowery
10037 Nile, he indolently floats, openly toying with his red-cheeked
10038 Cleopatra, ripening his apricot thigh upon the sunny deck. But ashore,
10039 all this effeminacy is dashed. The brigandish guise which the Canaller
10040 so proudly sports; his slouched and gaily-ribboned hat betoken his
10041 grand features. A terror to the smiling innocence of the villages
10042 through which he floats; his swart visage and bold swagger are not
10043 unshunned in cities. Once a vagabond on his own canal, I have received
10044 good turns from one of these Canallers; I thank him heartily; would
10045 fain be not ungrateful; but it is often one of the prime redeeming
10046 qualities of your man of violence, that at times he has as stiff an arm
10047 to back a poor stranger in a strait, as to plunder a wealthy one. In
10048 sum, gentlemen, what the wildness of this canal life is, is
10049 emphatically evinced by this; that our wild whale-fishery contains so
10050 many of its most finished graduates, and that scarce any race of
10051 mankind, except Sydney men, are so much distrusted by our whaling
10052 captains. Nor does it at all diminish the curiousness of this matter,
10053 that to many thousands of our rural boys and young men born along its
10054 line, the probationary life of the Grand Canal furnishes the sole
10055 transition between quietly reaping in a Christian corn-field, and
10056 recklessly ploughing the waters of the most barbaric seas.
10057 
10058 “‘I see! I see!’ impetuously exclaimed Don Pedro, spilling his chicha
10059 upon his silvery ruffles. ‘No need to travel! The world’s one Lima. I
10060 had thought, now, that at your temperate North the generations were
10061 cold and holy as the hills.—But the story.’
10062 
10063 “I left off, gentlemen, where the Lakeman shook the backstay. Hardly
10064 had he done so, when he was surrounded by the three junior mates and
10065 the four harpooneers, who all crowded him to the deck. But sliding down
10066 the ropes like baleful comets, the two Canallers rushed into the
10067 uproar, and sought to drag their man out of it towards the forecastle.
10068 Others of the sailors joined with them in this attempt, and a twisted
10069 turmoil ensued; while standing out of harm’s way, the valiant captain
10070 danced up and down with a whale-pike, calling upon his officers to
10071 manhandle that atrocious scoundrel, and smoke him along to the
10072 quarter-deck. At intervals, he ran close up to the revolving border of
10073 the confusion, and prying into the heart of it with his pike, sought to
10074 prick out the object of his resentment. But Steelkilt and his
10075 desperadoes were too much for them all; they succeeded in gaining the
10076 forecastle deck, where, hastily slewing about three or four large casks
10077 in a line with the windlass, these sea-Parisians entrenched themselves
10078 behind the barricade.
10079 
10080 “‘Come out of that, ye pirates!’ roared the captain, now menacing them
10081 with a pistol in each hand, just brought to him by the steward. ‘Come
10082 out of that, ye cut-throats!’
10083 
10084 “Steelkilt leaped on the barricade, and striding up and down there,
10085 defied the worst the pistols could do; but gave the captain to
10086 understand distinctly, that his (Steelkilt’s) death would be the signal
10087 for a murderous mutiny on the part of all hands. Fearing in his heart
10088 lest this might prove but too true, the captain a little desisted, but
10089 still commanded the insurgents instantly to return to their duty.
10090 
10091 “‘Will you promise not to touch us, if we do?’ demanded their
10092 ringleader.
10093 
10094 “‘Turn to! turn to!—I make no promise;—to your duty! Do you want to
10095 sink the ship, by knocking off at a time like this? Turn to!’ and he
10096 once more raised a pistol.
10097 
10098 “‘Sink the ship?’ cried Steelkilt. ‘Aye, let her sink. Not a man of us
10099 turns to, unless you swear not to raise a rope-yarn against us. What
10100 say ye, men?’ turning to his comrades. A fierce cheer was their
10101 response.
10102 
10103 “The Lakeman now patrolled the barricade, all the while keeping his eye
10104 on the Captain, and jerking out such sentences as these:—‘It’s not our
10105 fault; we didn’t want it; I told him to take his hammer away; it was
10106 boy’s business; he might have known me before this; I told him not to
10107 prick the buffalo; I believe I have broken a finger here against his
10108 cursed jaw; ain’t those mincing knives down in the forecastle there,
10109 men? look to those handspikes, my hearties. Captain, by God, look to
10110 yourself; say the word; don’t be a fool; forget it all; we are ready to
10111 turn to; treat us decently, and we’re your men; but we won’t be
10112 flogged.’
10113 
10114 “‘Turn to! I make no promises, turn to, I say!’
10115 
10116 “‘Look ye, now,’ cried the Lakeman, flinging out his arm towards him,
10117 ‘there are a few of us here (and I am one of them) who have shipped for
10118 the cruise, d’ye see; now as you well know, sir, we can claim our
10119 discharge as soon as the anchor is down; so we don’t want a row; it’s
10120 not our interest; we want to be peaceable; we are ready to work, but we
10121 won’t be flogged.’
10122 
10123 “‘Turn to!’ roared the Captain.
10124 
10125 “Steelkilt glanced round him a moment, and then said:—‘I tell you what
10126 it is now, Captain, rather than kill ye, and be hung for such a shabby
10127 rascal, we won’t lift a hand against ye unless ye attack us; but till
10128 you say the word about not flogging us, we don’t do a hand’s turn.’
10129 
10130 “‘Down into the forecastle then, down with ye, I’ll keep ye there till
10131 ye’re sick of it. Down ye go.’
10132 
10133 “‘Shall we?’ cried the ringleader to his men. Most of them were against
10134 it; but at length, in obedience to Steelkilt, they preceded him down
10135 into their dark den, growlingly disappearing, like bears into a cave.
10136 
10137 “As the Lakeman’s bare head was just level with the planks, the Captain
10138 and his posse leaped the barricade, and rapidly drawing over the slide
10139 of the scuttle, planted their group of hands upon it, and loudly called
10140 for the steward to bring the heavy brass padlock belonging to the
10141 companionway. Then opening the slide a little, the Captain whispered
10142 something down the crack, closed it, and turned the key upon them—ten
10143 in number—leaving on deck some twenty or more, who thus far had
10144 remained neutral.
10145 
10146 “All night a wide-awake watch was kept by all the officers, forward and
10147 aft, especially about the forecastle scuttle and fore hatchway; at
10148 which last place it was feared the insurgents might emerge, after
10149 breaking through the bulkhead below. But the hours of darkness passed
10150 in peace; the men who still remained at their duty toiling hard at the
10151 pumps, whose clinking and clanking at intervals through the dreary
10152 night dismally resounded through the ship.
10153 
10154 “At sunrise the Captain went forward, and knocking on the deck,
10155 summoned the prisoners to work; but with a yell they refused. Water was
10156 then lowered down to them, and a couple of handfuls of biscuit were
10157 tossed after it; when again turning the key upon them and pocketing it,
10158 the Captain returned to the quarter-deck. Twice every day for three
10159 days this was repeated; but on the fourth morning a confused wrangling,
10160 and then a scuffling was heard, as the customary summons was delivered;
10161 and suddenly four men burst up from the forecastle, saying they were
10162 ready to turn to. The fetid closeness of the air, and a famishing diet,
10163 united perhaps to some fears of ultimate retribution, had constrained
10164 them to surrender at discretion. Emboldened by this, the Captain
10165 reiterated his demand to the rest, but Steelkilt shouted up to him a
10166 terrific hint to stop his babbling and betake himself where he
10167 belonged. On the fifth morning three others of the mutineers bolted up
10168 into the air from the desperate arms below that sought to restrain
10169 them. Only three were left.
10170 
10171 “‘Better turn to, now?’ said the Captain with a heartless jeer.
10172 
10173 “‘Shut us up again, will ye!’ cried Steelkilt.
10174 
10175 “‘Oh certainly,’ said the Captain, and the key clicked.
10176 
10177 “It was at this point, gentlemen, that enraged by the defection of
10178 seven of his former associates, and stung by the mocking voice that had
10179 last hailed him, and maddened by his long entombment in a place as
10180 black as the bowels of despair; it was then that Steelkilt proposed to
10181 the two Canallers, thus far apparently of one mind with him, to burst
10182 out of their hole at the next summoning of the garrison; and armed with
10183 their keen mincing knives (long, crescentic, heavy implements with a
10184 handle at each end) run amuck from the bowsprit to the taffrail; and if
10185 by any devilishness of desperation possible, seize the ship. For
10186 himself, he would do this, he said, whether they joined him or not.
10187 That was the last night he should spend in that den. But the scheme met
10188 with no opposition on the part of the other two; they swore they were
10189 ready for that, or for any other mad thing, for anything in short but a
10190 surrender. And what was more, they each insisted upon being the first
10191 man on deck, when the time to make the rush should come. But to this
10192 their leader as fiercely objected, reserving that priority for himself;
10193 particularly as his two comrades would not yield, the one to the other,
10194 in the matter; and both of them could not be first, for the ladder
10195 would but admit one man at a time. And here, gentlemen, the foul play
10196 of these miscreants must come out.
10197 
10198 “Upon hearing the frantic project of their leader, each in his own
10199 separate soul had suddenly lighted, it would seem, upon the same piece
10200 of treachery, namely: to be foremost in breaking out, in order to be
10201 the first of the three, though the last of the ten, to surrender; and
10202 thereby secure whatever small chance of pardon such conduct might
10203 merit. But when Steelkilt made known his determination still to lead
10204 them to the last, they in some way, by some subtle chemistry of
10205 villany, mixed their before secret treacheries together; and when their
10206 leader fell into a doze, verbally opened their souls to each other in
10207 three sentences; and bound the sleeper with cords, and gagged him with
10208 cords; and shrieked out for the Captain at midnight.
10209 
10210 “Thinking murder at hand, and smelling in the dark for the blood, he
10211 and all his armed mates and harpooneers rushed for the forecastle. In a
10212 few minutes the scuttle was opened, and, bound hand and foot, the still
10213 struggling ringleader was shoved up into the air by his perfidious
10214 allies, who at once claimed the honor of securing a man who had been
10215 fully ripe for murder. But all these were collared, and dragged along
10216 the deck like dead cattle; and, side by side, were seized up into the
10217 mizzen rigging, like three quarters of meat, and there they hung till
10218 morning. ‘Damn ye,’ cried the Captain, pacing to and fro before them,
10219 ‘the vultures would not touch ye, ye villains!’
10220 
10221 “At sunrise he summoned all hands; and separating those who had
10222 rebelled from those who had taken no part in the mutiny, he told the
10223 former that he had a good mind to flog them all round—thought, upon the
10224 whole, he would do so—he ought to—justice demanded it; but for the
10225 present, considering their timely surrender, he would let them go with
10226 a reprimand, which he accordingly administered in the vernacular.
10227 
10228 “‘But as for you, ye carrion rogues,’ turning to the three men in the
10229 rigging—‘for you, I mean to mince ye up for the try-pots;’ and, seizing
10230 a rope, he applied it with all his might to the backs of the two
10231 traitors, till they yelled no more, but lifelessly hung their heads
10232 sideways, as the two crucified thieves are drawn.
10233 
10234 “‘My wrist is sprained with ye!’ he cried, at last; ‘but there is still
10235 rope enough left for you, my fine bantam, that wouldn’t give up. Take
10236 that gag from his mouth, and let us hear what he can say for himself.’
10237 
10238 “For a moment the exhausted mutineer made a tremulous motion of his
10239 cramped jaws, and then painfully twisting round his head, said in a
10240 sort of hiss, ‘What I say is this—and mind it well—if you flog me, I
10241 murder you!’
10242 
10243 “‘Say ye so? then see how ye frighten me’—and the Captain drew off with
10244 the rope to strike.
10245 
10246 “‘Best not,’ hissed the Lakeman.
10247 
10248 “‘But I must,’—and the rope was once more drawn back for the stroke.
10249 
10250 “Steelkilt here hissed out something, inaudible to all but the Captain;
10251 who, to the amazement of all hands, started back, paced the deck
10252 rapidly two or three times, and then suddenly throwing down his rope,
10253 said, ‘I won’t do it—let him go—cut him down: d’ye hear?’
10254 
10255 “But as the junior mates were hurrying to execute the order, a pale
10256 man, with a bandaged head, arrested them—Radney the chief mate. Ever
10257 since the blow, he had lain in his berth; but that morning, hearing the
10258 tumult on the deck, he had crept out, and thus far had watched the
10259 whole scene. Such was the state of his mouth, that he could hardly
10260 speak; but mumbling something about _his_ being willing and able to do
10261 what the captain dared not attempt, he snatched the rope and advanced
10262 to his pinioned foe.
10263 
10264 “‘You are a coward!’ hissed the Lakeman.
10265 
10266 “‘So I am, but take that.’ The mate was in the very act of striking,
10267 when another hiss stayed his uplifted arm. He paused: and then pausing
10268 no more, made good his word, spite of Steelkilt’s threat, whatever that
10269 might have been. The three men were then cut down, all hands were
10270 turned to, and, sullenly worked by the moody seamen, the iron pumps
10271 clanged as before.
10272 
10273 “Just after dark that day, when one watch had retired below, a clamor
10274 was heard in the forecastle; and the two trembling traitors running up,
10275 besieged the cabin door, saying they durst not consort with the crew.
10276 Entreaties, cuffs, and kicks could not drive them back, so at their own
10277 instance they were put down in the ship’s run for salvation. Still, no
10278 sign of mutiny reappeared among the rest. On the contrary, it seemed,
10279 that mainly at Steelkilt’s instigation, they had resolved to maintain
10280 the strictest peacefulness, obey all orders to the last, and, when the
10281 ship reached port, desert her in a body. But in order to insure the
10282 speediest end to the voyage, they all agreed to another thing—namely,
10283 not to sing out for whales, in case any should be discovered. For,
10284 spite of her leak, and spite of all her other perils, the Town-Ho still
10285 maintained her mast-heads, and her captain was just as willing to lower
10286 for a fish that moment, as on the day his craft first struck the
10287 cruising ground; and Radney the mate was quite as ready to change his
10288 berth for a boat, and with his bandaged mouth seek to gag in death the
10289 vital jaw of the whale.
10290 
10291 “But though the Lakeman had induced the seamen to adopt this sort of
10292 passiveness in their conduct, he kept his own counsel (at least till
10293 all was over) concerning his own proper and private revenge upon the
10294 man who had stung him in the ventricles of his heart. He was in Radney
10295 the chief mate’s watch; and as if the infatuated man sought to run more
10296 than half way to meet his doom, after the scene at the rigging, he
10297 insisted, against the express counsel of the captain, upon resuming the
10298 head of his watch at night. Upon this, and one or two other
10299 circumstances, Steelkilt systematically built the plan of his revenge.
10300 
10301 “During the night, Radney had an unseamanlike way of sitting on the
10302 bulwarks of the quarter-deck, and leaning his arm upon the gunwale of
10303 the boat which was hoisted up there, a little above the ship’s side. In
10304 this attitude, it was well known, he sometimes dozed. There was a
10305 considerable vacancy between the boat and the ship, and down between
10306 this was the sea. Steelkilt calculated his time, and found that his
10307 next trick at the helm would come round at two o’clock, in the morning
10308 of the third day from that in which he had been betrayed. At his
10309 leisure, he employed the interval in braiding something very carefully
10310 in his watches below.
10311 
10312 “‘What are you making there?’ said a shipmate.
10313 
10314 “‘What do you think? what does it look like?’
10315 
10316 “‘Like a lanyard for your bag; but it’s an odd one, seems to me.’
10317 
10318 “‘Yes, rather oddish,’ said the Lakeman, holding it at arm’s length
10319 before him; ‘but I think it will answer. Shipmate, I haven’t enough
10320 twine,—have you any?’
10321 
10322 “But there was none in the forecastle.
10323 
10324 “‘Then I must get some from old Rad;’ and he rose to go aft.
10325 
10326 “‘You don’t mean to go a begging to _him!_’ said a sailor.
10327 
10328 “‘Why not? Do you think he won’t do me a turn, when it’s to help
10329 himself in the end, shipmate?’ and going to the mate, he looked at him
10330 quietly, and asked him for some twine to mend his hammock. It was given
10331 him—neither twine nor lanyard were seen again; but the next night an
10332 iron ball, closely netted, partly rolled from the pocket of the
10333 Lakeman’s monkey jacket, as he was tucking the coat into his hammock
10334 for a pillow. Twenty-four hours after, his trick at the silent
10335 helm—nigh to the man who was apt to doze over the grave always ready
10336 dug to the seaman’s hand—that fatal hour was then to come; and in the
10337 fore-ordaining soul of Steelkilt, the mate was already stark and
10338 stretched as a corpse, with his forehead crushed in.
10339 
10340 “But, gentlemen, a fool saved the would-be murderer from the bloody
10341 deed he had planned. Yet complete revenge he had, and without being the
10342 avenger. For by a mysterious fatality, Heaven itself seemed to step in
10343 to take out of his hands into its own the damning thing he would have
10344 done.
10345 
10346 “It was just between daybreak and sunrise of the morning of the second
10347 day, when they were washing down the decks, that a stupid Teneriffe
10348 man, drawing water in the main-chains, all at once shouted out, ‘There
10349 she rolls! there she rolls!’ Jesu, what a whale! It was Moby Dick.
10350 
10351 “‘Moby Dick!’ cried Don Sebastian; ‘St. Dominic! Sir sailor, but do
10352 whales have christenings? Whom call you Moby Dick?’
10353 
10354 “‘A very white, and famous, and most deadly immortal monster, Don;—but
10355 that would be too long a story.’
10356 
10357 “‘How? how?’ cried all the young Spaniards, crowding.
10358 
10359 “‘Nay, Dons, Dons—nay, nay! I cannot rehearse that now. Let me get more
10360 into the air, Sirs.’
10361 
10362 “‘The chicha! the chicha!’ cried Don Pedro; ‘our vigorous friend looks
10363 faint;—fill up his empty glass!’
10364 
10365 “No need, gentlemen; one moment, and I proceed.—Now, gentlemen, so
10366 suddenly perceiving the snowy whale within fifty yards of the
10367 ship—forgetful of the compact among the crew—in the excitement of the
10368 moment, the Teneriffe man had instinctively and involuntarily lifted
10369 his voice for the monster, though for some little time past it had been
10370 plainly beheld from the three sullen mast-heads. All was now a phrensy.
10371 ‘The White Whale—the White Whale!’ was the cry from captain, mates, and
10372 harpooneers, who, undeterred by fearful rumours, were all anxious to
10373 capture so famous and precious a fish; while the dogged crew eyed
10374 askance, and with curses, the appalling beauty of the vast milky mass,
10375 that lit up by a horizontal spangling sun, shifted and glistened like a
10376 living opal in the blue morning sea. Gentlemen, a strange fatality
10377 pervades the whole career of these events, as if verily mapped out
10378 before the world itself was charted. The mutineer was the bowsman of
10379 the mate, and when fast to a fish, it was his duty to sit next him,
10380 while Radney stood up with his lance in the prow, and haul in or
10381 slacken the line, at the word of command. Moreover, when the four boats
10382 were lowered, the mate’s got the start; and none howled more fiercely
10383 with delight than did Steelkilt, as he strained at his oar. After a
10384 stiff pull, their harpooneer got fast, and, spear in hand, Radney
10385 sprang to the bow. He was always a furious man, it seems, in a boat.
10386 And now his bandaged cry was, to beach him on the whale’s topmost back.
10387 Nothing loath, his bowsman hauled him up and up, through a blinding
10388 foam that blent two whitenesses together; till of a sudden the boat
10389 struck as against a sunken ledge, and keeling over, spilled out the
10390 standing mate. That instant, as he fell on the whale’s slippery back,
10391 the boat righted, and was dashed aside by the swell, while Radney was
10392 tossed over into the sea, on the other flank of the whale. He struck
10393 out through the spray, and, for an instant, was dimly seen through that
10394 veil, wildly seeking to remove himself from the eye of Moby Dick. But
10395 the whale rushed round in a sudden maelstrom; seized the swimmer
10396 between his jaws; and rearing high up with him, plunged headlong again,
10397 and went down.
10398 
10399 “Meantime, at the first tap of the boat’s bottom, the Lakeman had
10400 slackened the line, so as to drop astern from the whirlpool; calmly
10401 looking on, he thought his own thoughts. But a sudden, terrific,
10402 downward jerking of the boat, quickly brought his knife to the line. He
10403 cut it; and the whale was free. But, at some distance, Moby Dick rose
10404 again, with some tatters of Radney’s red woollen shirt, caught in the
10405 teeth that had destroyed him. All four boats gave chase again; but the
10406 whale eluded them, and finally wholly disappeared.
10407 
10408 “In good time, the Town-Ho reached her port—a savage, solitary
10409 place—where no civilized creature resided. There, headed by the
10410 Lakeman, all but five or six of the foremastmen deliberately deserted
10411 among the palms; eventually, as it turned out, seizing a large double
10412 war-canoe of the savages, and setting sail for some other harbor.
10413 
10414 “The ship’s company being reduced to but a handful, the captain called
10415 upon the Islanders to assist him in the laborious business of heaving
10416 down the ship to stop the leak. But to such unresting vigilance over
10417 their dangerous allies was this small band of whites necessitated, both
10418 by night and by day, and so extreme was the hard work they underwent,
10419 that upon the vessel being ready again for sea, they were in such a
10420 weakened condition that the captain durst not put off with them in so
10421 heavy a vessel. After taking counsel with his officers, he anchored the
10422 ship as far off shore as possible; loaded and ran out his two cannon
10423 from the bows; stacked his muskets on the poop; and warning the
10424 Islanders not to approach the ship at their peril, took one man with
10425 him, and setting the sail of his best whale-boat, steered straight
10426 before the wind for Tahiti, five hundred miles distant, to procure a
10427 reinforcement to his crew.
10428 
10429 “On the fourth day of the sail, a large canoe was descried, which
10430 seemed to have touched at a low isle of corals. He steered away from
10431 it; but the savage craft bore down on him; and soon the voice of
10432 Steelkilt hailed him to heave to, or he would run him under water. The
10433 captain presented a pistol. With one foot on each prow of the yoked
10434 war-canoes, the Lakeman laughed him to scorn; assuring him that if the
10435 pistol so much as clicked in the lock, he would bury him in bubbles and
10436 foam.
10437 
10438 “‘What do you want of me?’ cried the captain.
10439 
10440 “‘Where are you bound? and for what are you bound?’ demanded Steelkilt;
10441 ‘no lies.’
10442 
10443 “‘I am bound to Tahiti for more men.’
10444 
10445 “‘Very good. Let me board you a moment—I come in peace.’ With that he
10446 leaped from the canoe, swam to the boat; and climbing the gunwale,
10447 stood face to face with the captain.
10448 
10449 “‘Cross your arms, sir; throw back your head. Now, repeat after me. As
10450 soon as Steelkilt leaves me, I swear to beach this boat on yonder
10451 island, and remain there six days. If I do not, may lightnings strike
10452 me!’
10453 
10454 “‘A pretty scholar,’ laughed the Lakeman. ‘Adios, Senor!’ and leaping
10455 into the sea, he swam back to his comrades.
10456 
10457 “Watching the boat till it was fairly beached, and drawn up to the
10458 roots of the cocoa-nut trees, Steelkilt made sail again, and in due
10459 time arrived at Tahiti, his own place of destination. There, luck
10460 befriended him; two ships were about to sail for France, and were
10461 providentially in want of precisely that number of men which the sailor
10462 headed. They embarked; and so for ever got the start of their former
10463 captain, had he been at all minded to work them legal retribution.
10464 
10465 “Some ten days after the French ships sailed, the whale-boat arrived,
10466 and the captain was forced to enlist some of the more civilized
10467 Tahitians, who had been somewhat used to the sea. Chartering a small
10468 native schooner, he returned with them to his vessel; and finding all
10469 right there, again resumed his cruisings.
10470 
10471 “Where Steelkilt now is, gentlemen, none know; but upon the island of
10472 Nantucket, the widow of Radney still turns to the sea which refuses to
10473 give up its dead; still in dreams sees the awful white whale that
10474 destroyed him.  * * * *
10475 
10476 “‘Are you through?’ said Don Sebastian, quietly.
10477 
10478 “‘I am, Don.’
10479 
10480 “‘Then I entreat you, tell me if to the best of your own convictions,
10481 this your story is in substance really true? It is so passing
10482 wonderful! Did you get it from an unquestionable source? Bear with me
10483 if I seem to press.’
10484 
10485 “‘Also bear with all of us, sir sailor; for we all join in Don
10486 Sebastian’s suit,’ cried the company, with exceeding interest.
10487 
10488 “‘Is there a copy of the Holy Evangelists in the Golden Inn,
10489 gentlemen?’
10490 
10491 “‘Nay,’ said Don Sebastian; ‘but I know a worthy priest near by, who
10492 will quickly procure one for me. I go for it; but are you well advised?
10493 this may grow too serious.’
10494 
10495 “‘Will you be so good as to bring the priest also, Don?’
10496 
10497 “‘Though there are no Auto-da-Fés in Lima now,’ said one of the company
10498 to another; ‘I fear our sailor friend runs risk of the archiepiscopacy.
10499 Let us withdraw more out of the moonlight. I see no need of this.’
10500 
10501 “‘Excuse me for running after you, Don Sebastian; but may I also beg
10502 that you will be particular in procuring the largest sized Evangelists
10503 you can.’
10504 
10505 * * * * * *
10506 
10507 “‘This is the priest, he brings you the Evangelists,’ said Don
10508 Sebastian, gravely, returning with a tall and solemn figure.
10509 
10510 “‘Let me remove my hat. Now, venerable priest, further into the light,
10511 and hold the Holy Book before me that I may touch it.
10512 
10513 “‘So help me Heaven, and on my honor the story I have told ye,
10514 gentlemen, is in substance and its great items, true. I know it to be
10515 true; it happened on this ball; I trod the ship; I knew the crew; I
10516 have seen and talked with Steelkilt since the death of Radney.’”
10517 
10518 
10519 CHAPTER 55. Of the Monstrous Pictures of Whales.
10520 
10521 I shall ere long paint to you as well as one can without canvas,
10522 something like the true form of the whale as he actually appears to the
10523 eye of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the whale is moored
10524 alongside the whale-ship so that he can be fairly stepped upon there.
10525 It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert to those curious
10526 imaginary portraits of him which even down to the present day
10527 confidently challenge the faith of the landsman. It is time to set the
10528 world right in this matter, by proving such pictures of the whale all
10529 wrong.
10530 
10531 It may be that the primal source of all those pictorial delusions will
10532 be found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian sculptures. For
10533 ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times when on the marble
10534 panellings of temples, the pedestals of statues, and on shields,
10535 medallions, cups, and coins, the dolphin was drawn in scales of
10536 chain-armor like Saladin’s, and a helmeted head like St. George’s; ever
10537 since then has something of the same sort of license prevailed, not
10538 only in most popular pictures of the whale, but in many scientific
10539 presentations of him.
10540 
10541 Now, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways purporting
10542 to be the whale’s, is to be found in the famous cavern-pagoda of
10543 Elephanta, in India. The Brahmins maintain that in the almost endless
10544 sculptures of that immemorial pagoda, all the trades and pursuits,
10545 every conceivable avocation of man, were prefigured ages before any of
10546 them actually came into being. No wonder then, that in some sort our
10547 noble profession of whaling should have been there shadowed forth. The
10548 Hindoo whale referred to, occurs in a separate department of the wall,
10549 depicting the incarnation of Vishnu in the form of leviathan, learnedly
10550 known as the Matse Avatar. But though this sculpture is half man and
10551 half whale, so as only to give the tail of the latter, yet that small
10552 section of him is all wrong. It looks more like the tapering tail of an
10553 anaconda, than the broad palms of the true whale’s majestic flukes.
10554 
10555 But go to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian
10556 painter’s portrait of this fish; for he succeeds no better than the
10557 antediluvian Hindoo. It is Guido’s picture of Perseus rescuing
10558 Andromeda from the sea-monster or whale. Where did Guido get the model
10559 of such a strange creature as that? Nor does Hogarth, in painting the
10560 same scene in his own “Perseus Descending,” make out one whit better.
10561 The huge corpulence of that Hogarthian monster undulates on the
10562 surface, scarcely drawing one inch of water. It has a sort of howdah on
10563 its back, and its distended tusked mouth into which the billows are
10564 rolling, might be taken for the Traitors’ Gate leading from the Thames
10565 by water into the Tower. Then, there are the Prodromus whales of old
10566 Scotch Sibbald, and Jonah’s whale, as depicted in the prints of old
10567 Bibles and the cuts of old primers. What shall be said of these? As for
10568 the book-binder’s whale winding like a vine-stalk round the stock of a
10569 descending anchor—as stamped and gilded on the backs and title-pages of
10570 many books both old and new—that is a very picturesque but purely
10571 fabulous creature, imitated, I take it, from the like figures on
10572 antique vases. Though universally denominated a dolphin, I nevertheless
10573 call this book-binder’s fish an attempt at a whale; because it was so
10574 intended when the device was first introduced. It was introduced by an
10575 old Italian publisher somewhere about the 15th century, during the
10576 Revival of Learning; and in those days, and even down to a
10577 comparatively late period, dolphins were popularly supposed to be a
10578 species of the Leviathan.
10579 
10580 In the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books you
10581 will at times meet with very curious touches at the whale, where all
10582 manner of spouts, jets d’eau, hot springs and cold, Saratoga and
10583 Baden-Baden, come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain. In the
10584 title-page of the original edition of the “Advancement of Learning” you
10585 will find some curious whales.
10586 
10587 But quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at those
10588 pictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific delineations,
10589 by those who know. In old Harris’s collection of voyages there are some
10590 plates of whales extracted from a Dutch book of voyages, A.D. 1671,
10591 entitled “A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in the ship Jonas in the
10592 Whale, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master.” In one of those plates the
10593 whales, like great rafts of logs, are represented lying among
10594 ice-isles, with white bears running over their living backs. In another
10595 plate, the prodigious blunder is made of representing the whale with
10596 perpendicular flukes.
10597 
10598 Then again, there is an imposing quarto, written by one Captain
10599 Colnett, a Post Captain in the English navy, entitled “A Voyage round
10600 Cape Horn into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending the
10601 Spermaceti Whale Fisheries.” In this book is an outline purporting to
10602 be a “Picture of a Physeter or Spermaceti whale, drawn by scale from
10603 one killed on the coast of Mexico, August, 1793, and hoisted on deck.”
10604 I doubt not the captain had this veracious picture taken for the
10605 benefit of his marines. To mention but one thing about it, let me say
10606 that it has an eye which applied, according to the accompanying scale,
10607 to a full grown sperm whale, would make the eye of that whale a
10608 bow-window some five feet long. Ah, my gallant captain, why did ye not
10609 give us Jonah looking out of that eye!
10610 
10611 Nor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History for the
10612 benefit of the young and tender, free from the same heinousness of
10613 mistake. Look at that popular work “Goldsmith’s Animated Nature.” In
10614 the abridged London edition of 1807, there are plates of an alleged
10615 “whale” and a “narwhale.” I do not wish to seem inelegant, but this
10616 unsightly whale looks much like an amputated sow; and, as for the
10617 narwhale, one glimpse at it is enough to amaze one, that in this
10618 nineteenth century such a hippogriff could be palmed for genuine upon
10619 any intelligent public of schoolboys.
10620 
10621 Then, again, in 1825, Bernard Germain, Count de Lacépède, a great
10622 naturalist, published a scientific systemized whale book, wherein are
10623 several pictures of the different species of the Leviathan. All these
10624 are not only incorrect, but the picture of the Mysticetus or Greenland
10625 whale (that is to say, the Right whale), even Scoresby, a long
10626 experienced man as touching that species, declares not to have its
10627 counterpart in nature.
10628 
10629 But the placing of the cap-sheaf to all this blundering business was
10630 reserved for the scientific Frederick Cuvier, brother to the famous
10631 Baron. In 1836, he published a Natural History of Whales, in which he
10632 gives what he calls a picture of the Sperm Whale. Before showing that
10633 picture to any Nantucketer, you had best provide for your summary
10634 retreat from Nantucket. In a word, Frederick Cuvier’s Sperm Whale is
10635 not a Sperm Whale, but a squash. Of course, he never had the benefit of
10636 a whaling voyage (such men seldom have), but whence he derived that
10637 picture, who can tell? Perhaps he got it as his scientific predecessor
10638 in the same field, Desmarest, got one of his authentic abortions; that
10639 is, from a Chinese drawing. And what sort of lively lads with the
10640 pencil those Chinese are, many queer cups and saucers inform us.
10641 
10642 As for the sign-painters’ whales seen in the streets hanging over the
10643 shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them? They are generally
10644 Richard III. whales, with dromedary humps, and very savage;
10645 breakfasting on three or four sailor tarts, that is whaleboats full of
10646 mariners: their deformities floundering in seas of blood and blue
10647 paint.
10648 
10649 But these manifold mistakes in depicting the whale are not so very
10650 surprising after all. Consider! Most of the scientific drawings have
10651 been taken from the stranded fish; and these are about as correct as a
10652 drawing of a wrecked ship, with broken back, would correctly represent
10653 the noble animal itself in all its undashed pride of hull and spars.
10654 Though elephants have stood for their full-lengths, the living
10655 Leviathan has never yet fairly floated himself for his portrait. The
10656 living whale, in his full majesty and significance, is only to be seen
10657 at sea in unfathomable waters; and afloat the vast bulk of him is out
10658 of sight, like a launched line-of-battle ship; and out of that element
10659 it is a thing eternally impossible for mortal man to hoist him bodily
10660 into the air, so as to preserve all his mighty swells and undulations.
10661 And, not to speak of the highly presumable difference of contour
10662 between a young sucking whale and a full-grown Platonian Leviathan;
10663 yet, even in the case of one of those young sucking whales hoisted to a
10664 ship’s deck, such is then the outlandish, eel-like, limbered, varying
10665 shape of him, that his precise expression the devil himself could not
10666 catch.
10667 
10668 But it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded
10669 whale, accurate hints may be derived touching his true form. Not at
10670 all. For it is one of the more curious things about this Leviathan,
10671 that his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape. Though
10672 Jeremy Bentham’s skeleton, which hangs for candelabra in the library of
10673 one of his executors, correctly conveys the idea of a burly-browed
10674 utilitarian old gentleman, with all Jeremy’s other leading personal
10675 characteristics; yet nothing of this kind could be inferred from any
10676 leviathan’s articulated bones. In fact, as the great Hunter says, the
10677 mere skeleton of the whale bears the same relation to the fully
10678 invested and padded animal as the insect does to the chrysalis that so
10679 roundingly envelopes it. This peculiarity is strikingly evinced in the
10680 head, as in some part of this book will be incidentally shown. It is
10681 also very curiously displayed in the side fin, the bones of which
10682 almost exactly answer to the bones of the human hand, minus only the
10683 thumb. This fin has four regular bone-fingers, the index, middle, ring,
10684 and little finger. But all these are permanently lodged in their fleshy
10685 covering, as the human fingers in an artificial covering. “However
10686 recklessly the whale may sometimes serve us,” said humorous Stubb one
10687 day, “he can never be truly said to handle us without mittens.”
10688 
10689 For all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it, you must needs
10690 conclude that the great Leviathan is that one creature in the world
10691 which must remain unpainted to the last. True, one portrait may hit the
10692 mark much nearer than another, but none can hit it with any very
10693 considerable degree of exactness. So there is no earthly way of finding
10694 out precisely what the whale really looks like. And the only mode in
10695 which you can derive even a tolerable idea of his living contour, is by
10696 going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you run no small risk of
10697 being eternally stove and sunk by him. Wherefore, it seems to me you
10698 had best not be too fastidious in your curiosity touching this
10699 Leviathan.
10700 
10701 
10702 CHAPTER 56. Of the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales, and the True
10703 Pictures of Whaling Scenes.
10704 
10705 In connexion with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly
10706 tempted here to enter upon those still more monstrous stories of them
10707 which are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,
10708 especially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, etc. But I pass
10709 that matter by.
10710 
10711 I know of only four published outlines of the great Sperm Whale;
10712 Colnett’s, Huggins’s, Frederick Cuvier’s, and Beale’s. In the previous
10713 chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to. Huggins’s is far
10714 better than theirs; but, by great odds, Beale’s is the best. All
10715 Beale’s drawings of this whale are good, excepting the middle figure in
10716 the picture of three whales in various attitudes, capping his second
10717 chapter. His frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales, though no
10718 doubt calculated to excite the civil scepticism of some parlor men, is
10719 admirably correct and life-like in its general effect. Some of the
10720 Sperm Whale drawings in J. Ross Browne are pretty correct in contour;
10721 but they are wretchedly engraved. That is not his fault though.
10722 
10723 Of the Right Whale, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby; but they
10724 are drawn on too small a scale to convey a desirable impression. He has
