10725 but one picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad deficiency,
10726 because it is by such pictures only, when at all well done, that you
10727 can derive anything like a truthful idea of the living whale as seen by
10728 his living hunters.
10729 
10730 But, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in some details
10731 not the most correct, presentations of whales and whaling scenes to be
10732 anywhere found, are two large French engravings, well executed, and
10733 taken from paintings by one Garnery. Respectively, they represent
10734 attacks on the Sperm and Right Whale. In the first engraving a noble
10735 Sperm Whale is depicted in full majesty of might, just risen beneath
10736 the boat from the profundities of the ocean, and bearing high in the
10737 air upon his back the terrific wreck of the stoven planks. The prow of
10738 the boat is partially unbroken, and is drawn just balancing upon the
10739 monster’s spine; and standing in that prow, for that one single
10740 incomputable flash of time, you behold an oarsman, half shrouded by the
10741 incensed boiling spout of the whale, and in the act of leaping, as if
10742 from a precipice. The action of the whole thing is wonderfully good and
10743 true. The half-emptied line-tub floats on the whitened sea; the wooden
10744 poles of the spilled harpoons obliquely bob in it; the heads of the
10745 swimming crew are scattered about the whale in contrasting expressions
10746 of affright; while in the black stormy distance the ship is bearing
10747 down upon the scene. Serious fault might be found with the anatomical
10748 details of this whale, but let that pass; since, for the life of me, I
10749 could not draw so good a one.
10750 
10751 In the second engraving, the boat is in the act of drawing alongside
10752 the barnacled flank of a large running Right Whale, that rolls his
10753 black weedy bulk in the sea like some mossy rock-slide from the
10754 Patagonian cliffs. His jets are erect, full, and black like soot; so
10755 that from so abounding a smoke in the chimney, you would think there
10756 must be a brave supper cooking in the great bowels below. Sea fowls are
10757 pecking at the small crabs, shell-fish, and other sea candies and
10758 maccaroni, which the Right Whale sometimes carries on his pestilent
10759 back. And all the while the thick-lipped leviathan is rushing through
10760 the deep, leaving tons of tumultuous white curds in his wake, and
10761 causing the slight boat to rock in the swells like a skiff caught nigh
10762 the paddle-wheels of an ocean steamer. Thus, the foreground is all
10763 raging commotion; but behind, in admirable artistic contrast, is the
10764 glassy level of a sea becalmed, the drooping unstarched sails of the
10765 powerless ship, and the inert mass of a dead whale, a conquered
10766 fortress, with the flag of capture lazily hanging from the whale-pole
10767 inserted into his spout-hole.
10768 
10769 Who Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not. But my life for it he
10770 was either practically conversant with his subject, or else
10771 marvellously tutored by some experienced whaleman. The French are the
10772 lads for painting action. Go and gaze upon all the paintings of Europe,
10773 and where will you find such a gallery of living and breathing
10774 commotion on canvas, as in that triumphal hall at Versailles; where the
10775 beholder fights his way, pell-mell, through the consecutive great
10776 battles of France; where every sword seems a flash of the Northern
10777 Lights, and the successive armed kings and Emperors dash by, like a
10778 charge of crowned centaurs? Not wholly unworthy of a place in that
10779 gallery, are these sea battle-pieces of Garnery.
10780 
10781 The natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness of
10782 things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings and engravings
10783 they have of their whaling scenes. With not one tenth of England’s
10784 experience in the fishery, and not the thousandth part of that of the
10785 Americans, they have nevertheless furnished both nations with the only
10786 finished sketches at all capable of conveying the real spirit of the
10787 whale hunt. For the most part, the English and American whale
10788 draughtsmen seem entirely content with presenting the mechanical
10789 outline of things, such as the vacant profile of the whale; which, so
10790 far as picturesqueness of effect is concerned, is about tantamount to
10791 sketching the profile of a pyramid. Even Scoresby, the justly renowned
10792 Right whaleman, after giving us a stiff full length of the Greenland
10793 whale, and three or four delicate miniatures of narwhales and
10794 porpoises, treats us to a series of classical engravings of boat hooks,
10795 chopping knives, and grapnels; and with the microscopic diligence of a
10796 Leuwenhoeck submits to the inspection of a shivering world ninety-six
10797 fac-similes of magnified Arctic snow crystals. I mean no disparagement
10798 to the excellent voyager (I honor him for a veteran), but in so
10799 important a matter it was certainly an oversight not to have procured
10800 for every crystal a sworn affidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of
10801 the Peace.
10802 
10803 In addition to those fine engravings from Garnery, there are two other
10804 French engravings worthy of note, by some one who subscribes himself
10805 “H. Durand.” One of them, though not precisely adapted to our present
10806 purpose, nevertheless deserves mention on other accounts. It is a quiet
10807 noon-scene among the isles of the Pacific; a French whaler anchored,
10808 inshore, in a calm, and lazily taking water on board; the loosened
10809 sails of the ship, and the long leaves of the palms in the background,
10810 both drooping together in the breezeless air. The effect is very fine,
10811 when considered with reference to its presenting the hardy fishermen
10812 under one of their few aspects of oriental repose. The other engraving
10813 is quite a different affair: the ship hove-to upon the open sea, and in
10814 the very heart of the Leviathanic life, with a Right Whale alongside;
10815 the vessel (in the act of cutting-in) hove over to the monster as if to
10816 a quay; and a boat, hurriedly pushing off from this scene of activity,
10817 is about giving chase to whales in the distance. The harpoons and
10818 lances lie levelled for use; three oarsmen are just setting the mast in
10819 its hole; while from a sudden roll of the sea, the little craft stands
10820 half-erect out of the water, like a rearing horse. From the ship, the
10821 smoke of the torments of the boiling whale is going up like the smoke
10822 over a village of smithies; and to windward, a black cloud, rising up
10823 with earnest of squalls and rains, seems to quicken the activity of the
10824 excited seamen.
10825 
10826 
10827 CHAPTER 57. Of Whales in Paint; in Teeth; in Wood; in Sheet-Iron; in
10828 Stone; in Mountains; in Stars.
10829 
10830 On Tower-hill, as you go down to the London docks, you may have seen a
10831 crippled beggar (or _kedger_, as the sailors say) holding a painted
10832 board before him, representing the tragic scene in which he lost his
10833 leg. There are three whales and three boats; and one of the boats
10834 (presumed to contain the missing leg in all its original integrity) is
10835 being crunched by the jaws of the foremost whale. Any time these ten
10836 years, they tell me, has that man held up that picture, and exhibited
10837 that stump to an incredulous world. But the time of his justification
10838 has now come. His three whales are as good whales as were ever
10839 published in Wapping, at any rate; and his stump as unquestionable a
10840 stump as any you will find in the western clearings. But, though for
10841 ever mounted on that stump, never a stump-speech does the poor whaleman
10842 make; but, with downcast eyes, stands ruefully contemplating his own
10843 amputation.
10844 
10845 Throughout the Pacific, and also in Nantucket, and New Bedford, and Sag
10846 Harbor, you will come across lively sketches of whales and
10847 whaling-scenes, graven by the fishermen themselves on Sperm
10848 Whale-teeth, or ladies’ busks wrought out of the Right Whale-bone, and
10849 other like skrimshander articles, as the whalemen call the numerous
10850 little ingenious contrivances they elaborately carve out of the rough
10851 material, in their hours of ocean leisure. Some of them have little
10852 boxes of dentistical-looking implements, specially intended for the
10853 skrimshandering business. But, in general, they toil with their
10854 jack-knives alone; and, with that almost omnipotent tool of the sailor,
10855 they will turn you out anything you please, in the way of a mariner’s
10856 fancy.
10857 
10858 Long exile from Christendom and civilization inevitably restores a man
10859 to that condition in which God placed him, _i.e._ what is called
10860 savagery. Your true whale-hunter is as much a savage as an Iroquois. I
10861 myself am a savage, owning no allegiance but to the King of the
10862 Cannibals; and ready at any moment to rebel against him.
10863 
10864 Now, one of the peculiar characteristics of the savage in his domestic
10865 hours, is his wonderful patience of industry. An ancient Hawaiian
10866 war-club or spear-paddle, in its full multiplicity and elaboration of
10867 carving, is as great a trophy of human perseverance as a Latin lexicon.
10868 For, with but a bit of broken sea-shell or a shark’s tooth, that
10869 miraculous intricacy of wooden net-work has been achieved; and it has
10870 cost steady years of steady application.
10871 
10872 As with the Hawaiian savage, so with the white sailor-savage. With the
10873 same marvellous patience, and with the same single shark’s tooth, of
10874 his one poor jack-knife, he will carve you a bit of bone sculpture, not
10875 quite as workmanlike, but as close packed in its maziness of design, as
10876 the Greek savage, Achilles’s shield; and full of barbaric spirit and
10877 suggestiveness, as the prints of that fine old Dutch savage, Albert
10878 Durer.
10879 
10880 Wooden whales, or whales cut in profile out of the small dark slabs of
10881 the noble South Sea war-wood, are frequently met with in the
10882 forecastles of American whalers. Some of them are done with much
10883 accuracy.
10884 
10885 At some old gable-roofed country houses you will see brass whales hung
10886 by the tail for knockers to the road-side door. When the porter is
10887 sleepy, the anvil-headed whale would be best. But these knocking whales
10888 are seldom remarkable as faithful essays. On the spires of some
10889 old-fashioned churches you will see sheet-iron whales placed there for
10890 weather-cocks; but they are so elevated, and besides that are to all
10891 intents and purposes so labelled with “_Hands off!_” you cannot examine
10892 them closely enough to decide upon their merit.
10893 
10894 In bony, ribby regions of the earth, where at the base of high broken
10895 cliffs masses of rock lie strewn in fantastic groupings upon the plain,
10896 you will often discover images as of the petrified forms of the
10897 Leviathan partly merged in grass, which of a windy day breaks against
10898 them in a surf of green surges.
10899 
10900 Then, again, in mountainous countries where the traveller is
10901 continually girdled by amphitheatrical heights; here and there from
10902 some lucky point of view you will catch passing glimpses of the
10903 profiles of whales defined along the undulating ridges. But you must be
10904 a thorough whaleman, to see these sights; and not only that, but if you
10905 wish to return to such a sight again, you must be sure and take the
10906 exact intersecting latitude and longitude of your first stand-point,
10907 else so chance-like are such observations of the hills, that your
10908 precise, previous stand-point would require a laborious re-discovery;
10909 like the Soloma Islands, which still remain incognita, though once
10910 high-ruffed Mendanna trod them and old Figuera chronicled them.
10911 
10912 Nor when expandingly lifted by your subject, can you fail to trace out
10913 great whales in the starry heavens, and boats in pursuit of them; as
10914 when long filled with thoughts of war the Eastern nations saw armies
10915 locked in battle among the clouds. Thus at the North have I chased
10916 Leviathan round and round the Pole with the revolutions of the bright
10917 points that first defined him to me. And beneath the effulgent
10918 Antarctic skies I have boarded the Argo-Navis, and joined the chase
10919 against the starry Cetus far beyond the utmost stretch of Hydrus and
10920 the Flying Fish.
10921 
10922 With a frigate’s anchors for my bridle-bitts and fasces of harpoons for
10923 spurs, would I could mount that whale and leap the topmost skies, to
10924 see whether the fabled heavens with all their countless tents really
10925 lie encamped beyond my mortal sight!
10926 
10927 
10928 CHAPTER 58. Brit.
10929 
10930 Steering north-eastward from the Crozetts, we fell in with vast meadows
10931 of brit, the minute, yellow substance, upon which the Right Whale
10932 largely feeds. For leagues and leagues it undulated round us, so that
10933 we seemed to be sailing through boundless fields of ripe and golden
10934 wheat.
10935 
10936 On the second day, numbers of Right Whales were seen, who, secure from
10937 the attack of a Sperm Whaler like the Pequod, with open jaws sluggishly
10938 swam through the brit, which, adhering to the fringing fibres of that
10939 wondrous Venetian blind in their mouths, was in that manner separated
10940 from the water that escaped at the lip.
10941 
10942 As morning mowers, who side by side slowly and seethingly advance their
10943 scythes through the long wet grass of marshy meads; even so these
10944 monsters swam, making a strange, grassy, cutting sound; and leaving
10945 behind them endless swaths of blue upon the yellow sea.*
10946 
10947 *That part of the sea known among whalemen as the “Brazil Banks” does
10948 not bear that name as the Banks of Newfoundland do, because of there
10949 being shallows and soundings there, but because of this remarkable
10950 meadow-like appearance, caused by the vast drifts of brit continually
10951 floating in those latitudes, where the Right Whale is often chased.
10952 
10953 But it was only the sound they made as they parted the brit which at
10954 all reminded one of mowers. Seen from the mast-heads, especially when
10955 they paused and were stationary for a while, their vast black forms
10956 looked more like lifeless masses of rock than anything else. And as in
10957 the great hunting countries of India, the stranger at a distance will
10958 sometimes pass on the plains recumbent elephants without knowing them
10959 to be such, taking them for bare, blackened elevations of the soil;
10960 even so, often, with him, who for the first time beholds this species
10961 of the leviathans of the sea. And even when recognised at last, their
10962 immense magnitude renders it very hard really to believe that such
10963 bulky masses of overgrowth can possibly be instinct, in all parts, with
10964 the same sort of life that lives in a dog or a horse.
10965 
10966 Indeed, in other respects, you can hardly regard any creatures of the
10967 deep with the same feelings that you do those of the shore. For though
10968 some old naturalists have maintained that all creatures of the land are
10969 of their kind in the sea; and though taking a broad general view of the
10970 thing, this may very well be; yet coming to specialties, where, for
10971 example, does the ocean furnish any fish that in disposition answers to
10972 the sagacious kindness of the dog? The accursed shark alone can in any
10973 generic respect be said to bear comparative analogy to him.
10974 
10975 But though, to landsmen in general, the native inhabitants of the seas
10976 have ever been regarded with emotions unspeakably unsocial and
10977 repelling; though we know the sea to be an everlasting terra incognita,
10978 so that Columbus sailed over numberless unknown worlds to discover his
10979 one superficial western one; though, by vast odds, the most terrific of
10980 all mortal disasters have immemorially and indiscriminately befallen
10981 tens and hundreds of thousands of those who have gone upon the waters;
10982 though but a moment’s consideration will teach, that however baby man
10983 may brag of his science and skill, and however much, in a flattering
10984 future, that science and skill may augment; yet for ever and for ever,
10985 to the crack of doom, the sea will insult and murder him, and pulverize
10986 the stateliest, stiffest frigate he can make; nevertheless, by the
10987 continual repetition of these very impressions, man has lost that sense
10988 of the full awfulness of the sea which aboriginally belongs to it.
10989 
10990 The first boat we read of, floated on an ocean, that with Portuguese
10991 vengeance had whelmed a whole world without leaving so much as a widow.
10992 That same ocean rolls now; that same ocean destroyed the wrecked ships
10993 of last year. Yea, foolish mortals, Noah’s flood is not yet subsided;
10994 two thirds of the fair world it yet covers.
10995 
10996 Wherein differ the sea and the land, that a miracle upon one is not a
10997 miracle upon the other? Preternatural terrors rested upon the Hebrews,
10998 when under the feet of Korah and his company the live ground opened and
10999 swallowed them up for ever; yet not a modern sun ever sets, but in
11000 precisely the same manner the live sea swallows up ships and crews.
11001 
11002 But not only is the sea such a foe to man who is an alien to it, but it
11003 is also a fiend to its own off-spring; worse than the Persian host who
11004 murdered his own guests; sparing not the creatures which itself hath
11005 spawned. Like a savage tigress that tossing in the jungle overlays her
11006 own cubs, so the sea dashes even the mightiest whales against the
11007 rocks, and leaves them there side by side with the split wrecks of
11008 ships. No mercy, no power but its own controls it. Panting and snorting
11009 like a mad battle steed that has lost its rider, the masterless ocean
11010 overruns the globe.
11011 
11012 Consider the subtleness of the sea; how its most dreaded creatures
11013 glide under water, unapparent for the most part, and treacherously
11014 hidden beneath the loveliest tints of azure. Consider also the devilish
11015 brilliance and beauty of many of its most remorseless tribes, as the
11016 dainty embellished shape of many species of sharks. Consider, once
11017 more, the universal cannibalism of the sea; all whose creatures prey
11018 upon each other, carrying on eternal war since the world began.
11019 
11020 Consider all this; and then turn to this green, gentle, and most docile
11021 earth; consider them both, the sea and the land; and do you not find a
11022 strange analogy to something in yourself? For as this appalling ocean
11023 surrounds the verdant land, so in the soul of man there lies one
11024 insular Tahiti, full of peace and joy, but encompassed by all the
11025 horrors of the half known life. God keep thee! Push not off from that
11026 isle, thou canst never return!
11027 
11028 
11029 CHAPTER 59. Squid.
11030 
11031 Slowly wading through the meadows of brit, the Pequod still held on her
11032 way north-eastward towards the island of Java; a gentle air impelling
11033 her keel, so that in the surrounding serenity her three tall tapering
11034 masts mildly waved to that languid breeze, as three mild palms on a
11035 plain. And still, at wide intervals in the silvery night, the lonely,
11036 alluring jet would be seen.
11037 
11038 But one transparent blue morning, when a stillness almost preternatural
11039 spread over the sea, however unattended with any stagnant calm; when
11040 the long burnished sun-glade on the waters seemed a golden finger laid
11041 across them, enjoining some secrecy; when the slippered waves whispered
11042 together as they softly ran on; in this profound hush of the visible
11043 sphere a strange spectre was seen by Daggoo from the main-mast-head.
11044 
11045 In the distance, a great white mass lazily rose, and rising higher and
11046 higher, and disentangling itself from the azure, at last gleamed before
11047 our prow like a snow-slide, new slid from the hills. Thus glistening
11048 for a moment, as slowly it subsided, and sank. Then once more arose,
11049 and silently gleamed. It seemed not a whale; and yet is this Moby Dick?
11050 thought Daggoo. Again the phantom went down, but on re-appearing once
11051 more, with a stiletto-like cry that startled every man from his nod,
11052 the negro yelled out—“There! there again! there she breaches! right
11053 ahead! The White Whale, the White Whale!”
11054 
11055 Upon this, the seamen rushed to the yard-arms, as in swarming-time the
11056 bees rush to the boughs. Bare-headed in the sultry sun, Ahab stood on
11057 the bowsprit, and with one hand pushed far behind in readiness to wave
11058 his orders to the helmsman, cast his eager glance in the direction
11059 indicated aloft by the outstretched motionless arm of Daggoo.
11060 
11061 Whether the flitting attendance of the one still and solitary jet had
11062 gradually worked upon Ahab, so that he was now prepared to connect the
11063 ideas of mildness and repose with the first sight of the particular
11064 whale he pursued; however this was, or whether his eagerness betrayed
11065 him; whichever way it might have been, no sooner did he distinctly
11066 perceive the white mass, than with a quick intensity he instantly gave
11067 orders for lowering.
11068 
11069 The four boats were soon on the water; Ahab’s in advance, and all
11070 swiftly pulling towards their prey. Soon it went down, and while, with
11071 oars suspended, we were awaiting its reappearance, lo! in the same spot
11072 where it sank, once more it slowly rose. Almost forgetting for the
11073 moment all thoughts of Moby Dick, we now gazed at the most wondrous
11074 phenomenon which the secret seas have hitherto revealed to mankind. A
11075 vast pulpy mass, furlongs in length and breadth, of a glancing
11076 cream-colour, lay floating on the water, innumerable long arms
11077 radiating from its centre, and curling and twisting like a nest of
11078 anacondas, as if blindly to clutch at any hapless object within reach.
11079 No perceptible face or front did it have; no conceivable token of
11080 either sensation or instinct; but undulated there on the billows, an
11081 unearthly, formless, chance-like apparition of life.
11082 
11083 As with a low sucking sound it slowly disappeared again, Starbuck still
11084 gazing at the agitated waters where it had sunk, with a wild voice
11085 exclaimed—“Almost rather had I seen Moby Dick and fought him, than to
11086 have seen thee, thou white ghost!”
11087 
11088 “What was it, Sir?” said Flask.
11089 
11090 “The great live squid, which, they say, few whale-ships ever beheld,
11091 and returned to their ports to tell of it.”
11092 
11093 But Ahab said nothing; turning his boat, he sailed back to the vessel;
11094 the rest as silently following.
11095 
11096 Whatever superstitions the sperm whalemen in general have connected
11097 with the sight of this object, certain it is, that a glimpse of it
11098 being so very unusual, that circumstance has gone far to invest it with
11099 portentousness. So rarely is it beheld, that though one and all of them
11100 declare it to be the largest animated thing in the ocean, yet very few
11101 of them have any but the most vague ideas concerning its true nature
11102 and form; notwithstanding, they believe it to furnish to the sperm
11103 whale his only food. For though other species of whales find their food
11104 above water, and may be seen by man in the act of feeding, the
11105 spermaceti whale obtains his whole food in unknown zones below the
11106 surface; and only by inference is it that any one can tell of what,
11107 precisely, that food consists. At times, when closely pursued, he will
11108 disgorge what are supposed to be the detached arms of the squid; some
11109 of them thus exhibited exceeding twenty and thirty feet in length. They
11110 fancy that the monster to which these arms belonged ordinarily clings
11111 by them to the bed of the ocean; and that the sperm whale, unlike other
11112 species, is supplied with teeth in order to attack and tear it.
11113 
11114 There seems some ground to imagine that the great Kraken of Bishop
11115 Pontoppodan may ultimately resolve itself into Squid. The manner in
11116 which the Bishop describes it, as alternately rising and sinking, with
11117 some other particulars he narrates, in all this the two correspond. But
11118 much abatement is necessary with respect to the incredible bulk he
11119 assigns it.
11120 
11121 By some naturalists who have vaguely heard rumors of the mysterious
11122 creature, here spoken of, it is included among the class of
11123 cuttle-fish, to which, indeed, in certain external respects it would
11124 seem to belong, but only as the Anak of the tribe.
11125 
11126 
11127 CHAPTER 60. The Line.
11128 
11129 With reference to the whaling scene shortly to be described, as well as
11130 for the better understanding of all similar scenes elsewhere presented,
11131 I have here to speak of the magical, sometimes horrible whale-line.
11132 
11133 The line originally used in the fishery was of the best hemp, slightly
11134 vapored with tar, not impregnated with it, as in the case of ordinary
11135 ropes; for while tar, as ordinarily used, makes the hemp more pliable
11136 to the rope-maker, and also renders the rope itself more convenient to
11137 the sailor for common ship use; yet, not only would the ordinary
11138 quantity too much stiffen the whale-line for the close coiling to which
11139 it must be subjected; but as most seamen are beginning to learn, tar in
11140 general by no means adds to the rope’s durability or strength, however
11141 much it may give it compactness and gloss.
11142 
11143 Of late years the Manilla rope has in the American fishery almost
11144 entirely superseded hemp as a material for whale-lines; for, though not
11145 so durable as hemp, it is stronger, and far more soft and elastic; and
11146 I will add (since there is an æsthetics in all things), is much more
11147 handsome and becoming to the boat, than hemp. Hemp is a dusky, dark
11148 fellow, a sort of Indian; but Manilla is as a golden-haired Circassian
11149 to behold.
11150 
11151 The whale-line is only two-thirds of an inch in thickness. At first
11152 sight, you would not think it so strong as it really is. By experiment
11153 its one and fifty yarns will each suspend a weight of one hundred and
11154 twenty pounds; so that the whole rope will bear a strain nearly equal
11155 to three tons. In length, the common sperm whale-line measures
11156 something over two hundred fathoms. Towards the stern of the boat it is
11157 spirally coiled away in the tub, not like the worm-pipe of a still
11158 though, but so as to form one round, cheese-shaped mass of densely
11159 bedded “sheaves,” or layers of concentric spiralizations, without any
11160 hollow but the “heart,” or minute vertical tube formed at the axis of
11161 the cheese. As the least tangle or kink in the coiling would, in
11162 running out, infallibly take somebody’s arm, leg, or entire body off,
11163 the utmost precaution is used in stowing the line in its tub. Some
11164 harpooneers will consume almost an entire morning in this business,
11165 carrying the line high aloft and then reeving it downwards through a
11166 block towards the tub, so as in the act of coiling to free it from all
11167 possible wrinkles and twists.
11168 
11169 In the English boats two tubs are used instead of one; the same line
11170 being continuously coiled in both tubs. There is some advantage in
11171 this; because these twin-tubs being so small they fit more readily into
11172 the boat, and do not strain it so much; whereas, the American tub,
11173 nearly three feet in diameter and of proportionate depth, makes a
11174 rather bulky freight for a craft whose planks are but one half-inch in
11175 thickness; for the bottom of the whale-boat is like critical ice, which
11176 will bear up a considerable distributed weight, but not very much of a
11177 concentrated one. When the painted canvas cover is clapped on the
11178 American line-tub, the boat looks as if it were pulling off with a
11179 prodigious great wedding-cake to present to the whales.
11180 
11181 Both ends of the line are exposed; the lower end terminating in an
11182 eye-splice or loop coming up from the bottom against the side of the
11183 tub, and hanging over its edge completely disengaged from everything.
11184 This arrangement of the lower end is necessary on two accounts. First:
11185 In order to facilitate the fastening to it of an additional line from a
11186 neighboring boat, in case the stricken whale should sound so deep as to
11187 threaten to carry off the entire line originally attached to the
11188 harpoon. In these instances, the whale of course is shifted like a mug
11189 of ale, as it were, from the one boat to the other; though the first
11190 boat always hovers at hand to assist its consort. Second: This
11191 arrangement is indispensable for common safety’s sake; for were the
11192 lower end of the line in any way attached to the boat, and were the
11193 whale then to run the line out to the end almost in a single, smoking
11194 minute as he sometimes does, he would not stop there, for the doomed
11195 boat would infallibly be dragged down after him into the profundity of
11196 the sea; and in that case no town-crier would ever find her again.
11197 
11198 Before lowering the boat for the chase, the upper end of the line is
11199 taken aft from the tub, and passing round the loggerhead there, is
11200 again carried forward the entire length of the boat, resting crosswise
11201 upon the loom or handle of every man’s oar, so that it jogs against his
11202 wrist in rowing; and also passing between the men, as they alternately
11203 sit at the opposite gunwales, to the leaded chocks or grooves in the
11204 extreme pointed prow of the boat, where a wooden pin or skewer the size
11205 of a common quill, prevents it from slipping out. From the chocks it
11206 hangs in a slight festoon over the bows, and is then passed inside the
11207 boat again; and some ten or twenty fathoms (called box-line) being
11208 coiled upon the box in the bows, it continues its way to the gunwale
11209 still a little further aft, and is then attached to the short-warp—the
11210 rope which is immediately connected with the harpoon; but previous to
11211 that connexion, the short-warp goes through sundry mystifications too
11212 tedious to detail.
11213 
11214 Thus the whale-line folds the whole boat in its complicated coils,
11215 twisting and writhing around it in almost every direction. All the
11216 oarsmen are involved in its perilous contortions; so that to the timid
11217 eye of the landsman, they seem as Indian jugglers, with the deadliest
11218 snakes sportively festooning their limbs. Nor can any son of mortal
11219 woman, for the first time, seat himself amid those hempen intricacies,
11220 and while straining his utmost at the oar, bethink him that at any
11221 unknown instant the harpoon may be darted, and all these horrible
11222 contortions be put in play like ringed lightnings; he cannot be thus
11223 circumstanced without a shudder that makes the very marrow in his bones
11224 to quiver in him like a shaken jelly. Yet habit—strange thing! what
11225 cannot habit accomplish?—Gayer sallies, more merry mirth, better jokes,
11226 and brighter repartees, you never heard over your mahogany, than you
11227 will hear over the half-inch white cedar of the whale-boat, when thus
11228 hung in hangman’s nooses; and, like the six burghers of Calais before
11229 King Edward, the six men composing the crew pull into the jaws of
11230 death, with a halter around every neck, as you may say.
11231 
11232 Perhaps a very little thought will now enable you to account for those
11233 repeated whaling disasters—some few of which are casually chronicled—of
11234 this man or that man being taken out of the boat by the line, and lost.
11235 For, when the line is darting out, to be seated then in the boat, is
11236 like being seated in the midst of the manifold whizzings of a
11237 steam-engine in full play, when every flying beam, and shaft, and
11238 wheel, is grazing you. It is worse; for you cannot sit motionless in
11239 the heart of these perils, because the boat is rocking like a cradle,
11240 and you are pitched one way and the other, without the slightest
11241 warning; and only by a certain self-adjusting buoyancy and
11242 simultaneousness of volition and action, can you escape being made a
11243 Mazeppa of, and run away with where the all-seeing sun himself could
11244 never pierce you out.
11245 
11246 Again: as the profound calm which only apparently precedes and
11247 prophesies of the storm, is perhaps more awful than the storm itself;
11248 for, indeed, the calm is but the wrapper and envelope of the storm; and
11249 contains it in itself, as the seemingly harmless rifle holds the fatal
11250 powder, and the ball, and the explosion; so the graceful repose of the
11251 line, as it silently serpentines about the oarsmen before being brought
11252 into actual play—this is a thing which carries more of true terror than
11253 any other aspect of this dangerous affair. But why say more? All men
11254 live enveloped in whale-lines. All are born with halters round their
11255 necks; but it is only when caught in the swift, sudden turn of death,
11256 that mortals realize the silent, subtle, ever-present perils of life.
11257 And if you be a philosopher, though seated in the whale-boat, you would
11258 not at heart feel one whit more of terror, than though seated before
11259 your evening fire with a poker, and not a harpoon, by your side.
11260 
11261 
11262 CHAPTER 61. Stubb Kills a Whale.
11263 
11264 If to Starbuck the apparition of the Squid was a thing of portents, to
11265 Queequeg it was quite a different object.
11266 
11267 “When you see him ’quid,” said the savage, honing his harpoon in the
11268 bow of his hoisted boat, “then you quick see him ’parm whale.”
11269 
11270 The next day was exceedingly still and sultry, and with nothing special
11271 to engage them, the Pequod’s crew could hardly resist the spell of
11272 sleep induced by such a vacant sea. For this part of the Indian Ocean
11273 through which we then were voyaging is not what whalemen call a lively
11274 ground; that is, it affords fewer glimpses of porpoises, dolphins,
11275 flying-fish, and other vivacious denizens of more stirring waters, than
11276 those off the Rio de la Plata, or the in-shore ground off Peru.
11277 
11278 It was my turn to stand at the foremast-head; and with my shoulders
11279 leaning against the slackened royal shrouds, to and fro I idly swayed
11280 in what seemed an enchanted air. No resolution could withstand it; in
11281 that dreamy mood losing all consciousness, at last my soul went out of
11282 my body; though my body still continued to sway as a pendulum will,
11283 long after the power which first moved it is withdrawn.
11284 
11285 Ere forgetfulness altogether came over me, I had noticed that the
11286 seamen at the main and mizzen-mast-heads were already drowsy. So that
11287 at last all three of us lifelessly swung from the spars, and for every
11288 swing that we made there was a nod from below from the slumbering
11289 helmsman. The waves, too, nodded their indolent crests; and across the
11290 wide trance of the sea, east nodded to west, and the sun over all.
11291 
11292 Suddenly bubbles seemed bursting beneath my closed eyes; like vices my
11293 hands grasped the shrouds; some invisible, gracious agency preserved
11294 me; with a shock I came back to life. And lo! close under our lee, not
11295 forty fathoms off, a gigantic Sperm Whale lay rolling in the water like
11296 the capsized hull of a frigate, his broad, glossy back, of an Ethiopian
11297 hue, glistening in the sun’s rays like a mirror. But lazily undulating
11298 in the trough of the sea, and ever and anon tranquilly spouting his
11299 vapory jet, the whale looked like a portly burgher smoking his pipe of
11300 a warm afternoon. But that pipe, poor whale, was thy last. As if struck
11301 by some enchanter’s wand, the sleepy ship and every sleeper in it all
11302 at once started into wakefulness; and more than a score of voices from
11303 all parts of the vessel, simultaneously with the three notes from
11304 aloft, shouted forth the accustomed cry, as the great fish slowly and
11305 regularly spouted the sparkling brine into the air.
11306 
11307 “Clear away the boats! Luff!” cried Ahab. And obeying his own order, he
11308 dashed the helm down before the helmsman could handle the spokes.
11309 
11310 The sudden exclamations of the crew must have alarmed the whale; and
11311 ere the boats were down, majestically turning, he swam away to the
11312 leeward, but with such a steady tranquillity, and making so few ripples
11313 as he swam, that thinking after all he might not as yet be alarmed,
11314 Ahab gave orders that not an oar should be used, and no man must speak
11315 but in whispers. So seated like Ontario Indians on the gunwales of the
11316 boats, we swiftly but silently paddled along; the calm not admitting of
11317 the noiseless sails being set. Presently, as we thus glided in chase,
11318 the monster perpendicularly flitted his tail forty feet into the air,
11319 and then sank out of sight like a tower swallowed up.
11320 
11321 “There go flukes!” was the cry, an announcement immediately followed by
11322 Stubb’s producing his match and igniting his pipe, for now a respite
11323 was granted. After the full interval of his sounding had elapsed, the
11324 whale rose again, and being now in advance of the smoker’s boat, and
11325 much nearer to it than to any of the others, Stubb counted upon the
11326 honor of the capture. It was obvious, now, that the whale had at length
11327 become aware of his pursuers. All silence of cautiousness was therefore
11328 no longer of use. Paddles were dropped, and oars came loudly into play.
11329 And still puffing at his pipe, Stubb cheered on his crew to the
11330 assault.
11331 
11332 Yes, a mighty change had come over the fish. All alive to his jeopardy,
11333 he was going “head out”; that part obliquely projecting from the mad
11334 yeast which he brewed.*
11335 
11336 *It will be seen in some other place of what a very light substance the
11337 entire interior of the sperm whale’s enormous head consists. Though
11338 apparently the most massive, it is by far the most buoyant part about
11339 him. So that with ease he elevates it in the air, and invariably does
11340 so when going at his utmost speed. Besides, such is the breadth of the
11341 upper part of the front of his head, and such the tapering cut-water
11342 formation of the lower part, that by obliquely elevating his head, he
11343 thereby may be said to transform himself from a bluff-bowed sluggish
11344 galliot into a sharppointed New York pilot-boat.
11345 
11346 “Start her, start her, my men! Don’t hurry yourselves; take plenty of
11347 time—but start her; start her like thunder-claps, that’s all,” cried
11348 Stubb, spluttering out the smoke as he spoke. “Start her, now; give ’em
11349 the long and strong stroke, Tashtego. Start her, Tash, my boy—start
11350 her, all; but keep cool, keep cool—cucumbers is the word—easy,
11351 easy—only start her like grim death and grinning devils, and raise the
11352 buried dead perpendicular out of their graves, boys—that’s all. Start
11353 her!”
11354 
11355 “Woo-hoo! Wa-hee!” screamed the Gay-Header in reply, raising some old
11356 war-whoop to the skies; as every oarsman in the strained boat
11357 involuntarily bounced forward with the one tremendous leading stroke
11358 which the eager Indian gave.
11359 
11360 But his wild screams were answered by others quite as wild. “Kee-hee!
11361 Kee-hee!” yelled Daggoo, straining forwards and backwards on his seat,
11362 like a pacing tiger in his cage.
11363 
11364 “Ka-la! Koo-loo!” howled Queequeg, as if smacking his lips over a
11365 mouthful of Grenadier’s steak. And thus with oars and yells the keels
11366 cut the sea. Meanwhile, Stubb retaining his place in the van, still
11367 encouraged his men to the onset, all the while puffing the smoke from
11368 his mouth. Like desperadoes they tugged and they strained, till the
11369 welcome cry was heard—“Stand up, Tashtego!—give it to him!” The harpoon
11370 was hurled. “Stern all!” The oarsmen backed water; the same moment
11371 something went hot and hissing along every one of their wrists. It was
11372 the magical line. An instant before, Stubb had swiftly caught two
11373 additional turns with it round the loggerhead, whence, by reason of its
11374 increased rapid circlings, a hempen blue smoke now jetted up and
11375 mingled with the steady fumes from his pipe. As the line passed round
11376 and round the loggerhead; so also, just before reaching that point, it
11377 blisteringly passed through and through both of Stubb’s hands, from
11378 which the hand-cloths, or squares of quilted canvas sometimes worn at
11379 these times, had accidentally dropped. It was like holding an enemy’s
11380 sharp two-edged sword by the blade, and that enemy all the time
11381 striving to wrest it out of your clutch.
11382 
11383 “Wet the line! wet the line!” cried Stubb to the tub oarsman (him
11384 seated by the tub) who, snatching off his hat, dashed sea-water into
11385 it.* More turns were taken, so that the line began holding its place.
11386 The boat now flew through the boiling water like a shark all fins.
11387 Stubb and Tashtego here changed places—stem for stern—a staggering
11388 business truly in that rocking commotion.
11389 
11390 *Partly to show the indispensableness of this act, it may here be
11391 stated, that, in the old Dutch fishery, a mop was used to dash the
11392 running line with water; in many other ships, a wooden piggin, or
11393 bailer, is set apart for that purpose. Your hat, however, is the most
11394 convenient.
11395 
11396 From the vibrating line extending the entire length of the upper part
11397 of the boat, and from its now being more tight than a harpstring, you
11398 would have thought the craft had two keels—one cleaving the water, the
11399 other the air—as the boat churned on through both opposing elements at
11400 once. A continual cascade played at the bows; a ceaseless whirling eddy
11401 in her wake; and, at the slightest motion from within, even but of a
11402 little finger, the vibrating, cracking craft canted over her spasmodic
11403 gunwale into the sea. Thus they rushed; each man with might and main
11404 clinging to his seat, to prevent being tossed to the foam; and the tall
11405 form of Tashtego at the steering oar crouching almost double, in order
11406 to bring down his centre of gravity. Whole Atlantics and Pacifics
11407 seemed passed as they shot on their way, till at length the whale
11408 somewhat slackened his flight.
11409 
11410 “Haul in—haul in!” cried Stubb to the bowsman! and, facing round
11411 towards the whale, all hands began pulling the boat up to him, while
11412 yet the boat was being towed on. Soon ranging up by his flank, Stubb,
11413 firmly planting his knee in the clumsy cleat, darted dart after dart
11414 into the flying fish; at the word of command, the boat alternately
11415 sterning out of the way of the whale’s horrible wallow, and then
11416 ranging up for another fling.
11417 
11418 The red tide now poured from all sides of the monster like brooks down
11419 a hill. His tormented body rolled not in brine but in blood, which
11420 bubbled and seethed for furlongs behind in their wake. The slanting sun
11421 playing upon this crimson pond in the sea, sent back its reflection
11422 into every face, so that they all glowed to each other like red men.
11423 And all the while, jet after jet of white smoke was agonizingly shot
11424 from the spiracle of the whale, and vehement puff after puff from the
11425 mouth of the excited headsman; as at every dart, hauling in upon his
11426 crooked lance (by the line attached to it), Stubb straightened it again
11427 and again, by a few rapid blows against the gunwale, then again and
11428 again sent it into the whale.
11429 
11430 “Pull up—pull up!” he now cried to the bowsman, as the waning whale
11431 relaxed in his wrath. “Pull up!—close to!” and the boat ranged along
11432 the fish’s flank. When reaching far over the bow, Stubb slowly churned
11433 his long sharp lance into the fish, and kept it there, carefully
11434 churning and churning, as if cautiously seeking to feel after some gold
11435 watch that the whale might have swallowed, and which he was fearful of
11436 breaking ere he could hook it out. But that gold watch he sought was
11437 the innermost life of the fish. And now it is struck; for, starting
11438 from his trance into that unspeakable thing called his “flurry,” the
11439 monster horribly wallowed in his blood, overwrapped himself in
11440 impenetrable, mad, boiling spray, so that the imperilled craft,
11441 instantly dropping astern, had much ado blindly to struggle out from
11442 that phrensied twilight into the clear air of the day.
11443 
11444 And now abating in his flurry, the whale once more rolled out into
11445 view; surging from side to side; spasmodically dilating and contracting
11446 his spout-hole, with sharp, cracking, agonized respirations. At last,
11447 gush after gush of clotted red gore, as if it had been the purple lees
11448 of red wine, shot into the frighted air; and falling back again, ran
11449 dripping down his motionless flanks into the sea. His heart had burst!
11450 
11451 “He’s dead, Mr. Stubb,” said Daggoo.
11452 
11453 “Yes; both pipes smoked out!” and withdrawing his own from his mouth,
11454 Stubb scattered the dead ashes over the water; and, for a moment, stood
11455 thoughtfully eyeing the vast corpse he had made.
11456 
11457 
11458 CHAPTER 62. The Dart.
11459 
11460 A word concerning an incident in the last chapter.
11461 
11462 According to the invariable usage of the fishery, the whale-boat pushes
11463 off from the ship, with the headsman or whale-killer as temporary
11464 steersman, and the harpooneer or whale-fastener pulling the foremost
11465 oar, the one known as the harpooneer-oar. Now it needs a strong,
11466 nervous arm to strike the first iron into the fish; for often, in what
11467 is called a long dart, the heavy implement has to be flung to the
11468 distance of twenty or thirty feet. But however prolonged and exhausting
11469 the chase, the harpooneer is expected to pull his oar meanwhile to the
11470 uttermost; indeed, he is expected to set an example of superhuman
11471 activity to the rest, not only by incredible rowing, but by repeated
11472 loud and intrepid exclamations; and what it is to keep shouting at the
11473 top of one’s compass, while all the other muscles are strained and half
11474 started—what that is none know but those who have tried it. For one, I
11475 cannot bawl very heartily and work very recklessly at one and the same
11476 time. In this straining, bawling state, then, with his back to the
11477 fish, all at once the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting
11478 cry—“Stand up, and give it to him!” He now has to drop and secure his
11479 oar, turn round on his centre half way, seize his harpoon from the
11480 crotch, and with what little strength may remain, he essays to pitch it
11481 somehow into the whale. No wonder, taking the whole fleet of whalemen
11482 in a body, that out of fifty fair chances for a dart, not five are
11483 successful; no wonder that so many hapless harpooneers are madly cursed
11484 and disrated; no wonder that some of them actually burst their
11485 blood-vessels in the boat; no wonder that some sperm whalemen are
11486 absent four years with four barrels; no wonder that to many ship
11487 owners, whaling is but a losing concern; for it is the harpooneer that
11488 makes the voyage, and if you take the breath out of his body how can
11489 you expect to find it there when most wanted!
11490 
11491 Again, if the dart be successful, then at the second critical instant,
11492 that is, when the whale starts to run, the boatheader and harpooneer
11493 likewise start to running fore and aft, to the imminent jeopardy of
11494 themselves and every one else. It is then they change places; and the
11495 headsman, the chief officer of the little craft, takes his proper
11496 station in the bows of the boat.
11497 
11498 Now, I care not who maintains the contrary, but all this is both
11499 foolish and unnecessary. The headsman should stay in the bows from
11500 first to last; he should both dart the harpoon and the lance, and no
11501 rowing whatever should be expected of him, except under circumstances
11502 obvious to any fisherman. I know that this would sometimes involve a
11503 slight loss of speed in the chase; but long experience in various
11504 whalemen of more than one nation has convinced me that in the vast
11505 majority of failures in the fishery, it has not by any means been so
11506 much the speed of the whale as the before described exhaustion of the
11507 harpooneer that has caused them.
11508 
11509 To insure the greatest efficiency in the dart, the harpooneers of this
11510 world must start to their feet from out of idleness, and not from out
11511 of toil.
11512 
11513 
11514 CHAPTER 63. The Crotch.
11515 
11516 Out of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs. So, in
11517 productive subjects, grow the chapters.
11518 
11519 The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent mention.
11520 It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet in length,
11521 which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale near the
11522 bow, for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden extremity of
11523 the harpoon, whose other naked, barbed end slopingly projects from the
11524 prow. Thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to its hurler, who
11525 snatches it up as readily from its rest as a backwoodsman swings his
11526 rifle from the wall. It is customary to have two harpoons reposing in
11527 the crotch, respectively called the first and second irons.
11528 
11529 But these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with
11530 the line; the object being this: to dart them both, if possible, one
11531 instantly after the other into the same whale; so that if, in the
11532 coming drag, one should draw out, the other may still retain a hold. It
11533 is a doubling of the chances. But it very often happens that owing to
11534 the instantaneous, violent, convulsive running of the whale upon
11535 receiving the first iron, it becomes impossible for the harpooneer,
11536 however lightning-like in his movements, to pitch the second iron into
11537 him. Nevertheless, as the second iron is already connected with the
11538 line, and the line is running, hence that weapon must, at all events,
11539 be anticipatingly tossed out of the boat, somehow and somewhere; else
11540 the most terrible jeopardy would involve all hands. Tumbled into the
11541 water, it accordingly is in such cases; the spare coils of box line
11542 (mentioned in a preceding chapter) making this feat, in most instances,
11543 prudently practicable. But this critical act is not always unattended
11544 with the saddest and most fatal casualties.
11545 
11546 Furthermore: you must know that when the second iron is thrown
11547 overboard, it thenceforth becomes a dangling, sharp-edged terror,
11548 skittishly curvetting about both boat and whale, entangling the lines,
11549 or cutting them, and making a prodigious sensation in all directions.
11550 Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until the whale is
11551 fairly captured and a corpse.
11552 
11553 Consider, now, how it must be in the case of four boats all engaging
11554 one unusually strong, active, and knowing whale; when owing to these
11555 qualities in him, as well as to the thousand concurring accidents of
11556 such an audacious enterprise, eight or ten loose second irons may be
11557 simultaneously dangling about him. For, of course, each boat is
11558 supplied with several harpoons to bend on to the line should the first
11559 one be ineffectually darted without recovery. All these particulars are
11560 faithfully narrated here, as they will not fail to elucidate several
11561 most important, however intricate passages, in scenes hereafter to be
11562 painted.
11563 
11564 
11565 CHAPTER 64. Stubb’s Supper.
11566 
11567 Stubb’s whale had been killed some distance from the ship. It was a
11568 calm; so, forming a tandem of three boats, we commenced the slow
11569 business of towing the trophy to the Pequod. And now, as we eighteen
11570 men with our thirty-six arms, and one hundred and eighty thumbs and
11571 fingers, slowly toiled hour after hour upon that inert, sluggish corpse
11572 in the sea; and it seemed hardly to budge at all, except at long
11573 intervals; good evidence was hereby furnished of the enormousness of
11574 the mass we moved. For, upon the great canal of Hang-Ho, or whatever
11575 they call it, in China, four or five laborers on the foot-path will
11576 draw a bulky freighted junk at the rate of a mile an hour; but this
11577 grand argosy we towed heavily forged along, as if laden with pig-lead
11578 in bulk.
11579 
11580 Darkness came on; but three lights up and down in the Pequod’s
11581 main-rigging dimly guided our way; till drawing nearer we saw Ahab
11582 dropping one of several more lanterns over the bulwarks. Vacantly
11583 eyeing the heaving whale for a moment, he issued the usual orders for
11584 securing it for the night, and then handing his lantern to a seaman,
11585 went his way into the cabin, and did not come forward again until
11586 morning.
11587 
11588 Though, in overseeing the pursuit of this whale, Captain Ahab had
11589 evinced his customary activity, to call it so; yet now that the
11590 creature was dead, some vague dissatisfaction, or impatience, or
11591 despair, seemed working in him; as if the sight of that dead body
11592 reminded him that Moby Dick was yet to be slain; and though a thousand
11593 other whales were brought to his ship, all that would not one jot
11594 advance his grand, monomaniac object. Very soon you would have thought
11595 from the sound on the Pequod’s decks, that all hands were preparing to
11596 cast anchor in the deep; for heavy chains are being dragged along the
11597 deck, and thrust rattling out of the port-holes. But by those clanking
11598 links, the vast corpse itself, not the ship, is to be moored. Tied by
11599 the head to the stern, and by the tail to the bows, the whale now lies
11600 with its black hull close to the vessel’s and seen through the darkness
11601 of the night, which obscured the spars and rigging aloft, the two—ship
11602 and whale, seemed yoked together like colossal bullocks, whereof one
11603 reclines while the other remains standing.*
11604 
11605 *A little item may as well be related here. The strongest and most
11606 reliable hold which the ship has upon the whale when moored alongside,
11607 is by the flukes or tail; and as from its greater density that part is
11608 relatively heavier than any other (excepting the side-fins), its
11609 flexibility even in death, causes it to sink low beneath the surface;
11610 so that with the hand you cannot get at it from the boat, in order to
11611 put the chain round it. But this difficulty is ingeniously overcome: a
11612 small, strong line is prepared with a wooden float at its outer end,
11613 and a weight in its middle, while the other end is secured to the ship.
11614 By adroit management the wooden float is made to rise on the other side
11615 of the mass, so that now having girdled the whale, the chain is readily
11616 made to follow suit; and being slipped along the body, is at last
11617 locked fast round the smallest part of the tail, at the point of
11618 junction with its broad flukes or lobes.
11619 
11620 If moody Ahab was now all quiescence, at least so far as could be known
11621 on deck, Stubb, his second mate, flushed with conquest, betrayed an
11622 unusual but still good-natured excitement. Such an unwonted bustle was
11623 he in that the staid Starbuck, his official superior, quietly resigned
11624 to him for the time the sole management of affairs. One small, helping
11625 cause of all this liveliness in Stubb, was soon made strangely
11626 manifest. Stubb was a high liver; he was somewhat intemperately fond of
11627 the whale as a flavorish thing to his palate.
11628 
11629 “A steak, a steak, ere I sleep! You, Daggoo! overboard you go, and cut
11630 me one from his small!”
11631 
11632 Here be it known, that though these wild fishermen do not, as a general
11633 thing, and according to the great military maxim, make the enemy defray
11634 the current expenses of the war (at least before realizing the proceeds
11635 of the voyage), yet now and then you find some of these Nantucketers
11636 who have a genuine relish for that particular part of the Sperm Whale
11637 designated by Stubb; comprising the tapering extremity of the body.
11638 
11639 About midnight that steak was cut and cooked; and lighted by two
11640 lanterns of sperm oil, Stubb stoutly stood up to his spermaceti supper
11641 at the capstan-head, as if that capstan were a sideboard. Nor was Stubb
11642 the only banqueter on whale’s flesh that night. Mingling their
11643 mumblings with his own mastications, thousands on thousands of sharks,
11644 swarming round the dead leviathan, smackingly feasted on its fatness.
11645 The few sleepers below in their bunks were often startled by the sharp
11646 slapping of their tails against the hull, within a few inches of the
11647 sleepers’ hearts. Peering over the side you could just see them (as
11648 before you heard them) wallowing in the sullen, black waters, and
11649 turning over on their backs as they scooped out huge globular pieces of
11650 the whale of the bigness of a human head. This particular feat of the
11651 shark seems all but miraculous. How at such an apparently unassailable
11652 surface, they contrive to gouge out such symmetrical mouthfuls, remains
11653 a part of the universal problem of all things. The mark they thus leave
11654 on the whale, may best be likened to the hollow made by a carpenter in
11655 countersinking for a screw.
11656 
11657 Though amid all the smoking horror and diabolism of a sea-fight, sharks
11658 will be seen longingly gazing up to the ship’s decks, like hungry dogs
11659 round a table where red meat is being carved, ready to bolt down every
11660 killed man that is tossed to them; and though, while the valiant
11661 butchers over the deck-table are thus cannibally carving each other’s
11662 live meat with carving-knives all gilded and tasselled, the sharks,
11663 also, with their jewel-hilted mouths, are quarrelsomely carving away
11664 under the table at the dead meat; and though, were you to turn the
11665 whole affair upside down, it would still be pretty much the same thing,
11666 that is to say, a shocking sharkish business enough for all parties;
11667 and though sharks also are the invariable outriders of all slave ships
11668 crossing the Atlantic, systematically trotting alongside, to be handy
11669 in case a parcel is to be carried anywhere, or a dead slave to be
11670 decently buried; and though one or two other like instances might be
11671 set down, touching the set terms, places, and occasions, when sharks do
11672 most socially congregate, and most hilariously feast; yet is there no
11673 conceivable time or occasion when you will find them in such countless
11674 numbers, and in gayer or more jovial spirits, than around a dead sperm
11675 whale, moored by night to a whaleship at sea. If you have never seen
11676 that sight, then suspend your decision about the propriety of
11677 devil-worship, and the expediency of conciliating the devil.
11678 
11679 But, as yet, Stubb heeded not the mumblings of the banquet that was
11680 going on so nigh him, no more than the sharks heeded the smacking of
11681 his own epicurean lips.
11682 
11683 “Cook, cook!—where’s that old Fleece?” he cried at length, widening his
11684 legs still further, as if to form a more secure base for his supper;
11685 and, at the same time darting his fork into the dish, as if stabbing
11686 with his lance; “cook, you cook!—sail this way, cook!”
11687 
11688 The old black, not in any very high glee at having been previously
11689 roused from his warm hammock at a most unseasonable hour, came
11690 shambling along from his galley, for, like many old blacks, there was
11691 something the matter with his knee-pans, which he did not keep well
11692 scoured like his other pans; this old Fleece, as they called him, came
11693 shuffling and limping along, assisting his step with his tongs, which,
11694 after a clumsy fashion, were made of straightened iron hoops; this old
11695 Ebony floundered along, and in obedience to the word of command, came
11696 to a dead stop on the opposite side of Stubb’s sideboard; when, with
11697 both hands folded before him, and resting on his two-legged cane, he
11698 bowed his arched back still further over, at the same time sideways
11699 inclining his head, so as to bring his best ear into play.
11700 
11701 “Cook,” said Stubb, rapidly lifting a rather reddish morsel to his
11702 mouth, “don’t you think this steak is rather overdone? You’ve been
11703 beating this steak too much, cook; it’s too tender. Don’t I always say
11704 that to be good, a whale-steak must be tough? There are those sharks
11705 now over the side, don’t you see they prefer it tough and rare? What a
11706 shindy they are kicking up! Cook, go and talk to ’em; tell ’em they are
11707 welcome to help themselves civilly, and in moderation, but they must
11708 keep quiet. Blast me, if I can hear my own voice. Away, cook, and
11709 deliver my message. Here, take this lantern,” snatching one from his
11710 sideboard; “now then, go and preach to ’em!”
11711 
11712 Sullenly taking the offered lantern, old Fleece limped across the deck
11713 to the bulwarks; and then, with one hand dropping his light low over
11714 the sea, so as to get a good view of his congregation, with the other
11715 hand he solemnly flourished his tongs, and leaning far over the side in
11716 a mumbling voice began addressing the sharks, while Stubb, softly
11717 crawling behind, overheard all that was said.
11718 
11719 “Fellow-critters: I’se ordered here to say dat you must stop dat dam
11720 noise dare. You hear? Stop dat dam smackin’ ob de lip! Massa Stubb say
11721 dat you can fill your dam bellies up to de hatchings, but by Gor! you
11722 must stop dat dam racket!”
11723 
11724 “Cook,” here interposed Stubb, accompanying the word with a sudden slap
11725 on the shoulder,—“Cook! why, damn your eyes, you mustn’t swear that way
11726 when you’re preaching. That’s no way to convert sinners, cook!”
11727 
11728 “Who dat? Den preach to him yourself,” sullenly turning to go.
11729 
11730 “No, cook; go on, go on.”
11731 
11732 “Well, den, Belubed fellow-critters:”—
11733 
11734 “Right!” exclaimed Stubb, approvingly, “coax ’em to it; try that,” and
11735 Fleece continued.
11736 
11737 “Do you is all sharks, and by natur wery woracious, yet I zay to you,
11738 fellow-critters, dat dat woraciousness—’top dat dam slappin’ ob de
11739 tail! How you tink to hear, spose you keep up such a dam slappin’ and
11740 bitin’ dare?”
11741 
11742 “Cook,” cried Stubb, collaring him, “I won’t have that swearing. Talk
11743 to ’em gentlemanly.”
11744 
11745 Once more the sermon proceeded.
11746 
11747 “Your woraciousness, fellow-critters, I don’t blame ye so much for; dat
11748 is natur, and can’t be helped; but to gobern dat wicked natur, dat is
11749 de pint. You is sharks, sartin; but if you gobern de shark in you, why
11750 den you be angel; for all angel is not’ing more dan de shark well
11751 goberned. Now, look here, bred’ren, just try wonst to be cibil, a
11752 helping yourselbs from dat whale. Don’t be tearin’ de blubber out your
11753 neighbour’s mout, I say. Is not one shark dood right as toder to dat
11754 whale? And, by Gor, none on you has de right to dat whale; dat whale
11755 belong to some one else. I know some o’ you has berry brig mout,
11756 brigger dan oders; but den de brig mouts sometimes has de small
11757 bellies; so dat de brigness of de mout is not to swaller wid, but to
11758 bit off de blubber for de small fry ob sharks, dat can’t get into de
11759 scrouge to help demselves.”
11760 
11761 “Well done, old Fleece!” cried Stubb, “that’s Christianity; go on.”
11762 
11763 “No use goin’ on; de dam willains will keep a scougin’ and slappin’
11764 each oder, Massa Stubb; dey don’t hear one word; no use a-preachin’ to
11765 such dam g’uttons as you call ’em, till dare bellies is full, and dare
11766 bellies is bottomless; and when dey do get ’em full, dey wont hear you
11767 den; for den dey sink in de sea, go fast to sleep on de coral, and
11768 can’t hear not’ing at all, no more, for eber and eber.”
11769 
11770 “Upon my soul, I am about of the same opinion; so give the benediction,
11771 Fleece, and I’ll away to my supper.”
11772 
11773 Upon this, Fleece, holding both hands over the fishy mob, raised his
11774 shrill voice, and cried—
11775 
11776 “Cussed fellow-critters! Kick up de damndest row as ever you can; fill
11777 your dam’ bellies ’till dey bust—and den die.”
11778 
11779 “Now, cook,” said Stubb, resuming his supper at the capstan; “stand
11780 just where you stood before, there, over against me, and pay particular
11781 attention.”
11782 
11783 “All dention,” said Fleece, again stooping over upon his tongs in the
11784 desired position.
11785 
11786 “Well,” said Stubb, helping himself freely meanwhile; “I shall now go
11787 back to the subject of this steak. In the first place, how old are you,
11788 cook?”
11789 
11790 “What dat do wid de ’teak,” said the old black, testily.
11791 
11792 “Silence! How old are you, cook?”
11793 
11794 “’Bout ninety, dey say,” he gloomily muttered.
11795 
11796 “And you have lived in this world hard upon one hundred years, cook,
11797 and don’t know yet how to cook a whale-steak?” rapidly bolting another
11798 mouthful at the last word, so that morsel seemed a continuation of the
11799 question. “Where were you born, cook?”
11800 
11801 “’Hind de hatchway, in ferry-boat, goin’ ober de Roanoke.”
11802 
11803 “Born in a ferry-boat! That’s queer, too. But I want to know what
11804 country you were born in, cook!”
11805 
11806 “Didn’t I say de Roanoke country?” he cried sharply.
11807 
11808 “No, you didn’t, cook; but I’ll tell you what I’m coming to, cook. You
11809 must go home and be born over again; you don’t know how to cook a
11810 whale-steak yet.”
11811 
11812 “Bress my soul, if I cook noder one,” he growled, angrily, turning
11813 round to depart.
11814 
11815 “Come back, cook;—here, hand me those tongs;—now take that bit of steak
11816 there, and tell me if you think that steak cooked as it should be? Take
11817 it, I say”—holding the tongs towards him—“take it, and taste it.”
11818 
11819 Faintly smacking his withered lips over it for a moment, the old negro
11820 muttered, “Best cooked ’teak I eber taste; joosy, berry joosy.”
11821 
11822 “Cook,” said Stubb, squaring himself once more; “do you belong to the
11823 church?”
11824 
11825 “Passed one once in Cape-Down,” said the old man sullenly.
11826 
11827 “And you have once in your life passed a holy church in Cape-Town,
11828 where you doubtless overheard a holy parson addressing his hearers as
11829 his beloved fellow-creatures, have you, cook! And yet you come here,
11830 and tell me such a dreadful lie as you did just now, eh?” said Stubb.
11831 “Where do you expect to go to, cook?”
11832 
11833 “Go to bed berry soon,” he mumbled, half-turning as he spoke.
11834 
11835 “Avast! heave to! I mean when you die, cook. It’s an awful question.
11836 Now what’s your answer?”
11837 
11838 “When dis old brack man dies,” said the negro slowly, changing his
11839 whole air and demeanor, “he hisself won’t go nowhere; but some bressed
11840 angel will come and fetch him.”
11841 
11842 “Fetch him? How? In a coach and four, as they fetched Elijah? And fetch
11843 him where?”
11844 
11845 “Up dere,” said Fleece, holding his tongs straight over his head, and
11846 keeping it there very solemnly.
11847 
11848 “So, then, you expect to go up into our main-top, do you, cook, when
11849 you are dead? But don’t you know the higher you climb, the colder it
11850 gets? Main-top, eh?”
11851 
11852 “Didn’t say dat t’all,” said Fleece, again in the sulks.
11853 
11854 “You said up there, didn’t you? and now look yourself, and see where
11855 your tongs are pointing. But, perhaps you expect to get into heaven by
11856 crawling through the lubber’s hole, cook; but, no, no, cook, you don’t
11857 get there, except you go the regular way, round by the rigging. It’s a
11858 ticklish business, but must be done, or else it’s no go. But none of us
11859 are in heaven yet. Drop your tongs, cook, and hear my orders. Do ye
11860 hear? Hold your hat in one hand, and clap t’other a’top of your heart,
11861 when I’m giving my orders, cook. What! that your heart, there?—that’s
11862 your gizzard! Aloft! aloft!—that’s it—now you have it. Hold it there
11863 now, and pay attention.”
11864 
11865 “All ’dention,” said the old black, with both hands placed as desired,
11866 vainly wriggling his grizzled head, as if to get both ears in front at
11867 one and the same time.
11868 
11869 “Well then, cook, you see this whale-steak of yours was so very bad,
11870 that I have put it out of sight as soon as possible; you see that,
11871 don’t you? Well, for the future, when you cook another whale-steak for
11872 my private table here, the capstan, I’ll tell you what to do so as not
11873 to spoil it by overdoing. Hold the steak in one hand, and show a live
11874 coal to it with the other; that done, dish it; d’ye hear? And now
11875 to-morrow, cook, when we are cutting in the fish, be sure you stand by
11876 to get the tips of his fins; have them put in pickle. As for the ends
11877 of the flukes, have them soused, cook. There, now ye may go.”
11878 
11879 But Fleece had hardly got three paces off, when he was recalled.
11880 
11881 “Cook, give me cutlets for supper to-morrow night in the mid-watch.
11882 D’ye hear? away you sail, then.—Halloa! stop! make a bow before you
11883 go.—Avast heaving again! Whale-balls for breakfast—don’t forget.”
11884 
11885 “Wish, by gor! whale eat him, ’stead of him eat whale. I’m bressed if
11886 he ain’t more of shark dan Massa Shark hisself,” muttered the old man,
11887 limping away; with which sage ejaculation he went to his hammock.
11888 
11889 
11890 CHAPTER 65. The Whale as a Dish.
11891 
11892 That mortal man should feed upon the creature that feeds his lamp, and,
11893 like Stubb, eat him by his own light, as you may say; this seems so
11894 outlandish a thing that one must needs go a little into the history and
11895 philosophy of it.
11896 
11897 It is upon record, that three centuries ago the tongue of the Right
11898 Whale was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large
11899 prices there. Also, that in Henry VIIIth’s time, a certain cook of the
11900 court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce to be
11901 eaten with barbacued porpoises, which, you remember, are a species of
11902 whale. Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered fine eating. The
11903 meat is made into balls about the size of billiard balls, and being
11904 well seasoned and spiced might be taken for turtle-balls or veal balls.
11905 The old monks of Dunfermline were very fond of them. They had a great
11906 porpoise grant from the crown.
11907 
11908 The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the whale would by all
11909 hands be considered a noble dish, were there not so much of him; but
11910 when you come to sit down before a meat-pie nearly one hundred feet
11911 long, it takes away your appetite. Only the most unprejudiced of men
11912 like Stubb, nowadays partake of cooked whales; but the Esquimaux are
11913 not so fastidious. We all know how they live upon whales, and have rare
11914 old vintages of prime old train oil. Zogranda, one of their most famous
11915 doctors, recommends strips of blubber for infants, as being exceedingly
11916 juicy and nourishing. And this reminds me that certain Englishmen, who
11917 long ago were accidentally left in Greenland by a whaling vessel—that
11918 these men actually lived for several months on the mouldy scraps of
11919 whales which had been left ashore after trying out the blubber. Among
11920 the Dutch whalemen these scraps are called “fritters”; which, indeed,
11921 they greatly resemble, being brown and crisp, and smelling something
11922 like old Amsterdam housewives’ dough-nuts or oly-cooks, when fresh.
11923 They have such an eatable look that the most self-denying stranger can
11924 hardly keep his hands off.
11925 
11926 But what further depreciates the whale as a civilized dish, is his
11927 exceeding richness. He is the great prize ox of the sea, too fat to be
11928 delicately good. Look at his hump, which would be as fine eating as the
11929 buffalo’s (which is esteemed a rare dish), were it not such a solid
11930 pyramid of fat. But the spermaceti itself, how bland and creamy that
11931 is; like the transparent, half-jellied, white meat of a cocoanut in the
11932 third month of its growth, yet far too rich to supply a substitute for
11933 butter. Nevertheless, many whalemen have a method of absorbing it into
11934 some other substance, and then partaking of it. In the long try watches
11935 of the night it is a common thing for the seamen to dip their
11936 ship-biscuit into the huge oil-pots and let them fry there awhile. Many
11937 a good supper have I thus made.
11938 
11939 In the case of a small Sperm Whale the brains are accounted a fine
11940 dish. The casket of the skull is broken into with an axe, and the two
11941 plump, whitish lobes being withdrawn (precisely resembling two large
11942 puddings), they are then mixed with flour, and cooked into a most
11943 delectable mess, in flavor somewhat resembling calves’ head, which is
11944 quite a dish among some epicures; and every one knows that some young
11945 bucks among the epicures, by continually dining upon calves’ brains, by
11946 and by get to have a little brains of their own, so as to be able to
11947 tell a calf’s head from their own heads; which, indeed, requires
11948 uncommon discrimination. And that is the reason why a young buck with
11949 an intelligent looking calf’s head before him, is somehow one of the
11950 saddest sights you can see. The head looks a sort of reproachfully at
11951 him, with an “Et tu Brute!” expression.
11952 
11953 It is not, perhaps, entirely because the whale is so excessively
11954 unctuous that landsmen seem to regard the eating of him with
11955 abhorrence; that appears to result, in some way, from the consideration
11956 before mentioned: _i.e._ that a man should eat a newly murdered thing
11957 of the sea, and eat it too by its own light. But no doubt the first man
11958 that ever murdered an ox was regarded as a murderer; perhaps he was
11959 hung; and if he had been put on his trial by oxen, he certainly would
11960 have been; and he certainly deserved it if any murderer does. Go to the
11961 meat-market of a Saturday night and see the crowds of live bipeds
11962 staring up at the long rows of dead quadrupeds. Does not that sight
11963 take a tooth out of the cannibal’s jaw? Cannibals? who is not a
11964 cannibal? I tell you it will be more tolerable for the Fejee that
11965 salted down a lean missionary in his cellar against a coming famine; it
11966 will be more tolerable for that provident Fejee, I say, in the day of
11967 judgment, than for thee, civilized and enlightened gourmand, who
11968 nailest geese to the ground and feastest on their bloated livers in thy
11969 paté-de-foie-gras.
11970 
11971 But Stubb, he eats the whale by its own light, does he? and that is
11972 adding insult to injury, is it? Look at your knife-handle, there, my
11973 civilized and enlightened gourmand dining off that roast beef, what is
11974 that handle made of?—what but the bones of the brother of the very ox
11975 you are eating? And what do you pick your teeth with, after devouring
11976 that fat goose? With a feather of the same fowl. And with what quill
11977 did the Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Cruelty to
11978 Ganders formally indite his circulars? It is only within the last month
11979 or two that that society passed a resolution to patronize nothing but
11980 steel pens.
11981 
11982 
11983 CHAPTER 66. The Shark Massacre.
11984 
11985 When in the Southern Fishery, a captured Sperm Whale, after long and
11986 weary toil, is brought alongside late at night, it is not, as a general
11987 thing at least, customary to proceed at once to the business of cutting
11988 him in. For that business is an exceedingly laborious one; is not very
11989 soon completed; and requires all hands to set about it. Therefore, the
11990 common usage is to take in all sail; lash the helm a’lee; and then send
11991 every one below to his hammock till daylight, with the reservation
11992 that, until that time, anchor-watches shall be kept; that is, two and
11993 two for an hour, each couple, the crew in rotation shall mount the deck
11994 to see that all goes well.
11995 
11996 But sometimes, especially upon the Line in the Pacific, this plan will
11997 not answer at all; because such incalculable hosts of sharks gather
11998 round the moored carcase, that were he left so for six hours, say, on a
11999 stretch, little more than the skeleton would be visible by morning. In
12000 most other parts of the ocean, however, where these fish do not so
12001 largely abound, their wondrous voracity can be at times considerably
12002 diminished, by vigorously stirring them up with sharp whaling-spades, a
12003 procedure notwithstanding, which, in some instances, only seems to
12004 tickle them into still greater activity. But it was not thus in the
12005 present case with the Pequod’s sharks; though, to be sure, any man
12006 unaccustomed to such sights, to have looked over her side that night,
12007 would have almost thought the whole round sea was one huge cheese, and
12008 those sharks the maggots in it.
12009 
12010 Nevertheless, upon Stubb setting the anchor-watch after his supper was
12011 concluded; and when, accordingly, Queequeg and a forecastle seaman came
12012 on deck, no small excitement was created among the sharks; for
12013 immediately suspending the cutting stages over the side, and lowering
