12014 three lanterns, so that they cast long gleams of light over the turbid
12015 sea, these two mariners, darting their long whaling-spades, kept up an
12016 incessant murdering of the sharks,* by striking the keen steel deep
12017 into their skulls, seemingly their only vital part. But in the foamy
12018 confusion of their mixed and struggling hosts, the marksmen could not
12019 always hit their mark; and this brought about new revelations of the
12020 incredible ferocity of the foe. They viciously snapped, not only at
12021 each other’s disembowelments, but like flexible bows, bent round, and
12022 bit their own; till those entrails seemed swallowed over and over again
12023 by the same mouth, to be oppositely voided by the gaping wound. Nor was
12024 this all. It was unsafe to meddle with the corpses and ghosts of these
12025 creatures. A sort of generic or Pantheistic vitality seemed to lurk in
12026 their very joints and bones, after what might be called the individual
12027 life had departed. Killed and hoisted on deck for the sake of his skin,
12028 one of these sharks almost took poor Queequeg’s hand off, when he tried
12029 to shut down the dead lid of his murderous jaw.
12030 
12031 *The whaling-spade used for cutting-in is made of the very best steel;
12032 is about the bigness of a man’s spread hand; and in general shape,
12033 corresponds to the garden implement after which it is named; only its
12034 sides are perfectly flat, and its upper end considerably narrower than
12035 the lower. This weapon is always kept as sharp as possible; and when
12036 being used is occasionally honed, just like a razor. In its socket, a
12037 stiff pole, from twenty to thirty feet long, is inserted for a handle.
12038 
12039 “Queequeg no care what god made him shark,” said the savage,
12040 agonizingly lifting his hand up and down; “wedder Fejee god or
12041 Nantucket god; but de god wat made shark must be one dam Ingin.”
12042 
12043 
12044 CHAPTER 67. Cutting In.
12045 
12046 It was a Saturday night, and such a Sabbath as followed! Ex officio
12047 professors of Sabbath breaking are all whalemen. The ivory Pequod was
12048 turned into what seemed a shamble; every sailor a butcher. You would
12049 have thought we were offering up ten thousand red oxen to the sea gods.
12050 
12051 In the first place, the enormous cutting tackles, among other ponderous
12052 things comprising a cluster of blocks generally painted green, and
12053 which no single man can possibly lift—this vast bunch of grapes was
12054 swayed up to the main-top and firmly lashed to the lower mast-head, the
12055 strongest point anywhere above a ship’s deck. The end of the
12056 hawser-like rope winding through these intricacies, was then conducted
12057 to the windlass, and the huge lower block of the tackles was swung over
12058 the whale; to this block the great blubber hook, weighing some one
12059 hundred pounds, was attached. And now suspended in stages over the
12060 side, Starbuck and Stubb, the mates, armed with their long spades,
12061 began cutting a hole in the body for the insertion of the hook just
12062 above the nearest of the two side-fins. This done, a broad,
12063 semicircular line is cut round the hole, the hook is inserted, and the
12064 main body of the crew striking up a wild chorus, now commence heaving
12065 in one dense crowd at the windlass. When instantly, the entire ship
12066 careens over on her side; every bolt in her starts like the nail-heads
12067 of an old house in frosty weather; she trembles, quivers, and nods her
12068 frighted mast-heads to the sky. More and more she leans over to the
12069 whale, while every gasping heave of the windlass is answered by a
12070 helping heave from the billows; till at last, a swift, startling snap
12071 is heard; with a great swash the ship rolls upwards and backwards from
12072 the whale, and the triumphant tackle rises into sight dragging after it
12073 the disengaged semicircular end of the first strip of blubber. Now as
12074 the blubber envelopes the whale precisely as the rind does an orange,
12075 so is it stripped off from the body precisely as an orange is sometimes
12076 stripped by spiralizing it. For the strain constantly kept up by the
12077 windlass continually keeps the whale rolling over and over in the
12078 water, and as the blubber in one strip uniformly peels off along the
12079 line called the “scarf,” simultaneously cut by the spades of Starbuck
12080 and Stubb, the mates; and just as fast as it is thus peeled off, and
12081 indeed by that very act itself, it is all the time being hoisted higher
12082 and higher aloft till its upper end grazes the main-top; the men at the
12083 windlass then cease heaving, and for a moment or two the prodigious
12084 blood-dripping mass sways to and fro as if let down from the sky, and
12085 every one present must take good heed to dodge it when it swings, else
12086 it may box his ears and pitch him headlong overboard.
12087 
12088 One of the attending harpooneers now advances with a long, keen weapon
12089 called a boarding-sword, and watching his chance he dexterously slices
12090 out a considerable hole in the lower part of the swaying mass. Into
12091 this hole, the end of the second alternating great tackle is then
12092 hooked so as to retain a hold upon the blubber, in order to prepare for
12093 what follows. Whereupon, this accomplished swordsman, warning all hands
12094 to stand off, once more makes a scientific dash at the mass, and with a
12095 few sidelong, desperate, lunging slicings, severs it completely in
12096 twain; so that while the short lower part is still fast, the long upper
12097 strip, called a blanket-piece, swings clear, and is all ready for
12098 lowering. The heavers forward now resume their song, and while the one
12099 tackle is peeling and hoisting a second strip from the whale, the other
12100 is slowly slackened away, and down goes the first strip through the
12101 main hatchway right beneath, into an unfurnished parlor called the
12102 blubber-room. Into this twilight apartment sundry nimble hands keep
12103 coiling away the long blanket-piece as if it were a great live mass of
12104 plaited serpents. And thus the work proceeds; the two tackles hoisting
12105 and lowering simultaneously; both whale and windlass heaving, the
12106 heavers singing, the blubber-room gentlemen coiling, the mates
12107 scarfing, the ship straining, and all hands swearing occasionally, by
12108 way of assuaging the general friction.
12109 
12110 
12111 CHAPTER 68. The Blanket.
12112 
12113 I have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject, the skin
12114 of the whale. I have had controversies about it with experienced
12115 whalemen afloat, and learned naturalists ashore. My original opinion
12116 remains unchanged; but it is only an opinion.
12117 
12118 The question is, what and where is the skin of the whale? Already you
12119 know what his blubber is. That blubber is something of the consistence
12120 of firm, close-grained beef, but tougher, more elastic and compact, and
12121 ranges from eight or ten to twelve and fifteen inches in thickness.
12122 
12123 Now, however preposterous it may at first seem to talk of any
12124 creature’s skin as being of that sort of consistence and thickness, yet
12125 in point of fact these are no arguments against such a presumption;
12126 because you cannot raise any other dense enveloping layer from the
12127 whale’s body but that same blubber; and the outermost enveloping layer
12128 of any animal, if reasonably dense, what can that be but the skin?
12129 True, from the unmarred dead body of the whale, you may scrape off with
12130 your hand an infinitely thin, transparent substance, somewhat
12131 resembling the thinnest shreds of isinglass, only it is almost as
12132 flexible and soft as satin; that is, previous to being dried, when it
12133 not only contracts and thickens, but becomes rather hard and brittle. I
12134 have several such dried bits, which I use for marks in my whale-books.
12135 It is transparent, as I said before; and being laid upon the printed
12136 page, I have sometimes pleased myself with fancying it exerted a
12137 magnifying influence. At any rate, it is pleasant to read about whales
12138 through their own spectacles, as you may say. But what I am driving at
12139 here is this. That same infinitely thin, isinglass substance, which, I
12140 admit, invests the entire body of the whale, is not so much to be
12141 regarded as the skin of the creature, as the skin of the skin, so to
12142 speak; for it were simply ridiculous to say, that the proper skin of
12143 the tremendous whale is thinner and more tender than the skin of a
12144 new-born child. But no more of this.
12145 
12146 Assuming the blubber to be the skin of the whale; then, when this skin,
12147 as in the case of a very large Sperm Whale, will yield the bulk of one
12148 hundred barrels of oil; and, when it is considered that, in quantity,
12149 or rather weight, that oil, in its expressed state, is only three
12150 fourths, and not the entire substance of the coat; some idea may hence
12151 be had of the enormousness of that animated mass, a mere part of whose
12152 mere integument yields such a lake of liquid as that. Reckoning ten
12153 barrels to the ton, you have ten tons for the net weight of only three
12154 quarters of the stuff of the whale’s skin.
12155 
12156 In life, the visible surface of the Sperm Whale is not the least among
12157 the many marvels he presents. Almost invariably it is all over
12158 obliquely crossed and re-crossed with numberless straight marks in
12159 thick array, something like those in the finest Italian line
12160 engravings. But these marks do not seem to be impressed upon the
12161 isinglass substance above mentioned, but seem to be seen through it, as
12162 if they were engraved upon the body itself. Nor is this all. In some
12163 instances, to the quick, observant eye, those linear marks, as in a
12164 veritable engraving, but afford the ground for far other delineations.
12165 These are hieroglyphical; that is, if you call those mysterious cyphers
12166 on the walls of pyramids hieroglyphics, then that is the proper word to
12167 use in the present connexion. By my retentive memory of the
12168 hieroglyphics upon one Sperm Whale in particular, I was much struck
12169 with a plate representing the old Indian characters chiselled on the
12170 famous hieroglyphic palisades on the banks of the Upper Mississippi.
12171 Like those mystic rocks, too, the mystic-marked whale remains
12172 undecipherable. This allusion to the Indian rocks reminds me of another
12173 thing. Besides all the other phenomena which the exterior of the Sperm
12174 Whale presents, he not seldom displays the back, and more especially
12175 his flanks, effaced in great part of the regular linear appearance, by
12176 reason of numerous rude scratches, altogether of an irregular, random
12177 aspect. I should say that those New England rocks on the sea-coast,
12178 which Agassiz imagines to bear the marks of violent scraping contact
12179 with vast floating icebergs—I should say, that those rocks must not a
12180 little resemble the Sperm Whale in this particular. It also seems to me
12181 that such scratches in the whale are probably made by hostile contact
12182 with other whales; for I have most remarked them in the large,
12183 full-grown bulls of the species.
12184 
12185 A word or two more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of the
12186 whale. It has already been said, that it is stript from him in long
12187 pieces, called blanket-pieces. Like most sea-terms, this one is very
12188 happy and significant. For the whale is indeed wrapt up in his blubber
12189 as in a real blanket or counterpane; or, still better, an Indian poncho
12190 slipt over his head, and skirting his extremity. It is by reason of
12191 this cosy blanketing of his body, that the whale is enabled to keep
12192 himself comfortable in all weathers, in all seas, times, and tides.
12193 What would become of a Greenland whale, say, in those shuddering, icy
12194 seas of the North, if unsupplied with his cosy surtout? True, other
12195 fish are found exceedingly brisk in those Hyperborean waters; but
12196 these, be it observed, are your cold-blooded, lungless fish, whose very
12197 bellies are refrigerators; creatures, that warm themselves under the
12198 lee of an iceberg, as a traveller in winter would bask before an inn
12199 fire; whereas, like man, the whale has lungs and warm blood. Freeze his
12200 blood, and he dies. How wonderful is it then—except after
12201 explanation—that this great monster, to whom corporeal warmth is as
12202 indispensable as it is to man; how wonderful that he should be found at
12203 home, immersed to his lips for life in those Arctic waters! where, when
12204 seamen fall overboard, they are sometimes found, months afterwards,
12205 perpendicularly frozen into the hearts of fields of ice, as a fly is
12206 found glued in amber. But more surprising is it to know, as has been
12207 proved by experiment, that the blood of a Polar whale is warmer than
12208 that of a Borneo negro in summer.
12209 
12210 It does seem to me, that herein we see the rare virtue of a strong
12211 individual vitality, and the rare virtue of thick walls, and the rare
12212 virtue of interior spaciousness. Oh, man! admire and model thyself
12213 after the whale! Do thou, too, remain warm among ice. Do thou, too,
12214 live in this world without being of it. Be cool at the equator; keep
12215 thy blood fluid at the Pole. Like the great dome of St. Peter’s, and
12216 like the great whale, retain, O man! in all seasons a temperature of
12217 thine own.
12218 
12219 But how easy and how hopeless to teach these fine things! Of erections,
12220 how few are domed like St. Peter’s! of creatures, how few vast as the
12221 whale!
12222 
12223 
12224 CHAPTER 69. The Funeral.
12225 
12226 “Haul in the chains! Let the carcase go astern!”
12227 
12228 The vast tackles have now done their duty. The peeled white body of the
12229 beheaded whale flashes like a marble sepulchre; though changed in hue,
12230 it has not perceptibly lost anything in bulk. It is still colossal.
12231 Slowly it floats more and more away, the water round it torn and
12232 splashed by the insatiate sharks, and the air above vexed with
12233 rapacious flights of screaming fowls, whose beaks are like so many
12234 insulting poniards in the whale. The vast white headless phantom floats
12235 further and further from the ship, and every rod that it so floats,
12236 what seem square roods of sharks and cubic roods of fowls, augment the
12237 murderous din. For hours and hours from the almost stationary ship that
12238 hideous sight is seen. Beneath the unclouded and mild azure sky, upon
12239 the fair face of the pleasant sea, wafted by the joyous breezes, that
12240 great mass of death floats on and on, till lost in infinite
12241 perspectives.
12242 
12243 There’s a most doleful and most mocking funeral! The sea-vultures all
12244 in pious mourning, the air-sharks all punctiliously in black or
12245 speckled. In life but few of them would have helped the whale, I ween,
12246 if peradventure he had needed it; but upon the banquet of his funeral
12247 they most piously do pounce. Oh, horrible vultureism of earth! from
12248 which not the mightiest whale is free.
12249 
12250 Nor is this the end. Desecrated as the body is, a vengeful ghost
12251 survives and hovers over it to scare. Espied by some timid man-of-war
12252 or blundering discovery-vessel from afar, when the distance obscuring
12253 the swarming fowls, nevertheless still shows the white mass floating in
12254 the sun, and the white spray heaving high against it; straightway the
12255 whale’s unharming corpse, with trembling fingers is set down in the
12256 log—_shoals, rocks, and breakers hereabouts: beware!_ And for years
12257 afterwards, perhaps, ships shun the place; leaping over it as silly
12258 sheep leap over a vacuum, because their leader originally leaped there
12259 when a stick was held. There’s your law of precedents; there’s your
12260 utility of traditions; there’s the story of your obstinate survival of
12261 old beliefs never bottomed on the earth, and now not even hovering in
12262 the air! There’s orthodoxy!
12263 
12264 Thus, while in life the great whale’s body may have been a real terror
12265 to his foes, in his death his ghost becomes a powerless panic to a
12266 world.
12267 
12268 Are you a believer in ghosts, my friend? There are other ghosts than
12269 the Cock-Lane one, and far deeper men than Doctor Johnson who believe
12270 in them.
12271 
12272 
12273 CHAPTER 70. The Sphynx.
12274 
12275 It should not have been omitted that previous to completely stripping
12276 the body of the leviathan, he was beheaded. Now, the beheading of the
12277 Sperm Whale is a scientific anatomical feat, upon which experienced
12278 whale surgeons very much pride themselves: and not without reason.
12279 
12280 Consider that the whale has nothing that can properly be called a neck;
12281 on the contrary, where his head and body seem to join, there, in that
12282 very place, is the thickest part of him. Remember, also, that the
12283 surgeon must operate from above, some eight or ten feet intervening
12284 between him and his subject, and that subject almost hidden in a
12285 discoloured, rolling, and oftentimes tumultuous and bursting sea. Bear
12286 in mind, too, that under these untoward circumstances he has to cut
12287 many feet deep in the flesh; and in that subterraneous manner, without
12288 so much as getting one single peep into the ever-contracting gash thus
12289 made, he must skilfully steer clear of all adjacent, interdicted parts,
12290 and exactly divide the spine at a critical point hard by its insertion
12291 into the skull. Do you not marvel, then, at Stubb’s boast, that he
12292 demanded but ten minutes to behead a sperm whale?
12293 
12294 When first severed, the head is dropped astern and held there by a
12295 cable till the body is stripped. That done, if it belong to a small
12296 whale it is hoisted on deck to be deliberately disposed of. But, with a
12297 full grown leviathan this is impossible; for the sperm whale’s head
12298 embraces nearly one third of his entire bulk, and completely to suspend
12299 such a burden as that, even by the immense tackles of a whaler, this
12300 were as vain a thing as to attempt weighing a Dutch barn in jewellers’
12301 scales.
12302 
12303 The Pequod’s whale being decapitated and the body stripped, the head
12304 was hoisted against the ship’s side—about half way out of the sea, so
12305 that it might yet in great part be buoyed up by its native element. And
12306 there with the strained craft steeply leaning over to it, by reason of
12307 the enormous downward drag from the lower mast-head, and every yard-arm
12308 on that side projecting like a crane over the waves; there, that
12309 blood-dripping head hung to the Pequod’s waist like the giant
12310 Holofernes’s from the girdle of Judith.
12311 
12312 When this last task was accomplished it was noon, and the seamen went
12313 below to their dinner. Silence reigned over the before tumultuous but
12314 now deserted deck. An intense copper calm, like a universal yellow
12315 lotus, was more and more unfolding its noiseless measureless leaves
12316 upon the sea.
12317 
12318 A short space elapsed, and up into this noiselessness came Ahab alone
12319 from his cabin. Taking a few turns on the quarter-deck, he paused to
12320 gaze over the side, then slowly getting into the main-chains he took
12321 Stubb’s long spade—still remaining there after the whale’s
12322 decapitation—and striking it into the lower part of the half-suspended
12323 mass, placed its other end crutch-wise under one arm, and so stood
12324 leaning over with eyes attentively fixed on this head.
12325 
12326 It was a black and hooded head; and hanging there in the midst of so
12327 intense a calm, it seemed the Sphynx’s in the desert. “Speak, thou vast
12328 and venerable head,” muttered Ahab, “which, though ungarnished with a
12329 beard, yet here and there lookest hoary with mosses; speak, mighty
12330 head, and tell us the secret thing that is in thee. Of all divers, thou
12331 hast dived the deepest. That head upon which the upper sun now gleams,
12332 has moved amid this world’s foundations. Where unrecorded names and
12333 navies rust, and untold hopes and anchors rot; where in her murderous
12334 hold this frigate earth is ballasted with bones of millions of the
12335 drowned; there, in that awful water-land, there was thy most familiar
12336 home. Thou hast been where bell or diver never went; hast slept by many
12337 a sailor’s side, where sleepless mothers would give their lives to lay
12338 them down. Thou saw’st the locked lovers when leaping from their
12339 flaming ship; heart to heart they sank beneath the exulting wave; true
12340 to each other, when heaven seemed false to them. Thou saw’st the
12341 murdered mate when tossed by pirates from the midnight deck; for hours
12342 he fell into the deeper midnight of the insatiate maw; and his
12343 murderers still sailed on unharmed—while swift lightnings shivered the
12344 neighboring ship that would have borne a righteous husband to
12345 outstretched, longing arms. O head! thou hast seen enough to split the
12346 planets and make an infidel of Abraham, and not one syllable is thine!”
12347 
12348 “Sail ho!” cried a triumphant voice from the main-mast-head.
12349 
12350 “Aye? Well, now, that’s cheering,” cried Ahab, suddenly erecting
12351 himself, while whole thunder-clouds swept aside from his brow. “That
12352 lively cry upon this deadly calm might almost convert a better
12353 man.—Where away?”
12354 
12355 “Three points on the starboard bow, sir, and bringing down her breeze
12356 to us!
12357 
12358 “Better and better, man. Would now St. Paul would come along that way,
12359 and to my breezelessness bring his breeze! O Nature, and O soul of man!
12360 how far beyond all utterance are your linked analogies! not the
12361 smallest atom stirs or lives on matter, but has its cunning duplicate
12362 in mind.”
12363 
12364 
12365 CHAPTER 71. The Jeroboam’s Story.
12366 
12367 Hand in hand, ship and breeze blew on; but the breeze came faster than
12368 the ship, and soon the Pequod began to rock.
12369 
12370 By and by, through the glass the stranger’s boats and manned mast-heads
12371 proved her a whale-ship. But as she was so far to windward, and
12372 shooting by, apparently making a passage to some other ground, the
12373 Pequod could not hope to reach her. So the signal was set to see what
12374 response would be made.
12375 
12376 Here be it said, that like the vessels of military marines, the ships
12377 of the American Whale Fleet have each a private signal; all which
12378 signals being collected in a book with the names of the respective
12379 vessels attached, every captain is provided with it. Thereby, the whale
12380 commanders are enabled to recognise each other upon the ocean, even at
12381 considerable distances and with no small facility.
12382 
12383 The Pequod’s signal was at last responded to by the stranger’s setting
12384 her own; which proved the ship to be the Jeroboam of Nantucket.
12385 Squaring her yards, she bore down, ranged abeam under the Pequod’s lee,
12386 and lowered a boat; it soon drew nigh; but, as the side-ladder was
12387 being rigged by Starbuck’s order to accommodate the visiting captain,
12388 the stranger in question waved his hand from his boat’s stern in token
12389 of that proceeding being entirely unnecessary. It turned out that the
12390 Jeroboam had a malignant epidemic on board, and that Mayhew, her
12391 captain, was fearful of infecting the Pequod’s company. For, though
12392 himself and boat’s crew remained untainted, and though his ship was
12393 half a rifle-shot off, and an incorruptible sea and air rolling and
12394 flowing between; yet conscientiously adhering to the timid quarantine
12395 of the land, he peremptorily refused to come into direct contact with
12396 the Pequod.
12397 
12398 But this did by no means prevent all communications. Preserving an
12399 interval of some few yards between itself and the ship, the Jeroboam’s
12400 boat by the occasional use of its oars contrived to keep parallel to
12401 the Pequod, as she heavily forged through the sea (for by this time it
12402 blew very fresh), with her main-topsail aback; though, indeed, at times
12403 by the sudden onset of a large rolling wave, the boat would be pushed
12404 some way ahead; but would be soon skilfully brought to her proper
12405 bearings again. Subject to this, and other the like interruptions now
12406 and then, a conversation was sustained between the two parties; but at
12407 intervals not without still another interruption of a very different
12408 sort.
12409 
12410 Pulling an oar in the Jeroboam’s boat, was a man of a singular
12411 appearance, even in that wild whaling life where individual
12412 notabilities make up all totalities. He was a small, short, youngish
12413 man, sprinkled all over his face with freckles, and wearing redundant
12414 yellow hair. A long-skirted, cabalistically-cut coat of a faded walnut
12415 tinge enveloped him; the overlapping sleeves of which were rolled up on
12416 his wrists. A deep, settled, fanatic delirium was in his eyes.
12417 
12418 So soon as this figure had been first descried, Stubb had
12419 exclaimed—“That’s he! that’s he!—the long-togged scaramouch the
12420 Town-Ho’s company told us of!” Stubb here alluded to a strange story
12421 told of the Jeroboam, and a certain man among her crew, some time
12422 previous when the Pequod spoke the Town-Ho. According to this account
12423 and what was subsequently learned, it seemed that the scaramouch in
12424 question had gained a wonderful ascendency over almost everybody in the
12425 Jeroboam. His story was this:
12426 
12427 He had been originally nurtured among the crazy society of Neskyeuna
12428 Shakers, where he had been a great prophet; in their cracked, secret
12429 meetings having several times descended from heaven by the way of a
12430 trap-door, announcing the speedy opening of the seventh vial, which he
12431 carried in his vest-pocket; but, which, instead of containing
12432 gunpowder, was supposed to be charged with laudanum. A strange,
12433 apostolic whim having seized him, he had left Neskyeuna for Nantucket,
12434 where, with that cunning peculiar to craziness, he assumed a steady,
12435 common-sense exterior, and offered himself as a green-hand candidate
12436 for the Jeroboam’s whaling voyage. They engaged him; but straightway
12437 upon the ship’s getting out of sight of land, his insanity broke out in
12438 a freshet. He announced himself as the archangel Gabriel, and commanded
12439 the captain to jump overboard. He published his manifesto, whereby he
12440 set himself forth as the deliverer of the isles of the sea and
12441 vicar-general of all Oceanica. The unflinching earnestness with which
12442 he declared these things;—the dark, daring play of his sleepless,
12443 excited imagination, and all the preternatural terrors of real
12444 delirium, united to invest this Gabriel in the minds of the majority of
12445 the ignorant crew, with an atmosphere of sacredness. Moreover, they
12446 were afraid of him. As such a man, however, was not of much practical
12447 use in the ship, especially as he refused to work except when he
12448 pleased, the incredulous captain would fain have been rid of him; but
12449 apprised that that individual’s intention was to land him in the first
12450 convenient port, the archangel forthwith opened all his seals and
12451 vials—devoting the ship and all hands to unconditional perdition, in
12452 case this intention was carried out. So strongly did he work upon his
12453 disciples among the crew, that at last in a body they went to the
12454 captain and told him if Gabriel was sent from the ship, not a man of
12455 them would remain. He was therefore forced to relinquish his plan. Nor
12456 would they permit Gabriel to be any way maltreated, say or do what he
12457 would; so that it came to pass that Gabriel had the complete freedom of
12458 the ship. The consequence of all this was, that the archangel cared
12459 little or nothing for the captain and mates; and since the epidemic had
12460 broken out, he carried a higher hand than ever; declaring that the
12461 plague, as he called it, was at his sole command; nor should it be
12462 stayed but according to his good pleasure. The sailors, mostly poor
12463 devils, cringed, and some of them fawned before him; in obedience to
12464 his instructions, sometimes rendering him personal homage, as to a god.
12465 Such things may seem incredible; but, however wondrous, they are true.
12466 Nor is the history of fanatics half so striking in respect to the
12467 measureless self-deception of the fanatic himself, as his measureless
12468 power of deceiving and bedevilling so many others. But it is time to
12469 return to the Pequod.
12470 
12471 “I fear not thy epidemic, man,” said Ahab from the bulwarks, to Captain
12472 Mayhew, who stood in the boat’s stern; “come on board.”
12473 
12474 But now Gabriel started to his feet.
12475 
12476 “Think, think of the fevers, yellow and bilious! Beware of the horrible
12477 plague!”
12478 
12479 “Gabriel! Gabriel!” cried Captain Mayhew; “thou must either—” But that
12480 instant a headlong wave shot the boat far ahead, and its seethings
12481 drowned all speech.
12482 
12483 “Hast thou seen the White Whale?” demanded Ahab, when the boat drifted
12484 back.
12485 
12486 “Think, think of thy whale-boat, stoven and sunk! Beware of the
12487 horrible tail!”
12488 
12489 “I tell thee again, Gabriel, that—” But again the boat tore ahead as if
12490 dragged by fiends. Nothing was said for some moments, while a
12491 succession of riotous waves rolled by, which by one of those occasional
12492 caprices of the seas were tumbling, not heaving it. Meantime, the
12493 hoisted sperm whale’s head jogged about very violently, and Gabriel was
12494 seen eyeing it with rather more apprehensiveness than his archangel
12495 nature seemed to warrant.
12496 
12497 When this interlude was over, Captain Mayhew began a dark story
12498 concerning Moby Dick; not, however, without frequent interruptions from
12499 Gabriel, whenever his name was mentioned, and the crazy sea that seemed
12500 leagued with him.
12501 
12502 It seemed that the Jeroboam had not long left home, when upon speaking
12503 a whale-ship, her people were reliably apprised of the existence of
12504 Moby Dick, and the havoc he had made. Greedily sucking in this
12505 intelligence, Gabriel solemnly warned the captain against attacking the
12506 White Whale, in case the monster should be seen; in his gibbering
12507 insanity, pronouncing the White Whale to be no less a being than the
12508 Shaker God incarnated; the Shakers receiving the Bible. But when, some
12509 year or two afterwards, Moby Dick was fairly sighted from the
12510 mast-heads, Macey, the chief mate, burned with ardour to encounter him;
12511 and the captain himself being not unwilling to let him have the
12512 opportunity, despite all the archangel’s denunciations and
12513 forewarnings, Macey succeeded in persuading five men to man his boat.
12514 With them he pushed off; and, after much weary pulling, and many
12515 perilous, unsuccessful onsets, he at last succeeded in getting one iron
12516 fast. Meantime, Gabriel, ascending to the main-royal mast-head, was
12517 tossing one arm in frantic gestures, and hurling forth prophecies of
12518 speedy doom to the sacrilegious assailants of his divinity. Now, while
12519 Macey, the mate, was standing up in his boat’s bow, and with all the
12520 reckless energy of his tribe was venting his wild exclamations upon the
12521 whale, and essaying to get a fair chance for his poised lance, lo! a
12522 broad white shadow rose from the sea; by its quick, fanning motion,
12523 temporarily taking the breath out of the bodies of the oarsmen. Next
12524 instant, the luckless mate, so full of furious life, was smitten bodily
12525 into the air, and making a long arc in his descent, fell into the sea
12526 at the distance of about fifty yards. Not a chip of the boat was
12527 harmed, nor a hair of any oarsman’s head; but the mate for ever sank.
12528 
12529 It is well to parenthesize here, that of the fatal accidents in the
12530 Sperm-Whale Fishery, this kind is perhaps almost as frequent as any.
12531 Sometimes, nothing is injured but the man who is thus annihilated;
12532 oftener the boat’s bow is knocked off, or the thigh-board, in which the
12533 headsman stands, is torn from its place and accompanies the body. But
12534 strangest of all is the circumstance, that in more instances than one,
12535 when the body has been recovered, not a single mark of violence is
12536 discernible; the man being stark dead.
12537 
12538 The whole calamity, with the falling form of Macey, was plainly
12539 descried from the ship. Raising a piercing shriek—“The vial! the vial!”
12540 Gabriel called off the terror-stricken crew from the further hunting of
12541 the whale. This terrible event clothed the archangel with added
12542 influence; because his credulous disciples believed that he had
12543 specifically fore-announced it, instead of only making a general
12544 prophecy, which any one might have done, and so have chanced to hit one
12545 of many marks in the wide margin allowed. He became a nameless terror
12546 to the ship.
12547 
12548 Mayhew having concluded his narration, Ahab put such questions to him,
12549 that the stranger captain could not forbear inquiring whether he
12550 intended to hunt the White Whale, if opportunity should offer. To which
12551 Ahab answered—“Aye.” Straightway, then, Gabriel once more started to
12552 his feet, glaring upon the old man, and vehemently exclaimed, with
12553 downward pointed finger—“Think, think of the blasphemer—dead, and down
12554 there!—beware of the blasphemer’s end!”
12555 
12556 Ahab stolidly turned aside; then said to Mayhew, “Captain, I have just
12557 bethought me of my letter-bag; there is a letter for one of thy
12558 officers, if I mistake not. Starbuck, look over the bag.”
12559 
12560 Every whale-ship takes out a goodly number of letters for various
12561 ships, whose delivery to the persons to whom they may be addressed,
12562 depends upon the mere chance of encountering them in the four oceans.
12563 Thus, most letters never reach their mark; and many are only received
12564 after attaining an age of two or three years or more.
12565 
12566 Soon Starbuck returned with a letter in his hand. It was sorely
12567 tumbled, damp, and covered with a dull, spotted, green mould, in
12568 consequence of being kept in a dark locker of the cabin. Of such a
12569 letter, Death himself might well have been the post-boy.
12570 
12571 “Can’st not read it?” cried Ahab. “Give it me, man. Aye, aye, it’s but
12572 a dim scrawl;—what’s this?” As he was studying it out, Starbuck took a
12573 long cutting-spade pole, and with his knife slightly split the end, to
12574 insert the letter there, and in that way, hand it to the boat, without
12575 its coming any closer to the ship.
12576 
12577 Meantime, Ahab holding the letter, muttered, “Mr. Har—yes, Mr. Harry—(a
12578 woman’s pinny hand,—the man’s wife, I’ll wager)—Aye—Mr. Harry Macey,
12579 Ship Jeroboam;—why it’s Macey, and he’s dead!”
12580 
12581 “Poor fellow! poor fellow! and from his wife,” sighed Mayhew; “but let
12582 me have it.”
12583 
12584 “Nay, keep it thyself,” cried Gabriel to Ahab; “thou art soon going
12585 that way.”
12586 
12587 “Curses throttle thee!” yelled Ahab. “Captain Mayhew, stand by now to
12588 receive it”; and taking the fatal missive from Starbuck’s hands, he
12589 caught it in the slit of the pole, and reached it over towards the
12590 boat. But as he did so, the oarsmen expectantly desisted from rowing;
12591 the boat drifted a little towards the ship’s stern; so that, as if by
12592 magic, the letter suddenly ranged along with Gabriel’s eager hand. He
12593 clutched it in an instant, seized the boat-knife, and impaling the
12594 letter on it, sent it thus loaded back into the ship. It fell at Ahab’s
12595 feet. Then Gabriel shrieked out to his comrades to give way with their
12596 oars, and in that manner the mutinous boat rapidly shot away from the
12597 Pequod.
12598 
12599 As, after this interlude, the seamen resumed their work upon the jacket
12600 of the whale, many strange things were hinted in reference to this wild
12601 affair.
12602 
12603 
12604 CHAPTER 72. The Monkey-Rope.
12605 
12606 In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a whale,
12607 there is much running backwards and forwards among the crew. Now hands
12608 are wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there. There is no
12609 staying in any one place; for at one and the same time everything has
12610 to be done everywhere. It is much the same with him who endeavors the
12611 description of the scene. We must now retrace our way a little. It was
12612 mentioned that upon first breaking ground in the whale’s back, the
12613 blubber-hook was inserted into the original hole there cut by the
12614 spades of the mates. But how did so clumsy and weighty a mass as that
12615 same hook get fixed in that hole? It was inserted there by my
12616 particular friend Queequeg, whose duty it was, as harpooneer, to
12617 descend upon the monster’s back for the special purpose referred to.
12618 But in very many cases, circumstances require that the harpooneer shall
12619 remain on the whale till the whole flensing or stripping operation is
12620 concluded. The whale, be it observed, lies almost entirely submerged,
12621 excepting the immediate parts operated upon. So down there, some ten
12622 feet below the level of the deck, the poor harpooneer flounders about,
12623 half on the whale and half in the water, as the vast mass revolves like
12624 a tread-mill beneath him. On the occasion in question, Queequeg figured
12625 in the Highland costume—a shirt and socks—in which to my eyes, at
12626 least, he appeared to uncommon advantage; and no one had a better
12627 chance to observe him, as will presently be seen.
12628 
12629 Being the savage’s bowsman, that is, the person who pulled the bow-oar
12630 in his boat (the second one from forward), it was my cheerful duty to
12631 attend upon him while taking that hard-scrabble scramble upon the dead
12632 whale’s back. You have seen Italian organ-boys holding a dancing-ape by
12633 a long cord. Just so, from the ship’s steep side, did I hold Queequeg
12634 down there in the sea, by what is technically called in the fishery a
12635 monkey-rope, attached to a strong strip of canvas belted round his
12636 waist.
12637 
12638 It was a humorously perilous business for both of us. For, before we
12639 proceed further, it must be said that the monkey-rope was fast at both
12640 ends; fast to Queequeg’s broad canvas belt, and fast to my narrow
12641 leather one. So that for better or for worse, we two, for the time,
12642 were wedded; and should poor Queequeg sink to rise no more, then both
12643 usage and honor demanded, that instead of cutting the cord, it should
12644 drag me down in his wake. So, then, an elongated Siamese ligature
12645 united us. Queequeg was my own inseparable twin brother; nor could I
12646 any way get rid of the dangerous liabilities which the hempen bond
12647 entailed.
12648 
12649 So strongly and metaphysically did I conceive of my situation then,
12650 that while earnestly watching his motions, I seemed distinctly to
12651 perceive that my own individuality was now merged in a joint stock
12652 company of two; that my free will had received a mortal wound; and that
12653 another’s mistake or misfortune might plunge innocent me into unmerited
12654 disaster and death. Therefore, I saw that here was a sort of
12655 interregnum in Providence; for its even-handed equity never could have
12656 so gross an injustice. And yet still further pondering—while I jerked
12657 him now and then from between the whale and ship, which would threaten
12658 to jam him—still further pondering, I say, I saw that this situation of
12659 mine was the precise situation of every mortal that breathes; only, in
12660 most cases, he, one way or other, has this Siamese connexion with a
12661 plurality of other mortals. If your banker breaks, you snap; if your
12662 apothecary by mistake sends you poison in your pills, you die. True,
12663 you may say that, by exceeding caution, you may possibly escape these
12664 and the multitudinous other evil chances of life. But handle Queequeg’s
12665 monkey-rope heedfully as I would, sometimes he jerked it so, that I
12666 came very near sliding overboard. Nor could I possibly forget that, do
12667 what I would, I only had the management of one end of it.*
12668 
12669 *The monkey-rope is found in all whalers; but it was only in the Pequod
12670 that the monkey and his holder were ever tied together. This
12671 improvement upon the original usage was introduced by no less a man
12672 than Stubb, in order to afford the imperilled harpooneer the strongest
12673 possible guarantee for the faithfulness and vigilance of his
12674 monkey-rope holder.
12675 
12676 I have hinted that I would often jerk poor Queequeg from between the
12677 whale and the ship—where he would occasionally fall, from the incessant
12678 rolling and swaying of both. But this was not the only jamming jeopardy
12679 he was exposed to. Unappalled by the massacre made upon them during the
12680 night, the sharks now freshly and more keenly allured by the before
12681 pent blood which began to flow from the carcass—the rabid creatures
12682 swarmed round it like bees in a beehive.
12683 
12684 And right in among those sharks was Queequeg; who often pushed them
12685 aside with his floundering feet. A thing altogether incredible were it
12686 not that attracted by such prey as a dead whale, the otherwise
12687 miscellaneously carnivorous shark will seldom touch a man.
12688 
12689 Nevertheless, it may well be believed that since they have such a
12690 ravenous finger in the pie, it is deemed but wise to look sharp to
12691 them. Accordingly, besides the monkey-rope, with which I now and then
12692 jerked the poor fellow from too close a vicinity to the maw of what
12693 seemed a peculiarly ferocious shark—he was provided with still another
12694 protection. Suspended over the side in one of the stages, Tashtego and
12695 Daggoo continually flourished over his head a couple of keen
12696 whale-spades, wherewith they slaughtered as many sharks as they could
12697 reach. This procedure of theirs, to be sure, was very disinterested and
12698 benevolent of them. They meant Queequeg’s best happiness, I admit; but
12699 in their hasty zeal to befriend him, and from the circumstance that
12700 both he and the sharks were at times half hidden by the blood-muddled
12701 water, those indiscreet spades of theirs would come nearer amputating a
12702 leg than a tail. But poor Queequeg, I suppose, straining and gasping
12703 there with that great iron hook—poor Queequeg, I suppose, only prayed
12704 to his Yojo, and gave up his life into the hands of his gods.
12705 
12706 Well, well, my dear comrade and twin-brother, thought I, as I drew in
12707 and then slacked off the rope to every swell of the sea—what matters
12708 it, after all? Are you not the precious image of each and all of us men
12709 in this whaling world? That unsounded ocean you gasp in, is Life; those
12710 sharks, your foes; those spades, your friends; and what between sharks
12711 and spades you are in a sad pickle and peril, poor lad.
12712 
12713 But courage! there is good cheer in store for you, Queequeg. For now,
12714 as with blue lips and blood-shot eyes the exhausted savage at last
12715 climbs up the chains and stands all dripping and involuntarily
12716 trembling over the side; the steward advances, and with a benevolent,
12717 consolatory glance hands him—what? Some hot Cognac? No! hands him, ye
12718 gods! hands him a cup of tepid ginger and water!
12719 
12720 “Ginger? Do I smell ginger?” suspiciously asked Stubb, coming near.
12721 “Yes, this must be ginger,” peering into the as yet untasted cup. Then
12722 standing as if incredulous for a while, he calmly walked towards the
12723 astonished steward slowly saying, “Ginger? ginger? and will you have
12724 the goodness to tell me, Mr. Dough-Boy, where lies the virtue of
12725 ginger? Ginger! is ginger the sort of fuel you use, Dough-boy, to
12726 kindle a fire in this shivering cannibal? Ginger!—what the devil is
12727 ginger? Sea-coal? firewood?—lucifer matches?—tinder?—gunpowder?—what
12728 the devil is ginger, I say, that you offer this cup to our poor
12729 Queequeg here.”
12730 
12731 “There is some sneaking Temperance Society movement about this
12732 business,” he suddenly added, now approaching Starbuck, who had just
12733 come from forward. “Will you look at that kannakin, sir: smell of it,
12734 if you please.” Then watching the mate’s countenance, he added, “The
12735 steward, Mr. Starbuck, had the face to offer that calomel and jalap to
12736 Queequeg, there, this instant off the whale. Is the steward an
12737 apothecary, sir? and may I ask whether this is the sort of bitters by
12738 which he blows back the life into a half-drowned man?”
12739 
12740 “I trust not,” said Starbuck, “it is poor stuff enough.”
12741 
12742 “Aye, aye, steward,” cried Stubb, “we’ll teach you to drug a
12743 harpooneer; none of your apothecary’s medicine here; you want to poison
12744 us, do ye? You have got out insurances on our lives and want to murder
12745 us all, and pocket the proceeds, do ye?”
12746 
12747 “It was not me,” cried Dough-Boy, “it was Aunt Charity that brought the
12748 ginger on board; and bade me never give the harpooneers any spirits,
12749 but only this ginger-jub—so she called it.”
12750 
12751 “Ginger-jub! you gingerly rascal! take that! and run along with ye to
12752 the lockers, and get something better. I hope I do no wrong, Mr.
12753 Starbuck. It is the captain’s orders—grog for the harpooneer on a
12754 whale.”
12755 
12756 “Enough,” replied Starbuck, “only don’t hit him again, but—”
12757 
12758 “Oh, I never hurt when I hit, except when I hit a whale or something of
12759 that sort; and this fellow’s a weazel. What were you about saying,
12760 sir?”
12761 
12762 “Only this: go down with him, and get what thou wantest thyself.”
12763 
12764 When Stubb reappeared, he came with a dark flask in one hand, and a
12765 sort of tea-caddy in the other. The first contained strong spirits, and
12766 was handed to Queequeg; the second was Aunt Charity’s gift, and that
12767 was freely given to the waves.
12768 
12769 
12770 CHAPTER 73. Stubb and Flask kill a Right Whale; and Then Have a Talk
12771 over Him.
12772 
12773 It must be borne in mind that all this time we have a Sperm Whale’s
12774 prodigious head hanging to the Pequod’s side. But we must let it
12775 continue hanging there a while till we can get a chance to attend to
12776 it. For the present other matters press, and the best we can do now for
12777 the head, is to pray heaven the tackles may hold.
12778 
12779 Now, during the past night and forenoon, the Pequod had gradually
12780 drifted into a sea, which, by its occasional patches of yellow brit,
12781 gave unusual tokens of the vicinity of Right Whales, a species of the
12782 Leviathan that but few supposed to be at this particular time lurking
12783 anywhere near. And though all hands commonly disdained the capture of
12784 those inferior creatures; and though the Pequod was not commissioned to
12785 cruise for them at all, and though she had passed numbers of them near
12786 the Crozetts without lowering a boat; yet now that a Sperm Whale had
12787 been brought alongside and beheaded, to the surprise of all, the
12788 announcement was made that a Right Whale should be captured that day,
12789 if opportunity offered.
12790 
12791 Nor was this long wanting. Tall spouts were seen to leeward; and two
12792 boats, Stubb’s and Flask’s, were detached in pursuit. Pulling further
12793 and further away, they at last became almost invisible to the men at
12794 the mast-head. But suddenly in the distance, they saw a great heap of
12795 tumultuous white water, and soon after news came from aloft that one or
12796 both the boats must be fast. An interval passed and the boats were in
12797 plain sight, in the act of being dragged right towards the ship by the
12798 towing whale. So close did the monster come to the hull, that at first
12799 it seemed as if he meant it malice; but suddenly going down in a
12800 maelstrom, within three rods of the planks, he wholly disappeared from
12801 view, as if diving under the keel. “Cut, cut!” was the cry from the
12802 ship to the boats, which, for one instant, seemed on the point of being
12803 brought with a deadly dash against the vessel’s side. But having plenty
12804 of line yet in the tubs, and the whale not sounding very rapidly, they
12805 paid out abundance of rope, and at the same time pulled with all their
12806 might so as to get ahead of the ship. For a few minutes the struggle
12807 was intensely critical; for while they still slacked out the tightened
12808 line in one direction, and still plied their oars in another, the
12809 contending strain threatened to take them under. But it was only a few
12810 feet advance they sought to gain. And they stuck to it till they did
12811 gain it; when instantly, a swift tremor was felt running like lightning
12812 along the keel, as the strained line, scraping beneath the ship,
12813 suddenly rose to view under her bows, snapping and quivering; and so
12814 flinging off its drippings, that the drops fell like bits of broken
12815 glass on the water, while the whale beyond also rose to sight, and once
12816 more the boats were free to fly. But the fagged whale abated his speed,
12817 and blindly altering his course, went round the stern of the ship
12818 towing the two boats after him, so that they performed a complete
12819 circuit.
12820 
12821 Meantime, they hauled more and more upon their lines, till close
12822 flanking him on both sides, Stubb answered Flask with lance for lance;
12823 and thus round and round the Pequod the battle went, while the
12824 multitudes of sharks that had before swum round the Sperm Whale’s body,
12825 rushed to the fresh blood that was spilled, thirstily drinking at every
12826 new gash, as the eager Israelites did at the new bursting fountains
12827 that poured from the smitten rock.
12828 
12829 At last his spout grew thick, and with a frightful roll and vomit, he
12830 turned upon his back a corpse.
12831 
12832 While the two headsmen were engaged in making fast cords to his flukes,
12833 and in other ways getting the mass in readiness for towing, some
12834 conversation ensued between them.
12835 
12836 “I wonder what the old man wants with this lump of foul lard,” said
12837 Stubb, not without some disgust at the thought of having to do with so
12838 ignoble a leviathan.
12839 
12840 “Wants with it?” said Flask, coiling some spare line in the boat’s bow,
12841 “did you never hear that the ship which but once has a Sperm Whale’s
12842 head hoisted on her starboard side, and at the same time a Right
12843 Whale’s on the larboard; did you never hear, Stubb, that that ship can
12844 never afterwards capsize?”
12845 
12846 “Why not?
12847 
12848 “I don’t know, but I heard that gamboge ghost of a Fedallah saying so,
12849 and he seems to know all about ships’ charms. But I sometimes think
12850 he’ll charm the ship to no good at last. I don’t half like that chap,
12851 Stubb. Did you ever notice how that tusk of his is a sort of carved
12852 into a snake’s head, Stubb?”
12853 
12854 “Sink him! I never look at him at all; but if ever I get a chance of a
12855 dark night, and he standing hard by the bulwarks, and no one by; look
12856 down there, Flask”—pointing into the sea with a peculiar motion of both
12857 hands—“Aye, will I! Flask, I take that Fedallah to be the devil in
12858 disguise. Do you believe that cock and bull story about his having been
12859 stowed away on board ship? He’s the devil, I say. The reason why you
12860 don’t see his tail, is because he tucks it up out of sight; he carries
12861 it coiled away in his pocket, I guess. Blast him! now that I think of
12862 it, he’s always wanting oakum to stuff into the toes of his boots.”
12863 
12864 “He sleeps in his boots, don’t he? He hasn’t got any hammock; but I’ve
12865 seen him lay of nights in a coil of rigging.”
12866 
12867 “No doubt, and it’s because of his cursed tail; he coils it down, do ye
12868 see, in the eye of the rigging.”
12869 
12870 “What’s the old man have so much to do with him for?”
12871 
12872 “Striking up a swap or a bargain, I suppose.”
12873 
12874 “Bargain?—about what?”
12875 
12876 “Why, do ye see, the old man is hard bent after that White Whale, and
12877 the devil there is trying to come round him, and get him to swap away
12878 his silver watch, or his soul, or something of that sort, and then
12879 he’ll surrender Moby Dick.”
12880 
12881 “Pooh! Stubb, you are skylarking; how can Fedallah do that?”
12882 
12883 “I don’t know, Flask, but the devil is a curious chap, and a wicked
12884 one, I tell ye. Why, they say as how he went a sauntering into the old
12885 flag-ship once, switching his tail about devilish easy and
12886 gentlemanlike, and inquiring if the old governor was at home. Well, he
12887 was at home, and asked the devil what he wanted. The devil, switching
12888 his hoofs, up and says, ‘I want John.’ ‘What for?’ says the old
12889 governor. ‘What business is that of yours,’ says the devil, getting
12890 mad,—‘I want to use him.’ ‘Take him,’ says the governor—and by the
12891 Lord, Flask, if the devil didn’t give John the Asiatic cholera before
12892 he got through with him, I’ll eat this whale in one mouthful. But look
12893 sharp—ain’t you all ready there? Well, then, pull ahead, and let’s get
12894 the whale alongside.”
12895 
12896 “I think I remember some such story as you were telling,” said Flask,
12897 when at last the two boats were slowly advancing with their burden
12898 towards the ship, “but I can’t remember where.”
12899 
12900 “Three Spaniards? Adventures of those three bloody-minded soldadoes?
12901 Did ye read it there, Flask? I guess ye did?”
12902 
12903 “No: never saw such a book; heard of it, though. But now, tell me,
12904 Stubb, do you suppose that that devil you was speaking of just now, was
12905 the same you say is now on board the Pequod?”
12906 
12907 “Am I the same man that helped kill this whale? Doesn’t the devil live
12908 for ever; who ever heard that the devil was dead? Did you ever see any
12909 parson a wearing mourning for the devil? And if the devil has a
12910 latch-key to get into the admiral’s cabin, don’t you suppose he can
12911 crawl into a porthole? Tell me that, Mr. Flask?”
12912 
12913 “How old do you suppose Fedallah is, Stubb?”
12914 
12915 “Do you see that mainmast there?” pointing to the ship; “well, that’s
12916 the figure one; now take all the hoops in the Pequod’s hold, and string
12917 along in a row with that mast, for oughts, do you see; well, that
12918 wouldn’t begin to be Fedallah’s age. Nor all the coopers in creation
12919 couldn’t show hoops enough to make oughts enough.”
12920 
12921 “But see here, Stubb, I thought you a little boasted just now, that you
12922 meant to give Fedallah a sea-toss, if you got a good chance. Now, if
12923 he’s so old as all those hoops of yours come to, and if he is going to
12924 live for ever, what good will it do to pitch him overboard—tell me
12925 that?
12926 
12927 “Give him a good ducking, anyhow.”
12928 
12929 “But he’d crawl back.”
12930 
12931 “Duck him again; and keep ducking him.”
12932 
12933 “Suppose he should take it into his head to duck you, though—yes, and
12934 drown you—what then?”
12935 
12936 “I should like to see him try it; I’d give him such a pair of black
12937 eyes that he wouldn’t dare to show his face in the admiral’s cabin
12938 again for a long while, let alone down in the orlop there, where he
12939 lives, and hereabouts on the upper decks where he sneaks so much. Damn
12940 the devil, Flask; so you suppose I’m afraid of the devil? Who’s afraid
12941 of him, except the old governor who daresn’t catch him and put him in
12942 double-darbies, as he deserves, but lets him go about kidnapping
12943 people; aye, and signed a bond with him, that all the people the devil
12944 kidnapped, he’d roast for him? There’s a governor!”
12945 
12946 “Do you suppose Fedallah wants to kidnap Captain Ahab?”
12947 
12948 “Do I suppose it? You’ll know it before long, Flask. But I am going now
12949 to keep a sharp look-out on him; and if I see anything very suspicious
12950 going on, I’ll just take him by the nape of his neck, and say—Look
12951 here, Beelzebub, you don’t do it; and if he makes any fuss, by the Lord
12952 I’ll make a grab into his pocket for his tail, take it to the capstan,
12953 and give him such a wrenching and heaving, that his tail will come
12954 short off at the stump—do you see; and then, I rather guess when he
12955 finds himself docked in that queer fashion, he’ll sneak off without the
12956 poor satisfaction of feeling his tail between his legs.”
12957 
12958 “And what will you do with the tail, Stubb?”
12959 
12960 “Do with it? Sell it for an ox whip when we get home;—what else?”
12961 
12962 “Now, do you mean what you say, and have been saying all along, Stubb?”
12963 
12964 “Mean or not mean, here we are at the ship.”
12965 
12966 The boats were here hailed, to tow the whale on the larboard side,
12967 where fluke chains and other necessaries were already prepared for
12968 securing him.
12969 
12970 “Didn’t I tell you so?” said Flask; “yes, you’ll soon see this right
12971 whale’s head hoisted up opposite that parmacetti’s.”
12972 
12973 In good time, Flask’s saying proved true. As before, the Pequod steeply
12974 leaned over towards the sperm whale’s head, now, by the counterpoise of
12975 both heads, she regained her even keel; though sorely strained, you may
12976 well believe. So, when on one side you hoist in Locke’s head, you go
12977 over that way; but now, on the other side, hoist in Kant’s and you come
12978 back again; but in very poor plight. Thus, some minds for ever keep
12979 trimming boat. Oh, ye foolish! throw all these thunder-heads overboard,
12980 and then you will float light and right.
12981 
12982 In disposing of the body of a right whale, when brought alongside the
12983 ship, the same preliminary proceedings commonly take place as in the
12984 case of a sperm whale; only, in the latter instance, the head is cut
12985 off whole, but in the former the lips and tongue are separately removed
12986 and hoisted on deck, with all the well known black bone attached to
12987 what is called the crown-piece. But nothing like this, in the present
12988 case, had been done. The carcases of both whales had dropped astern;
12989 and the head-laden ship not a little resembled a mule carrying a pair
12990 of overburdening panniers.
12991 
12992 Meantime, Fedallah was calmly eyeing the right whale’s head, and ever
12993 and anon glancing from the deep wrinkles there to the lines in his own
12994 hand. And Ahab chanced so to stand, that the Parsee occupied his
12995 shadow; while, if the Parsee’s shadow was there at all it seemed only
12996 to blend with, and lengthen Ahab’s. As the crew toiled on, Laplandish
12997 speculations were bandied among them, concerning all these passing
12998 things.
12999 
13000 
13001 CHAPTER 74. The Sperm Whale’s Head—Contrasted View.
13002 
13003 Here, now, are two great whales, laying their heads together; let us
13004 join them, and lay together our own.
13005 
13006 Of the grand order of folio leviathans, the Sperm Whale and the Right
13007 Whale are by far the most noteworthy. They are the only whales
13008 regularly hunted by man. To the Nantucketer, they present the two
13009 extremes of all the known varieties of the whale. As the external
13010 difference between them is mainly observable in their heads; and as a
13011 head of each is this moment hanging from the Pequod’s side; and as we
13012 may freely go from one to the other, by merely stepping across the
13013 deck:—where, I should like to know, will you obtain a better chance to
13014 study practical cetology than here?
13015 
13016 In the first place, you are struck by the general contrast between
13017 these heads. Both are massive enough in all conscience; but there is a
13018 certain mathematical symmetry in the Sperm Whale’s which the Right
13019 Whale’s sadly lacks. There is more character in the Sperm Whale’s head.
13020 As you behold it, you involuntarily yield the immense superiority to
13021 him, in point of pervading dignity. In the present instance, too, this
13022 dignity is heightened by the pepper and salt colour of his head at the
13023 summit, giving token of advanced age and large experience. In short, he
13024 is what the fishermen technically call a “grey-headed whale.”
13025 
13026 Let us now note what is least dissimilar in these heads—namely, the two
13027 most important organs, the eye and the ear. Far back on the side of the
13028 head, and low down, near the angle of either whale’s jaw, if you
13029 narrowly search, you will at last see a lashless eye, which you would
13030 fancy to be a young colt’s eye; so out of all proportion is it to the
13031 magnitude of the head.
13032 
13033 Now, from this peculiar sideway position of the whale’s eyes, it is
13034 plain that he can never see an object which is exactly ahead, no more
13035 than he can one exactly astern. In a word, the position of the whale’s
13036 eyes corresponds to that of a man’s ears; and you may fancy, for
13037 yourself, how it would fare with you, did you sideways survey objects
13038 through your ears. You would find that you could only command some
13039 thirty degrees of vision in advance of the straight side-line of sight;
13040 and about thirty more behind it. If your bitterest foe were walking
13041 straight towards you, with dagger uplifted in broad day, you would not
13042 be able to see him, any more than if he were stealing upon you from
13043 behind. In a word, you would have two backs, so to speak; but, at the
13044 same time, also, two fronts (side fronts): for what is it that makes
13045 the front of a man—what, indeed, but his eyes?
13046 
13047 Moreover, while in most other animals that I can now think of, the eyes
13048 are so planted as imperceptibly to blend their visual power, so as to
13049 produce one picture and not two to the brain; the peculiar position of
13050 the whale’s eyes, effectually divided as they are by many cubic feet of
13051 solid head, which towers between them like a great mountain separating
13052 two lakes in valleys; this, of course, must wholly separate the
13053 impressions which each independent organ imparts. The whale, therefore,
13054 must see one distinct picture on this side, and another distinct
13055 picture on that side; while all between must be profound darkness and
13056 nothingness to him. Man may, in effect, be said to look out on the
13057 world from a sentry-box with two joined sashes for his window. But with
13058 the whale, these two sashes are separately inserted, making two
13059 distinct windows, but sadly impairing the view. This peculiarity of the
13060 whale’s eyes is a thing always to be borne in mind in the fishery; and
13061 to be remembered by the reader in some subsequent scenes.
13062 
13063 A curious and most puzzling question might be started concerning this
13064 visual matter as touching the Leviathan. But I must be content with a
13065 hint. So long as a man’s eyes are open in the light, the act of seeing
13066 is involuntary; that is, he cannot then help mechanically seeing
13067 whatever objects are before him. Nevertheless, any one’s experience
13068 will teach him, that though he can take in an undiscriminating sweep of
13069 things at one glance, it is quite impossible for him, attentively, and
13070 completely, to examine any two things—however large or however small—at
13071 one and the same instant of time; never mind if they lie side by side
13072 and touch each other. But if you now come to separate these two
13073 objects, and surround each by a circle of profound darkness; then, in
13074 order to see one of them, in such a manner as to bring your mind to
13075 bear on it, the other will be utterly excluded from your contemporary
13076 consciousness. How is it, then, with the whale? True, both his eyes, in
13077 themselves, must simultaneously act; but is his brain so much more
13078 comprehensive, combining, and subtle than man’s, that he can at the
13079 same moment of time attentively examine two distinct prospects, one on
13080 one side of him, and the other in an exactly opposite direction? If he
13081 can, then is it as marvellous a thing in him, as if a man were able
13082 simultaneously to go through the demonstrations of two distinct
13083 problems in Euclid. Nor, strictly investigated, is there any
13084 incongruity in this comparison.
13085 
13086 It may be but an idle whim, but it has always seemed to me, that the
13087 extraordinary vacillations of movement displayed by some whales when
13088 beset by three or four boats; the timidity and liability to queer
13089 frights, so common to such whales; I think that all this indirectly
13090 proceeds from the helpless perplexity of volition, in which their
13091 divided and diametrically opposite powers of vision must involve them.
13092 
13093 But the ear of the whale is full as curious as the eye. If you are an
13094 entire stranger to their race, you might hunt over these two heads for
13095 hours, and never discover that organ. The ear has no external leaf
13096 whatever; and into the hole itself you can hardly insert a quill, so
13097 wondrously minute is it. It is lodged a little behind the eye. With
13098 respect to their ears, this important difference is to be observed
13099 between the sperm whale and the right. While the ear of the former has
13100 an external opening, that of the latter is entirely and evenly covered
13101 over with a membrane, so as to be quite imperceptible from without.
13102 
13103 Is it not curious, that so vast a being as the whale should see the
13104 world through so small an eye, and hear the thunder through an ear
13105 which is smaller than a hare’s? But if his eyes were broad as the lens
13106 of Herschel’s great telescope; and his ears capacious as the porches of
13107 cathedrals; would that make him any longer of sight, or sharper of
13108 hearing? Not at all.—Why then do you try to “enlarge” your mind?
13109 Subtilize it.
13110 
13111 Let us now with whatever levers and steam-engines we have at hand, cant
13112 over the sperm whale’s head, that it may lie bottom up; then, ascending
13113 by a ladder to the summit, have a peep down the mouth; and were it not
13114 that the body is now completely separated from it, with a lantern we
13115 might descend into the great Kentucky Mammoth Cave of his stomach. But
13116 let us hold on here by this tooth, and look about us where we are. What
13117 a really beautiful and chaste-looking mouth! from floor to ceiling,
13118 lined, or rather papered with a glistening white membrane, glossy as
13119 bridal satins.
13120 
13121 But come out now, and look at this portentous lower jaw, which seems
13122 like the long narrow lid of an immense snuff-box, with the hinge at one
13123 end, instead of one side. If you pry it up, so as to get it overhead,
13124 and expose its rows of teeth, it seems a terrific portcullis; and such,
13125 alas! it proves to many a poor wight in the fishery, upon whom these
13126 spikes fall with impaling force. But far more terrible is it to behold,
13127 when fathoms down in the sea, you see some sulky whale, floating there
13128 suspended, with his prodigious jaw, some fifteen feet long, hanging
13129 straight down at right-angles with his body, for all the world like a
13130 ship’s jib-boom. This whale is not dead; he is only dispirited; out of
13131 sorts, perhaps; hypochondriac; and so supine, that the hinges of his
13132 jaw have relaxed, leaving him there in that ungainly sort of plight, a
13133 reproach to all his tribe, who must, no doubt, imprecate lock-jaws upon
13134 him.
13135 
13136 In most cases this lower jaw—being easily unhinged by a practised
13137 artist—is disengaged and hoisted on deck for the purpose of extracting
13138 the ivory teeth, and furnishing a supply of that hard white whalebone
13139 with which the fishermen fashion all sorts of curious articles,
13140 including canes, umbrella-stocks, and handles to riding-whips.
13141 
13142 With a long, weary hoist the jaw is dragged on board, as if it were an
13143 anchor; and when the proper time comes—some few days after the other
13144 work—Queequeg, Daggoo, and Tashtego, being all accomplished dentists,
13145 are set to drawing teeth. With a keen cutting-spade, Queequeg lances
13146 the gums; then the jaw is lashed down to ringbolts, and a tackle being
13147 rigged from aloft, they drag out these teeth, as Michigan oxen drag
13148 stumps of old oaks out of wild wood lands. There are generally
13149 forty-two teeth in all; in old whales, much worn down, but undecayed;
13150 nor filled after our artificial fashion. The jaw is afterwards sawn
13151 into slabs, and piled away like joists for building houses.
13152 
13153 
13154 CHAPTER 75. The Right Whale’s Head—Contrasted View.
13155 
13156 Crossing the deck, let us now have a good long look at the Right
13157 Whale’s head.
13158 
13159 As in general shape the noble Sperm Whale’s head may be compared to a
13160 Roman war-chariot (especially in front, where it is so broadly
13161 rounded); so, at a broad view, the Right Whale’s head bears a rather
13162 inelegant resemblance to a gigantic galliot-toed shoe. Two hundred
13163 years ago an old Dutch voyager likened its shape to that of a
13164 shoemaker’s last. And in this same last or shoe, that old woman of the
13165 nursery tale, with the swarming brood, might very comfortably be
13166 lodged, she and all her progeny.
13167 
13168 But as you come nearer to this great head it begins to assume different
13169 aspects, according to your point of view. If you stand on its summit
13170 and look at these two F-shaped spoutholes, you would take the whole
13171 head for an enormous bass-viol, and these spiracles, the apertures in
13172 its sounding-board. Then, again, if you fix your eye upon this strange,
13173 crested, comb-like incrustation on the top of the mass—this green,
13174 barnacled thing, which the Greenlanders call the “crown,” and the
13175 Southern fishers the “bonnet” of the Right Whale; fixing your eyes
13176 solely on this, you would take the head for the trunk of some huge oak,
13177 with a bird’s nest in its crotch. At any rate, when you watch those
13178 live crabs that nestle here on this bonnet, such an idea will be almost
13179 sure to occur to you; unless, indeed, your fancy has been fixed by the
13180 technical term “crown” also bestowed upon it; in which case you will
13181 take great interest in thinking how this mighty monster is actually a
13182 diademed king of the sea, whose green crown has been put together for
13183 him in this marvellous manner. But if this whale be a king, he is a
13184 very sulky looking fellow to grace a diadem. Look at that hanging lower
13185 lip! what a huge sulk and pout is there! a sulk and pout, by
13186 carpenter’s measurement, about twenty feet long and five feet deep; a
13187 sulk and pout that will yield you some 500 gallons of oil and more.
13188 
13189 A great pity, now, that this unfortunate whale should be hare-lipped.
13190 The fissure is about a foot across. Probably the mother during an
13191 important interval was sailing down the Peruvian coast, when
13192 earthquakes caused the beach to gape. Over this lip, as over a slippery
13193 threshold, we now slide into the mouth. Upon my word were I at
13194 Mackinaw, I should take this to be the inside of an Indian wigwam. Good
13195 Lord! is this the road that Jonah went? The roof is about twelve feet
13196 high, and runs to a pretty sharp angle, as if there were a regular
13197 ridge-pole there; while these ribbed, arched, hairy sides, present us
13198 with those wondrous, half vertical, scimetar-shaped slats of whalebone,
13199 say three hundred on a side, which depending from the upper part of the
13200 head or crown bone, form those Venetian blinds which have elsewhere
13201 been cursorily mentioned. The edges of these bones are fringed with
13202 hairy fibres, through which the Right Whale strains the water, and in
13203 whose intricacies he retains the small fish, when openmouthed he goes
13204 through the seas of brit in feeding time. In the central blinds of
13205 bone, as they stand in their natural order, there are certain curious
13206 marks, curves, hollows, and ridges, whereby some whalemen calculate the
13207 creature’s age, as the age of an oak by its circular rings. Though the
13208 certainty of this criterion is far from demonstrable, yet it has the
13209 savor of analogical probability. At any rate, if we yield to it, we
13210 must grant a far greater age to the Right Whale than at first glance
13211 will seem reasonable.
13212 
13213 In old times, there seem to have prevailed the most curious fancies
13214 concerning these blinds. One voyager in Purchas calls them the wondrous
13215 “whiskers” inside of the whale’s mouth;* another, “hogs’ bristles”; a
13216 third old gentleman in Hackluyt uses the following elegant language:
13217 “There are about two hundred and fifty fins growing on each side of his
13218 upper _chop_, which arch over his tongue on each side of his mouth.”
13219 
13220 *This reminds us that the Right Whale really has a sort of whisker, or
13221 rather a moustache, consisting of a few scattered white hairs on the
13222 upper part of the outer end of the lower jaw. Sometimes these tufts
13223 impart a rather brigandish expression to his otherwise solemn
13224 countenance.
13225 
13226 As every one knows, these same “hogs’ bristles,” “fins,” “whiskers,”
13227 “blinds,” or whatever you please, furnish to the ladies their busks and
13228 other stiffening contrivances. But in this particular, the demand has
13229 long been on the decline. It was in Queen Anne’s time that the bone was
13230 in its glory, the farthingale being then all the fashion. And as those
13231 ancient dames moved about gaily, though in the jaws of the whale, as
13232 you may say; even so, in a shower, with the like thoughtlessness, do we
13233 nowadays fly under the same jaws for protection; the umbrella being a
13234 tent spread over the same bone.
13235 
13236 But now forget all about blinds and whiskers for a moment, and,
13237 standing in the Right Whale’s mouth, look around you afresh. Seeing all
13238 these colonnades of bone so methodically ranged about, would you not
13239 think you were inside of the great Haarlem organ, and gazing upon its
13240 thousand pipes? For a carpet to the organ we have a rug of the softest
13241 Turkey—the tongue, which is glued, as it were, to the floor of the
13242 mouth. It is very fat and tender, and apt to tear in pieces in hoisting
13243 it on deck. This particular tongue now before us; at a passing glance I
13244 should say it was a six-barreler; that is, it will yield you about that
13245 amount of oil.
13246 
13247 Ere this, you must have plainly seen the truth of what I started
13248 with—that the Sperm Whale and the Right Whale have almost entirely
13249 different heads. To sum up, then: in the Right Whale’s there is no
13250 great well of sperm; no ivory teeth at all; no long, slender mandible
13251 of a lower jaw, like the Sperm Whale’s. Nor in the Sperm Whale are
13252 there any of those blinds of bone; no huge lower lip; and scarcely
13253 anything of a tongue. Again, the Right Whale has two external
13254 spout-holes, the Sperm Whale only one.
13255 
13256 Look your last, now, on these venerable hooded heads, while they yet
13257 lie together; for one will soon sink, unrecorded, in the sea; the other
13258 will not be very long in following.
13259 
13260 Can you catch the expression of the Sperm Whale’s there? It is the same
13261 he died with, only some of the longer wrinkles in the forehead seem now
13262 faded away. I think his broad brow to be full of a prairie-like
13263 placidity, born of a speculative indifference as to death. But mark the
13264 other head’s expression. See that amazing lower lip, pressed by
13265 accident against the vessel’s side, so as firmly to embrace the jaw.
13266 Does not this whole head seem to speak of an enormous practical
13267 resolution in facing death? This Right Whale I take to have been a
13268 Stoic; the Sperm Whale, a Platonian, who might have taken up Spinoza in
13269 his latter years.
13270 
13271 
13272 CHAPTER 76. The Battering-Ram.
13273 
13274 Ere quitting, for the nonce, the Sperm Whale’s head, I would have you,
13275 as a sensible physiologist, simply—particularly remark its front
13276 aspect, in all its compacted collectedness. I would have you
13277 investigate it now with the sole view of forming to yourself some
13278 unexaggerated, intelligent estimate of whatever battering-ram power may
13279 be lodged there. Here is a vital point; for you must either
13280 satisfactorily settle this matter with yourself, or for ever remain an
13281 infidel as to one of the most appalling, but not the less true events,
13282 perhaps anywhere to be found in all recorded history.
13283 
13284 You observe that in the ordinary swimming position of the Sperm Whale,
13285 the front of his head presents an almost wholly vertical plane to the
13286 water; you observe that the lower part of that front slopes
13287 considerably backwards, so as to furnish more of a retreat for the long
13288 socket which receives the boom-like lower jaw; you observe that the
13289 mouth is entirely under the head, much in the same way, indeed, as
13290 though your own mouth were entirely under your chin. Moreover you
13291 observe that the whale has no external nose; and that what nose he
13292 has—his spout hole—is on the top of his head; you observe that his eyes
13293 and ears are at the sides of his head, nearly one third of his entire
13294 length from the front. Wherefore, you must now have perceived that the
13295 front of the Sperm Whale’s head is a dead, blind wall, without a single
13296 organ or tender prominence of any sort whatsoever. Furthermore, you are
13297 now to consider that only in the extreme, lower, backward sloping part
13298 of the front of the head, is there the slightest vestige of bone; and
13299 not till you get near twenty feet from the forehead do you come to the
13300 full cranial development. So that this whole enormous boneless mass is
13301 as one wad. Finally, though, as will soon be revealed, its contents
