13302 partly comprise the most delicate oil; yet, you are now to be apprised
13303 of the nature of the substance which so impregnably invests all that
13304 apparent effeminacy. In some previous place I have described to you how
13305 the blubber wraps the body of the whale, as the rind wraps an orange.
13306 Just so with the head; but with this difference: about the head this
13307 envelope, though not so thick, is of a boneless toughness, inestimable
13308 by any man who has not handled it. The severest pointed harpoon, the
13309 sharpest lance darted by the strongest human arm, impotently rebounds
13310 from it. It is as though the forehead of the Sperm Whale were paved
13311 with horses’ hoofs. I do not think that any sensation lurks in it.
13312 
13313 Bethink yourself also of another thing. When two large, loaded Indiamen
13314 chance to crowd and crush towards each other in the docks, what do the
13315 sailors do? They do not suspend between them, at the point of coming
13316 contact, any merely hard substance, like iron or wood. No, they hold
13317 there a large, round wad of tow and cork, enveloped in the thickest and
13318 toughest of ox-hide. That bravely and uninjured takes the jam which
13319 would have snapped all their oaken handspikes and iron crow-bars. By
13320 itself this sufficiently illustrates the obvious fact I drive at. But
13321 supplementary to this, it has hypothetically occurred to me, that as
13322 ordinary fish possess what is called a swimming bladder in them,
13323 capable, at will, of distension or contraction; and as the Sperm Whale,
13324 as far as I know, has no such provision in him; considering, too, the
13325 otherwise inexplicable manner in which he now depresses his head
13326 altogether beneath the surface, and anon swims with it high elevated
13327 out of the water; considering the unobstructed elasticity of its
13328 envelope; considering the unique interior of his head; it has
13329 hypothetically occurred to me, I say, that those mystical lung-celled
13330 honeycombs there may possibly have some hitherto unknown and
13331 unsuspected connexion with the outer air, so as to be susceptible to
13332 atmospheric distension and contraction. If this be so, fancy the
13333 irresistibleness of that might, to which the most impalpable and
13334 destructive of all elements contributes.
13335 
13336 Now, mark. Unerringly impelling this dead, impregnable, uninjurable
13337 wall, and this most buoyant thing within; there swims behind it all a
13338 mass of tremendous life, only to be adequately estimated as piled wood
13339 is—by the cord; and all obedient to one volition, as the smallest
13340 insect. So that when I shall hereafter detail to you all the
13341 specialities and concentrations of potency everywhere lurking in this
13342 expansive monster; when I shall show you some of his more
13343 inconsiderable braining feats; I trust you will have renounced all
13344 ignorant incredulity, and be ready to abide by this; that though the
13345 Sperm Whale stove a passage through the Isthmus of Darien, and mixed
13346 the Atlantic with the Pacific, you would not elevate one hair of your
13347 eye-brow. For unless you own the whale, you are but a provincial and
13348 sentimentalist in Truth. But clear Truth is a thing for salamander
13349 giants only to encounter; how small the chances for the provincials
13350 then? What befell the weakling youth lifting the dread goddess’s veil
13351 at Lais?
13352 
13353 
13354 CHAPTER 77. The Great Heidelburgh Tun.
13355 
13356 Now comes the Baling of the Case. But to comprehend it aright, you must
13357 know something of the curious internal structure of the thing operated
13358 upon.
13359 
13360 Regarding the Sperm Whale’s head as a solid oblong, you may, on an
13361 inclined plane, sideways divide it into two quoins,* whereof the lower
13362 is the bony structure, forming the cranium and jaws, and the upper an
13363 unctuous mass wholly free from bones; its broad forward end forming the
13364 expanded vertical apparent forehead of the whale. At the middle of the
13365 forehead horizontally subdivide this upper quoin, and then you have two
13366 almost equal parts, which before were naturally divided by an internal
13367 wall of a thick tendinous substance.
13368 
13369 *Quoin is not a Euclidean term. It belongs to the pure nautical
13370 mathematics. I know not that it has been defined before. A quoin is a
13371 solid which differs from a wedge in having its sharp end formed by the
13372 steep inclination of one side, instead of the mutual tapering of both
13373 sides.
13374 
13375 The lower subdivided part, called the junk, is one immense honeycomb of
13376 oil, formed by the crossing and recrossing, into ten thousand
13377 infiltrated cells, of tough elastic white fibres throughout its whole
13378 extent. The upper part, known as the Case, may be regarded as the great
13379 Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale. And as that famous great tierce is
13380 mystically carved in front, so the whale’s vast plaited forehead forms
13381 innumerable strange devices for the emblematical adornment of his
13382 wondrous tun. Moreover, as that of Heidelburgh was always replenished
13383 with the most excellent of the wines of the Rhenish valleys, so the tun
13384 of the whale contains by far the most precious of all his oily
13385 vintages; namely, the highly-prized spermaceti, in its absolutely pure,
13386 limpid, and odoriferous state. Nor is this precious substance found
13387 unalloyed in any other part of the creature. Though in life it remains
13388 perfectly fluid, yet, upon exposure to the air, after death, it soon
13389 begins to concrete; sending forth beautiful crystalline shoots, as when
13390 the first thin delicate ice is just forming in water. A large whale’s
13391 case generally yields about five hundred gallons of sperm, though from
13392 unavoidable circumstances, considerable of it is spilled, leaks, and
13393 dribbles away, or is otherwise irrevocably lost in the ticklish
13394 business of securing what you can.
13395 
13396 I know not with what fine and costly material the Heidelburgh Tun was
13397 coated within, but in superlative richness that coating could not
13398 possibly have compared with the silken pearl-coloured membrane, like
13399 the lining of a fine pelisse, forming the inner surface of the Sperm
13400 Whale’s case.
13401 
13402 It will have been seen that the Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale
13403 embraces the entire length of the entire top of the head; and since—as
13404 has been elsewhere set forth—the head embraces one third of the whole
13405 length of the creature, then setting that length down at eighty feet
13406 for a good sized whale, you have more than twenty-six feet for the
13407 depth of the tun, when it is lengthwise hoisted up and down against a
13408 ship’s side.
13409 
13410 As in decapitating the whale, the operator’s instrument is brought
13411 close to the spot where an entrance is subsequently forced into the
13412 spermaceti magazine; he has, therefore, to be uncommonly heedful, lest
13413 a careless, untimely stroke should invade the sanctuary and wastingly
13414 let out its invaluable contents. It is this decapitated end of the
13415 head, also, which is at last elevated out of the water, and retained in
13416 that position by the enormous cutting tackles, whose hempen
13417 combinations, on one side, make quite a wilderness of ropes in that
13418 quarter.
13419 
13420 Thus much being said, attend now, I pray you, to that marvellous and—in
13421 this particular instance—almost fatal operation whereby the Sperm
13422 Whale’s great Heidelburgh Tun is tapped.
13423 
13424 
13425 CHAPTER 78. Cistern and Buckets.
13426 
13427 Nimble as a cat, Tashtego mounts aloft; and without altering his erect
13428 posture, runs straight out upon the overhanging mainyard-arm, to the
13429 part where it exactly projects over the hoisted Tun. He has carried
13430 with him a light tackle called a whip, consisting of only two parts,
13431 travelling through a single-sheaved block. Securing this block, so that
13432 it hangs down from the yard-arm, he swings one end of the rope, till it
13433 is caught and firmly held by a hand on deck. Then, hand-over-hand, down
13434 the other part, the Indian drops through the air, till dexterously he
13435 lands on the summit of the head. There—still high elevated above the
13436 rest of the company, to whom he vivaciously cries—he seems some Turkish
13437 Muezzin calling the good people to prayers from the top of a tower. A
13438 short-handled sharp spade being sent up to him, he diligently searches
13439 for the proper place to begin breaking into the Tun. In this business
13440 he proceeds very heedfully, like a treasure-hunter in some old house,
13441 sounding the walls to find where the gold is masoned in. By the time
13442 this cautious search is over, a stout iron-bound bucket, precisely like
13443 a well-bucket, has been attached to one end of the whip; while the
13444 other end, being stretched across the deck, is there held by two or
13445 three alert hands. These last now hoist the bucket within grasp of the
13446 Indian, to whom another person has reached up a very long pole.
13447 Inserting this pole into the bucket, Tashtego downward guides the
13448 bucket into the Tun, till it entirely disappears; then giving the word
13449 to the seamen at the whip, up comes the bucket again, all bubbling like
13450 a dairy-maid’s pail of new milk. Carefully lowered from its height, the
13451 full-freighted vessel is caught by an appointed hand, and quickly
13452 emptied into a large tub. Then remounting aloft, it again goes through
13453 the same round until the deep cistern will yield no more. Towards the
13454 end, Tashtego has to ram his long pole harder and harder, and deeper
13455 and deeper into the Tun, until some twenty feet of the pole have gone
13456 down.
13457 
13458 Now, the people of the Pequod had been baling some time in this way;
13459 several tubs had been filled with the fragrant sperm; when all at once
13460 a queer accident happened. Whether it was that Tashtego, that wild
13461 Indian, was so heedless and reckless as to let go for a moment his
13462 one-handed hold on the great cabled tackles suspending the head; or
13463 whether the place where he stood was so treacherous and oozy; or
13464 whether the Evil One himself would have it to fall out so, without
13465 stating his particular reasons; how it was exactly, there is no telling
13466 now; but, on a sudden, as the eightieth or ninetieth bucket came
13467 suckingly up—my God! poor Tashtego—like the twin reciprocating bucket
13468 in a veritable well, dropped head-foremost down into this great Tun of
13469 Heidelburgh, and with a horrible oily gurgling, went clean out of
13470 sight!
13471 
13472 “Man overboard!” cried Daggoo, who amid the general consternation first
13473 came to his senses. “Swing the bucket this way!” and putting one foot
13474 into it, so as the better to secure his slippery hand-hold on the whip
13475 itself, the hoisters ran him high up to the top of the head, almost
13476 before Tashtego could have reached its interior bottom. Meantime, there
13477 was a terrible tumult. Looking over the side, they saw the before
13478 lifeless head throbbing and heaving just below the surface of the sea,
13479 as if that moment seized with some momentous idea; whereas it was only
13480 the poor Indian unconsciously revealing by those struggles the perilous
13481 depth to which he had sunk.
13482 
13483 At this instant, while Daggoo, on the summit of the head, was clearing
13484 the whip—which had somehow got foul of the great cutting tackles—a
13485 sharp cracking noise was heard; and to the unspeakable horror of all,
13486 one of the two enormous hooks suspending the head tore out, and with a
13487 vast vibration the enormous mass sideways swung, till the drunk ship
13488 reeled and shook as if smitten by an iceberg. The one remaining hook,
13489 upon which the entire strain now depended, seemed every instant to be
13490 on the point of giving way; an event still more likely from the violent
13491 motions of the head.
13492 
13493 “Come down, come down!” yelled the seamen to Daggoo, but with one hand
13494 holding on to the heavy tackles, so that if the head should drop, he
13495 would still remain suspended; the negro having cleared the foul line,
13496 rammed down the bucket into the now collapsed well, meaning that the
13497 buried harpooneer should grasp it, and so be hoisted out.
13498 
13499 “In heaven’s name, man,” cried Stubb, “are you ramming home a cartridge
13500 there?—Avast! How will that help him; jamming that iron-bound bucket on
13501 top of his head? Avast, will ye!”
13502 
13503 “Stand clear of the tackle!” cried a voice like the bursting of a
13504 rocket.
13505 
13506 Almost in the same instant, with a thunder-boom, the enormous mass
13507 dropped into the sea, like Niagara’s Table-Rock into the whirlpool; the
13508 suddenly relieved hull rolled away from it, to far down her glittering
13509 copper; and all caught their breath, as half swinging—now over the
13510 sailors’ heads, and now over the water—Daggoo, through a thick mist of
13511 spray, was dimly beheld clinging to the pendulous tackles, while poor,
13512 buried-alive Tashtego was sinking utterly down to the bottom of the
13513 sea! But hardly had the blinding vapor cleared away, when a naked
13514 figure with a boarding-sword in his hand, was for one swift moment seen
13515 hovering over the bulwarks. The next, a loud splash announced that my
13516 brave Queequeg had dived to the rescue. One packed rush was made to the
13517 side, and every eye counted every ripple, as moment followed moment,
13518 and no sign of either the sinker or the diver could be seen. Some hands
13519 now jumped into a boat alongside, and pushed a little off from the
13520 ship.
13521 
13522 “Ha! ha!” cried Daggoo, all at once, from his now quiet, swinging perch
13523 overhead; and looking further off from the side, we saw an arm thrust
13524 upright from the blue waves; a sight strange to see, as an arm thrust
13525 forth from the grass over a grave.
13526 
13527 “Both! both!—it is both!”—cried Daggoo again with a joyful shout; and
13528 soon after, Queequeg was seen boldly striking out with one hand, and
13529 with the other clutching the long hair of the Indian. Drawn into the
13530 waiting boat, they were quickly brought to the deck; but Tashtego was
13531 long in coming to, and Queequeg did not look very brisk.
13532 
13533 Now, how had this noble rescue been accomplished? Why, diving after the
13534 slowly descending head, Queequeg with his keen sword had made side
13535 lunges near its bottom, so as to scuttle a large hole there; then
13536 dropping his sword, had thrust his long arm far inwards and upwards,
13537 and so hauled out poor Tash by the head. He averred, that upon first
13538 thrusting in for him, a leg was presented; but well knowing that that
13539 was not as it ought to be, and might occasion great trouble;—he had
13540 thrust back the leg, and by a dexterous heave and toss, had wrought a
13541 somerset upon the Indian; so that with the next trial, he came forth in
13542 the good old way—head foremost. As for the great head itself, that was
13543 doing as well as could be expected.
13544 
13545 And thus, through the courage and great skill in obstetrics of
13546 Queequeg, the deliverance, or rather, delivery of Tashtego, was
13547 successfully accomplished, in the teeth, too, of the most untoward and
13548 apparently hopeless impediments; which is a lesson by no means to be
13549 forgotten. Midwifery should be taught in the same course with fencing
13550 and boxing, riding and rowing.
13551 
13552 I know that this queer adventure of the Gay-Header’s will be sure to
13553 seem incredible to some landsmen, though they themselves may have
13554 either seen or heard of some one’s falling into a cistern ashore; an
13555 accident which not seldom happens, and with much less reason too than
13556 the Indian’s, considering the exceeding slipperiness of the curb of the
13557 Sperm Whale’s well.
13558 
13559 But, peradventure, it may be sagaciously urged, how is this? We thought
13560 the tissued, infiltrated head of the Sperm Whale, was the lightest and
13561 most corky part about him; and yet thou makest it sink in an element of
13562 a far greater specific gravity than itself. We have thee there. Not at
13563 all, but I have ye; for at the time poor Tash fell in, the case had
13564 been nearly emptied of its lighter contents, leaving little but the
13565 dense tendinous wall of the well—a double welded, hammered substance,
13566 as I have before said, much heavier than the sea water, and a lump of
13567 which sinks in it like lead almost. But the tendency to rapid sinking
13568 in this substance was in the present instance materially counteracted
13569 by the other parts of the head remaining undetached from it, so that it
13570 sank very slowly and deliberately indeed, affording Queequeg a fair
13571 chance for performing his agile obstetrics on the run, as you may say.
13572 Yes, it was a running delivery, so it was.
13573 
13574 Now, had Tashtego perished in that head, it had been a very precious
13575 perishing; smothered in the very whitest and daintiest of fragrant
13576 spermaceti; coffined, hearsed, and tombed in the secret inner chamber
13577 and sanctum sanctorum of the whale. Only one sweeter end can readily be
13578 recalled—the delicious death of an Ohio honey-hunter, who seeking honey
13579 in the crotch of a hollow tree, found such exceeding store of it, that
13580 leaning too far over, it sucked him in, so that he died embalmed. How
13581 many, think ye, have likewise fallen into Plato’s honey head, and
13582 sweetly perished there?
13583 
13584 
13585 CHAPTER 79. The Prairie.
13586 
13587 To scan the lines of his face, or feel the bumps on the head of this
13588 Leviathan; this is a thing which no Physiognomist or Phrenologist has
13589 as yet undertaken. Such an enterprise would seem almost as hopeful as
13590 for Lavater to have scrutinized the wrinkles on the Rock of Gibraltar,
13591 or for Gall to have mounted a ladder and manipulated the Dome of the
13592 Pantheon. Still, in that famous work of his, Lavater not only treats of
13593 the various faces of men, but also attentively studies the faces of
13594 horses, birds, serpents, and fish; and dwells in detail upon the
13595 modifications of expression discernible therein. Nor have Gall and his
13596 disciple Spurzheim failed to throw out some hints touching the
13597 phrenological characteristics of other beings than man. Therefore,
13598 though I am but ill qualified for a pioneer, in the application of
13599 these two semi-sciences to the whale, I will do my endeavor. I try all
13600 things; I achieve what I can.
13601 
13602 Physiognomically regarded, the Sperm Whale is an anomalous creature. He
13603 has no proper nose. And since the nose is the central and most
13604 conspicuous of the features; and since it perhaps most modifies and
13605 finally controls their combined expression; hence it would seem that
13606 its entire absence, as an external appendage, must very largely affect
13607 the countenance of the whale. For as in landscape gardening, a spire,
13608 cupola, monument, or tower of some sort, is deemed almost indispensable
13609 to the completion of the scene; so no face can be physiognomically in
13610 keeping without the elevated open-work belfry of the nose. Dash the
13611 nose from Phidias’s marble Jove, and what a sorry remainder!
13612 Nevertheless, Leviathan is of so mighty a magnitude, all his
13613 proportions are so stately, that the same deficiency which in the
13614 sculptured Jove were hideous, in him is no blemish at all. Nay, it is
13615 an added grandeur. A nose to the whale would have been impertinent. As
13616 on your physiognomical voyage you sail round his vast head in your
13617 jolly-boat, your noble conceptions of him are never insulted by the
13618 reflection that he has a nose to be pulled. A pestilent conceit, which
13619 so often will insist upon obtruding even when beholding the mightiest
13620 royal beadle on his throne.
13621 
13622 In some particulars, perhaps the most imposing physiognomical view to
13623 be had of the Sperm Whale, is that of the full front of his head. This
13624 aspect is sublime.
13625 
13626 In thought, a fine human brow is like the East when troubled with the
13627 morning. In the repose of the pasture, the curled brow of the bull has
13628 a touch of the grand in it. Pushing heavy cannon up mountain defiles,
13629 the elephant’s brow is majestic. Human or animal, the mystical brow is
13630 as that great golden seal affixed by the German emperors to their
13631 decrees. It signifies—“God: done this day by my hand.” But in most
13632 creatures, nay in man himself, very often the brow is but a mere strip
13633 of alpine land lying along the snow line. Few are the foreheads which
13634 like Shakespeare’s or Melancthon’s rise so high, and descend so low,
13635 that the eyes themselves seem clear, eternal, tideless mountain lakes;
13636 and all above them in the forehead’s wrinkles, you seem to track the
13637 antlered thoughts descending there to drink, as the Highland hunters
13638 track the snow prints of the deer. But in the great Sperm Whale, this
13639 high and mighty god-like dignity inherent in the brow is so immensely
13640 amplified, that gazing on it, in that full front view, you feel the
13641 Deity and the dread powers more forcibly than in beholding any other
13642 object in living nature. For you see no one point precisely; not one
13643 distinct feature is revealed; no nose, eyes, ears, or mouth; no face;
13644 he has none, proper; nothing but that one broad firmament of a
13645 forehead, pleated with riddles; dumbly lowering with the doom of boats,
13646 and ships, and men. Nor, in profile, does this wondrous brow diminish;
13647 though that way viewed its grandeur does not domineer upon you so. In
13648 profile, you plainly perceive that horizontal, semi-crescentic
13649 depression in the forehead’s middle, which, in man, is Lavater’s mark
13650 of genius.
13651 
13652 But how? Genius in the Sperm Whale? Has the Sperm Whale ever written a
13653 book, spoken a speech? No, his great genius is declared in his doing
13654 nothing particular to prove it. It is moreover declared in his
13655 pyramidical silence. And this reminds me that had the great Sperm Whale
13656 been known to the young Orient World, he would have been deified by
13657 their child-magian thoughts. They deified the crocodile of the Nile,
13658 because the crocodile is tongueless; and the Sperm Whale has no tongue,
13659 or at least it is so exceedingly small, as to be incapable of
13660 protrusion. If hereafter any highly cultured, poetical nation shall
13661 lure back to their birth-right, the merry May-day gods of old; and
13662 livingly enthrone them again in the now egotistical sky; in the now
13663 unhaunted hill; then be sure, exalted to Jove’s high seat, the great
13664 Sperm Whale shall lord it.
13665 
13666 Champollion deciphered the wrinkled granite hieroglyphics. But there is
13667 no Champollion to decipher the Egypt of every man’s and every being’s
13668 face. Physiognomy, like every other human science, is but a passing
13669 fable. If then, Sir William Jones, who read in thirty languages, could
13670 not read the simplest peasant’s face in its profounder and more subtle
13671 meanings, how may unlettered Ishmael hope to read the awful Chaldee of
13672 the Sperm Whale’s brow? I but put that brow before you. Read it if you
13673 can.
13674 
13675 
13676 CHAPTER 80. The Nut.
13677 
13678 If the Sperm Whale be physiognomically a Sphinx, to the phrenologist
13679 his brain seems that geometrical circle which it is impossible to
13680 square.
13681 
13682 In the full-grown creature the skull will measure at least twenty feet
13683 in length. Unhinge the lower jaw, and the side view of this skull is as
13684 the side of a moderately inclined plane resting throughout on a level
13685 base. But in life—as we have elsewhere seen—this inclined plane is
13686 angularly filled up, and almost squared by the enormous superincumbent
13687 mass of the junk and sperm. At the high end the skull forms a crater to
13688 bed that part of the mass; while under the long floor of this crater—in
13689 another cavity seldom exceeding ten inches in length and as many in
13690 depth—reposes the mere handful of this monster’s brain. The brain is at
13691 least twenty feet from his apparent forehead in life; it is hidden away
13692 behind its vast outworks, like the innermost citadel within the
13693 amplified fortifications of Quebec. So like a choice casket is it
13694 secreted in him, that I have known some whalemen who peremptorily deny
13695 that the Sperm Whale has any other brain than that palpable semblance
13696 of one formed by the cubic-yards of his sperm magazine. Lying in
13697 strange folds, courses, and convolutions, to their apprehensions, it
13698 seems more in keeping with the idea of his general might to regard that
13699 mystic part of him as the seat of his intelligence.
13700 
13701 It is plain, then, that phrenologically the head of this Leviathan, in
13702 the creature’s living intact state, is an entire delusion. As for his
13703 true brain, you can then see no indications of it, nor feel any. The
13704 whale, like all things that are mighty, wears a false brow to the
13705 common world.
13706 
13707 If you unload his skull of its spermy heaps and then take a rear view
13708 of its rear end, which is the high end, you will be struck by its
13709 resemblance to the human skull, beheld in the same situation, and from
13710 the same point of view. Indeed, place this reversed skull (scaled down
13711 to the human magnitude) among a plate of men’s skulls, and you would
13712 involuntarily confound it with them; and remarking the depressions on
13713 one part of its summit, in phrenological phrase you would say—This man
13714 had no self-esteem, and no veneration. And by those negations,
13715 considered along with the affirmative fact of his prodigious bulk and
13716 power, you can best form to yourself the truest, though not the most
13717 exhilarating conception of what the most exalted potency is.
13718 
13719 But if from the comparative dimensions of the whale’s proper brain, you
13720 deem it incapable of being adequately charted, then I have another idea
13721 for you. If you attentively regard almost any quadruped’s spine, you
13722 will be struck with the resemblance of its vertebræ to a strung
13723 necklace of dwarfed skulls, all bearing rudimental resemblance to the
13724 skull proper. It is a German conceit, that the vertebræ are absolutely
13725 undeveloped skulls. But the curious external resemblance, I take it the
13726 Germans were not the first men to perceive. A foreign friend once
13727 pointed it out to me, in the skeleton of a foe he had slain, and with
13728 the vertebræ of which he was inlaying, in a sort of basso-relievo, the
13729 beaked prow of his canoe. Now, I consider that the phrenologists have
13730 omitted an important thing in not pushing their investigations from the
13731 cerebellum through the spinal canal. For I believe that much of a man’s
13732 character will be found betokened in his backbone. I would rather feel
13733 your spine than your skull, whoever you are. A thin joist of a spine
13734 never yet upheld a full and noble soul. I rejoice in my spine, as in
13735 the firm audacious staff of that flag which I fling half out to the
13736 world.
13737 
13738 Apply this spinal branch of phrenology to the Sperm Whale. His cranial
13739 cavity is continuous with the first neck-vertebra; and in that vertebra
13740 the bottom of the spinal canal will measure ten inches across, being
13741 eight in height, and of a triangular figure with the base downwards. As
13742 it passes through the remaining vertebræ the canal tapers in size, but
13743 for a considerable distance remains of large capacity. Now, of course,
13744 this canal is filled with much the same strangely fibrous substance—the
13745 spinal cord—as the brain; and directly communicates with the brain. And
13746 what is still more, for many feet after emerging from the brain’s
13747 cavity, the spinal cord remains of an undecreasing girth, almost equal
13748 to that of the brain. Under all these circumstances, would it be
13749 unreasonable to survey and map out the whale’s spine phrenologically?
13750 For, viewed in this light, the wonderful comparative smallness of his
13751 brain proper is more than compensated by the wonderful comparative
13752 magnitude of his spinal cord.
13753 
13754 But leaving this hint to operate as it may with the phrenologists, I
13755 would merely assume the spinal theory for a moment, in reference to the
13756 Sperm Whale’s hump. This august hump, if I mistake not, rises over one
13757 of the larger vertebræ, and is, therefore, in some sort, the outer
13758 convex mould of it. From its relative situation then, I should call
13759 this high hump the organ of firmness or indomitableness in the Sperm
13760 Whale. And that the great monster is indomitable, you will yet have
13761 reason to know.
13762 
13763 
13764 CHAPTER 81. The Pequod Meets The Virgin.
13765 
13766 The predestinated day arrived, and we duly met the ship Jungfrau,
13767 Derick De Deer, master, of Bremen.
13768 
13769 At one time the greatest whaling people in the world, the Dutch and
13770 Germans are now among the least; but here and there at very wide
13771 intervals of latitude and longitude, you still occasionally meet with
13772 their flag in the Pacific.
13773 
13774 For some reason, the Jungfrau seemed quite eager to pay her respects.
13775 While yet some distance from the Pequod, she rounded to, and dropping a
13776 boat, her captain was impelled towards us, impatiently standing in the
13777 bows instead of the stern.
13778 
13779 “What has he in his hand there?” cried Starbuck, pointing to something
13780 wavingly held by the German. “Impossible!—a lamp-feeder!”
13781 
13782 “Not that,” said Stubb, “no, no, it’s a coffee-pot, Mr. Starbuck; he’s
13783 coming off to make us our coffee, is the Yarman; don’t you see that big
13784 tin can there alongside of him?—that’s his boiling water. Oh! he’s all
13785 right, is the Yarman.”
13786 
13787 “Go along with you,” cried Flask, “it’s a lamp-feeder and an oil-can.
13788 He’s out of oil, and has come a-begging.”
13789 
13790 However curious it may seem for an oil-ship to be borrowing oil on the
13791 whale-ground, and however much it may invertedly contradict the old
13792 proverb about carrying coals to Newcastle, yet sometimes such a thing
13793 really happens; and in the present case Captain Derick De Deer did
13794 indubitably conduct a lamp-feeder as Flask did declare.
13795 
13796 As he mounted the deck, Ahab abruptly accosted him, without at all
13797 heeding what he had in his hand; but in his broken lingo, the German
13798 soon evinced his complete ignorance of the White Whale; immediately
13799 turning the conversation to his lamp-feeder and oil can, with some
13800 remarks touching his having to turn into his hammock at night in
13801 profound darkness—his last drop of Bremen oil being gone, and not a
13802 single flying-fish yet captured to supply the deficiency; concluding by
13803 hinting that his ship was indeed what in the Fishery is technically
13804 called a _clean_ one (that is, an empty one), well deserving the name
13805 of Jungfrau or the Virgin.
13806 
13807 His necessities supplied, Derick departed; but he had not gained his
13808 ship’s side, when whales were almost simultaneously raised from the
13809 mast-heads of both vessels; and so eager for the chase was Derick, that
13810 without pausing to put his oil-can and lamp-feeder aboard, he slewed
13811 round his boat and made after the leviathan lamp-feeders.
13812 
13813 Now, the game having risen to leeward, he and the other three German
13814 boats that soon followed him, had considerably the start of the
13815 Pequod’s keels. There were eight whales, an average pod. Aware of their
13816 danger, they were going all abreast with great speed straight before
13817 the wind, rubbing their flanks as closely as so many spans of horses in
13818 harness. They left a great, wide wake, as though continually unrolling
13819 a great wide parchment upon the sea.
13820 
13821 Full in this rapid wake, and many fathoms in the rear, swam a huge,
13822 humped old bull, which by his comparatively slow progress, as well as
13823 by the unusual yellowish incrustations overgrowing him, seemed
13824 afflicted with the jaundice, or some other infirmity. Whether this
13825 whale belonged to the pod in advance, seemed questionable; for it is
13826 not customary for such venerable leviathans to be at all social.
13827 Nevertheless, he stuck to their wake, though indeed their back water
13828 must have retarded him, because the white-bone or swell at his broad
13829 muzzle was a dashed one, like the swell formed when two hostile
13830 currents meet. His spout was short, slow, and laborious; coming forth
13831 with a choking sort of gush, and spending itself in torn shreds,
13832 followed by strange subterranean commotions in him, which seemed to
13833 have egress at his other buried extremity, causing the waters behind
13834 him to upbubble.
13835 
13836 “Who’s got some paregoric?” said Stubb, “he has the stomach-ache, I’m
13837 afraid. Lord, think of having half an acre of stomach-ache! Adverse
13838 winds are holding mad Christmas in him, boys. It’s the first foul wind
13839 I ever knew to blow from astern; but look, did ever whale yaw so
13840 before? it must be, he’s lost his tiller.”
13841 
13842 As an overladen Indiaman bearing down the Hindostan coast with a deck
13843 load of frightened horses, careens, buries, rolls, and wallows on her
13844 way; so did this old whale heave his aged bulk, and now and then partly
13845 turning over on his cumbrous rib-ends, expose the cause of his devious
13846 wake in the unnatural stump of his starboard fin. Whether he had lost
13847 that fin in battle, or had been born without it, it were hard to say.
13848 
13849 “Only wait a bit, old chap, and I’ll give ye a sling for that wounded
13850 arm,” cried cruel Flask, pointing to the whale-line near him.
13851 
13852 “Mind he don’t sling thee with it,” cried Starbuck. “Give way, or the
13853 German will have him.”
13854 
13855 With one intent all the combined rival boats were pointed for this one
13856 fish, because not only was he the largest, and therefore the most
13857 valuable whale, but he was nearest to them, and the other whales were
13858 going with such great velocity, moreover, as almost to defy pursuit for
13859 the time. At this juncture the Pequod’s keels had shot by the three
13860 German boats last lowered; but from the great start he had had,
13861 Derick’s boat still led the chase, though every moment neared by his
13862 foreign rivals. The only thing they feared, was, that from being
13863 already so nigh to his mark, he would be enabled to dart his iron
13864 before they could completely overtake and pass him. As for Derick, he
13865 seemed quite confident that this would be the case, and occasionally
13866 with a deriding gesture shook his lamp-feeder at the other boats.
13867 
13868 “The ungracious and ungrateful dog!” cried Starbuck; “he mocks and
13869 dares me with the very poor-box I filled for him not five minutes
13870 ago!”—then in his old intense whisper—“Give way, greyhounds! Dog to
13871 it!”
13872 
13873 “I tell ye what it is, men”—cried Stubb to his crew—“it’s against my
13874 religion to get mad; but I’d like to eat that villainous
13875 Yarman—Pull—won’t ye? Are ye going to let that rascal beat ye? Do ye
13876 love brandy? A hogshead of brandy, then, to the best man. Come, why
13877 don’t some of ye burst a blood-vessel? Who’s that been dropping an
13878 anchor overboard—we don’t budge an inch—we’re becalmed. Halloo, here’s
13879 grass growing in the boat’s bottom—and by the Lord, the mast there’s
13880 budding. This won’t do, boys. Look at that Yarman! The short and long
13881 of it is, men, will ye spit fire or not?”
13882 
13883 “Oh! see the suds he makes!” cried Flask, dancing up and down—“What a
13884 hump—Oh, _do_ pile on the beef—lays like a log! Oh! my lads, _do_
13885 spring—slap-jacks and quahogs for supper, you know, my lads—baked clams
13886 and muffins—oh, _do_, _do_, spring,—he’s a hundred barreller—don’t lose
13887 him now—don’t oh, _don’t!_—see that Yarman—Oh, won’t ye pull for your
13888 duff, my lads—such a sog! such a sogger! Don’t ye love sperm? There
13889 goes three thousand dollars, men!—a bank!—a whole bank! The bank of
13890 England!—Oh, _do_, _do_, _do!_—What’s that Yarman about now?”
13891 
13892 At this moment Derick was in the act of pitching his lamp-feeder at the
13893 advancing boats, and also his oil-can; perhaps with the double view of
13894 retarding his rivals’ way, and at the same time economically
13895 accelerating his own by the momentary impetus of the backward toss.
13896 
13897 “The unmannerly Dutch dogger!” cried Stubb. “Pull now, men, like fifty
13898 thousand line-of-battle-ship loads of red-haired devils. What d’ye say,
13899 Tashtego; are you the man to snap your spine in two-and-twenty pieces
13900 for the honor of old Gayhead? What d’ye say?”
13901 
13902 “I say, pull like god-dam,”—cried the Indian.
13903 
13904 Fiercely, but evenly incited by the taunts of the German, the Pequod’s
13905 three boats now began ranging almost abreast; and, so disposed,
13906 momentarily neared him. In that fine, loose, chivalrous attitude of the
13907 headsman when drawing near to his prey, the three mates stood up
13908 proudly, occasionally backing the after oarsman with an exhilarating
13909 cry of, “There she slides, now! Hurrah for the white-ash breeze! Down
13910 with the Yarman! Sail over him!”
13911 
13912 But so decided an original start had Derick had, that spite of all
13913 their gallantry, he would have proved the victor in this race, had not
13914 a righteous judgment descended upon him in a crab which caught the
13915 blade of his midship oarsman. While this clumsy lubber was striving to
13916 free his white-ash, and while, in consequence, Derick’s boat was nigh
13917 to capsizing, and he thundering away at his men in a mighty rage;—that
13918 was a good time for Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask. With a shout, they took
13919 a mortal start forwards, and slantingly ranged up on the German’s
13920 quarter. An instant more, and all four boats were diagonically in the
13921 whale’s immediate wake, while stretching from them, on both sides, was
13922 the foaming swell that he made.
13923 
13924 It was a terrific, most pitiable, and maddening sight. The whale was
13925 now going head out, and sending his spout before him in a continual
13926 tormented jet; while his one poor fin beat his side in an agony of
13927 fright. Now to this hand, now to that, he yawed in his faltering
13928 flight, and still at every billow that he broke, he spasmodically sank
13929 in the sea, or sideways rolled towards the sky his one beating fin. So
13930 have I seen a bird with clipped wing making affrighted broken circles
13931 in the air, vainly striving to escape the piratical hawks. But the bird
13932 has a voice, and with plaintive cries will make known her fear; but the
13933 fear of this vast dumb brute of the sea, was chained up and enchanted
13934 in him; he had no voice, save that choking respiration through his
13935 spiracle, and this made the sight of him unspeakably pitiable; while
13936 still, in his amazing bulk, portcullis jaw, and omnipotent tail, there
13937 was enough to appal the stoutest man who so pitied.
13938 
13939 Seeing now that but a very few moments more would give the Pequod’s
13940 boats the advantage, and rather than be thus foiled of his game, Derick
13941 chose to hazard what to him must have seemed a most unusually long
13942 dart, ere the last chance would for ever escape.
13943 
13944 But no sooner did his harpooneer stand up for the stroke, than all
13945 three tigers—Queequeg, Tashtego, Daggoo—instinctively sprang to their
13946 feet, and standing in a diagonal row, simultaneously pointed their
13947 barbs; and darted over the head of the German harpooneer, their three
13948 Nantucket irons entered the whale. Blinding vapors of foam and
13949 white-fire! The three boats, in the first fury of the whale’s headlong
13950 rush, bumped the German’s aside with such force, that both Derick and
13951 his baffled harpooneer were spilled out, and sailed over by the three
13952 flying keels.
13953 
13954 “Don’t be afraid, my butter-boxes,” cried Stubb, casting a passing
13955 glance upon them as he shot by; “ye’ll be picked up presently—all
13956 right—I saw some sharks astern—St. Bernard’s dogs, you know—relieve
13957 distressed travellers. Hurrah! this is the way to sail now. Every keel
13958 a sunbeam! Hurrah!—Here we go like three tin kettles at the tail of a
13959 mad cougar! This puts me in mind of fastening to an elephant in a
13960 tilbury on a plain—makes the wheel-spokes fly, boys, when you fasten to
13961 him that way; and there’s danger of being pitched out too, when you
13962 strike a hill. Hurrah! this is the way a fellow feels when he’s going
13963 to Davy Jones—all a rush down an endless inclined plane! Hurrah! this
13964 whale carries the everlasting mail!”
13965 
13966 But the monster’s run was a brief one. Giving a sudden gasp, he
13967 tumultuously sounded. With a grating rush, the three lines flew round
13968 the loggerheads with such a force as to gouge deep grooves in them;
13969 while so fearful were the harpooneers that this rapid sounding would
13970 soon exhaust the lines, that using all their dexterous might, they
13971 caught repeated smoking turns with the rope to hold on; till at
13972 last—owing to the perpendicular strain from the lead-lined chocks of
13973 the boats, whence the three ropes went straight down into the blue—the
13974 gunwales of the bows were almost even with the water, while the three
13975 sterns tilted high in the air. And the whale soon ceasing to sound, for
13976 some time they remained in that attitude, fearful of expending more
13977 line, though the position was a little ticklish. But though boats have
13978 been taken down and lost in this way, yet it is this “holding on,” as
13979 it is called; this hooking up by the sharp barbs of his live flesh from
13980 the back; this it is that often torments the Leviathan into soon rising
13981 again to meet the sharp lance of his foes. Yet not to speak of the
13982 peril of the thing, it is to be doubted whether this course is always
13983 the best; for it is but reasonable to presume, that the longer the
13984 stricken whale stays under water, the more he is exhausted. Because,
13985 owing to the enormous surface of him—in a full grown sperm whale
13986 something less than 2000 square feet—the pressure of the water is
13987 immense. We all know what an astonishing atmospheric weight we
13988 ourselves stand up under; even here, above-ground, in the air; how
13989 vast, then, the burden of a whale, bearing on his back a column of two
13990 hundred fathoms of ocean! It must at least equal the weight of fifty
13991 atmospheres. One whaleman has estimated it at the weight of twenty
13992 line-of-battle ships, with all their guns, and stores, and men on
13993 board.
13994 
13995 As the three boats lay there on that gently rolling sea, gazing down
13996 into its eternal blue noon; and as not a single groan or cry of any
13997 sort, nay, not so much as a ripple or a bubble came up from its depths;
13998 what landsman would have thought, that beneath all that silence and
13999 placidity, the utmost monster of the seas was writhing and wrenching in
14000 agony! Not eight inches of perpendicular rope were visible at the bows.
14001 Seems it credible that by three such thin threads the great Leviathan
14002 was suspended like the big weight to an eight day clock. Suspended? and
14003 to what? To three bits of board. Is this the creature of whom it was
14004 once so triumphantly said—“Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons?
14005 or his head with fish-spears? The sword of him that layeth at him
14006 cannot hold, the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon: he esteemeth iron
14007 as straw; the arrow cannot make him flee; darts are counted as stubble;
14008 he laugheth at the shaking of a spear!” This the creature? this he? Oh!
14009 that unfulfilments should follow the prophets. For with the strength of
14010 a thousand thighs in his tail, Leviathan had run his head under the
14011 mountains of the sea, to hide him from the Pequod’s fish-spears!
14012 
14013 In that sloping afternoon sunlight, the shadows that the three boats
14014 sent down beneath the surface, must have been long enough and broad
14015 enough to shade half Xerxes’ army. Who can tell how appalling to the
14016 wounded whale must have been such huge phantoms flitting over his head!
14017 
14018 “Stand by, men; he stirs,” cried Starbuck, as the three lines suddenly
14019 vibrated in the water, distinctly conducting upwards to them, as by
14020 magnetic wires, the life and death throbs of the whale, so that every
14021 oarsman felt them in his seat. The next moment, relieved in great part
14022 from the downward strain at the bows, the boats gave a sudden bounce
14023 upwards, as a small icefield will, when a dense herd of white bears are
14024 scared from it into the sea.
14025 
14026 “Haul in! Haul in!” cried Starbuck again; “he’s rising.”
14027 
14028 The lines, of which, hardly an instant before, not one hand’s breadth
14029 could have been gained, were now in long quick coils flung back all
14030 dripping into the boats, and soon the whale broke water within two
14031 ship’s lengths of the hunters.
14032 
14033 His motions plainly denoted his extreme exhaustion. In most land
14034 animals there are certain valves or flood-gates in many of their veins,
14035 whereby when wounded, the blood is in some degree at least instantly
14036 shut off in certain directions. Not so with the whale; one of whose
14037 peculiarities it is to have an entire non-valvular structure of the
14038 blood-vessels, so that when pierced even by so small a point as a
14039 harpoon, a deadly drain is at once begun upon his whole arterial
14040 system; and when this is heightened by the extraordinary pressure of
14041 water at a great distance below the surface, his life may be said to
14042 pour from him in incessant streams. Yet so vast is the quantity of
14043 blood in him, and so distant and numerous its interior fountains, that
14044 he will keep thus bleeding and bleeding for a considerable period; even
14045 as in a drought a river will flow, whose source is in the well-springs
14046 of far-off and undiscernible hills. Even now, when the boats pulled
14047 upon this whale, and perilously drew over his swaying flukes, and the
14048 lances were darted into him, they were followed by steady jets from the
14049 new made wound, which kept continually playing, while the natural
14050 spout-hole in his head was only at intervals, however rapid, sending
14051 its affrighted moisture into the air. From this last vent no blood yet
14052 came, because no vital part of him had thus far been struck. His life,
14053 as they significantly call it, was untouched.
14054 
14055 As the boats now more closely surrounded him, the whole upper part of
14056 his form, with much of it that is ordinarily submerged, was plainly
14057 revealed. His eyes, or rather the places where his eyes had been, were
14058 beheld. As strange misgrown masses gather in the knot-holes of the
14059 noblest oaks when prostrate, so from the points which the whale’s eyes
14060 had once occupied, now protruded blind bulbs, horribly pitiable to see.
14061 But pity there was none. For all his old age, and his one arm, and his
14062 blind eyes, he must die the death and be murdered, in order to light
14063 the gay bridals and other merry-makings of men, and also to illuminate
14064 the solemn churches that preach unconditional inoffensiveness by all to
14065 all. Still rolling in his blood, at last he partially disclosed a
14066 strangely discoloured bunch or protuberance, the size of a bushel, low
14067 down on the flank.
14068 
14069 “A nice spot,” cried Flask; “just let me prick him there once.”
14070 
14071 “Avast!” cried Starbuck, “there’s no need of that!”
14072 
14073 But humane Starbuck was too late. At the instant of the dart an
14074 ulcerous jet shot from this cruel wound, and goaded by it into more
14075 than sufferable anguish, the whale now spouting thick blood, with swift
14076 fury blindly darted at the craft, bespattering them and their glorying
14077 crews all over with showers of gore, capsizing Flask’s boat and marring
14078 the bows. It was his death stroke. For, by this time, so spent was he
14079 by loss of blood, that he helplessly rolled away from the wreck he had
14080 made; lay panting on his side, impotently flapped with his stumped fin,
14081 then over and over slowly revolved like a waning world; turned up the
14082 white secrets of his belly; lay like a log, and died. It was most
14083 piteous, that last expiring spout. As when by unseen hands the water is
14084 gradually drawn off from some mighty fountain, and with half-stifled
14085 melancholy gurglings the spray-column lowers and lowers to the
14086 ground—so the last long dying spout of the whale.
14087 
14088 Soon, while the crews were awaiting the arrival of the ship, the body
14089 showed symptoms of sinking with all its treasures unrifled.
14090 Immediately, by Starbuck’s orders, lines were secured to it at
14091 different points, so that ere long every boat was a buoy; the sunken
14092 whale being suspended a few inches beneath them by the cords. By very
14093 heedful management, when the ship drew nigh, the whale was transferred
14094 to her side, and was strongly secured there by the stiffest
14095 fluke-chains, for it was plain that unless artificially upheld, the
14096 body would at once sink to the bottom.
14097 
14098 It so chanced that almost upon first cutting into him with the spade,
14099 the entire length of a corroded harpoon was found imbedded in his
14100 flesh, on the lower part of the bunch before described. But as the
14101 stumps of harpoons are frequently found in the dead bodies of captured
14102 whales, with the flesh perfectly healed around them, and no prominence
14103 of any kind to denote their place; therefore, there must needs have
14104 been some other unknown reason in the present case fully to account for
14105 the ulceration alluded to. But still more curious was the fact of a
14106 lance-head of stone being found in him, not far from the buried iron,
14107 the flesh perfectly firm about it. Who had darted that stone lance? And
14108 when? It might have been darted by some Nor’ West Indian long before
14109 America was discovered.
14110 
14111 What other marvels might have been rummaged out of this monstrous
14112 cabinet there is no telling. But a sudden stop was put to further
14113 discoveries, by the ship’s being unprecedentedly dragged over sideways
14114 to the sea, owing to the body’s immensely increasing tendency to sink.
14115 However, Starbuck, who had the ordering of affairs, hung on to it to
14116 the last; hung on to it so resolutely, indeed, that when at length the
14117 ship would have been capsized, if still persisting in locking arms with
14118 the body; then, when the command was given to break clear from it, such
14119 was the immovable strain upon the timber-heads to which the
14120 fluke-chains and cables were fastened, that it was impossible to cast
14121 them off. Meantime everything in the Pequod was aslant. To cross to the
14122 other side of the deck was like walking up the steep gabled roof of a
14123 house. The ship groaned and gasped. Many of the ivory inlayings of her
14124 bulwarks and cabins were started from their places, by the unnatural
14125 dislocation. In vain handspikes and crows were brought to bear upon the
14126 immovable fluke-chains, to pry them adrift from the timberheads; and so
14127 low had the whale now settled that the submerged ends could not be at
14128 all approached, while every moment whole tons of ponderosity seemed
14129 added to the sinking bulk, and the ship seemed on the point of going
14130 over.
14131 
14132 “Hold on, hold on, won’t ye?” cried Stubb to the body, “don’t be in
14133 such a devil of a hurry to sink! By thunder, men, we must do something
14134 or go for it. No use prying there; avast, I say with your handspikes,
14135 and run one of ye for a prayer book and a pen-knife, and cut the big
14136 chains.”
14137 
14138 “Knife? Aye, aye,” cried Queequeg, and seizing the carpenter’s heavy
14139 hatchet, he leaned out of a porthole, and steel to iron, began slashing
14140 at the largest fluke-chains. But a few strokes, full of sparks, were
14141 given, when the exceeding strain effected the rest. With a terrific
14142 snap, every fastening went adrift; the ship righted, the carcase sank.
14143 
14144 Now, this occasional inevitable sinking of the recently killed Sperm
14145 Whale is a very curious thing; nor has any fisherman yet adequately
14146 accounted for it. Usually the dead Sperm Whale floats with great
14147 buoyancy, with its side or belly considerably elevated above the
14148 surface. If the only whales that thus sank were old, meagre, and
14149 broken-hearted creatures, their pads of lard diminished and all their
14150 bones heavy and rheumatic; then you might with some reason assert that
14151 this sinking is caused by an uncommon specific gravity in the fish so
14152 sinking, consequent upon this absence of buoyant matter in him. But it
14153 is not so. For young whales, in the highest health, and swelling with
14154 noble aspirations, prematurely cut off in the warm flush and May of
14155 life, with all their panting lard about them; even these brawny,
14156 buoyant heroes do sometimes sink.
14157 
14158 Be it said, however, that the Sperm Whale is far less liable to this
14159 accident than any other species. Where one of that sort go down, twenty
14160 Right Whales do. This difference in the species is no doubt imputable
14161 in no small degree to the greater quantity of bone in the Right Whale;
14162 his Venetian blinds alone sometimes weighing more than a ton; from this
14163 incumbrance the Sperm Whale is wholly free. But there are instances
14164 where, after the lapse of many hours or several days, the sunken whale
14165 again rises, more buoyant than in life. But the reason of this is
14166 obvious. Gases are generated in him; he swells to a prodigious
14167 magnitude; becomes a sort of animal balloon. A line-of-battle ship
14168 could hardly keep him under then. In the Shore Whaling, on soundings,
14169 among the Bays of New Zealand, when a Right Whale gives token of
14170 sinking, they fasten buoys to him, with plenty of rope; so that when
14171 the body has gone down, they know where to look for it when it shall
14172 have ascended again.
14173 
14174 It was not long after the sinking of the body that a cry was heard from
14175 the Pequod’s mast-heads, announcing that the Jungfrau was again
14176 lowering her boats; though the only spout in sight was that of a
14177 Fin-Back, belonging to the species of uncapturable whales, because of
14178 its incredible power of swimming. Nevertheless, the Fin-Back’s spout is
14179 so similar to the Sperm Whale’s, that by unskilful fishermen it is
14180 often mistaken for it. And consequently Derick and all his host were
14181 now in valiant chase of this unnearable brute. The Virgin crowding all
14182 sail, made after her four young keels, and thus they all disappeared
14183 far to leeward, still in bold, hopeful chase.
14184 
14185 Oh! many are the Fin-Backs, and many are the Dericks, my friend.
14186 
14187 
14188 CHAPTER 82. The Honor and Glory of Whaling.
14189 
14190 There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the
14191 true method.
14192 
14193 The more I dive into this matter of whaling, and push my researches up
14194 to the very spring-head of it so much the more am I impressed with its
14195 great honorableness and antiquity; and especially when I find so many
14196 great demi-gods and heroes, prophets of all sorts, who one way or other
14197 have shed distinction upon it, I am transported with the reflection
14198 that I myself belong, though but subordinately, to so emblazoned a
14199 fraternity.
14200 
14201 The gallant Perseus, a son of Jupiter, was the first whaleman; and to
14202 the eternal honor of our calling be it said, that the first whale
14203 attacked by our brotherhood was not killed with any sordid intent.
14204 Those were the knightly days of our profession, when we only bore arms
14205 to succor the distressed, and not to fill men’s lamp-feeders. Every one
14206 knows the fine story of Perseus and Andromeda; how the lovely
14207 Andromeda, the daughter of a king, was tied to a rock on the sea-coast,
14208 and as Leviathan was in the very act of carrying her off, Perseus, the
14209 prince of whalemen, intrepidly advancing, harpooned the monster, and
14210 delivered and married the maid. It was an admirable artistic exploit,
14211 rarely achieved by the best harpooneers of the present day; inasmuch as
14212 this Leviathan was slain at the very first dart. And let no man doubt
14213 this Arkite story; for in the ancient Joppa, now Jaffa, on the Syrian
14214 coast, in one of the Pagan temples, there stood for many ages the vast
14215 skeleton of a whale, which the city’s legends and all the inhabitants
14216 asserted to be the identical bones of the monster that Perseus slew.
14217 When the Romans took Joppa, the same skeleton was carried to Italy in
14218 triumph. What seems most singular and suggestively important in this
14219 story, is this: it was from Joppa that Jonah set sail.
14220 
14221 Akin to the adventure of Perseus and Andromeda—indeed, by some supposed
14222 to be indirectly derived from it—is that famous story of St. George and
14223 the Dragon; which dragon I maintain to have been a whale; for in many
14224 old chronicles whales and dragons are strangely jumbled together, and
14225 often stand for each other. “Thou art as a lion of the waters, and as a
14226 dragon of the sea,” saith Ezekiel; hereby, plainly meaning a whale; in
14227 truth, some versions of the Bible use that word itself. Besides, it
14228 would much subtract from the glory of the exploit had St. George but
14229 encountered a crawling reptile of the land, instead of doing battle
14230 with the great monster of the deep. Any man may kill a snake, but only
14231 a Perseus, a St. George, a Coffin, have the heart in them to march
14232 boldly up to a whale.
14233 
14234 Let not the modern paintings of this scene mislead us; for though the
14235 creature encountered by that valiant whaleman of old is vaguely
14236 represented of a griffin-like shape, and though the battle is depicted
14237 on land and the saint on horseback, yet considering the great ignorance
14238 of those times, when the true form of the whale was unknown to artists;
14239 and considering that as in Perseus’ case, St. George’s whale might have
14240 crawled up out of the sea on the beach; and considering that the animal
14241 ridden by St. George might have been only a large seal, or sea-horse;
14242 bearing all this in mind, it will not appear altogether incompatible
14243 with the sacred legend and the ancientest draughts of the scene, to
14244 hold this so-called dragon no other than the great Leviathan himself.
14245 In fact, placed before the strict and piercing truth, this whole story
14246 will fare like that fish, flesh, and fowl idol of the Philistines,
14247 Dagon by name; who being planted before the ark of Israel, his horse’s
14248 head and both the palms of his hands fell off from him, and only the
14249 stump or fishy part of him remained. Thus, then, one of our own noble
14250 stamp, even a whaleman, is the tutelary guardian of England; and by
14251 good rights, we harpooneers of Nantucket should be enrolled in the most
14252 noble order of St. George. And therefore, let not the knights of that
14253 honorable company (none of whom, I venture to say, have ever had to do
14254 with a whale like their great patron), let them never eye a Nantucketer
14255 with disdain, since even in our woollen frocks and tarred trowsers we
14256 are much better entitled to St. George’s decoration than they.
14257 
14258 Whether to admit Hercules among us or not, concerning this I long
14259 remained dubious: for though according to the Greek mythologies, that
14260 antique Crockett and Kit Carson—that brawny doer of rejoicing good
14261 deeds, was swallowed down and thrown up by a whale; still, whether that
14262 strictly makes a whaleman of him, that might be mooted. It nowhere
14263 appears that he ever actually harpooned his fish, unless, indeed, from
14264 the inside. Nevertheless, he may be deemed a sort of involuntary
14265 whaleman; at any rate the whale caught him, if he did not the whale. I
14266 claim him for one of our clan.
14267 
14268 But, by the best contradictory authorities, this Grecian story of
14269 Hercules and the whale is considered to be derived from the still more
14270 ancient Hebrew story of Jonah and the whale; and vice versâ; certainly
14271 they are very similar. If I claim the demi-god then, why not the
14272 prophet?
14273 
14274 Nor do heroes, saints, demigods, and prophets alone comprise the whole
14275 roll of our order. Our grand master is still to be named; for like
14276 royal kings of old times, we find the head waters of our fraternity in
14277 nothing short of the great gods themselves. That wondrous oriental
14278 story is now to be rehearsed from the Shaster, which gives us the dread
14279 Vishnoo, one of the three persons in the godhead of the Hindoos; gives
14280 us this divine Vishnoo himself for our Lord;—Vishnoo, who, by the first
14281 of his ten earthly incarnations, has for ever set apart and sanctified
14282 the whale. When Brahma, or the God of Gods, saith the Shaster, resolved
14283 to recreate the world after one of its periodical dissolutions, he gave
14284 birth to Vishnoo, to preside over the work; but the Vedas, or mystical
14285 books, whose perusal would seem to have been indispensable to Vishnoo
14286 before beginning the creation, and which therefore must have contained
14287 something in the shape of practical hints to young architects, these
14288 Vedas were lying at the bottom of the waters; so Vishnoo became
14289 incarnate in a whale, and sounding down in him to the uttermost depths,
14290 rescued the sacred volumes. Was not this Vishnoo a whaleman, then? even
14291 as a man who rides a horse is called a horseman?
14292 
14293 Perseus, St. George, Hercules, Jonah, and Vishnoo! there’s a
14294 member-roll for you! What club but the whaleman’s can head off like
14295 that?
14296 
14297 
14298 CHAPTER 83. Jonah Historically Regarded.
14299 
14300 Reference was made to the historical story of Jonah and the whale in
14301 the preceding chapter. Now some Nantucketers rather distrust this
14302 historical story of Jonah and the whale. But then there were some
14303 sceptical Greeks and Romans, who, standing out from the orthodox pagans
14304 of their times, equally doubted the story of Hercules and the whale,
14305 and Arion and the dolphin; and yet their doubting those traditions did
14306 not make those traditions one whit the less facts, for all that.
14307 
14308 One old Sag-Harbor whaleman’s chief reason for questioning the Hebrew
14309 story was this:—He had one of those quaint old-fashioned Bibles,
14310 embellished with curious, unscientific plates; one of which represented
14311 Jonah’s whale with two spouts in his head—a peculiarity only true with
14312 respect to a species of the Leviathan (the Right Whale, and the
14313 varieties of that order), concerning which the fishermen have this
14314 saying, “A penny roll would choke him”; his swallow is so very small.
14315 But, to this, Bishop Jebb’s anticipative answer is ready. It is not
14316 necessary, hints the Bishop, that we consider Jonah as tombed in the
14317 whale’s belly, but as temporarily lodged in some part of his mouth. And
14318 this seems reasonable enough in the good Bishop. For truly, the Right
14319 Whale’s mouth would accommodate a couple of whist-tables, and
14320 comfortably seat all the players. Possibly, too, Jonah might have
14321 ensconced himself in a hollow tooth; but, on second thoughts, the Right
14322 Whale is toothless.
14323 
14324 Another reason which Sag-Harbor (he went by that name) urged for his
14325 want of faith in this matter of the prophet, was something obscurely in
14326 reference to his incarcerated body and the whale’s gastric juices. But
14327 this objection likewise falls to the ground, because a German exegetist
14328 supposes that Jonah must have taken refuge in the floating body of a
14329 _dead_ whale—even as the French soldiers in the Russian campaign turned
14330 their dead horses into tents, and crawled into them. Besides, it has
14331 been divined by other continental commentators, that when Jonah was
14332 thrown overboard from the Joppa ship, he straightway effected his
14333 escape to another vessel near by, some vessel with a whale for a
14334 figure-head; and, I would add, possibly called “The Whale,” as some
14335 craft are nowadays christened the “Shark,” the “Gull,” the “Eagle.” Nor
14336 have there been wanting learned exegetists who have opined that the
14337 whale mentioned in the book of Jonah merely meant a life-preserver—an
14338 inflated bag of wind—which the endangered prophet swam to, and so was
14339 saved from a watery doom. Poor Sag-Harbor, therefore, seems worsted all
14340 round. But he had still another reason for his want of faith. It was
14341 this, if I remember right: Jonah was swallowed by the whale in the
14342 Mediterranean Sea, and after three days he was vomited up somewhere
14343 within three days’ journey of Nineveh, a city on the Tigris, very much
14344 more than three days’ journey across from the nearest point of the
14345 Mediterranean coast. How is that?
14346 
14347 But was there no other way for the whale to land the prophet within
14348 that short distance of Nineveh? Yes. He might have carried him round by
14349 the way of the Cape of Good Hope. But not to speak of the passage
14350 through the whole length of the Mediterranean, and another passage up
14351 the Persian Gulf and Red Sea, such a supposition would involve the
14352 complete circumnavigation of all Africa in three days, not to speak of
14353 the Tigris waters, near the site of Nineveh, being too shallow for any
14354 whale to swim in. Besides, this idea of Jonah’s weathering the Cape of
14355 Good Hope at so early a day would wrest the honor of the discovery of
14356 that great headland from Bartholomew Diaz, its reputed discoverer, and
14357 so make modern history a liar.
14358 
14359 But all these foolish arguments of old Sag-Harbor only evinced his
14360 foolish pride of reason—a thing still more reprehensible in him, seeing
14361 that he had but little learning except what he had picked up from the
14362 sun and the sea. I say it only shows his foolish, impious pride, and
14363 abominable, devilish rebellion against the reverend clergy. For by a
14364 Portuguese Catholic priest, this very idea of Jonah’s going to Nineveh
14365 via the Cape of Good Hope was advanced as a signal magnification of the
14366 general miracle. And so it was. Besides, to this day, the highly
14367 enlightened Turks devoutly believe in the historical story of Jonah.
14368 And some three centuries ago, an English traveller in old Harris’s
14369 Voyages, speaks of a Turkish Mosque built in honor of Jonah, in which
14370 Mosque was a miraculous lamp that burnt without any oil.
14371 
14372 
14373 CHAPTER 84. Pitchpoling.
14374 
14375 To make them run easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are
14376 anointed; and for much the same purpose, some whalers perform an
14377 analogous operation upon their boat; they grease the bottom. Nor is it
14378 to be doubted that as such a procedure can do no harm, it may possibly
14379 be of no contemptible advantage; considering that oil and water are
14380 hostile; that oil is a sliding thing, and that the object in view is to
14381 make the boat slide bravely. Queequeg believed strongly in anointing
14382 his boat, and one morning not long after the German ship Jungfrau
14383 disappeared, took more than customary pains in that occupation;
14384 crawling under its bottom, where it hung over the side, and rubbing in
14385 the unctuousness as though diligently seeking to insure a crop of hair
14386 from the craft’s bald keel. He seemed to be working in obedience to
14387 some particular presentiment. Nor did it remain unwarranted by the
14388 event.
14389 
14390 Towards noon whales were raised; but so soon as the ship sailed down to
14391 them, they turned and fled with swift precipitancy; a disordered
14392 flight, as of Cleopatra’s barges from Actium.
14393 
14394 Nevertheless, the boats pursued, and Stubb’s was foremost. By great
14395 exertion, Tashtego at last succeeded in planting one iron; but the
14396 stricken whale, without at all sounding, still continued his horizontal
14397 flight, with added fleetness. Such unintermitted strainings upon the
14398 planted iron must sooner or later inevitably extract it. It became
14399 imperative to lance the flying whale, or be content to lose him. But to
14400 haul the boat up to his flank was impossible, he swam so fast and
14401 furious. What then remained?
14402 
14403 Of all the wondrous devices and dexterities, the sleights of hand and
14404 countless subtleties, to which the veteran whaleman is so often forced,
14405 none exceed that fine manœuvre with the lance called pitchpoling. Small
14406 sword, or broad sword, in all its exercises boasts nothing like it. It
14407 is only indispensable with an inveterate running whale; its grand fact
14408 and feature is the wonderful distance to which the long lance is
14409 accurately darted from a violently rocking, jerking boat, under extreme
14410 headway. Steel and wood included, the entire spear is some ten or
14411 twelve feet in length; the staff is much slighter than that of the
14412 harpoon, and also of a lighter material—pine. It is furnished with a
14413 small rope called a warp, of considerable length, by which it can be
14414 hauled back to the hand after darting.
14415 
14416 But before going further, it is important to mention here, that though
14417 the harpoon may be pitchpoled in the same way with the lance, yet it is
14418 seldom done; and when done, is still less frequently successful, on
14419 account of the greater weight and inferior length of the harpoon as
14420 compared with the lance, which in effect become serious drawbacks. As a
14421 general thing, therefore, you must first get fast to a whale, before
14422 any pitchpoling comes into play.
14423 
14424 Look now at Stubb; a man who from his humorous, deliberate coolness and
14425 equanimity in the direst emergencies, was specially qualified to excel
14426 in pitchpoling. Look at him; he stands upright in the tossed bow of the
14427 flying boat; wrapt in fleecy foam, the towing whale is forty feet
14428 ahead. Handling the long lance lightly, glancing twice or thrice along
14429 its length to see if it be exactly straight, Stubb whistlingly gathers
14430 up the coil of the warp in one hand, so as to secure its free end in
14431 his grasp, leaving the rest unobstructed. Then holding the lance full
14432 before his waistband’s middle, he levels it at the whale; when,
14433 covering him with it, he steadily depresses the butt-end in his hand,
14434 thereby elevating the point till the weapon stands fairly balanced upon
14435 his palm, fifteen feet in the air. He minds you somewhat of a juggler,
14436 balancing a long staff on his chin. Next moment with a rapid, nameless
14437 impulse, in a superb lofty arch the bright steel spans the foaming
14438 distance, and quivers in the life spot of the whale. Instead of
14439 sparkling water, he now spouts red blood.
14440 
14441 “That drove the spigot out of him!” cried Stubb. “’Tis July’s immortal
14442 Fourth; all fountains must run wine today! Would now, it were old
14443 Orleans whiskey, or old Ohio, or unspeakable old Monongahela! Then,
14444 Tashtego, lad, I’d have ye hold a canakin to the jet, and we’d drink
14445 round it! Yea, verily, hearts alive, we’d brew choice punch in the
14446 spread of his spout-hole there, and from that live punch-bowl quaff the
14447 living stuff.”
14448 
14449 Again and again to such gamesome talk, the dexterous dart is repeated,
14450 the spear returning to its master like a greyhound held in skilful
14451 leash. The agonized whale goes into his flurry; the tow-line is
14452 slackened, and the pitchpoler dropping astern, folds his hands, and
14453 mutely watches the monster die.
14454 
14455 
14456 CHAPTER 85. The Fountain.
14457 
14458 That for six thousand years—and no one knows how many millions of ages
14459 before—the great whales should have been spouting all over the sea, and
14460 sprinkling and mistifying the gardens of the deep, as with so many
14461 sprinkling or mistifying pots; and that for some centuries back,
14462 thousands of hunters should have been close by the fountain of the
14463 whale, watching these sprinklings and spoutings—that all this should
14464 be, and yet, that down to this blessed minute (fifteen and a quarter
14465 minutes past one o’clock P.M. of this sixteenth day of December, A.D.
14466 1851), it should still remain a problem, whether these spoutings are,
14467 after all, really water, or nothing but vapor—this is surely a
14468 noteworthy thing.
14469 
14470 Let us, then, look at this matter, along with some interesting items
14471 contingent. Every one knows that by the peculiar cunning of their
14472 gills, the finny tribes in general breathe the air which at all times
14473 is combined with the element in which they swim; hence, a herring or a
14474 cod might live a century, and never once raise its head above the
14475 surface. But owing to his marked internal structure which gives him
14476 regular lungs, like a human being’s, the whale can only live by
14477 inhaling the disengaged air in the open atmosphere. Wherefore the
14478 necessity for his periodical visits to the upper world. But he cannot
14479 in any degree breathe through his mouth, for, in his ordinary attitude,
14480 the Sperm Whale’s mouth is buried at least eight feet beneath the
14481 surface; and what is still more, his windpipe has no connexion with his
14482 mouth. No, he breathes through his spiracle alone; and this is on the
14483 top of his head.
14484 
14485 If I say, that in any creature breathing is only a function
14486 indispensable to vitality, inasmuch as it withdraws from the air a
14487 certain element, which being subsequently brought into contact with the
14488 blood imparts to the blood its vivifying principle, I do not think I
14489 shall err; though I may possibly use some superfluous scientific words.
14490 Assume it, and it follows that if all the blood in a man could be
14491 aerated with one breath, he might then seal up his nostrils and not
14492 fetch another for a considerable time. That is to say, he would then
14493 live without breathing. Anomalous as it may seem, this is precisely the
14494 case with the whale, who systematically lives, by intervals, his full
14495 hour and more (when at the bottom) without drawing a single breath, or
14496 so much as in any way inhaling a particle of air; for, remember, he has
14497 no gills. How is this? Between his ribs and on each side of his spine
14498 he is supplied with a remarkable involved Cretan labyrinth of
14499 vermicelli-like vessels, which vessels, when he quits the surface, are
14500 completely distended with oxygenated blood. So that for an hour or
14501 more, a thousand fathoms in the sea, he carries a surplus stock of
14502 vitality in him, just as the camel crossing the waterless desert
14503 carries a surplus supply of drink for future use in its four
14504 supplementary stomachs. The anatomical fact of this labyrinth is
14505 indisputable; and that the supposition founded upon it is reasonable
14506 and true, seems the more cogent to me, when I consider the otherwise
14507 inexplicable obstinacy of that leviathan in _having his spoutings out_,
14508 as the fishermen phrase it. This is what I mean. If unmolested, upon
14509 rising to the surface, the Sperm Whale will continue there for a period
14510 of time exactly uniform with all his other unmolested risings. Say he
14511 stays eleven minutes, and jets seventy times, that is, respires seventy
14512 breaths; then whenever he rises again, he will be sure to have his
14513 seventy breaths over again, to a minute. Now, if after he fetches a few
14514 breaths you alarm him, so that he sounds, he will be always dodging up
14515 again to make good his regular allowance of air. And not till those
14516 seventy breaths are told, will he finally go down to stay out his full
14517 term below. Remark, however, that in different individuals these rates
14518 are different; but in any one they are alike. Now, why should the whale
14519 thus insist upon having his spoutings out, unless it be to replenish
14520 his reservoir of air, ere descending for good? How obvious is it, too,
14521 that this necessity for the whale’s rising exposes him to all the fatal
14522 hazards of the chase. For not by hook or by net could this vast
14523 leviathan be caught, when sailing a thousand fathoms beneath the
14524 sunlight. Not so much thy skill, then, O hunter, as the great
14525 necessities that strike the victory to thee!
14526 
14527 In man, breathing is incessantly going on—one breath only serving for
14528 two or three pulsations; so that whatever other business he has to
14529 attend to, waking or sleeping, breathe he must, or die he will. But the
14530 Sperm Whale only breathes about one seventh or Sunday of his time.
14531 
14532 It has been said that the whale only breathes through his spout-hole;
14533 if it could truthfully be added that his spouts are mixed with water,
14534 then I opine we should be furnished with the reason why his sense of
14535 smell seems obliterated in him; for the only thing about him that at
14536 all answers to his nose is that identical spout-hole; and being so
14537 clogged with two elements, it could not be expected to have the power
14538 of smelling. But owing to the mystery of the spout—whether it be water
14539 or whether it be vapor—no absolute certainty can as yet be arrived at
14540 on this head. Sure it is, nevertheless, that the Sperm Whale has no
14541 proper olfactories. But what does he want of them? No roses, no
14542 violets, no Cologne-water in the sea.
14543 
14544 Furthermore, as his windpipe solely opens into the tube of his spouting
