14545 canal, and as that long canal—like the grand Erie Canal—is furnished
14546 with a sort of locks (that open and shut) for the downward retention of
14547 air or the upward exclusion of water, therefore the whale has no voice;
14548 unless you insult him by saying, that when he so strangely rumbles, he
14549 talks through his nose. But then again, what has the whale to say?
14550 Seldom have I known any profound being that had anything to say to this
14551 world, unless forced to stammer out something by way of getting a
14552 living. Oh! happy that the world is such an excellent listener!
14553 
14554 Now, the spouting canal of the Sperm Whale, chiefly intended as it is
14555 for the conveyance of air, and for several feet laid along,
14556 horizontally, just beneath the upper surface of his head, and a little
14557 to one side; this curious canal is very much like a gas-pipe laid down
14558 in a city on one side of a street. But the question returns whether
14559 this gas-pipe is also a water-pipe; in other words, whether the spout
14560 of the Sperm Whale is the mere vapor of the exhaled breath, or whether
14561 that exhaled breath is mixed with water taken in at the mouth, and
14562 discharged through the spiracle. It is certain that the mouth
14563 indirectly communicates with the spouting canal; but it cannot be
14564 proved that this is for the purpose of discharging water through the
14565 spiracle. Because the greatest necessity for so doing would seem to be,
14566 when in feeding he accidentally takes in water. But the Sperm Whale’s
14567 food is far beneath the surface, and there he cannot spout even if he
14568 would. Besides, if you regard him very closely, and time him with your
14569 watch, you will find that when unmolested, there is an undeviating
14570 rhyme between the periods of his jets and the ordinary periods of
14571 respiration.
14572 
14573 But why pester one with all this reasoning on the subject? Speak out!
14574 You have seen him spout; then declare what the spout is; can you not
14575 tell water from air? My dear sir, in this world it is not so easy to
14576 settle these plain things. I have ever found your plain things the
14577 knottiest of all. And as for this whale spout, you might almost stand
14578 in it, and yet be undecided as to what it is precisely.
14579 
14580 The central body of it is hidden in the snowy sparkling mist enveloping
14581 it; and how can you certainly tell whether any water falls from it,
14582 when, always, when you are close enough to a whale to get a close view
14583 of his spout, he is in a prodigious commotion, the water cascading all
14584 around him. And if at such times you should think that you really
14585 perceived drops of moisture in the spout, how do you know that they are
14586 not merely condensed from its vapor; or how do you know that they are
14587 not those identical drops superficially lodged in the spout-hole
14588 fissure, which is countersunk into the summit of the whale’s head? For
14589 even when tranquilly swimming through the mid-day sea in a calm, with
14590 his elevated hump sun-dried as a dromedary’s in the desert; even then,
14591 the whale always carries a small basin of water on his head, as under a
14592 blazing sun you will sometimes see a cavity in a rock filled up with
14593 rain.
14594 
14595 Nor is it at all prudent for the hunter to be over curious touching the
14596 precise nature of the whale spout. It will not do for him to be peering
14597 into it, and putting his face in it. You cannot go with your pitcher to
14598 this fountain and fill it, and bring it away. For even when coming into
14599 slight contact with the outer, vapory shreds of the jet, which will
14600 often happen, your skin will feverishly smart, from the acridness of
14601 the thing so touching it. And I know one, who coming into still closer
14602 contact with the spout, whether with some scientific object in view, or
14603 otherwise, I cannot say, the skin peeled off from his cheek and arm.
14604 Wherefore, among whalemen, the spout is deemed poisonous; they try to
14605 evade it. Another thing; I have heard it said, and I do not much doubt
14606 it, that if the jet is fairly spouted into your eyes, it will blind
14607 you. The wisest thing the investigator can do then, it seems to me, is
14608 to let this deadly spout alone.
14609 
14610 Still, we can hypothesize, even if we cannot prove and establish. My
14611 hypothesis is this: that the spout is nothing but mist. And besides
14612 other reasons, to this conclusion I am impelled, by considerations
14613 touching the great inherent dignity and sublimity of the Sperm Whale; I
14614 account him no common, shallow being, inasmuch as it is an undisputed
14615 fact that he is never found on soundings, or near shores; all other
14616 whales sometimes are. He is both ponderous and profound. And I am
14617 convinced that from the heads of all ponderous profound beings, such as
14618 Plato, Pyrrho, the Devil, Jupiter, Dante, and so on, there always goes
14619 up a certain semi-visible steam, while in the act of thinking deep
14620 thoughts. While composing a little treatise on Eternity, I had the
14621 curiosity to place a mirror before me; and ere long saw reflected
14622 there, a curious involved worming and undulation in the atmosphere over
14623 my head. The invariable moisture of my hair, while plunged in deep
14624 thought, after six cups of hot tea in my thin shingled attic, of an
14625 August noon; this seems an additional argument for the above
14626 supposition.
14627 
14628 And how nobly it raises our conceit of the mighty, misty monster, to
14629 behold him solemnly sailing through a calm tropical sea; his vast, mild
14630 head overhung by a canopy of vapor, engendered by his incommunicable
14631 contemplations, and that vapor—as you will sometimes see it—glorified
14632 by a rainbow, as if Heaven itself had put its seal upon his thoughts.
14633 For, d’ye see, rainbows do not visit the clear air; they only irradiate
14634 vapor. And so, through all the thick mists of the dim doubts in my
14635 mind, divine intuitions now and then shoot, enkindling my fog with a
14636 heavenly ray. And for this I thank God; for all have doubts; many deny;
14637 but doubts or denials, few along with them, have intuitions. Doubts of
14638 all things earthly, and intuitions of some things heavenly; this
14639 combination makes neither believer nor infidel, but makes a man who
14640 regards them both with equal eye.
14641 
14642 
14643 CHAPTER 86. The Tail.
14644 
14645 Other poets have warbled the praises of the soft eye of the antelope,
14646 and the lovely plumage of the bird that never alights; less celestial,
14647 I celebrate a tail.
14648 
14649 Reckoning the largest sized Sperm Whale’s tail to begin at that point
14650 of the trunk where it tapers to about the girth of a man, it comprises
14651 upon its upper surface alone, an area of at least fifty square feet.
14652 The compact round body of its root expands into two broad, firm, flat
14653 palms or flukes, gradually shoaling away to less than an inch in
14654 thickness. At the crotch or junction, these flukes slightly overlap,
14655 then sideways recede from each other like wings, leaving a wide vacancy
14656 between. In no living thing are the lines of beauty more exquisitely
14657 defined than in the crescentic borders of these flukes. At its utmost
14658 expansion in the full grown whale, the tail will considerably exceed
14659 twenty feet across.
14660 
14661 The entire member seems a dense webbed bed of welded sinews; but cut
14662 into it, and you find that three distinct strata compose it:—upper,
14663 middle, and lower. The fibres in the upper and lower layers, are long
14664 and horizontal; those of the middle one, very short, and running
14665 crosswise between the outside layers. This triune structure, as much as
14666 anything else, imparts power to the tail. To the student of old Roman
14667 walls, the middle layer will furnish a curious parallel to the thin
14668 course of tiles always alternating with the stone in those wonderful
14669 relics of the antique, and which undoubtedly contribute so much to the
14670 great strength of the masonry.
14671 
14672 But as if this vast local power in the tendinous tail were not enough,
14673 the whole bulk of the leviathan is knit over with a warp and woof of
14674 muscular fibres and filaments, which passing on either side the loins
14675 and running down into the flukes, insensibly blend with them, and
14676 largely contribute to their might; so that in the tail the confluent
14677 measureless force of the whole whale seems concentrated to a point.
14678 Could annihilation occur to matter, this were the thing to do it.
14679 
14680 Nor does this—its amazing strength, at all tend to cripple the graceful
14681 flexion of its motions; where infantileness of ease undulates through a
14682 Titanism of power. On the contrary, those motions derive their most
14683 appalling beauty from it. Real strength never impairs beauty or
14684 harmony, but it often bestows it; and in everything imposingly
14685 beautiful, strength has much to do with the magic. Take away the tied
14686 tendons that all over seem bursting from the marble in the carved
14687 Hercules, and its charm would be gone. As devout Eckerman lifted the
14688 linen sheet from the naked corpse of Goethe, he was overwhelmed with
14689 the massive chest of the man, that seemed as a Roman triumphal arch.
14690 When Angelo paints even God the Father in human form, mark what
14691 robustness is there. And whatever they may reveal of the divine love in
14692 the Son, the soft, curled, hermaphroditical Italian pictures, in which
14693 his idea has been most successfully embodied; these pictures, so
14694 destitute as they are of all brawniness, hint nothing of any power, but
14695 the mere negative, feminine one of submission and endurance, which on
14696 all hands it is conceded, form the peculiar practical virtues of his
14697 teachings.
14698 
14699 Such is the subtle elasticity of the organ I treat of, that whether
14700 wielded in sport, or in earnest, or in anger, whatever be the mood it
14701 be in, its flexions are invariably marked by exceeding grace. Therein
14702 no fairy’s arm can transcend it.
14703 
14704 Five great motions are peculiar to it. First, when used as a fin for
14705 progression; Second, when used as a mace in battle; Third, in sweeping;
14706 Fourth, in lobtailing; Fifth, in peaking flukes.
14707 
14708 First: Being horizontal in its position, the Leviathan’s tail acts in a
14709 different manner from the tails of all other sea creatures. It never
14710 wriggles. In man or fish, wriggling is a sign of inferiority. To the
14711 whale, his tail is the sole means of propulsion. Scroll-wise coiled
14712 forwards beneath the body, and then rapidly sprung backwards, it is
14713 this which gives that singular darting, leaping motion to the monster
14714 when furiously swimming. His side-fins only serve to steer by.
14715 
14716 Second: It is a little significant, that while one sperm whale only
14717 fights another sperm whale with his head and jaw, nevertheless, in his
14718 conflicts with man, he chiefly and contemptuously uses his tail. In
14719 striking at a boat, he swiftly curves away his flukes from it, and the
14720 blow is only inflicted by the recoil. If it be made in the unobstructed
14721 air, especially if it descend to its mark, the stroke is then simply
14722 irresistible. No ribs of man or boat can withstand it. Your only
14723 salvation lies in eluding it; but if it comes sideways through the
14724 opposing water, then partly owing to the light buoyancy of the
14725 whale-boat, and the elasticity of its materials, a cracked rib or a
14726 dashed plank or two, a sort of stitch in the side, is generally the
14727 most serious result. These submerged side blows are so often received
14728 in the fishery, that they are accounted mere child’s play. Some one
14729 strips off a frock, and the hole is stopped.
14730 
14731 Third: I cannot demonstrate it, but it seems to me, that in the whale
14732 the sense of touch is concentrated in the tail; for in this respect
14733 there is a delicacy in it only equalled by the daintiness of the
14734 elephant’s trunk. This delicacy is chiefly evinced in the action of
14735 sweeping, when in maidenly gentleness the whale with a certain soft
14736 slowness moves his immense flukes from side to side upon the surface of
14737 the sea; and if he feel but a sailor’s whisker, woe to that sailor,
14738 whiskers and all. What tenderness there is in that preliminary touch!
14739 Had this tail any prehensile power, I should straightway bethink me of
14740 Darmonodes’ elephant that so frequented the flower-market, and with low
14741 salutations presented nosegays to damsels, and then caressed their
14742 zones. On more accounts than one, a pity it is that the whale does not
14743 possess this prehensile virtue in his tail; for I have heard of yet
14744 another elephant, that when wounded in the fight, curved round his
14745 trunk and extracted the dart.
14746 
14747 Fourth: Stealing unawares upon the whale in the fancied security of the
14748 middle of solitary seas, you find him unbent from the vast corpulence
14749 of his dignity, and kitten-like, he plays on the ocean as if it were a
14750 hearth. But still you see his power in his play. The broad palms of his
14751 tail are flirted high into the air; then smiting the surface, the
14752 thunderous concussion resounds for miles. You would almost think a
14753 great gun had been discharged; and if you noticed the light wreath of
14754 vapor from the spiracle at his other extremity, you would think that
14755 that was the smoke from the touch-hole.
14756 
14757 Fifth: As in the ordinary floating posture of the leviathan the flukes
14758 lie considerably below the level of his back, they are then completely
14759 out of sight beneath the surface; but when he is about to plunge into
14760 the deeps, his entire flukes with at least thirty feet of his body are
14761 tossed erect in the air, and so remain vibrating a moment, till they
14762 downwards shoot out of view. Excepting the sublime _breach_—somewhere
14763 else to be described—this peaking of the whale’s flukes is perhaps the
14764 grandest sight to be seen in all animated nature. Out of the bottomless
14765 profundities the gigantic tail seems spasmodically snatching at the
14766 highest heaven. So in dreams, have I seen majestic Satan thrusting
14767 forth his tormented colossal claw from the flame Baltic of Hell. But in
14768 gazing at such scenes, it is all in all what mood you are in; if in the
14769 Dantean, the devils will occur to you; if in that of Isaiah, the
14770 archangels. Standing at the mast-head of my ship during a sunrise that
14771 crimsoned sky and sea, I once saw a large herd of whales in the east,
14772 all heading towards the sun, and for a moment vibrating in concert with
14773 peaked flukes. As it seemed to me at the time, such a grand embodiment
14774 of adoration of the gods was never beheld, even in Persia, the home of
14775 the fire worshippers. As Ptolemy Philopater testified of the African
14776 elephant, I then testified of the whale, pronouncing him the most
14777 devout of all beings. For according to King Juba, the military
14778 elephants of antiquity often hailed the morning with their trunks
14779 uplifted in the profoundest silence.
14780 
14781 The chance comparison in this chapter, between the whale and the
14782 elephant, so far as some aspects of the tail of the one and the trunk
14783 of the other are concerned, should not tend to place those two opposite
14784 organs on an equality, much less the creatures to which they
14785 respectively belong. For as the mightiest elephant is but a terrier to
14786 Leviathan, so, compared with Leviathan’s tail, his trunk is but the
14787 stalk of a lily. The most direful blow from the elephant’s trunk were
14788 as the playful tap of a fan, compared with the measureless crush and
14789 crash of the sperm whale’s ponderous flukes, which in repeated
14790 instances have one after the other hurled entire boats with all their
14791 oars and crews into the air, very much as an Indian juggler tosses his
14792 balls.*
14793 
14794 *Though all comparison in the way of general bulk between the whale and
14795 the elephant is preposterous, inasmuch as in that particular the
14796 elephant stands in much the same respect to the whale that a dog does
14797 to the elephant; nevertheless, there are not wanting some points of
14798 curious similitude; among these is the spout. It is well known that the
14799 elephant will often draw up water or dust in his trunk, and then
14800 elevating it, jet it forth in a stream.
14801 
14802 The more I consider this mighty tail, the more do I deplore my
14803 inability to express it. At times there are gestures in it, which,
14804 though they would well grace the hand of man, remain wholly
14805 inexplicable. In an extensive herd, so remarkable, occasionally, are
14806 these mystic gestures, that I have heard hunters who have declared them
14807 akin to Free-Mason signs and symbols; that the whale, indeed, by these
14808 methods intelligently conversed with the world. Nor are there wanting
14809 other motions of the whale in his general body, full of strangeness,
14810 and unaccountable to his most experienced assailant. Dissect him how I
14811 may, then, I but go skin deep; I know him not, and never will. But if I
14812 know not even the tail of this whale, how understand his head? much
14813 more, how comprehend his face, when face he has none? Thou shalt see my
14814 back parts, my tail, he seems to say, but my face shall not be seen.
14815 But I cannot completely make out his back parts; and hint what he will
14816 about his face, I say again he has no face.
14817 
14818 
14819 CHAPTER 87. The Grand Armada.
14820 
14821 The long and narrow peninsula of Malacca, extending south-eastward from
14822 the territories of Birmah, forms the most southerly point of all Asia.
14823 In a continuous line from that peninsula stretch the long islands of
14824 Sumatra, Java, Bally, and Timor; which, with many others, form a vast
14825 mole, or rampart, lengthwise connecting Asia with Australia, and
14826 dividing the long unbroken Indian ocean from the thickly studded
14827 oriental archipelagoes. This rampart is pierced by several sally-ports
14828 for the convenience of ships and whales; conspicuous among which are
14829 the straits of Sunda and Malacca. By the straits of Sunda, chiefly,
14830 vessels bound to China from the west, emerge into the China seas.
14831 
14832 Those narrow straits of Sunda divide Sumatra from Java; and standing
14833 midway in that vast rampart of islands, buttressed by that bold green
14834 promontory, known to seamen as Java Head; they not a little correspond
14835 to the central gateway opening into some vast walled empire: and
14836 considering the inexhaustible wealth of spices, and silks, and jewels,
14837 and gold, and ivory, with which the thousand islands of that oriental
14838 sea are enriched, it seems a significant provision of nature, that such
14839 treasures, by the very formation of the land, should at least bear the
14840 appearance, however ineffectual, of being guarded from the all-grasping
14841 western world. The shores of the Straits of Sunda are unsupplied with
14842 those domineering fortresses which guard the entrances to the
14843 Mediterranean, the Baltic, and the Propontis. Unlike the Danes, these
14844 Orientals do not demand the obsequious homage of lowered top-sails from
14845 the endless procession of ships before the wind, which for centuries
14846 past, by night and by day, have passed between the islands of Sumatra
14847 and Java, freighted with the costliest cargoes of the east. But while
14848 they freely waive a ceremonial like this, they do by no means renounce
14849 their claim to more solid tribute.
14850 
14851 Time out of mind the piratical proas of the Malays, lurking among the
14852 low shaded coves and islets of Sumatra, have sallied out upon the
14853 vessels sailing through the straits, fiercely demanding tribute at the
14854 point of their spears. Though by the repeated bloody chastisements they
14855 have received at the hands of European cruisers, the audacity of these
14856 corsairs has of late been somewhat repressed; yet, even at the present
14857 day, we occasionally hear of English and American vessels, which, in
14858 those waters, have been remorselessly boarded and pillaged.
14859 
14860 With a fair, fresh wind, the Pequod was now drawing nigh to these
14861 straits; Ahab purposing to pass through them into the Javan sea, and
14862 thence, cruising northwards, over waters known to be frequented here
14863 and there by the Sperm Whale, sweep inshore by the Philippine Islands,
14864 and gain the far coast of Japan, in time for the great whaling season
14865 there. By these means, the circumnavigating Pequod would sweep almost
14866 all the known Sperm Whale cruising grounds of the world, previous to
14867 descending upon the Line in the Pacific; where Ahab, though everywhere
14868 else foiled in his pursuit, firmly counted upon giving battle to Moby
14869 Dick, in the sea he was most known to frequent; and at a season when he
14870 might most reasonably be presumed to be haunting it.
14871 
14872 But how now? in this zoned quest, does Ahab touch no land? does his
14873 crew drink air? Surely, he will stop for water. Nay. For a long time,
14874 now, the circus-running sun has raced within his fiery ring, and needs
14875 no sustenance but what’s in himself. So Ahab. Mark this, too, in the
14876 whaler. While other hulls are loaded down with alien stuff, to be
14877 transferred to foreign wharves; the world-wandering whale-ship carries
14878 no cargo but herself and crew, their weapons and their wants. She has a
14879 whole lake’s contents bottled in her ample hold. She is ballasted with
14880 utilities; not altogether with unusable pig-lead and kentledge. She
14881 carries years’ water in her. Clear old prime Nantucket water; which,
14882 when three years afloat, the Nantucketer, in the Pacific, prefers to
14883 drink before the brackish fluid, but yesterday rafted off in casks,
14884 from the Peruvian or Indian streams. Hence it is, that, while other
14885 ships may have gone to China from New York, and back again, touching at
14886 a score of ports, the whale-ship, in all that interval, may not have
14887 sighted one grain of soil; her crew having seen no man but floating
14888 seamen like themselves. So that did you carry them the news that
14889 another flood had come; they would only answer—“Well, boys, here’s the
14890 ark!”
14891 
14892 Now, as many Sperm Whales had been captured off the western coast of
14893 Java, in the near vicinity of the Straits of Sunda; indeed, as most of
14894 the ground, roundabout, was generally recognised by the fishermen as an
14895 excellent spot for cruising; therefore, as the Pequod gained more and
14896 more upon Java Head, the look-outs were repeatedly hailed, and
14897 admonished to keep wide awake. But though the green palmy cliffs of the
14898 land soon loomed on the starboard bow, and with delighted nostrils the
14899 fresh cinnamon was snuffed in the air, yet not a single jet was
14900 descried. Almost renouncing all thought of falling in with any game
14901 hereabouts, the ship had well nigh entered the straits, when the
14902 customary cheering cry was heard from aloft, and ere long a spectacle
14903 of singular magnificence saluted us.
14904 
14905 But here be it premised, that owing to the unwearied activity with
14906 which of late they have been hunted over all four oceans, the Sperm
14907 Whales, instead of almost invariably sailing in small detached
14908 companies, as in former times, are now frequently met with in extensive
14909 herds, sometimes embracing so great a multitude, that it would almost
14910 seem as if numerous nations of them had sworn solemn league and
14911 covenant for mutual assistance and protection. To this aggregation of
14912 the Sperm Whale into such immense caravans, may be imputed the
14913 circumstance that even in the best cruising grounds, you may now
14914 sometimes sail for weeks and months together, without being greeted by
14915 a single spout; and then be suddenly saluted by what sometimes seems
14916 thousands on thousands.
14917 
14918 Broad on both bows, at the distance of some two or three miles, and
14919 forming a great semicircle, embracing one half of the level horizon, a
14920 continuous chain of whale-jets were up-playing and sparkling in the
14921 noon-day air. Unlike the straight perpendicular twin-jets of the Right
14922 Whale, which, dividing at top, fall over in two branches, like the
14923 cleft drooping boughs of a willow, the single forward-slanting spout of
14924 the Sperm Whale presents a thick curled bush of white mist, continually
14925 rising and falling away to leeward.
14926 
14927 Seen from the Pequod’s deck, then, as she would rise on a high hill of
14928 the sea, this host of vapory spouts, individually curling up into the
14929 air, and beheld through a blending atmosphere of bluish haze, showed
14930 like the thousand cheerful chimneys of some dense metropolis, descried
14931 of a balmy autumnal morning, by some horseman on a height.
14932 
14933 As marching armies approaching an unfriendly defile in the mountains,
14934 accelerate their march, all eagerness to place that perilous passage in
14935 their rear, and once more expand in comparative security upon the
14936 plain; even so did this vast fleet of whales now seem hurrying forward
14937 through the straits; gradually contracting the wings of their
14938 semicircle, and swimming on, in one solid, but still crescentic centre.
14939 
14940 Crowding all sail the Pequod pressed after them; the harpooneers
14941 handling their weapons, and loudly cheering from the heads of their yet
14942 suspended boats. If the wind only held, little doubt had they, that
14943 chased through these Straits of Sunda, the vast host would only deploy
14944 into the Oriental seas to witness the capture of not a few of their
14945 number. And who could tell whether, in that congregated caravan, Moby
14946 Dick himself might not temporarily be swimming, like the worshipped
14947 white-elephant in the coronation procession of the Siamese! So with
14948 stun-sail piled on stun-sail, we sailed along, driving these leviathans
14949 before us; when, of a sudden, the voice of Tashtego was heard, loudly
14950 directing attention to something in our wake.
14951 
14952 Corresponding to the crescent in our van, we beheld another in our
14953 rear. It seemed formed of detached white vapors, rising and falling
14954 something like the spouts of the whales; only they did not so
14955 completely come and go; for they constantly hovered, without finally
14956 disappearing. Levelling his glass at this sight, Ahab quickly revolved
14957 in his pivot-hole, crying, “Aloft there, and rig whips and buckets to
14958 wet the sails;—Malays, sir, and after us!”
14959 
14960 As if too long lurking behind the headlands, till the Pequod should
14961 fairly have entered the straits, these rascally Asiatics were now in
14962 hot pursuit, to make up for their over-cautious delay. But when the
14963 swift Pequod, with a fresh leading wind, was herself in hot chase; how
14964 very kind of these tawny philanthropists to assist in speeding her on
14965 to her own chosen pursuit,—mere riding-whips and rowels to her, that
14966 they were. As with glass under arm, Ahab to-and-fro paced the deck; in
14967 his forward turn beholding the monsters he chased, and in the after one
14968 the bloodthirsty pirates chasing _him_; some such fancy as the above
14969 seemed his. And when he glanced upon the green walls of the watery
14970 defile in which the ship was then sailing, and bethought him that
14971 through that gate lay the route to his vengeance, and beheld, how that
14972 through that same gate he was now both chasing and being chased to his
14973 deadly end; and not only that, but a herd of remorseless wild pirates
14974 and inhuman atheistical devils were infernally cheering him on with
14975 their curses;—when all these conceits had passed through his brain,
14976 Ahab’s brow was left gaunt and ribbed, like the black sand beach after
14977 some stormy tide has been gnawing it, without being able to drag the
14978 firm thing from its place.
14979 
14980 But thoughts like these troubled very few of the reckless crew; and
14981 when, after steadily dropping and dropping the pirates astern, the
14982 Pequod at last shot by the vivid green Cockatoo Point on the Sumatra
14983 side, emerging at last upon the broad waters beyond; then, the
14984 harpooneers seemed more to grieve that the swift whales had been
14985 gaining upon the ship, than to rejoice that the ship had so
14986 victoriously gained upon the Malays. But still driving on in the wake
14987 of the whales, at length they seemed abating their speed; gradually the
14988 ship neared them; and the wind now dying away, word was passed to
14989 spring to the boats. But no sooner did the herd, by some presumed
14990 wonderful instinct of the Sperm Whale, become notified of the three
14991 keels that were after them,—though as yet a mile in their rear,—than
14992 they rallied again, and forming in close ranks and battalions, so that
14993 their spouts all looked like flashing lines of stacked bayonets, moved
14994 on with redoubled velocity.
14995 
14996 Stripped to our shirts and drawers, we sprang to the white-ash, and
14997 after several hours’ pulling were almost disposed to renounce the
14998 chase, when a general pausing commotion among the whales gave animating
14999 token that they were now at last under the influence of that strange
15000 perplexity of inert irresolution, which, when the fishermen perceive it
15001 in the whale, they say he is gallied. The compact martial columns in
15002 which they had been hitherto rapidly and steadily swimming, were now
15003 broken up in one measureless rout; and like King Porus’ elephants in
15004 the Indian battle with Alexander, they seemed going mad with
15005 consternation. In all directions expanding in vast irregular circles,
15006 and aimlessly swimming hither and thither, by their short thick
15007 spoutings, they plainly betrayed their distraction of panic. This was
15008 still more strangely evinced by those of their number, who, completely
15009 paralysed as it were, helplessly floated like water-logged dismantled
15010 ships on the sea. Had these Leviathans been but a flock of simple
15011 sheep, pursued over the pasture by three fierce wolves, they could not
15012 possibly have evinced such excessive dismay. But this occasional
15013 timidity is characteristic of almost all herding creatures. Though
15014 banding together in tens of thousands, the lion-maned buffaloes of the
15015 West have fled before a solitary horseman. Witness, too, all human
15016 beings, how when herded together in the sheepfold of a theatre’s pit,
15017 they will, at the slightest alarm of fire, rush helter-skelter for the
15018 outlets, crowding, trampling, jamming, and remorselessly dashing each
15019 other to death. Best, therefore, withhold any amazement at the
15020 strangely gallied whales before us, for there is no folly of the beasts
15021 of the earth which is not infinitely outdone by the madness of men.
15022 
15023 Though many of the whales, as has been said, were in violent motion,
15024 yet it is to be observed that as a whole the herd neither advanced nor
15025 retreated, but collectively remained in one place. As is customary in
15026 those cases, the boats at once separated, each making for some one lone
15027 whale on the outskirts of the shoal. In about three minutes’ time,
15028 Queequeg’s harpoon was flung; the stricken fish darted blinding spray
15029 in our faces, and then running away with us like light, steered
15030 straight for the heart of the herd. Though such a movement on the part
15031 of the whale struck under such circumstances, is in no wise
15032 unprecedented; and indeed is almost always more or less anticipated;
15033 yet does it present one of the more perilous vicissitudes of the
15034 fishery. For as the swift monster drags you deeper and deeper into the
15035 frantic shoal, you bid adieu to circumspect life and only exist in a
15036 delirious throb.
15037 
15038 As, blind and deaf, the whale plunged forward, as if by sheer power of
15039 speed to rid himself of the iron leech that had fastened to him; as we
15040 thus tore a white gash in the sea, on all sides menaced as we flew, by
15041 the crazed creatures to and fro rushing about us; our beset boat was
15042 like a ship mobbed by ice-isles in a tempest, and striving to steer
15043 through their complicated channels and straits, knowing not at what
15044 moment it may be locked in and crushed.
15045 
15046 But not a bit daunted, Queequeg steered us manfully; now sheering off
15047 from this monster directly across our route in advance; now edging away
15048 from that, whose colossal flukes were suspended overhead, while all the
15049 time, Starbuck stood up in the bows, lance in hand, pricking out of our
15050 way whatever whales he could reach by short darts, for there was no
15051 time to make long ones. Nor were the oarsmen quite idle, though their
15052 wonted duty was now altogether dispensed with. They chiefly attended to
15053 the shouting part of the business. “Out of the way, Commodore!” cried
15054 one, to a great dromedary that of a sudden rose bodily to the surface,
15055 and for an instant threatened to swamp us. “Hard down with your tail,
15056 there!” cried a second to another, which, close to our gunwale, seemed
15057 calmly cooling himself with his own fan-like extremity.
15058 
15059 All whaleboats carry certain curious contrivances, originally invented
15060 by the Nantucket Indians, called druggs. Two thick squares of wood of
15061 equal size are stoutly clenched together, so that they cross each
15062 other’s grain at right angles; a line of considerable length is then
15063 attached to the middle of this block, and the other end of the line
15064 being looped, it can in a moment be fastened to a harpoon. It is
15065 chiefly among gallied whales that this drugg is used. For then, more
15066 whales are close round you than you can possibly chase at one time. But
15067 sperm whales are not every day encountered; while you may, then, you
15068 must kill all you can. And if you cannot kill them all at once, you
15069 must wing them, so that they can be afterwards killed at your leisure.
15070 Hence it is, that at times like these the drugg, comes into
15071 requisition. Our boat was furnished with three of them. The first and
15072 second were successfully darted, and we saw the whales staggeringly
15073 running off, fettered by the enormous sidelong resistance of the towing
15074 drugg. They were cramped like malefactors with the chain and ball. But
15075 upon flinging the third, in the act of tossing overboard the clumsy
15076 wooden block, it caught under one of the seats of the boat, and in an
15077 instant tore it out and carried it away, dropping the oarsman in the
15078 boat’s bottom as the seat slid from under him. On both sides the sea
15079 came in at the wounded planks, but we stuffed two or three drawers and
15080 shirts in, and so stopped the leaks for the time.
15081 
15082 It had been next to impossible to dart these drugged-harpoons, were it
15083 not that as we advanced into the herd, our whale’s way greatly
15084 diminished; moreover, that as we went still further and further from
15085 the circumference of commotion, the direful disorders seemed waning. So
15086 that when at last the jerking harpoon drew out, and the towing whale
15087 sideways vanished; then, with the tapering force of his parting
15088 momentum, we glided between two whales into the innermost heart of the
15089 shoal, as if from some mountain torrent we had slid into a serene
15090 valley lake. Here the storms in the roaring glens between the outermost
15091 whales, were heard but not felt. In this central expanse the sea
15092 presented that smooth satin-like surface, called a sleek, produced by
15093 the subtle moisture thrown off by the whale in his more quiet moods.
15094 Yes, we were now in that enchanted calm which they say lurks at the
15095 heart of every commotion. And still in the distracted distance we
15096 beheld the tumults of the outer concentric circles, and saw successive
15097 pods of whales, eight or ten in each, swiftly going round and round,
15098 like multiplied spans of horses in a ring; and so closely shoulder to
15099 shoulder, that a Titanic circus-rider might easily have over-arched the
15100 middle ones, and so have gone round on their backs. Owing to the
15101 density of the crowd of reposing whales, more immediately surrounding
15102 the embayed axis of the herd, no possible chance of escape was at
15103 present afforded us. We must watch for a breach in the living wall that
15104 hemmed us in; the wall that had only admitted us in order to shut us
15105 up. Keeping at the centre of the lake, we were occasionally visited by
15106 small tame cows and calves; the women and children of this routed host.
15107 
15108 Now, inclusive of the occasional wide intervals between the revolving
15109 outer circles, and inclusive of the spaces between the various pods in
15110 any one of those circles, the entire area at this juncture, embraced by
15111 the whole multitude, must have contained at least two or three square
15112 miles. At any rate—though indeed such a test at such a time might be
15113 deceptive—spoutings might be discovered from our low boat that seemed
15114 playing up almost from the rim of the horizon. I mention this
15115 circumstance, because, as if the cows and calves had been purposely
15116 locked up in this innermost fold; and as if the wide extent of the herd
15117 had hitherto prevented them from learning the precise cause of its
15118 stopping; or, possibly, being so young, unsophisticated, and every way
15119 innocent and inexperienced; however it may have been, these smaller
15120 whales—now and then visiting our becalmed boat from the margin of the
15121 lake—evinced a wondrous fearlessness and confidence, or else a still
15122 becharmed panic which it was impossible not to marvel at. Like
15123 household dogs they came snuffling round us, right up to our gunwales,
15124 and touching them; till it almost seemed that some spell had suddenly
15125 domesticated them. Queequeg patted their foreheads; Starbuck scratched
15126 their backs with his lance; but fearful of the consequences, for the
15127 time refrained from darting it.
15128 
15129 But far beneath this wondrous world upon the surface, another and still
15130 stranger world met our eyes as we gazed over the side. For, suspended
15131 in those watery vaults, floated the forms of the nursing mothers of the
15132 whales, and those that by their enormous girth seemed shortly to become
15133 mothers. The lake, as I have hinted, was to a considerable depth
15134 exceedingly transparent; and as human infants while suckling will
15135 calmly and fixedly gaze away from the breast, as if leading two
15136 different lives at the time; and while yet drawing mortal nourishment,
15137 be still spiritually feasting upon some unearthly reminiscence;—even so
15138 did the young of these whales seem looking up towards us, but not at
15139 us, as if we were but a bit of Gulfweed in their new-born sight.
15140 Floating on their sides, the mothers also seemed quietly eyeing us. One
15141 of these little infants, that from certain queer tokens seemed hardly a
15142 day old, might have measured some fourteen feet in length, and some six
15143 feet in girth. He was a little frisky; though as yet his body seemed
15144 scarce yet recovered from that irksome position it had so lately
15145 occupied in the maternal reticule; where, tail to head, and all ready
15146 for the final spring, the unborn whale lies bent like a Tartar’s bow.
15147 The delicate side-fins, and the palms of his flukes, still freshly
15148 retained the plaited crumpled appearance of a baby’s ears newly arrived
15149 from foreign parts.
15150 
15151 “Line! line!” cried Queequeg, looking over the gunwale; “him fast! him
15152 fast!—Who line him! Who struck?—Two whale; one big, one little!”
15153 
15154 “What ails ye, man?” cried Starbuck.
15155 
15156 “Look-e here,” said Queequeg, pointing down.
15157 
15158 As when the stricken whale, that from the tub has reeled out hundreds
15159 of fathoms of rope; as, after deep sounding, he floats up again, and
15160 shows the slackened curling line buoyantly rising and spiralling
15161 towards the air; so now, Starbuck saw long coils of the umbilical cord
15162 of Madame Leviathan, by which the young cub seemed still tethered to
15163 its dam. Not seldom in the rapid vicissitudes of the chase, this
15164 natural line, with the maternal end loose, becomes entangled with the
15165 hempen one, so that the cub is thereby trapped. Some of the subtlest
15166 secrets of the seas seemed divulged to us in this enchanted pond. We
15167 saw young Leviathan amours in the deep.*
15168 
15169 *The sperm whale, as with all other species of the Leviathan, but
15170 unlike most other fish, breeds indifferently at all seasons; after a
15171 gestation which may probably be set down at nine months, producing but
15172 one at a time; though in some few known instances giving birth to an
15173 Esau and Jacob:—a contingency provided for in suckling by two teats,
15174 curiously situated, one on each side of the anus; but the breasts
15175 themselves extend upwards from that. When by chance these precious
15176 parts in a nursing whale are cut by the hunter’s lance, the mother’s
15177 pouring milk and blood rivallingly discolour the sea for rods. The milk
15178 is very sweet and rich; it has been tasted by man; it might do well
15179 with strawberries. When overflowing with mutual esteem, the whales
15180 salute _more hominum_.
15181 
15182 And thus, though surrounded by circle upon circle of consternations and
15183 affrights, did these inscrutable creatures at the centre freely and
15184 fearlessly indulge in all peaceful concernments; yea, serenely revelled
15185 in dalliance and delight. But even so, amid the tornadoed Atlantic of
15186 my being, do I myself still for ever centrally disport in mute calm;
15187 and while ponderous planets of unwaning woe revolve round me, deep down
15188 and deep inland there I still bathe me in eternal mildness of joy.
15189 
15190 Meanwhile, as we thus lay entranced, the occasional sudden frantic
15191 spectacles in the distance evinced the activity of the other boats,
15192 still engaged in drugging the whales on the frontier of the host; or
15193 possibly carrying on the war within the first circle, where abundance
15194 of room and some convenient retreats were afforded them. But the sight
15195 of the enraged drugged whales now and then blindly darting to and fro
15196 across the circles, was nothing to what at last met our eyes. It is
15197 sometimes the custom when fast to a whale more than commonly powerful
15198 and alert, to seek to hamstring him, as it were, by sundering or
15199 maiming his gigantic tail-tendon. It is done by darting a short-handled
15200 cutting-spade, to which is attached a rope for hauling it back again. A
15201 whale wounded (as we afterwards learned) in this part, but not
15202 effectually, as it seemed, had broken away from the boat, carrying
15203 along with him half of the harpoon line; and in the extraordinary agony
15204 of the wound, he was now dashing among the revolving circles like the
15205 lone mounted desperado Arnold, at the battle of Saratoga, carrying
15206 dismay wherever he went.
15207 
15208 But agonizing as was the wound of this whale, and an appalling
15209 spectacle enough, any way; yet the peculiar horror with which he seemed
15210 to inspire the rest of the herd, was owing to a cause which at first
15211 the intervening distance obscured from us. But at length we perceived
15212 that by one of the unimaginable accidents of the fishery, this whale
15213 had become entangled in the harpoon-line that he towed; he had also run
15214 away with the cutting-spade in him; and while the free end of the rope
15215 attached to that weapon, had permanently caught in the coils of the
15216 harpoon-line round his tail, the cutting-spade itself had worked loose
15217 from his flesh. So that tormented to madness, he was now churning
15218 through the water, violently flailing with his flexible tail, and
15219 tossing the keen spade about him, wounding and murdering his own
15220 comrades.
15221 
15222 This terrific object seemed to recall the whole herd from their
15223 stationary fright. First, the whales forming the margin of our lake
15224 began to crowd a little, and tumble against each other, as if lifted by
15225 half spent billows from afar; then the lake itself began faintly to
15226 heave and swell; the submarine bridal-chambers and nurseries vanished;
15227 in more and more contracting orbits the whales in the more central
15228 circles began to swim in thickening clusters. Yes, the long calm was
15229 departing. A low advancing hum was soon heard; and then like to the
15230 tumultuous masses of block-ice when the great river Hudson breaks up in
15231 Spring, the entire host of whales came tumbling upon their inner
15232 centre, as if to pile themselves up in one common mountain. Instantly
15233 Starbuck and Queequeg changed places; Starbuck taking the stern.
15234 
15235 “Oars! Oars!” he intensely whispered, seizing the helm—“gripe your
15236 oars, and clutch your souls, now! My God, men, stand by! Shove him off,
15237 you Queequeg—the whale there!—prick him!—hit him! Stand up—stand up,
15238 and stay so! Spring, men—pull, men; never mind their backs—scrape
15239 them!—scrape away!”
15240 
15241 The boat was now all but jammed between two vast black bulks, leaving a
15242 narrow Dardanelles between their long lengths. But by desperate
15243 endeavor we at last shot into a temporary opening; then giving way
15244 rapidly, and at the same time earnestly watching for another outlet.
15245 After many similar hair-breadth escapes, we at last swiftly glided into
15246 what had just been one of the outer circles, but now crossed by random
15247 whales, all violently making for one centre. This lucky salvation was
15248 cheaply purchased by the loss of Queequeg’s hat, who, while standing in
15249 the bows to prick the fugitive whales, had his hat taken clean from his
15250 head by the air-eddy made by the sudden tossing of a pair of broad
15251 flukes close by.
15252 
15253 Riotous and disordered as the universal commotion now was, it soon
15254 resolved itself into what seemed a systematic movement; for having
15255 clumped together at last in one dense body, they then renewed their
15256 onward flight with augmented fleetness. Further pursuit was useless;
15257 but the boats still lingered in their wake to pick up what drugged
15258 whales might be dropped astern, and likewise to secure one which Flask
15259 had killed and waifed. The waif is a pennoned pole, two or three of
15260 which are carried by every boat; and which, when additional game is at
15261 hand, are inserted upright into the floating body of a dead whale, both
15262 to mark its place on the sea, and also as token of prior possession,
15263 should the boats of any other ship draw near.
15264 
15265 The result of this lowering was somewhat illustrative of that sagacious
15266 saying in the Fishery,—the more whales the less fish. Of all the
15267 drugged whales only one was captured. The rest contrived to escape for
15268 the time, but only to be taken, as will hereafter be seen, by some
15269 other craft than the Pequod.
15270 
15271 
15272 CHAPTER 88. Schools and Schoolmasters.
15273 
15274 The previous chapter gave account of an immense body or herd of Sperm
15275 Whales, and there was also then given the probable cause inducing those
15276 vast aggregations.
15277 
15278 Now, though such great bodies are at times encountered, yet, as must
15279 have been seen, even at the present day, small detached bands are
15280 occasionally observed, embracing from twenty to fifty individuals each.
15281 Such bands are known as schools. They generally are of two sorts; those
15282 composed almost entirely of females, and those mustering none but young
15283 vigorous males, or bulls, as they are familiarly designated.
15284 
15285 In cavalier attendance upon the school of females, you invariably see a
15286 male of full grown magnitude, but not old; who, upon any alarm, evinces
15287 his gallantry by falling in the rear and covering the flight of his
15288 ladies. In truth, this gentleman is a luxurious Ottoman, swimming about
15289 over the watery world, surroundingly accompanied by all the solaces and
15290 endearments of the harem. The contrast between this Ottoman and his
15291 concubines is striking; because, while he is always of the largest
15292 leviathanic proportions, the ladies, even at full growth, are not more
15293 than one-third of the bulk of an average-sized male. They are
15294 comparatively delicate, indeed; I dare say, not to exceed half a dozen
15295 yards round the waist. Nevertheless, it cannot be denied, that upon the
15296 whole they are hereditarily entitled to _en bon point_.
15297 
15298 It is very curious to watch this harem and its lord in their indolent
15299 ramblings. Like fashionables, they are for ever on the move in
15300 leisurely search of variety. You meet them on the Line in time for the
15301 full flower of the Equatorial feeding season, having just returned,
15302 perhaps, from spending the summer in the Northern seas, and so cheating
15303 summer of all unpleasant weariness and warmth. By the time they have
15304 lounged up and down the promenade of the Equator awhile, they start for
15305 the Oriental waters in anticipation of the cool season there, and so
15306 evade the other excessive temperature of the year.
15307 
15308 When serenely advancing on one of these journeys, if any strange
15309 suspicious sights are seen, my lord whale keeps a wary eye on his
15310 interesting family. Should any unwarrantably pert young Leviathan
15311 coming that way, presume to draw confidentially close to one of the
15312 ladies, with what prodigious fury the Bashaw assails him, and chases
15313 him away! High times, indeed, if unprincipled young rakes like him are
15314 to be permitted to invade the sanctity of domestic bliss; though do
15315 what the Bashaw will, he cannot keep the most notorious Lothario out of
15316 his bed; for, alas! all fish bed in common. As ashore, the ladies often
15317 cause the most terrible duels among their rival admirers; just so with
15318 the whales, who sometimes come to deadly battle, and all for love. They
15319 fence with their long lower jaws, sometimes locking them together, and
15320 so striving for the supremacy like elks that warringly interweave their
15321 antlers. Not a few are captured having the deep scars of these
15322 encounters,—furrowed heads, broken teeth, scolloped fins; and in some
15323 instances, wrenched and dislocated mouths.
15324 
15325 But supposing the invader of domestic bliss to betake himself away at
15326 the first rush of the harem’s lord, then is it very diverting to watch
15327 that lord. Gently he insinuates his vast bulk among them again and
15328 revels there awhile, still in tantalizing vicinity to young Lothario,
15329 like pious Solomon devoutly worshipping among his thousand concubines.
15330 Granting other whales to be in sight, the fishermen will seldom give
15331 chase to one of these Grand Turks; for these Grand Turks are too lavish
15332 of their strength, and hence their unctuousness is small. As for the
15333 sons and the daughters they beget, why, those sons and daughters must
15334 take care of themselves; at least, with only the maternal help. For
15335 like certain other omnivorous roving lovers that might be named, my
15336 Lord Whale has no taste for the nursery, however much for the bower;
15337 and so, being a great traveller, he leaves his anonymous babies all
15338 over the world; every baby an exotic. In good time, nevertheless, as
15339 the ardour of youth declines; as years and dumps increase; as
15340 reflection lends her solemn pauses; in short, as a general lassitude
15341 overtakes the sated Turk; then a love of ease and virtue supplants the
15342 love for maidens; our Ottoman enters upon the impotent, repentant,
15343 admonitory stage of life, forswears, disbands the harem, and grown to
15344 an exemplary, sulky old soul, goes about all alone among the meridians
15345 and parallels saying his prayers, and warning each young Leviathan from
15346 his amorous errors.
15347 
15348 Now, as the harem of whales is called by the fishermen a school, so is
15349 the lord and master of that school technically known as the
15350 schoolmaster. It is therefore not in strict character, however
15351 admirably satirical, that after going to school himself, he should then
15352 go abroad inculcating not what he learned there, but the folly of it.
15353 His title, schoolmaster, would very naturally seem derived from the
15354 name bestowed upon the harem itself, but some have surmised that the
15355 man who first thus entitled this sort of Ottoman whale, must have read
15356 the memoirs of Vidocq, and informed himself what sort of a
15357 country-schoolmaster that famous Frenchman was in his younger days, and
15358 what was the nature of those occult lessons he inculcated into some of
15359 his pupils.
15360 
15361 The same secludedness and isolation to which the schoolmaster whale
15362 betakes himself in his advancing years, is true of all aged Sperm
15363 Whales. Almost universally, a lone whale—as a solitary Leviathan is
15364 called—proves an ancient one. Like venerable moss-bearded Daniel Boone,
15365 he will have no one near him but Nature herself; and her he takes to
15366 wife in the wilderness of waters, and the best of wives she is, though
15367 she keeps so many moody secrets.
15368 
15369 The schools composing none but young and vigorous males, previously
15370 mentioned, offer a strong contrast to the harem schools. For while
15371 those female whales are characteristically timid, the young males, or
15372 forty-barrel-bulls, as they call them, are by far the most pugnacious
15373 of all Leviathans, and proverbially the most dangerous to encounter;
15374 excepting those wondrous grey-headed, grizzled whales, sometimes met,
15375 and these will fight you like grim fiends exasperated by a penal gout.
15376 
15377 The Forty-barrel-bull schools are larger than the harem schools. Like a
15378 mob of young collegians, they are full of fight, fun, and wickedness,
15379 tumbling round the world at such a reckless, rollicking rate, that no
15380 prudent underwriter would insure them any more than he would a riotous
15381 lad at Yale or Harvard. They soon relinquish this turbulence though,
15382 and when about three-fourths grown, break up, and separately go about
15383 in quest of settlements, that is, harems.
15384 
15385 Another point of difference between the male and female schools is
15386 still more characteristic of the sexes. Say you strike a
15387 Forty-barrel-bull—poor devil! all his comrades quit him. But strike a
15388 member of the harem school, and her companions swim around her with
15389 every token of concern, sometimes lingering so near her and so long, as
15390 themselves to fall a prey.
15391 
15392 
15393 CHAPTER 89. Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish.
15394 
15395 The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the last chapter but one,
15396 necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the whale
15397 fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge.
15398 
15399 It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in company,
15400 a whale may be struck by one vessel, then escape, and be finally killed
15401 and captured by another vessel; and herein are indirectly comprised
15402 many minor contingencies, all partaking of this one grand feature. For
15403 example,—after a weary and perilous chase and capture of a whale, the
15404 body may get loose from the ship by reason of a violent storm; and
15405 drifting far away to leeward, be retaken by a second whaler, who, in a
15406 calm, snugly tows it alongside, without risk of life or line. Thus the
15407 most vexatious and violent disputes would often arise between the
15408 fishermen, were there not some written or unwritten, universal,
15409 undisputed law applicable to all cases.
15410 
15411 Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative
15412 enactment, was that of Holland. It was decreed by the States-General in
15413 A.D. 1695. But though no other nation has ever had any written whaling
15414 law, yet the American fishermen have been their own legislators and
15415 lawyers in this matter. They have provided a system which for terse
15416 comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian’s Pandects and the By-laws of the
15417 Chinese Society for the Suppression of Meddling with other People’s
15418 Business. Yes; these laws might be engraven on a Queen Anne’s farthing,
15419 or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the neck, so small are they.
15420 
15421 I. A Fast-Fish belongs to the party fast to it.
15422 
15423 II. A Loose-Fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it.
15424 
15425 But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable
15426 brevity of it, which necessitates a vast volume of commentaries to
15427 expound it.
15428 
15429 First: What is a Fast-Fish? Alive or dead a fish is technically fast,
15430 when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat, by any medium at
15431 all controllable by the occupant or occupants,—a mast, an oar, a
15432 nine-inch cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it is all the
15433 same. Likewise a fish is technically fast when it bears a waif, or any
15434 other recognised symbol of possession; so long as the party waifing it
15435 plainly evince their ability at any time to take it alongside, as well
15436 as their intention so to do.
15437 
15438 These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the whalemen
15439 themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder knocks—the
15440 Coke-upon-Littleton of the fist. True, among the more upright and
15441 honorable whalemen allowances are always made for peculiar cases, where
15442 it would be an outrageous moral injustice for one party to claim
15443 possession of a whale previously chased or killed by another party. But
15444 others are by no means so scrupulous.
15445 
15446 Some fifty years ago there was a curious case of whale-trover litigated
15447 in England, wherein the plaintiffs set forth that after a hard chase of
15448 a whale in the Northern seas; and when indeed they (the plaintiffs) had
15449 succeeded in harpooning the fish; they were at last, through peril of
15450 their lives, obliged to forsake not only their lines, but their boat
15451 itself. Ultimately the defendants (the crew of another ship) came up
15452 with the whale, struck, killed, seized, and finally appropriated it
15453 before the very eyes of the plaintiffs. And when those defendants were
15454 remonstrated with, their captain snapped his fingers in the plaintiffs’
15455 teeth, and assured them that by way of doxology to the deed he had
15456 done, he would now retain their line, harpoons, and boat, which had
15457 remained attached to the whale at the time of the seizure. Wherefore
15458 the plaintiffs now sued for the recovery of the value of their whale,
15459 line, harpoons, and boat.
15460 
15461 Mr. Erskine was counsel for the defendants; Lord Ellenborough was the
15462 judge. In the course of the defence, the witty Erskine went on to
15463 illustrate his position, by alluding to a recent crim. con. case,
15464 wherein a gentleman, after in vain trying to bridle his wife’s
15465 viciousness, had at last abandoned her upon the seas of life; but in
15466 the course of years, repenting of that step, he instituted an action to
15467 recover possession of her. Erskine was on the other side; and he then
15468 supported it by saying, that though the gentleman had originally
15469 harpooned the lady, and had once had her fast, and only by reason of
15470 the great stress of her plunging viciousness, had at last abandoned
15471 her; yet abandon her he did, so that she became a loose-fish; and
15472 therefore when a subsequent gentleman re-harpooned her, the lady then
15473 became that subsequent gentleman’s property, along with whatever
15474 harpoon might have been found sticking in her.
15475 
15476 Now in the present case Erskine contended that the examples of the
15477 whale and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other.
15478 
15479 These pleadings, and the counter pleadings, being duly heard, the very
15480 learned judge in set terms decided, to wit,—That as for the boat, he
15481 awarded it to the plaintiffs, because they had merely abandoned it to
15482 save their lives; but that with regard to the controverted whale,
15483 harpoons, and line, they belonged to the defendants; the whale, because
15484 it was a Loose-Fish at the time of the final capture; and the harpoons
15485 and line because when the fish made off with them, it (the fish)
15486 acquired a property in those articles; and hence anybody who afterwards
15487 took the fish had a right to them. Now the defendants afterwards took
15488 the fish; ergo, the aforesaid articles were theirs.
15489 
15490 A common man looking at this decision of the very learned Judge, might
15491 possibly object to it. But ploughed up to the primary rock of the
15492 matter, the two great principles laid down in the twin whaling laws
15493 previously quoted, and applied and elucidated by Lord Ellenborough in
15494 the above cited case; these two laws touching Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish,
15495 I say, will, on reflection, be found the fundamentals of all human
15496 jurisprudence; for notwithstanding its complicated tracery of
15497 sculpture, the Temple of the Law, like the Temple of the Philistines,
15498 has but two props to stand on.
15499 
15500 Is it not a saying in every one’s mouth, Possession is half of the law:
15501 that is, regardless of how the thing came into possession? But often
15502 possession is the whole of the law. What are the sinews and souls of
15503 Russian serfs and Republican slaves but Fast-Fish, whereof possession
15504 is the whole of the law? What to the rapacious landlord is the widow’s
15505 last mite but a Fast-Fish? What is yonder undetected villain’s marble
15506 mansion with a door-plate for a waif; what is that but a Fast-Fish?
15507 What is the ruinous discount which Mordecai, the broker, gets from poor
15508 Woebegone, the bankrupt, on a loan to keep Woebegone’s family from
15509 starvation; what is that ruinous discount but a Fast-Fish? What is the
15510 Archbishop of Savesoul’s income of £100,000 seized from the scant bread
15511 and cheese of hundreds of thousands of broken-backed laborers (all sure
15512 of heaven without any of Savesoul’s help) what is that globular
15513 £100,000 but a Fast-Fish? What are the Duke of Dunder’s hereditary
15514 towns and hamlets but Fast-Fish? What to that redoubted harpooneer,
15515 John Bull, is poor Ireland, but a Fast-Fish? What to that apostolic
15516 lancer, Brother Jonathan, is Texas but a Fast-Fish? And concerning all
15517 these, is not Possession the whole of the law?
15518 
15519 But if the doctrine of Fast-Fish be pretty generally applicable, the
15520 kindred doctrine of Loose-Fish is still more widely so. That is
15521 internationally and universally applicable.
15522 
15523 What was America in 1492 but a Loose-Fish, in which Columbus struck the
15524 Spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and
15525 mistress? What was Poland to the Czar? What Greece to the Turk? What
15526 India to England? What at last will Mexico be to the United States? All
15527 Loose-Fish.
15528 
15529 What are the Rights of Man and the Liberties of the World but
15530 Loose-Fish? What all men’s minds and opinions but Loose-Fish? What is
15531 the principle of religious belief in them but a Loose-Fish? What to the
15532 ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thoughts of thinkers but
15533 Loose-Fish? What is the great globe itself but a Loose-Fish? And what
15534 are you, reader, but a Loose-Fish and a Fast-Fish, too?
15535 
15536 
15537 CHAPTER 90. Heads or Tails.
15538 
15539 “De balena vero sufficit, si rex habeat caput, et regina caudam.”
15540 _Bracton, l. 3, c. 3._
15541 
15542 Latin from the books of the Laws of England, which taken along with the
15543 context, means, that of all whales captured by anybody on the coast of
15544 that land, the King, as Honorary Grand Harpooneer, must have the head,
15545 and the Queen be respectfully presented with the tail. A division
15546 which, in the whale, is much like halving an apple; there is no
15547 intermediate remainder. Now as this law, under a modified form, is to
15548 this day in force in England; and as it offers in various respects a
15549 strange anomaly touching the general law of Fast and Loose-Fish, it is
15550 here treated of in a separate chapter, on the same courteous principle
15551 that prompts the English railways to be at the expense of a separate
15552 car, specially reserved for the accommodation of royalty. In the first
15553 place, in curious proof of the fact that the above-mentioned law is
15554 still in force, I proceed to lay before you a circumstance that
15555 happened within the last two years.
15556 
15557 It seems that some honest mariners of Dover, or Sandwich, or some one
15558 of the Cinque Ports, had after a hard chase succeeded in killing and
15559 beaching a fine whale which they had originally descried afar off from
15560 the shore. Now the Cinque Ports are partially or somehow under the
15561 jurisdiction of a sort of policeman or beadle, called a Lord Warden.
15562 Holding the office directly from the crown, I believe, all the royal
15563 emoluments incident to the Cinque Port territories become by assignment
15564 his. By some writers this office is called a sinecure. But not so.
15565 Because the Lord Warden is busily employed at times in fobbing his
15566 perquisites; which are his chiefly by virtue of that same fobbing of
15567 them.
15568 
15569 Now when these poor sun-burnt mariners, bare-footed, and with their
15570 trowsers rolled high up on their eely legs, had wearily hauled their
15571 fat fish high and dry, promising themselves a good £150 from the
15572 precious oil and bone; and in fantasy sipping rare tea with their
15573 wives, and good ale with their cronies, upon the strength of their
15574 respective shares; up steps a very learned and most Christian and
15575 charitable gentleman, with a copy of Blackstone under his arm; and
15576 laying it upon the whale’s head, he says—“Hands off! this fish, my
15577 masters, is a Fast-Fish. I seize it as the Lord Warden’s.” Upon this
15578 the poor mariners in their respectful consternation—so truly
15579 English—knowing not what to say, fall to vigorously scratching their
15580 heads all round; meanwhile ruefully glancing from the whale to the
15581 stranger. But that did in nowise mend the matter, or at all soften the
15582 hard heart of the learned gentleman with the copy of Blackstone. At
15583 length one of them, after long scratching about for his ideas, made
15584 bold to speak,
15585 
15586 “Please, sir, who is the Lord Warden?”
15587 
15588 “The Duke.”
15589 
15590 “But the duke had nothing to do with taking this fish?”
15591 
15592 “It is his.”
15593 
15594 “We have been at great trouble, and peril, and some expense, and is all
15595 that to go to the Duke’s benefit; we getting nothing at all for our
15596 pains but our blisters?”
15597 
15598 “It is his.”
15599 
15600 “Is the Duke so very poor as to be forced to this desperate mode of
15601 getting a livelihood?”
15602 
15603 “It is his.”
15604 
15605 “I thought to relieve my old bed-ridden mother by part of my share of
15606 this whale.”
15607 
15608 “It is his.”
15609 
15610 “Won’t the Duke be content with a quarter or a half?”
15611 
15612 “It is his.”
15613 
15614 In a word, the whale was seized and sold, and his Grace the Duke of
15615 Wellington received the money. Thinking that viewed in some particular
15616 lights, the case might by a bare possibility in some small degree be
15617 deemed, under the circumstances, a rather hard one, an honest clergyman
15618 of the town respectfully addressed a note to his Grace, begging him to
15619 take the case of those unfortunate mariners into full consideration. To
15620 which my Lord Duke in substance replied (both letters were published)
15621 that he had already done so, and received the money, and would be
15622 obliged to the reverend gentleman if for the future he (the reverend
15623 gentleman) would decline meddling with other people’s business. Is this
15624 the still militant old man, standing at the corners of the three
15625 kingdoms, on all hands coercing alms of beggars?
15626 
15627 It will readily be seen that in this case the alleged right of the Duke
15628 to the whale was a delegated one from the Sovereign. We must needs
15629 inquire then on what principle the Sovereign is originally invested
15630 with that right. The law itself has already been set forth. But Plowdon
15631 gives us the reason for it. Says Plowdon, the whale so caught belongs
15632 to the King and Queen, “because of its superior excellence.” And by the
15633 soundest commentators this has ever been held a cogent argument in such
15634 matters.
15635 
15636 But why should the King have the head, and the Queen the tail? A reason
15637 for that, ye lawyers!
15638 
15639 In his treatise on “Queen-Gold,” or Queen-pinmoney, an old King’s Bench
15640 author, one William Prynne, thus discourseth: “Ye tail is ye Queen’s,
15641 that ye Queen’s wardrobe may be supplied with ye whalebone.” Now this
15642 was written at a time when the black limber bone of the Greenland or
15643 Right whale was largely used in ladies’ bodices. But this same bone is
15644 not in the tail; it is in the head, which is a sad mistake for a
15645 sagacious lawyer like Prynne. But is the Queen a mermaid, to be
15646 presented with a tail? An allegorical meaning may lurk here.
15647 
15648 There are two royal fish so styled by the English law writers—the whale
15649 and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain limitations, and
15650 nominally supplying the tenth branch of the crown’s ordinary revenue. I
15651 know not that any other author has hinted of the matter; but by
15652 inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be divided in the same
15653 way as the whale, the King receiving the highly dense and elastic head
15654 peculiar to that fish, which, symbolically regarded, may possibly be
15655 humorously grounded upon some presumed congeniality. And thus there
15656 seems a reason in all things, even in law.
15657 
15658 
15659 CHAPTER 91. The Pequod Meets The Rose-Bud.
15660 
15661 “In vain it was to rake for Ambergriese in the paunch of this
15662 Leviathan, insufferable fetor denying not inquiry.” _Sir T. Browne,
15663 V.E._
15664 
15665 It was a week or two after the last whaling scene recounted, and when
15666 we were slowly sailing over a sleepy, vapory, mid-day sea, that the
15667 many noses on the Pequod’s deck proved more vigilant discoverers than
15668 the three pairs of eyes aloft. A peculiar and not very pleasant smell
15669 was smelt in the sea.
15670 
15671 “I will bet something now,” said Stubb, “that somewhere hereabouts are
15672 some of those drugged whales we tickled the other day. I thought they
15673 would keel up before long.”
15674 
15675 Presently, the vapors in advance slid aside; and there in the distance
15676 lay a ship, whose furled sails betokened that some sort of whale must
15677 be alongside. As we glided nearer, the stranger showed French colours
15678 from his peak; and by the eddying cloud of vulture sea-fowl that
15679 circled, and hovered, and swooped around him, it was plain that the
15680 whale alongside must be what the fishermen call a blasted whale, that
15681 is, a whale that has died unmolested on the sea, and so floated an
15682 unappropriated corpse. It may well be conceived, what an unsavory odor
15683 such a mass must exhale; worse than an Assyrian city in the plague,
15684 when the living are incompetent to bury the departed. So intolerable
15685 indeed is it regarded by some, that no cupidity could persuade them to
15686 moor alongside of it. Yet are there those who will still do it;
15687 notwithstanding the fact that the oil obtained from such subjects is of
15688 a very inferior quality, and by no means of the nature of
15689 attar-of-rose.
15690 
15691 Coming still nearer with the expiring breeze, we saw that the Frenchman
15692 had a second whale alongside; and this second whale seemed even more of
15693 a nosegay than the first. In truth, it turned out to be one of those
15694 problematical whales that seem to dry up and die with a sort of
15695 prodigious dyspepsia, or indigestion; leaving their defunct bodies
15696 almost entirely bankrupt of anything like oil. Nevertheless, in the
15697 proper place we shall see that no knowing fisherman will ever turn up
15698 his nose at such a whale as this, however much he may shun blasted
15699 whales in general.
15700 
15701 The Pequod had now swept so nigh to the stranger, that Stubb vowed he
15702 recognised his cutting spade-pole entangled in the lines that were
15703 knotted round the tail of one of these whales.
15704 
15705 “There’s a pretty fellow, now,” he banteringly laughed, standing in the
15706 ship’s bows, “there’s a jackal for ye! I well know that these Crappoes
15707 of Frenchmen are but poor devils in the fishery; sometimes lowering
15708 their boats for breakers, mistaking them for Sperm Whale spouts; yes,
15709 and sometimes sailing from their port with their hold full of boxes of
15710 tallow candles, and cases of snuffers, foreseeing that all the oil they
15711 will get won’t be enough to dip the Captain’s wick into; aye, we all
15712 know these things; but look ye, here’s a Crappo that is content with
15713 our leavings, the drugged whale there, I mean; aye, and is content too
15714 with scraping the dry bones of that other precious fish he has there.
15715 Poor devil! I say, pass round a hat, some one, and let’s make him a
15716 present of a little oil for dear charity’s sake. For what oil he’ll get
15717 from that drugged whale there, wouldn’t be fit to burn in a jail; no,
15718 not in a condemned cell. And as for the other whale, why, I’ll agree to
15719 get more oil by chopping up and trying out these three masts of ours,
15720 than he’ll get from that bundle of bones; though, now that I think of
15721 it, it may contain something worth a good deal more than oil; yes,
15722 ambergris. I wonder now if our old man has thought of that. It’s worth
15723 trying. Yes, I’m for it;” and so saying he started for the
15724 quarter-deck.
15725 
15726 By this time the faint air had become a complete calm; so that whether
15727 or no, the Pequod was now fairly entrapped in the smell, with no hope
15728 of escaping except by its breezing up again. Issuing from the cabin,
15729 Stubb now called his boat’s crew, and pulled off for the stranger.
15730 Drawing across her bow, he perceived that in accordance with the
15731 fanciful French taste, the upper part of her stem-piece was carved in
15732 the likeness of a huge drooping stalk, was painted green, and for
15733 thorns had copper spikes projecting from it here and there; the whole
15734 terminating in a symmetrical folded bulb of a bright red colour. Upon
15735 her head boards, in large gilt letters, he read “Bouton de
15736 Rose,”—Rose-button, or Rose-bud; and this was the romantic name of this
15737 aromatic ship.
15738 
15739 Though Stubb did not understand the _Bouton_ part of the inscription,
15740 yet the word _rose_, and the bulbous figure-head put together,
15741 sufficiently explained the whole to him.
15742 
15743 “A wooden rose-bud, eh?” he cried with his hand to his nose, “that will
15744 do very well; but how like all creation it smells!”
15745 
15746 Now in order to hold direct communication with the people on deck, he
15747 had to pull round the bows to the starboard side, and thus come close
15748 to the blasted whale; and so talk over it.
15749 
15750 Arrived then at this spot, with one hand still to his nose, he
15751 bawled—“Bouton-de-Rose, ahoy! are there any of you Bouton-de-Roses that
15752 speak English?”
15753 
15754 “Yes,” rejoined a Guernsey-man from the bulwarks, who turned out to be
15755 the chief-mate.
15756 
15757 “Well, then, my Bouton-de-Rose-bud, have you seen the White Whale?”
15758 
15759 “_What_ whale?”
15760 
15761 “The _White_ Whale—a Sperm Whale—Moby Dick, have ye seen him?
15762 
15763 “Never heard of such a whale. Cachalot Blanche! White Whale—no.”
15764 
15765 “Very good, then; good bye now, and I’ll call again in a minute.”
15766 
15767 Then rapidly pulling back towards the Pequod, and seeing Ahab leaning
15768 over the quarter-deck rail awaiting his report, he moulded his two
15769 hands into a trumpet and shouted—“No, Sir! No!” Upon which Ahab
15770 retired, and Stubb returned to the Frenchman.
15771 
15772 He now perceived that the Guernsey-man, who had just got into the
15773 chains, and was using a cutting-spade, had slung his nose in a sort of
15774 bag.
15775 
15776 “What’s the matter with your nose, there?” said Stubb. “Broke it?”
15777 
15778 “I wish it was broken, or that I didn’t have any nose at all!” answered
15779 the Guernsey-man, who did not seem to relish the job he was at very
15780 much. “But what are you holding _yours_ for?”
15781 
15782 “Oh, nothing! It’s a wax nose; I have to hold it on. Fine day, ain’t
15783 it? Air rather gardenny, I should say; throw us a bunch of posies, will
15784 ye, Bouton-de-Rose?”
15785 
15786 “What in the devil’s name do you want here?” roared the Guernseyman,
15787 flying into a sudden passion.
15788 
15789 “Oh! keep cool—cool? yes, that’s the word! why don’t you pack those
15790 whales in ice while you’re working at ’em? But joking aside, though; do
15791 you know, Rose-bud, that it’s all nonsense trying to get any oil out of
15792 such whales? As for that dried up one, there, he hasn’t a gill in his
15793 whole carcase.”
15794 
15795 “I know that well enough; but, d’ye see, the Captain here won’t believe
15796 it; this is his first voyage; he was a Cologne manufacturer before. But
15797 come aboard, and mayhap he’ll believe you, if he won’t me; and so I’ll
15798 get out of this dirty scrape.”
15799 
15800 “Anything to oblige ye, my sweet and pleasant fellow,” rejoined Stubb,
15801 and with that he soon mounted to the deck. There a queer scene
