15802 presented itself. The sailors, in tasselled caps of red worsted, were
15803 getting the heavy tackles in readiness for the whales. But they worked
15804 rather slow and talked very fast, and seemed in anything but a good
15805 humor. All their noses upwardly projected from their faces like so many
15806 jib-booms. Now and then pairs of them would drop their work, and run up
15807 to the mast-head to get some fresh air. Some thinking they would catch
15808 the plague, dipped oakum in coal-tar, and at intervals held it to their
15809 nostrils. Others having broken the stems of their pipes almost short
15810 off at the bowl, were vigorously puffing tobacco-smoke, so that it
15811 constantly filled their olfactories.
15812 
15813 Stubb was struck by a shower of outcries and anathemas proceeding from
15814 the Captain’s round-house abaft; and looking in that direction saw a
15815 fiery face thrust from behind the door, which was held ajar from
15816 within. This was the tormented surgeon, who, after in vain
15817 remonstrating against the proceedings of the day, had betaken himself
15818 to the Captain’s round-house (_cabinet_ he called it) to avoid the
15819 pest; but still, could not help yelling out his entreaties and
15820 indignations at times.
15821 
15822 Marking all this, Stubb argued well for his scheme, and turning to the
15823 Guernsey-man had a little chat with him, during which the stranger mate
15824 expressed his detestation of his Captain as a conceited ignoramus, who
15825 had brought them all into so unsavory and unprofitable a pickle.
15826 Sounding him carefully, Stubb further perceived that the Guernsey-man
15827 had not the slightest suspicion concerning the ambergris. He therefore
15828 held his peace on that head, but otherwise was quite frank and
15829 confidential with him, so that the two quickly concocted a little plan
15830 for both circumventing and satirizing the Captain, without his at all
15831 dreaming of distrusting their sincerity. According to this little plan
15832 of theirs, the Guernsey-man, under cover of an interpreter’s office,
15833 was to tell the Captain what he pleased, but as coming from Stubb; and
15834 as for Stubb, he was to utter any nonsense that should come uppermost
15835 in him during the interview.
15836 
15837 By this time their destined victim appeared from his cabin. He was a
15838 small and dark, but rather delicate looking man for a sea-captain, with
15839 large whiskers and moustache, however; and wore a red cotton velvet
15840 vest with watch-seals at his side. To this gentleman, Stubb was now
15841 politely introduced by the Guernsey-man, who at once ostentatiously put
15842 on the aspect of interpreting between them.
15843 
15844 “What shall I say to him first?” said he.
15845 
15846 “Why,” said Stubb, eyeing the velvet vest and the watch and seals, “you
15847 may as well begin by telling him that he looks a sort of babyish to me,
15848 though I don’t pretend to be a judge.”
15849 
15850 “He says, Monsieur,” said the Guernsey-man, in French, turning to his
15851 captain, “that only yesterday his ship spoke a vessel, whose captain
15852 and chief-mate, with six sailors, had all died of a fever caught from a
15853 blasted whale they had brought alongside.”
15854 
15855 Upon this the captain started, and eagerly desired to know more.
15856 
15857 “What now?” said the Guernsey-man to Stubb.
15858 
15859 “Why, since he takes it so easy, tell him that now I have eyed him
15860 carefully, I’m quite certain that he’s no more fit to command a
15861 whale-ship than a St. Jago monkey. In fact, tell him from me he’s a
15862 baboon.”
15863 
15864 “He vows and declares, Monsieur, that the other whale, the dried one,
15865 is far more deadly than the blasted one; in fine, Monsieur, he conjures
15866 us, as we value our lives, to cut loose from these fish.”
15867 
15868 Instantly the captain ran forward, and in a loud voice commanded his
15869 crew to desist from hoisting the cutting-tackles, and at once cast
15870 loose the cables and chains confining the whales to the ship.
15871 
15872 “What now?” said the Guernsey-man, when the Captain had returned to
15873 them.
15874 
15875 “Why, let me see; yes, you may as well tell him now that—that—in fact,
15876 tell him I’ve diddled him, and (aside to himself) perhaps somebody
15877 else.”
15878 
15879 “He says, Monsieur, that he’s very happy to have been of any service to
15880 us.”
15881 
15882 Hearing this, the captain vowed that they were the grateful parties
15883 (meaning himself and mate) and concluded by inviting Stubb down into
15884 his cabin to drink a bottle of Bordeaux.
15885 
15886 “He wants you to take a glass of wine with him,” said the interpreter.
15887 
15888 “Thank him heartily; but tell him it’s against my principles to drink
15889 with the man I’ve diddled. In fact, tell him I must go.”
15890 
15891 “He says, Monsieur, that his principles won’t admit of his drinking;
15892 but that if Monsieur wants to live another day to drink, then Monsieur
15893 had best drop all four boats, and pull the ship away from these whales,
15894 for it’s so calm they won’t drift.”
15895 
15896 By this time Stubb was over the side, and getting into his boat, hailed
15897 the Guernsey-man to this effect,—that having a long tow-line in his
15898 boat, he would do what he could to help them, by pulling out the
15899 lighter whale of the two from the ship’s side. While the Frenchman’s
15900 boats, then, were engaged in towing the ship one way, Stubb
15901 benevolently towed away at his whale the other way, ostentatiously
15902 slacking out a most unusually long tow-line.
15903 
15904 Presently a breeze sprang up; Stubb feigned to cast off from the whale;
15905 hoisting his boats, the Frenchman soon increased his distance, while
15906 the Pequod slid in between him and Stubb’s whale. Whereupon Stubb
15907 quickly pulled to the floating body, and hailing the Pequod to give
15908 notice of his intentions, at once proceeded to reap the fruit of his
15909 unrighteous cunning. Seizing his sharp boat-spade, he commenced an
15910 excavation in the body, a little behind the side fin. You would almost
15911 have thought he was digging a cellar there in the sea; and when at
15912 length his spade struck against the gaunt ribs, it was like turning up
15913 old Roman tiles and pottery buried in fat English loam. His boat’s crew
15914 were all in high excitement, eagerly helping their chief, and looking
15915 as anxious as gold-hunters.
15916 
15917 And all the time numberless fowls were diving, and ducking, and
15918 screaming, and yelling, and fighting around them. Stubb was beginning
15919 to look disappointed, especially as the horrible nosegay increased,
15920 when suddenly from out the very heart of this plague, there stole a
15921 faint stream of perfume, which flowed through the tide of bad smells
15922 without being absorbed by it, as one river will flow into and then
15923 along with another, without at all blending with it for a time.
15924 
15925 “I have it, I have it,” cried Stubb, with delight, striking something
15926 in the subterranean regions, “a purse! a purse!”
15927 
15928 Dropping his spade, he thrust both hands in, and drew out handfuls of
15929 something that looked like ripe Windsor soap, or rich mottled old
15930 cheese; very unctuous and savory withal. You might easily dent it with
15931 your thumb; it is of a hue between yellow and ash colour. And this,
15932 good friends, is ambergris, worth a gold guinea an ounce to any
15933 druggist. Some six handfuls were obtained; but more was unavoidably
15934 lost in the sea, and still more, perhaps, might have been secured were
15935 it not for impatient Ahab’s loud command to Stubb to desist, and come
15936 on board, else the ship would bid them good bye.
15937 
15938 
15939 CHAPTER 92. Ambergris.
15940 
15941 Now this ambergris is a very curious substance, and so important as an
15942 article of commerce, that in 1791 a certain Nantucket-born Captain
15943 Coffin was examined at the bar of the English House of Commons on that
15944 subject. For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively late day,
15945 the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber itself, a problem
15946 to the learned. Though the word ambergris is but the French compound
15947 for grey amber, yet the two substances are quite distinct. For amber,
15948 though at times found on the sea-coast, is also dug up in some far
15949 inland soils, whereas ambergris is never found except upon the sea.
15950 Besides, amber is a hard, transparent, brittle, odorless substance,
15951 used for mouth-pieces to pipes, for beads and ornaments; but ambergris
15952 is soft, waxy, and so highly fragrant and spicy, that it is largely
15953 used in perfumery, in pastiles, precious candles, hair-powders, and
15954 pomatum. The Turks use it in cooking, and also carry it to Mecca, for
15955 the same purpose that frankincense is carried to St. Peter’s in Rome.
15956 Some wine merchants drop a few grains into claret, to flavor it.
15957 
15958 Who would think, then, that such fine ladies and gentlemen should
15959 regale themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowels of a
15960 sick whale! Yet so it is. By some, ambergris is supposed to be the
15961 cause, and by others the effect, of the dyspepsia in the whale. How to
15962 cure such a dyspepsia it were hard to say, unless by administering
15963 three or four boat loads of Brandreth’s pills, and then running out of
15964 harm’s way, as laborers do in blasting rocks.
15965 
15966 I have forgotten to say that there were found in this ambergris,
15967 certain hard, round, bony plates, which at first Stubb thought might be
15968 sailors’ trowsers buttons; but it afterwards turned out that they were
15969 nothing more than pieces of small squid bones embalmed in that manner.
15970 
15971 Now that the incorruption of this most fragrant ambergris should be
15972 found in the heart of such decay; is this nothing? Bethink thee of that
15973 saying of St. Paul in Corinthians, about corruption and incorruption;
15974 how that we are sown in dishonor, but raised in glory. And likewise
15975 call to mind that saying of Paracelsus about what it is that maketh the
15976 best musk. Also forget not the strange fact that of all things of
15977 ill-savor, Cologne-water, in its rudimental manufacturing stages, is
15978 the worst.
15979 
15980 I should like to conclude the chapter with the above appeal, but
15981 cannot, owing to my anxiety to repel a charge often made against
15982 whalemen, and which, in the estimation of some already biased minds,
15983 might be considered as indirectly substantiated by what has been said
15984 of the Frenchman’s two whales. Elsewhere in this volume the slanderous
15985 aspersion has been disproved, that the vocation of whaling is
15986 throughout a slatternly, untidy business. But there is another thing to
15987 rebut. They hint that all whales always smell bad. Now how did this
15988 odious stigma originate?
15989 
15990 I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the
15991 Greenland whaling ships in London, more than two centuries ago. Because
15992 those whalemen did not then, and do not now, try out their oil at sea
15993 as the Southern ships have always done; but cutting up the fresh
15994 blubber in small bits, thrust it through the bung holes of large casks,
15995 and carry it home in that manner; the shortness of the season in those
15996 Icy Seas, and the sudden and violent storms to which they are exposed,
15997 forbidding any other course. The consequence is, that upon breaking
15998 into the hold, and unloading one of these whale cemeteries, in the
15999 Greenland dock, a savor is given forth somewhat similar to that arising
16000 from excavating an old city grave-yard, for the foundations of a
16001 Lying-in Hospital.
16002 
16003 I partly surmise also, that this wicked charge against whalers may be
16004 likewise imputed to the existence on the coast of Greenland, in former
16005 times, of a Dutch village called Schmerenburgh or Smeerenberg, which
16006 latter name is the one used by the learned Fogo Von Slack, in his great
16007 work on Smells, a text-book on that subject. As its name imports
16008 (smeer, fat; berg, to put up), this village was founded in order to
16009 afford a place for the blubber of the Dutch whale fleet to be tried
16010 out, without being taken home to Holland for that purpose. It was a
16011 collection of furnaces, fat-kettles, and oil sheds; and when the works
16012 were in full operation certainly gave forth no very pleasant savor. But
16013 all this is quite different with a South Sea Sperm Whaler; which in a
16014 voyage of four years perhaps, after completely filling her hold with
16015 oil, does not, perhaps, consume fifty days in the business of boiling
16016 out; and in the state that it is casked, the oil is nearly scentless.
16017 The truth is, that living or dead, if but decently treated, whales as a
16018 species are by no means creatures of ill odor; nor can whalemen be
16019 recognised, as the people of the middle ages affected to detect a Jew
16020 in the company, by the nose. Nor indeed can the whale possibly be
16021 otherwise than fragrant, when, as a general thing, he enjoys such high
16022 health; taking abundance of exercise; always out of doors; though, it
16023 is true, seldom in the open air. I say, that the motion of a Sperm
16024 Whale’s flukes above water dispenses a perfume, as when a musk-scented
16025 lady rustles her dress in a warm parlor. What then shall I liken the
16026 Sperm Whale to for fragrance, considering his magnitude? Must it not be
16027 to that famous elephant, with jewelled tusks, and redolent with myrrh,
16028 which was led out of an Indian town to do honor to Alexander the Great?
16029 
16030 
16031 CHAPTER 93. The Castaway.
16032 
16033 It was but some few days after encountering the Frenchman, that a most
16034 significant event befell the most insignificant of the Pequod’s crew;
16035 an event most lamentable; and which ended in providing the sometimes
16036 madly merry and predestinated craft with a living and ever accompanying
16037 prophecy of whatever shattered sequel might prove her own.
16038 
16039 Now, in the whale ship, it is not every one that goes in the boats.
16040 Some few hands are reserved called ship-keepers, whose province it is
16041 to work the vessel while the boats are pursuing the whale. As a general
16042 thing, these ship-keepers are as hardy fellows as the men comprising
16043 the boats’ crews. But if there happen to be an unduly slender, clumsy,
16044 or timorous wight in the ship, that wight is certain to be made a
16045 ship-keeper. It was so in the Pequod with the little negro Pippin by
16046 nick-name, Pip by abbreviation. Poor Pip! ye have heard of him before;
16047 ye must remember his tambourine on that dramatic midnight, so
16048 gloomy-jolly.
16049 
16050 In outer aspect, Pip and Dough-Boy made a match, like a black pony and
16051 a white one, of equal developments, though of dissimilar colour, driven
16052 in one eccentric span. But while hapless Dough-Boy was by nature dull
16053 and torpid in his intellects, Pip, though over tender-hearted, was at
16054 bottom very bright, with that pleasant, genial, jolly brightness
16055 peculiar to his tribe; a tribe, which ever enjoy all holidays and
16056 festivities with finer, freer relish than any other race. For blacks,
16057 the year’s calendar should show naught but three hundred and sixty-five
16058 Fourth of Julys and New Year’s Days. Nor smile so, while I write that
16059 this little black was brilliant, for even blackness has its brilliancy;
16060 behold yon lustrous ebony, panelled in king’s cabinets. But Pip loved
16061 life, and all life’s peaceable securities; so that the panic-striking
16062 business in which he had somehow unaccountably become entrapped, had
16063 most sadly blurred his brightness; though, as ere long will be seen,
16064 what was thus temporarily subdued in him, in the end was destined to be
16065 luridly illumined by strange wild fires, that fictitiously showed him
16066 off to ten times the natural lustre with which in his native Tolland
16067 County in Connecticut, he had once enlivened many a fiddler’s frolic on
16068 the green; and at melodious even-tide, with his gay ha-ha! had turned
16069 the round horizon into one star-belled tambourine. So, though in the
16070 clear air of day, suspended against a blue-veined neck, the
16071 pure-watered diamond drop will healthful glow; yet, when the cunning
16072 jeweller would show you the diamond in its most impressive lustre, he
16073 lays it against a gloomy ground, and then lights it up, not by the sun,
16074 but by some unnatural gases. Then come out those fiery effulgences,
16075 infernally superb; then the evil-blazing diamond, once the divinest
16076 symbol of the crystal skies, looks like some crown-jewel stolen from
16077 the King of Hell. But let us to the story.
16078 
16079 It came to pass, that in the ambergris affair Stubb’s after-oarsman
16080 chanced so to sprain his hand, as for a time to become quite maimed;
16081 and, temporarily, Pip was put into his place.
16082 
16083 The first time Stubb lowered with him, Pip evinced much nervousness;
16084 but happily, for that time, escaped close contact with the whale; and
16085 therefore came off not altogether discreditably; though Stubb observing
16086 him, took care, afterwards, to exhort him to cherish his courageousness
16087 to the utmost, for he might often find it needful.
16088 
16089 Now upon the second lowering, the boat paddled upon the whale; and as
16090 the fish received the darted iron, it gave its customary rap, which
16091 happened, in this instance, to be right under poor Pip’s seat. The
16092 involuntary consternation of the moment caused him to leap, paddle in
16093 hand, out of the boat; and in such a way, that part of the slack whale
16094 line coming against his chest, he breasted it overboard with him, so as
16095 to become entangled in it, when at last plumping into the water. That
16096 instant the stricken whale started on a fierce run, the line swiftly
16097 straightened; and presto! poor Pip came all foaming up to the chocks of
16098 the boat, remorselessly dragged there by the line, which had taken
16099 several turns around his chest and neck.
16100 
16101 Tashtego stood in the bows. He was full of the fire of the hunt. He
16102 hated Pip for a poltroon. Snatching the boat-knife from its sheath, he
16103 suspended its sharp edge over the line, and turning towards Stubb,
16104 exclaimed interrogatively, “Cut?” Meantime Pip’s blue, choked face
16105 plainly looked, Do, for God’s sake! All passed in a flash. In less than
16106 half a minute, this entire thing happened.
16107 
16108 “Damn him, cut!” roared Stubb; and so the whale was lost and Pip was
16109 saved.
16110 
16111 So soon as he recovered himself, the poor little negro was assailed by
16112 yells and execrations from the crew. Tranquilly permitting these
16113 irregular cursings to evaporate, Stubb then in a plain, business-like,
16114 but still half humorous manner, cursed Pip officially; and that done,
16115 unofficially gave him much wholesome advice. The substance was, Never
16116 jump from a boat, Pip, except—but all the rest was indefinite, as the
16117 soundest advice ever is. Now, in general, _Stick to the boat_, is your
16118 true motto in whaling; but cases will sometimes happen when _Leap from
16119 the boat_, is still better. Moreover, as if perceiving at last that if
16120 he should give undiluted conscientious advice to Pip, he would be
16121 leaving him too wide a margin to jump in for the future; Stubb suddenly
16122 dropped all advice, and concluded with a peremptory command, “Stick to
16123 the boat, Pip, or by the Lord, I won’t pick you up if you jump; mind
16124 that. We can’t afford to lose whales by the likes of you; a whale would
16125 sell for thirty times what you would, Pip, in Alabama. Bear that in
16126 mind, and don’t jump any more.” Hereby perhaps Stubb indirectly hinted,
16127 that though man loved his fellow, yet man is a money-making animal,
16128 which propensity too often interferes with his benevolence.
16129 
16130 But we are all in the hands of the Gods; and Pip jumped again. It was
16131 under very similar circumstances to the first performance; but this
16132 time he did not breast out the line; and hence, when the whale started
16133 to run, Pip was left behind on the sea, like a hurried traveller’s
16134 trunk. Alas! Stubb was but too true to his word. It was a beautiful,
16135 bounteous, blue day; the spangled sea calm and cool, and flatly
16136 stretching away, all round, to the horizon, like gold-beater’s skin
16137 hammered out to the extremest. Bobbing up and down in that sea, Pip’s
16138 ebon head showed like a head of cloves. No boat-knife was lifted when
16139 he fell so rapidly astern. Stubb’s inexorable back was turned upon him;
16140 and the whale was winged. In three minutes, a whole mile of shoreless
16141 ocean was between Pip and Stubb. Out from the centre of the sea, poor
16142 Pip turned his crisp, curling, black head to the sun, another lonely
16143 castaway, though the loftiest and the brightest.
16144 
16145 Now, in calm weather, to swim in the open ocean is as easy to the
16146 practised swimmer as to ride in a spring-carriage ashore. But the awful
16147 lonesomeness is intolerable. The intense concentration of self in the
16148 middle of such a heartless immensity, my God! who can tell it? Mark,
16149 how when sailors in a dead calm bathe in the open sea—mark how closely
16150 they hug their ship and only coast along her sides.
16151 
16152 But had Stubb really abandoned the poor little negro to his fate? No;
16153 he did not mean to, at least. Because there were two boats in his wake,
16154 and he supposed, no doubt, that they would of course come up to Pip
16155 very quickly, and pick him up; though, indeed, such considerations
16156 towards oarsmen jeopardized through their own timidity, is not always
16157 manifested by the hunters in all similar instances; and such instances
16158 not unfrequently occur; almost invariably in the fishery, a coward, so
16159 called, is marked with the same ruthless detestation peculiar to
16160 military navies and armies.
16161 
16162 But it so happened, that those boats, without seeing Pip, suddenly
16163 spying whales close to them on one side, turned, and gave chase; and
16164 Stubb’s boat was now so far away, and he and all his crew so intent
16165 upon his fish, that Pip’s ringed horizon began to expand around him
16166 miserably. By the merest chance the ship itself at last rescued him;
16167 but from that hour the little negro went about the deck an idiot; such,
16168 at least, they said he was. The sea had jeeringly kept his finite body
16169 up, but drowned the infinite of his soul. Not drowned entirely, though.
16170 Rather carried down alive to wondrous depths, where strange shapes of
16171 the unwarped primal world glided to and fro before his passive eyes;
16172 and the miser-merman, Wisdom, revealed his hoarded heaps; and among the
16173 joyous, heartless, ever-juvenile eternities, Pip saw the multitudinous,
16174 God-omnipresent, coral insects, that out of the firmament of waters
16175 heaved the colossal orbs. He saw God’s foot upon the treadle of the
16176 loom, and spoke it; and therefore his shipmates called him mad. So
16177 man’s insanity is heaven’s sense; and wandering from all mortal reason,
16178 man comes at last to that celestial thought, which, to reason, is
16179 absurd and frantic; and weal or woe, feels then uncompromised,
16180 indifferent as his God.
16181 
16182 For the rest, blame not Stubb too hardly. The thing is common in that
16183 fishery; and in the sequel of the narrative, it will then be seen what
16184 like abandonment befell myself.
16185 
16186 
16187 CHAPTER 94. A Squeeze of the Hand.
16188 
16189 That whale of Stubb’s, so dearly purchased, was duly brought to the
16190 Pequod’s side, where all those cutting and hoisting operations
16191 previously detailed, were regularly gone through, even to the baling of
16192 the Heidelburgh Tun, or Case.
16193 
16194 While some were occupied with this latter duty, others were employed in
16195 dragging away the larger tubs, so soon as filled with the sperm; and
16196 when the proper time arrived, this same sperm was carefully manipulated
16197 ere going to the try-works, of which anon.
16198 
16199 It had cooled and crystallized to such a degree, that when, with
16200 several others, I sat down before a large Constantine’s bath of it, I
16201 found it strangely concreted into lumps, here and there rolling about
16202 in the liquid part. It was our business to squeeze these lumps back
16203 into fluid. A sweet and unctuous duty! No wonder that in old times this
16204 sperm was such a favourite cosmetic. Such a clearer! such a sweetener!
16205 such a softener! such a delicious molifier! After having my hands in it
16206 for only a few minutes, my fingers felt like eels, and began, as it
16207 were, to serpentine and spiralise.
16208 
16209 As I sat there at my ease, cross-legged on the deck; after the bitter
16210 exertion at the windlass; under a blue tranquil sky; the ship under
16211 indolent sail, and gliding so serenely along; as I bathed my hands
16212 among those soft, gentle globules of infiltrated tissues, woven almost
16213 within the hour; as they richly broke to my fingers, and discharged all
16214 their opulence, like fully ripe grapes their wine; as I snuffed up that
16215 uncontaminated aroma,—literally and truly, like the smell of spring
16216 violets; I declare to you, that for the time I lived as in a musky
16217 meadow; I forgot all about our horrible oath; in that inexpressible
16218 sperm, I washed my hands and my heart of it; I almost began to credit
16219 the old Paracelsan superstition that sperm is of rare virtue in
16220 allaying the heat of anger; while bathing in that bath, I felt divinely
16221 free from all ill-will, or petulance, or malice, of any sort
16222 whatsoever.
16223 
16224 Squeeze! squeeze! squeeze! all the morning long; I squeezed that sperm
16225 till I myself almost melted into it; I squeezed that sperm till a
16226 strange sort of insanity came over me; and I found myself unwittingly
16227 squeezing my co-laborers’ hands in it, mistaking their hands for the
16228 gentle globules. Such an abounding, affectionate, friendly, loving
16229 feeling did this avocation beget; that at last I was continually
16230 squeezing their hands, and looking up into their eyes sentimentally; as
16231 much as to say,—Oh! my dear fellow beings, why should we longer cherish
16232 any social acerbities, or know the slightest ill-humor or envy! Come;
16233 let us squeeze hands all round; nay, let us all squeeze ourselves into
16234 each other; let us squeeze ourselves universally into the very milk and
16235 sperm of kindness.
16236 
16237 Would that I could keep squeezing that sperm for ever! For now, since
16238 by many prolonged, repeated experiences, I have perceived that in all
16239 cases man must eventually lower, or at least shift, his conceit of
16240 attainable felicity; not placing it anywhere in the intellect or the
16241 fancy; but in the wife, the heart, the bed, the table, the saddle, the
16242 fireside, the country; now that I have perceived all this, I am ready
16243 to squeeze case eternally. In thoughts of the visions of the night, I
16244 saw long rows of angels in paradise, each with his hands in a jar of
16245 spermaceti.
16246 
16247 Now, while discoursing of sperm, it behooves to speak of other things
16248 akin to it, in the business of preparing the sperm whale for the
16249 try-works.
16250 
16251 First comes white-horse, so called, which is obtained from the tapering
16252 part of the fish, and also from the thicker portions of his flukes. It
16253 is tough with congealed tendons—a wad of muscle—but still contains some
16254 oil. After being severed from the whale, the white-horse is first cut
16255 into portable oblongs ere going to the mincer. They look much like
16256 blocks of Berkshire marble.
16257 
16258 Plum-pudding is the term bestowed upon certain fragmentary parts of the
16259 whale’s flesh, here and there adhering to the blanket of blubber, and
16260 often participating to a considerable degree in its unctuousness. It is
16261 a most refreshing, convivial, beautiful object to behold. As its name
16262 imports, it is of an exceedingly rich, mottled tint, with a bestreaked
16263 snowy and golden ground, dotted with spots of the deepest crimson and
16264 purple. It is plums of rubies, in pictures of citron. Spite of reason,
16265 it is hard to keep yourself from eating it. I confess, that once I
16266 stole behind the foremast to try it. It tasted something as I should
16267 conceive a royal cutlet from the thigh of Louis le Gros might have
16268 tasted, supposing him to have been killed the first day after the
16269 venison season, and that particular venison season contemporary with an
16270 unusually fine vintage of the vineyards of Champagne.
16271 
16272 There is another substance, and a very singular one, which turns up in
16273 the course of this business, but which I feel it to be very puzzling
16274 adequately to describe. It is called slobgollion; an appellation
16275 original with the whalemen, and even so is the nature of the substance.
16276 It is an ineffably oozy, stringy affair, most frequently found in the
16277 tubs of sperm, after a prolonged squeezing, and subsequent decanting. I
16278 hold it to be the wondrously thin, ruptured membranes of the case,
16279 coalescing.
16280 
16281 Gurry, so called, is a term properly belonging to right whalemen, but
16282 sometimes incidentally used by the sperm fishermen. It designates the
16283 dark, glutinous substance which is scraped off the back of the
16284 Greenland or right whale, and much of which covers the decks of those
16285 inferior souls who hunt that ignoble Leviathan.
16286 
16287 Nippers. Strictly this word is not indigenous to the whale’s
16288 vocabulary. But as applied by whalemen, it becomes so. A whaleman’s
16289 nipper is a short firm strip of tendinous stuff cut from the tapering
16290 part of Leviathan’s tail: it averages an inch in thickness, and for the
16291 rest, is about the size of the iron part of a hoe. Edgewise moved along
16292 the oily deck, it operates like a leathern squilgee; and by nameless
16293 blandishments, as of magic, allures along with it all impurities.
16294 
16295 But to learn all about these recondite matters, your best way is at
16296 once to descend into the blubber-room, and have a long talk with its
16297 inmates. This place has previously been mentioned as the receptacle for
16298 the blanket-pieces, when stript and hoisted from the whale. When the
16299 proper time arrives for cutting up its contents, this apartment is a
16300 scene of terror to all tyros, especially by night. On one side, lit by
16301 a dull lantern, a space has been left clear for the workmen. They
16302 generally go in pairs,—a pike-and-gaffman and a spade-man. The
16303 whaling-pike is similar to a frigate’s boarding-weapon of the same
16304 name. The gaff is something like a boat-hook. With his gaff, the
16305 gaffman hooks on to a sheet of blubber, and strives to hold it from
16306 slipping, as the ship pitches and lurches about. Meanwhile, the
16307 spade-man stands on the sheet itself, perpendicularly chopping it into
16308 the portable horse-pieces. This spade is sharp as hone can make it; the
16309 spademan’s feet are shoeless; the thing he stands on will sometimes
16310 irresistibly slide away from him, like a sledge. If he cuts off one of
16311 his own toes, or one of his assistants’, would you be very much
16312 astonished? Toes are scarce among veteran blubber-room men.
16313 
16314 
16315 CHAPTER 95. The Cassock.
16316 
16317 Had you stepped on board the Pequod at a certain juncture of this
16318 post-mortemizing of the whale; and had you strolled forward nigh the
16319 windlass, pretty sure am I that you would have scanned with no small
16320 curiosity a very strange, enigmatical object, which you would have seen
16321 there, lying along lengthwise in the lee scuppers. Not the wondrous
16322 cistern in the whale’s huge head; not the prodigy of his unhinged lower
16323 jaw; not the miracle of his symmetrical tail; none of these would so
16324 surprise you, as half a glimpse of that unaccountable cone,—longer than
16325 a Kentuckian is tall, nigh a foot in diameter at the base, and
16326 jet-black as Yojo, the ebony idol of Queequeg. And an idol, indeed, it
16327 is; or, rather, in old times, its likeness was. Such an idol as that
16328 found in the secret groves of Queen Maachah in Judea; and for
16329 worshipping which, King Asa, her son, did depose her, and destroyed the
16330 idol, and burnt it for an abomination at the brook Kedron, as darkly
16331 set forth in the 15th chapter of the First Book of Kings.
16332 
16333 Look at the sailor, called the mincer, who now comes along, and
16334 assisted by two allies, heavily backs the grandissimus, as the mariners
16335 call it, and with bowed shoulders, staggers off with it as if he were a
16336 grenadier carrying a dead comrade from the field. Extending it upon the
16337 forecastle deck, he now proceeds cylindrically to remove its dark pelt,
16338 as an African hunter the pelt of a boa. This done he turns the pelt
16339 inside out, like a pantaloon leg; gives it a good stretching, so as
16340 almost to double its diameter; and at last hangs it, well spread, in
16341 the rigging, to dry. Ere long, it is taken down; when removing some
16342 three feet of it, towards the pointed extremity, and then cutting two
16343 slits for arm-holes at the other end, he lengthwise slips himself
16344 bodily into it. The mincer now stands before you invested in the full
16345 canonicals of his calling. Immemorial to all his order, this
16346 investiture alone will adequately protect him, while employed in the
16347 peculiar functions of his office.
16348 
16349 That office consists in mincing the horse-pieces of blubber for the
16350 pots; an operation which is conducted at a curious wooden horse,
16351 planted endwise against the bulwarks, and with a capacious tub beneath
16352 it, into which the minced pieces drop, fast as the sheets from a rapt
16353 orator’s desk. Arrayed in decent black; occupying a conspicuous pulpit;
16354 intent on bible leaves; what a candidate for an archbishopric, what a
16355 lad for a Pope were this mincer!*
16356 
16357 *Bible leaves! Bible leaves! This is the invariable cry from the mates
16358 to the mincer. It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his work into as
16359 thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business of
16360 boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity considerably
16361 increased, besides perhaps improving it in quality.
16362 
16363 
16364 CHAPTER 96. The Try-Works.
16365 
16366 Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly
16367 distinguished by her try-works. She presents the curious anomaly of the
16368 most solid masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the
16369 completed ship. It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were
16370 transported to her planks.
16371 
16372 The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the most
16373 roomy part of the deck. The timbers beneath are of a peculiar strength,
16374 fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of brick and
16375 mortar, some ten feet by eight square, and five in height. The
16376 foundation does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly
16377 secured to the surface by ponderous knees of iron bracing it on all
16378 sides, and screwing it down to the timbers. On the flanks it is cased
16379 with wood, and at top completely covered by a large, sloping, battened
16380 hatchway. Removing this hatch we expose the great try-pots, two in
16381 number, and each of several barrels’ capacity. When not in use, they
16382 are kept remarkably clean. Sometimes they are polished with soapstone
16383 and sand, till they shine within like silver punch-bowls. During the
16384 night-watches some cynical old sailors will crawl into them and coil
16385 themselves away there for a nap. While employed in polishing them—one
16386 man in each pot, side by side—many confidential communications are
16387 carried on, over the iron lips. It is a place also for profound
16388 mathematical meditation. It was in the left hand try-pot of the Pequod,
16389 with the soapstone diligently circling round me, that I was first
16390 indirectly struck by the remarkable fact, that in geometry all bodies
16391 gliding along the cycloid, my soapstone for example, will descend from
16392 any point in precisely the same time.
16393 
16394 Removing the fire-board from the front of the try-works, the bare
16395 masonry of that side is exposed, penetrated by the two iron mouths of
16396 the furnaces, directly underneath the pots. These mouths are fitted
16397 with heavy doors of iron. The intense heat of the fire is prevented
16398 from communicating itself to the deck, by means of a shallow reservoir
16399 extending under the entire inclosed surface of the works. By a tunnel
16400 inserted at the rear, this reservoir is kept replenished with water as
16401 fast as it evaporates. There are no external chimneys; they open direct
16402 from the rear wall. And here let us go back for a moment.
16403 
16404 It was about nine o’clock at night that the Pequod’s try-works were
16405 first started on this present voyage. It belonged to Stubb to oversee
16406 the business.
16407 
16408 “All ready there? Off hatch, then, and start her. You cook, fire the
16409 works.” This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been thrusting
16410 his shavings into the furnace throughout the passage. Here be it said
16411 that in a whaling voyage the first fire in the try-works has to be fed
16412 for a time with wood. After that no wood is used, except as a means of
16413 quick ignition to the staple fuel. In a word, after being tried out,
16414 the crisp, shrivelled blubber, now called scraps or fritters, still
16415 contains considerable of its unctuous properties. These fritters feed
16416 the flames. Like a plethoric burning martyr, or a self-consuming
16417 misanthrope, once ignited, the whale supplies his own fuel and burns by
16418 his own body. Would that he consumed his own smoke! for his smoke is
16419 horrible to inhale, and inhale it you must, and not only that, but you
16420 must live in it for the time. It has an unspeakable, wild, Hindoo odor
16421 about it, such as may lurk in the vicinity of funereal pyres. It smells
16422 like the left wing of the day of judgment; it is an argument for the
16423 pit.
16424 
16425 By midnight the works were in full operation. We were clear from the
16426 carcase; sail had been made; the wind was freshening; the wild ocean
16427 darkness was intense. But that darkness was licked up by the fierce
16428 flames, which at intervals forked forth from the sooty flues, and
16429 illuminated every lofty rope in the rigging, as with the famed Greek
16430 fire. The burning ship drove on, as if remorselessly commissioned to
16431 some vengeful deed. So the pitch and sulphur-freighted brigs of the
16432 bold Hydriote, Canaris, issuing from their midnight harbors, with broad
16433 sheets of flame for sails, bore down upon the Turkish frigates, and
16434 folded them in conflagrations.
16435 
16436 The hatch, removed from the top of the works, now afforded a wide
16437 hearth in front of them. Standing on this were the Tartarean shapes of
16438 the pagan harpooneers, always the whale-ship’s stokers. With huge
16439 pronged poles they pitched hissing masses of blubber into the scalding
16440 pots, or stirred up the fires beneath, till the snaky flames darted,
16441 curling, out of the doors to catch them by the feet. The smoke rolled
16442 away in sullen heaps. To every pitch of the ship there was a pitch of
16443 the boiling oil, which seemed all eagerness to leap into their faces.
16444 Opposite the mouth of the works, on the further side of the wide wooden
16445 hearth, was the windlass. This served for a sea-sofa. Here lounged the
16446 watch, when not otherwise employed, looking into the red heat of the
16447 fire, till their eyes felt scorched in their heads. Their tawny
16448 features, now all begrimed with smoke and sweat, their matted beards,
16449 and the contrasting barbaric brilliancy of their teeth, all these were
16450 strangely revealed in the capricious emblazonings of the works. As they
16451 narrated to each other their unholy adventures, their tales of terror
16452 told in words of mirth; as their uncivilized laughter forked upwards
16453 out of them, like the flames from the furnace; as to and fro, in their
16454 front, the harpooneers wildly gesticulated with their huge pronged
16455 forks and dippers; as the wind howled on, and the sea leaped, and the
16456 ship groaned and dived, and yet steadfastly shot her red hell further
16457 and further into the blackness of the sea and the night, and scornfully
16458 champed the white bone in her mouth, and viciously spat round her on
16459 all sides; then the rushing Pequod, freighted with savages, and laden
16460 with fire, and burning a corpse, and plunging into that blackness of
16461 darkness, seemed the material counterpart of her monomaniac commander’s
16462 soul.
16463 
16464 So seemed it to me, as I stood at her helm, and for long hours silently
16465 guided the way of this fire-ship on the sea. Wrapped, for that
16466 interval, in darkness myself, I but the better saw the redness, the
16467 madness, the ghastliness of others. The continual sight of the fiend
16468 shapes before me, capering half in smoke and half in fire, these at
16469 last begat kindred visions in my soul, so soon as I began to yield to
16470 that unaccountable drowsiness which ever would come over me at a
16471 midnight helm.
16472 
16473 But that night, in particular, a strange (and ever since inexplicable)
16474 thing occurred to me. Starting from a brief standing sleep, I was
16475 horribly conscious of something fatally wrong. The jaw-bone tiller
16476 smote my side, which leaned against it; in my ears was the low hum of
16477 sails, just beginning to shake in the wind; I thought my eyes were
16478 open; I was half conscious of putting my fingers to the lids and
16479 mechanically stretching them still further apart. But, spite of all
16480 this, I could see no compass before me to steer by; though it seemed
16481 but a minute since I had been watching the card, by the steady binnacle
16482 lamp illuminating it. Nothing seemed before me but a jet gloom, now and
16483 then made ghastly by flashes of redness. Uppermost was the impression,
16484 that whatever swift, rushing thing I stood on was not so much bound to
16485 any haven ahead as rushing from all havens astern. A stark, bewildered
16486 feeling, as of death, came over me. Convulsively my hands grasped the
16487 tiller, but with the crazy conceit that the tiller was, somehow, in
16488 some enchanted way, inverted. My God! what is the matter with me?
16489 thought I. Lo! in my brief sleep I had turned myself about, and was
16490 fronting the ship’s stern, with my back to her prow and the compass. In
16491 an instant I faced back, just in time to prevent the vessel from flying
16492 up into the wind, and very probably capsizing her. How glad and how
16493 grateful the relief from this unnatural hallucination of the night, and
16494 the fatal contingency of being brought by the lee!
16495 
16496 Look not too long in the face of the fire, O man! Never dream with thy
16497 hand on the helm! Turn not thy back to the compass; accept the first
16498 hint of the hitching tiller; believe not the artificial fire, when its
16499 redness makes all things look ghastly. To-morrow, in the natural sun,
16500 the skies will be bright; those who glared like devils in the forking
16501 flames, the morn will show in far other, at least gentler, relief; the
16502 glorious, golden, glad sun, the only true lamp—all others but liars!
16503 
16504 Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia’s Dismal Swamp, nor Rome’s
16505 accursed Campagna, nor wide Sahara, nor all the millions of miles of
16506 deserts and of griefs beneath the moon. The sun hides not the ocean,
16507 which is the dark side of this earth, and which is two thirds of this
16508 earth. So, therefore, that mortal man who hath more of joy than sorrow
16509 in him, that mortal man cannot be true—not true, or undeveloped. With
16510 books the same. The truest of all men was the Man of Sorrows, and the
16511 truest of all books is Solomon’s, and Ecclesiastes is the fine hammered
16512 steel of woe. “All is vanity.” ALL. This wilful world hath not got hold
16513 of unchristian Solomon’s wisdom yet. But he who dodges hospitals and
16514 jails, and walks fast crossing graveyards, and would rather talk of
16515 operas than hell; calls Cowper, Young, Pascal, Rousseau, poor devils
16516 all of sick men; and throughout a care-free lifetime swears by Rabelais
16517 as passing wise, and therefore jolly;—not that man is fitted to sit
16518 down on tomb-stones, and break the green damp mould with unfathomably
16519 wondrous Solomon.
16520 
16521 But even Solomon, he says, “the man that wandereth out of the way of
16522 understanding shall remain” (_i.e._, even while living) “in the
16523 congregation of the dead.” Give not thyself up, then, to fire, lest it
16524 invert thee, deaden thee; as for the time it did me. There is a wisdom
16525 that is woe; but there is a woe that is madness. And there is a
16526 Catskill eagle in some souls that can alike dive down into the blackest
16527 gorges, and soar out of them again and become invisible in the sunny
16528 spaces. And even if he for ever flies within the gorge, that gorge is
16529 in the mountains; so that even in his lowest swoop the mountain eagle
16530 is still higher than other birds upon the plain, even though they soar.
16531 
16532 
16533 CHAPTER 97. The Lamp.
16534 
16535 Had you descended from the Pequod’s try-works to the Pequod’s
16536 forecastle, where the off duty watch were sleeping, for one single
16537 moment you would have almost thought you were standing in some
16538 illuminated shrine of canonized kings and counsellors. There they lay
16539 in their triangular oaken vaults, each mariner a chiselled muteness; a
16540 score of lamps flashing upon his hooded eyes.
16541 
16542 In merchantmen, oil for the sailor is more scarce than the milk of
16543 queens. To dress in the dark, and eat in the dark, and stumble in
16544 darkness to his pallet, this is his usual lot. But the whaleman, as he
16545 seeks the food of light, so he lives in light. He makes his berth an
16546 Aladdin’s lamp, and lays him down in it; so that in the pitchiest night
16547 the ship’s black hull still houses an illumination.
16548 
16549 See with what entire freedom the whaleman takes his handful of
16550 lamps—often but old bottles and vials, though—to the copper cooler at
16551 the try-works, and replenishes them there, as mugs of ale at a vat. He
16552 burns, too, the purest of oil, in its unmanufactured, and, therefore,
16553 unvitiated state; a fluid unknown to solar, lunar, or astral
16554 contrivances ashore. It is sweet as early grass butter in April. He
16555 goes and hunts for his oil, so as to be sure of its freshness and
16556 genuineness, even as the traveller on the prairie hunts up his own
16557 supper of game.
16558 
16559 
16560 CHAPTER 98. Stowing Down and Clearing Up.
16561 
16562 Already has it been related how the great leviathan is afar off
16563 descried from the mast-head; how he is chased over the watery moors,
16564 and slaughtered in the valleys of the deep; how he is then towed
16565 alongside and beheaded; and how (on the principle which entitled the
16566 headsman of old to the garments in which the beheaded was killed) his
16567 great padded surtout becomes the property of his executioner; how, in
16568 due time, he is condemned to the pots, and, like Shadrach, Meshach, and
16569 Abednego, his spermaceti, oil, and bone pass unscathed through the
16570 fire;—but now it remains to conclude the last chapter of this part of
16571 the description by rehearsing—singing, if I may—the romantic proceeding
16572 of decanting off his oil into the casks and striking them down into the
16573 hold, where once again leviathan returns to his native profundities,
16574 sliding along beneath the surface as before; but, alas! never more to
16575 rise and blow.
16576 
16577 While still warm, the oil, like hot punch, is received into the
16578 six-barrel casks; and while, perhaps, the ship is pitching and rolling
16579 this way and that in the midnight sea, the enormous casks are slewed
16580 round and headed over, end for end, and sometimes perilously scoot
16581 across the slippery deck, like so many land slides, till at last
16582 man-handled and stayed in their course; and all round the hoops, rap,
16583 rap, go as many hammers as can play upon them, for now, _ex officio_,
16584 every sailor is a cooper.
16585 
16586 At length, when the last pint is casked, and all is cool, then the
16587 great hatchways are unsealed, the bowels of the ship are thrown open,
16588 and down go the casks to their final rest in the sea. This done, the
16589 hatches are replaced, and hermetically closed, like a closet walled up.
16590 
16591 In the sperm fishery, this is perhaps one of the most remarkable
16592 incidents in all the business of whaling. One day the planks stream
16593 with freshets of blood and oil; on the sacred quarter-deck enormous
16594 masses of the whale’s head are profanely piled; great rusty casks lie
16595 about, as in a brewery yard; the smoke from the try-works has besooted
16596 all the bulwarks; the mariners go about suffused with unctuousness; the
16597 entire ship seems great leviathan himself; while on all hands the din
16598 is deafening.
16599 
16600 But a day or two after, you look about you, and prick your ears in this
16601 self-same ship; and were it not for the tell-tale boats and try-works,
16602 you would all but swear you trod some silent merchant vessel, with a
16603 most scrupulously neat commander. The unmanufactured sperm oil
16604 possesses a singularly cleansing virtue. This is the reason why the
16605 decks never look so white as just after what they call an affair of
16606 oil. Besides, from the ashes of the burned scraps of the whale, a
16607 potent lye is readily made; and whenever any adhesiveness from the back
16608 of the whale remains clinging to the side, that lye quickly
16609 exterminates it. Hands go diligently along the bulwarks, and with
16610 buckets of water and rags restore them to their full tidiness. The soot
16611 is brushed from the lower rigging. All the numerous implements which
16612 have been in use are likewise faithfully cleansed and put away. The
16613 great hatch is scrubbed and placed upon the try-works, completely
16614 hiding the pots; every cask is out of sight; all tackles are coiled in
16615 unseen nooks; and when by the combined and simultaneous industry of
16616 almost the entire ship’s company, the whole of this conscientious duty
16617 is at last concluded, then the crew themselves proceed to their own
16618 ablutions; shift themselves from top to toe; and finally issue to the
16619 immaculate deck, fresh and all aglow, as bridegrooms new-leaped from
16620 out the daintiest Holland.
16621 
16622 Now, with elated step, they pace the planks in twos and threes, and
16623 humorously discourse of parlors, sofas, carpets, and fine cambrics;
16624 propose to mat the deck; think of having hanging to the top; object not
16625 to taking tea by moonlight on the piazza of the forecastle. To hint to
16626 such musked mariners of oil, and bone, and blubber, were little short
16627 of audacity. They know not the thing you distantly allude to. Away, and
16628 bring us napkins!
16629 
16630 But mark: aloft there, at the three mast heads, stand three men intent
16631 on spying out more whales, which, if caught, infallibly will again soil
16632 the old oaken furniture, and drop at least one small grease-spot
16633 somewhere. Yes; and many is the time, when, after the severest
16634 uninterrupted labors, which know no night; continuing straight through
16635 for ninety-six hours; when from the boat, where they have swelled their
16636 wrists with all day rowing on the Line,—they only step to the deck to
16637 carry vast chains, and heave the heavy windlass, and cut and slash,
16638 yea, and in their very sweatings to be smoked and burned anew by the
16639 combined fires of the equatorial sun and the equatorial try-works;
16640 when, on the heel of all this, they have finally bestirred themselves
16641 to cleanse the ship, and make a spotless dairy room of it; many is the
16642 time the poor fellows, just buttoning the necks of their clean frocks,
16643 are startled by the cry of “There she blows!” and away they fly to
16644 fight another whale, and go through the whole weary thing again. Oh! my
16645 friends, but this is man-killing! Yet this is life. For hardly have we
16646 mortals by long toilings extracted from this world’s vast bulk its
16647 small but valuable sperm; and then, with weary patience, cleansed
16648 ourselves from its defilements, and learned to live here in clean
16649 tabernacles of the soul; hardly is this done, when—_There she
16650 blows!_—the ghost is spouted up, and away we sail to fight some other
16651 world, and go through young life’s old routine again.
16652 
16653 Oh! the metempsychosis! Oh! Pythagoras, that in bright Greece, two
16654 thousand years ago, did die, so good, so wise, so mild; I sailed with
16655 thee along the Peruvian coast last voyage—and, foolish as I am, taught
16656 thee, a green simple boy, how to splice a rope!
16657 
16658 
16659 CHAPTER 99. The Doubloon.
16660 
16661 Ere now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his quarter-deck,
16662 taking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and mainmast; but in
16663 the multiplicity of other things requiring narration it has not been
16664 added how that sometimes in these walks, when most plunged in his mood,
16665 he was wont to pause in turn at each spot, and stand there strangely
16666 eyeing the particular object before him. When he halted before the
16667 binnacle, with his glance fastened on the pointed needle in the
16668 compass, that glance shot like a javelin with the pointed intensity of
16669 his purpose; and when resuming his walk he again paused before the
16670 mainmast, then, as the same riveted glance fastened upon the riveted
16671 gold coin there, he still wore the same aspect of nailed firmness, only
16672 dashed with a certain wild longing, if not hopefulness.
16673 
16674 But one morning, turning to pass the doubloon, he seemed to be newly
16675 attracted by the strange figures and inscriptions stamped on it, as
16676 though now for the first time beginning to interpret for himself in
16677 some monomaniac way whatever significance might lurk in them. And some
16678 certain significance lurks in all things, else all things are little
16679 worth, and the round world itself but an empty cipher, except to sell
16680 by the cartload, as they do hills about Boston, to fill up some morass
16681 in the Milky Way.
16682 
16683 Now this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere out of
16684 the heart of gorgeous hills, whence, east and west, over golden sands,
16685 the head-waters of many a Pactolus flows. And though now nailed amidst
16686 all the rustiness of iron bolts and the verdigris of copper spikes,
16687 yet, untouchable and immaculate to any foulness, it still preserved its
16688 Quito glow. Nor, though placed amongst a ruthless crew and every hour
16689 passed by ruthless hands, and through the livelong nights shrouded with
16690 thick darkness which might cover any pilfering approach, nevertheless
16691 every sunrise found the doubloon where the sunset left it last. For it
16692 was set apart and sanctified to one awe-striking end; and however
16693 wanton in their sailor ways, one and all, the mariners revered it as
16694 the white whale’s talisman. Sometimes they talked it over in the weary
16695 watch by night, wondering whose it was to be at last, and whether he
16696 would ever live to spend it.
16697 
16698 Now those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the sun
16699 and tropic token-pieces. Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes; sun’s
16700 disks and stars; ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners waving,
16701 are in luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold seems
16702 almost to derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories, by
16703 passing through those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic.
16704 
16705 It so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy
16706 example of these things. On its round border it bore the letters,
16707 REPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR: QUITO. So this bright coin came from a country
16708 planted in the middle of the world, and beneath the great equator, and
16709 named after it; and it had been cast midway up the Andes, in the
16710 unwaning clime that knows no autumn. Zoned by those letters you saw the
16711 likeness of three Andes’ summits; from one a flame; a tower on another;
16712 on the third a crowing cock; while arching over all was a segment of
16713 the partitioned zodiac, the signs all marked with their usual
16714 cabalistics, and the keystone sun entering the equinoctial point at
16715 Libra.
16716 
16717 Before this equatorial coin, Ahab, not unobserved by others, was now
16718 pausing.
16719 
16720 “There’s something ever egotistical in mountain-tops and towers, and
16721 all other grand and lofty things; look here,—three peaks as proud as
16722 Lucifer. The firm tower, that is Ahab; the volcano, that is Ahab; the
16723 courageous, the undaunted, and victorious fowl, that, too, is Ahab; all
16724 are Ahab; and this round gold is but the image of the rounder globe,
16725 which, like a magician’s glass, to each and every man in turn but
16726 mirrors back his own mysterious self. Great pains, small gains for
16727 those who ask the world to solve them; it cannot solve itself. Methinks
16728 now this coined sun wears a ruddy face; but see! aye, he enters the
16729 sign of storms, the equinox! and but six months before he wheeled out
16730 of a former equinox at Aries! From storm to storm! So be it, then. Born
16731 in throes, ’tis fit that man should live in pains and die in pangs! So
16732 be it, then! Here’s stout stuff for woe to work on. So be it, then.”
16733 
16734 “No fairy fingers can have pressed the gold, but devil’s claws must
16735 have left their mouldings there since yesterday,” murmured Starbuck to
16736 himself, leaning against the bulwarks. “The old man seems to read
16737 Belshazzar’s awful writing. I have never marked the coin inspectingly.
16738 He goes below; let me read. A dark valley between three mighty,
16739 heaven-abiding peaks, that almost seem the Trinity, in some faint
16740 earthly symbol. So in this vale of Death, God girds us round; and over
16741 all our gloom, the sun of Righteousness still shines a beacon and a
16742 hope. If we bend down our eyes, the dark vale shows her mouldy soil;
16743 but if we lift them, the bright sun meets our glance half way, to
16744 cheer. Yet, oh, the great sun is no fixture; and if, at midnight, we
16745 would fain snatch some sweet solace from him, we gaze for him in vain!
16746 This coin speaks wisely, mildly, truly, but still sadly to me. I will
16747 quit it, lest Truth shake me falsely.”
16748 
16749 “There now’s the old Mogul,” soliloquized Stubb by the try-works, “he’s
16750 been twigging it; and there goes Starbuck from the same, and both with
16751 faces which I should say might be somewhere within nine fathoms long.
16752 And all from looking at a piece of gold, which did I have it now on
16753 Negro Hill or in Corlaer’s Hook, I’d not look at it very long ere
16754 spending it. Humph! in my poor, insignificant opinion, I regard this as
16755 queer. I have seen doubloons before now in my voyagings; your doubloons
16756 of old Spain, your doubloons of Peru, your doubloons of Chili, your
16757 doubloons of Bolivia, your doubloons of Popayan; with plenty of gold
16758 moidores and pistoles, and joes, and half joes, and quarter joes. What
16759 then should there be in this doubloon of the Equator that is so killing
16760 wonderful? By Golconda! let me read it once. Halloa! here’s signs and
16761 wonders truly! That, now, is what old Bowditch in his Epitome calls the
16762 zodiac, and what my almanac below calls ditto. I’ll get the almanac and
16763 as I have heard devils can be raised with Daboll’s arithmetic, I’ll try
16764 my hand at raising a meaning out of these queer curvicues here with the
16765 Massachusetts calendar. Here’s the book. Let’s see now. Signs and
16766 wonders; and the sun, he’s always among ’em. Hem, hem, hem; here they
16767 are—here they go—all alive:—Aries, or the Ram; Taurus, or the Bull and
16768 Jimimi! here’s Gemini himself, or the Twins. Well; the sun he wheels
16769 among ’em. Aye, here on the coin he’s just crossing the threshold
16770 between two of twelve sitting-rooms all in a ring. Book! you lie there;
16771 the fact is, you books must know your places. You’ll do to give us the
16772 bare words and facts, but we come in to supply the thoughts. That’s my
16773 small experience, so far as the Massachusetts calendar, and Bowditch’s
16774 navigator, and Daboll’s arithmetic go. Signs and wonders, eh? Pity if
16775 there is nothing wonderful in signs, and significant in wonders!
16776 There’s a clue somewhere; wait a bit; hist—hark! By Jove, I have it!
16777 Look you, Doubloon, your zodiac here is the life of man in one round
16778 chapter; and now I’ll read it off, straight out of the book. Come,
16779 Almanack! To begin: there’s Aries, or the Ram—lecherous dog, he begets
16780 us; then, Taurus, or the Bull—he bumps us the first thing; then Gemini,
16781 or the Twins—that is, Virtue and Vice; we try to reach Virtue, when lo!
16782 comes Cancer the Crab, and drags us back; and here, going from Virtue,
16783 Leo, a roaring Lion, lies in the path—he gives a few fierce bites and
16784 surly dabs with his paw; we escape, and hail Virgo, the Virgin! that’s
16785 our first love; we marry and think to be happy for aye, when pop comes
16786 Libra, or the Scales—happiness weighed and found wanting; and while we
16787 are very sad about that, Lord! how we suddenly jump, as Scorpio, or the
16788 Scorpion, stings us in the rear; we are curing the wound, when whang
16789 come the arrows all round; Sagittarius, or the Archer, is amusing
16790 himself. As we pluck out the shafts, stand aside! here’s the
16791 battering-ram, Capricornus, or the Goat; full tilt, he comes rushing,
16792 and headlong we are tossed; when Aquarius, or the Water-bearer, pours
16793 out his whole deluge and drowns us; and to wind up with Pisces, or the
16794 Fishes, we sleep. There’s a sermon now, writ in high heaven, and the
16795 sun goes through it every year, and yet comes out of it all alive and
16796 hearty. Jollily he, aloft there, wheels through toil and trouble; and
16797 so, alow here, does jolly Stubb. Oh, jolly’s the word for aye! Adieu,
16798 Doubloon! But stop; here comes little King-Post; dodge round the
16799 try-works, now, and let’s hear what he’ll have to say. There; he’s
16800 before it; he’ll out with something presently. So, so; he’s beginning.”
16801 
16802 “I see nothing here, but a round thing made of gold, and whoever raises
16803 a certain whale, this round thing belongs to him. So, what’s all this
16804 staring been about? It is worth sixteen dollars, that’s true; and at
16805 two cents the cigar, that’s nine hundred and sixty cigars. I won’t
16806 smoke dirty pipes like Stubb, but I like cigars, and here’s nine
16807 hundred and sixty of them; so here goes Flask aloft to spy ’em out.”
16808 
16809 “Shall I call that wise or foolish, now; if it be really wise it has a
16810 foolish look to it; yet, if it be really foolish, then has it a sort of
16811 wiseish look to it. But, avast; here comes our old Manxman—the old
16812 hearse-driver, he must have been, that is, before he took to the sea.
16813 He luffs up before the doubloon; halloa, and goes round on the other
16814 side of the mast; why, there’s a horse-shoe nailed on that side; and
16815 now he’s back again; what does that mean? Hark! he’s muttering—voice
16816 like an old worn-out coffee-mill. Prick ears, and listen!”
16817 
16818 “If the White Whale be raised, it must be in a month and a day, when
16819 the sun stands in some one of these signs. I’ve studied signs, and know
16820 their marks; they were taught me two score years ago, by the old witch
16821 in Copenhagen. Now, in what sign will the sun then be? The horse-shoe
16822 sign; for there it is, right opposite the gold. And what’s the
16823 horse-shoe sign? The lion is the horse-shoe sign—the roaring and
16824 devouring lion. Ship, old ship! my old head shakes to think of thee.”
16825 
16826 “There’s another rendering now; but still one text. All sorts of men in
16827 one kind of world, you see. Dodge again! here comes Queequeg—all
16828 tattooing—looks like the signs of the Zodiac himself. What says the
16829 Cannibal? As I live he’s comparing notes; looking at his thigh bone;
16830 thinks the sun is in the thigh, or in the calf, or in the bowels, I
16831 suppose, as the old women talk Surgeon’s Astronomy in the back country.
16832 And by Jove, he’s found something there in the vicinity of his thigh—I
16833 guess it’s Sagittarius, or the Archer. No: he don’t know what to make
16834 of the doubloon; he takes it for an old button off some king’s
16835 trowsers. But, aside again! here comes that ghost-devil, Fedallah; tail
16836 coiled out of sight as usual, oakum in the toes of his pumps as usual.
16837 What does he say, with that look of his? Ah, only makes a sign to the
16838 sign and bows himself; there is a sun on the coin—fire worshipper,
16839 depend upon it. Ho! more and more. This way comes Pip—poor boy! would
16840 he had died, or I; he’s half horrible to me. He too has been watching
16841 all of these interpreters—myself included—and look now, he comes to
16842 read, with that unearthly idiot face. Stand away again and hear him.
16843 Hark!”
16844 
16845 “I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look.”
16846 
16847 “Upon my soul, he’s been studying Murray’s Grammar! Improving his mind,
16848 poor fellow! But what’s that he says now—hist!”
16849 
16850 “I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look.”
16851 
16852 “Why, he’s getting it by heart—hist! again.”
16853 
16854 “I look, you look, he looks; we look, ye look, they look.”
16855 
16856 “Well, that’s funny.”
16857 
16858 “And I, you, and he; and we, ye, and they, are all bats; and I’m a
16859 crow, especially when I stand a’top of this pine tree here. Caw! caw!
16860 caw! caw! caw! caw! Ain’t I a crow? And where’s the scare-crow? There
16861 he stands; two bones stuck into a pair of old trowsers, and two more
16862 poked into the sleeves of an old jacket.”
16863 
16864 “Wonder if he means me?—complimentary!—poor lad!—I could go hang
16865 myself. Any way, for the present, I’ll quit Pip’s vicinity. I can stand
16866 the rest, for they have plain wits; but he’s too crazy-witty for my
16867 sanity. So, so, I leave him muttering.”
16868 
16869 “Here’s the ship’s navel, this doubloon here, and they are all on fire
16870 to unscrew it. But, unscrew your navel, and what’s the consequence?
16871 Then again, if it stays here, that is ugly, too, for when aught’s
16872 nailed to the mast it’s a sign that things grow desperate. Ha, ha! old
16873 Ahab! the White Whale; he’ll nail ye! This is a pine tree. My father,
16874 in old Tolland county, cut down a pine tree once, and found a silver
16875 ring grown over in it; some old darkey’s wedding ring. How did it get
16876 there? And so they’ll say in the resurrection, when they come to fish
16877 up this old mast, and find a doubloon lodged in it, with bedded oysters
16878 for the shaggy bark. Oh, the gold! the precious, precious, gold! the
16879 green miser’ll hoard ye soon! Hish! hish! God goes ’mong the worlds
16880 blackberrying. Cook! ho, cook! and cook us! Jenny! hey, hey, hey, hey,
16881 hey, Jenny, Jenny! and get your hoe-cake done!”
16882 
16883 
16884 CHAPTER 100. Leg and Arm.
16885 
16886 The Pequod, of Nantucket, Meets the Samuel Enderby, of London.
16887 
16888 “Ship, ahoy! Hast seen the White Whale?”
16889 
16890 So cried Ahab, once more hailing a ship showing English colours,
16891 bearing down under the stern. Trumpet to mouth, the old man was
16892 standing in his hoisted quarter-boat, his ivory leg plainly revealed to
16893 the stranger captain, who was carelessly reclining in his own boat’s
16894 bow. He was a darkly-tanned, burly, good-natured, fine-looking man, of
16895 sixty or thereabouts, dressed in a spacious roundabout, that hung round
16896 him in festoons of blue pilot-cloth; and one empty arm of this jacket
16897 streamed behind him like the broidered arm of a hussar’s surcoat.
16898 
16899 “Hast seen the White Whale?”
16900 
16901 “See you this?” and withdrawing it from the folds that had hidden it,
16902 he held up a white arm of sperm whale bone, terminating in a wooden
16903 head like a mallet.
16904 
16905 “Man my boat!” cried Ahab, impetuously, and tossing about the oars near
16906 him—“Stand by to lower!”
16907 
16908 In less than a minute, without quitting his little craft, he and his
16909 crew were dropped to the water, and were soon alongside of the
16910 stranger. But here a curious difficulty presented itself. In the
16911 excitement of the moment, Ahab had forgotten that since the loss of his
16912 leg he had never once stepped on board of any vessel at sea but his
16913 own, and then it was always by an ingenious and very handy mechanical
16914 contrivance peculiar to the Pequod, and a thing not to be rigged and
16915 shipped in any other vessel at a moment’s warning. Now, it is no very
16916 easy matter for anybody—except those who are almost hourly used to it,
16917 like whalemen—to clamber up a ship’s side from a boat on the open sea;
16918 for the great swells now lift the boat high up towards the bulwarks,
16919 and then instantaneously drop it half way down to the kelson. So,
16920 deprived of one leg, and the strange ship of course being altogether
16921 unsupplied with the kindly invention, Ahab now found himself abjectly
16922 reduced to a clumsy landsman again; hopelessly eyeing the uncertain
16923 changeful height he could hardly hope to attain.
16924 
16925 It has before been hinted, perhaps, that every little untoward
16926 circumstance that befell him, and which indirectly sprang from his
16927 luckless mishap, almost invariably irritated or exasperated Ahab. And
16928 in the present instance, all this was heightened by the sight of the
16929 two officers of the strange ship, leaning over the side, by the
16930 perpendicular ladder of nailed cleets there, and swinging towards him a
16931 pair of tastefully-ornamented man-ropes; for at first they did not seem
16932 to bethink them that a one-legged man must be too much of a cripple to
16933 use their sea bannisters. But this awkwardness only lasted a minute,
16934 because the strange captain, observing at a glance how affairs stood,
16935 cried out, “I see, I see!—avast heaving there! Jump, boys, and swing
16936 over the cutting-tackle.”
16937 
16938 As good luck would have it, they had had a whale alongside a day or two
16939 previous, and the great tackles were still aloft, and the massive
16940 curved blubber-hook, now clean and dry, was still attached to the end.
16941 This was quickly lowered to Ahab, who at once comprehending it all,
16942 slid his solitary thigh into the curve of the hook (it was like sitting
16943 in the fluke of an anchor, or the crotch of an apple tree), and then
16944 giving the word, held himself fast, and at the same time also helped to
16945 hoist his own weight, by pulling hand-over-hand upon one of the running
16946 parts of the tackle. Soon he was carefully swung inside the high
16947 bulwarks, and gently landed upon the capstan head. With his ivory arm
16948 frankly thrust forth in welcome, the other captain advanced, and Ahab,
16949 putting out his ivory leg, and crossing the ivory arm (like two
16950 sword-fish blades) cried out in his walrus way, “Aye, aye, hearty! let
16951 us shake bones together!—an arm and a leg!—an arm that never can
16952 shrink, d’ye see; and a leg that never can run. Where did’st thou see
16953 the White Whale?—how long ago?”
16954 
16955 “The White Whale,” said the Englishman, pointing his ivory arm towards
16956 the East, and taking a rueful sight along it, as if it had been a
16957 telescope; “there I saw him, on the Line, last season.”
16958 
16959 “And he took that arm off, did he?” asked Ahab, now sliding down from
16960 the capstan, and resting on the Englishman’s shoulder, as he did so.
16961 
16962 “Aye, he was the cause of it, at least; and that leg, too?”
16963 
16964 “Spin me the yarn,” said Ahab; “how was it?”
16965 
16966 “It was the first time in my life that I ever cruised on the Line,”
16967 began the Englishman. “I was ignorant of the White Whale at that time.
16968 Well, one day we lowered for a pod of four or five whales, and my boat
16969 fastened to one of them; a regular circus horse he was, too, that went
16970 milling and milling round so, that my boat’s crew could only trim dish,
16971 by sitting all their sterns on the outer gunwale. Presently up breaches
16972 from the bottom of the sea a bouncing great whale, with a milky-white
16973 head and hump, all crows’ feet and wrinkles.”
16974 
16975 “It was he, it was he!” cried Ahab, suddenly letting out his suspended
16976 breath.
16977 
16978 “And harpoons sticking in near his starboard fin.”
16979 
16980 “Aye, aye—they were mine—_my_ irons,” cried Ahab, exultingly—“but on!”
16981 
16982 “Give me a chance, then,” said the Englishman, good-humoredly. “Well,
16983 this old great-grandfather, with the white head and hump, runs all
16984 afoam into the pod, and goes to snapping furiously at my fast-line!
16985 
16986 “Aye, I see!—wanted to part it; free the fast-fish—an old trick—I know
16987 him.”
16988 
16989 “How it was exactly,” continued the one-armed commander, “I do not
16990 know; but in biting the line, it got foul of his teeth, caught there
16991 somehow; but we didn’t know it then; so that when we afterwards pulled
16992 on the line, bounce we came plump on to his hump! instead of the other
16993 whale’s; that went off to windward, all fluking. Seeing how matters
16994 stood, and what a noble great whale it was—the noblest and biggest I
16995 ever saw, sir, in my life—I resolved to capture him, spite of the
16996 boiling rage he seemed to be in. And thinking the hap-hazard line would
16997 get loose, or the tooth it was tangled to might draw (for I have a
16998 devil of a boat’s crew for a pull on a whale-line); seeing all this, I
16999 say, I jumped into my first mate’s boat—Mr. Mounttop’s here (by the
17000 way, Captain—Mounttop; Mounttop—the captain);—as I was saying, I jumped
17001 into Mounttop’s boat, which, d’ye see, was gunwale and gunwale with
17002 mine, then; and snatching the first harpoon, let this old
17003 great-grandfather have it. But, Lord, look you, sir—hearts and souls
17004 alive, man—the next instant, in a jiff, I was blind as a bat—both eyes
17005 out—all befogged and bedeadened with black foam—the whale’s tail
17006 looming straight up out of it, perpendicular in the air, like a marble
17007 steeple. No use sterning all, then; but as I was groping at midday,
17008 with a blinding sun, all crown-jewels; as I was groping, I say, after
17009 the second iron, to toss it overboard—down comes the tail like a Lima
17010 tower, cutting my boat in two, leaving each half in splinters; and,
17011 flukes first, the white hump backed through the wreck, as though it was
17012 all chips. We all struck out. To escape his terrible flailings, I
17013 seized hold of my harpoon-pole sticking in him, and for a moment clung
17014 to that like a sucking fish. But a combing sea dashed me off, and at
17015 the same instant, the fish, taking one good dart forwards, went down
17016 like a flash; and the barb of that cursed second iron towing along near
17017 me caught me here” (clapping his hand just below his shoulder); “yes,
17018 caught me just here, I say, and bore me down to Hell’s flames, I was
17019 thinking; when, when, all of a sudden, thank the good God, the barb
17020 ript its way along the flesh—clear along the whole length of my
17021 arm—came out nigh my wrist, and up I floated;—and that gentleman there
17022 will tell you the rest (by the way, captain—Dr. Bunger, ship’s surgeon:
17023 Bunger, my lad,—the captain). Now, Bunger boy, spin your part of the
17024 yarn.”
17025 
17026 The professional gentleman thus familiarly pointed out, had been all
17027 the time standing near them, with nothing specific visible, to denote
17028 his gentlemanly rank on board. His face was an exceedingly round but
17029 sober one; he was dressed in a faded blue woollen frock or shirt, and
17030 patched trowsers; and had thus far been dividing his attention between
17031 a marlingspike he held in one hand, and a pill-box held in the other,
17032 occasionally casting a critical glance at the ivory limbs of the two
17033 crippled captains. But, at his superior’s introduction of him to Ahab,
17034 he politely bowed, and straightway went on to do his captain’s bidding.
17035 
17036 “It was a shocking bad wound,” began the whale-surgeon; “and, taking my
17037 advice, Captain Boomer here, stood our old Sammy—”
17038 
17039 “Samuel Enderby is the name of my ship,” interrupted the one-armed
17040 captain, addressing Ahab; “go on, boy.”
17041 
17042 “Stood our old Sammy off to the northward, to get out of the blazing
17043 hot weather there on the Line. But it was no use—I did all I could; sat
17044 up with him nights; was very severe with him in the matter of diet—”
17045 
17046 “Oh, very severe!” chimed in the patient himself; then suddenly
17047 altering his voice, “Drinking hot rum toddies with me every night, till
17048 he couldn’t see to put on the bandages; and sending me to bed, half
17049 seas over, about three o’clock in the morning. Oh, ye stars! he sat up
17050 with me indeed, and was very severe in my diet. Oh! a great watcher,
17051 and very dietetically severe, is Dr. Bunger. (Bunger, you dog, laugh
17052 out! why don’t ye? You know you’re a precious jolly rascal.) But, heave
17053 ahead, boy, I’d rather be killed by you than kept alive by any other
17054 man.”
17055 
17056 “My captain, you must have ere this perceived, respected sir”—said the
17057 imperturbable godly-looking Bunger, slightly bowing to Ahab—“is apt to
17058 be facetious at times; he spins us many clever things of that sort. But
