17059 I may as well say—en passant, as the French remark—that I myself—that
17060 is to say, Jack Bunger, late of the reverend clergy—am a strict total
17061 abstinence man; I never drink—”
17062 
17063 “Water!” cried the captain; “he never drinks it; it’s a sort of fits to
17064 him; fresh water throws him into the hydrophobia; but go on—go on with
17065 the arm story.”
17066 
17067 “Yes, I may as well,” said the surgeon, coolly. “I was about observing,
17068 sir, before Captain Boomer’s facetious interruption, that spite of my
17069 best and severest endeavors, the wound kept getting worse and worse;
17070 the truth was, sir, it was as ugly gaping wound as surgeon ever saw;
17071 more than two feet and several inches long. I measured it with the lead
17072 line. In short, it grew black; I knew what was threatened, and off it
17073 came. But I had no hand in shipping that ivory arm there; that thing is
17074 against all rule”—pointing at it with the marlingspike—“that is the
17075 captain’s work, not mine; he ordered the carpenter to make it; he had
17076 that club-hammer there put to the end, to knock some one’s brains out
17077 with, I suppose, as he tried mine once. He flies into diabolical
17078 passions sometimes. Do ye see this dent, sir”—removing his hat, and
17079 brushing aside his hair, and exposing a bowl-like cavity in his skull,
17080 but which bore not the slightest scarry trace, or any token of ever
17081 having been a wound—“Well, the captain there will tell you how that
17082 came here; he knows.”
17083 
17084 “No, I don’t,” said the captain, “but his mother did; he was born with
17085 it. Oh, you solemn rogue, you—you Bunger! was there ever such another
17086 Bunger in the watery world? Bunger, when you die, you ought to die in
17087 pickle, you dog; you should be preserved to future ages, you rascal.”
17088 
17089 “What became of the White Whale?” now cried Ahab, who thus far had been
17090 impatiently listening to this by-play between the two Englishmen.
17091 
17092 “Oh!” cried the one-armed captain, “oh, yes! Well; after he sounded, we
17093 didn’t see him again for some time; in fact, as I before hinted, I
17094 didn’t then know what whale it was that had served me such a trick,
17095 till some time afterwards, when coming back to the Line, we heard about
17096 Moby Dick—as some call him—and then I knew it was he.”
17097 
17098 “Did’st thou cross his wake again?”
17099 
17100 “Twice.”
17101 
17102 “But could not fasten?”
17103 
17104 “Didn’t want to try to: ain’t one limb enough? What should I do without
17105 this other arm? And I’m thinking Moby Dick doesn’t bite so much as he
17106 swallows.”
17107 
17108 “Well, then,” interrupted Bunger, “give him your left arm for bait to
17109 get the right. Do you know, gentlemen”—very gravely and mathematically
17110 bowing to each Captain in succession—“Do you know, gentlemen, that the
17111 digestive organs of the whale are so inscrutably constructed by Divine
17112 Providence, that it is quite impossible for him to completely digest
17113 even a man’s arm? And he knows it too. So that what you take for the
17114 White Whale’s malice is only his awkwardness. For he never means to
17115 swallow a single limb; he only thinks to terrify by feints. But
17116 sometimes he is like the old juggling fellow, formerly a patient of
17117 mine in Ceylon, that making believe swallow jack-knives, once upon a
17118 time let one drop into him in good earnest, and there it stayed for a
17119 twelvemonth or more; when I gave him an emetic, and he heaved it up in
17120 small tacks, d’ye see. No possible way for him to digest that
17121 jack-knife, and fully incorporate it into his general bodily system.
17122 Yes, Captain Boomer, if you are quick enough about it, and have a mind
17123 to pawn one arm for the sake of the privilege of giving decent burial
17124 to the other, why in that case the arm is yours; only let the whale
17125 have another chance at you shortly, that’s all.”
17126 
17127 “No, thank ye, Bunger,” said the English Captain, “he’s welcome to the
17128 arm he has, since I can’t help it, and didn’t know him then; but not to
17129 another one. No more White Whales for me; I’ve lowered for him once,
17130 and that has satisfied me. There would be great glory in killing him, I
17131 know that; and there is a ship-load of precious sperm in him, but, hark
17132 ye, he’s best let alone; don’t you think so, Captain?”—glancing at the
17133 ivory leg.
17134 
17135 “He is. But he will still be hunted, for all that. What is best let
17136 alone, that accursed thing is not always what least allures. He’s all a
17137 magnet! How long since thou saw’st him last? Which way heading?”
17138 
17139 “Bless my soul, and curse the foul fiend’s,” cried Bunger, stoopingly
17140 walking round Ahab, and like a dog, strangely snuffing; “this man’s
17141 blood—bring the thermometer!—it’s at the boiling point!—his pulse makes
17142 these planks beat!—sir!”—taking a lancet from his pocket, and drawing
17143 near to Ahab’s arm.
17144 
17145 “Avast!” roared Ahab, dashing him against the bulwarks—“Man the boat!
17146 Which way heading?”
17147 
17148 “Good God!” cried the English Captain, to whom the question was put.
17149 “What’s the matter? He was heading east, I think.—Is your Captain
17150 crazy?” whispering Fedallah.
17151 
17152 But Fedallah, putting a finger on his lip, slid over the bulwarks to
17153 take the boat’s steering oar, and Ahab, swinging the cutting-tackle
17154 towards him, commanded the ship’s sailors to stand by to lower.
17155 
17156 In a moment he was standing in the boat’s stern, and the Manilla men
17157 were springing to their oars. In vain the English Captain hailed him.
17158 With back to the stranger ship, and face set like a flint to his own,
17159 Ahab stood upright till alongside of the Pequod.
17160 
17161 
17162 CHAPTER 101. The Decanter.
17163 
17164 Ere the English ship fades from sight, be it set down here, that she
17165 hailed from London, and was named after the late Samuel Enderby,
17166 merchant of that city, the original of the famous whaling house of
17167 Enderby & Sons; a house which in my poor whaleman’s opinion, comes not
17168 far behind the united royal houses of the Tudors and Bourbons, in point
17169 of real historical interest. How long, prior to the year of our Lord
17170 1775, this great whaling house was in existence, my numerous
17171 fish-documents do not make plain; but in that year (1775) it fitted out
17172 the first English ships that ever regularly hunted the Sperm Whale;
17173 though for some score of years previous (ever since 1726) our valiant
17174 Coffins and Maceys of Nantucket and the Vineyard had in large fleets
17175 pursued that Leviathan, but only in the North and South Atlantic: not
17176 elsewhere. Be it distinctly recorded here, that the Nantucketers were
17177 the first among mankind to harpoon with civilized steel the great Sperm
17178 Whale; and that for half a century they were the only people of the
17179 whole globe who so harpooned him.
17180 
17181 In 1778, a fine ship, the Amelia, fitted out for the express purpose,
17182 and at the sole charge of the vigorous Enderbys, boldly rounded Cape
17183 Horn, and was the first among the nations to lower a whale-boat of any
17184 sort in the great South Sea. The voyage was a skilful and lucky one;
17185 and returning to her berth with her hold full of the precious sperm,
17186 the Amelia’s example was soon followed by other ships, English and
17187 American, and thus the vast Sperm Whale grounds of the Pacific were
17188 thrown open. But not content with this good deed, the indefatigable
17189 house again bestirred itself: Samuel and all his Sons—how many, their
17190 mother only knows—and under their immediate auspices, and partly, I
17191 think, at their expense, the British government was induced to send the
17192 sloop-of-war Rattler on a whaling voyage of discovery into the South
17193 Sea. Commanded by a naval Post-Captain, the Rattler made a rattling
17194 voyage of it, and did some service; how much does not appear. But this
17195 is not all. In 1819, the same house fitted out a discovery whale ship
17196 of their own, to go on a tasting cruise to the remote waters of Japan.
17197 That ship—well called the “Syren”—made a noble experimental cruise; and
17198 it was thus that the great Japanese Whaling Ground first became
17199 generally known. The Syren in this famous voyage was commanded by a
17200 Captain Coffin, a Nantucketer.
17201 
17202 All honor to the Enderbies, therefore, whose house, I think, exists to
17203 the present day; though doubtless the original Samuel must long ago
17204 have slipped his cable for the great South Sea of the other world.
17205 
17206 The ship named after him was worthy of the honor, being a very fast
17207 sailer and a noble craft every way. I boarded her once at midnight
17208 somewhere off the Patagonian coast, and drank good flip down in the
17209 forecastle. It was a fine gam we had, and they were all trumps—every
17210 soul on board. A short life to them, and a jolly death. And that fine
17211 gam I had—long, very long after old Ahab touched her planks with his
17212 ivory heel—it minds me of the noble, solid, Saxon hospitality of that
17213 ship; and may my parson forget me, and the devil remember me, if I ever
17214 lose sight of it. Flip? Did I say we had flip? Yes, and we flipped it
17215 at the rate of ten gallons the hour; and when the squall came (for it’s
17216 squally off there by Patagonia), and all hands—visitors and all—were
17217 called to reef topsails, we were so top-heavy that we had to swing each
17218 other aloft in bowlines; and we ignorantly furled the skirts of our
17219 jackets into the sails, so that we hung there, reefed fast in the
17220 howling gale, a warning example to all drunken tars. However, the masts
17221 did not go overboard; and by and by we scrambled down, so sober, that
17222 we had to pass the flip again, though the savage salt spray bursting
17223 down the forecastle scuttle, rather too much diluted and pickled it to
17224 my taste.
17225 
17226 The beef was fine—tough, but with body in it. They said it was
17227 bull-beef; others, that it was dromedary beef; but I do not know, for
17228 certain, how that was. They had dumplings too; small, but substantial,
17229 symmetrically globular, and indestructible dumplings. I fancied that
17230 you could feel them, and roll them about in you after they were
17231 swallowed. If you stooped over too far forward, you risked their
17232 pitching out of you like billiard-balls. The bread—but that couldn’t be
17233 helped; besides, it was an anti-scorbutic; in short, the bread
17234 contained the only fresh fare they had. But the forecastle was not very
17235 light, and it was very easy to step over into a dark corner when you
17236 ate it. But all in all, taking her from truck to helm, considering the
17237 dimensions of the cook’s boilers, including his own live parchment
17238 boilers; fore and aft, I say, the Samuel Enderby was a jolly ship; of
17239 good fare and plenty; fine flip and strong; crack fellows all, and
17240 capital from boot heels to hat-band.
17241 
17242 But why was it, think ye, that the Samuel Enderby, and some other
17243 English whalers I know of—not all though—were such famous, hospitable
17244 ships; that passed round the beef, and the bread, and the can, and the
17245 joke; and were not soon weary of eating, and drinking, and laughing? I
17246 will tell you. The abounding good cheer of these English whalers is
17247 matter for historical research. Nor have I been at all sparing of
17248 historical whale research, when it has seemed needed.
17249 
17250 The English were preceded in the whale fishery by the Hollanders,
17251 Zealanders, and Danes; from whom they derived many terms still extant
17252 in the fishery; and what is yet more, their fat old fashions, touching
17253 plenty to eat and drink. For, as a general thing, the English
17254 merchant-ship scrimps her crew; but not so the English whaler. Hence,
17255 in the English, this thing of whaling good cheer is not normal and
17256 natural, but incidental and particular; and, therefore, must have some
17257 special origin, which is here pointed out, and will be still further
17258 elucidated.
17259 
17260 During my researches in the Leviathanic histories, I stumbled upon an
17261 ancient Dutch volume, which, by the musty whaling smell of it, I knew
17262 must be about whalers. The title was, “Dan Coopman,” wherefore I
17263 concluded that this must be the invaluable memoirs of some Amsterdam
17264 cooper in the fishery, as every whale ship must carry its cooper. I was
17265 reinforced in this opinion by seeing that it was the production of one
17266 “Fitz Swackhammer.” But my friend Dr. Snodhead, a very learned man,
17267 professor of Low Dutch and High German in the college of Santa Claus
17268 and St. Pott’s, to whom I handed the work for translation, giving him a
17269 box of sperm candles for his trouble—this same Dr. Snodhead, so soon as
17270 he spied the book, assured me that “Dan Coopman” did not mean “The
17271 Cooper,” but “The Merchant.” In short, this ancient and learned Low
17272 Dutch book treated of the commerce of Holland; and, among other
17273 subjects, contained a very interesting account of its whale fishery.
17274 And in this chapter it was, headed, “Smeer,” or “Fat,” that I found a
17275 long detailed list of the outfits for the larders and cellars of 180
17276 sail of Dutch whalemen; from which list, as translated by Dr. Snodhead,
17277 I transcribe the following:
17278 
17279 400,000 lbs. of beef. 60,000 lbs. Friesland pork. 150,000 lbs. of stock
17280 fish. 550,000 lbs. of biscuit. 72,000 lbs. of soft bread. 2,800 firkins
17281 of butter. 20,000 lbs. Texel & Leyden cheese. 144,000 lbs. cheese
17282 (probably an inferior article). 550 ankers of Geneva. 10,800 barrels of
17283 beer.
17284 
17285 Most statistical tables are parchingly dry in the reading; not so in
17286 the present case, however, where the reader is flooded with whole
17287 pipes, barrels, quarts, and gills of good gin and good cheer.
17288 
17289 At the time, I devoted three days to the studious digesting of all this
17290 beer, beef, and bread, during which many profound thoughts were
17291 incidentally suggested to me, capable of a transcendental and Platonic
17292 application; and, furthermore, I compiled supplementary tables of my
17293 own, touching the probable quantity of stock-fish, etc., consumed by
17294 every Low Dutch harpooneer in that ancient Greenland and Spitzbergen
17295 whale fishery. In the first place, the amount of butter, and Texel and
17296 Leyden cheese consumed, seems amazing. I impute it, though, to their
17297 naturally unctuous natures, being rendered still more unctuous by the
17298 nature of their vocation, and especially by their pursuing their game
17299 in those frigid Polar Seas, on the very coasts of that Esquimaux
17300 country where the convivial natives pledge each other in bumpers of
17301 train oil.
17302 
17303 The quantity of beer, too, is very large, 10,800 barrels. Now, as those
17304 polar fisheries could only be prosecuted in the short summer of that
17305 climate, so that the whole cruise of one of these Dutch whalemen,
17306 including the short voyage to and from the Spitzbergen sea, did not
17307 much exceed three months, say, and reckoning 30 men to each of their
17308 fleet of 180 sail, we have 5,400 Low Dutch seamen in all; therefore, I
17309 say, we have precisely two barrels of beer per man, for a twelve weeks’
17310 allowance, exclusive of his fair proportion of that 550 ankers of gin.
17311 Now, whether these gin and beer harpooneers, so fuddled as one might
17312 fancy them to have been, were the right sort of men to stand up in a
17313 boat’s head, and take good aim at flying whales; this would seem
17314 somewhat improbable. Yet they did aim at them, and hit them too. But
17315 this was very far North, be it remembered, where beer agrees well with
17316 the constitution; upon the Equator, in our southern fishery, beer would
17317 be apt to make the harpooneer sleepy at the mast-head and boozy in his
17318 boat; and grievous loss might ensue to Nantucket and New Bedford.
17319 
17320 But no more; enough has been said to show that the old Dutch whalers of
17321 two or three centuries ago were high livers; and that the English
17322 whalers have not neglected so excellent an example. For, say they, when
17323 cruising in an empty ship, if you can get nothing better out of the
17324 world, get a good dinner out of it, at least. And this empties the
17325 decanter.
17326 
17327 
17328 CHAPTER 102. A Bower in the Arsacides.
17329 
17330 Hitherto, in descriptively treating of the Sperm Whale, I have chiefly
17331 dwelt upon the marvels of his outer aspect; or separately and in detail
17332 upon some few interior structural features. But to a large and thorough
17333 sweeping comprehension of him, it behooves me now to unbutton him still
17334 further, and untagging the points of his hose, unbuckling his garters,
17335 and casting loose the hooks and the eyes of the joints of his innermost
17336 bones, set him before you in his ultimatum; that is to say, in his
17337 unconditional skeleton.
17338 
17339 But how now, Ishmael? How is it, that you, a mere oarsman in the
17340 fishery, pretend to know aught about the subterranean parts of the
17341 whale? Did erudite Stubb, mounted upon your capstan, deliver lectures
17342 on the anatomy of the Cetacea; and by help of the windlass, hold up a
17343 specimen rib for exhibition? Explain thyself, Ishmael. Can you land a
17344 full-grown whale on your deck for examination, as a cook dishes a
17345 roast-pig? Surely not. A veritable witness have you hitherto been,
17346 Ishmael; but have a care how you seize the privilege of Jonah alone;
17347 the privilege of discoursing upon the joists and beams; the rafters,
17348 ridge-pole, sleepers, and under-pinnings, making up the frame-work of
17349 leviathan; and belike of the tallow-vats, dairy-rooms, butteries, and
17350 cheeseries in his bowels.
17351 
17352 I confess, that since Jonah, few whalemen have penetrated very far
17353 beneath the skin of the adult whale; nevertheless, I have been blessed
17354 with an opportunity to dissect him in miniature. In a ship I belonged
17355 to, a small cub Sperm Whale was once bodily hoisted to the deck for his
17356 poke or bag, to make sheaths for the barbs of the harpoons, and for the
17357 heads of the lances. Think you I let that chance go, without using my
17358 boat-hatchet and jack-knife, and breaking the seal and reading all the
17359 contents of that young cub?
17360 
17361 And as for my exact knowledge of the bones of the leviathan in their
17362 gigantic, full grown development, for that rare knowledge I am indebted
17363 to my late royal friend Tranquo, king of Tranque, one of the Arsacides.
17364 For being at Tranque, years ago, when attached to the trading-ship Dey
17365 of Algiers, I was invited to spend part of the Arsacidean holidays with
17366 the lord of Tranque, at his retired palm villa at Pupella; a sea-side
17367 glen not very far distant from what our sailors called Bamboo-Town, his
17368 capital.
17369 
17370 Among many other fine qualities, my royal friend Tranquo, being gifted
17371 with a devout love for all matters of barbaric vertu, had brought
17372 together in Pupella whatever rare things the more ingenious of his
17373 people could invent; chiefly carved woods of wonderful devices,
17374 chiselled shells, inlaid spears, costly paddles, aromatic canoes; and
17375 all these distributed among whatever natural wonders, the
17376 wonder-freighted, tribute-rendering waves had cast upon his shores.
17377 
17378 Chief among these latter was a great Sperm Whale, which, after an
17379 unusually long raging gale, had been found dead and stranded, with his
17380 head against a cocoa-nut tree, whose plumage-like, tufted droopings
17381 seemed his verdant jet. When the vast body had at last been stripped of
17382 its fathom-deep enfoldings, and the bones become dust dry in the sun,
17383 then the skeleton was carefully transported up the Pupella glen, where
17384 a grand temple of lordly palms now sheltered it.
17385 
17386 The ribs were hung with trophies; the vertebræ were carved with
17387 Arsacidean annals, in strange hieroglyphics; in the skull, the priests
17388 kept up an unextinguished aromatic flame, so that the mystic head again
17389 sent forth its vapory spout; while, suspended from a bough, the
17390 terrific lower jaw vibrated over all the devotees, like the hair-hung
17391 sword that so affrighted Damocles.
17392 
17393 It was a wondrous sight. The wood was green as mosses of the Icy Glen;
17394 the trees stood high and haughty, feeling their living sap; the
17395 industrious earth beneath was as a weaver’s loom, with a gorgeous
17396 carpet on it, whereof the ground-vine tendrils formed the warp and
17397 woof, and the living flowers the figures. All the trees, with all their
17398 laden branches; all the shrubs, and ferns, and grasses; the
17399 message-carrying air; all these unceasingly were active. Through the
17400 lacings of the leaves, the great sun seemed a flying shuttle weaving
17401 the unwearied verdure. Oh, busy weaver! unseen weaver!—pause!—one
17402 word!—whither flows the fabric? what palace may it deck? wherefore all
17403 these ceaseless toilings? Speak, weaver!—stay thy hand!—but one single
17404 word with thee! Nay—the shuttle flies—the figures float from forth the
17405 loom; the freshet-rushing carpet for ever slides away. The weaver-god,
17406 he weaves; and by that weaving is he deafened, that he hears no mortal
17407 voice; and by that humming, we, too, who look on the loom are deafened;
17408 and only when we escape it shall we hear the thousand voices that speak
17409 through it. For even so it is in all material factories. The spoken
17410 words that are inaudible among the flying spindles; those same words
17411 are plainly heard without the walls, bursting from the opened
17412 casements. Thereby have villainies been detected. Ah, mortal! then, be
17413 heedful; for so, in all this din of the great world’s loom, thy
17414 subtlest thinkings may be overheard afar.
17415 
17416 Now, amid the green, life-restless loom of that Arsacidean wood, the
17417 great, white, worshipped skeleton lay lounging—a gigantic idler! Yet,
17418 as the ever-woven verdant warp and woof intermixed and hummed around
17419 him, the mighty idler seemed the cunning weaver; himself all woven over
17420 with the vines; every month assuming greener, fresher verdure; but
17421 himself a skeleton. Life folded Death; Death trellised Life; the grim
17422 god wived with youthful Life, and begat him curly-headed glories.
17423 
17424 Now, when with royal Tranquo I visited this wondrous whale, and saw the
17425 skull an altar, and the artificial smoke ascending from where the real
17426 jet had issued, I marvelled that the king should regard a chapel as an
17427 object of vertu. He laughed. But more I marvelled that the priests
17428 should swear that smoky jet of his was genuine. To and fro I paced
17429 before this skeleton—brushed the vines aside—broke through the ribs—and
17430 with a ball of Arsacidean twine, wandered, eddied long amid its many
17431 winding, shaded colonnades and arbours. But soon my line was out; and
17432 following it back, I emerged from the opening where I entered. I saw no
17433 living thing within; naught was there but bones.
17434 
17435 Cutting me a green measuring-rod, I once more dived within the
17436 skeleton. From their arrow-slit in the skull, the priests perceived me
17437 taking the altitude of the final rib, “How now!” they shouted; “Dar’st
17438 thou measure this our god! That’s for us.” “Aye, priests—well, how long
17439 do ye make him, then?” But hereupon a fierce contest rose among them,
17440 concerning feet and inches; they cracked each other’s sconces with
17441 their yard-sticks—the great skull echoed—and seizing that lucky chance,
17442 I quickly concluded my own admeasurements.
17443 
17444 These admeasurements I now propose to set before you. But first, be it
17445 recorded, that, in this matter, I am not free to utter any fancied
17446 measurement I please. Because there are skeleton authorities you can
17447 refer to, to test my accuracy. There is a Leviathanic Museum, they tell
17448 me, in Hull, England, one of the whaling ports of that country, where
17449 they have some fine specimens of fin-backs and other whales. Likewise,
17450 I have heard that in the museum of Manchester, in New Hampshire, they
17451 have what the proprietors call “the only perfect specimen of a
17452 Greenland or River Whale in the United States.” Moreover, at a place in
17453 Yorkshire, England, Burton Constable by name, a certain Sir Clifford
17454 Constable has in his possession the skeleton of a Sperm Whale, but of
17455 moderate size, by no means of the full-grown magnitude of my friend
17456 King Tranquo’s.
17457 
17458 In both cases, the stranded whales to which these two skeletons
17459 belonged, were originally claimed by their proprietors upon similar
17460 grounds. King Tranquo seizing his because he wanted it; and Sir
17461 Clifford, because he was lord of the seignories of those parts. Sir
17462 Clifford’s whale has been articulated throughout; so that, like a great
17463 chest of drawers, you can open and shut him, in all his bony
17464 cavities—spread out his ribs like a gigantic fan—and swing all day upon
17465 his lower jaw. Locks are to be put upon some of his trap-doors and
17466 shutters; and a footman will show round future visitors with a bunch of
17467 keys at his side. Sir Clifford thinks of charging twopence for a peep
17468 at the whispering gallery in the spinal column; threepence to hear the
17469 echo in the hollow of his cerebellum; and sixpence for the unrivalled
17470 view from his forehead.
17471 
17472 The skeleton dimensions I shall now proceed to set down are copied
17473 verbatim from my right arm, where I had them tattooed; as in my wild
17474 wanderings at that period, there was no other secure way of preserving
17475 such valuable statistics. But as I was crowded for space, and wished
17476 the other parts of my body to remain a blank page for a poem I was then
17477 composing—at least, what untattooed parts might remain—I did not
17478 trouble myself with the odd inches; nor, indeed, should inches at all
17479 enter into a congenial admeasurement of the whale.
17480 
17481 
17482 CHAPTER 103. Measurement of The Whale’s Skeleton.
17483 
17484 In the first place, I wish to lay before you a particular, plain
17485 statement, touching the living bulk of this leviathan, whose skeleton
17486 we are briefly to exhibit. Such a statement may prove useful here.
17487 
17488 According to a careful calculation I have made, and which I partly base
17489 upon Captain Scoresby’s estimate, of seventy tons for the largest sized
17490 Greenland whale of sixty feet in length; according to my careful
17491 calculation, I say, a Sperm Whale of the largest magnitude, between
17492 eighty-five and ninety feet in length, and something less than forty
17493 feet in its fullest circumference, such a whale will weigh at least
17494 ninety tons; so that, reckoning thirteen men to a ton, he would
17495 considerably outweigh the combined population of a whole village of one
17496 thousand one hundred inhabitants.
17497 
17498 Think you not then that brains, like yoked cattle, should be put to
17499 this leviathan, to make him at all budge to any landsman’s imagination?
17500 
17501 Having already in various ways put before you his skull, spout-hole,
17502 jaw, teeth, tail, forehead, fins, and divers other parts, I shall now
17503 simply point out what is most interesting in the general bulk of his
17504 unobstructed bones. But as the colossal skull embraces so very large a
17505 proportion of the entire extent of the skeleton; as it is by far the
17506 most complicated part; and as nothing is to be repeated concerning it
17507 in this chapter, you must not fail to carry it in your mind, or under
17508 your arm, as we proceed, otherwise you will not gain a complete notion
17509 of the general structure we are about to view.
17510 
17511 In length, the Sperm Whale’s skeleton at Tranque measured seventy-two
17512 feet; so that when fully invested and extended in life, he must have
17513 been ninety feet long; for in the whale, the skeleton loses about one
17514 fifth in length compared with the living body. Of this seventy-two
17515 feet, his skull and jaw comprised some twenty feet, leaving some fifty
17516 feet of plain back-bone. Attached to this back-bone, for something less
17517 than a third of its length, was the mighty circular basket of ribs
17518 which once enclosed his vitals.
17519 
17520 To me this vast ivory-ribbed chest, with the long, unrelieved spine,
17521 extending far away from it in a straight line, not a little resembled
17522 the hull of a great ship new-laid upon the stocks, when only some
17523 twenty of her naked bow-ribs are inserted, and the keel is otherwise,
17524 for the time, but a long, disconnected timber.
17525 
17526 The ribs were ten on a side. The first, to begin from the neck, was
17527 nearly six feet long; the second, third, and fourth were each
17528 successively longer, till you came to the climax of the fifth, or one
17529 of the middle ribs, which measured eight feet and some inches. From
17530 that part, the remaining ribs diminished, till the tenth and last only
17531 spanned five feet and some inches. In general thickness, they all bore
17532 a seemly correspondence to their length. The middle ribs were the most
17533 arched. In some of the Arsacides they are used for beams whereon to lay
17534 footpath bridges over small streams.
17535 
17536 In considering these ribs, I could not but be struck anew with the
17537 circumstance, so variously repeated in this book, that the skeleton of
17538 the whale is by no means the mould of his invested form. The largest of
17539 the Tranque ribs, one of the middle ones, occupied that part of the
17540 fish which, in life, is greatest in depth. Now, the greatest depth of
17541 the invested body of this particular whale must have been at least
17542 sixteen feet; whereas, the corresponding rib measured but little more
17543 than eight feet. So that this rib only conveyed half of the true notion
17544 of the living magnitude of that part. Besides, for some way, where I
17545 now saw but a naked spine, all that had been once wrapped round with
17546 tons of added bulk in flesh, muscle, blood, and bowels. Still more, for
17547 the ample fins, I here saw but a few disordered joints; and in place of
17548 the weighty and majestic, but boneless flukes, an utter blank!
17549 
17550 How vain and foolish, then, thought I, for timid untravelled man to try
17551 to comprehend aright this wondrous whale, by merely poring over his
17552 dead attenuated skeleton, stretched in this peaceful wood. No. Only in
17553 the heart of quickest perils; only when within the eddyings of his
17554 angry flukes; only on the profound unbounded sea, can the fully
17555 invested whale be truly and livingly found out.
17556 
17557 But the spine. For that, the best way we can consider it is, with a
17558 crane, to pile its bones high up on end. No speedy enterprise. But now
17559 it’s done, it looks much like Pompey’s Pillar.
17560 
17561 There are forty and odd vertebræ in all, which in the skeleton are not
17562 locked together. They mostly lie like the great knobbed blocks on a
17563 Gothic spire, forming solid courses of heavy masonry. The largest, a
17564 middle one, is in width something less than three feet, and in depth
17565 more than four. The smallest, where the spine tapers away into the
17566 tail, is only two inches in width, and looks something like a white
17567 billiard-ball. I was told that there were still smaller ones, but they
17568 had been lost by some little cannibal urchins, the priest’s children,
17569 who had stolen them to play marbles with. Thus we see how that the
17570 spine of even the hugest of living things tapers off at last into
17571 simple child’s play.
17572 
17573 
17574 CHAPTER 104. The Fossil Whale.
17575 
17576 From his mighty bulk the whale affords a most congenial theme whereon
17577 to enlarge, amplify, and generally expatiate. Would you, you could not
17578 compress him. By good rights he should only be treated of in imperial
17579 folio. Not to tell over again his furlongs from spiracle to tail, and
17580 the yards he measures about the waist; only think of the gigantic
17581 involutions of his intestines, where they lie in him like great cables
17582 and hawsers coiled away in the subterranean orlop-deck of a
17583 line-of-battle-ship.
17584 
17585 Since I have undertaken to manhandle this Leviathan, it behooves me to
17586 approve myself omnisciently exhaustive in the enterprise; not
17587 overlooking the minutest seminal germs of his blood, and spinning him
17588 out to the uttermost coil of his bowels. Having already described him
17589 in most of his present habitatory and anatomical peculiarities, it now
17590 remains to magnify him in an archæological, fossiliferous, and
17591 antediluvian point of view. Applied to any other creature than the
17592 Leviathan—to an ant or a flea—such portly terms might justly be deemed
17593 unwarrantably grandiloquent. But when Leviathan is the text, the case
17594 is altered. Fain am I to stagger to this emprise under the weightiest
17595 words of the dictionary. And here be it said, that whenever it has been
17596 convenient to consult one in the course of these dissertations, I have
17597 invariably used a huge quarto edition of Johnson, expressly purchased
17598 for that purpose; because that famous lexicographer’s uncommon personal
17599 bulk more fitted him to compile a lexicon to be used by a whale author
17600 like me.
17601 
17602 One often hears of writers that rise and swell with their subject,
17603 though it may seem but an ordinary one. How, then, with me, writing of
17604 this Leviathan? Unconsciously my chirography expands into placard
17605 capitals. Give me a condor’s quill! Give me Vesuvius’ crater for an
17606 inkstand! Friends, hold my arms! For in the mere act of penning my
17607 thoughts of this Leviathan, they weary me, and make me faint with their
17608 outreaching comprehensiveness of sweep, as if to include the whole
17609 circle of the sciences, and all the generations of whales, and men, and
17610 mastodons, past, present, and to come, with all the revolving panoramas
17611 of empire on earth, and throughout the whole universe, not excluding
17612 its suburbs. Such, and so magnifying, is the virtue of a large and
17613 liberal theme! We expand to its bulk. To produce a mighty book, you
17614 must choose a mighty theme. No great and enduring volume can ever be
17615 written on the flea, though many there be who have tried it.
17616 
17617 Ere entering upon the subject of Fossil Whales, I present my
17618 credentials as a geologist, by stating that in my miscellaneous time I
17619 have been a stone-mason, and also a great digger of ditches, canals and
17620 wells, wine-vaults, cellars, and cisterns of all sorts. Likewise, by
17621 way of preliminary, I desire to remind the reader, that while in the
17622 earlier geological strata there are found the fossils of monsters now
17623 almost completely extinct; the subsequent relics discovered in what are
17624 called the Tertiary formations seem the connecting, or at any rate
17625 intercepted links, between the antichronical creatures, and those whose
17626 remote posterity are said to have entered the Ark; all the Fossil
17627 Whales hitherto discovered belong to the Tertiary period, which is the
17628 last preceding the superficial formations. And though none of them
17629 precisely answer to any known species of the present time, they are yet
17630 sufficiently akin to them in general respects, to justify their taking
17631 rank as Cetacean fossils.
17632 
17633 Detached broken fossils of pre-adamite whales, fragments of their bones
17634 and skeletons, have within thirty years past, at various intervals,
17635 been found at the base of the Alps, in Lombardy, in France, in England,
17636 in Scotland, and in the States of Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.
17637 Among the more curious of such remains is part of a skull, which in the
17638 year 1779 was disinterred in the Rue Dauphine in Paris, a short street
17639 opening almost directly upon the palace of the Tuileries; and bones
17640 disinterred in excavating the great docks of Antwerp, in Napoleon’s
17641 time. Cuvier pronounced these fragments to have belonged to some
17642 utterly unknown Leviathanic species.
17643 
17644 But by far the most wonderful of all Cetacean relics was the almost
17645 complete vast skeleton of an extinct monster, found in the year 1842,
17646 on the plantation of Judge Creagh, in Alabama. The awe-stricken
17647 credulous slaves in the vicinity took it for the bones of one of the
17648 fallen angels. The Alabama doctors declared it a huge reptile, and
17649 bestowed upon it the name of Basilosaurus. But some specimen bones of
17650 it being taken across the sea to Owen, the English Anatomist, it turned
17651 out that this alleged reptile was a whale, though of a departed
17652 species. A significant illustration of the fact, again and again
17653 repeated in this book, that the skeleton of the whale furnishes but
17654 little clue to the shape of his fully invested body. So Owen
17655 rechristened the monster Zeuglodon; and in his paper read before the
17656 London Geological Society, pronounced it, in substance, one of the most
17657 extraordinary creatures which the mutations of the globe have blotted
17658 out of existence.
17659 
17660 When I stand among these mighty Leviathan skeletons, skulls, tusks,
17661 jaws, ribs, and vertebræ, all characterized by partial resemblances to
17662 the existing breeds of sea-monsters; but at the same time bearing on
17663 the other hand similar affinities to the annihilated antichronical
17664 Leviathans, their incalculable seniors; I am, by a flood, borne back to
17665 that wondrous period, ere time itself can be said to have begun; for
17666 time began with man. Here Saturn’s grey chaos rolls over me, and I
17667 obtain dim, shuddering glimpses into those Polar eternities; when
17668 wedged bastions of ice pressed hard upon what are now the Tropics; and
17669 in all the 25,000 miles of this world’s circumference, not an
17670 inhabitable hand’s breadth of land was visible. Then the whole world
17671 was the whale’s; and, king of creation, he left his wake along the
17672 present lines of the Andes and the Himmalehs. Who can show a pedigree
17673 like Leviathan? Ahab’s harpoon had shed older blood than the Pharaoh’s.
17674 Methuselah seems a school-boy. I look round to shake hands with Shem. I
17675 am horror-struck at this antemosaic, unsourced existence of the
17676 unspeakable terrors of the whale, which, having been before all time,
17677 must needs exist after all humane ages are over.
17678 
17679 But not alone has this Leviathan left his pre-adamite traces in the
17680 stereotype plates of nature, and in limestone and marl bequeathed his
17681 ancient bust; but upon Egyptian tablets, whose antiquity seems to claim
17682 for them an almost fossiliferous character, we find the unmistakable
17683 print of his fin. In an apartment of the great temple of Denderah, some
17684 fifty years ago, there was discovered upon the granite ceiling a
17685 sculptured and painted planisphere, abounding in centaurs, griffins,
17686 and dolphins, similar to the grotesque figures on the celestial globe
17687 of the moderns. Gliding among them, old Leviathan swam as of yore; was
17688 there swimming in that planisphere, centuries before Solomon was
17689 cradled.
17690 
17691 Nor must there be omitted another strange attestation of the antiquity
17692 of the whale, in his own osseous post-diluvian reality, as set down by
17693 the venerable John Leo, the old Barbary traveller.
17694 
17695 “Not far from the Sea-side, they have a Temple, the Rafters and Beams
17696 of which are made of Whale-Bones; for Whales of a monstrous size are
17697 oftentimes cast up dead upon that shore. The Common People imagine,
17698 that by a secret Power bestowed by God upon the Temple, no Whale can
17699 pass it without immediate death. But the truth of the Matter is, that
17700 on either side of the Temple, there are Rocks that shoot two Miles into
17701 the Sea, and wound the Whales when they light upon ’em. They keep a
17702 Whale’s Rib of an incredible length for a Miracle, which lying upon the
17703 Ground with its convex part uppermost, makes an Arch, the Head of which
17704 cannot be reached by a Man upon a Camel’s Back. This Rib (says John
17705 Leo) is said to have layn there a hundred Years before I saw it. Their
17706 Historians affirm, that a Prophet who prophesy’d of Mahomet, came from
17707 this Temple, and some do not stand to assert, that the Prophet Jonas
17708 was cast forth by the Whale at the Base of the Temple.”
17709 
17710 In this Afric Temple of the Whale I leave you, reader, and if you be a
17711 Nantucketer, and a whaleman, you will silently worship there.
17712 
17713 
17714 CHAPTER 105. Does the Whale’s Magnitude Diminish?—Will He Perish?
17715 
17716 Inasmuch, then, as this Leviathan comes floundering down upon us from
17717 the head-waters of the Eternities, it may be fitly inquired, whether,
17718 in the long course of his generations, he has not degenerated from the
17719 original bulk of his sires.
17720 
17721 But upon investigation we find, that not only are the whales of the
17722 present day superior in magnitude to those whose fossil remains are
17723 found in the Tertiary system (embracing a distinct geological period
17724 prior to man), but of the whales found in that Tertiary system, those
17725 belonging to its latter formations exceed in size those of its earlier
17726 ones.
17727 
17728 Of all the pre-adamite whales yet exhumed, by far the largest is the
17729 Alabama one mentioned in the last chapter, and that was less than
17730 seventy feet in length in the skeleton. Whereas, we have already seen,
17731 that the tape-measure gives seventy-two feet for the skeleton of a
17732 large sized modern whale. And I have heard, on whalemen’s authority,
17733 that Sperm Whales have been captured near a hundred feet long at the
17734 time of capture.
17735 
17736 But may it not be, that while the whales of the present hour are an
17737 advance in magnitude upon those of all previous geological periods; may
17738 it not be, that since Adam’s time they have degenerated?
17739 
17740 Assuredly, we must conclude so, if we are to credit the accounts of
17741 such gentlemen as Pliny, and the ancient naturalists generally. For
17742 Pliny tells us of whales that embraced acres of living bulk, and
17743 Aldrovandus of others which measured eight hundred feet in length—Rope
17744 Walks and Thames Tunnels of Whales! And even in the days of Banks and
17745 Solander, Cooke’s naturalists, we find a Danish member of the Academy
17746 of Sciences setting down certain Iceland Whales (reydan-siskur, or
17747 Wrinkled Bellies) at one hundred and twenty yards; that is, three
17748 hundred and sixty feet. And Lacépède, the French naturalist, in his
17749 elaborate history of whales, in the very beginning of his work (page
17750 3), sets down the Right Whale at one hundred metres, three hundred and
17751 twenty-eight feet. And this work was published so late as A.D. 1825.
17752 
17753 But will any whaleman believe these stories? No. The whale of to-day is
17754 as big as his ancestors in Pliny’s time. And if ever I go where Pliny
17755 is, I, a whaleman (more than he was), will make bold to tell him so.
17756 Because I cannot understand how it is, that while the Egyptian mummies
17757 that were buried thousands of years before even Pliny was born, do not
17758 measure so much in their coffins as a modern Kentuckian in his socks;
17759 and while the cattle and other animals sculptured on the oldest
17760 Egyptian and Nineveh tablets, by the relative proportions in which they
17761 are drawn, just as plainly prove that the high-bred, stall-fed, prize
17762 cattle of Smithfield, not only equal, but far exceed in magnitude the
17763 fattest of Pharaoh’s fat kine; in the face of all this, I will not
17764 admit that of all animals the whale alone should have degenerated.
17765 
17766 But still another inquiry remains; one often agitated by the more
17767 recondite Nantucketers. Whether owing to the almost omniscient
17768 look-outs at the mast-heads of the whale-ships, now penetrating even
17769 through Behring’s straits, and into the remotest secret drawers and
17770 lockers of the world; and the thousand harpoons and lances darted along
17771 all continental coasts; the moot point is, whether Leviathan can long
17772 endure so wide a chase, and so remorseless a havoc; whether he must not
17773 at last be exterminated from the waters, and the last whale, like the
17774 last man, smoke his last pipe, and then himself evaporate in the final
17775 puff.
17776 
17777 Comparing the humped herds of whales with the humped herds of buffalo,
17778 which, not forty years ago, overspread by tens of thousands the
17779 prairies of Illinois and Missouri, and shook their iron manes and
17780 scowled with their thunder-clotted brows upon the sites of populous
17781 river-capitals, where now the polite broker sells you land at a dollar
17782 an inch; in such a comparison an irresistible argument would seem
17783 furnished, to show that the hunted whale cannot now escape speedy
17784 extinction.
17785 
17786 But you must look at this matter in every light. Though so short a
17787 period ago—not a good lifetime—the census of the buffalo in Illinois
17788 exceeded the census of men now in London, and though at the present day
17789 not one horn or hoof of them remains in all that region; and though the
17790 cause of this wondrous extermination was the spear of man; yet the far
17791 different nature of the whale-hunt peremptorily forbids so inglorious
17792 an end to the Leviathan. Forty men in one ship hunting the Sperm Whales
17793 for forty-eight months think they have done extremely well, and thank
17794 God, if at last they carry home the oil of forty fish. Whereas, in the
17795 days of the old Canadian and Indian hunters and trappers of the West,
17796 when the far west (in whose sunset suns still rise) was a wilderness
17797 and a virgin, the same number of moccasined men, for the same number of
17798 months, mounted on horse instead of sailing in ships, would have slain
17799 not forty, but forty thousand and more buffaloes; a fact that, if need
17800 were, could be statistically stated.
17801 
17802 Nor, considered aright, does it seem any argument in favour of the
17803 gradual extinction of the Sperm Whale, for example, that in former
17804 years (the latter part of the last century, say) these Leviathans, in
17805 small pods, were encountered much oftener than at present, and, in
17806 consequence, the voyages were not so prolonged, and were also much more
17807 remunerative. Because, as has been elsewhere noticed, those whales,
17808 influenced by some views to safety, now swim the seas in immense
17809 caravans, so that to a large degree the scattered solitaries, yokes,
17810 and pods, and schools of other days are now aggregated into vast but
17811 widely separated, unfrequent armies. That is all. And equally
17812 fallacious seems the conceit, that because the so-called whale-bone
17813 whales no longer haunt many grounds in former years abounding with
17814 them, hence that species also is declining. For they are only being
17815 driven from promontory to cape; and if one coast is no longer enlivened
17816 with their jets, then, be sure, some other and remoter strand has been
17817 very recently startled by the unfamiliar spectacle.
17818 
17819 Furthermore: concerning these last mentioned Leviathans, they have two
17820 firm fortresses, which, in all human probability, will for ever remain
17821 impregnable. And as upon the invasion of their valleys, the frosty
17822 Swiss have retreated to their mountains; so, hunted from the savannas
17823 and glades of the middle seas, the whale-bone whales can at last resort
17824 to their Polar citadels, and diving under the ultimate glassy barriers
17825 and walls there, come up among icy fields and floes; and in a charmed
17826 circle of everlasting December, bid defiance to all pursuit from man.
17827 
17828 But as perhaps fifty of these whale-bone whales are harpooned for one
17829 cachalot, some philosophers of the forecastle have concluded that this
17830 positive havoc has already very seriously diminished their battalions.
17831 But though for some time past a number of these whales, not less than
17832 13,000, have been annually slain on the nor’ west coast by the
17833 Americans alone; yet there are considerations which render even this
17834 circumstance of little or no account as an opposing argument in this
17835 matter.
17836 
17837 Natural as it is to be somewhat incredulous concerning the populousness
17838 of the more enormous creatures of the globe, yet what shall we say to
17839 Harto, the historian of Goa, when he tells us that at one hunting the
17840 King of Siam took 4,000 elephants; that in those regions elephants are
17841 numerous as droves of cattle in the temperate climes. And there seems
17842 no reason to doubt that if these elephants, which have now been hunted
17843 for thousands of years, by Semiramis, by Porus, by Hannibal, and by all
17844 the successive monarchs of the East—if they still survive there in
17845 great numbers, much more may the great whale outlast all hunting, since
17846 he has a pasture to expatiate in, which is precisely twice as large as
17847 all Asia, both Americas, Europe and Africa, New Holland, and all the
17848 Isles of the sea combined.
17849 
17850 Moreover: we are to consider, that from the presumed great longevity of
17851 whales, their probably attaining the age of a century and more,
17852 therefore at any one period of time, several distinct adult generations
17853 must be contemporary. And what that is, we may soon gain some idea of,
17854 by imagining all the grave-yards, cemeteries, and family vaults of
17855 creation yielding up the live bodies of all the men, women, and
17856 children who were alive seventy-five years ago; and adding this
17857 countless host to the present human population of the globe.
17858 
17859 Wherefore, for all these things, we account the whale immortal in his
17860 species, however perishable in his individuality. He swam the seas
17861 before the continents broke water; he once swam over the site of the
17862 Tuileries, and Windsor Castle, and the Kremlin. In Noah’s flood he
17863 despised Noah’s Ark; and if ever the world is to be again flooded, like
17864 the Netherlands, to kill off its rats, then the eternal whale will
17865 still survive, and rearing upon the topmost crest of the equatorial
17866 flood, spout his frothed defiance to the skies.
17867 
17868 
17869 CHAPTER 106. Ahab’s Leg.
17870 
17871 The precipitating manner in which Captain Ahab had quitted the Samuel
17872 Enderby of London, had not been unattended with some small violence to
17873 his own person. He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart of his
17874 boat that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock. And when
17875 after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there, he so
17876 vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman (it
17877 was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly enough);
17878 then, the already shaken ivory received such an additional twist and
17879 wrench, that though it still remained entire, and to all appearances
17880 lusty, yet Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy.
17881 
17882 And, indeed, it seemed small matter for wonder, that for all his
17883 pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab did at times give careful heed to the
17884 condition of that dead bone upon which he partly stood. For it had not
17885 been very long prior to the Pequod’s sailing from Nantucket, that he
17886 had been found one night lying prone upon the ground, and insensible;
17887 by some unknown, and seemingly inexplicable, unimaginable casualty, his
17888 ivory limb having been so violently displaced, that it had stake-wise
17889 smitten, and all but pierced his groin; nor was it without extreme
17890 difficulty that the agonizing wound was entirely cured.
17891 
17892 Nor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind, that all
17893 the anguish of that then present suffering was but the direct issue of
17894 a former woe; and he too plainly seemed to see, that as the most
17895 poisonous reptile of the marsh perpetuates his kind as inevitably as
17896 the sweetest songster of the grove; so, equally with every felicity,
17897 all miserable events do naturally beget their like. Yea, more than
17898 equally, thought Ahab; since both the ancestry and posterity of Grief
17899 go further than the ancestry and posterity of Joy. For, not to hint of
17900 this: that it is an inference from certain canonic teachings, that
17901 while some natural enjoyments here shall have no children born to them
17902 for the other world, but, on the contrary, shall be followed by the
17903 joy-childlessness of all hell’s despair; whereas, some guilty mortal
17904 miseries shall still fertilely beget to themselves an eternally
17905 progressive progeny of griefs beyond the grave; not at all to hint of
17906 this, there still seems an inequality in the deeper analysis of the
17907 thing. For, thought Ahab, while even the highest earthly felicities
17908 ever have a certain unsignifying pettiness lurking in them, but, at
17909 bottom, all heartwoes, a mystic significance, and, in some men, an
17910 archangelic grandeur; so do their diligent tracings-out not belie the
17911 obvious deduction. To trail the genealogies of these high mortal
17912 miseries, carries us at last among the sourceless primogenitures of the
17913 gods; so that, in the face of all the glad, hay-making suns, and soft
17914 cymballing, round harvest-moons, we must needs give in to this: that
17915 the gods themselves are not for ever glad. The ineffaceable, sad
17916 birth-mark in the brow of man, is but the stamp of sorrow in the
17917 signers.
17918 
17919 Unwittingly here a secret has been divulged, which perhaps might more
17920 properly, in set way, have been disclosed before. With many other
17921 particulars concerning Ahab, always had it remained a mystery to some,
17922 why it was, that for a certain period, both before and after the
17923 sailing of the Pequod, he had hidden himself away with such
17924 Grand-Lama-like exclusiveness; and, for that one interval, sought
17925 speechless refuge, as it were, among the marble senate of the dead.
17926 Captain Peleg’s bruited reason for this thing appeared by no means
17927 adequate; though, indeed, as touching all Ahab’s deeper part, every
17928 revelation partook more of significant darkness than of explanatory
17929 light. But, in the end, it all came out; this one matter did, at least.
17930 That direful mishap was at the bottom of his temporary recluseness. And
17931 not only this, but to that ever-contracting, dropping circle ashore,
17932 who, for any reason, possessed the privilege of a less banned approach
17933 to him; to that timid circle the above hinted casualty—remaining, as it
17934 did, moodily unaccounted for by Ahab—invested itself with terrors, not
17935 entirely underived from the land of spirits and of wails. So that,
17936 through their zeal for him, they had all conspired, so far as in them
17937 lay, to muffle up the knowledge of this thing from others; and hence it
17938 was, that not till a considerable interval had elapsed, did it
17939 transpire upon the Pequod’s decks.
17940 
17941 But be all this as it may; let the unseen, ambiguous synod in the air,
17942 or the vindictive princes and potentates of fire, have to do or not
17943 with earthly Ahab, yet, in this present matter of his leg, he took
17944 plain practical procedures;—he called the carpenter.
17945 
17946 And when that functionary appeared before him, he bade him without
17947 delay set about making a new leg, and directed the mates to see him
17948 supplied with all the studs and joists of jaw-ivory (Sperm Whale) which
17949 had thus far been accumulated on the voyage, in order that a careful
17950 selection of the stoutest, clearest-grained stuff might be secured.
17951 This done, the carpenter received orders to have the leg completed that
17952 night; and to provide all the fittings for it, independent of those
17953 pertaining to the distrusted one in use. Moreover, the ship’s forge was
17954 ordered to be hoisted out of its temporary idleness in the hold; and,
17955 to accelerate the affair, the blacksmith was commanded to proceed at
17956 once to the forging of whatever iron contrivances might be needed.
17957 
17958 
17959 CHAPTER 107. The Carpenter.
17960 
17961 Seat thyself sultanically among the moons of Saturn, and take high
17962 abstracted man alone; and he seems a wonder, a grandeur, and a woe. But
17963 from the same point, take mankind in mass, and for the most part, they
17964 seem a mob of unnecessary duplicates, both contemporary and hereditary.
17965 But most humble though he was, and far from furnishing an example of
17966 the high, humane abstraction; the Pequod’s carpenter was no duplicate;
17967 hence, he now comes in person on this stage.
17968 
17969 Like all sea-going ship carpenters, and more especially those belonging
17970 to whaling vessels, he was, to a certain off-handed, practical extent,
17971 alike experienced in numerous trades and callings collateral to his
17972 own; the carpenter’s pursuit being the ancient and outbranching trunk
17973 of all those numerous handicrafts which more or less have to do with
17974 wood as an auxiliary material. But, besides the application to him of
17975 the generic remark above, this carpenter of the Pequod was singularly
17976 efficient in those thousand nameless mechanical emergencies continually
17977 recurring in a large ship, upon a three or four years’ voyage, in
17978 uncivilized and far-distant seas. For not to speak of his readiness in
17979 ordinary duties:—repairing stove boats, sprung spars, reforming the
17980 shape of clumsy-bladed oars, inserting bull’s eyes in the deck, or new
17981 tree-nails in the side planks, and other miscellaneous matters more
17982 directly pertaining to his special business; he was moreover
17983 unhesitatingly expert in all manner of conflicting aptitudes, both
17984 useful and capricious.
17985 
17986 The one grand stage where he enacted all his various parts so manifold,
17987 was his vice-bench; a long rude ponderous table furnished with several
17988 vices, of different sizes, and both of iron and of wood. At all times
17989 except when whales were alongside, this bench was securely lashed
17990 athwartships against the rear of the Try-works.
17991 
17992 A belaying pin is found too large to be easily inserted into its hole:
17993 the carpenter claps it into one of his ever-ready vices, and
17994 straightway files it smaller. A lost land-bird of strange plumage
17995 strays on board, and is made a captive: out of clean shaved rods of
17996 right-whale bone, and cross-beams of sperm whale ivory, the carpenter
17997 makes a pagoda-looking cage for it. An oarsman sprains his wrist: the
17998 carpenter concocts a soothing lotion. Stubb longed for vermillion stars
17999 to be painted upon the blade of his every oar; screwing each oar in his
18000 big vice of wood, the carpenter symmetrically supplies the
18001 constellation. A sailor takes a fancy to wear shark-bone ear-rings: the
18002 carpenter drills his ears. Another has the toothache: the carpenter out
18003 pincers, and clapping one hand upon his bench bids him be seated there;
18004 but the poor fellow unmanageably winces under the unconcluded
18005 operation; whirling round the handle of his wooden vice, the carpenter
18006 signs him to clap his jaw in that, if he would have him draw the tooth.
18007 
18008 Thus, this carpenter was prepared at all points, and alike indifferent
18009 and without respect in all. Teeth he accounted bits of ivory; heads he
18010 deemed but top-blocks; men themselves he lightly held for capstans. But
18011 while now upon so wide a field thus variously accomplished and with
18012 such liveliness of expertness in him, too; all this would seem to argue
18013 some uncommon vivacity of intelligence. But not precisely so. For
18014 nothing was this man more remarkable, than for a certain impersonal
18015 stolidity as it were; impersonal, I say; for it so shaded off into the
18016 surrounding infinite of things, that it seemed one with the general
18017 stolidity discernible in the whole visible world; which while
18018 pauselessly active in uncounted modes, still eternally holds its peace,
18019 and ignores you, though you dig foundations for cathedrals. Yet was
18020 this half-horrible stolidity in him, involving, too, as it appeared, an
18021 all-ramifying heartlessness;—yet was it oddly dashed at times, with an
18022 old, crutch-like, antediluvian, wheezing humorousness, not unstreaked
18023 now and then with a certain grizzled wittiness; such as might have
18024 served to pass the time during the midnight watch on the bearded
18025 forecastle of Noah’s ark. Was it that this old carpenter had been a
18026 life-long wanderer, whose much rolling, to and fro, not only had
18027 gathered no moss; but what is more, had rubbed off whatever small
18028 outward clingings might have originally pertained to him? He was a
18029 stript abstract; an unfractioned integral; uncompromised as a new-born
18030 babe; living without premeditated reference to this world or the next.
18031 You might almost say, that this strange uncompromisedness in him
18032 involved a sort of unintelligence; for in his numerous trades, he did
18033 not seem to work so much by reason or by instinct, or simply because he
18034 had been tutored to it, or by any intermixture of all these, even or
18035 uneven; but merely by a kind of deaf and dumb, spontaneous literal
18036 process. He was a pure manipulator; his brain, if he had ever had one,
18037 must have early oozed along into the muscles of his fingers. He was
18038 like one of those unreasoning but still highly useful, _multum in
18039 parvo_, Sheffield contrivances, assuming the exterior—though a little
18040 swelled—of a common pocket knife; but containing, not only blades of
18041 various sizes, but also screw-drivers, cork-screws, tweezers, awls,
18042 pens, rulers, nail-filers, countersinkers. So, if his superiors wanted
18043 to use the carpenter for a screw-driver, all they had to do was to open
18044 that part of him, and the screw was fast: or if for tweezers, take him
18045 up by the legs, and there they were.
18046 
18047 Yet, as previously hinted, this omnitooled, open-and-shut carpenter,
18048 was, after all, no mere machine of an automaton. If he did not have a
18049 common soul in him, he had a subtle something that somehow anomalously
18050 did its duty. What that was, whether essence of quicksilver, or a few
18051 drops of hartshorn, there is no telling. But there it was; and there it
18052 had abided for now some sixty years or more. And this it was, this same
18053 unaccountable, cunning life-principle in him; this it was, that kept
18054 him a great part of the time soliloquizing; but only like an
18055 unreasoning wheel, which also hummingly soliloquizes; or rather, his
18056 body was a sentry-box and this soliloquizer on guard there, and talking
18057 all the time to keep himself awake.
18058 
18059 
18060 CHAPTER 108. Ahab and the Carpenter.
18061 
18062 The Deck—First Night Watch.
18063 
18064 (_Carpenter standing before his vice-bench, and by the light of two
18065 lanterns busily filing the ivory joist for the leg, which joist is
18066 firmly fixed in the vice. Slabs of ivory, leather straps, pads, screws,
18067 and various tools of all sorts lying about the bench. Forward, the red
18068 flame of the forge is seen, where the blacksmith is at work._)
18069 
18070 Drat the file, and drat the bone! That is hard which should be soft,
18071 and that is soft which should be hard. So we go, who file old jaws and
18072 shinbones. Let’s try another. Aye, now, this works better (_sneezes_).
18073 Halloa, this bone dust is (_sneezes_)—why it’s (_sneezes_)—yes it’s
18074 (_sneezes_)—bless my soul, it won’t let me speak! This is what an old
18075 fellow gets now for working in dead lumber. Saw a live tree, and you
18076 don’t get this dust; amputate a live bone, and you don’t get it
18077 (_sneezes_). Come, come, you old Smut, there, bear a hand, and let’s
18078 have that ferule and buckle-screw; I’ll be ready for them presently.
18079 Lucky now (_sneezes_) there’s no knee-joint to make; that might puzzle
18080 a little; but a mere shinbone—why it’s easy as making hop-poles; only I
18081 should like to put a good finish on. Time, time; if I but only had the
18082 time, I could turn him out as neat a leg now as ever (_sneezes_)
18083 scraped to a lady in a parlor. Those buckskin legs and calves of legs
18084 I’ve seen in shop windows wouldn’t compare at all. They soak water,
18085 they do; and of course get rheumatic, and have to be doctored
18086 (_sneezes_) with washes and lotions, just like live legs. There; before
18087 I saw it off, now, I must call his old Mogulship, and see whether the
18088 length will be all right; too short, if anything, I guess. Ha! that’s
18089 the heel; we are in luck; here he comes, or it’s somebody else, that’s
18090 certain.
18091 
18092 AHAB (_advancing_). (_During the ensuing scene, the carpenter continues
18093 sneezing at times._)
18094 
18095 Well, manmaker!
18096 
18097 Just in time, sir. If the captain pleases, I will now mark the length.
18098 Let me measure, sir.
18099 
18100 Measured for a leg! good. Well, it’s not the first time. About it!
18101 There; keep thy finger on it. This is a cogent vice thou hast here,
18102 carpenter; let me feel its grip once. So, so; it does pinch some.
18103 
18104 Oh, sir, it will break bones—beware, beware!
18105 
18106 No fear; I like a good grip; I like to feel something in this slippery
18107 world that can hold, man. What’s Prometheus about there?—the
18108 blacksmith, I mean—what’s he about?
18109 
18110 He must be forging the buckle-screw, sir, now.
18111 
18112 Right. It’s a partnership; he supplies the muscle part. He makes a
18113 fierce red flame there!
18114 
18115 Aye, sir; he must have the white heat for this kind of fine work.
18116 
18117 Um-m. So he must. I do deem it now a most meaning thing, that that old
18118 Greek, Prometheus, who made men, they say, should have been a
18119 blacksmith, and animated them with fire; for what’s made in fire must
18120 properly belong to fire; and so hell’s probable. How the soot flies!
18121 This must be the remainder the Greek made the Africans of. Carpenter,
18122 when he’s through with that buckle, tell him to forge a pair of steel
18123 shoulder-blades; there’s a pedlar aboard with a crushing pack.
18124 
18125 Sir?
18126 
18127 Hold; while Prometheus is about it, I’ll order a complete man after a
18128 desirable pattern. Imprimis, fifty feet high in his socks; then, chest
18129 modelled after the Thames Tunnel; then, legs with roots to ’em, to stay
18130 in one place; then, arms three feet through the wrist; no heart at all,
18131 brass forehead, and about a quarter of an acre of fine brains; and let
18132 me see—shall I order eyes to see outwards? No, but put a sky-light on
18133 top of his head to illuminate inwards. There, take the order, and away.
18134 
18135 Now, what’s he speaking about, and who’s he speaking to, I should like
18136 to know? Shall I keep standing here? (_aside_).
18137 
18138 ’Tis but indifferent architecture to make a blind dome; here’s one. No,
18139 no, no; I must have a lantern.
18140 
18141 Ho, ho! That’s it, hey? Here are two, sir; one will serve my turn.
18142 
18143 What art thou thrusting that thief-catcher into my face for, man?
18144 Thrusted light is worse than presented pistols.
18145 
18146 I thought, sir, that you spoke to carpenter.
18147 
18148 Carpenter? why that’s—but no;—a very tidy, and, I may say, an extremely
18149 gentlemanlike sort of business thou art in here, carpenter;—or would’st
18150 thou rather work in clay?
18151 
18152 Sir?—Clay? clay, sir? That’s mud; we leave clay to ditchers, sir.
18153 
18154 The fellow’s impious! What art thou sneezing about?
18155 
18156 Bone is rather dusty, sir.
18157 
18158 Take the hint, then; and when thou art dead, never bury thyself under
18159 living people’s noses.
18160 
18161 Sir?—oh! ah!—I guess so;—yes—oh, dear!
18162 
18163 Look ye, carpenter, I dare say thou callest thyself a right good
18164 workmanlike workman, eh? Well, then, will it speak thoroughly well for
18165 thy work, if, when I come to mount this leg thou makest, I shall
18166 nevertheless feel another leg in the same identical place with it; that
18167 is, carpenter, my old lost leg; the flesh and blood one, I mean. Canst
18168 thou not drive that old Adam away?
18169 
18170 Truly, sir, I begin to understand somewhat now. Yes, I have heard
18171 something curious on that score, sir; how that a dismasted man never
18172 entirely loses the feeling of his old spar, but it will be still
18173 pricking him at times. May I humbly ask if it be really so, sir?
18174 
18175 It is, man. Look, put thy live leg here in the place where mine once
18176 was; so, now, here is only one distinct leg to the eye, yet two to the
18177 soul. Where thou feelest tingling life; there, exactly there, there to
18178 a hair, do I. Is’t a riddle?
18179 
18180 I should humbly call it a poser, sir.
18181 
18182 Hist, then. How dost thou know that some entire, living, thinking thing
18183 may not be invisibly and uninterpenetratingly standing precisely where
18184 thou now standest; aye, and standing there in thy spite? In thy most
18185 solitary hours, then, dost thou not fear eavesdroppers? Hold, don’t
18186 speak! And if I still feel the smart of my crushed leg, though it be
18187 now so long dissolved; then, why mayst not thou, carpenter, feel the
18188 fiery pains of hell for ever, and without a body? Hah!
18189 
18190 Good Lord! Truly, sir, if it comes to that, I must calculate over
18191 again; I think I didn’t carry a small figure, sir.
18192 
18193 Look ye, pudding-heads should never grant premises.—How long before the
18194 leg is done?
18195 
18196 Perhaps an hour, sir.
18197 
18198 Bungle away at it then, and bring it to me (_turns to go_). Oh, Life!
18199 Here I am, proud as Greek god, and yet standing debtor to this
18200 blockhead for a bone to stand on! Cursed be that mortal
18201 inter-indebtedness which will not do away with ledgers. I would be free
18202 as air; and I’m down in the whole world’s books. I am so rich, I could
18203 have given bid for bid with the wealthiest Prætorians at the auction of
18204 the Roman empire (which was the world’s); and yet I owe for the flesh
18205 in the tongue I brag with. By heavens! I’ll get a crucible, and into
18206 it, and dissolve myself down to one small, compendious vertebra. So.
18207 
18208 CARPENTER (_resuming his work_).
18209 
18210 Well, well, well! Stubb knows him best of all, and Stubb always says
18211 he’s queer; says nothing but that one sufficient little word queer;
18212 he’s queer, says Stubb; he’s queer—queer, queer; and keeps dinning it
18213 into Mr. Starbuck all the time—queer—sir—queer, queer, very queer. And
18214 here’s his leg! Yes, now that I think of it, here’s his bedfellow! has
18215 a stick of whale’s jaw-bone for a wife! And this is his leg; he’ll
18216 stand on this. What was that now about one leg standing in three
18217 places, and all three places standing in one hell—how was that? Oh! I
18218 don’t wonder he looked so scornful at me! I’m a sort of
18219 strange-thoughted sometimes, they say; but that’s only haphazard-like.
18220 Then, a short, little old body like me, should never undertake to wade
18221 out into deep waters with tall, heron-built captains; the water chucks
18222 you under the chin pretty quick, and there’s a great cry for
18223 life-boats. And here’s the heron’s leg! long and slim, sure enough!
18224 Now, for most folks one pair of legs lasts a lifetime, and that must be
18225 because they use them mercifully, as a tender-hearted old lady uses her
18226 roly-poly old coach-horses. But Ahab; oh he’s a hard driver. Look,
18227 driven one leg to death, and spavined the other for life, and now wears
18228 out bone legs by the cord. Halloa, there, you Smut! bear a hand there
18229 with those screws, and let’s finish it before the resurrection fellow
18230 comes a-calling with his horn for all legs, true or false, as
18231 brewery-men go round collecting old beer barrels, to fill ’em up again.
18232 What a leg this is! It looks like a real live leg, filed down to
18233 nothing but the core; he’ll be standing on this to-morrow; he’ll be
18234 taking altitudes on it. Halloa! I almost forgot the little oval slate,
18235 smoothed ivory, where he figures up the latitude. So, so; chisel, file,
18236 and sand-paper, now!
18237 
18238 
18239 CHAPTER 109. Ahab and Starbuck in the Cabin.
18240 
18241 According to usage they were pumping the ship next morning; and lo! no
18242 inconsiderable oil came up with the water; the casks below must have
18243 sprung a bad leak. Much concern was shown; and Starbuck went down into
18244 the cabin to report this unfavourable affair.*
18245 
18246 *In Sperm-whalemen with any considerable quantity of oil on board, it
18247 is a regular semi-weekly duty to conduct a hose into the hold, and
18248 drench the casks with sea-water; which afterwards, at varying
18249 intervals, is removed by the ship’s pumps. Hereby the casks are sought
18250 to be kept damply tight; while by the changed character of the
18251 withdrawn water, the mariners readily detect any serious leakage in the
18252 precious cargo.
18253 
18254 Now, from the South and West the Pequod was drawing nigh to Formosa and
18255 the Bashee Isles, between which lies one of the tropical outlets from
18256 the China waters into the Pacific. And so Starbuck found Ahab with a
18257 general chart of the oriental archipelagoes spread before him; and
18258 another separate one representing the long eastern coasts of the
18259 Japanese islands—Niphon, Matsmai, and Sikoke. With his snow-white new
18260 ivory leg braced against the screwed leg of his table, and with a long
18261 pruning-hook of a jack-knife in his hand, the wondrous old man, with
18262 his back to the gangway door, was wrinkling his brow, and tracing his
18263 old courses again.
18264 
18265 “Who’s there?” hearing the footstep at the door, but not turning round
18266 to it. “On deck! Begone!”
18267 
18268 “Captain Ahab mistakes; it is I. The oil in the hold is leaking, sir.
18269 We must up Burtons and break out.”
18270 
18271 “Up Burtons and break out? Now that we are nearing Japan; heave-to here
18272 for a week to tinker a parcel of old hoops?”
18273 
18274 “Either do that, sir, or waste in one day more oil than we may make
18275 good in a year. What we come twenty thousand miles to get is worth
18276 saving, sir.”
18277 
18278 “So it is, so it is; if we get it.”
18279 
18280 “I was speaking of the oil in the hold, sir.”
18281 
18282 “And I was not speaking or thinking of that at all. Begone! Let it
18283 leak! I’m all aleak myself. Aye! leaks in leaks! not only full of leaky
18284 casks, but those leaky casks are in a leaky ship; and that’s a far
18285 worse plight than the Pequod’s, man. Yet I don’t stop to plug my leak;
18286 for who can find it in the deep-loaded hull; or how hope to plug it,
18287 even if found, in this life’s howling gale? Starbuck! I’ll not have the
18288 Burtons hoisted.”
18289 
18290 “What will the owners say, sir?”
18291 
18292 “Let the owners stand on Nantucket beach and outyell the Typhoons. What
18293 cares Ahab? Owners, owners? Thou art always prating to me, Starbuck,
18294 about those miserly owners, as if the owners were my conscience. But
18295 look ye, the only real owner of anything is its commander; and hark ye,
18296 my conscience is in this ship’s keel.—On deck!”
18297 
18298 “Captain Ahab,” said the reddening mate, moving further into the cabin,
18299 with a daring so strangely respectful and cautious that it almost
18300 seemed not only every way seeking to avoid the slightest outward
18301 manifestation of itself, but within also seemed more than half
18302 distrustful of itself; “A better man than I might well pass over in
18303 thee what he would quickly enough resent in a younger man; aye, and in
18304 a happier, Captain Ahab.”
18305 
18306 “Devils! Dost thou then so much as dare to critically think of me?—On
18307 deck!”
18308 
18309 “Nay, sir, not yet; I do entreat. And I do dare, sir—to be forbearing!
18310 Shall we not understand each other better than hitherto, Captain Ahab?”
18311 
18312 Ahab seized a loaded musket from the rack (forming part of most
18313 South-Sea-men’s cabin furniture), and pointing it towards Starbuck,
18314 exclaimed: “There is one God that is Lord over the earth, and one
18315 Captain that is lord over the Pequod.—On deck!”
18316 
18317 For an instant in the flashing eyes of the mate, and his fiery cheeks,
18318 you would have almost thought that he had really received the blaze of
18319 the levelled tube. But, mastering his emotion, he half calmly rose, and
18320 as he quitted the cabin, paused for an instant and said: “Thou hast
18321 outraged, not insulted me, sir; but for that I ask thee not to beware
18322 of Starbuck; thou wouldst but laugh; but let Ahab beware of Ahab;
18323 beware of thyself, old man.”
18324 
18325 “He waxes brave, but nevertheless obeys; most careful bravery that!”
18326 murmured Ahab, as Starbuck disappeared. “What’s that he said—Ahab
18327 beware of Ahab—there’s something there!” Then unconsciously using the
18328 musket for a staff, with an iron brow he paced to and fro in the little
18329 cabin; but presently the thick plaits of his forehead relaxed, and
18330 returning the gun to the rack, he went to the deck.
18331 
18332 “Thou art but too good a fellow, Starbuck,” he said lowly to the mate;
18333 then raising his voice to the crew: “Furl the t’gallant-sails, and
18334 close-reef the top-sails, fore and aft; back the main-yard; up Burton,
18335 and break out in the main-hold.”
18336 
18337 It were perhaps vain to surmise exactly why it was, that as respecting
18338 Starbuck, Ahab thus acted. It may have been a flash of honesty in him;
18339 or mere prudential policy which, under the circumstance, imperiously
18340 forbade the slightest symptom of open disaffection, however transient,
