18341 in the important chief officer of his ship. However it was, his orders
18342 were executed; and the Burtons were hoisted.
18343 
18344 
18345 CHAPTER 110. Queequeg in His Coffin.
18346 
18347 Upon searching, it was found that the casks last struck into the hold
18348 were perfectly sound, and that the leak must be further off. So, it
18349 being calm weather, they broke out deeper and deeper, disturbing the
18350 slumbers of the huge ground-tier butts; and from that black midnight
18351 sending those gigantic moles into the daylight above. So deep did they
18352 go; and so ancient, and corroded, and weedy the aspect of the lowermost
18353 puncheons, that you almost looked next for some mouldy corner-stone
18354 cask containing coins of Captain Noah, with copies of the posted
18355 placards, vainly warning the infatuated old world from the flood.
18356 Tierce after tierce, too, of water, and bread, and beef, and shooks of
18357 staves, and iron bundles of hoops, were hoisted out, till at last the
18358 piled decks were hard to get about; and the hollow hull echoed under
18359 foot, as if you were treading over empty catacombs, and reeled and
18360 rolled in the sea like an air-freighted demijohn. Top-heavy was the
18361 ship as a dinnerless student with all Aristotle in his head. Well was
18362 it that the Typhoons did not visit them then.
18363 
18364 Now, at this time it was that my poor pagan companion, and fast
18365 bosom-friend, Queequeg, was seized with a fever, which brought him nigh
18366 to his endless end.
18367 
18368 Be it said, that in this vocation of whaling, sinecures are unknown;
18369 dignity and danger go hand in hand; till you get to be Captain, the
18370 higher you rise the harder you toil. So with poor Queequeg, who, as
18371 harpooneer, must not only face all the rage of the living whale, but—as
18372 we have elsewhere seen—mount his dead back in a rolling sea; and
18373 finally descend into the gloom of the hold, and bitterly sweating all
18374 day in that subterraneous confinement, resolutely manhandle the
18375 clumsiest casks and see to their stowage. To be short, among whalemen,
18376 the harpooneers are the holders, so called.
18377 
18378 Poor Queequeg! when the ship was about half disembowelled, you should
18379 have stooped over the hatchway, and peered down upon him there; where,
18380 stripped to his woollen drawers, the tattooed savage was crawling about
18381 amid that dampness and slime, like a green spotted lizard at the bottom
18382 of a well. And a well, or an ice-house, it somehow proved to him, poor
18383 pagan; where, strange to say, for all the heat of his sweatings, he
18384 caught a terrible chill which lapsed into a fever; and at last, after
18385 some days’ suffering, laid him in his hammock, close to the very sill
18386 of the door of death. How he wasted and wasted away in those few
18387 long-lingering days, till there seemed but little left of him but his
18388 frame and tattooing. But as all else in him thinned, and his
18389 cheek-bones grew sharper, his eyes, nevertheless, seemed growing fuller
18390 and fuller; they became of a strange softness of lustre; and mildly but
18391 deeply looked out at you there from his sickness, a wondrous testimony
18392 to that immortal health in him which could not die, or be weakened. And
18393 like circles on the water, which, as they grow fainter, expand; so his
18394 eyes seemed rounding and rounding, like the rings of Eternity. An awe
18395 that cannot be named would steal over you as you sat by the side of
18396 this waning savage, and saw as strange things in his face, as any
18397 beheld who were bystanders when Zoroaster died. For whatever is truly
18398 wondrous and fearful in man, never yet was put into words or books. And
18399 the drawing near of Death, which alike levels all, alike impresses all
18400 with a last revelation, which only an author from the dead could
18401 adequately tell. So that—let us say it again—no dying Chaldee or Greek
18402 had higher and holier thoughts than those, whose mysterious shades you
18403 saw creeping over the face of poor Queequeg, as he quietly lay in his
18404 swaying hammock, and the rolling sea seemed gently rocking him to his
18405 final rest, and the ocean’s invisible flood-tide lifted him higher and
18406 higher towards his destined heaven.
18407 
18408 Not a man of the crew but gave him up; and, as for Queequeg himself,
18409 what he thought of his case was forcibly shown by a curious favour he
18410 asked. He called one to him in the grey morning watch, when the day was
18411 just breaking, and taking his hand, said that while in Nantucket he had
18412 chanced to see certain little canoes of dark wood, like the rich
18413 war-wood of his native isle; and upon inquiry, he had learned that all
18414 whalemen who died in Nantucket, were laid in those same dark canoes,
18415 and that the fancy of being so laid had much pleased him; for it was
18416 not unlike the custom of his own race, who, after embalming a dead
18417 warrior, stretched him out in his canoe, and so left him to be floated
18418 away to the starry archipelagoes; for not only do they believe that the
18419 stars are isles, but that far beyond all visible horizons, their own
18420 mild, uncontinented seas, interflow with the blue heavens; and so form
18421 the white breakers of the milky way. He added, that he shuddered at the
18422 thought of being buried in his hammock, according to the usual
18423 sea-custom, tossed like something vile to the death-devouring sharks.
18424 No: he desired a canoe like those of Nantucket, all the more congenial
18425 to him, being a whaleman, that like a whale-boat these coffin-canoes
18426 were without a keel; though that involved but uncertain steering, and
18427 much lee-way adown the dim ages.
18428 
18429 Now, when this strange circumstance was made known aft, the carpenter
18430 was at once commanded to do Queequeg’s bidding, whatever it might
18431 include. There was some heathenish, coffin-coloured old lumber aboard,
18432 which, upon a long previous voyage, had been cut from the aboriginal
18433 groves of the Lackaday islands, and from these dark planks the coffin
18434 was recommended to be made. No sooner was the carpenter apprised of the
18435 order, than taking his rule, he forthwith with all the indifferent
18436 promptitude of his character, proceeded into the forecastle and took
18437 Queequeg’s measure with great accuracy, regularly chalking Queequeg’s
18438 person as he shifted the rule.
18439 
18440 “Ah! poor fellow! he’ll have to die now,” ejaculated the Long Island
18441 sailor.
18442 
18443 Going to his vice-bench, the carpenter for convenience sake and general
18444 reference, now transferringly measured on it the exact length the
18445 coffin was to be, and then made the transfer permanent by cutting two
18446 notches at its extremities. This done, he marshalled the planks and his
18447 tools, and to work.
18448 
18449 When the last nail was driven, and the lid duly planed and fitted, he
18450 lightly shouldered the coffin and went forward with it, inquiring
18451 whether they were ready for it yet in that direction.
18452 
18453 Overhearing the indignant but half-humorous cries with which the people
18454 on deck began to drive the coffin away, Queequeg, to every one’s
18455 consternation, commanded that the thing should be instantly brought to
18456 him, nor was there any denying him; seeing that, of all mortals, some
18457 dying men are the most tyrannical; and certainly, since they will
18458 shortly trouble us so little for evermore, the poor fellows ought to be
18459 indulged.
18460 
18461 Leaning over in his hammock, Queequeg long regarded the coffin with an
18462 attentive eye. He then called for his harpoon, had the wooden stock
18463 drawn from it, and then had the iron part placed in the coffin along
18464 with one of the paddles of his boat. All by his own request, also,
18465 biscuits were then ranged round the sides within: a flask of fresh
18466 water was placed at the head, and a small bag of woody earth scraped up
18467 in the hold at the foot; and a piece of sail-cloth being rolled up for
18468 a pillow, Queequeg now entreated to be lifted into his final bed, that
18469 he might make trial of its comforts, if any it had. He lay without
18470 moving a few minutes, then told one to go to his bag and bring out his
18471 little god, Yojo. Then crossing his arms on his breast with Yojo
18472 between, he called for the coffin lid (hatch he called it) to be placed
18473 over him. The head part turned over with a leather hinge, and there lay
18474 Queequeg in his coffin with little but his composed countenance in
18475 view. “Rarmai” (it will do; it is easy), he murmured at last, and
18476 signed to be replaced in his hammock.
18477 
18478 But ere this was done, Pip, who had been slily hovering near by all
18479 this while, drew nigh to him where he lay, and with soft sobbings, took
18480 him by the hand; in the other, holding his tambourine.
18481 
18482 “Poor rover! will ye never have done with all this weary roving? where
18483 go ye now? But if the currents carry ye to those sweet Antilles where
18484 the beaches are only beat with water-lilies, will ye do one little
18485 errand for me? Seek out one Pip, who’s now been missing long: I think
18486 he’s in those far Antilles. If ye find him, then comfort him; for he
18487 must be very sad; for look! he’s left his tambourine behind;—I found
18488 it. Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! Now, Queequeg, die; and I’ll beat ye your
18489 dying march.”
18490 
18491 “I have heard,” murmured Starbuck, gazing down the scuttle, “that in
18492 violent fevers, men, all ignorance, have talked in ancient tongues; and
18493 that when the mystery is probed, it turns out always that in their
18494 wholly forgotten childhood those ancient tongues had been really spoken
18495 in their hearing by some lofty scholars. So, to my fond faith, poor
18496 Pip, in this strange sweetness of his lunacy, brings heavenly vouchers
18497 of all our heavenly homes. Where learned he that, but there?—Hark! he
18498 speaks again: but more wildly now.”
18499 
18500 “Form two and two! Let’s make a General of him! Ho, where’s his
18501 harpoon? Lay it across here.—Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! huzza! Oh for a game
18502 cock now to sit upon his head and crow! Queequeg dies game!—mind ye
18503 that; Queequeg dies game!—take ye good heed of that; Queequeg dies
18504 game! I say; game, game, game! but base little Pip, he died a coward;
18505 died all a’shiver;—out upon Pip! Hark ye; if ye find Pip, tell all the
18506 Antilles he’s a runaway; a coward, a coward, a coward! Tell them he
18507 jumped from a whale-boat! I’d never beat my tambourine over base Pip,
18508 and hail him General, if he were once more dying here. No, no! shame
18509 upon all cowards—shame upon them! Let ’em go drown like Pip, that
18510 jumped from a whale-boat. Shame! shame!”
18511 
18512 During all this, Queequeg lay with closed eyes, as if in a dream. Pip
18513 was led away, and the sick man was replaced in his hammock.
18514 
18515 But now that he had apparently made every preparation for death; now
18516 that his coffin was proved a good fit, Queequeg suddenly rallied; soon
18517 there seemed no need of the carpenter’s box: and thereupon, when some
18518 expressed their delighted surprise, he, in substance, said, that the
18519 cause of his sudden convalescence was this;—at a critical moment, he
18520 had just recalled a little duty ashore, which he was leaving undone;
18521 and therefore had changed his mind about dying: he could not die yet,
18522 he averred. They asked him, then, whether to live or die was a matter
18523 of his own sovereign will and pleasure. He answered, certainly. In a
18524 word, it was Queequeg’s conceit, that if a man made up his mind to
18525 live, mere sickness could not kill him: nothing but a whale, or a gale,
18526 or some violent, ungovernable, unintelligent destroyer of that sort.
18527 
18528 Now, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and civilized;
18529 that while a sick, civilized man may be six months convalescing,
18530 generally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well again in a day.
18531 So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength; and at length after
18532 sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days (but eating with a
18533 vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet, threw out his arms
18534 and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned a little bit, and then
18535 springing into the head of his hoisted boat, and poising a harpoon,
18536 pronounced himself fit for a fight.
18537 
18538 With a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest; and
18539 emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there.
18540 Many spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of
18541 grotesque figures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was
18542 striving, in his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on
18543 his body. And this tattooing had been the work of a departed prophet
18544 and seer of his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had written
18545 out on his body a complete theory of the heavens and the earth, and a
18546 mystical treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that Queequeg in
18547 his own proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous work in one
18548 volume; but whose mysteries not even himself could read, though his own
18549 live heart beat against them; and these mysteries were therefore
18550 destined in the end to moulder away with the living parchment whereon
18551 they were inscribed, and so be unsolved to the last. And this thought
18552 it must have been which suggested to Ahab that wild exclamation of his,
18553 when one morning turning away from surveying poor Queequeg—“Oh,
18554 devilish tantalization of the gods!”
18555 
18556 
18557 CHAPTER 111. The Pacific.
18558 
18559 When gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great
18560 South Sea; were it not for other things, I could have greeted my dear
18561 Pacific with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my
18562 youth was answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a
18563 thousand leagues of blue.
18564 
18565 There is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea, whose gently
18566 awful stirrings seem to speak of some hidden soul beneath; like those
18567 fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried Evangelist St.
18568 John. And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures, wide-rolling watery
18569 prairies and Potters’ Fields of all four continents, the waves should
18570 rise and fall, and ebb and flow unceasingly; for here, millions of
18571 mixed shades and shadows, drowned dreams, somnambulisms, reveries; all
18572 that we call lives and souls, lie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing
18573 like slumberers in their beds; the ever-rolling waves but made so by
18574 their restlessness.
18575 
18576 To any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld, must
18577 ever after be the sea of his adoption. It rolls the midmost waters of
18578 the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its arms. The same
18579 waves wash the moles of the new-built Californian towns, but yesterday
18580 planted by the recentest race of men, and lave the faded but still
18581 gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than Abraham; while all between
18582 float milky-ways of coral isles, and low-lying, endless, unknown
18583 Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans. Thus this mysterious, divine
18584 Pacific zones the world’s whole bulk about; makes all coasts one bay to
18585 it; seems the tide-beating heart of earth. Lifted by those eternal
18586 swells, you needs must own the seductive god, bowing your head to Pan.
18587 
18588 But few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab’s brain, as standing like an iron
18589 statue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with one
18590 nostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee isles
18591 (in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with the other
18592 consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea; that sea in
18593 which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming. Launched at
18594 length upon these almost final waters, and gliding towards the Japanese
18595 cruising-ground, the old man’s purpose intensified itself. His firm
18596 lips met like the lips of a vice; the Delta of his forehead’s veins
18597 swelled like overladen brooks; in his very sleep, his ringing cry ran
18598 through the vaulted hull, “Stern all! the White Whale spouts thick
18599 blood!”
18600 
18601 
18602 CHAPTER 112. The Blacksmith.
18603 
18604 Availing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned in
18605 these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active pursuits
18606 shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered old
18607 blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again, after
18608 concluding his contributory work for Ahab’s leg, but still retained it
18609 on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast; being now almost
18610 incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers, and bowsmen to do
18611 some little job for them; altering, or repairing, or new shaping their
18612 various weapons and boat furniture. Often he would be surrounded by an
18613 eager circle, all waiting to be served; holding boat-spades,
18614 pike-heads, harpoons, and lances, and jealously watching his every
18615 sooty movement, as he toiled. Nevertheless, this old man’s was a
18616 patient hammer wielded by a patient arm. No murmur, no impatience, no
18617 petulance did come from him. Silent, slow, and solemn; bowing over
18618 still further his chronically broken back, he toiled away, as if toil
18619 were life itself, and the heavy beating of his hammer the heavy beating
18620 of his heart. And so it was.—Most miserable!
18621 
18622 A peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful appearing
18623 yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage excited the
18624 curiosity of the mariners. And to the importunity of their persisted
18625 questionings he had finally given in; and so it came to pass that every
18626 one now knew the shameful story of his wretched fate.
18627 
18628 Belated, and not innocently, one bitter winter’s midnight, on the road
18629 running between two country towns, the blacksmith half-stupidly felt
18630 the deadly numbness stealing over him, and sought refuge in a leaning,
18631 dilapidated barn. The issue was, the loss of the extremities of both
18632 feet. Out of this revelation, part by part, at last came out the four
18633 acts of the gladness, and the one long, and as yet uncatastrophied
18634 fifth act of the grief of his life’s drama.
18635 
18636 He was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly
18637 encountered that thing in sorrow’s technicals called ruin. He had been
18638 an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty to do; owned a house
18639 and garden; embraced a youthful, daughter-like, loving wife, and three
18640 blithe, ruddy children; every Sunday went to a cheerful-looking church,
18641 planted in a grove. But one night, under cover of darkness, and further
18642 concealed in a most cunning disguisement, a desperate burglar slid into
18643 his happy home, and robbed them all of everything. And darker yet to
18644 tell, the blacksmith himself did ignorantly conduct this burglar into
18645 his family’s heart. It was the Bottle Conjuror! Upon the opening of
18646 that fatal cork, forth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home. Now,
18647 for prudent, most wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith’s shop was
18648 in the basement of his dwelling, but with a separate entrance to it; so
18649 that always had the young and loving healthy wife listened with no
18650 unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure, to the stout ringing
18651 of her young-armed old husband’s hammer; whose reverberations, muffled
18652 by passing through the floors and walls, came up to her, not unsweetly,
18653 in her nursery; and so, to stout Labor’s iron lullaby, the blacksmith’s
18654 infants were rocked to slumber.
18655 
18656 Oh, woe on woe! Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely?
18657 Hadst thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin came
18658 upon him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief, and her
18659 orphans a truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in their after
18660 years; and all of them a care-killing competency. But Death plucked
18661 down some virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling daily toil solely
18662 hung the responsibilities of some other family, and left the worse than
18663 useless old man standing, till the hideous rot of life should make him
18664 easier to harvest.
18665 
18666 Why tell the whole? The blows of the basement hammer every day grew
18667 more and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter than the
18668 last; the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes,
18669 glitteringly gazing into the weeping faces of her children; the bellows
18670 fell; the forge choked up with cinders; the house was sold; the mother
18671 dived down into the long church-yard grass; her children twice followed
18672 her thither; and the houseless, familyless old man staggered off a
18673 vagabond in crape; his every woe unreverenced; his grey head a scorn to
18674 flaxen curls!
18675 
18676 Death seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this; but Death
18677 is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried; it is but
18678 the first salutation to the possibilities of the immense Remote, the
18679 Wild, the Watery, the Unshored; therefore, to the death-longing eyes of
18680 such men, who still have left in them some interior compunctions
18681 against suicide, does the all-contributed and all-receptive ocean
18682 alluringly spread forth his whole plain of unimaginable, taking
18683 terrors, and wonderful, new-life adventures; and from the hearts of
18684 infinite Pacifics, the thousand mermaids sing to them—“Come hither,
18685 broken-hearted; here is another life without the guilt of intermediate
18686 death; here are wonders supernatural, without dying for them. Come
18687 hither! bury thyself in a life which, to your now equally abhorred and
18688 abhorring, landed world, is more oblivious than death. Come hither! put
18689 up _thy_ gravestone, too, within the churchyard, and come hither, till
18690 we marry thee!”
18691 
18692 Hearkening to these voices, East and West, by early sunrise, and by
18693 fall of eve, the blacksmith’s soul responded, Aye, I come! And so Perth
18694 went a-whaling.
18695 
18696 
18697 CHAPTER 113. The Forge.
18698 
18699 With matted beard, and swathed in a bristling shark-skin apron, about
18700 mid-day, Perth was standing between his forge and anvil, the latter
18701 placed upon an iron-wood log, with one hand holding a pike-head in the
18702 coals, and with the other at his forge’s lungs, when Captain Ahab came
18703 along, carrying in his hand a small rusty-looking leathern bag. While
18704 yet a little distance from the forge, moody Ahab paused; till at last,
18705 Perth, withdrawing his iron from the fire, began hammering it upon the
18706 anvil—the red mass sending off the sparks in thick hovering flights,
18707 some of which flew close to Ahab.
18708 
18709 “Are these thy Mother Carey’s chickens, Perth? they are always flying
18710 in thy wake; birds of good omen, too, but not to all;—look here, they
18711 burn; but thou—thou liv’st among them without a scorch.”
18712 
18713 “Because I am scorched all over, Captain Ahab,” answered Perth, resting
18714 for a moment on his hammer; “I am past scorching; not easily can’st
18715 thou scorch a scar.”
18716 
18717 “Well, well; no more. Thy shrunk voice sounds too calmly, sanely woeful
18718 to me. In no Paradise myself, I am impatient of all misery in others
18719 that is not mad. Thou should’st go mad, blacksmith; say, why dost thou
18720 not go mad? How can’st thou endure without being mad? Do the heavens
18721 yet hate thee, that thou can’st not go mad?—What wert thou making
18722 there?”
18723 
18724 “Welding an old pike-head, sir; there were seams and dents in it.”
18725 
18726 “And can’st thou make it all smooth again, blacksmith, after such hard
18727 usage as it had?”
18728 
18729 “I think so, sir.”
18730 
18731 “And I suppose thou can’st smoothe almost any seams and dents; never
18732 mind how hard the metal, blacksmith?”
18733 
18734 “Aye, sir, I think I can; all seams and dents but one.”
18735 
18736 “Look ye here, then,” cried Ahab, passionately advancing, and leaning
18737 with both hands on Perth’s shoulders; “look ye here—_here_—can ye
18738 smoothe out a seam like this, blacksmith,” sweeping one hand across his
18739 ribbed brow; “if thou could’st, blacksmith, glad enough would I lay my
18740 head upon thy anvil, and feel thy heaviest hammer between my eyes.
18741 Answer! Can’st thou smoothe this seam?”
18742 
18743 “Oh! that is the one, sir! Said I not all seams and dents but one?”
18744 
18745 “Aye, blacksmith, it is the one; aye, man, it is unsmoothable; for
18746 though thou only see’st it here in my flesh, it has worked down into
18747 the bone of my skull—_that_ is all wrinkles! But, away with child’s
18748 play; no more gaffs and pikes to-day. Look ye here!” jingling the
18749 leathern bag, as if it were full of gold coins. “I, too, want a harpoon
18750 made; one that a thousand yoke of fiends could not part, Perth;
18751 something that will stick in a whale like his own fin-bone. There’s the
18752 stuff,” flinging the pouch upon the anvil. “Look ye, blacksmith, these
18753 are the gathered nail-stubbs of the steel shoes of racing horses.”
18754 
18755 “Horse-shoe stubbs, sir? Why, Captain Ahab, thou hast here, then, the
18756 best and stubbornest stuff we blacksmiths ever work.”
18757 
18758 “I know it, old man; these stubbs will weld together like glue from the
18759 melted bones of murderers. Quick! forge me the harpoon. And forge me
18760 first, twelve rods for its shank; then wind, and twist, and hammer
18761 these twelve together like the yarns and strands of a tow-line. Quick!
18762 I’ll blow the fire.”
18763 
18764 When at last the twelve rods were made, Ahab tried them, one by one, by
18765 spiralling them, with his own hand, round a long, heavy iron bolt. “A
18766 flaw!” rejecting the last one. “Work that over again, Perth.”
18767 
18768 This done, Perth was about to begin welding the twelve into one, when
18769 Ahab stayed his hand, and said he would weld his own iron. As, then,
18770 with regular, gasping hems, he hammered on the anvil, Perth passing to
18771 him the glowing rods, one after the other, and the hard pressed forge
18772 shooting up its intense straight flame, the Parsee passed silently, and
18773 bowing over his head towards the fire, seemed invoking some curse or
18774 some blessing on the toil. But, as Ahab looked up, he slid aside.
18775 
18776 “What’s that bunch of lucifers dodging about there for?” muttered
18777 Stubb, looking on from the forecastle. “That Parsee smells fire like a
18778 fusee; and smells of it himself, like a hot musket’s powder-pan.”
18779 
18780 At last the shank, in one complete rod, received its final heat; and as
18781 Perth, to temper it, plunged it all hissing into the cask of water near
18782 by, the scalding steam shot up into Ahab’s bent face.
18783 
18784 “Would’st thou brand me, Perth?” wincing for a moment with the pain;
18785 “have I been but forging my own branding-iron, then?”
18786 
18787 “Pray God, not that; yet I fear something, Captain Ahab. Is not this
18788 harpoon for the White Whale?”
18789 
18790 “For the white fiend! But now for the barbs; thou must make them
18791 thyself, man. Here are my razors—the best of steel; here, and make the
18792 barbs sharp as the needle-sleet of the Icy Sea.”
18793 
18794 For a moment, the old blacksmith eyed the razors as though he would
18795 fain not use them.
18796 
18797 “Take them, man, I have no need for them; for I now neither shave, sup,
18798 nor pray till—but here—to work!”
18799 
18800 Fashioned at last into an arrowy shape, and welded by Perth to the
18801 shank, the steel soon pointed the end of the iron; and as the
18802 blacksmith was about giving the barbs their final heat, prior to
18803 tempering them, he cried to Ahab to place the water-cask near.
18804 
18805 “No, no—no water for that; I want it of the true death-temper. Ahoy,
18806 there! Tashtego, Queequeg, Daggoo! What say ye, pagans! Will ye give me
18807 as much blood as will cover this barb?” holding it high up. A cluster
18808 of dark nods replied, Yes. Three punctures were made in the heathen
18809 flesh, and the White Whale’s barbs were then tempered.
18810 
18811 “Ego non baptizo te in nomine patris, sed in nomine diaboli!”
18812 deliriously howled Ahab, as the malignant iron scorchingly devoured the
18813 baptismal blood.
18814 
18815 Now, mustering the spare poles from below, and selecting one of
18816 hickory, with the bark still investing it, Ahab fitted the end to the
18817 socket of the iron. A coil of new tow-line was then unwound, and some
18818 fathoms of it taken to the windlass, and stretched to a great tension.
18819 Pressing his foot upon it, till the rope hummed like a harp-string,
18820 then eagerly bending over it, and seeing no strandings, Ahab exclaimed,
18821 “Good! and now for the seizings.”
18822 
18823 At one extremity the rope was unstranded, and the separate spread yarns
18824 were all braided and woven round the socket of the harpoon; the pole
18825 was then driven hard up into the socket; from the lower end the rope
18826 was traced half-way along the pole’s length, and firmly secured so,
18827 with intertwistings of twine. This done, pole, iron, and rope—like the
18828 Three Fates—remained inseparable, and Ahab moodily stalked away with
18829 the weapon; the sound of his ivory leg, and the sound of the hickory
18830 pole, both hollowly ringing along every plank. But ere he entered his
18831 cabin, light, unnatural, half-bantering, yet most piteous sound was
18832 heard. Oh, Pip! thy wretched laugh, thy idle but unresting eye; all thy
18833 strange mummeries not unmeaningly blended with the black tragedy of the
18834 melancholy ship, and mocked it!
18835 
18836 
18837 CHAPTER 114. The Gilder.
18838 
18839 Penetrating further and further into the heart of the Japanese cruising
18840 ground, the Pequod was soon all astir in the fishery. Often, in mild,
18841 pleasant weather, for twelve, fifteen, eighteen, and twenty hours on
18842 the stretch, they were engaged in the boats, steadily pulling, or
18843 sailing, or paddling after the whales, or for an interlude of sixty or
18844 seventy minutes calmly awaiting their uprising; though with but small
18845 success for their pains.
18846 
18847 At such times, under an abated sun; afloat all day upon smooth, slow
18848 heaving swells; seated in his boat, light as a birch canoe; and so
18849 sociably mixing with the soft waves themselves, that like hearth-stone
18850 cats they purr against the gunwale; these are the times of dreamy
18851 quietude, when beholding the tranquil beauty and brilliancy of the
18852 ocean’s skin, one forgets the tiger heart that pants beneath it; and
18853 would not willingly remember, that this velvet paw but conceals a
18854 remorseless fang.
18855 
18856 These are the times, when in his whale-boat the rover softly feels a
18857 certain filial, confident, land-like feeling towards the sea; that he
18858 regards it as so much flowery earth; and the distant ship revealing
18859 only the tops of her masts, seems struggling forward, not through high
18860 rolling waves, but through the tall grass of a rolling prairie: as when
18861 the western emigrants’ horses only show their erected ears, while their
18862 hidden bodies widely wade through the amazing verdure.
18863 
18864 The long-drawn virgin vales; the mild blue hill-sides; as over these
18865 there steals the hush, the hum; you almost swear that play-wearied
18866 children lie sleeping in these solitudes, in some glad May-time, when
18867 the flowers of the woods are plucked. And all this mixes with your most
18868 mystic mood; so that fact and fancy, half-way meeting, interpenetrate,
18869 and form one seamless whole.
18870 
18871 Nor did such soothing scenes, however temporary, fail of at least as
18872 temporary an effect on Ahab. But if these secret golden keys did seem
18873 to open in him his own secret golden treasuries, yet did his breath
18874 upon them prove but tarnishing.
18875 
18876 Oh, grassy glades! oh, ever vernal endless landscapes in the soul; in
18877 ye,—though long parched by the dead drought of the earthy life,—in ye,
18878 men yet may roll, like young horses in new morning clover; and for some
18879 few fleeting moments, feel the cool dew of the life immortal on them.
18880 Would to God these blessed calms would last. But the mingled, mingling
18881 threads of life are woven by warp and woof: calms crossed by storms, a
18882 storm for every calm. There is no steady unretracing progress in this
18883 life; we do not advance through fixed gradations, and at the last one
18884 pause:—through infancy’s unconscious spell, boyhood’s thoughtless
18885 faith, adolescence’ doubt (the common doom), then scepticism, then
18886 disbelief, resting at last in manhood’s pondering repose of If. But
18887 once gone through, we trace the round again; and are infants, boys, and
18888 men, and Ifs eternally. Where lies the final harbor, whence we unmoor
18889 no more? In what rapt ether sails the world, of which the weariest will
18890 never weary? Where is the foundling’s father hidden? Our souls are like
18891 those orphans whose unwedded mothers die in bearing them: the secret of
18892 our paternity lies in their grave, and we must there to learn it.
18893 
18894 And that same day, too, gazing far down from his boat’s side into that
18895 same golden sea, Starbuck lowly murmured:—
18896 
18897 “Loveliness unfathomable, as ever lover saw in his young bride’s
18898 eye!—Tell me not of thy teeth-tiered sharks, and thy kidnapping
18899 cannibal ways. Let faith oust fact; let fancy oust memory; I look deep
18900 down and do believe.”
18901 
18902 And Stubb, fish-like, with sparkling scales, leaped up in that same
18903 golden light:—
18904 
18905 “I am Stubb, and Stubb has his history; but here Stubb takes oaths that
18906 he has always been jolly!”
18907 
18908 
18909 CHAPTER 115. The Pequod Meets The Bachelor.
18910 
18911 And jolly enough were the sights and the sounds that came bearing down
18912 before the wind, some few weeks after Ahab’s harpoon had been welded.
18913 
18914 It was a Nantucket ship, the Bachelor, which had just wedged in her
18915 last cask of oil, and bolted down her bursting hatches; and now, in
18916 glad holiday apparel, was joyously, though somewhat vain-gloriously,
18917 sailing round among the widely-separated ships on the ground, previous
18918 to pointing her prow for home.
18919 
18920 The three men at her mast-head wore long streamers of narrow red
18921 bunting at their hats; from the stern, a whale-boat was suspended,
18922 bottom down; and hanging captive from the bowsprit was seen the long
18923 lower jaw of the last whale they had slain. Signals, ensigns, and jacks
18924 of all colours were flying from her rigging, on every side. Sideways
18925 lashed in each of her three basketed tops were two barrels of sperm;
18926 above which, in her top-mast cross-trees, you saw slender breakers of
18927 the same precious fluid; and nailed to her main truck was a brazen
18928 lamp.
18929 
18930 As was afterwards learned, the Bachelor had met with the most
18931 surprising success; all the more wonderful, for that while cruising in
18932 the same seas numerous other vessels had gone entire months without
18933 securing a single fish. Not only had barrels of beef and bread been
18934 given away to make room for the far more valuable sperm, but additional
18935 supplemental casks had been bartered for, from the ships she had met;
18936 and these were stowed along the deck, and in the captain’s and
18937 officers’ state-rooms. Even the cabin table itself had been knocked
18938 into kindling-wood; and the cabin mess dined off the broad head of an
18939 oil-butt, lashed down to the floor for a centrepiece. In the
18940 forecastle, the sailors had actually caulked and pitched their chests,
18941 and filled them; it was humorously added, that the cook had clapped a
18942 head on his largest boiler, and filled it; that the steward had plugged
18943 his spare coffee-pot and filled it; that the harpooneers had headed the
18944 sockets of their irons and filled them; that indeed everything was
18945 filled with sperm, except the captain’s pantaloons pockets, and those
18946 he reserved to thrust his hands into, in self-complacent testimony of
18947 his entire satisfaction.
18948 
18949 As this glad ship of good luck bore down upon the moody Pequod, the
18950 barbarian sound of enormous drums came from her forecastle; and drawing
18951 still nearer, a crowd of her men were seen standing round her huge
18952 try-pots, which, covered with the parchment-like _poke_ or stomach skin
18953 of the black fish, gave forth a loud roar to every stroke of the
18954 clenched hands of the crew. On the quarter-deck, the mates and
18955 harpooneers were dancing with the olive-hued girls who had eloped with
18956 them from the Polynesian Isles; while suspended in an ornamented boat,
18957 firmly secured aloft between the foremast and mainmast, three Long
18958 Island negroes, with glittering fiddle-bows of whale ivory, were
18959 presiding over the hilarious jig. Meanwhile, others of the ship’s
18960 company were tumultuously busy at the masonry of the try-works, from
18961 which the huge pots had been removed. You would have almost thought
18962 they were pulling down the cursed Bastille, such wild cries they
18963 raised, as the now useless brick and mortar were being hurled into the
18964 sea.
18965 
18966 Lord and master over all this scene, the captain stood erect on the
18967 ship’s elevated quarter-deck, so that the whole rejoicing drama was
18968 full before him, and seemed merely contrived for his own individual
18969 diversion.
18970 
18971 And Ahab, he too was standing on his quarter-deck, shaggy and black,
18972 with a stubborn gloom; and as the two ships crossed each other’s
18973 wakes—one all jubilations for things passed, the other all forebodings
18974 as to things to come—their two captains in themselves impersonated the
18975 whole striking contrast of the scene.
18976 
18977 “Come aboard, come aboard!” cried the gay Bachelor’s commander, lifting
18978 a glass and a bottle in the air.
18979 
18980 “Hast seen the White Whale?” gritted Ahab in reply.
18981 
18982 “No; only heard of him; but don’t believe in him at all,” said the
18983 other good-humoredly. “Come aboard!”
18984 
18985 “Thou art too damned jolly. Sail on. Hast lost any men?”
18986 
18987 “Not enough to speak of—two islanders, that’s all;—but come aboard, old
18988 hearty, come along. I’ll soon take that black from your brow. Come
18989 along, will ye (merry’s the play); a full ship and homeward-bound.”
18990 
18991 “How wondrous familiar is a fool!” muttered Ahab; then aloud, “Thou art
18992 a full ship and homeward bound, thou sayst; well, then, call me an
18993 empty ship, and outward-bound. So go thy ways, and I will mine. Forward
18994 there! Set all sail, and keep her to the wind!”
18995 
18996 And thus, while the one ship went cheerily before the breeze, the other
18997 stubbornly fought against it; and so the two vessels parted; the crew
18998 of the Pequod looking with grave, lingering glances towards the
18999 receding Bachelor; but the Bachelor’s men never heeding their gaze for
19000 the lively revelry they were in. And as Ahab, leaning over the
19001 taffrail, eyed the homeward-bound craft, he took from his pocket a
19002 small vial of sand, and then looking from the ship to the vial, seemed
19003 thereby bringing two remote associations together, for that vial was
19004 filled with Nantucket soundings.
19005 
19006 
19007 CHAPTER 116. The Dying Whale.
19008 
19009 Not seldom in this life, when, on the right side, fortune’s favourites
19010 sail close by us, we, though all adroop before, catch somewhat of the
19011 rushing breeze, and joyfully feel our bagging sails fill out. So seemed
19012 it with the Pequod. For next day after encountering the gay Bachelor,
19013 whales were seen and four were slain; and one of them by Ahab.
19014 
19015 It was far down the afternoon; and when all the spearings of the
19016 crimson fight were done: and floating in the lovely sunset sea and sky,
19017 sun and whale both stilly died together; then, such a sweetness and
19018 such plaintiveness, such inwreathing orisons curled up in that rosy
19019 air, that it almost seemed as if far over from the deep green convent
19020 valleys of the Manilla isles, the Spanish land-breeze, wantonly turned
19021 sailor, had gone to sea, freighted with these vesper hymns.
19022 
19023 Soothed again, but only soothed to deeper gloom, Ahab, who had sterned
19024 off from the whale, sat intently watching his final wanings from the
19025 now tranquil boat. For that strange spectacle observable in all sperm
19026 whales dying—the turning sunwards of the head, and so expiring—that
19027 strange spectacle, beheld of such a placid evening, somehow to Ahab
19028 conveyed a wondrousness unknown before.
19029 
19030 “He turns and turns him to it,—how slowly, but how steadfastly, his
19031 homage-rendering and invoking brow, with his last dying motions. He too
19032 worships fire; most faithful, broad, baronial vassal of the sun!—Oh
19033 that these too-favouring eyes should see these too-favouring sights.
19034 Look! here, far water-locked; beyond all hum of human weal or woe; in
19035 these most candid and impartial seas; where to traditions no rocks
19036 furnish tablets; where for long Chinese ages, the billows have still
19037 rolled on speechless and unspoken to, as stars that shine upon the
19038 Niger’s unknown source; here, too, life dies sunwards full of faith;
19039 but see! no sooner dead, than death whirls round the corpse, and it
19040 heads some other way.
19041 
19042 “Oh, thou dark Hindoo half of nature, who of drowned bones hast builded
19043 thy separate throne somewhere in the heart of these unverdured seas;
19044 thou art an infidel, thou queen, and too truly speakest to me in the
19045 wide-slaughtering Typhoon, and the hushed burial of its after calm. Nor
19046 has this thy whale sunwards turned his dying head, and then gone round
19047 again, without a lesson to me.
19048 
19049 “Oh, trebly hooped and welded hip of power! Oh, high aspiring,
19050 rainbowed jet!—that one strivest, this one jettest all in vain! In
19051 vain, oh whale, dost thou seek intercedings with yon all-quickening
19052 sun, that only calls forth life, but gives it not again. Yet dost thou,
19053 darker half, rock me with a prouder, if a darker faith. All thy
19054 unnamable imminglings float beneath me here; I am buoyed by breaths of
19055 once living things, exhaled as air, but water now.
19056 
19057 “Then hail, for ever hail, O sea, in whose eternal tossings the wild
19058 fowl finds his only rest. Born of earth, yet suckled by the sea; though
19059 hill and valley mothered me, ye billows are my foster-brothers!”
19060 
19061 
19062 CHAPTER 117. The Whale Watch.
19063 
19064 The four whales slain that evening had died wide apart; one, far to
19065 windward; one, less distant, to leeward; one ahead; one astern. These
19066 last three were brought alongside ere nightfall; but the windward one
19067 could not be reached till morning; and the boat that had killed it lay
19068 by its side all night; and that boat was Ahab’s.
19069 
19070 The waif-pole was thrust upright into the dead whale’s spout-hole; and
19071 the lantern hanging from its top, cast a troubled flickering glare upon
19072 the black, glossy back, and far out upon the midnight waves, which
19073 gently chafed the whale’s broad flank, like soft surf upon a beach.
19074 
19075 Ahab and all his boat’s crew seemed asleep but the Parsee; who
19076 crouching in the bow, sat watching the sharks, that spectrally played
19077 round the whale, and tapped the light cedar planks with their tails. A
19078 sound like the moaning in squadrons over Asphaltites of unforgiven
19079 ghosts of Gomorrah, ran shuddering through the air.
19080 
19081 Started from his slumbers, Ahab, face to face, saw the Parsee; and
19082 hooped round by the gloom of the night they seemed the last men in a
19083 flooded world. “I have dreamed it again,” said he.
19084 
19085 “Of the hearses? Have I not said, old man, that neither hearse nor
19086 coffin can be thine?”
19087 
19088 “And who are hearsed that die on the sea?”
19089 
19090 “But I said, old man, that ere thou couldst die on this voyage, two
19091 hearses must verily be seen by thee on the sea; the first not made by
19092 mortal hands; and the visible wood of the last one must be grown in
19093 America.”
19094 
19095 “Aye, aye! a strange sight that, Parsee:—a hearse and its plumes
19096 floating over the ocean with the waves for the pall-bearers. Ha! Such a
19097 sight we shall not soon see.”
19098 
19099 “Believe it or not, thou canst not die till it be seen, old man.”
19100 
19101 “And what was that saying about thyself?”
19102 
19103 “Though it come to the last, I shall still go before thee thy pilot.”
19104 
19105 “And when thou art so gone before—if that ever befall—then ere I can
19106 follow, thou must still appear to me, to pilot me still?—Was it not so?
19107 Well, then, did I believe all ye say, oh my pilot! I have here two
19108 pledges that I shall yet slay Moby Dick and survive it.”
19109 
19110 “Take another pledge, old man,” said the Parsee, as his eyes lighted up
19111 like fire-flies in the gloom—“Hemp only can kill thee.”
19112 
19113 “The gallows, ye mean.—I am immortal then, on land and on sea,” cried
19114 Ahab, with a laugh of derision;—“Immortal on land and on sea!”
19115 
19116 Both were silent again, as one man. The grey dawn came on, and the
19117 slumbering crew arose from the boat’s bottom, and ere noon the dead
19118 whale was brought to the ship.
19119 
19120 
19121 CHAPTER 118. The Quadrant.
19122 
19123 The season for the Line at length drew near; and every day when Ahab,
19124 coming from his cabin, cast his eyes aloft, the vigilant helmsman would
19125 ostentatiously handle his spokes, and the eager mariners quickly run to
19126 the braces, and would stand there with all their eyes centrally fixed
19127 on the nailed doubloon; impatient for the order to point the ship’s
19128 prow for the equator. In good time the order came. It was hard upon
19129 high noon; and Ahab, seated in the bows of his high-hoisted boat, was
19130 about taking his wonted daily observation of the sun to determine his
19131 latitude.
19132 
19133 Now, in that Japanese sea, the days in summer are as freshets of
19134 effulgences. That unblinkingly vivid Japanese sun seems the blazing
19135 focus of the glassy ocean’s immeasurable burning-glass. The sky looks
19136 lacquered; clouds there are none; the horizon floats; and this
19137 nakedness of unrelieved radiance is as the insufferable splendors of
19138 God’s throne. Well that Ahab’s quadrant was furnished with coloured
19139 glasses, through which to take sight of that solar fire. So, swinging
19140 his seated form to the roll of the ship, and with his
19141 astrological-looking instrument placed to his eye, he remained in that
19142 posture for some moments to catch the precise instant when the sun
19143 should gain its precise meridian. Meantime while his whole attention
19144 was absorbed, the Parsee was kneeling beneath him on the ship’s deck,
19145 and with face thrown up like Ahab’s, was eyeing the same sun with him;
19146 only the lids of his eyes half hooded their orbs, and his wild face was
19147 subdued to an earthly passionlessness. At length the desired
19148 observation was taken; and with his pencil upon his ivory leg, Ahab
19149 soon calculated what his latitude must be at that precise instant. Then
19150 falling into a moment’s revery, he again looked up towards the sun and
19151 murmured to himself: “Thou sea-mark! thou high and mighty Pilot! thou
19152 tellest me truly where I _am_—but canst thou cast the least hint where
19153 I _shall_ be? Or canst thou tell where some other thing besides me is
19154 this moment living? Where is Moby Dick? This instant thou must be
19155 eyeing him. These eyes of mine look into the very eye that is even now
19156 beholding him; aye, and into the eye that is even now equally beholding
19157 the objects on the unknown, thither side of thee, thou sun!”
19158 
19159 Then gazing at his quadrant, and handling, one after the other, its
19160 numerous cabalistical contrivances, he pondered again, and muttered:
19161 “Foolish toy! babies’ plaything of haughty Admirals, and Commodores,
19162 and Captains; the world brags of thee, of thy cunning and might; but
19163 what after all canst thou do, but tell the poor, pitiful point, where
19164 thou thyself happenest to be on this wide planet, and the hand that
19165 holds thee: no! not one jot more! Thou canst not tell where one drop of
19166 water or one grain of sand will be to-morrow noon; and yet with thy
19167 impotence thou insultest the sun! Science! Curse thee, thou vain toy;
19168 and cursed be all the things that cast man’s eyes aloft to that heaven,
19169 whose live vividness but scorches him, as these old eyes are even now
19170 scorched with thy light, O sun! Level by nature to this earth’s horizon
19171 are the glances of man’s eyes; not shot from the crown of his head, as
19172 if God had meant him to gaze on his firmament. Curse thee, thou
19173 quadrant!” dashing it to the deck, “no longer will I guide my earthly
19174 way by thee; the level ship’s compass, and the level dead-reckoning, by
19175 log and by line; _these_ shall conduct me, and show me my place on the
19176 sea. Aye,” lighting from the boat to the deck, “thus I trample on thee,
19177 thou paltry thing that feebly pointest on high; thus I split and
19178 destroy thee!”
19179 
19180 As the frantic old man thus spoke and thus trampled with his live and
19181 dead feet, a sneering triumph that seemed meant for Ahab, and a
19182 fatalistic despair that seemed meant for himself—these passed over the
19183 mute, motionless Parsee’s face. Unobserved he rose and glided away;
19184 while, awestruck by the aspect of their commander, the seamen clustered
19185 together on the forecastle, till Ahab, troubledly pacing the deck,
19186 shouted out—“To the braces! Up helm!—square in!”
19187 
19188 In an instant the yards swung round; and as the ship half-wheeled upon
19189 her heel, her three firm-seated graceful masts erectly poised upon her
19190 long, ribbed hull, seemed as the three Horatii pirouetting on one
19191 sufficient steed.
19192 
19193 Standing between the knight-heads, Starbuck watched the Pequod’s
19194 tumultuous way, and Ahab’s also, as he went lurching along the deck.
19195 
19196 “I have sat before the dense coal fire and watched it all aglow, full
19197 of its tormented flaming life; and I have seen it wane at last, down,
19198 down, to dumbest dust. Old man of oceans! of all this fiery life of
19199 thine, what will at length remain but one little heap of ashes!”
19200 
19201 “Aye,” cried Stubb, “but sea-coal ashes—mind ye that, Mr.
19202 Starbuck—sea-coal, not your common charcoal. Well, well; I heard Ahab
19203 mutter, ‘Here some one thrusts these cards into these old hands of
19204 mine; swears that I must play them, and no others.’ And damn me, Ahab,
19205 but thou actest right; live in the game, and die in it!”
19206 
19207 
19208 CHAPTER 119. The Candles.
19209 
19210 Warmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the tiger of Bengal
19211 crouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure. Skies the most
19212 effulgent but basket the deadliest thunders: gorgeous Cuba knows
19213 tornadoes that never swept tame northern lands. So, too, it is, that in
19214 these resplendent Japanese seas the mariner encounters the direst of
19215 all storms, the Typhoon. It will sometimes burst from out that
19216 cloudless sky, like an exploding bomb upon a dazed and sleepy town.
19217 
19218 Towards evening of that day, the Pequod was torn of her canvas, and
19219 bare-poled was left to fight a Typhoon which had struck her directly
19220 ahead. When darkness came on, sky and sea roared and split with the
19221 thunder, and blazed with the lightning, that showed the disabled masts
19222 fluttering here and there with the rags which the first fury of the
19223 tempest had left for its after sport.
19224 
19225 Holding by a shroud, Starbuck was standing on the quarter-deck; at
19226 every flash of the lightning glancing aloft, to see what additional
19227 disaster might have befallen the intricate hamper there; while Stubb
19228 and Flask were directing the men in the higher hoisting and firmer
19229 lashing of the boats. But all their pains seemed naught. Though lifted
19230 to the very top of the cranes, the windward quarter boat (Ahab’s) did
19231 not escape. A great rolling sea, dashing high up against the reeling
19232 ship’s high teetering side, stove in the boat’s bottom at the stern,
19233 and left it again, all dripping through like a sieve.
19234 
19235 “Bad work, bad work! Mr. Starbuck,” said Stubb, regarding the wreck,
19236 “but the sea will have its way. Stubb, for one, can’t fight it. You
19237 see, Mr. Starbuck, a wave has such a great long start before it leaps,
19238 all round the world it runs, and then comes the spring! But as for me,
19239 all the start I have to meet it, is just across the deck here. But
19240 never mind; it’s all in fun: so the old song says;”—(_sings_.)
19241 
19242 
19243   Oh! jolly is the gale, And a joker is the whale, A’ flourishin’ his
19244   tail,— Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad, is the
19245   Ocean, oh!
19246 
19247   The scud all a flyin’, That’s his flip only foamin’; When he stirs in
19248   the spicin’,— Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad,
19249   is the Ocean, oh!
19250 
19251   Thunder splits the ships, But he only smacks his lips, A tastin’ of
19252   this flip,— Such a funny, sporty, gamy, jesty, joky, hoky-poky lad,
19253   is the Ocean, oh!
19254 
19255 
19256 
19257 “Avast Stubb,” cried Starbuck, “let the Typhoon sing, and strike his
19258 harp here in our rigging; but if thou art a brave man thou wilt hold
19259 thy peace.”
19260 
19261 “But I am not a brave man; never said I was a brave man; I am a coward;
19262 and I sing to keep up my spirits. And I tell you what it is, Mr.
19263 Starbuck, there’s no way to stop my singing in this world but to cut my
19264 throat. And when that’s done, ten to one I sing ye the doxology for a
19265 wind-up.”
19266 
19267 “Madman! look through my eyes if thou hast none of thine own.”
19268 
19269 “What! how can you see better of a dark night than anybody else, never
19270 mind how foolish?”
19271 
19272 “Here!” cried Starbuck, seizing Stubb by the shoulder, and pointing his
19273 hand towards the weather bow, “markest thou not that the gale comes
19274 from the eastward, the very course Ahab is to run for Moby Dick? the
19275 very course he swung to this day noon? now mark his boat there; where
19276 is that stove? In the stern-sheets, man; where he is wont to stand—his
19277 stand-point is stove, man! Now jump overboard, and sing away, if thou
19278 must!
19279 
19280 “I don’t half understand ye: what’s in the wind?”
19281 
19282 “Yes, yes, round the Cape of Good Hope is the shortest way to
19283 Nantucket,” soliloquized Starbuck suddenly, heedless of Stubb’s
19284 question. “The gale that now hammers at us to stave us, we can turn it
19285 into a fair wind that will drive us towards home. Yonder, to windward,
19286 all is blackness of doom; but to leeward, homeward—I see it lightens up
19287 there; but not with the lightning.”
19288 
19289 At that moment in one of the intervals of profound darkness, following
19290 the flashes, a voice was heard at his side; and almost at the same
19291 instant a volley of thunder peals rolled overhead.
19292 
19293 “Who’s there?”
19294 
19295 “Old Thunder!” said Ahab, groping his way along the bulwarks to his
19296 pivot-hole; but suddenly finding his path made plain to him by elbowed
19297 lances of fire.
19298 
19299 Now, as the lightning rod to a spire on shore is intended to carry off
19300 the perilous fluid into the soil; so the kindred rod which at sea some
19301 ships carry to each mast, is intended to conduct it into the water. But
19302 as this conductor must descend to considerable depth, that its end may
19303 avoid all contact with the hull; and as moreover, if kept constantly
19304 towing there, it would be liable to many mishaps, besides interfering
19305 not a little with some of the rigging, and more or less impeding the
19306 vessel’s way in the water; because of all this, the lower parts of a
19307 ship’s lightning-rods are not always overboard; but are generally made
19308 in long slender links, so as to be the more readily hauled up into the
19309 chains outside, or thrown down into the sea, as occasion may require.
19310 
19311 “The rods! the rods!” cried Starbuck to the crew, suddenly admonished
19312 to vigilance by the vivid lightning that had just been darting
19313 flambeaux, to light Ahab to his post. “Are they overboard? drop them
19314 over, fore and aft. Quick!”
19315 
19316 “Avast!” cried Ahab; “let’s have fair play here, though we be the
19317 weaker side. Yet I’ll contribute to raise rods on the Himmalehs and
19318 Andes, that all the world may be secured; but out on privileges! Let
19319 them be, sir.”
19320 
19321 “Look aloft!” cried Starbuck. “The corpusants! the corpusants!”
19322 
19323 All the yard-arms were tipped with a pallid fire; and touched at each
19324 tri-pointed lightning-rod-end with three tapering white flames, each of
19325 the three tall masts was silently burning in that sulphurous air, like
19326 three gigantic wax tapers before an altar.
19327 
19328 “Blast the boat! let it go!” cried Stubb at this instant, as a swashing
19329 sea heaved up under his own little craft, so that its gunwale violently
19330 jammed his hand, as he was passing a lashing. “Blast it!”—but slipping
19331 backward on the deck, his uplifted eyes caught the flames; and
19332 immediately shifting his tone he cried—“The corpusants have mercy on us
19333 all!”
19334 
19335 To sailors, oaths are household words; they will swear in the trance of
19336 the calm, and in the teeth of the tempest; they will imprecate curses
19337 from the topsail-yard-arms, when most they teeter over to a seething
19338 sea; but in all my voyagings, seldom have I heard a common oath when
19339 God’s burning finger has been laid on the ship; when His “Mene, Mene,
19340 Tekel Upharsin” has been woven into the shrouds and the cordage.
19341 
19342 While this pallidness was burning aloft, few words were heard from the
19343 enchanted crew; who in one thick cluster stood on the forecastle, all
19344 their eyes gleaming in that pale phosphorescence, like a far away
19345 constellation of stars. Relieved against the ghostly light, the
19346 gigantic jet negro, Daggoo, loomed up to thrice his real stature, and
19347 seemed the black cloud from which the thunder had come. The parted
19348 mouth of Tashtego revealed his shark-white teeth, which strangely
19349 gleamed as if they too had been tipped by corpusants; while lit up by
19350 the preternatural light, Queequeg’s tattooing burned like Satanic blue
19351 flames on his body.
19352 
19353 The tableau all waned at last with the pallidness aloft; and once more
19354 the Pequod and every soul on her decks were wrapped in a pall. A moment
19355 or two passed, when Starbuck, going forward, pushed against some one.
19356 It was Stubb. “What thinkest thou now, man; I heard thy cry; it was not
19357 the same in the song.”
19358 
19359 “No, no, it wasn’t; I said the corpusants have mercy on us all; and I
19360 hope they will, still. But do they only have mercy on long faces?—have
19361 they no bowels for a laugh? And look ye, Mr. Starbuck—but it’s too dark
19362 to look. Hear me, then: I take that mast-head flame we saw for a sign
19363 of good luck; for those masts are rooted in a hold that is going to be
19364 chock a’ block with sperm-oil, d’ye see; and so, all that sperm will
19365 work up into the masts, like sap in a tree. Yes, our three masts will
19366 yet be as three spermaceti candles—that’s the good promise we saw.”
19367 
19368 At that moment Starbuck caught sight of Stubb’s face slowly beginning
19369 to glimmer into sight. Glancing upwards, he cried: “See! see!” and once
19370 more the high tapering flames were beheld with what seemed redoubled
19371 supernaturalness in their pallor.
19372 
19373 “The corpusants have mercy on us all,” cried Stubb, again.
19374 
19375 At the base of the mainmast, full beneath the doubloon and the flame,
19376 the Parsee was kneeling in Ahab’s front, but with his head bowed away
19377 from him; while near by, from the arched and overhanging rigging, where
19378 they had just been engaged securing a spar, a number of the seamen,
19379 arrested by the glare, now cohered together, and hung pendulous, like a
19380 knot of numbed wasps from a drooping, orchard twig. In various
19381 enchanted attitudes, like the standing, or stepping, or running
19382 skeletons in Herculaneum, others remained rooted to the deck; but all
19383 their eyes upcast.
19384 
19385 “Aye, aye, men!” cried Ahab. “Look up at it; mark it well; the white
19386 flame but lights the way to the White Whale! Hand me those mainmast
19387 links there; I would fain feel this pulse, and let mine beat against
19388 it; blood against fire! So.”
19389 
19390 Then turning—the last link held fast in his left hand, he put his foot
19391 upon the Parsee; and with fixed upward eye, and high-flung right arm,
19392 he stood erect before the lofty tri-pointed trinity of flames.
19393 
19394 “Oh! thou clear spirit of clear fire, whom on these seas I as Persian
19395 once did worship, till in the sacramental act so burned by thee, that
19396 to this hour I bear the scar; I now know thee, thou clear spirit, and I
19397 now know that thy right worship is defiance. To neither love nor
19398 reverence wilt thou be kind; and e’en for hate thou canst but kill; and
19399 all are killed. No fearless fool now fronts thee. I own thy speechless,
19400 placeless power; but to the last gasp of my earthquake life will
19401 dispute its unconditional, unintegral mastery in me. In the midst of
19402 the personified impersonal, a personality stands here. Though but a
19403 point at best; whencesoe’er I came; wheresoe’er I go; yet while I
19404 earthly live, the queenly personality lives in me, and feels her royal
19405 rights. But war is pain, and hate is woe. Come in thy lowest form of
19406 love, and I will kneel and kiss thee; but at thy highest, come as mere
19407 supernal power; and though thou launchest navies of full-freighted
19408 worlds, there’s that in here that still remains indifferent. Oh, thou
19409 clear spirit, of thy fire thou madest me, and like a true child of
19410 fire, I breathe it back to thee.”
19411 
19412 [_Sudden, repeated flashes of lightning; the nine flames leap
19413 lengthwise to thrice their previous height; Ahab, with the rest, closes
19414 his eyes, his right hand pressed hard upon them._]
19415 
19416 “I own thy speechless, placeless power; said I not so? Nor was it wrung
19417 from me; nor do I now drop these links. Thou canst blind; but I can
19418 then grope. Thou canst consume; but I can then be ashes. Take the
19419 homage of these poor eyes, and shutter-hands. I would not take it. The
19420 lightning flashes through my skull; mine eye-balls ache and ache; my
19421 whole beaten brain seems as beheaded, and rolling on some stunning
19422 ground. Oh, oh! Yet blindfold, yet will I talk to thee. Light though
19423 thou be, thou leapest out of darkness; but I am darkness leaping out of
19424 light, leaping out of thee! The javelins cease; open eyes; see, or not?
19425 There burn the flames! Oh, thou magnanimous! now I do glory in my
19426 genealogy. But thou art but my fiery father; my sweet mother, I know
19427 not. Oh, cruel! what hast thou done with her? There lies my puzzle; but
19428 thine is greater. Thou knowest not how came ye, hence callest thyself
19429 unbegotten; certainly knowest not thy beginning, hence callest thyself
19430 unbegun. I know that of me, which thou knowest not of thyself, oh, thou
19431 omnipotent. There is some unsuffusing thing beyond thee, thou clear
19432 spirit, to whom all thy eternity is but time, all thy creativeness
19433 mechanical. Through thee, thy flaming self, my scorched eyes do dimly
19434 see it. Oh, thou foundling fire, thou hermit immemorial, thou too hast
19435 thy incommunicable riddle, thy unparticipated grief. Here again with
19436 haughty agony, I read my sire. Leap! leap up, and lick the sky! I leap
19437 with thee; I burn with thee; would fain be welded with thee; defyingly
19438 I worship thee!”
19439 
19440 “The boat! the boat!” cried Starbuck, “look at thy boat, old man!”
19441 
19442 Ahab’s harpoon, the one forged at Perth’s fire, remained firmly lashed
19443 in its conspicuous crotch, so that it projected beyond his whale-boat’s
19444 bow; but the sea that had stove its bottom had caused the loose leather
19445 sheath to drop off; and from the keen steel barb there now came a
19446 levelled flame of pale, forked fire. As the silent harpoon burned there
19447 like a serpent’s tongue, Starbuck grasped Ahab by the arm—“God, God is
19448 against thee, old man; forbear! ’tis an ill voyage! ill begun, ill
19449 continued; let me square the yards, while we may, old man, and make a
19450 fair wind of it homewards, to go on a better voyage than this.”
19451 
19452 Overhearing Starbuck, the panic-stricken crew instantly ran to the
19453 braces—though not a sail was left aloft. For the moment all the aghast
19454 mate’s thoughts seemed theirs; they raised a half mutinous cry. But
19455 dashing the rattling lightning links to the deck, and snatching the
19456 burning harpoon, Ahab waved it like a torch among them; swearing to
19457 transfix with it the first sailor that but cast loose a rope’s end.
19458 Petrified by his aspect, and still more shrinking from the fiery dart
19459 that he held, the men fell back in dismay, and Ahab again spoke:—
19460 
19461 “All your oaths to hunt the White Whale are as binding as mine; and
19462 heart, soul, and body, lungs and life, old Ahab is bound. And that ye
19463 may know to what tune this heart beats; look ye here; thus I blow out
19464 the last fear!” And with one blast of his breath he extinguished the
19465 flame.
19466 
19467 As in the hurricane that sweeps the plain, men fly the neighborhood of
19468 some lone, gigantic elm, whose very height and strength but render it
19469 so much the more unsafe, because so much the more a mark for
19470 thunderbolts; so at those last words of Ahab’s many of the mariners did
19471 run from him in a terror of dismay.
19472 
19473 
19474 CHAPTER 120. The Deck Towards the End of the First Night Watch.
19475 
19476 _Ahab standing by the helm. Starbuck approaching him._
19477 
19478 “We must send down the main-top-sail yard, sir. The band is working
19479 loose and the lee lift is half-stranded. Shall I strike it, sir?”
19480 
19481 “Strike nothing; lash it. If I had sky-sail poles, I’d sway them up
19482 now.”
19483 
19484 “Sir!—in God’s name!—sir?”
19485 
19486 “Well.”
19487 
19488 “The anchors are working, sir. Shall I get them inboard?”
19489 
19490 “Strike nothing, and stir nothing, but lash everything. The wind rises,
19491 but it has not got up to my table-lands yet. Quick, and see to it.—By
19492 masts and keels! he takes me for the hunch-backed skipper of some
19493 coasting smack. Send down my main-top-sail yard! Ho, gluepots! Loftiest
19494 trucks were made for wildest winds, and this brain-truck of mine now
19495 sails amid the cloud-scud. Shall I strike that? Oh, none but cowards
19496 send down their brain-trucks in tempest time. What a hooroosh aloft
19497 there! I would e’en take it for sublime, did I not know that the colic
19498 is a noisy malady. Oh, take medicine, take medicine!”
19499 
19500 
19501 CHAPTER 121. Midnight.—The Forecastle Bulwarks.
19502 
19503 _Stubb and Flask mounted on them, and passing additional lashings over
19504 the anchors there hanging._
19505 
19506 “No, Stubb; you may pound that knot there as much as you please, but
19507 you will never pound into me what you were just now saying. And how
19508 long ago is it since you said the very contrary? Didn’t you once say
19509 that whatever ship Ahab sails in, that ship should pay something extra
19510 on its insurance policy, just as though it were loaded with powder
19511 barrels aft and boxes of lucifers forward? Stop, now; didn’t you say
19512 so?”
19513 
19514 “Well, suppose I did? What then? I’ve part changed my flesh since that
19515 time, why not my mind? Besides, supposing we _are_ loaded with powder
19516 barrels aft and lucifers forward; how the devil could the lucifers get
19517 afire in this drenching spray here? Why, my little man, you have pretty
19518 red hair, but you couldn’t get afire now. Shake yourself; you’re
19519 Aquarius, or the water-bearer, Flask; might fill pitchers at your coat
19520 collar. Don’t you see, then, that for these extra risks the Marine
19521 Insurance companies have extra guarantees? Here are hydrants, Flask.
19522 But hark, again, and I’ll answer ye the other thing. First take your
19523 leg off from the crown of the anchor here, though, so I can pass the
19524 rope; now listen. What’s the mighty difference between holding a mast’s
19525 lightning-rod in the storm, and standing close by a mast that hasn’t
19526 got any lightning-rod at all in a storm? Don’t you see, you
19527 timber-head, that no harm can come to the holder of the rod, unless the
19528 mast is first struck? What are you talking about, then? Not one ship in
19529 a hundred carries rods, and Ahab,—aye, man, and all of us,—were in no
19530 more danger then, in my poor opinion, than all the crews in ten
19531 thousand ships now sailing the seas. Why, you King-Post, you, I suppose
19532 you would have every man in the world go about with a small
19533 lightning-rod running up the corner of his hat, like a militia
19534 officer’s skewered feather, and trailing behind like his sash. Why
19535 don’t ye be sensible, Flask? it’s easy to be sensible; why don’t ye,
19536 then? any man with half an eye can be sensible.”
19537 
19538 “I don’t know that, Stubb. You sometimes find it rather hard.”
19539 
19540 “Yes, when a fellow’s soaked through, it’s hard to be sensible, that’s
19541 a fact. And I am about drenched with this spray. Never mind; catch the
19542 turn there, and pass it. Seems to me we are lashing down these anchors
19543 now as if they were never going to be used again. Tying these two
19544 anchors here, Flask, seems like tying a man’s hands behind him. And
19545 what big generous hands they are, to be sure. These are your iron
19546 fists, hey? What a hold they have, too! I wonder, Flask, whether the
19547 world is anchored anywhere; if she is, she swings with an uncommon long
19548 cable, though. There, hammer that knot down, and we’ve done. So; next
19549 to touching land, lighting on deck is the most satisfactory. I say,
19550 just wring out my jacket skirts, will ye? Thank ye. They laugh at
19551 long-togs so, Flask; but seems to me, a long tailed coat ought always
19552 to be worn in all storms afloat. The tails tapering down that way,
19553 serve to carry off the water, d’ye see. Same with cocked hats; the
19554 cocks form gable-end eave-troughs, Flask. No more monkey-jackets and
19555 tarpaulins for me; I must mount a swallow-tail, and drive down a
19556 beaver; so. Halloa! whew! there goes my tarpaulin overboard; Lord,
19557 Lord, that the winds that come from heaven should be so unmannerly!
19558 This is a nasty night, lad.”
19559 
19560 
19561 CHAPTER 122. Midnight Aloft.—Thunder and Lightning.
19562 
19563 _The main-top-sail yard_.—_Tashtego passing new lashings around it_.
19564 
19565 “Um, um, um. Stop that thunder! Plenty too much thunder up here. What’s
19566 the use of thunder? Um, um, um. We don’t want thunder; we want rum;
19567 give us a glass of rum. Um, um, um!”
