19569 
19570 CHAPTER 123. The Musket.
19571 
19572 During the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the man at the Pequod’s
19573 jaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to the deck by
19574 its spasmodic motions, even though preventer tackles had been attached
19575 to it—for they were slack—because some play to the tiller was
19576 indispensable.
19577 
19578 In a severe gale like this, while the ship is but a tossed shuttlecock
19579 to the blast, it is by no means uncommon to see the needles in the
19580 compasses, at intervals, go round and round. It was thus with the
19581 Pequod’s; at almost every shock the helmsman had not failed to notice
19582 the whirling velocity with which they revolved upon the cards; it is a
19583 sight that hardly anyone can behold without some sort of unwonted
19584 emotion.
19585 
19586 Some hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through the
19587 strenuous exertions of Starbuck and Stubb—one engaged forward and the
19588 other aft—the shivered remnants of the jib and fore and main-top-sails
19589 were cut adrift from the spars, and went eddying away to leeward, like
19590 the feathers of an albatross, which sometimes are cast to the winds
19591 when that storm-tossed bird is on the wing.
19592 
19593 The three corresponding new sails were now bent and reefed, and a
19594 storm-trysail was set further aft; so that the ship soon went through
19595 the water with some precision again; and the course—for the present,
19596 East-south-east—which he was to steer, if practicable, was once more
19597 given to the helmsman. For during the violence of the gale, he had only
19598 steered according to its vicissitudes. But as he was now bringing the
19599 ship as near her course as possible, watching the compass meanwhile,
19600 lo! a good sign! the wind seemed coming round astern; aye, the foul
19601 breeze became fair!
19602 
19603 Instantly the yards were squared, to the lively song of “_Ho! the fair
19604 wind! oh-ye-ho, cheerly men!_” the crew singing for joy, that so
19605 promising an event should so soon have falsified the evil portents
19606 preceding it.
19607 
19608 In compliance with the standing order of his commander—to report
19609 immediately, and at any one of the twenty-four hours, any decided
19610 change in the affairs of the deck,—Starbuck had no sooner trimmed the
19611 yards to the breeze—however reluctantly and gloomily,—than he
19612 mechanically went below to apprise Captain Ahab of the circumstance.
19613 
19614 Ere knocking at his state-room, he involuntarily paused before it a
19615 moment. The cabin lamp—taking long swings this way and that—was burning
19616 fitfully, and casting fitful shadows upon the old man’s bolted door,—a
19617 thin one, with fixed blinds inserted, in place of upper panels. The
19618 isolated subterraneousness of the cabin made a certain humming silence
19619 to reign there, though it was hooped round by all the roar of the
19620 elements. The loaded muskets in the rack were shiningly revealed, as
19621 they stood upright against the forward bulkhead. Starbuck was an
19622 honest, upright man; but out of Starbuck’s heart, at that instant when
19623 he saw the muskets, there strangely evolved an evil thought; but so
19624 blent with its neutral or good accompaniments that for the instant he
19625 hardly knew it for itself.
19626 
19627 “He would have shot me once,” he murmured, “yes, there’s the very
19628 musket that he pointed at me;—that one with the studded stock; let me
19629 touch it—lift it. Strange, that I, who have handled so many deadly
19630 lances, strange, that I should shake so now. Loaded? I must see. Aye,
19631 aye; and powder in the pan;—that’s not good. Best spill it?—wait. I’ll
19632 cure myself of this. I’ll hold the musket boldly while I think.—I come
19633 to report a fair wind to him. But how fair? Fair for death and
19634 doom,—_that’s_ fair for Moby Dick. It’s a fair wind that’s only fair
19635 for that accursed fish.—The very tube he pointed at me!—the very one;
19636 _this_ one—I hold it here; he would have killed me with the very thing
19637 I handle now.—Aye and he would fain kill all his crew. Does he not say
19638 he will not strike his spars to any gale? Has he not dashed his
19639 heavenly quadrant? and in these same perilous seas, gropes he not his
19640 way by mere dead reckoning of the error-abounding log? and in this very
19641 Typhoon, did he not swear that he would have no lightning-rods? But
19642 shall this crazed old man be tamely suffered to drag a whole ship’s
19643 company down to doom with him?—Yes, it would make him the wilful
19644 murderer of thirty men and more, if this ship come to any deadly harm;
19645 and come to deadly harm, my soul swears this ship will, if Ahab have
19646 his way. If, then, he were this instant—put aside, that crime would not
19647 be his. Ha! is he muttering in his sleep? Yes, just there,—in there,
19648 he’s sleeping. Sleeping? aye, but still alive, and soon awake again. I
19649 can’t withstand thee, then, old man. Not reasoning; not remonstrance;
19650 not entreaty wilt thou hearken to; all this thou scornest. Flat
19651 obedience to thy own flat commands, this is all thou breathest. Aye,
19652 and say’st the men have vow’d thy vow; say’st all of us are Ahabs.
19653 Great God forbid!—But is there no other way? no lawful way?—Make him a
19654 prisoner to be taken home? What! hope to wrest this old man’s living
19655 power from his own living hands? Only a fool would try it. Say he were
19656 pinioned even; knotted all over with ropes and hawsers; chained down to
19657 ring-bolts on this cabin floor; he would be more hideous than a caged
19658 tiger, then. I could not endure the sight; could not possibly fly his
19659 howlings; all comfort, sleep itself, inestimable reason would leave me
19660 on the long intolerable voyage. What, then, remains? The land is
19661 hundreds of leagues away, and locked Japan the nearest. I stand alone
19662 here upon an open sea, with two oceans and a whole continent between me
19663 and law.—Aye, aye, ’tis so.—Is heaven a murderer when its lightning
19664 strikes a would-be murderer in his bed, tindering sheets and skin
19665 together?—And would I be a murderer, then, if”—and slowly, stealthily,
19666 and half sideways looking, he placed the loaded musket’s end against
19667 the door.
19668 
19669 “On this level, Ahab’s hammock swings within; his head this way. A
19670 touch, and Starbuck may survive to hug his wife and child again.—Oh
19671 Mary! Mary!—boy! boy! boy!—But if I wake thee not to death, old man,
19672 who can tell to what unsounded deeps Starbuck’s body this day week may
19673 sink, with all the crew! Great God, where art Thou? Shall I? shall
19674 I?—The wind has gone down and shifted, sir; the fore and main topsails
19675 are reefed and set; she heads her course.”
19676 
19677 “Stern all! Oh Moby Dick, I clutch thy heart at last!”
19678 
19679 Such were the sounds that now came hurtling from out the old man’s
19680 tormented sleep, as if Starbuck’s voice had caused the long dumb dream
19681 to speak.
19682 
19683 The yet levelled musket shook like a drunkard’s arm against the panel;
19684 Starbuck seemed wrestling with an angel; but turning from the door, he
19685 placed the death-tube in its rack, and left the place.
19686 
19687 “He’s too sound asleep, Mr. Stubb; go thou down, and wake him, and tell
19688 him. I must see to the deck here. Thou know’st what to say.”
19689 
19690 
19691 CHAPTER 124. The Needle.
19692 
19693 Next morning the not-yet-subsided sea rolled in long slow billows of
19694 mighty bulk, and striving in the Pequod’s gurgling track, pushed her on
19695 like giants’ palms outspread. The strong, unstaggering breeze abounded
19696 so, that sky and air seemed vast outbellying sails; the whole world
19697 boomed before the wind. Muffled in the full morning light, the
19698 invisible sun was only known by the spread intensity of his place;
19699 where his bayonet rays moved on in stacks. Emblazonings, as of crowned
19700 Babylonian kings and queens, reigned over everything. The sea was as a
19701 crucible of molten gold, that bubblingly leaps with light and heat.
19702 
19703 Long maintaining an enchanted silence, Ahab stood apart; and every time
19704 the tetering ship loweringly pitched down her bowsprit, he turned to
19705 eye the bright sun’s rays produced ahead; and when she profoundly
19706 settled by the stern, he turned behind, and saw the sun’s rearward
19707 place, and how the same yellow rays were blending with his undeviating
19708 wake.
19709 
19710 “Ha, ha, my ship! thou mightest well be taken now for the sea-chariot
19711 of the sun. Ho, ho! all ye nations before my prow, I bring the sun to
19712 ye! Yoke on the further billows; hallo! a tandem, I drive the sea!”
19713 
19714 But suddenly reined back by some counter thought, he hurried towards
19715 the helm, huskily demanding how the ship was heading.
19716 
19717 “East-sou-east, sir,” said the frightened steersman.
19718 
19719 “Thou liest!” smiting him with his clenched fist. “Heading East at this
19720 hour in the morning, and the sun astern?”
19721 
19722 Upon this every soul was confounded; for the phenomenon just then
19723 observed by Ahab had unaccountably escaped every one else; but its very
19724 blinding palpableness must have been the cause.
19725 
19726 Thrusting his head half way into the binnacle, Ahab caught one glimpse
19727 of the compasses; his uplifted arm slowly fell; for a moment he almost
19728 seemed to stagger. Standing behind him Starbuck looked, and lo! the two
19729 compasses pointed East, and the Pequod was as infallibly going West.
19730 
19731 But ere the first wild alarm could get out abroad among the crew, the
19732 old man with a rigid laugh exclaimed, “I have it! It has happened
19733 before. Mr. Starbuck, last night’s thunder turned our compasses—that’s
19734 all. Thou hast before now heard of such a thing, I take it.”
19735 
19736 “Aye; but never before has it happened to me, sir,” said the pale mate,
19737 gloomily.
19738 
19739 Here, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more than
19740 one case occurred to ships in violent storms. The magnetic energy, as
19741 developed in the mariner’s needle, is, as all know, essentially one
19742 with the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is not to be much
19743 marvelled at, that such things should be. Instances where the lightning
19744 has actually struck the vessel, so as to smite down some of the spars
19745 and rigging, the effect upon the needle has at times been still more
19746 fatal; all its loadstone virtue being annihilated, so that the before
19747 magnetic steel was of no more use than an old wife’s knitting needle.
19748 But in either case, the needle never again, of itself, recovers the
19749 original virtue thus marred or lost; and if the binnacle compasses be
19750 affected, the same fate reaches all the others that may be in the ship;
19751 even were the lowermost one inserted into the kelson.
19752 
19753 Deliberately standing before the binnacle, and eyeing the transpointed
19754 compasses, the old man, with the sharp of his extended hand, now took
19755 the precise bearing of the sun, and satisfied that the needles were
19756 exactly inverted, shouted out his orders for the ship’s course to be
19757 changed accordingly. The yards were hard up; and once more the Pequod
19758 thrust her undaunted bows into the opposing wind, for the supposed fair
19759 one had only been juggling her.
19760 
19761 Meanwhile, whatever were his own secret thoughts, Starbuck said
19762 nothing, but quietly he issued all requisite orders; while Stubb and
19763 Flask—who in some small degree seemed then to be sharing his
19764 feelings—likewise unmurmuringly acquiesced. As for the men, though some
19765 of them lowly rumbled, their fear of Ahab was greater than their fear
19766 of Fate. But as ever before, the pagan harpooneers remained almost
19767 wholly unimpressed; or if impressed, it was only with a certain
19768 magnetism shot into their congenial hearts from inflexible Ahab’s.
19769 
19770 For a space the old man walked the deck in rolling reveries. But
19771 chancing to slip with his ivory heel, he saw the crushed copper
19772 sight-tubes of the quadrant he had the day before dashed to the deck.
19773 
19774 “Thou poor, proud heaven-gazer and sun’s pilot! yesterday I wrecked
19775 thee, and to-day the compasses would fain have wrecked me. So, so. But
19776 Ahab is lord over the level loadstone yet. Mr. Starbuck—a lance without
19777 a pole; a top-maul, and the smallest of the sail-maker’s needles.
19778 Quick!”
19779 
19780 Accessory, perhaps, to the impulse dictating the thing he was now about
19781 to do, were certain prudential motives, whose object might have been to
19782 revive the spirits of his crew by a stroke of his subtile skill, in a
19783 matter so wondrous as that of the inverted compasses. Besides, the old
19784 man well knew that to steer by transpointed needles, though clumsily
19785 practicable, was not a thing to be passed over by superstitious
19786 sailors, without some shudderings and evil portents.
19787 
19788 “Men,” said he, steadily turning upon the crew, as the mate handed him
19789 the things he had demanded, “my men, the thunder turned old Ahab’s
19790 needles; but out of this bit of steel Ahab can make one of his own,
19791 that will point as true as any.”
19792 
19793 Abashed glances of servile wonder were exchanged by the sailors, as
19794 this was said; and with fascinated eyes they awaited whatever magic
19795 might follow. But Starbuck looked away.
19796 
19797 With a blow from the top-maul Ahab knocked off the steel head of the
19798 lance, and then handing to the mate the long iron rod remaining, bade
19799 him hold it upright, without its touching the deck. Then, with the
19800 maul, after repeatedly smiting the upper end of this iron rod, he
19801 placed the blunted needle endwise on the top of it, and less strongly
19802 hammered that, several times, the mate still holding the rod as before.
19803 Then going through some small strange motions with it—whether
19804 indispensable to the magnetizing of the steel, or merely intended to
19805 augment the awe of the crew, is uncertain—he called for linen thread;
19806 and moving to the binnacle, slipped out the two reversed needles there,
19807 and horizontally suspended the sail-needle by its middle, over one of
19808 the compass-cards. At first, the steel went round and round, quivering
19809 and vibrating at either end; but at last it settled to its place, when
19810 Ahab, who had been intently watching for this result, stepped frankly
19811 back from the binnacle, and pointing his stretched arm towards it,
19812 exclaimed,—“Look ye, for yourselves, if Ahab be not lord of the level
19813 loadstone! The sun is East, and that compass swears it!”
19814 
19815 One after another they peered in, for nothing but their own eyes could
19816 persuade such ignorance as theirs, and one after another they slunk
19817 away.
19818 
19819 In his fiery eyes of scorn and triumph, you then saw Ahab in all his
19820 fatal pride.
19821 
19822 
19823 CHAPTER 125. The Log and Line.
19824 
19825 While now the fated Pequod had been so long afloat this voyage, the log
19826 and line had but very seldom been in use. Owing to a confident reliance
19827 upon other means of determining the vessel’s place, some merchantmen,
19828 and many whalemen, especially when cruising, wholly neglect to heave
19829 the log; though at the same time, and frequently more for form’s sake
19830 than anything else, regularly putting down upon the customary slate the
19831 course steered by the ship, as well as the presumed average rate of
19832 progression every hour. It had been thus with the Pequod. The wooden
19833 reel and angular log attached hung, long untouched, just beneath the
19834 railing of the after bulwarks. Rains and spray had damped it; sun and
19835 wind had warped it; all the elements had combined to rot a thing that
19836 hung so idly. But heedless of all this, his mood seized Ahab, as he
19837 happened to glance upon the reel, not many hours after the magnet
19838 scene, and he remembered how his quadrant was no more, and recalled his
19839 frantic oath about the level log and line. The ship was sailing
19840 plungingly; astern the billows rolled in riots.
19841 
19842 “Forward, there! Heave the log!”
19843 
19844 Two seamen came. The golden-hued Tahitian and the grizzly Manxman.
19845 “Take the reel, one of ye, I’ll heave.”
19846 
19847 They went towards the extreme stern, on the ship’s lee side, where the
19848 deck, with the oblique energy of the wind, was now almost dipping into
19849 the creamy, sidelong-rushing sea.
19850 
19851 The Manxman took the reel, and holding it high up, by the projecting
19852 handle-ends of the spindle, round which the spool of line revolved, so
19853 stood with the angular log hanging downwards, till Ahab advanced to
19854 him.
19855 
19856 Ahab stood before him, and was lightly unwinding some thirty or forty
19857 turns to form a preliminary hand-coil to toss overboard, when the old
19858 Manxman, who was intently eyeing both him and the line, made bold to
19859 speak.
19860 
19861 “Sir, I mistrust it; this line looks far gone, long heat and wet have
19862 spoiled it.”
19863 
19864 “’Twill hold, old gentleman. Long heat and wet, have they spoiled thee?
19865 Thou seem’st to hold. Or, truer perhaps, life holds thee; not thou it.”
19866 
19867 “I hold the spool, sir. But just as my captain says. With these grey
19868 hairs of mine ’tis not worth while disputing, ’specially with a
19869 superior, who’ll ne’er confess.”
19870 
19871 “What’s that? There now’s a patched professor in Queen Nature’s
19872 granite-founded College; but methinks he’s too subservient. Where wert
19873 thou born?”
19874 
19875 “In the little rocky Isle of Man, sir.”
19876 
19877 “Excellent! Thou’st hit the world by that.”
19878 
19879 “I know not, sir, but I was born there.”
19880 
19881 “In the Isle of Man, hey? Well, the other way, it’s good. Here’s a man
19882 from Man; a man born in once independent Man, and now unmanned of Man;
19883 which is sucked in—by what? Up with the reel! The dead, blind wall
19884 butts all inquiring heads at last. Up with it! So.”
19885 
19886 The log was heaved. The loose coils rapidly straightened out in a long
19887 dragging line astern, and then, instantly, the reel began to whirl. In
19888 turn, jerkingly raised and lowered by the rolling billows, the towing
19889 resistance of the log caused the old reelman to stagger strangely.
19890 
19891 “Hold hard!”
19892 
19893 Snap! the overstrained line sagged down in one long festoon; the
19894 tugging log was gone.
19895 
19896 “I crush the quadrant, the thunder turns the needles, and now the mad
19897 sea parts the log-line. But Ahab can mend all. Haul in here, Tahitian;
19898 reel up, Manxman. And look ye, let the carpenter make another log, and
19899 mend thou the line. See to it.”
19900 
19901 “There he goes now; to him nothing’s happened; but to me, the skewer
19902 seems loosening out of the middle of the world. Haul in, haul in,
19903 Tahitian! These lines run whole, and whirling out: come in broken, and
19904 dragging slow. Ha, Pip? come to help; eh, Pip?”
19905 
19906 “Pip? whom call ye Pip? Pip jumped from the whale-boat. Pip’s missing.
19907 Let’s see now if ye haven’t fished him up here, fisherman. It drags
19908 hard; I guess he’s holding on. Jerk him, Tahiti! Jerk him off; we haul
19909 in no cowards here. Ho! there’s his arm just breaking water. A hatchet!
19910 a hatchet! cut it off—we haul in no cowards here. Captain Ahab! sir,
19911 sir! here’s Pip, trying to get on board again.”
19912 
19913 “Peace, thou crazy loon,” cried the Manxman, seizing him by the arm.
19914 “Away from the quarter-deck!”
19915 
19916 “The greater idiot ever scolds the lesser,” muttered Ahab, advancing.
19917 “Hands off from that holiness! Where sayest thou Pip was, boy?
19918 
19919 “Astern there, sir, astern! Lo! lo!”
19920 
19921 “And who art thou, boy? I see not my reflection in the vacant pupils of
19922 thy eyes. Oh God! that man should be a thing for immortal souls to
19923 sieve through! Who art thou, boy?”
19924 
19925 “Bell-boy, sir; ship’s-crier; ding, dong, ding! Pip! Pip! Pip! One
19926 hundred pounds of clay reward for Pip; five feet high—looks
19927 cowardly—quickest known by that! Ding, dong, ding! Who’s seen Pip the
19928 coward?”
19929 
19930 “There can be no hearts above the snow-line. Oh, ye frozen heavens!
19931 look down here. Ye did beget this luckless child, and have abandoned
19932 him, ye creative libertines. Here, boy; Ahab’s cabin shall be Pip’s
19933 home henceforth, while Ahab lives. Thou touchest my inmost centre, boy;
19934 thou art tied to me by cords woven of my heart-strings. Come, let’s
19935 down.”
19936 
19937 “What’s this? here’s velvet shark-skin,” intently gazing at Ahab’s
19938 hand, and feeling it. “Ah, now, had poor Pip but felt so kind a thing
19939 as this, perhaps he had ne’er been lost! This seems to me, sir, as a
19940 man-rope; something that weak souls may hold by. Oh, sir, let old Perth
19941 now come and rivet these two hands together; the black one with the
19942 white, for I will not let this go.”
19943 
19944 “Oh, boy, nor will I thee, unless I should thereby drag thee to worse
19945 horrors than are here. Come, then, to my cabin. Lo! ye believers in
19946 gods all goodness, and in man all ill, lo you! see the omniscient gods
19947 oblivious of suffering man; and man, though idiotic, and knowing not
19948 what he does, yet full of the sweet things of love and gratitude. Come!
19949 I feel prouder leading thee by thy black hand, than though I grasped an
19950 Emperor’s!”
19951 
19952 “There go two daft ones now,” muttered the old Manxman. “One daft with
19953 strength, the other daft with weakness. But here’s the end of the
19954 rotten line—all dripping, too. Mend it, eh? I think we had best have a
19955 new line altogether. I’ll see Mr. Stubb about it.”
19956 
19957 
19958 CHAPTER 126. The Life-Buoy.
19959 
19960 Steering now south-eastward by Ahab’s levelled steel, and her progress
19961 solely determined by Ahab’s level log and line; the Pequod held on her
19962 path towards the Equator. Making so long a passage through such
19963 unfrequented waters, descrying no ships, and ere long, sideways
19964 impelled by unvarying trade winds, over waves monotonously mild; all
19965 these seemed the strange calm things preluding some riotous and
19966 desperate scene.
19967 
19968 At last, when the ship drew near to the outskirts, as it were, of the
19969 Equatorial fishing-ground, and in the deep darkness that goes before
19970 the dawn, was sailing by a cluster of rocky islets; the watch—then
19971 headed by Flask—was startled by a cry so plaintively wild and
19972 unearthly—like half-articulated wailings of the ghosts of all Herod’s
19973 murdered Innocents—that one and all, they started from their reveries,
19974 and for the space of some moments stood, or sat, or leaned all
19975 transfixedly listening, like the carved Roman slave, while that wild
19976 cry remained within hearing. The Christian or civilized part of the
19977 crew said it was mermaids, and shuddered; but the pagan harpooneers
19978 remained unappalled. Yet the grey Manxman—the oldest mariner of
19979 all—declared that the wild thrilling sounds that were heard, were the
19980 voices of newly drowned men in the sea.
19981 
19982 Below in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when he
19983 came to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not
19984 unaccompanied with hinted dark meanings. He hollowly laughed, and thus
19985 explained the wonder.
19986 
19987 Those rocky islands the ship had passed were the resort of great
19988 numbers of seals, and some young seals that had lost their dams, or
19989 some dams that had lost their cubs, must have risen nigh the ship and
19990 kept company with her, crying and sobbing with their human sort of
19991 wail. But this only the more affected some of them, because most
19992 mariners cherish a very superstitious feeling about seals, arising not
19993 only from their peculiar tones when in distress, but also from the
19994 human look of their round heads and semi-intelligent faces, seen
19995 peeringly uprising from the water alongside. In the sea, under certain
19996 circumstances, seals have more than once been mistaken for men.
19997 
19998 But the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible
19999 confirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning. At
20000 sun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;
20001 and whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for
20002 sailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was thus
20003 with the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may, he had
20004 not been long at his perch, when a cry was heard—a cry and a
20005 rushing—and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and
20006 looking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of the
20007 sea.
20008 
20009 The life-buoy—a long slender cask—was dropped from the stern, where it
20010 always hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to seize it,
20011 and the sun having long beat upon this cask it had shrunken, so that it
20012 slowly filled, and that parched wood also filled at its every pore; and
20013 the studded iron-bound cask followed the sailor to the bottom, as if to
20014 yield him his pillow, though in sooth but a hard one.
20015 
20016 And thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look out
20017 for the White Whale, on the White Whale’s own peculiar ground; that man
20018 was swallowed up in the deep. But few, perhaps, thought of that at the
20019 time. Indeed, in some sort, they were not grieved at this event, at
20020 least as a portent; for they regarded it, not as a foreshadowing of
20021 evil in the future, but as the fulfilment of an evil already presaged.
20022 They declared that now they knew the reason of those wild shrieks they
20023 had heard the night before. But again the old Manxman said nay.
20024 
20025 The lost life-buoy was now to be replaced; Starbuck was directed to see
20026 to it; but as no cask of sufficient lightness could be found, and as in
20027 the feverish eagerness of what seemed the approaching crisis of the
20028 voyage, all hands were impatient of any toil but what was directly
20029 connected with its final end, whatever that might prove to be;
20030 therefore, they were going to leave the ship’s stern unprovided with a
20031 buoy, when by certain strange signs and inuendoes Queequeg hinted a
20032 hint concerning his coffin.
20033 
20034 “A life-buoy of a coffin!” cried Starbuck, starting.
20035 
20036 “Rather queer, that, I should say,” said Stubb.
20037 
20038 “It will make a good enough one,” said Flask, “the carpenter here can
20039 arrange it easily.”
20040 
20041 “Bring it up; there’s nothing else for it,” said Starbuck, after a
20042 melancholy pause. “Rig it, carpenter; do not look at me so—the coffin,
20043 I mean. Dost thou hear me? Rig it.”
20044 
20045 “And shall I nail down the lid, sir?” moving his hand as with a hammer.
20046 
20047 “Aye.”
20048 
20049 “And shall I caulk the seams, sir?” moving his hand as with a
20050 caulking-iron.
20051 
20052 “Aye.”
20053 
20054 “And shall I then pay over the same with pitch, sir?” moving his hand
20055 as with a pitch-pot.
20056 
20057 “Away! what possesses thee to this? Make a life-buoy of the coffin, and
20058 no more.—Mr. Stubb, Mr. Flask, come forward with me.”
20059 
20060 “He goes off in a huff. The whole he can endure; at the parts he
20061 baulks. Now I don’t like this. I make a leg for Captain Ahab, and he
20062 wears it like a gentleman; but I make a bandbox for Queequeg, and he
20063 won’t put his head into it. Are all my pains to go for nothing with
20064 that coffin? And now I’m ordered to make a life-buoy of it. It’s like
20065 turning an old coat; going to bring the flesh on the other side now. I
20066 don’t like this cobbling sort of business—I don’t like it at all; it’s
20067 undignified; it’s not my place. Let tinkers’ brats do tinkerings; we
20068 are their betters. I like to take in hand none but clean, virgin,
20069 fair-and-square mathematical jobs, something that regularly begins at
20070 the beginning, and is at the middle when midway, and comes to an end at
20071 the conclusion; not a cobbler’s job, that’s at an end in the middle,
20072 and at the beginning at the end. It’s the old woman’s tricks to be
20073 giving cobbling jobs. Lord! what an affection all old women have for
20074 tinkers. I know an old woman of sixty-five who ran away with a
20075 bald-headed young tinker once. And that’s the reason I never would work
20076 for lonely widow old women ashore, when I kept my job-shop in the
20077 Vineyard; they might have taken it into their lonely old heads to run
20078 off with me. But heigh-ho! there are no caps at sea but snow-caps. Let
20079 me see. Nail down the lid; caulk the seams; pay over the same with
20080 pitch; batten them down tight, and hang it with the snap-spring over
20081 the ship’s stern. Were ever such things done before with a coffin? Some
20082 superstitious old carpenters, now, would be tied up in the rigging, ere
20083 they would do the job. But I’m made of knotty Aroostook hemlock; I
20084 don’t budge. Cruppered with a coffin! Sailing about with a grave-yard
20085 tray! But never mind. We workers in woods make bridal-bedsteads and
20086 card-tables, as well as coffins and hearses. We work by the month, or
20087 by the job, or by the profit; not for us to ask the why and wherefore
20088 of our work, unless it be too confounded cobbling, and then we stash it
20089 if we can. Hem! I’ll do the job, now, tenderly. I’ll have me—let’s
20090 see—how many in the ship’s company, all told? But I’ve forgotten. Any
20091 way, I’ll have me thirty separate, Turk’s-headed life-lines, each three
20092 feet long hanging all round to the coffin. Then, if the hull go down,
20093 there’ll be thirty lively fellows all fighting for one coffin, a sight
20094 not seen very often beneath the sun! Come hammer, caulking-iron,
20095 pitch-pot, and marling-spike! Let’s to it.”
20096 
20097 
20098 CHAPTER 127. The Deck.
20099 
20100 _The coffin laid upon two line-tubs, between the vice-bench and the

20112

20175 “There’s a sight! There’s a sound! The greyheaded woodpecker tapping
20176 the hollow tree! Blind and dumb might well be envied now. See! that
20177 thing rests on two line-tubs, full of tow-lines. A most malicious wag,
20178 that fellow. Rat-tat! So man’s seconds tick! Oh! how immaterial are all
20179 materials! What things real are there, but imponderable thoughts? Here
20180 now’s the very dreaded symbol of grim death, by a mere hap, made the
20181 expressive sign of the help and hope of most endangered life. A
20182 life-buoy of a coffin! Does it go further? Can it be that in some
20183 spiritual sense the coffin is, after all, but an immortality-preserver!
20184 I’ll think of that. But no. So far gone am I in the dark side of earth,
20185 that its other side, the theoretic bright one, seems but uncertain
20186 twilight to me. Will ye never have done, Carpenter, with that accursed
20187 sound? I go below; let me not see that thing here when I return again.
20188 Now, then, Pip, we’ll talk this over; I do suck most wondrous
20189 philosophies from thee! Some unknown conduits from the unknown worlds
20190 must empty into thee!”

20192 
20193 CHAPTER 128. The Pequod Meets The Rachel.
20194 
20195 Next day, a large ship, the Rachel, was descried, bearing directly down
20196 upon the Pequod, all her spars thickly clustering with men. At the time
20197 the Pequod was making good speed through the water; but as the
20198 broad-winged windward stranger shot nigh to her, the boastful sails all
20199 fell together as blank bladders that are burst, and all life fled from
20200 the smitten hull.
20201 
20202 “Bad news; she brings bad news,” muttered the old Manxman. But ere her
20203 commander, who, with trumpet to mouth, stood up in his boat; ere he
20204 could hopefully hail, Ahab’s voice was heard.
20205 
20206 “Hast seen the White Whale?”
20207 
20208 “Aye, yesterday. Have ye seen a whale-boat adrift?”
20209 
20210 Throttling his joy, Ahab negatively answered this unexpected question;
20211 and would then have fain boarded the stranger, when the stranger
20212 captain himself, having stopped his vessel’s way, was seen descending
20213 her side. A few keen pulls, and his boat-hook soon clinched the
20214 Pequod’s main-chains, and he sprang to the deck. Immediately he was
20215 recognised by Ahab for a Nantucketer he knew. But no formal salutation
20216 was exchanged.
20217 
20218 “Where was he?—not killed!—not killed!” cried Ahab, closely advancing.
20219 “How was it?”
20220 
20221 It seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous,
20222 while three of the stranger’s boats were engaged with a shoal of
20223 whales, which had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and
20224 while they were yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and head
20225 of Moby Dick had suddenly loomed up out of the water, not very far to
20226 leeward; whereupon, the fourth rigged boat—a reserved one—had been
20227 instantly lowered in chase. After a keen sail before the wind, this
20228 fourth boat—the swiftest keeled of all—seemed to have succeeded in
20229 fastening—at least, as well as the man at the mast-head could tell
20230 anything about it. In the distance he saw the diminished dotted boat;
20231 and then a swift gleam of bubbling white water; and after that nothing
20232 more; whence it was concluded that the stricken whale must have
20233 indefinitely run away with his pursuers, as often happens. There was
20234 some apprehension, but no positive alarm, as yet. The recall signals
20235 were placed in the rigging; darkness came on; and forced to pick up her
20236 three far to windward boats—ere going in quest of the fourth one in the
20237 precisely opposite direction—the ship had not only been necessitated to
20238 leave that boat to its fate till near midnight, but, for the time, to
20239 increase her distance from it. But the rest of her crew being at last
20240 safe aboard, she crowded all sail—stunsail on stunsail—after the
20241 missing boat; kindling a fire in her try-pots for a beacon; and every
20242 other man aloft on the look-out. But though when she had thus sailed a
20243 sufficient distance to gain the presumed place of the absent ones when
20244 last seen; though she then paused to lower her spare boats to pull all
20245 around her; and not finding anything, had again dashed on; again
20246 paused, and lowered her boats; and though she had thus continued doing
20247 till daylight; yet not the least glimpse of the missing keel had been
20248 seen.
20249 
20250 The story told, the stranger Captain immediately went on to reveal his
20251 object in boarding the Pequod. He desired that ship to unite with his
20252 own in the search; by sailing over the sea some four or five miles
20253 apart, on parallel lines, and so sweeping a double horizon, as it were.
20254 
20255 “I will wager something now,” whispered Stubb to Flask, “that some one
20256 in that missing boat wore off that Captain’s best coat; mayhap, his
20257 watch—he’s so cursed anxious to get it back. Who ever heard of two
20258 pious whale-ships cruising after one missing whale-boat in the height
20259 of the whaling season? See, Flask, only see how pale he looks—pale in
20260 the very buttons of his eyes—look—it wasn’t the coat—it must have been
20261 the—”
20262 
20263 “My boy, my own boy is among them. For God’s sake—I beg, I
20264 conjure”—here exclaimed the stranger Captain to Ahab, who thus far had
20265 but icily received his petition. “For eight-and-forty hours let me
20266 charter your ship—I will gladly pay for it, and roundly pay for it—if
20267 there be no other way—for eight-and-forty hours only—only that—you
20268 must, oh, you must, and you _shall_ do this thing.”
20269 
20270 “His son!” cried Stubb, “oh, it’s his son he’s lost! I take back the
20271 coat and watch—what says Ahab? We must save that boy.”
20272 
20273 “He’s drowned with the rest on ’em, last night,” said the old Manx
20274 sailor standing behind them; “I heard; all of ye heard their spirits.”
20275 
20276 Now, as it shortly turned out, what made this incident of the Rachel’s
20277 the more melancholy, was the circumstance, that not only was one of the
20278 Captain’s sons among the number of the missing boat’s crew; but among
20279 the number of the other boat’s crews, at the same time, but on the
20280 other hand, separated from the ship during the dark vicissitudes of the
20281 chase, there had been still another son; as that for a time, the
20282 wretched father was plunged to the bottom of the cruellest perplexity;
20283 which was only solved for him by his chief mate’s instinctively
20284 adopting the ordinary procedure of a whale-ship in such emergencies,
20285 that is, when placed between jeopardized but divided boats, always to
20286 pick up the majority first. But the captain, for some unknown
20287 constitutional reason, had refrained from mentioning all this, and not
20288 till forced to it by Ahab’s iciness did he allude to his one yet
20289 missing boy; a little lad, but twelve years old, whose father with the
20290 earnest but unmisgiving hardihood of a Nantucketer’s paternal love, had
20291 thus early sought to initiate him in the perils and wonders of a
20292 vocation almost immemorially the destiny of all his race. Nor does it
20293 unfrequently occur, that Nantucket captains will send a son of such
20294 tender age away from them, for a protracted three or four years’ voyage
20295 in some other ship than their own; so that their first knowledge of a
20296 whaleman’s career shall be unenervated by any chance display of a
20297 father’s natural but untimely partiality, or undue apprehensiveness and
20298 concern.
20299 
20300 Meantime, now the stranger was still beseeching his poor boon of Ahab;
20301 and Ahab still stood like an anvil, receiving every shock, but without
20302 the least quivering of his own.
20303 
20304 “I will not go,” said the stranger, “till you say _aye_ to me. Do to me
20305 as you would have me do to you in the like case. For _you_ too have a
20306 boy, Captain Ahab—though but a child, and nestling safely at home now—a
20307 child of your old age too—Yes, yes, you relent; I see it—run, run, men,
20308 now, and stand by to square in the yards.”
20309 
20310 “Avast,” cried Ahab—“touch not a rope-yarn”; then in a voice that
20311 prolongingly moulded every word—“Captain Gardiner, I will not do it.
20312 Even now I lose time. Good-bye, good-bye. God bless ye, man, and may I
20313 forgive myself, but I must go. Mr. Starbuck, look at the binnacle
20314 watch, and in three minutes from this present instant warn off all
20315 strangers: then brace forward again, and let the ship sail as before.”
20316 
20317 Hurriedly turning, with averted face, he descended into his cabin,
20318 leaving the strange captain transfixed at this unconditional and utter
20319 rejection of his so earnest suit. But starting from his enchantment,
20320 Gardiner silently hurried to the side; more fell than stepped into his
20321 boat, and returned to his ship.
20322 
20323 Soon the two ships diverged their wakes; and long as the strange vessel
20324 was in view, she was seen to yaw hither and thither at every dark spot,
20325 however small, on the sea. This way and that her yards were swung
20326 round; starboard and larboard, she continued to tack; now she beat
20327 against a head sea; and again it pushed her before it; while all the
20328 while, her masts and yards were thickly clustered with men, as three
20329 tall cherry trees, when the boys are cherrying among the boughs.
20330 
20331 But by her still halting course and winding, woeful way, you plainly
20332 saw that this ship that so wept with spray, still remained without
20333 comfort. She was Rachel, weeping for her children, because they were
20334 not.
20335 
20336 
20337 CHAPTER 129. The Cabin.
20338 
20339 (_Ahab moving to go on deck; Pip catches him by the hand to follow._)
20340 
20341 “Lad, lad, I tell thee thou must not follow Ahab now. The hour is
20342 coming when Ahab would not scare thee from him, yet would not have thee
20343 by him. There is that in thee, poor lad, which I feel too curing to my
20344 malady. Like cures like; and for this hunt, my malady becomes my most
20345 desired health. Do thou abide below here, where they shall serve thee,
20346 as if thou wert the captain. Aye, lad, thou shalt sit here in my own
20347 screwed chair; another screw to it, thou must be.”
20348 
20349 “No, no, no! ye have not a whole body, sir; do ye but use poor me for
20350 your one lost leg; only tread upon me, sir; I ask no more, so I remain
20351 a part of ye.”
20352 
20353 “Oh! spite of million villains, this makes me a bigot in the fadeless
20354 fidelity of man!—and a black! and crazy!—but methinks like-cures-like
20355 applies to him too; he grows so sane again.”
20356 
20357 “They tell me, sir, that Stubb did once desert poor little Pip, whose
20358 drowned bones now show white, for all the blackness of his living skin.
20359 But I will never desert ye, sir, as Stubb did him. Sir, I must go with
20360 ye.”
20361 
20362 “If thou speakest thus to me much more, Ahab’s purpose keels up in him.
20363 I tell thee no; it cannot be.”
20364 
20365 “Oh good master, master, master!
20366 
20367 “Weep so, and I will murder thee! have a care, for Ahab too is mad.
20368 Listen, and thou wilt often hear my ivory foot upon the deck, and still
20369 know that I am there. And now I quit thee. Thy hand!—Met! True art
20370 thou, lad, as the circumference to its centre. So: God for ever bless
20371 thee; and if it come to that,—God for ever save thee, let what will
20372 befall.”
20373 
20374 (_Ahab goes; Pip steps one step forward._)
20375 
20376 “Here he this instant stood; I stand in his air,—but I’m alone. Now
20377 were even poor Pip here I could endure it, but he’s missing. Pip! Pip!
20378 Ding, dong, ding! Who’s seen Pip? He must be up here; let’s try the
20379 door. What? neither lock, nor bolt, nor bar; and yet there’s no opening
20380 it. It must be the spell; he told me to stay here: Aye, and told me
20381 this screwed chair was mine. Here, then, I’ll seat me, against the
20382 transom, in the ship’s full middle, all her keel and her three masts
20383 before me. Here, our old sailors say, in their black seventy-fours
20384 great admirals sometimes sit at table, and lord it over rows of
20385 captains and lieutenants. Ha! what’s this? epaulets! epaulets! the
20386 epaulets all come crowding! Pass round the decanters; glad to see ye;
20387 fill up, monsieurs! What an odd feeling, now, when a black boy’s host
20388 to white men with gold lace upon their coats!—Monsieurs, have ye seen
20389 one Pip?—a little negro lad, five feet high, hang-dog look, and
20390 cowardly! Jumped from a whale-boat once;—seen him? No! Well then, fill
20391 up again, captains, and let’s drink shame upon all cowards! I name no
20392 names. Shame upon them! Put one foot upon the table. Shame upon all
20393 cowards.—Hist! above there, I hear ivory—Oh, master! master! I am
20394 indeed down-hearted when you walk over me. But here I’ll stay, though
20395 this stern strikes rocks; and they bulge through; and oysters come to
20396 join me.”

20399 CHAPTER 130. The Hat.
20400 
20401 And now that at the proper time and place, after so long and wide a
20402 preliminary cruise, Ahab,—all other whaling waters swept—seemed to have
20403 chased his foe into an ocean-fold, to slay him the more securely there;
20404 now, that he found himself hard by the very latitude and longitude
20405 where his tormenting wound had been inflicted; now that a vessel had
20406 been spoken which on the very day preceding had actually encountered
20407 Moby Dick;—and now that all his successive meetings with various ships
20408 contrastingly concurred to show the demoniac indifference with which
20409 the white whale tore his hunters, whether sinning or sinned against;
20410 now it was that there lurked a something in the old man’s eyes, which
20411 it was hardly sufferable for feeble souls to see. As the unsetting
20412 polar star, which through the livelong, arctic, six months’ night
20413 sustains its piercing, steady, central gaze; so Ahab’s purpose now
20414 fixedly gleamed down upon the constant midnight of the gloomy crew. It
20415 domineered above them so, that all their bodings, doubts, misgivings,
20416 fears, were fain to hide beneath their souls, and not sprout forth a
20417 single spear or leaf.
20418 
20419 In this foreshadowing interval too, all humor, forced or natural,
20420 vanished. Stubb no more strove to raise a smile; Starbuck no more
20421 strove to check one. Alike, joy and sorrow, hope and fear, seemed
20422 ground to finest dust, and powdered, for the time, in the clamped
20423 mortar of Ahab’s iron soul. Like machines, they dumbly moved about the
20424 deck, ever conscious that the old man’s despot eye was on them.
20425 
20426 But did you deeply scan him in his more secret confidential hours; when
20427 he thought no glance but one was on him; then you would have seen that
20428 even as Ahab’s eyes so awed the crew’s, the inscrutable Parsee’s glance
20429 awed his; or somehow, at least, in some wild way, at times affected it.
20430 Such an added, gliding strangeness began to invest the thin Fedallah
20431 now; such ceaseless shudderings shook him; that the men looked dubious
20432 at him; half uncertain, as it seemed, whether indeed he were a mortal
20433 substance, or else a tremulous shadow cast upon the deck by some unseen
20434 being’s body. And that shadow was always hovering there. For not by
20435 night, even, had Fedallah ever certainly been known to slumber, or go
20436 below. He would stand still for hours: but never sat or leaned; his wan
20437 but wondrous eyes did plainly say—We two watchmen never rest.
20438 
20439 Nor, at any time, by night or day could the mariners now step upon the
20440 deck, unless Ahab was before them; either standing in his pivot-hole,
20441 or exactly pacing the planks between two undeviating limits,—the
20442 main-mast and the mizen; or else they saw him standing in the
20443 cabin-scuttle,—his living foot advanced upon the deck, as if to step;
20444 his hat slouched heavily over his eyes; so that however motionless he
20445 stood, however the days and nights were added on, that he had not swung
20446 in his hammock; yet hidden beneath that slouching hat, they could never
20447 tell unerringly whether, for all this, his eyes were really closed at
20448 times; or whether he was still intently scanning them; no matter,
20449 though he stood so in the scuttle for a whole hour on the stretch, and
20450 the unheeded night-damp gathered in beads of dew upon that stone-carved
20451 coat and hat. The clothes that the night had wet, the next day’s
20452 sunshine dried upon him; and so, day after day, and night after night;
20453 he went no more beneath the planks; whatever he wanted from the cabin
20454 that thing he sent for.
20455 
20456 He ate in the same open air; that is, his two only meals,—breakfast and
20457 dinner: supper he never touched; nor reaped his beard; which darkly
20458 grew all gnarled, as unearthed roots of trees blown over, which still
20459 grow idly on at naked base, though perished in the upper verdure. But
20460 though his whole life was now become one watch on deck; and though the
20461 Parsee’s mystic watch was without intermission as his own; yet these
20462 two never seemed to speak—one man to the other—unless at long intervals
20463 some passing unmomentous matter made it necessary. Though such a potent
20464 spell seemed secretly to join the twain; openly, and to the awe-struck
20465 crew, they seemed pole-like asunder. If by day they chanced to speak
20466 one word; by night, dumb men were both, so far as concerned the
20467 slightest verbal interchange. At times, for longest hours, without a
20468 single hail, they stood far parted in the starlight; Ahab in his
20469 scuttle, the Parsee by the mainmast; but still fixedly gazing upon each
20470 other; as if in the Parsee Ahab saw his forethrown shadow, in Ahab the
20471 Parsee his abandoned substance.
20472 
20473 And yet, somehow, did Ahab—in his own proper self, as daily, hourly,
20474 and every instant, commandingly revealed to his subordinates,—Ahab
20475 seemed an independent lord; the Parsee but his slave. Still again both
20476 seemed yoked together, and an unseen tyrant driving them; the lean
20477 shade siding the solid rib. For be this Parsee what he may, all rib and
20478 keel was solid Ahab.
20479 
20480 At the first faintest glimmering of the dawn, his iron voice was heard
20481 from aft,—“Man the mast-heads!”—and all through the day, till after
20482 sunset and after twilight, the same voice every hour, at the striking
20483 of the helmsman’s bell, was heard—“What d’ye see?—sharp! sharp!”
20484 
20485 But when three or four days had slided by, after meeting the
20486 children-seeking Rachel; and no spout had yet been seen; the monomaniac
20487 old man seemed distrustful of his crew’s fidelity; at least, of nearly
20488 all except the Pagan harpooneers; he seemed to doubt, even, whether
20489 Stubb and Flask might not willingly overlook the sight he sought. But
20490 if these suspicions were really his, he sagaciously refrained from
20491 verbally expressing them, however his actions might seem to hint them.
20492 
20493 “I will have the first sight of the whale myself,”—he said. “Aye! Ahab
20494 must have the doubloon!” and with his own hands he rigged a nest of
20495 basketed bowlines; and sending a hand aloft, with a single sheaved
20496 block, to secure to the main-mast head, he received the two ends of the
20497 downward-reeved rope; and attaching one to his basket prepared a pin
20498 for the other end, in order to fasten it at the rail. This done, with
20499 that end yet in his hand and standing beside the pin, he looked round
20500 upon his crew, sweeping from one to the other; pausing his glance long
20501 upon Daggoo, Queequeg, Tashtego; but shunning Fedallah; and then
20502 settling his firm relying eye upon the chief mate, said,—“Take the
20503 rope, sir—I give it into thy hands, Starbuck.” Then arranging his
20504 person in the basket, he gave the word for them to hoist him to his
20505 perch, Starbuck being the one who secured the rope at last; and
20506 afterwards stood near it. And thus, with one hand clinging round the
20507 royal mast, Ahab gazed abroad upon the sea for miles and miles,—ahead,
20508 astern, this side, and that,—within the wide expanded circle commanded
20509 at so great a height.
20510 
20511 When in working with his hands at some lofty almost isolated place in
20512 the rigging, which chances to afford no foothold, the sailor at sea is
20513 hoisted up to that spot, and sustained there by the rope; under these
20514 circumstances, its fastened end on deck is always given in strict
20515 charge to some one man who has the special watch of it. Because in such
20516 a wilderness of running rigging, whose various different relations
20517 aloft cannot always be infallibly discerned by what is seen of them at
20518 the deck; and when the deck-ends of these ropes are being every few
20519 minutes cast down from the fastenings, it would be but a natural
20520 fatality, if, unprovided with a constant watchman, the hoisted sailor
20521 should by some carelessness of the crew be cast adrift and fall all
20522 swooping to the sea. So Ahab’s proceedings in this matter were not
20523 unusual; the only strange thing about them seemed to be, that Starbuck,
20524 almost the one only man who had ever ventured to oppose him with
20525 anything in the slightest degree approaching to decision—one of those
20526 too, whose faithfulness on the look-out he had seemed to doubt
20527 somewhat;—it was strange, that this was the very man he should select
20528 for his watchman; freely giving his whole life into such an otherwise
20529 distrusted person’s hands.
20530 
20531 Now, the first time Ahab was perched aloft; ere he had been there ten
20532 minutes; one of those red-billed savage sea-hawks which so often fly
20533 incommodiously close round the manned mast-heads of whalemen in these
20534 latitudes; one of these birds came wheeling and screaming round his
20535 head in a maze of untrackably swift circlings. Then it darted a
20536 thousand feet straight up into the air; then spiralized downwards, and
20537 went eddying again round his head.
20538 
20539 But with his gaze fixed upon the dim and distant horizon, Ahab seemed
20540 not to mark this wild bird; nor, indeed, would any one else have marked
20541 it much, it being no uncommon circumstance; only now almost the least
20542 heedful eye seemed to see some sort of cunning meaning in almost every
20543 sight.
20544 
20545 “Your hat, your hat, sir!” suddenly cried the Sicilian seaman, who
20546 being posted at the mizen-mast-head, stood directly behind Ahab, though
20547 somewhat lower than his level, and with a deep gulf of air dividing
20548 them.
20549 
20550 But already the sable wing was before the old man’s eyes; the long
20551 hooked bill at his head: with a scream, the black hawk darted away with
20552 his prize.
20553 
20554 An eagle flew thrice round Tarquin’s head, removing his cap to replace
20555 it, and thereupon Tanaquil, his wife, declared that Tarquin would be
20556 king of Rome. But only by the replacing of the cap was that omen
20557 accounted good. Ahab’s hat was never restored; the wild hawk flew on
20558 and on with it; far in advance of the prow: and at last disappeared;
20559 while from the point of that disappearance, a minute black spot was
20560 dimly discerned, falling from that vast height into the sea.
20561

20563 CHAPTER 131. The Pequod Meets The Delight.
20564 
20565 The intense Pequod sailed on; the rolling waves and days went by; the
20566 life-buoy-coffin still lightly swung; and another ship, most miserably
20567 misnamed the Delight, was descried. As she drew nigh, all eyes were
20568 fixed upon her broad beams, called shears, which, in some
20569 whaling-ships, cross the quarter-deck at the height of eight or nine
20570 feet; serving to carry the spare, unrigged, or disabled boats.
20571 
20572 Upon the stranger’s shears were beheld the shattered, white ribs, and
20573 some few splintered planks, of what had once been a whale-boat; but you
20574 now saw through this wreck, as plainly as you see through the peeled,
20575 half-unhinged, and bleaching skeleton of a horse.
20576 
20577 “Hast seen the White Whale?”
20578 
20579 “Look!” replied the hollow-cheeked captain from his taffrail; and with
20580 his trumpet he pointed to the wreck.
20581 
20582 “Hast killed him?”
20583 
20584 “The harpoon is not yet forged that ever will do that,” answered the
20585 other, sadly glancing upon a rounded hammock on the deck, whose
20586 gathered sides some noiseless sailors were busy in sewing together.
20587 
20588 “Not forged!” and snatching Perth’s levelled iron from the crotch, Ahab
20589 held it out, exclaiming—“Look ye, Nantucketer; here in this hand I hold
20590 his death! Tempered in blood, and tempered by lightning are these
20591 barbs; and I swear to temper them triply in that hot place behind the
20592 fin, where the White Whale most feels his accursed life!”
20593 
20594 “Then God keep thee, old man—see’st thou that”—pointing to the
20595 hammock—“I bury but one of five stout men, who were alive only
20596 yesterday; but were dead ere night. Only _that_ one I bury; the rest
20597 were buried before they died; you sail upon their tomb.” Then turning
20598 to his crew—“Are ye ready there? place the plank then on the rail, and
20599 lift the body; so, then—Oh! God”—advancing towards the hammock with
20600 uplifted hands—“may the resurrection and the life——”
20601 
20602 “Brace forward! Up helm!” cried Ahab like lightning to his men.
20603 
20604 But the suddenly started Pequod was not quick enough to escape the
20605 sound of the splash that the corpse soon made as it struck the sea; not
20606 so quick, indeed, but that some of the flying bubbles might have
20607 sprinkled her hull with their ghostly baptism.
20608 
20609 As Ahab now glided from the dejected Delight, the strange life-buoy
20610 hanging at the Pequod’s stern came into conspicuous relief.
20611 
20612 “Ha! yonder! look yonder, men!” cried a foreboding voice in her wake.
20613 “In vain, oh, ye strangers, ye fly our sad burial; ye but turn us your
20614 taffrail to show us your coffin!”
20615 
20616 
20617 CHAPTER 132. The Symphony.
20618 
20619 It was a clear steel-blue day. The firmaments of air and sea were
20620 hardly separable in that all-pervading azure; only, the pensive air was
20621 transparently pure and soft, with a woman’s look, and the robust and
20622 man-like sea heaved with long, strong, lingering swells, as Samson’s
20623 chest in his sleep.
20624 
20625 Hither, and thither, on high, glided the snow-white wings of small,
20626 unspeckled birds; these were the gentle thoughts of the feminine air;
20627 but to and fro in the deeps, far down in the bottomless blue, rushed
20628 mighty leviathans, sword-fish, and sharks; and these were the strong,
20629 troubled, murderous thinkings of the masculine sea.
20630 
20631 But though thus contrasting within, the contrast was only in shades and
20632 shadows without; those two seemed one; it was only the sex, as it were,
20633 that distinguished them.
20634 
20635 Aloft, like a royal czar and king, the sun seemed giving this gentle
20636 air to this bold and rolling sea; even as bride to groom. And at the
20637 girdling line of the horizon, a soft and tremulous motion—most seen
20638 here at the equator—denoted the fond, throbbing trust, the loving
20639 alarms, with which the poor bride gave her bosom away.
20640 
20641 Tied up and twisted; gnarled and knotted with wrinkles; haggardly firm
20642 and unyielding; his eyes glowing like coals, that still glow in the
20643 ashes of ruin; untottering Ahab stood forth in the clearness of the
20644 morn; lifting his splintered helmet of a brow to the fair girl’s
20645 forehead of heaven.
20646 
20647 Oh, immortal infancy, and innocency of the azure! Invisible winged
20648 creatures that frolic all round us! Sweet childhood of air and sky! how
20649 oblivious were ye of old Ahab’s close-coiled woe! But so have I seen
20650 little Miriam and Martha, laughing-eyed elves, heedlessly gambol around
20651 their old sire; sporting with the circle of singed locks which grew on
20652 the marge of that burnt-out crater of his brain.
20653 
20654 Slowly crossing the deck from the scuttle, Ahab leaned over the side
20655 and watched how his shadow in the water sank and sank to his gaze, the
20656 more and the more that he strove to pierce the profundity. But the
20657 lovely aromas in that enchanted air did at last seem to dispel, for a
20658 moment, the cankerous thing in his soul. That glad, happy air, that
20659 winsome sky, did at last stroke and caress him; the step-mother world,
20660 so long cruel—forbidding—now threw affectionate arms round his stubborn
20661 neck, and did seem to joyously sob over him, as if over one, that
20662 however wilful and erring, she could yet find it in her heart to save
20663 and to bless. From beneath his slouched hat Ahab dropped a tear into
20664 the sea; nor did all the Pacific contain such wealth as that one wee
20665 drop.
20666 
20667 Starbuck saw the old man; saw him, how he heavily leaned over the side;
20668 and he seemed to hear in his own true heart the measureless sobbing
20669 that stole out of the centre of the serenity around. Careful not to
20670 touch him, or be noticed by him, he yet drew near to him, and stood
20671 there.
20672 
20673 Ahab turned.
20674 
20675 “Starbuck!”
20676 
20677 “Sir.”
20678 
20679 “Oh, Starbuck! it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky. On such
20680 a day—very much such a sweetness as this—I struck my first whale—a
20681 boy-harpooneer of eighteen! Forty—forty—forty years ago!—ago! Forty
20682 years of continual whaling! forty years of privation, and peril, and
20683 storm-time! forty years on the pitiless sea! for forty years has Ahab
20684 forsaken the peaceful land, for forty years to make war on the horrors
20685 of the deep! Aye and yes, Starbuck, out of those forty years I have not
20686 spent three ashore. When I think of this life I have led; the
20687 desolation of solitude it has been; the masoned, walled-town of a
20688 Captain’s exclusiveness, which admits but small entrance to any
20689 sympathy from the green country without—oh, weariness! heaviness!
20690 Guinea-coast slavery of solitary command!—when I think of all this;
20691 only half-suspected, not so keenly known to me before—and how for forty
20692 years I have fed upon dry salted fare—fit emblem of the dry nourishment
20693 of my soil!—when the poorest landsman has had fresh fruit to his daily
20694 hand, and broken the world’s fresh bread to my mouldy crusts—away,
20695 whole oceans away, from that young girl-wife I wedded past fifty, and
20696 sailed for Cape Horn the next day, leaving but one dent in my marriage
20697 pillow—wife? wife?—rather a widow with her husband alive! Aye, I
20698 widowed that poor girl when I married her, Starbuck; and then, the
20699 madness, the frenzy, the boiling blood and the smoking brow, with
20700 which, for a thousand lowerings old Ahab has furiously, foamingly
20701 chased his prey—more a demon than a man!—aye, aye! what a forty years’
20702 fool—fool—old fool, has old Ahab been! Why this strife of the chase?
20703 why weary, and palsy the arm at the oar, and the iron, and the lance?
20704 how the richer or better is Ahab now? Behold. Oh, Starbuck! is it not
20705 hard, that with this weary load I bear, one poor leg should have been
20706 snatched from under me? Here, brush this old hair aside; it blinds me,
20707 that I seem to weep. Locks so grey did never grow but from out some
20708 ashes! But do I look very old, so very, very old, Starbuck? I feel
20709 deadly faint, bowed, and humped, as though I were Adam, staggering
20710 beneath the piled centuries since Paradise. God! God! God!—crack my
20711 heart!—stave my brain!—mockery! mockery! bitter, biting mockery of grey
20712 hairs, have I lived enough joy to wear ye; and seem and feel thus
20713 intolerably old? Close! stand close to me, Starbuck; let me look into a
20714 human eye; it is better than to gaze into sea or sky; better than to
20715 gaze upon God. By the green land; by the bright hearth-stone! this is
20716 the magic glass, man; I see my wife and my child in thine eye. No, no;
20717 stay on board, on board!—lower not when I do; when branded Ahab gives
20718 chase to Moby Dick. That hazard shall not be thine. No, no! not with
20719 the far away home I see in that eye!”
20720 
20721 “Oh, my Captain! my Captain! noble soul! grand old heart, after all!
20722 why should any one give chase to that hated fish! Away with me! let us
20723 fly these deadly waters! let us home! Wife and child, too, are
20724 Starbuck’s—wife and child of his brotherly, sisterly, play-fellow
20725 youth; even as thine, sir, are the wife and child of thy loving,
20726 longing, paternal old age! Away! let us away!—this instant let me alter
20727 the course! How cheerily, how hilariously, O my Captain, would we bowl
20728 on our way to see old Nantucket again! I think, sir, they have some
20729 such mild blue days, even as this, in Nantucket.”
20730 
20731 “They have, they have. I have seen them—some summer days in the
20732 morning. About this time—yes, it is his noon nap now—the boy
20733 vivaciously wakes; sits up in bed; and his mother tells him of me, of
20734 cannibal old me; how I am abroad upon the deep, but will yet come back
20735 to dance him again.”
20736 
20737 “’Tis my Mary, my Mary herself! She promised that my boy, every
20738 morning, should be carried to the hill to catch the first glimpse of
20739 his father’s sail! Yes, yes! no more! it is done! we head for
20740 Nantucket! Come, my Captain, study out the course, and let us away!
20741 See, see! the boy’s face from the window! the boy’s hand on the hill!”
20742 
20743 But Ahab’s glance was averted; like a blighted fruit tree he shook, and
20744 cast his last, cindered apple to the soil.
20745 
20746 “What is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what
20747 cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor
20748 commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep
20749 pushing, and crowding, and jamming myself on all the time; recklessly
20750 making me ready to do what in my own proper, natural heart, I durst not
20751 so much as dare? Is Ahab, Ahab? Is it I, God, or who, that lifts this
20752 arm? But if the great sun move not of himself; but is as an errand-boy
20753 in heaven; nor one single star can revolve, but by some invisible
20754 power; how then can this one small heart beat; this one small brain
20755 think thoughts; unless God does that beating, does that thinking, does
20756 that living, and not I. By heaven, man, we are turned round and round
20757 in this world, like yonder windlass, and Fate is the handspike. And all
20758 the time, lo! that smiling sky, and this unsounded sea! Look! see yon
20759 Albicore! who put it into him to chase and fang that flying-fish? Where
20760 do murderers go, man! Who’s to doom, when the judge himself is dragged
20761 to the bar? But it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky; and
20762 the air smells now, as if it blew from a far-away meadow; they have
20763 been making hay somewhere under the slopes of the Andes, Starbuck, and
20764 the mowers are sleeping among the new-mown hay. Sleeping? Aye, toil we
20765 how we may, we all sleep at last on the field. Sleep? Aye, and rust
20766 amid greenness; as last year’s scythes flung down, and left in the
20767 half-cut swaths—Starbuck!”
20768 
20769 But blanched to a corpse’s hue with despair, the Mate had stolen away.
20770 
20771 Ahab crossed the deck to gaze over on the other side; but started at
20772 two reflected, fixed eyes in the water there. Fedallah was motionlessly
20773 leaning over the same rail.
20774 
20775 
20776 CHAPTER 133. The Chase—First Day.
20777 
20778 That night, in the mid-watch, when the old man—as his wont at
20779 intervals—stepped forth from the scuttle in which he leaned, and went
20780 to his pivot-hole, he suddenly thrust out his face fiercely, snuffing
20781 up the sea air as a sagacious ship’s dog will, in drawing nigh to some
20782 barbarous isle. He declared that a whale must be near. Soon that
20783 peculiar odor, sometimes to a great distance given forth by the living
20784 sperm whale, was palpable to all the watch; nor was any mariner
20785 surprised when, after inspecting the compass, and then the dog-vane,
20786 and then ascertaining the precise bearing of the odor as nearly as
20787 possible, Ahab rapidly ordered the ship’s course to be slightly
20788 altered, and the sail to be shortened.
20789 
20790 The acute policy dictating these movements was sufficiently vindicated
20791 at daybreak, by the sight of a long sleek on the sea directly and
20792 lengthwise ahead, smooth as oil, and resembling in the pleated watery
20793 wrinkles bordering it, the polished metallic-like marks of some swift
20794 tide-rip, at the mouth of a deep, rapid stream.
20795 
20796 “Man the mast-heads! Call all hands!”
20797 
20798 Thundering with the butts of three clubbed handspikes on the forecastle
20799 deck, Daggoo roused the sleepers with such judgment claps that they
20800 seemed to exhale from the scuttle, so instantaneously did they appear
20801 with their clothes in their hands.
20802 
20803 “What d’ye see?” cried Ahab, flattening his face to the sky.
20804 
20805 “Nothing, nothing sir!” was the sound hailing down in reply.
20806 
20807 “T’gallant sails!—stunsails! alow and aloft, and on both sides!”
20808 
20809 All sail being set, he now cast loose the life-line, reserved for
20810 swaying him to the main royal-mast head; and in a few moments they were
20811 hoisting him thither, when, while but two thirds of the way aloft, and
20812 while peering ahead through the horizontal vacancy between the
20813 main-top-sail and top-gallant-sail, he raised a gull-like cry in the
20814 air. “There she blows!—there she blows! A hump like a snow-hill! It is
20815 Moby Dick!”
20816 
20817 Fired by the cry which seemed simultaneously taken up by the three
20818 look-outs, the men on deck rushed to the rigging to behold the famous
20819 whale they had so long been pursuing. Ahab had now gained his final
20820 perch, some feet above the other look-outs, Tashtego standing just
20821 beneath him on the cap of the top-gallant-mast, so that the Indian’s
20822 head was almost on a level with Ahab’s heel. From this height the whale
20823 was now seen some mile or so ahead, at every roll of the sea revealing
20824 his high sparkling hump, and regularly jetting his silent spout into
20825 the air. To the credulous mariners it seemed the same silent spout they
20826 had so long ago beheld in the moonlit Atlantic and Indian Oceans.
20827 
20828 “And did none of ye see it before?” cried Ahab, hailing the perched men
20829 all around him.
20830 
20831 “I saw him almost that same instant, sir, that Captain Ahab did, and I
20832 cried out,” said Tashtego.
20833 
20834 “Not the same instant; not the same—no, the doubloon is mine, Fate
20835 reserved the doubloon for me. _I_ only; none of ye could have raised
20836 the White Whale first. There she blows!—there she blows!—there she
20837 blows! There again!—there again!” he cried, in long-drawn, lingering,
20838 methodic tones, attuned to the gradual prolongings of the whale’s
20839 visible jets. “He’s going to sound! In stunsails! Down
20840 top-gallant-sails! Stand by three boats. Mr. Starbuck, remember, stay
20841 on board, and keep the ship. Helm there! Luff, luff a point! So;
20842 steady, man, steady! There go flukes! No, no; only black water! All
20843 ready the boats there? Stand by, stand by! Lower me, Mr. Starbuck;
20844 lower, lower,—quick, quicker!” and he slid through the air to the deck.
20845 
20846 “He is heading straight to leeward, sir,” cried Stubb, “right away from
20847 us; cannot have seen the ship yet.”
20848 
20849 “Be dumb, man! Stand by the braces! Hard down the helm!—brace up!
20850 Shiver her!—shiver her!—So; well that! Boats, boats!”
20851 
20852 Soon all the boats but Starbuck’s were dropped; all the boat-sails
20853 set—all the paddles plying; with rippling swiftness, shooting to
20854 leeward; and Ahab heading the onset. A pale, death-glimmer lit up
20855 Fedallah’s sunken eyes; a hideous motion gnawed his mouth.
20856 
20857 Like noiseless nautilus shells, their light prows sped through the sea;
20858 but only slowly they neared the foe. As they neared him, the ocean grew
20859 still more smooth; seemed drawing a carpet over its waves; seemed a
20860 noon-meadow, so serenely it spread. At length the breathless hunter
20861 came so nigh his seemingly unsuspecting prey, that his entire dazzling
20862 hump was distinctly visible, sliding along the sea as if an isolated
20863 thing, and continually set in a revolving ring of finest, fleecy,
20864 greenish foam. He saw the vast, involved wrinkles of the slightly
20865 projecting head beyond. Before it, far out on the soft Turkish-rugged
20866 waters, went the glistening white shadow from his broad, milky
20867 forehead, a musical rippling playfully accompanying the shade; and
20868 behind, the blue waters interchangeably flowed over into the moving
20869 valley of his steady wake; and on either hand bright bubbles arose and
20870 danced by his side. But these were broken again by the light toes of
20871 hundreds of gay fowl softly feathering the sea, alternate with their
20872 fitful flight; and like to some flag-staff rising from the painted hull
20873 of an argosy, the tall but shattered pole of a recent lance projected
20874 from the white whale’s back; and at intervals one of the cloud of
20875 soft-toed fowls hovering, and to and fro skimming like a canopy over
20876 the fish, silently perched and rocked on this pole, the long tail
20877 feathers streaming like pennons.
20878 
20879 A gentle joyousness—a mighty mildness of repose in swiftness, invested
20880 the gliding whale. Not the white bull Jupiter swimming away with
20881 ravished Europa clinging to his graceful horns; his lovely, leering
20882 eyes sideways intent upon the maid; with smooth bewitching fleetness,
20883 rippling straight for the nuptial bower in Crete; not Jove, not that
20884 great majesty Supreme! did surpass the glorified White Whale as he so
20885 divinely swam.
20886 
20887 On each soft side—coincident with the parted swell, that but once
20888 leaving him, then flowed so wide away—on each bright side, the whale
20889 shed off enticings. No wonder there had been some among the hunters who
20890 namelessly transported and allured by all this serenity, had ventured
20891 to assail it; but had fatally found that quietude but the vesture of
20892 tornadoes. Yet calm, enticing calm, oh, whale! thou glidest on, to all
20893 who for the first time eye thee, no matter how many in that same way
20894 thou may’st have bejuggled and destroyed before.
20895 
20896 And thus, through the serene tranquillities of the tropical sea, among
20897 waves whose hand-clappings were suspended by exceeding rapture, Moby
20898 Dick moved on, still withholding from sight the full terrors of his
20899 submerged trunk, entirely hiding the wrenched hideousness of his jaw.
20900 But soon the fore part of him slowly rose from the water; for an
20901 instant his whole marbleized body formed a high arch, like Virginia’s
20902 Natural Bridge, and warningly waving his bannered flukes in the air,
20903 the grand god revealed himself, sounded, and went out of sight.
20904 Hoveringly halting, and dipping on the wing, the white sea-fowls
20905 longingly lingered over the agitated pool that he left.
20906 
20907 With oars apeak, and paddles down, the sheets of their sails adrift,
20908 the three boats now stilly floated, awaiting Moby Dick’s reappearance.
20909 
20910 “An hour,” said Ahab, standing rooted in his boat’s stern; and he gazed
20911 beyond the whale’s place, towards the dim blue spaces and wide wooing
20912 vacancies to leeward. It was only an instant; for again his eyes seemed
20913 whirling round in his head as he swept the watery circle. The breeze
20914 now freshened; the sea began to swell.
20915 
20916 “The birds!—the birds!” cried Tashtego.
20917 
20918 In long Indian file, as when herons take wing, the white birds were now
20919 all flying towards Ahab’s boat; and when within a few yards began
20920 fluttering over the water there, wheeling round and round, with joyous,
20921 expectant cries. Their vision was keener than man’s; Ahab could
20922 discover no sign in the sea. But suddenly as he peered down and down
20923 into its depths, he profoundly saw a white living spot no bigger than a
20924 white weasel, with wonderful celerity uprising, and magnifying as it
20925 rose, till it turned, and then there were plainly revealed two long
20926 crooked rows of white, glistening teeth, floating up from the
20927 undiscoverable bottom. It was Moby Dick’s open mouth and scrolled jaw;
20928 his vast, shadowed bulk still half blending with the blue of the sea.
20929 The glittering mouth yawned beneath the boat like an open-doored marble
20930 tomb; and giving one sidelong sweep with his steering oar, Ahab whirled
20931 the craft aside from this tremendous apparition. Then, calling upon
20932 Fedallah to change places with him, went forward to the bows, and
20933 seizing Perth’s harpoon, commanded his crew to grasp their oars and
20934 stand by to stern.
20935 
20936 Now, by reason of this timely spinning round the boat upon its axis,
20937 its bow, by anticipation, was made to face the whale’s head while yet
20938 under water. But as if perceiving this stratagem, Moby Dick, with that
20939 malicious intelligence ascribed to him, sidelingly transplanted
20940 himself, as it were, in an instant, shooting his pleated head
20941 lengthwise beneath the boat.
20942 
20943 Through and through; through every plank and each rib, it thrilled for
20944 an instant, the whale obliquely lying on his back, in the manner of a
20945 biting shark, slowly and feelingly taking its bows full within his
20946 mouth, so that the long, narrow, scrolled lower jaw curled high up into
20947 the open air, and one of the teeth caught in a row-lock. The bluish
20948 pearl-white of the inside of the jaw was within six inches of Ahab’s
20949 head, and reached higher than that. In this attitude the White Whale
20950 now shook the slight cedar as a mildly cruel cat her mouse. With
20951 unastonished eyes Fedallah gazed, and crossed his arms; but the
20952 tiger-yellow crew were tumbling over each other’s heads to gain the
20953 uttermost stern.
20954 
20955 And now, while both elastic gunwales were springing in and out, as the
20956 whale dallied with the doomed craft in this devilish way; and from his
20957 body being submerged beneath the boat, he could not be darted at from
20958 the bows, for the bows were almost inside of him, as it were; and while
20959 the other boats involuntarily paused, as before a quick crisis
20960 impossible to withstand, then it was that monomaniac Ahab, furious with
20961 this tantalizing vicinity of his foe, which placed him all alive and
20962 helpless in the very jaws he hated; frenzied with all this, he seized
20963 the long bone with his naked hands, and wildly strove to wrench it from
20964 its gripe. As now he thus vainly strove, the jaw slipped from him; the
20965 frail gunwales bent in, collapsed, and snapped, as both jaws, like an
20966 enormous shears, sliding further aft, bit the craft completely in
20967 twain, and locked themselves fast again in the sea, midway between the
20968 two floating wrecks. These floated aside, the broken ends drooping, the
20969 crew at the stern-wreck clinging to the gunwales, and striving to hold
20970 fast to the oars to lash them across.
20971 
20972 At that preluding moment, ere the boat was yet snapped, Ahab, the first
20973 to perceive the whale’s intent, by the crafty upraising of his head, a
20974 movement that loosed his hold for the time; at that moment his hand had
20975 made one final effort to push the boat out of the bite. But only
20976 slipping further into the whale’s mouth, and tilting over sideways as
20977 it slipped, the boat had shaken off his hold on the jaw; spilled him
20978 out of it, as he leaned to the push; and so he fell flat-faced upon the
20979 sea.
20980 
20981 Ripplingly withdrawing from his prey, Moby Dick now lay at a little
