20982 distance, vertically thrusting his oblong white head up and down in the
20983 billows; and at the same time slowly revolving his whole spindled body;
20984 so that when his vast wrinkled forehead rose—some twenty or more feet
20985 out of the water—the now rising swells, with all their confluent waves,
20986 dazzlingly broke against it; vindictively tossing their shivered spray
20987 still higher into the air.* So, in a gale, the but half baffled Channel
20988 billows only recoil from the base of the Eddystone, triumphantly to
20989 overleap its summit with their scud.
20990 
20991 *This motion is peculiar to the sperm whale. It receives its
20992 designation (pitchpoling) from its being likened to that preliminary
20993 up-and-down poise of the whale-lance, in the exercise called
20994 pitchpoling, previously described. By this motion the whale must best
20995 and most comprehensively view whatever objects may be encircling him.
20996 
20997 But soon resuming his horizontal attitude, Moby Dick swam swiftly round
20998 and round the wrecked crew; sideways churning the water in his vengeful
20999 wake, as if lashing himself up to still another and more deadly
21000 assault. The sight of the splintered boat seemed to madden him, as the
21001 blood of grapes and mulberries cast before Antiochus’s elephants in the
21002 book of Maccabees. Meanwhile Ahab half smothered in the foam of the
21003 whale’s insolent tail, and too much of a cripple to swim,—though he
21004 could still keep afloat, even in the heart of such a whirlpool as that;
21005 helpless Ahab’s head was seen, like a tossed bubble which the least
21006 chance shock might burst. From the boat’s fragmentary stern, Fedallah
21007 incuriously and mildly eyed him; the clinging crew, at the other
21008 drifting end, could not succor him; more than enough was it for them to
21009 look to themselves. For so revolvingly appalling was the White Whale’s
21010 aspect, and so planetarily swift the ever-contracting circles he made,
21011 that he seemed horizontally swooping upon them. And though the other
21012 boats, unharmed, still hovered hard by; still they dared not pull into
21013 the eddy to strike, lest that should be the signal for the instant
21014 destruction of the jeopardized castaways, Ahab and all; nor in that
21015 case could they themselves hope to escape. With straining eyes, then,
21016 they remained on the outer edge of the direful zone, whose centre had
21017 now become the old man’s head.
21018 
21019 Meantime, from the beginning all this had been descried from the ship’s
21020 mast heads; and squaring her yards, she had borne down upon the scene;
21021 and was now so nigh, that Ahab in the water hailed her!—“Sail on
21022 the”—but that moment a breaking sea dashed on him from Moby Dick, and
21023 whelmed him for the time. But struggling out of it again, and chancing
21024 to rise on a towering crest, he shouted,—“Sail on the whale!—Drive him
21025 off!”
21026 
21027 The Pequod’s prows were pointed; and breaking up the charmed circle,
21028 she effectually parted the white whale from his victim. As he sullenly
21029 swam off, the boats flew to the rescue.
21030 
21031 Dragged into Stubb’s boat with blood-shot, blinded eyes, the white
21032 brine caking in his wrinkles; the long tension of Ahab’s bodily
21033 strength did crack, and helplessly he yielded to his body’s doom: for a
21034 time, lying all crushed in the bottom of Stubb’s boat, like one trodden
21035 under foot of herds of elephants. Far inland, nameless wails came from
21036 him, as desolate sounds from out ravines.
21037 
21038 But this intensity of his physical prostration did but so much the more
21039 abbreviate it. In an instant’s compass, great hearts sometimes condense
21040 to one deep pang, the sum total of those shallow pains kindly diffused
21041 through feebler men’s whole lives. And so, such hearts, though summary
21042 in each one suffering; still, if the gods decree it, in their life-time
21043 aggregate a whole age of woe, wholly made up of instantaneous
21044 intensities; for even in their pointless centres, those noble natures
21045 contain the entire circumferences of inferior souls.
21046 
21047 “The harpoon,” said Ahab, half way rising, and draggingly leaning on
21048 one bended arm—“is it safe?”
21049 
21050 “Aye, sir, for it was not darted; this is it,” said Stubb, showing it.
21051 
21052 “Lay it before me;—any missing men?”
21053 
21054 “One, two, three, four, five;—there were five oars, sir, and here are
21055 five men.”
21056 
21057 “That’s good.—Help me, man; I wish to stand. So, so, I see him! there!
21058 there! going to leeward still; what a leaping spout!—Hands off from me!
21059 The eternal sap runs up in Ahab’s bones again! Set the sail; out oars;
21060 the helm!”
21061 
21062 It is often the case that when a boat is stove, its crew, being picked
21063 up by another boat, help to work that second boat; and the chase is
21064 thus continued with what is called double-banked oars. It was thus now.
21065 But the added power of the boat did not equal the added power of the
21066 whale, for he seemed to have treble-banked his every fin; swimming with
21067 a velocity which plainly showed, that if now, under these
21068 circumstances, pushed on, the chase would prove an indefinitely
21069 prolonged, if not a hopeless one; nor could any crew endure for so long
21070 a period, such an unintermitted, intense straining at the oar; a thing
21071 barely tolerable only in some one brief vicissitude. The ship itself,
21072 then, as it sometimes happens, offered the most promising intermediate
21073 means of overtaking the chase. Accordingly, the boats now made for her,
21074 and were soon swayed up to their cranes—the two parts of the wrecked
21075 boat having been previously secured by her—and then hoisting everything
21076 to her side, and stacking her canvas high up, and sideways
21077 outstretching it with stun-sails, like the double-jointed wings of an
21078 albatross; the Pequod bore down in the leeward wake of Moby-Dick. At
21079 the well known, methodic intervals, the whale’s glittering spout was
21080 regularly announced from the manned mast-heads; and when he would be
21081 reported as just gone down, Ahab would take the time, and then pacing
21082 the deck, binnacle-watch in hand, so soon as the last second of the
21083 allotted hour expired, his voice was heard.—“Whose is the doubloon now?
21084 D’ye see him?” and if the reply was, No, sir! straightway he commanded
21085 them to lift him to his perch. In this way the day wore on; Ahab, now
21086 aloft and motionless; anon, unrestingly pacing the planks.
21087 
21088 As he was thus walking, uttering no sound, except to hail the men
21089 aloft, or to bid them hoist a sail still higher, or to spread one to a
21090 still greater breadth—thus to and fro pacing, beneath his slouched hat,
21091 at every turn he passed his own wrecked boat, which had been dropped
21092 upon the quarter-deck, and lay there reversed; broken bow to shattered
21093 stern. At last he paused before it; and as in an already over-clouded
21094 sky fresh troops of clouds will sometimes sail across, so over the old
21095 man’s face there now stole some such added gloom as this.
21096 
21097 Stubb saw him pause; and perhaps intending, not vainly, though, to
21098 evince his own unabated fortitude, and thus keep up a valiant place in
21099 his Captain’s mind, he advanced, and eyeing the wreck exclaimed—“The
21100 thistle the ass refused; it pricked his mouth too keenly, sir; ha! ha!”
21101 
21102 “What soulless thing is this that laughs before a wreck? Man, man! did
21103 I not know thee brave as fearless fire (and as mechanical) I could
21104 swear thou wert a poltroon. Groan nor laugh should be heard before a
21105 wreck.”
21106 
21107 “Aye, sir,” said Starbuck drawing near, “’tis a solemn sight; an omen,
21108 and an ill one.”
21109 
21110 “Omen? omen?—the dictionary! If the gods think to speak outright to
21111 man, they will honorably speak outright; not shake their heads, and
21112 give an old wives’ darkling hint.—Begone! Ye two are the opposite poles
21113 of one thing; Starbuck is Stubb reversed, and Stubb is Starbuck; and ye
21114 two are all mankind; and Ahab stands alone among the millions of the
21115 peopled earth, nor gods nor men his neighbors! Cold, cold—I shiver!—How
21116 now? Aloft there! D’ye see him? Sing out for every spout, though he
21117 spout ten times a second!”
21118 
21119 The day was nearly done; only the hem of his golden robe was rustling.
21120 Soon, it was almost dark, but the look-out men still remained unset.
21121 
21122 “Can’t see the spout now, sir;—too dark”—cried a voice from the air.
21123 
21124 “How heading when last seen?”
21125 
21126 “As before, sir,—straight to leeward.”
21127 
21128 “Good! he will travel slower now ’tis night. Down royals and
21129 top-gallant stun-sails, Mr. Starbuck. We must not run over him before
21130 morning; he’s making a passage now, and may heave-to a while. Helm
21131 there! keep her full before the wind!—Aloft! come down!—Mr. Stubb, send
21132 a fresh hand to the fore-mast head, and see it manned till
21133 morning.”—Then advancing towards the doubloon in the main-mast—“Men,
21134 this gold is mine, for I earned it; but I shall let it abide here till
21135 the White Whale is dead; and then, whosoever of ye first raises him,
21136 upon the day he shall be killed, this gold is that man’s; and if on
21137 that day I shall again raise him, then, ten times its sum shall be
21138 divided among all of ye! Away now!—the deck is thine, sir!”
21139 
21140 And so saying, he placed himself half way within the scuttle, and
21141 slouching his hat, stood there till dawn, except when at intervals
21142 rousing himself to see how the night wore on.
21143 
21144 
21145 CHAPTER 134. The Chase—Second Day.
21146 
21147 At day-break, the three mast-heads were punctually manned afresh.
21148 
21149 “D’ye see him?” cried Ahab after allowing a little space for the light
21150 to spread.
21151 
21152 “See nothing, sir.”
21153 
21154 “Turn up all hands and make sail! he travels faster than I thought
21155 for;—the top-gallant sails!—aye, they should have been kept on her all
21156 night. But no matter—’tis but resting for the rush.”
21157 
21158 Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular
21159 whale, continued through day into night, and through night into day, is
21160 a thing by no means unprecedented in the South sea fishery. For such is
21161 the wonderful skill, prescience of experience, and invincible
21162 confidence acquired by some great natural geniuses among the Nantucket
21163 commanders; that from the simple observation of a whale when last
21164 descried, they will, under certain given circumstances, pretty
21165 accurately foretell both the direction in which he will continue to
21166 swim for a time, while out of sight, as well as his probable rate of
21167 progression during that period. And, in these cases, somewhat as a
21168 pilot, when about losing sight of a coast, whose general trending he
21169 well knows, and which he desires shortly to return to again, but at
21170 some further point; like as this pilot stands by his compass, and takes
21171 the precise bearing of the cape at present visible, in order the more
21172 certainly to hit aright the remote, unseen headland, eventually to be
21173 visited: so does the fisherman, at his compass, with the whale; for
21174 after being chased, and diligently marked, through several hours of
21175 daylight, then, when night obscures the fish, the creature’s future
21176 wake through the darkness is almost as established to the sagacious
21177 mind of the hunter, as the pilot’s coast is to him. So that to this
21178 hunter’s wondrous skill, the proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in
21179 water, a wake, is to all desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the
21180 steadfast land. And as the mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway
21181 is so familiarly known in its every pace, that, with watches in their
21182 hands, men time his rate as doctors that of a baby’s pulse; and lightly
21183 say of it, the up train or the down train will reach such or such a
21184 spot, at such or such an hour; even so, almost, there are occasions
21185 when these Nantucketers time that other Leviathan of the deep,
21186 according to the observed humor of his speed; and say to themselves, so
21187 many hours hence this whale will have gone two hundred miles, will have
21188 about reached this or that degree of latitude or longitude. But to
21189 render this acuteness at all successful in the end, the wind and the
21190 sea must be the whaleman’s allies; for of what present avail to the
21191 becalmed or windbound mariner is the skill that assures him he is
21192 exactly ninety-three leagues and a quarter from his port? Inferable
21193 from these statements, are many collateral subtile matters touching the
21194 chase of whales.
21195 
21196 The ship tore on; leaving such a furrow in the sea as when a
21197 cannon-ball, missent, becomes a plough-share and turns up the level
21198 field.
21199 
21200 “By salt and hemp!” cried Stubb, “but this swift motion of the deck
21201 creeps up one’s legs and tingles at the heart. This ship and I are two
21202 brave fellows!—Ha, ha! Some one take me up, and launch me, spine-wise,
21203 on the sea,—for by live-oaks! my spine’s a keel. Ha, ha! we go the gait
21204 that leaves no dust behind!”
21205 
21206 “There she blows—she blows!—she blows!—right ahead!” was now the
21207 mast-head cry.
21208 
21209 “Aye, aye!” cried Stubb, “I knew it—ye can’t escape—blow on and split
21210 your spout, O whale! the mad fiend himself is after ye! blow your
21211 trump—blister your lungs!—Ahab will dam off your blood, as a miller
21212 shuts his watergate upon the stream!”
21213 
21214 And Stubb did but speak out for well nigh all that crew. The frenzies
21215 of the chase had by this time worked them bubblingly up, like old wine
21216 worked anew. Whatever pale fears and forebodings some of them might
21217 have felt before; these were not only now kept out of sight through the
21218 growing awe of Ahab, but they were broken up, and on all sides routed,
21219 as timid prairie hares that scatter before the bounding bison. The hand
21220 of Fate had snatched all their souls; and by the stirring perils of the
21221 previous day; the rack of the past night’s suspense; the fixed,
21222 unfearing, blind, reckless way in which their wild craft went plunging
21223 towards its flying mark; by all these things, their hearts were bowled
21224 along. The wind that made great bellies of their sails, and rushed the
21225 vessel on by arms invisible as irresistible; this seemed the symbol of
21226 that unseen agency which so enslaved them to the race.
21227 
21228 They were one man, not thirty. For as the one ship that held them all;
21229 though it was put together of all contrasting things—oak, and maple,
21230 and pine wood; iron, and pitch, and hemp—yet all these ran into each
21231 other in the one concrete hull, which shot on its way, both balanced
21232 and directed by the long central keel; even so, all the individualities
21233 of the crew, this man’s valor, that man’s fear; guilt and guiltiness,
21234 all varieties were welded into oneness, and were all directed to that
21235 fatal goal which Ahab their one lord and keel did point to.
21236 
21237 The rigging lived. The mast-heads, like the tops of tall palms, were
21238 outspreadingly tufted with arms and legs. Clinging to a spar with one
21239 hand, some reached forth the other with impatient wavings; others,
21240 shading their eyes from the vivid sunlight, sat far out on the rocking
21241 yards; all the spars in full bearing of mortals, ready and ripe for
21242 their fate. Ah! how they still strove through that infinite blueness to
21243 seek out the thing that might destroy them!
21244 
21245 “Why sing ye not out for him, if ye see him?” cried Ahab, when, after
21246 the lapse of some minutes since the first cry, no more had been heard.
21247 “Sway me up, men; ye have been deceived; not Moby Dick casts one odd
21248 jet that way, and then disappears.”
21249 
21250 It was even so; in their headlong eagerness, the men had mistaken some
21251 other thing for the whale-spout, as the event itself soon proved; for
21252 hardly had Ahab reached his perch; hardly was the rope belayed to its
21253 pin on deck, when he struck the key-note to an orchestra, that made the
21254 air vibrate as with the combined discharges of rifles. The triumphant
21255 halloo of thirty buckskin lungs was heard, as—much nearer to the ship
21256 than the place of the imaginary jet, less than a mile ahead—Moby Dick
21257 bodily burst into view! For not by any calm and indolent spoutings; not
21258 by the peaceable gush of that mystic fountain in his head, did the
21259 White Whale now reveal his vicinity; but by the far more wondrous
21260 phenomenon of breaching. Rising with his utmost velocity from the
21261 furthest depths, the Sperm Whale thus booms his entire bulk into the
21262 pure element of air, and piling up a mountain of dazzling foam, shows
21263 his place to the distance of seven miles and more. In those moments,
21264 the torn, enraged waves he shakes off, seem his mane; in some cases,
21265 this breaching is his act of defiance.
21266 
21267 “There she breaches! there she breaches!” was the cry, as in his
21268 immeasurable bravadoes the White Whale tossed himself salmon-like to
21269 Heaven. So suddenly seen in the blue plain of the sea, and relieved
21270 against the still bluer margin of the sky, the spray that he raised,
21271 for the moment, intolerably glittered and glared like a glacier; and
21272 stood there gradually fading and fading away from its first sparkling
21273 intensity, to the dim mistiness of an advancing shower in a vale.
21274 
21275 “Aye, breach your last to the sun, Moby Dick!” cried Ahab, “thy hour
21276 and thy harpoon are at hand!—Down! down all of ye, but one man at the
21277 fore. The boats!—stand by!”
21278 
21279 Unmindful of the tedious rope-ladders of the shrouds, the men, like
21280 shooting stars, slid to the deck, by the isolated backstays and
21281 halyards; while Ahab, less dartingly, but still rapidly was dropped
21282 from his perch.
21283 
21284 “Lower away,” he cried, so soon as he had reached his boat—a spare one,
21285 rigged the afternoon previous. “Mr. Starbuck, the ship is thine—keep
21286 away from the boats, but keep near them. Lower, all!”
21287 
21288 As if to strike a quick terror into them, by this time being the first
21289 assailant himself, Moby Dick had turned, and was now coming for the
21290 three crews. Ahab’s boat was central; and cheering his men, he told
21291 them he would take the whale head-and-head,—that is, pull straight up
21292 to his forehead,—a not uncommon thing; for when within a certain limit,
21293 such a course excludes the coming onset from the whale’s sidelong
21294 vision. But ere that close limit was gained, and while yet all three
21295 boats were plain as the ship’s three masts to his eye; the White Whale
21296 churning himself into furious speed, almost in an instant as it were,
21297 rushing among the boats with open jaws, and a lashing tail, offered
21298 appalling battle on every side; and heedless of the irons darted at him
21299 from every boat, seemed only intent on annihilating each separate plank
21300 of which those boats were made. But skilfully manœuvred, incessantly
21301 wheeling like trained chargers in the field; the boats for a while
21302 eluded him; though, at times, but by a plank’s breadth; while all the
21303 time, Ahab’s unearthly slogan tore every other cry but his to shreds.
21304 
21305 But at last in his untraceable evolutions, the White Whale so crossed
21306 and recrossed, and in a thousand ways entangled the slack of the three
21307 lines now fast to him, that they foreshortened, and, of themselves,
21308 warped the devoted boats towards the planted irons in him; though now
21309 for a moment the whale drew aside a little, as if to rally for a more
21310 tremendous charge. Seizing that opportunity, Ahab first paid out more
21311 line: and then was rapidly hauling and jerking in upon it again—hoping
21312 that way to disencumber it of some snarls—when lo!—a sight more savage
21313 than the embattled teeth of sharks!
21314 
21315 Caught and twisted—corkscrewed in the mazes of the line, loose harpoons
21316 and lances, with all their bristling barbs and points, came flashing
21317 and dripping up to the chocks in the bows of Ahab’s boat. Only one
21318 thing could be done. Seizing the boat-knife, he critically reached
21319 within—through—and then, without—the rays of steel; dragged in the line
21320 beyond, passed it, inboard, to the bowsman, and then, twice sundering
21321 the rope near the chocks—dropped the intercepted fagot of steel into
21322 the sea; and was all fast again. That instant, the White Whale made a
21323 sudden rush among the remaining tangles of the other lines; by so
21324 doing, irresistibly dragged the more involved boats of Stubb and Flask
21325 towards his flukes; dashed them together like two rolling husks on a
21326 surf-beaten beach, and then, diving down into the sea, disappeared in a
21327 boiling maelstrom, in which, for a space, the odorous cedar chips of
21328 the wrecks danced round and round, like the grated nutmeg in a swiftly
21329 stirred bowl of punch.
21330 
21331 While the two crews were yet circling in the waters, reaching out after
21332 the revolving line-tubs, oars, and other floating furniture, while
21333 aslope little Flask bobbed up and down like an empty vial, twitching
21334 his legs upwards to escape the dreaded jaws of sharks; and Stubb was
21335 lustily singing out for some one to ladle him up; and while the old
21336 man’s line—now parting—admitted of his pulling into the creamy pool to
21337 rescue whom he could;—in that wild simultaneousness of a thousand
21338 concreted perils,—Ahab’s yet unstricken boat seemed drawn up towards
21339 Heaven by invisible wires,—as, arrow-like, shooting perpendicularly
21340 from the sea, the White Whale dashed his broad forehead against its
21341 bottom, and sent it, turning over and over, into the air; till it fell
21342 again—gunwale downwards—and Ahab and his men struggled out from under
21343 it, like seals from a sea-side cave.
21344 
21345 The first uprising momentum of the whale—modifying its direction as he
21346 struck the surface—involuntarily launched him along it, to a little
21347 distance from the centre of the destruction he had made; and with his
21348 back to it, he now lay for a moment slowly feeling with his flukes from
21349 side to side; and whenever a stray oar, bit of plank, the least chip or
21350 crumb of the boats touched his skin, his tail swiftly drew back, and
21351 came sideways smiting the sea. But soon, as if satisfied that his work
21352 for that time was done, he pushed his pleated forehead through the
21353 ocean, and trailing after him the intertangled lines, continued his
21354 leeward way at a traveller’s methodic pace.
21355 
21356 As before, the attentive ship having descried the whole fight, again
21357 came bearing down to the rescue, and dropping a boat, picked up the
21358 floating mariners, tubs, oars, and whatever else could be caught at,
21359 and safely landed them on her decks. Some sprained shoulders, wrists,
21360 and ankles; livid contusions; wrenched harpoons and lances;
21361 inextricable intricacies of rope; shattered oars and planks; all these
21362 were there; but no fatal or even serious ill seemed to have befallen
21363 any one. As with Fedallah the day before, so Ahab was now found grimly
21364 clinging to his boat’s broken half, which afforded a comparatively easy
21365 float; nor did it so exhaust him as the previous day’s mishap.
21366 
21367 But when he was helped to the deck, all eyes were fastened upon him; as
21368 instead of standing by himself he still half-hung upon the shoulder of
21369 Starbuck, who had thus far been the foremost to assist him. His ivory
21370 leg had been snapped off, leaving but one short sharp splinter.
21371 
21372 “Aye, aye, Starbuck, ’tis sweet to lean sometimes, be the leaner who he
21373 will; and would old Ahab had leaned oftener than he has.”
21374 
21375 “The ferrule has not stood, sir,” said the carpenter, now coming up; “I
21376 put good work into that leg.”
21377 
21378 “But no bones broken, sir, I hope,” said Stubb with true concern.
21379 
21380 “Aye! and all splintered to pieces, Stubb!—d’ye see it.—But even with a
21381 broken bone, old Ahab is untouched; and I account no living bone of
21382 mine one jot more me, than this dead one that’s lost. Nor white whale,
21383 nor man, nor fiend, can so much as graze old Ahab in his own proper and
21384 inaccessible being. Can any lead touch yonder floor, any mast scrape
21385 yonder roof?—Aloft there! which way?”
21386 
21387 “Dead to leeward, sir.”
21388 
21389 “Up helm, then; pile on the sail again, ship keepers! down the rest of
21390 the spare boats and rig them—Mr. Starbuck away, and muster the boat’s
21391 crews.”
21392 
21393 “Let me first help thee towards the bulwarks, sir.”
21394 
21395 “Oh, oh, oh! how this splinter gores me now! Accursed fate! that the
21396 unconquerable captain in the soul should have such a craven mate!”
21397 
21398 “Sir?”
21399 
21400 “My body, man, not thee. Give me something for a cane—there, that
21401 shivered lance will do. Muster the men. Surely I have not seen him yet.
21402 By heaven it cannot be!—missing?—quick! call them all.”
21403 
21404 The old man’s hinted thought was true. Upon mustering the company, the
21405 Parsee was not there.
21406 
21407 “The Parsee!” cried Stubb—“he must have been caught in——”
21408 
21409 “The black vomit wrench thee!—run all of ye above, alow, cabin,
21410 forecastle—find him—not gone—not gone!”
21411 
21412 But quickly they returned to him with the tidings that the Parsee was
21413 nowhere to be found.
21414 
21415 “Aye, sir,” said Stubb—“caught among the tangles of your line—I thought
21416 I saw him dragging under.”
21417 
21418 “_My_ line! _my_ line? Gone?—gone? What means that little word?—What
21419 death-knell rings in it, that old Ahab shakes as if he were the belfry.
21420 The harpoon, too!—toss over the litter there,—d’ye see it?—the forged
21421 iron, men, the white whale’s—no, no, no,—blistered fool! this hand did
21422 dart it!—’tis in the fish!—Aloft there! Keep him nailed—Quick!—all
21423 hands to the rigging of the boats—collect the oars—harpooneers! the
21424 irons, the irons!—hoist the royals higher—a pull on all the
21425 sheets!—helm there! steady, steady for your life! I’ll ten times girdle
21426 the unmeasured globe; yea and dive straight through it, but I’ll slay
21427 him yet!”
21428 
21429 “Great God! but for one single instant show thyself,” cried Starbuck;
21430 “never, never wilt thou capture him, old man—In Jesus’ name no more of
21431 this, that’s worse than devil’s madness. Two days chased; twice stove
21432 to splinters; thy very leg once more snatched from under thee; thy evil
21433 shadow gone—all good angels mobbing thee with warnings:—what more
21434 wouldst thou have?—Shall we keep chasing this murderous fish till he
21435 swamps the last man? Shall we be dragged by him to the bottom of the
21436 sea? Shall we be towed by him to the infernal world? Oh, oh,—Impiety
21437 and blasphemy to hunt him more!”
21438 
21439 “Starbuck, of late I’ve felt strangely moved to thee; ever since that
21440 hour we both saw—thou know’st what, in one another’s eyes. But in this
21441 matter of the whale, be the front of thy face to me as the palm of this
21442 hand—a lipless, unfeatured blank. Ahab is for ever Ahab, man. This
21443 whole act’s immutably decreed. ’Twas rehearsed by thee and me a billion
21444 years before this ocean rolled. Fool! I am the Fates’ lieutenant; I act
21445 under orders. Look thou, underling! that thou obeyest mine.—Stand round
21446 me, men. Ye see an old man cut down to the stump; leaning on a shivered
21447 lance; propped up on a lonely foot. ’Tis Ahab—his body’s part; but
21448 Ahab’s soul’s a centipede, that moves upon a hundred legs. I feel
21449 strained, half stranded, as ropes that tow dismasted frigates in a
21450 gale; and I may look so. But ere I break, ye’ll hear me crack; and till
21451 ye hear _that_, know that Ahab’s hawser tows his purpose yet. Believe
21452 ye, men, in the things called omens? Then laugh aloud, and cry encore!
21453 For ere they drown, drowning things will twice rise to the surface;
21454 then rise again, to sink for evermore. So with Moby Dick—two days he’s
21455 floated—tomorrow will be the third. Aye, men, he’ll rise once more,—but
21456 only to spout his last! D’ye feel brave men, brave?”
21457 
21458 “As fearless fire,” cried Stubb.
21459 
21460 “And as mechanical,” muttered Ahab. Then as the men went forward, he
21461 muttered on: “The things called omens! And yesterday I talked the same
21462 to Starbuck there, concerning my broken boat. Oh! how valiantly I seek
21463 to drive out of others’ hearts what’s clinched so fast in mine!—The
21464 Parsee—the Parsee!—gone, gone? and he was to go before:—but still was
21465 to be seen again ere I could perish—How’s that?—There’s a riddle now
21466 might baffle all the lawyers backed by the ghosts of the whole line of
21467 judges:—like a hawk’s beak it pecks my brain. _I’ll_, _I’ll_ solve it,
21468 though!”
21469 
21470 When dusk descended, the whale was still in sight to leeward.
21471 
21472 So once more the sail was shortened, and everything passed nearly as on
21473 the previous night; only, the sound of hammers, and the hum of the
21474 grindstone was heard till nearly daylight, as the men toiled by
21475 lanterns in the complete and careful rigging of the spare boats and
21476 sharpening their fresh weapons for the morrow. Meantime, of the broken
21477 keel of Ahab’s wrecked craft the carpenter made him another leg; while
21478 still as on the night before, slouched Ahab stood fixed within his
21479 scuttle; his hid, heliotrope glance anticipatingly gone backward on its
21480 dial; sat due eastward for the earliest sun.
21481 
21482 
21483 CHAPTER 135. The Chase.—Third Day.
21484 
21485 The morning of the third day dawned fair and fresh, and once more the
21486 solitary night-man at the fore-mast-head was relieved by crowds of the
21487 daylight look-outs, who dotted every mast and almost every spar.
21488 
21489 “D’ye see him?” cried Ahab; but the whale was not yet in sight.
21490 
21491 “In his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, that’s all. Helm
21492 there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going. What a lovely day
21493 again! were it a new-made world, and made for a summer-house to the
21494 angels, and this morning the first of its throwing open to them, a
21495 fairer day could not dawn upon that world. Here’s food for thought, had
21496 Ahab time to think; but Ahab never thinks; he only feels, feels, feels;
21497 _that’s_ tingling enough for mortal man! to think’s audacity. God only
21498 has that right and privilege. Thinking is, or ought to be, a coolness
21499 and a calmness; and our poor hearts throb, and our poor brains beat too
21500 much for that. And yet, I’ve sometimes thought my brain was very
21501 calm—frozen calm, this old skull cracks so, like a glass in which the
21502 contents turned to ice, and shiver it. And still this hair is growing
21503 now; this moment growing, and heat must breed it; but no, it’s like
21504 that sort of common grass that will grow anywhere, between the earthy
21505 clefts of Greenland ice or in Vesuvius lava. How the wild winds blow
21506 it; they whip it about me as the torn shreds of split sails lash the
21507 tossed ship they cling to. A vile wind that has no doubt blown ere this
21508 through prison corridors and cells, and wards of hospitals, and
21509 ventilated them, and now comes blowing hither as innocent as fleeces.
21510 Out upon it!—it’s tainted. Were I the wind, I’d blow no more on such a
21511 wicked, miserable world. I’d crawl somewhere to a cave, and slink
21512 there. And yet, ’tis a noble and heroic thing, the wind! who ever
21513 conquered it? In every fight it has the last and bitterest blow. Run
21514 tilting at it, and you but run through it. Ha! a coward wind that
21515 strikes stark naked men, but will not stand to receive a single blow.
21516 Even Ahab is a braver thing—a nobler thing than _that_. Would now the
21517 wind but had a body; but all the things that most exasperate and
21518 outrage mortal man, all these things are bodiless, but only bodiless as
21519 objects, not as agents. There’s a most special, a most cunning, oh, a
21520 most malicious difference! And yet, I say again, and swear it now, that
21521 there’s something all glorious and gracious in the wind. These warm
21522 Trade Winds, at least, that in the clear heavens blow straight on, in
21523 strong and steadfast, vigorous mildness; and veer not from their mark,
21524 however the baser currents of the sea may turn and tack, and mightiest
21525 Mississippies of the land swift and swerve about, uncertain where to go
21526 at last. And by the eternal Poles! these same Trades that so directly
21527 blow my good ship on; these Trades, or something like them—something so
21528 unchangeable, and full as strong, blow my keeled soul along! To it!
21529 Aloft there! What d’ye see?”
21530 
21531 “Nothing, sir.”
21532 
21533 “Nothing! and noon at hand! The doubloon goes a-begging! See the sun!
21534 Aye, aye, it must be so. I’ve oversailed him. How, got the start? Aye,
21535 he’s chasing _me_ now; not I, _him_—that’s bad; I might have known it,
21536 too. Fool! the lines—the harpoons he’s towing. Aye, aye, I have run him
21537 by last night. About! about! Come down, all of ye, but the regular look
21538 outs! Man the braces!”
21539 
21540 Steering as she had done, the wind had been somewhat on the Pequod’s
21541 quarter, so that now being pointed in the reverse direction, the braced
21542 ship sailed hard upon the breeze as she rechurned the cream in her own
21543 white wake.
21544 
21545 “Against the wind he now steers for the open jaw,” murmured Starbuck to
21546 himself, as he coiled the new-hauled main-brace upon the rail. “God
21547 keep us, but already my bones feel damp within me, and from the inside
21548 wet my flesh. I misdoubt me that I disobey my God in obeying him!”
21549 
21550 “Stand by to sway me up!” cried Ahab, advancing to the hempen basket.
21551 “We should meet him soon.”
21552 
21553 “Aye, aye, sir,” and straightway Starbuck did Ahab’s bidding, and once
21554 more Ahab swung on high.
21555 
21556 A whole hour now passed; gold-beaten out to ages. Time itself now held
21557 long breaths with keen suspense. But at last, some three points off the
21558 weather bow, Ahab descried the spout again, and instantly from the
21559 three mast-heads three shrieks went up as if the tongues of fire had
21560 voiced it.
21561 
21562 “Forehead to forehead I meet thee, this third time, Moby Dick! On deck
21563 there!—brace sharper up; crowd her into the wind’s eye. He’s too far
21564 off to lower yet, Mr. Starbuck. The sails shake! Stand over that
21565 helmsman with a top-maul! So, so; he travels fast, and I must down. But
21566 let me have one more good round look aloft here at the sea; there’s
21567 time for that. An old, old sight, and yet somehow so young; aye, and
21568 not changed a wink since I first saw it, a boy, from the sand-hills of
21569 Nantucket! The same!—the same!—the same to Noah as to me. There’s a
21570 soft shower to leeward. Such lovely leewardings! They must lead
21571 somewhere—to something else than common land, more palmy than the
21572 palms. Leeward! the white whale goes that way; look to windward, then;
21573 the better if the bitterer quarter. But good bye, good bye, old
21574 mast-head! What’s this?—green? aye, tiny mosses in these warped cracks.
21575 No such green weather stains on Ahab’s head! There’s the difference now
21576 between man’s old age and matter’s. But aye, old mast, we both grow old
21577 together; sound in our hulls, though, are we not, my ship? Aye, minus a
21578 leg, that’s all. By heaven this dead wood has the better of my live
21579 flesh every way. I can’t compare with it; and I’ve known some ships
21580 made of dead trees outlast the lives of men made of the most vital
21581 stuff of vital fathers. What’s that he said? he should still go before
21582 me, my pilot; and yet to be seen again? But where? Will I have eyes at
21583 the bottom of the sea, supposing I descend those endless stairs? and
21584 all night I’ve been sailing from him, wherever he did sink to. Aye,
21585 aye, like many more thou told’st direful truth as touching thyself, O
21586 Parsee; but, Ahab, there thy shot fell short. Good-bye, mast-head—keep
21587 a good eye upon the whale, the while I’m gone. We’ll talk to-morrow,
21588 nay, to-night, when the white whale lies down there, tied by head and
21589 tail.”
21590 
21591 He gave the word; and still gazing round him, was steadily lowered
21592 through the cloven blue air to the deck.
21593 
21594 In due time the boats were lowered; but as standing in his shallop’s
21595 stern, Ahab just hovered upon the point of the descent, he waved to the
21596 mate,—who held one of the tackle-ropes on deck—and bade him pause.
21597 
21598 “Starbuck!”
21599 
21600 “Sir?”
21601 
21602 “For the third time my soul’s ship starts upon this voyage, Starbuck.”
21603 
21604 “Aye, sir, thou wilt have it so.”
21605 
21606 “Some ships sail from their ports, and ever afterwards are missing,
21607 Starbuck!”
21608 
21609 “Truth, sir: saddest truth.”
21610 
21611 “Some men die at ebb tide; some at low water; some at the full of the
21612 flood;—and I feel now like a billow that’s all one crested comb,
21613 Starbuck. I am old;—shake hands with me, man.”
21614 
21615 Their hands met; their eyes fastened; Starbuck’s tears the glue.
21616 
21617 “Oh, my captain, my captain!—noble heart—go not—go not!—see, it’s a
21618 brave man that weeps; how great the agony of the persuasion then!”
21619 
21620 “Lower away!”—cried Ahab, tossing the mate’s arm from him. “Stand by
21621 the crew!”
21622 
21623 In an instant the boat was pulling round close under the stern.
21624 
21625 “The sharks! the sharks!” cried a voice from the low cabin-window
21626 there; “O master, my master, come back!”
21627 
21628 But Ahab heard nothing; for his own voice was high-lifted then; and the
21629 boat leaped on.
21630 
21631 Yet the voice spake true; for scarce had he pushed from the ship, when
21632 numbers of sharks, seemingly rising from out the dark waters beneath
21633 the hull, maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars, every time
21634 they dipped in the water; and in this way accompanied the boat with
21635 their bites. It is a thing not uncommonly happening to the whale-boats
21636 in those swarming seas; the sharks at times apparently following them
21637 in the same prescient way that vultures hover over the banners of
21638 marching regiments in the east. But these were the first sharks that
21639 had been observed by the Pequod since the White Whale had been first
21640 descried; and whether it was that Ahab’s crew were all such
21641 tiger-yellow barbarians, and therefore their flesh more musky to the
21642 senses of the sharks—a matter sometimes well known to affect
21643 them,—however it was, they seemed to follow that one boat without
21644 molesting the others.
21645 
21646 “Heart of wrought steel!” murmured Starbuck gazing over the side, and
21647 following with his eyes the receding boat—“canst thou yet ring boldly
21648 to that sight?—lowering thy keel among ravening sharks, and followed by
21649 them, open-mouthed to the chase; and this the critical third day?—For
21650 when three days flow together in one continuous intense pursuit; be
21651 sure the first is the morning, the second the noon, and the third the
21652 evening and the end of that thing—be that end what it may. Oh! my God!
21653 what is this that shoots through me, and leaves me so deadly calm, yet
21654 expectant,—fixed at the top of a shudder! Future things swim before me,
21655 as in empty outlines and skeletons; all the past is somehow grown dim.
21656 Mary, girl! thou fadest in pale glories behind me; boy! I seem to see
21657 but thy eyes grown wondrous blue. Strangest problems of life seem
21658 clearing; but clouds sweep between—Is my journey’s end coming? My legs
21659 feel faint; like his who has footed it all day. Feel thy heart,—beats
21660 it yet? Stir thyself, Starbuck!—stave it off—move, move! speak
21661 aloud!—Mast-head there! See ye my boy’s hand on the hill?—Crazed;—aloft
21662 there!—keep thy keenest eye upon the boats:—mark well the whale!—Ho!
21663 again!—drive off that hawk! see! he pecks—he tears the vane”—pointing
21664 to the red flag flying at the main-truck—“Ha! he soars away with
21665 it!—Where’s the old man now? see’st thou that sight, oh Ahab!—shudder,
21666 shudder!”
21667 
21668 The boats had not gone very far, when by a signal from the mast-heads—a
21669 downward pointed arm, Ahab knew that the whale had sounded; but
21670 intending to be near him at the next rising, he held on his way a
21671 little sideways from the vessel; the becharmed crew maintaining the
21672 profoundest silence, as the head-beat waves hammered and hammered
21673 against the opposing bow.
21674 
21675 “Drive, drive in your nails, oh ye waves! to their uttermost heads
21676 drive them in! ye but strike a thing without a lid; and no coffin and
21677 no hearse can be mine:—and hemp only can kill me! Ha! ha!”
21678 
21679 Suddenly the waters around them slowly swelled in broad circles; then
21680 quickly upheaved, as if sideways sliding from a submerged berg of ice,
21681 swiftly rising to the surface. A low rumbling sound was heard; a
21682 subterraneous hum; and then all held their breaths; as bedraggled with
21683 trailing ropes, and harpoons, and lances, a vast form shot lengthwise,
21684 but obliquely from the sea. Shrouded in a thin drooping veil of mist,
21685 it hovered for a moment in the rainbowed air; and then fell swamping
21686 back into the deep. Crushed thirty feet upwards, the waters flashed for
21687 an instant like heaps of fountains, then brokenly sank in a shower of
21688 flakes, leaving the circling surface creamed like new milk round the
21689 marble trunk of the whale.
21690 
21691 “Give way!” cried Ahab to the oarsmen, and the boats darted forward to
21692 the attack; but maddened by yesterday’s fresh irons that corroded in
21693 him, Moby Dick seemed combinedly possessed by all the angels that fell
21694 from heaven. The wide tiers of welded tendons overspreading his broad
21695 white forehead, beneath the transparent skin, looked knitted together;
21696 as head on, he came churning his tail among the boats; and once more
21697 flailed them apart; spilling out the irons and lances from the two
21698 mates’ boats, and dashing in one side of the upper part of their bows,
21699 but leaving Ahab’s almost without a scar.
21700 
21701 While Daggoo and Queequeg were stopping the strained planks; and as the
21702 whale swimming out from them, turned, and showed one entire flank as he
21703 shot by them again; at that moment a quick cry went up. Lashed round
21704 and round to the fish’s back; pinioned in the turns upon turns in
21705 which, during the past night, the whale had reeled the involutions of
21706 the lines around him, the half torn body of the Parsee was seen; his
21707 sable raiment frayed to shreds; his distended eyes turned full upon old
21708 Ahab.
21709 
21710 The harpoon dropped from his hand.
21711 
21712 “Befooled, befooled!”—drawing in a long lean breath—“Aye, Parsee! I see
21713 thee again.—Aye, and thou goest before; and this, _this_ then is the
21714 hearse that thou didst promise. But I hold thee to the last letter of
21715 thy word. Where is the second hearse? Away, mates, to the ship! those
21716 boats are useless now; repair them if ye can in time, and return to me;
21717 if not, Ahab is enough to die—Down, men! the first thing that but
21718 offers to jump from this boat I stand in, that thing I harpoon. Ye are
21719 not other men, but my arms and my legs; and so obey me.—Where’s the
21720 whale? gone down again?”
21721 
21722 But he looked too nigh the boat; for as if bent upon escaping with the
21723 corpse he bore, and as if the particular place of the last encounter
21724 had been but a stage in his leeward voyage, Moby Dick was now again
21725 steadily swimming forward; and had almost passed the ship,—which thus
21726 far had been sailing in the contrary direction to him, though for the
21727 present her headway had been stopped. He seemed swimming with his
21728 utmost velocity, and now only intent upon pursuing his own straight
21729 path in the sea.
21730 
21731 “Oh! Ahab,” cried Starbuck, “not too late is it, even now, the third
21732 day, to desist. See! Moby Dick seeks thee not. It is thou, thou, that
21733 madly seekest him!”
21734 
21735 Setting sail to the rising wind, the lonely boat was swiftly impelled
21736 to leeward, by both oars and canvas. And at last when Ahab was sliding
21737 by the vessel, so near as plainly to distinguish Starbuck’s face as he
21738 leaned over the rail, he hailed him to turn the vessel about, and
21739 follow him, not too swiftly, at a judicious interval. Glancing upwards,
21740 he saw Tashtego, Queequeg, and Daggoo, eagerly mounting to the three
21741 mast-heads; while the oarsmen were rocking in the two staved boats
21742 which had but just been hoisted to the side, and were busily at work in
21743 repairing them. One after the other, through the port-holes, as he
21744 sped, he also caught flying glimpses of Stubb and Flask, busying
21745 themselves on deck among bundles of new irons and lances. As he saw all
21746 this; as he heard the hammers in the broken boats; far other hammers
21747 seemed driving a nail into his heart. But he rallied. And now marking
21748 that the vane or flag was gone from the main-mast-head, he shouted to
21749 Tashtego, who had just gained that perch, to descend again for another
21750 flag, and a hammer and nails, and so nail it to the mast.
21751 
21752 Whether fagged by the three days’ running chase, and the resistance to
21753 his swimming in the knotted hamper he bore; or whether it was some
21754 latent deceitfulness and malice in him: whichever was true, the White
21755 Whale’s way now began to abate, as it seemed, from the boat so rapidly
21756 nearing him once more; though indeed the whale’s last start had not
21757 been so long a one as before. And still as Ahab glided over the waves
21758 the unpitying sharks accompanied him; and so pertinaciously stuck to
21759 the boat; and so continually bit at the plying oars, that the blades
21760 became jagged and crunched, and left small splinters in the sea, at
21761 almost every dip.
21762 
21763 “Heed them not! those teeth but give new rowlocks to your oars. Pull
21764 on! ’tis the better rest, the shark’s jaw than the yielding water.”
21765 
21766 “But at every bite, sir, the thin blades grow smaller and smaller!”
21767 
21768 “They will last long enough! pull on!—But who can tell”—he
21769 muttered—“whether these sharks swim to feast on the whale or on
21770 Ahab?—But pull on! Aye, all alive, now—we near him. The helm! take the
21771 helm! let me pass,”—and so saying two of the oarsmen helped him forward
21772 to the bows of the still flying boat.
21773 
21774 At length as the craft was cast to one side, and ran ranging along with
21775 the White Whale’s flank, he seemed strangely oblivious of its
21776 advance—as the whale sometimes will—and Ahab was fairly within the
21777 smoky mountain mist, which, thrown off from the whale’s spout, curled
21778 round his great, Monadnock hump; he was even thus close to him; when,
21779 with body arched back, and both arms lengthwise high-lifted to the
21780 poise, he darted his fierce iron, and his far fiercer curse into the
21781 hated whale. As both steel and curse sank to the socket, as if sucked
21782 into a morass, Moby Dick sideways writhed; spasmodically rolled his
21783 nigh flank against the bow, and, without staving a hole in it, so
21784 suddenly canted the boat over, that had it not been for the elevated
21785 part of the gunwale to which he then clung, Ahab would once more have
21786 been tossed into the sea. As it was, three of the oarsmen—who foreknew
21787 not the precise instant of the dart, and were therefore unprepared for
21788 its effects—these were flung out; but so fell, that, in an instant two
21789 of them clutched the gunwale again, and rising to its level on a
21790 combing wave, hurled themselves bodily inboard again; the third man
21791 helplessly dropping astern, but still afloat and swimming.
21792 
21793 Almost simultaneously, with a mighty volition of ungraduated,
21794 instantaneous swiftness, the White Whale darted through the weltering
21795 sea. But when Ahab cried out to the steersman to take new turns with
21796 the line, and hold it so; and commanded the crew to turn round on their
21797 seats, and tow the boat up to the mark; the moment the treacherous line
21798 felt that double strain and tug, it snapped in the empty air!
21799 
21800 “What breaks in me? Some sinew cracks!—’tis whole again; oars! oars!
21801 Burst in upon him!”
21802 
21803 Hearing the tremendous rush of the sea-crashing boat, the whale wheeled
21804 round to present his blank forehead at bay; but in that evolution,
21805 catching sight of the nearing black hull of the ship; seemingly seeing
21806 in it the source of all his persecutions; bethinking it—it may be—a
21807 larger and nobler foe; of a sudden, he bore down upon its advancing
21808 prow, smiting his jaws amid fiery showers of foam.
21809 
21810 Ahab staggered; his hand smote his forehead. “I grow blind; hands!
21811 stretch out before me that I may yet grope my way. Is’t night?”
21812 
21813 “The whale! The ship!” cried the cringing oarsmen.
21814 
21815 “Oars! oars! Slope downwards to thy depths, O sea, that ere it be for
21816 ever too late, Ahab may slide this last, last time upon his mark! I
21817 see: the ship! the ship! Dash on, my men! Will ye not save my ship?”
21818 
21819 But as the oarsmen violently forced their boat through the
21820 sledge-hammering seas, the before whale-smitten bow-ends of two planks
21821 burst through, and in an instant almost, the temporarily disabled boat
21822 lay nearly level with the waves; its half-wading, splashing crew,
21823 trying hard to stop the gap and bale out the pouring water.
21824 
21825 Meantime, for that one beholding instant, Tashtego’s mast-head hammer
21826 remained suspended in his hand; and the red flag, half-wrapping him as
21827 with a plaid, then streamed itself straight out from him, as his own
21828 forward-flowing heart; while Starbuck and Stubb, standing upon the
21829 bowsprit beneath, caught sight of the down-coming monster just as soon
21830 as he.
21831 
21832 “The whale, the whale! Up helm, up helm! Oh, all ye sweet powers of
21833 air, now hug me close! Let not Starbuck die, if die he must, in a
21834 woman’s fainting fit. Up helm, I say—ye fools, the jaw! the jaw! Is
21835 this the end of all my bursting prayers? all my life-long fidelities?
21836 Oh, Ahab, Ahab, lo, thy work. Steady! helmsman, steady. Nay, nay! Up
21837 helm again! He turns to meet us! Oh, his unappeasable brow drives on
21838 towards one, whose duty tells him he cannot depart. My God, stand by me
21839 now!”
21840 
21841 “Stand not by me, but stand under me, whoever you are that will now
21842 help Stubb; for Stubb, too, sticks here. I grin at thee, thou grinning
21843 whale! Who ever helped Stubb, or kept Stubb awake, but Stubb’s own
21844 unwinking eye? And now poor Stubb goes to bed upon a mattrass that is
21845 all too soft; would it were stuffed with brushwood! I grin at thee,
21846 thou grinning whale! Look ye, sun, moon, and stars! I call ye assassins
21847 of as good a fellow as ever spouted up his ghost. For all that, I would
21848 yet ring glasses with ye, would ye but hand the cup! Oh, oh! oh, oh!
21849 thou grinning whale, but there’ll be plenty of gulping soon! Why fly ye
21850 not, O Ahab! For me, off shoes and jacket to it; let Stubb die in his
21851 drawers! A most mouldy and over salted death, though;—cherries!
21852 cherries! cherries! Oh, Flask, for one red cherry ere we die!”
21853 
21854 “Cherries? I only wish that we were where they grow. Oh, Stubb, I hope
21855 my poor mother’s drawn my part-pay ere this; if not, few coppers will
21856 now come to her, for the voyage is up.”
21857 
21858 From the ship’s bows, nearly all the seamen now hung inactive; hammers,
21859 bits of plank, lances, and harpoons, mechanically retained in their
21860 hands, just as they had darted from their various employments; all
21861 their enchanted eyes intent upon the whale, which from side to side
21862 strangely vibrating his predestinating head, sent a broad band of
21863 overspreading semicircular foam before him as he rushed. Retribution,
21864 swift vengeance, eternal malice were in his whole aspect, and spite of
21865 all that mortal man could do, the solid white buttress of his forehead
21866 smote the ship’s starboard bow, till men and timbers reeled. Some fell
21867 flat upon their faces. Like dislodged trucks, the heads of the
21868 harpooneers aloft shook on their bull-like necks. Through the breach,
21869 they heard the waters pour, as mountain torrents down a flume.
21870 
21871 “The ship! The hearse!—the second hearse!” cried Ahab from the boat;
21872 “its wood could only be American!”
21873 
21874 Diving beneath the settling ship, the whale ran quivering along its
21875 keel; but turning under water, swiftly shot to the surface again, far
21876 off the other bow, but within a few yards of Ahab’s boat, where, for a
21877 time, he lay quiescent.
21878 
21879 “I turn my body from the sun. What ho, Tashtego! let me hear thy
21880 hammer. Oh! ye three unsurrendered spires of mine; thou uncracked keel;
21881 and only god-bullied hull; thou firm deck, and haughty helm, and
21882 Pole-pointed prow,—death-glorious ship! must ye then perish, and
21883 without me? Am I cut off from the last fond pride of meanest
21884 shipwrecked captains? Oh, lonely death on lonely life! Oh, now I feel
21885 my topmost greatness lies in my topmost grief. Ho, ho! from all your
21886 furthest bounds, pour ye now in, ye bold billows of my whole foregone
21887 life, and top this one piled comber of my death! Towards thee I roll,
21888 thou all-destroying but unconquering whale; to the last I grapple with
21889 thee; from hell’s heart I stab at thee; for hate’s sake I spit my last
21890 breath at thee. Sink all coffins and all hearses to one common pool!
21891 and since neither can be mine, let me then tow to pieces, while still
21892 chasing thee, though tied to thee, thou damned whale! _Thus_, I give up
21893 the spear!”
21894 
21895 The harpoon was darted; the stricken whale flew forward; with igniting
21896 velocity the line ran through the grooves;—ran foul. Ahab stooped to
21897 clear it; he did clear it; but the flying turn caught him round the
21898 neck, and voicelessly as Turkish mutes bowstring their victim, he was
21899 shot out of the boat, ere the crew knew he was gone. Next instant, the
21900 heavy eye-splice in the rope’s final end flew out of the stark-empty
21901 tub, knocked down an oarsman, and smiting the sea, disappeared in its
21902 depths.
21903 
21904 For an instant, the tranced boat’s crew stood still; then turned. “The
21905 ship? Great God, where is the ship?” Soon they through dim, bewildering
21906 mediums saw her sidelong fading phantom, as in the gaseous Fata
21907 Morgana; only the uppermost masts out of water; while fixed by
21908 infatuation, or fidelity, or fate, to their once lofty perches, the
21909 pagan harpooneers still maintained their sinking lookouts on the sea.
21910 And now, concentric circles seized the lone boat itself, and all its
21911 crew, and each floating oar, and every lance-pole, and spinning,
21912 animate and inanimate, all round and round in one vortex, carried the
21913 smallest chip of the Pequod out of sight.
21914 
21915 But as the last whelmings intermixingly poured themselves over the
21916 sunken head of the Indian at the mainmast, leaving a few inches of the
21917 erect spar yet visible, together with long streaming yards of the flag,
21918 which calmly undulated, with ironical coincidings, over the destroying
21919 billows they almost touched;—at that instant, a red arm and a hammer
21920 hovered backwardly uplifted in the open air, in the act of nailing the
21921 flag faster and yet faster to the subsiding spar. A sky-hawk that
21922 tauntingly had followed the main-truck downwards from its natural home
21923 among the stars, pecking at the flag, and incommoding Tashtego there;
21924 this bird now chanced to intercept its broad fluttering wing between
21925 the hammer and the wood; and simultaneously feeling that etherial
21926 thrill, the submerged savage beneath, in his death-gasp, kept his
21927 hammer frozen there; and so the bird of heaven, with archangelic
21928 shrieks, and his imperial beak thrust upwards, and his whole captive
21929 form folded in the flag of Ahab, went down with his ship, which, like
21930 Satan, would not sink to hell till she had dragged a living part of
21931 heaven along with her, and helmeted herself with it.
21932 
21933 Now small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen
21934 white surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the
21935 great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years ago.
21936 
21937 
21938 Epilogue
21939 
21940 “AND I ONLY AM ESCAPED ALONE TO TELL THEE” Job.
21941 
21942 The drama’s done. Why then here does any one step forth?—Because one
21943 did survive the wreck.
21944 
21945 It so chanced, that after the Parsee’s disappearance, I was he whom the
21946 Fates ordained to take the place of Ahab’s bowsman, when that bowsman
21947 assumed the vacant post; the same, who, when on the last day the three
21948 men were tossed from out of the rocking boat, was dropped astern. So,
21949 floating on the margin of the ensuing scene, and in full sight of it,
21950 when the halfspent suction of the sunk ship reached me, I was then, but
21951 slowly, drawn towards the closing vortex. When I reached it, it had
21952 subsided to a creamy pool. Round and round, then, and ever contracting
21953 towards the button-like black bubble at the axis of that slowly
21954 wheeling circle, like another Ixion I did revolve. Till, gaining that
21955 vital centre, the black bubble upward burst; and now, liberated by
21956 reason of its cunning spring, and, owing to its great buoyancy, rising
21957 with great force, the coffin life-buoy shot lengthwise from the sea,
21958 fell over, and floated by my side. Buoyed up by that coffin, for almost
21959 one whole day and night, I floated on a soft and dirgelike main. The
21960 unharming sharks, they glided by as if with padlocks on their mouths;
21961 the savage sea-hawks sailed with sheathed beaks. On the second day, a
21962 sail drew near, nearer, and picked me up at last. It was the
21963 devious-cruising Rachel, that in her retracing search after her missing
21964 children, only found another orphan.
21965 
21966
